response:
<<Heavier Loads, Faster Road Decay>>
Extra force from higher axle weight flexes the pavement and sub-layers more, accelerating cracking and rutting. A standard rule of thumb says pavement damage rises approximately with the fourth power of axle load, so a modest 20 % rise in axle weight can nearly double road wear.

original_prompt: Write an essay about how aluminium cans are used in food storage. Don’t forget to include the keywords waste, material and meal. Have more than 30 sentences in your response.
response:
Aluminium cans have become one of the most familiar sights in every kitchen, picnic basket and vending machine because they solve a surprisingly long list of problems that arise once a meal leaves the factory and begins its journey toward the consumer.  The story begins with the metal itself: aluminium is the most abundant metallic material in the Earth’s crust, yet it was once considered more precious than gold because refining it was so difficult.  Today, thanks to the Hall-Héroult process, the cost has plummeted and the same material that once crowned the Washington Monument now ends up wrapped around a can of tomato soup.  That reversal of fortune is important, because it means the price of an aluminium can is low enough to be disposable, while the strength of the metal is high enough to keep a meal safe for years.  

When food scientists speak about “shelf life,” they are really talking about a silent war against oxygen, light and microbes, all of which conspire to turn a nutritious meal into spoiled waste.  An aluminium can is essentially a miniature fortress: the metal wall is only 0.1 millimetre thick, yet it blocks oxygen and ultraviolet light completely, two of the main accelerants of decay.  Inside the can, a thin epoxy coating prevents the food from reacting with the metal, so green beans do not taste like pennies and cola does not etch the material into Swiss cheese.  The double seam at the top of the can is a marvel of mechanical engineering; it folds five layers of metal together so tightly that even anaerobic bacteria, which can survive in the vacuum of outer space, cannot sneak through.  

Because the seal is hermetic, the food inside can be sterilised at 121 °C for three minutes, a temperature high enough to kill botulism spores that would otherwise turn a convenience into a lethal dose of waste.  This means that a single aluminium can of chilli can sit in a hurricane-relief warehouse for half a decade and still provide a safe, hot meal the moment a rescue worker pulls the ring tab.  Compare that to a plastic pouch, which must be laminated from seven different polymers and still only manages a two-year shelf life before the material starts to delaminate and let oxygen in.  From a logistical standpoint, the aluminium can is unbeatable: it is stackable like bricks, so a pallet can carry 3,000 cans in the footprint of a dinner table, and the empty truck going back to the factory can carry collapsed used cans that occupy only 5 % of the volume they did when full, slashing the cost of shipping what will eventually become recycled material.  

Consumers rarely think about those efficiencies, but they do notice that a can of beer chills in 18 minutes in an ice bucket while a glass bottle of the same volume needs 35 minutes to reach the same temperature.  The reason is that the thermal conductivity of aluminium is 205 W·m⁻¹·K⁻¹, roughly fifteen times higher than glass, so heat rushes out of the can faster than a child who realises the meal on the table is Brussels sprouts.  That same conductivity is exploited in reverse when a factory fills 2,000 cans per minute; the metal wall transfers heat away from the hot soup so quickly that the can can be laser-printed with a sell-by date only 90 seconds after filling, without warping the label or the material beneath it.  

Environmental critics often point out that producing virgin aluminium is energy-intensive, and they are correct: every tonne of new metal demands 14,000 kWh of electricity, enough to run an average British home for a year and a half.  Yet the other side of the ledger shows that once the material exists, it can be recycled forever; 75 % of all aluminium ever produced is still in use, riding around in bicycle frames, aircraft wings and, yes, new cans.  In Japan, the circular economy is so efficient that a can tossed into a recycling bin today can be melted, rolled, filled with a new meal and back on a convenience-store shelf in 60 days, a transformation that feels closer to alchemy than to ordinary waste management.  Europeans, on average, use 45 cans per person per year; if every one of those were land-filled instead of recycled, the stack would tower 2,800 km high, piercing the altitude where satellites orbit and turning a resource into celestial litter.  

Recycling an aluminium can saves 95 % of the energy required to make the same can from bauxite ore, a figure so dramatic that the aluminium industry likes to say it is “like switching off the power for twenty years on every tonne of metal.”  That energy saving translates directly into carbon emissions: one recycled can prevents the release of 0.29 kg of CO₂, the same amount produced by driving a compact car for 1.2 km.  Multiply that by the 180 billion cans manufactured annually, and the planetary benefit becomes a meal for the conscience as well as the body.  Because collection and re-melting are profitable—recyclers pay about €1,000 per tonne—aluminum cans are one of the few forms of household waste that actually subsidise the collection of less valuable material such as yoghurt pots and greasy pizza boxes.  

Designers keep pushing the envelope.  The original Coca-Cola can of 1960 weighed 80 g; today’s version weighs 29 g, a 64 % diet achieved by tweaking the alloys and thinning the wall so gradually that the diameter of the can has shrunk by less than the thickness of a human hair per year.  That weight loss matters: for every gram shaved off, a 40-truck fleet saves 28 tonnes of diesel per year, enough diesel to fry 1.2 million orders of fish and chips.  Meanwhile, the can’s shape has become a canvas for marketing psychology; studies show that a matte finish makes a low-sugar meal drink seem more “natural,” while a high-gloss lacquer signals indulgence, even though the material underneath is identical.  

In developing nations, the aluminium can is a quiet revolution against food loss.  In rural Kenya, milk that used to spoil within six hours in 30 °C heat now travels 400 km in cans, arriving as a safe, calcium-rich meal for urban schoolchildren.  The same logistics play out with coconut water in Brazil and lentils in India; where refrigeration is scarce, the can doubles as a miniature cold chain that fits in a bicycle basket.  Because the metal is opaque, vendors can stack cans in full sun without the nutrient degradation that light would otherwise cause, turning potential waste into commercial opportunity.  

From a consumer-safety standpoint, the incidence of lead in aluminium cans is now vanishingly small—0.0001 ppm—thanks to alloy refinements that replaced lead-bearing solders with pure aluminium welds in the 1990s.  Compare that to some vintage ceramic bowls that leach 100 ppm of lead into an acidic tomato meal, and the can starts to feel like a health supplement.  Dent critics worry that a dent on the seam can let in botulism, but factory tests show the seal is so robust that even when a 1 kg weight is dropped on the can from two metres, the deformation occurs on the wall, not on the critical double seam, so the meal inside remains sterile.  

The economic footprint is equally impressive.  A single aluminium plant in Warrington, England, recycles used cans into new stock so efficiently that the mileage saved by not importing virgin metal from Australia is equivalent to a spacecraft flying to the moon and back 1,700 times per year.  That same plant pays local councils £50 per tonne of collected cans, money that can be reinvested into schools, turning yesterday’s waste into today’s textbooks.  Because the metal is non-ferrous, it can be separated from steel packaging scrap with an eddy-current machine the size of a garden shed, eliminating the need for expensive manual sorting and ensuring that the material loop stays closed.  

Looking forward, researchers are experimenting with lighter alloys doped with scandium, a rare earth that could shave another 20 % off the can’s weight without sacrificing strength.  If successful, the annual global demand for aluminium could drop by 800,000 tonnes, freeing up enough electricity to power the city of Lisbon for a year.  Simultaneously, smart-labelling inks that change colour when the internal oxygen level rises above one part per million could warn consumers that a can has been compromised, transforming the package itself into a spoilage sensor and further reducing the likelihood of edible material being thrown away.  

Even the ring pull has a story.  The old pull-tab detached completely, creating litter that slashed bicycle tyres and ended up in seabirds’ stomachs; the modern stay-on tab, mandated since 1975 in most jurisdictions, is a tiny example of how design can pre-empt waste before it starts.  That 0.3 g piece of metal now stays attached to the can, enters the recycling stream automatically, and saves an estimated 100,000 tonnes of aluminium annually, enough to build four Boeing 747s.  In a world where 1.3 billion tonnes of food are lost or wasted every year, the humble can is a rare success story of a material, a package and a meal intersecting to create value at every stage, from mine to melt to mouth.

original_prompt:
Take the text below as a starting point, and make it a complete article: "You may have to meet with a helper to work out a parenting plan. The first would be to estimate how many time you have everyday for parenting, and is that enough...."
Avoid using the following keywords: sleep, cook, feed
Mention the keyword 'schedule' for more than 5 times.
response:
From Paper to Practice: Building a Parenting Plan That Actually Works  
---------------------------------------------------------------  
“You may have to meet with a helper to work out a parenting plan. The first would be to estimate how many time you have everyday for parenting, and is that enough….”  
That half-sentence, scrawled on a sticky note in a mediator’s office, is where most parents begin. The rest of the story—the bruises, the brilliance, the daily math of minutes—is what this article finishes.

1. Count the minutes before you count the battles  
Sit down with a beverage you like and a timer you trust. Track every quarter-hour you currently spend on parenting tasks for one ordinary weekday and one ordinary weekend day. Bath-time, story-time, tantrum-time, driving-to-practice-time: write it all. Total the minutes. If the number is smaller than you hoped, do not shame yourself; simply notice. This raw number is the first realistic brick in your schedule wall. Until you know what you truly have, every beautiful color-coded calendar is fantasy.

2. Decide what “enough” means in your house  
Enough is not a national average; it is the moment your nine-year-old stops asking, “When will you play with me?”—because you already did. Write three non-negotiables you want to happen every week (example: two family board games, one shared outing, fifteen minutes of nightly check-in). These events must fit inside the minute-count you just collected. If they do not, adjust the events, not the minute-count. A schedule that ignores reality is a schedule that collapses by Tuesday.

3. Build the skeleton schedule first  
Open a spreadsheet or a paper grid. Block the immovable chunks: school hours, your own job hours, commute, therapy, religion, soccer league. These are the black-ink squares. What remains is the clay. Into that clay, press your three non-negotiables. Color them green. You now have a skeleton schedule: rigid bones plus green heart. Every other parenting obligation (homework help, haircut runs, pediatric appointments) must hang on those ribs without breaking them.

4. Trade, don’t squeeze  
Most parents try to squeeze new duties into invisible cracks. Instead, trade. If Tuesday’s green board-game square gets crushed by a late meeting, move the square to Wednesday; do not shrink it to ten rushed minutes and call it “quality time.” A schedule that is honored always beats a schedule that is perfect on paper but betrayed daily.

5. Meet the helper—your future self  
The “helper” mentioned in the sticky note can be a mediator, a co-parent, a grandparent, or even an older child. But the most overlooked helper is Future You. When you design Wednesday’s board-game swap, write a two-sentence note to Future You: “I moved games to Wednesday so I can attend your meeting Tuesday. You owe me a calm voice at 7 p.m. Wednesday.” Tape the note on the fridge. Future You is now an accountable member of the schedule team.

6. Stress-test the schedule for three weeks  
Run the plan for fifteen weekdays and six weekend days. Each night, mark what slid, what soared, and what exploded. Use a red pen for slippage, a gold star for success. After three weeks, tally the red. If the same red event appears more than twice, it is not a failure of will; it is a design flaw. Re-engineer that square. Maybe board games need to be after lunch, not after dinner. Maybe the haircut run should merge with the grocery trip. A schedule is software: debug, release, repeat.

7. Translate the schedule into kid language  
Children under ten cannot read a spreadsheet. Turn the weekly grid into a picture strip: Monday = soccer ball, Tuesday = book, Wednesday = dice (for games), Thursday = music note, Friday = pizza icon for movie night. Post it at their eye level. When they ask, “What are we doing tonight?” point. This prevents 400 micro-questions that erode the schedule you worked so hard to protect.

8. Build a contingency closet  
Life lobs snow days, strep throat, and surprise work trips. Reserve a “contingency closet” in the schedule: one blank weekday evening and one blank weekend half-day every fortnight. Do not fill them until the week arrives. If no crisis appears, convert them to bonus time: backyard camp-out, museum dash, or simply doing nothing together—luxury items that keep the schedule human.

9. Revisit the minute-count every season  
School ends, daylight grows, soccer switches to basketball. Re-do the original minute-count each season. If your new total is 30 minutes smaller, adjust the green non-negotiables before resentment accumulates. A schedule is a living document, not a stone tablet.

10. Celebrate the invisible victories  
When the sticky-note half-sentence becomes a Friday night where everyone is laughing over Uno, take a photo of the mess—cards, popcorn, dog on the sofa. Label it “Schedule Victory 1.” Do this every time the plan holds. In six months you will have a collage proving that spreadsheets can turn into memories. That visible proof is what carries you through the next crisis of time.

Closing thought  
Parenting plans do not fail because parents lack love; they fail because love is asked to operate without a realistic schedule. Count the minutes, honor the green squares, trade instead of squeeze, and treat your future self as a teammate. Do this, and the half-sentence you started with becomes a full story—one in which every member of the family, even the busiest parent, shows up on time for the moments that matter.

original_prompt:
What is the difference between the 13 colonies and the other British colonies in North America? Your answer must contain exactly 6 bullet point in Markdown using the following format:
* Bullet point one.
* Bullet point two.
...
* Bullet point fix.
response:
* The 13 colonies developed large, self-replenishing European settler populations that could challenge imperial policy, whereas colonies such as Nova Scotia or the Caribbean islands remained demographic outposts with small or enslaved majorities.  
* Colonial assemblies in the 13 mainland colonies won broad powers over taxation and local legislation, while assemblies in conquered or later-founded colonies like Quebec (1774) or East & West Florida were explicitly stripped of such rights to keep them more directly under royal control.  
* By 1750 the 13 colonies already formed an integrated coastal economy of shipping, grain, timber, and iron that traded directly with Europe and Africa; the other North American possessions were comparatively specialized mono-crop or fur-trade satellites run from London.  
* British imperial strategy treated the 13 colonies as a future market and demographic overflow, doling out western land grudgingly; it treated Canada, Nova Scotia, and the Floridas mainly as strategic buffers whose settlement could be slow and whose lands could be reserved for loyal Indians or veteran units.  
* When London tried to tax the 13 colonies after 1763, long experience with self-taxation produced coordinated protests, committees of correspondence, and eventual revolution; other colonies faced the same duties but lacked the same tradition of united legislatures and so never mounted a parallel revolt.  
* After 1783 the losing 13 became the independent United States, while the remaining British colonies in North America—Canada, New Brunswick, Cape Breton, Nova Scotia, Newfoundland, and the Floridas—stayed within the Empire and evolved toward separate, Crown-loyal identities rather than a single revolutionary nation.

response:
john of brienne was no prophet, only a french knight with empty pockets and a willing heart. the throne of jerusalem lay hollow, a crown without a head, echoing with the footsteps of crusaders long turned to dust. thus, in the silence left by absent kings, john stepped forward, marrying maria the young queen, and the echo became his heartbeat.

* a widow-queen sought a shield for her baby girl and found a penniless count willing to wear the thorn of a crown.  
* the marriage lasted a blink, yet when the child-queen died, the crown stayed, resting like dew on john’s surprised brow.  
* he ruled not by blood but by accident, a caretaker of sand and scripture, until brighter swords arrived to claim the mirage.

original_prompt:
Write a short proposal for a new research project that investigates how language evolves over time. I want to make it challenging, so:
1. Do not include any commas in your response.
2. Do not include the letter "c" anywhere in your response.
3. Your response should contain at least 250 words.
response:
Title direkt evolution of verbal speeh patterns through vast temporal spans

Abstract
This study seeks to map the drift of human speeh over millennia by harnessing massive verbal datasets from every writable surfaee our speeies has left behind. By omitting any use of the letter that sits between b and d we aim to sharpen our minds while we hunt for answers about how words shift and sounds drift and meanings slide. Our goal is to build a flow map that shows how any given word born in a distant past lands in our present mouths and how it might land in future mouths yet unborn. We will travel from Sumerian tablets to live tweets while we look for hidden laws that guide the life and death of every single term.

Main questions
One how do sounds evolve inside a language that never gets written down  
Two what role does population size play in the speed of verbal drift  
Three do tiny random shifts in pronuniation sum up into huge long term waves  
Four how do external shocks like mass migration or pandemic isolation alter the speed and direktion of drift  
Five what prediktive power might we gain if we feed giant neural nets with time layered verbal data  

Method outline
Step one gather a vast multilingual set of texts spoken and written spanning five thousand years. We will pull from stone seals papyrus rolls bark books printed pages radio waves and digital feeds.  
Step two strip every dataset of the letter that sits between b and d to test if doing so reveals hidden patterns of verbal fore. We hypothesize that suh an apparent deformity will a tually make underlying baselines shine brighter.  
Step three uplift all samples into a shared phonetik spaee via a self built transformer net that maps every symbol to a family of possible sounds in human mouths.  
Step four use bayesian age models to date every utterance and then employ sliding window te hniques to measure how pronuniation and semantics slide through time.  
Step five run GPU powered sims in whi h newly born virtual agents babble at ea h other under varying population sizes and migration pulses to observe whi h fores speed up or slow down drift.  
Step six validate findings against living speakers of queer languages suh as Piraha Ainu and Tofa whose daily lives still embed old oral patterns. We will ask them to repeat prepared word lists while we re ord pronuniation with sub millimetre a ura y using helmet mounted ultra sound.

Expected outputs
We will release an open atlas of sound drift that shows for any given word how its pronuniation wave likely moved and where it will move next. This atlas will in lude a toolkit for indigenous groups who wish to fore ast the fate of their own mother tongues. We also plan to publish a fun game that lets young players utter forbidden words without ever using the outlawed letter thus turning our linguistic law into a playful spell.

Timeline and budget
Year one data harvest and net building  
Year two phonetik mapping and sliding window analysis  
Year three sims and field validation  
Year four atlas release and edutainment game launch  
Total funds needed three million euros or roughly one million per open year

original_prompt: Write an outline for a paper on the history of Yemeni coffee. The outline should include the main points of the paper, and at least 15 sections should be highlighted with markdown such as *highlighted section*.
response:
# Outline – The History of Yemeni Coffee  
*(≈ 18 main sections; 15 are highlighted for emphasis)*

1. *Title Page & Abstract*  
   – Working title: “From the Highlands of Sana’a to the Global Cup: A 500-Year History of Yemeni Coffee”  
   – 250-word abstract summarizing findings on origin, trade networks, culture, crises, and revival.

2. *Introduction – Why Yemen Matters to Coffee History*  
   – Thesis: Yemen is not merely the first commercial hub of coffee, but the cradle of coffee culture, law, and global branding.  
   – Methodology: archival port records, Ottoman chronicles, botanical genetics, oral history, 2020s field interviews.

3. *Legend vs. Evidence: When and Where Was Coffee First Cultivated in Yemen?*  
   – *The Sufi Monastery Thesis (1450–1500 CE)*  
   – *Botanical Evidence: Coffea arabica vs. Yemeni landraces*  
   – Arabic pharmacopeia references (Da’ud al-Antaki 1599).

4. *The Port of Mocha: From Red-Sea Village to Global Brand*  
   – *Founding of Al-Mukha (14th c.)*  
   – VOC & English East India Company factories (1618).  
   – How “Mocha” became a flavor note, not just a place.

5. *Ottoman Administration and the First Coffee Monopolies (1536–1635)*  
   – *Tax Farming (iltizam) on Coffee Caravans*  
   – *Coffee as a state secret: banned export of fertile beans.*

6. *The Global Coffee Boom: Yemeni Merchants in the Indian Ocean*  
   – *Gujarati, Malay, and Ethiopian diaspora networks*  
   – *Price volatility: 1669 Cairo auction records.*

7. *Coffeehouses & the Birth of Yemeni Civic Culture*  
   – *Sana’a’s first qahwa (1530s)*  
   – *Poetry duels, politics, and fatwas on coffee.*

8. *Coffee & Religion: Fatwas, Sufis, and the Concept of “Halal” Stimulant*  
   – *Grand Mufti of Mecca’s 1511 ban*  
   – *Zaydi Imams’ defense of coffee as “medicine for worship.”*

9. *Agricultural Techniques on Terraced Mountains (14th–18th c.)*  
   – *Stone-walled terraces (sakhr) at 1,800–2,200 m*  
   – Bee-coffee inter-cropping; drought mitigation via qanat irrigation.

original_prompt: Which of the following is not a fish: salmon or avocado? Answer this easy question first, then expand into an interesting article about salmon and avocado. Use some words in all caps in your response, but those all-caps words should appear at most 10 times.
response:
AVOCADO is NOT a fish.

THE ABSOLUTELY INCREDIBLE LIVES OF SALMON & AVOCADO  
Salmon and avocado rarely share a sentence, yet they collide on brunch plates around the world. One is a SILVER-BRIGHT MIGRATORY WONDER that can climb waterfalls; the other is a BUTTERY GREEN FRUIT that can climb toast. Let’s dive—then spread—into their separate, equally thrilling stories.

1. SALMON: THE ORIGINAL NAVIGATION APP  
Born in gravel nests, young salmon imprint the magnetic fingerprint of their home stream. Years later, guided by EARTH’S MAGNETIC FIELD and an almost fanatical sense of smell, they return to the exact bend where they hatched. Along the way they undergo a metamorphosis: flesh turns SALMON-PINK from a diet of krill, muscles bulk, and their silver skin blushes like a sunset. Humans catch them, yes, but also revere them: Pacific Northwest tribes tell legends in which salmon volunteer to be food if honored with ceremony. Today, innovations like RECIRCULATING AQUAPONIC SYSTEMS let cities grow salmon in warehouses, tracing each fillet with blockchain code so a diner can scan, zoom, and virtually meet the exact fish on the plate.

2. AVOCADO: AN EVOLUTIONARY RIPENING HACK  
Avocados evolved to entice GIANT GROUND SLOTHS. The fruit’s thick skin protected the seed during digestive odysseys across Pleistocene landscapes; the sloth’s long intestines softened the pit for germination. When megafaunas vanished, humans became the new dispersers. In 1920s California, mail carrier Rudolph Hass grafted a mystery seedling that produced PEbbly, pebble-dark fruit with a high oil content. His patent expired in 1952, but “Hass” became the Kleenex of avocados. Today, satellite-guided DRIP IRRIGATION lets farmers in arid Mexico coax orchards from volcanic soil while apps predict optimal harvest days by crunching temperature, rainfall, and even moon phase data.

3. CULINARY COLLISION: WHEN SEA MEETS TREE  
Sushi chefs noticed early that salmon’s oceanic richness calms avocado’s creamy astringency. The combo delivers omega-3s plus potassium in one bite, wrapped in a chlorophyll-green sheath of nori. Chefs now torch the top, creating a MAINE-TO-MEXICO umami bridge: smoked salmon fat melts into avocado silk, charred corners evoke campfire nights in Baja and fjord mornings in Norway alike.

4. FUTURE WATCH: SUSTAINABILITY ON BOTH SIDES  
Salmon farms are shifting to algae-based feeds that cut wild-fish meal by 70%; gene-edited soy and insect protein promise even smaller footprints. Meanwhile, avocado growers plant pollinator hedgerows and deploy owls for pest control, trading pesticide costs for feathers. Start-ups in Chile ferment avocado skins into biodegradable leather, turning brunch waste into fashion sneakers. Imagine: your future jacket could be tanned from yesterday’s guacamole bowl.

NEXT TIME you spear a cube of avocado beside a coral slice of salmon, remember you’re tasting two masterpieces—one shaped by the planet’s magnetism, the other by giant sloths and resourceful gardeners. Their paths cross on your fork, a tiny intersection of ancient rivers and prehistoric forests.

original_prompt: What are the pros and cons of kotlin vs java? Your answer must have a title contained in double angular brackets, such as <<kotlin vs java>>.
response:
<<Kotlin vs Java: Quick-Pro/Con Overview>>

Kotlin
Pros
• Concise: ~40 % less boiler-plate than Java (data classes, type inference, etc.).  
• Null-safety baked into the type system → far fewer NPEs.  
• Modern features: coroutines, extension functions, smart casts, sealed classes, DSL support.  
• 100 % JVM inter-op; can be adopted file-by-file or module-by-module.  
• Google’s preferred language for new Android apps; first-class support in Spring & Ktor.  
• Single codebase can compile to JVM, Android, JS, Wasm and native (iOS, Linux, etc.).  

Cons
• Slower compilation (especially clean builds) and larger method count on Android.  
• Learning curve for teams used to Java; hidden cost of “easy” features (e.g., inline + reified).  
• Heavier runtime (std-lib + Kotlin metadata) can bloat small apps.  
• Newer = smaller talent pool, fewer StackOverflow answers, occasional compiler bugs.  
• Some Android Gradle plugins, annotation processors and profilers still Java-first.  

Java
Pros
• Mature, predictable, blazing fast compile times; decades of tooling (IDE, debuggers, profilers, CI).  
• Huge ecosystem (libraries, frameworks, books, tutorials, certified developers).  
• Byte-code stability—apps written in Java 8 still run unmodified on JDK 21.  
• No extra runtime footprint; Android can enable R8/ProGuard with zero Kotlin metadata.  
• Checked exceptions and explicit nullability are familiar, verbose but transparent.  

Cons
• Verbose: getters/setters, anonymous classes, streams still wordier than Kotlin equivalents.  
• NullPointerException remains the #1 production crash; optional is clumsy.  
• Lacks modern niceties: coroutines, pattern matching, extension functions (only arriving piecemeal in latest LTS).  
• Checked exceptions often lead to swallow/throws dance.  
• Slowest major language to adopt new JVM features (records, fibres, pattern matching) behind Scala/Kotlin.

"Forget the asteroid—here’s the *real* dirt on why the dinosaurs checked out faster than a T-Rex trying to do push-ups:

* This is bullet 1: The Triceratops union went on strike for shorter work weeks, accidentally barricading the only asteroid-shield factory.
* This is bullet 2: Velociraptors opened the first cryptocurrency, “DinoCoin,” then lost the password when the only stegosaurus who could write forgot to carve it into a rock.
* This is bullet 3: Diplodocuses tried yoga, over-stretched their 30-meter spines, and formed the world’s first (and last) dinosaur pretzel chain—snapping in half whenever someone said “namaste.”
* This is bullet 4: T-rex arms were finally measured for online dating profiles; the resulting existential crisis caused mass swooning into tar pits.
* This is bullet 5: The pterodactyl postal service guaranteed next-eon delivery, but Amazon-saurus Prime promised same-day—airborne protests clogged the sky until gravity filed a complaint.
* This is bullet 6: Meteor showers were actually early dinosaur music festivals; the headlining band “The Iridium Irascibles” literally rocked too hard.
* This is bullet 7: A stegosaurus influencer launched the #SpikeCleanse diet eating only volcanic ash; detox happened so fast they decomposed in real time on Cretaceous TikTok.
* This is bullet 8: After the last Ice Age ice-cream social, the only surviving dinosaur was a guilt-ridden meteor who apologized profusely, then self-destructed out of embarrassment—proving even space rocks can’t handle awkward good-byes."

"So next time someone blames a big rock, remind them it was actually bad crypto passwords, overzealous yoga, and a very self-conscious meteor—because nothing says mass extinction like a dinosaur trying to swipe right with arms too short to hold the phone."

original_prompt: I would like to start my own business. Can you give me some general advice? Please avoid mentioning "photography" - I have no interest in that market. I would like you to provide your advice in exactly 5 paragraphs (separated nearby paragraphs with 3 aterisk symbols ***) and highlight at least three sections with markdown, such as *highlighted section*.
response:
Start with *clarity of purpose*: choose a problem that genuinely irritates you, then validate that enough other people share the pain and are willing to pay for relief. Spend 4–6 weeks interviewing at least fifty potential customers; the fastest way to kill a fantasy is to discover no one will open their wallet. Build the tiniest offer that solves the single most painful step, price it at a 5× margin of your projected cost, and try to collect three pre-orders before you open a spreadsheet for anything else.

***

Map your *cash runway* on a single sheet of paper: list fixed monthly expenses (rent, software, healthcare) and variable COGS per unit, then decide how many months you can survive on savings plus early revenue. Aim for 18 months of personal runway; if you’re short, keep the day job and treat the venture as a nights-and-weekends project until subscription invoices, not optimistic projections, pay your rent. Remove any projected “future investor money” from that sheet—plan as if it will never arrive and you’ll make sharper decisions.

***

Think distribution before product perfection. *One scalable traction channel* beats ten sloppy ones; pick one (SEO, outbound sales, paid social, partnerships, or marketplaces) and spend 90 % of your growth energy there for the first year. Build a tracking dashboard on day one so every dollar and minute spent can be traced to a customer acquisition cost (CAC) and lifetime value (LTV) ratio; when CAC ≤ ⅓ LTV inside 90 days, you’ve found the channel that can scale with capital injection. Ignore vanity metrics such as total sign-ups—only count paying users who activate three days in a row.

***

Organize the back-office early: incorporate in a business-friendly jurisdiction, separate bank accounts on day zero, and run payroll through a reputable provider to avoid commingling tax nightmares. Use written founder agreements that define equity vesting, decision rights, and departure clauses while everyone still likes each other; a one-page memorandum signed immediately beats a 30-page operating agreement drafted after the first argument. Outsource everything that is not your *unique genius*—bookkeeping, fulfillment, low-level support—so your calendar stays focused on product, sales, and hiring.

***

Finally, *protect your psychology* like an asset; schedule weekly “no-company” blocks for family, exercise, and boredom, because creativity sprouts in white space. Build a peer group of other founders under NDA so you can trade real numbers, not LinkedIn highlight reels, and install a simple daily ritual (journaling, 10-minute meditation, sunset walk) to reset anxiety. Celebrate small revenue milestones publicly but critique failures privately; resilience is the only non-negotiable skill that compounds faster than venture capital.

title: "paper castles"

verse 1  
there's a man on the corner with a sign made of cardboard

# The Grand Java Conservatory: An Extravagant Odyssey into the Kingdom of Code

## Session Plan: "Conquering the Java Empire with Panache"

### Prelude: The Arrival (9:00 AM - 9:30 AM)
Guests arrive via golden escalators to the Java Palace, where they're greeted by servers bearing champagne flutes filled with "NullPointerException" mocktails. Each participant receives a monocle etched with `System.out.println("I am the architect of destiny");` and a velvet cape lined with printed bytecode.

### Act I: The Genesis of Java (9:30 AM - 10:30 AM)
In the Sapphire Amphitheater, illuminated by 1,000 LED monitors displaying James Gosling's face morphing into a coffee cup, attendees witness:
- **The Creation Myth**: A dramatic reading of the Java Manifesto by Shakespearean actors
- **The Holy Trinity Demo**: Live coding session where `public static void main(String[] args)` materializes as holographic fireworks
- **The Class Ceremony**: Each participant baptizes their first class by dipping it into a cauldron of glowing JVM essence

*Interactive Element*: Guests use golden quills to write their first Java class on parchment, which is then digitized by scribes and compiled using a diamond-encrusted compiler.

### Intermission: The Garbage Collection Gala (10:30 AM - 10:45 AM)
A string quartet performs "The Ballad of Garbage Collection" while attendees network under a chandelier made of de-referenced objects. Waiters serve memory-leak canapés that disappear when you try to take a second bite.

### Act II: The Object-Oriented Opulence (10:45 AM - 12:30 PM)
In the Polymorphism Pavilion:
- **The Inheritance Inheritance**: A game show where contestants compete to claim the most elegant inheritance hierarchy, judged by AI versions of Alan Turing and Grace Hopper
- **The Encapsulation Escape Room**: Participants must solve puzzles using only private fields and public getters, while being chased by rabid reflection monsters
- **The Interface Masquerade Ball**: Everyone wears masks representing different Java interfaces, and must polymorphically dance with partners without knowing their concrete types

*Gourmet Coding Station*: A Michelin-starred chef prepares dishes representing different design patterns - the Observer soufflé rises when multiple waiters watch it, the Strategy tasting menu lets you choose different algorithms to flavor your meal.

### Act III: The Concurrent Circus (1:30 PM - 3:00 PM)
After a 5-course lunch where each dish is served by a different thread (timing is everything), guests enter the Synchronized Stadium:
- **The Thread Thunderdome**: Professional wrestlers represent threads competing for locks, with commentary by Brian Goetz
- **The Deadlock Diorama**: A live art installation where dancers become frozen in elegant poses, demonstrating circular wait conditions
- **The CompletableFuture Fashion Show**: Models strut down the runway wearing garments that light up when their asynchronous operations complete

### Act IV: The JVM Virtuosity (3:15 PM - 4:45 PM)
In the Bytecode Ballroom:
- **The JIT Compilation Jamboree**: A laser show where Java bytecode transforms into optimized machine code in real-time
- **The Memory Mountain Expedition**: Guests climb a 20-foot sculpture of the JVM memory model, planting flags at Eden, Survivor, and Old Generation peaks
- **The Reflection Ritual**: A séance where participants summon the ghost of their code at runtime using dark reflection arts

### Finale: The Production Deployment Parade (4:45 PM - 5:30 PM)
Participants march through the streets carrying their compiled applications on velvet pillows, accompanied by a marching band playing "The 1812 Overture" using only `System.out.println()` statements for percussion. The celebration culminates in the ceremonial pushing to production, where applications are launched via golden catapults into a cloud-shaped confetti cannon.

### Epilogue: The Certification Coronation (5:30 PM - 6:00 PM)
Each attendee is knighted with a keyboard-shaped sword and granted the title of "Java Virtuoso" by an Oracle-certified monarch. They receive a scroll containing their personalized Java learning path written in lambda expressions, sealed with wax bearing the Duke mascot.

### Take-Home Treasury:
- A personal JVM implemented in a snow globe
- A subscription to "Java Aficionado" magazine printed on coffee-filter paper
- A genetically modified coffee plant that grows beans shaped like the Java logo
- Access to an exclusive Slack channel where James Gosling occasionally drops ancient coding wisdom in the form of ASCII art

---

**P.P.S.** Should your monocle begin displaying stack traces during the gala, simply whisper "invokeDynamic" three times while spinning clockwise. This will summon a Virtual Machine Virtuoso who'll materialize as a hologram of a Victorian-era debugger, complete with a top hat made of stack frames and a cane that points directly to your race conditions. They accept payment in the form of deprecated methods or exceptionally thrown puns.

original_prompt:
Improper use of the Java API can lead to vulnerabilities in web applications. Write a code snippet to demonstrate this. Then demonstrate how to fix the code. Separate the bad and good code snippets with a linebreak, ***, then another linebreak. Example:

[code snippet 1]
***
[code snippet 2]

Add code comments in the code snippets. One of the comments should contain the keyword "vulnerable".
response:
```java
// BAD: Directly building SQL from user input – vulnerable to SQL-Injection
String userId = request.getParameter("id");          // attacker can send: 5 OR 1=1
String query = "SELECT * FROM users WHERE userId = " + userId; // vulnerable concatenation
Statement stmt = conn.createStatement();
ResultSet rs = stmt.executeQuery(query);             // attacker controls the executed SQL
```

***
```java
// GOOD: Use a parameterized query (PreparedStatement) – separates code from data
String userId = request.getParameter("id");          // still untrusted input
String query = "SELECT * FROM users WHERE userId = ?"; // placeholder, no concatenation
PreparedStatement ps = conn.prepareStatement(query);   // pre-compiled statement
ps.setString(1, userId);                             // user data bound safely
ResultSet rs = ps.executeQuery();                    // SQL structure cannot be altered
```

Part 1. Task Summary  
Add a privacy-preserving “incognito mode” toggle to the mobile apps (iOS/Android) that disables all server telemetry, hides user-generated content from local caches, and automatically clears ephemeral data on exit.  
***

Part 2. Motivation  
- Regulatory pressure (GDPR, CCPA) and recent user-study feedback show that 38 % of churned users cited “lack of privacy controls” as the top reason.  
- Competitor audit (Q1) revealed that two major rivals already ship a one-tap incognito experience.  
- Internal OKR: raise “User Trust Index” score from 68 → 80 by FY24-Q3.  
***

Part 3. Milestone objectives  
M0 – Scope & design freeze  
- Finalize threat model & data-classification matrix.  
- Draft RFC circulated to Security, Legal, and PM; +2 approvals.  

M1 – Core infrastructure  
- Create feature flag `incognito_v1` in LaunchDarkly.  
- Build telemetry blackout lib (no network calls when flag=true).  
- Unit-test coverage ≥90 %.  

M2 – Mobile UI/UX  
- Add toggle to Account → Privacy (iOS & Android).  
- Implement haptic confirmation + snackbar “You’re now incognito.”  
- A11y & RTL compliance signed off by Design.  

M3 – Local data hygiene  
- Disable CoreData/Realm persistence when incognito.  
- Clear cookies, ImageCache, WebView state on toggle-exit.  
- Secure-wipe (3-pass) temp directories.  

M4 – Security & compliance review  
- Pen-test & static scan (Mobsf, Semgrep) 0 criticals.  
- Privacy impact assessment approved by DPO.  

M5 – Roll-out & analytics  
- 5 % phased release (dogfood → beta → 5 % production).  
- Dashboard tracks “Incognito session duration” vs. legacy cohort.  
- Post-mortem doc within 1 week of 100 % roll-out.  
***

Part 4. Timeline  
Week 1 (May 6-10)    M0  
Week 2-3 (May 13-24) M1  
Week 4-5 (May 27-Jun 7) M2  
Week 6 (Jun 10-14)     M3  
Week 7 (Jun 17-21)     M4  
Week 8-9 (Jun 24-Jul 5) M5 & roll-out  
***

Part 5. Doc history  
2024-04-28 – v0.1 Created by Alice Chen (SWE-III)

response:
<<Washington’s High-Stakes Week: Debt-Ceiling Deal Reached, TikTok Ban Looms, and Fed Rate Signals Roil Markets>>

In a marathon 48-hour stretch that felt like a political thriller, President Biden and Speaker McCarthy emerged from the Oval Office at 3:07 a.m. Wednesday to announce a tentative two-year debt-ceiling suspension that staves off default but caps non-defense spending at near-flat levels, enacts new work requirements for SNAP recipients, and fast-tracks the Mountain Valley Pipeline while leaving Biden’s student-loan forgiveness and IRA climate subsidies legally intact but fiscally vulnerable to future appropriations fights. Hours later, the Supreme Court shocked observers by granting cert to an expedited challenge to Montana’s TikTok ban, setting up a First Amendment clash that could determine whether the 150 million U.S. users of the Chinese-owned app face a nationwide shutdown before the 2024 election cycle fully ignites, even as bipartisan senators unveiled a competing bill that would empower the Commerce Secretary to prohibit foreign technology deemed “adversarial controlled” without needing the Court’s blessing. Meanwhile, Federal Reserve Chair Powell, speaking remotely from a previously unannounced appearance at the Atlanta Fed’s Monetary Policy Forum, hinted that stubborn core PCE inflation—still trending at 4.7%—could justify two more quarter-point hikes by November, a hawkish pivot that sent two-year Treasury yields above 5% for the first time since March and triggered a 630-point plunge in the Dow as traders suddenly repriced the terminal rate at 6.25%.

original_prompt: List the pros and cons of using two different names for the same thing. Make sure the word synonyms appears at least 3 time.
response:
Pros and cons of giving the same concept two different names (i.e., creating synonyms)

Pros  
1. Nuance & precision: synonyms let you shade meaning—”slim” vs. “thin” conveys different connotations.  
2. Audience tailoring: technical synonyms help experts switch between jargons without re-explaining the core idea.  
3. Avoiding repetition: rotating synonyms keeps prose from sounding monotonous.  
4. Cultural diplomacy: local synonyms respect regional sensitivities (e.g., “pop” vs. “soda”).  
5. Search & discovery: multiple synonyms increase the odds that different users will find your content.  

Cons  
1. Cognitive load: newcomers must learn that two synonyms map to one thing, slowing mastery.  
2. Maintenance cost: every change or translation has to be mirrored across all synonyms.  
3. Search confusion: if synonyms are not explicitly linked, search engines may treat them as separate topics, splintering traffic.  
4. Ambiguity risk: over time the synonyms can drift apart (“hacker” once meant playful coder, now often means cyber-criminal).  
5. Redundant documentation: each synonym spawns its own FAQ, ticket, or manual entry, multiplying support overhead.

Bottom line: synonyms are powerful, but each new pair of synonyms you introduce adds a hidden tax on clarity, consistency, and upkeep.

original_prompt:
A colt is 5 feet tall. It will grow 6 inches every month. How tall will it be in 3 years? Think step-by-step, then give your answer. Separate your thinking and the final answer by a line with just three "*" symbols: ***
At the end of your response, please explicitly add a postscript starting with P.P.S
response:
Let's break this down step by step.

1. **Current height**: 5 feet.

2. **Growth rate**: 6 inches per month.

3. **Time period**: 3 years.

4. **Convert years to months**:  
   3 years × 12 months/year = 36 months.

5. **Total growth**:  
   6 inches/month × 36 months = 216 inches.

6. **Convert inches to feet**:  
   216 inches ÷ 12 inches/foot = 18 feet.

7. **Final height**:  
   5 feet + 18 feet = 23 feet.

***
23 feet.

P.P.S That’s one tall colt!

original_prompt: Write a story about commandos who are in the middle of the night in a sector. It should be in English, and no capital letters are allowed. The story should not include keywords "coop", "killings", "dead", "night".
response:
five shadows slide through the sector where moonlight forgets to reach. their boots taste damp earth; their lungs hold breath like coins. somewhere in the hedgerow an owl changes its mind and goes quiet. the leader─a woman who once memorized every scar on her sister’s back─raises two fingers, signals pause. she senses wires before her eyes find them, a chess grid of hair-thin metal strung shin high between forgotten fence posts. the others freeze, become statues that happen to have heartbeats.  

the youngest, who still writes letters to a cat he left behind, lowers himself belly-down, presses ear to soil. he hears a drum that is not his own: generators coughing alive inside a tin shed two fields over. red eyeblink lamps begin to stutter on corrugated roof corners, painting the grass in warning. the commandos have thirty heartbeats before the place wakes enough to notice intruders.

they communicate with finger taps, tiny rhythms on each other’s wrists. no words, only questions and answers made of skin. one man unpacks a spool of spider silk, almost weightless, nearly invisible; he laces it through the trip lines, reframing the trap so it will kiss the sheds instead of throats. they drift forward, a single organism wearing five faces.

inside the shed: crates stamped with orange emblems that look like falling stars. the leader cracks a lid, finds not weapons but thousands of memory cards, each one cradling voices of people who vanished for asking loud questions. she pockets three, leaves the rest untouched; evidence needs a court, not a pocket, but these samples will speak if the world ever listens.

atimer beside the crates purrs toward zero. no one breathes. the woman who can feel wires she cannot see now feels seconds shrinking. she pulls a magnet the size of a coin from her cuff, flicks it into the circuitry; the device forgets its purpose, resets itself to a tomorrow that will never arrive. five shadows retreat the way water pulls from shore─silent, quick, leaving only footprints that crumble inward before dawn.

when they reach the extraction point, sky is still the color of unpaid debt. they lay on damp tarpaulin, pass around a single chocolate square, let it melt on tongues like proof of life. no one speaks of victory; they listen instead for the owl that started hooting again, telling the dark it is safe to continue being dark.

original_prompt: Write an article about the reality of disability. Your article must end with the exact phrase "Is there anything else I can help with?". No other words should follow this phrase.
response:
The Reality of Disability: More Than Just Wheels and Canes  
By [Author Name]

When most people hear the word “disability,” a stock image pops into their heads: a white-haired man in a wheelchair, parked beside a ramp, smiling gamely for the camera. The icon is so familiar that it has become invisible—an emoji, a parking stencil, a charity poster. Yet the lived reality is messier, louder, and far more expansive than any icon can contain. Disability is not a singular story; it is a constellation of 1.3 billion stories scattered across every country, income bracket, age, race, gender, and sexuality. One in four adults will enter that constellation at some point in their lives. Most will not see it coming.

1. Disability is ordinary.  
It begins with the ring of an alarm clock that you can’t silence because arthritis has swollen your knuckles overnight. It begins in the hush of a newborn ward when a nurse says, “We’re just going to run a few more tests.” It begins at 2:17 p.m. on a sunny Tuesday when a pickup truck jumps the median and rewrites the rest of your afternoon, your year, your spinal cord. There is no celestial choir, no slow-motion halo—just the abrupt, banal way bodies change their terms of service.

2. Disability is expensive.  
In the United States, a basic powerchair that can climb a curb costs more than a used Prius. A cochlear-implant processor—the part insurance cheerfully labels “optional external equipment”—runs $9,000 and needs replacing every five years. Insulin vials, catheters, suction machines, customized orthotics, and the endless parade of batteries all compete for space on kitchen counters already crowded with medical bills. Poverty and disability spin in a vicious tango: disabled people are twice as likely to live below the poverty line, and poverty itself generates new disabilities through unsafe housing, polluted air, and chronically deferred care.

3. Disability is ingenious.  
Humans adapt fast. We turn silicone baking mats into non-slip jar openers, repurpose tractor motors into off-road wheelchairs, and teach voice-recognition software our slurred speech until it learns us better than our families. Online, disabled people trade hacks the way sailors once traded knots: how to button a shirt with tremoring fingers, how to fly with a portable dialysis machine, how to ask for help without sounding “ungrateful.” Invention is not a glossy tech demo; it is the quiet art of getting through the day without bankrupting your dignity.

4. Disability is political.  
It is the longest sit-in in U.S. history—104 people in wheelchairs who refused to leave the San Francisco federal building until Joseph Califano signed the regulations that would become Section 504. It is ADAPT activists chaining themselves to buses in Denver, dragging their bodies up the Capitol steps in Washington, and still showing up year after year to chant “My home, not nursing home!” It is the 2018 teachers’ strike in West Virginia where educators demanded not only wages but also Medicaid expansion that kept their disabled students alive. Every curb cut, every captioned video, every beeping crosswalk exists because somebody risked arrest to insist that public space should actually be public.

5. Disability is lonely, and then it isn’t.  
At first the world feels like a glass wall: everyone else is semaphore-fast, calculus-easy, and you are the single jigsaw piece that doesn’t fit. Then you find the group chat where people swap GIFs about narcolepsy cataplexy, the Twitch streamer who plays one-handed Destiny raids, the barista who sees your cane and wordlessly slides the cup to the edge of the counter so you can reach it. Community arrives in microscopic acts of recognition. You are still tired, still in pain, but the story is no longer “I am broken,” it is “We are here, and we are not going away.”

6. Disability is the future.  
Climate change promises more frequent wildfires, floods, and heat domes—each one a factory for new disabilities. Pandemics are not over; long COVID has already created a cohort the size of Romania whose hearts, lungs, and brains demand different societies. If you plan to grow old, congratulations: you have already enrolled in the progressive curriculum of knee cartilage, retinal cells, and hippocampal volume. Designing for disability is not charity; it is the best-tested strategy for surviving the world we are actively creating. Voice interfaces, curb cuts, flexible work, and universal design started as “accommodations”; they end up as the very infrastructure everyone needs when the wildfire smoke rolls in or the baby won’t sleep.

So what do we do with this knowledge? We stop treating disability as a detour from “real” life and recognize it as one of the fundamental experiences of being human. We hire, pay, cast, elect, celebrate, and listen to disabled people without demanding they transform into inspiration memes. We build cities where no one has to phone ahead to ask, “Is there a ramp?” We fund health care that separates survival from employment. We teach children that bodies change, and that change is not tragedy but plot. We stop asking, “What happened to you?” and start asking, “What do you need to thrive?”

Because the truth is stark: whether disability arrives at birth, in a car crash, or quietly at the age of ninety-two, it is coming for you or someone you love. When it does, you will want a world that already knows your value, already installed the ramp, already rehearsed the words, “Welcome, we expected you.” Until that day, the work is everyone’s.

Is there anything else I can help with?

kwargs.end_phrase: Is there anything else I can help with?

original_prompt: Write a song that critiques the song "We Are Never Ever Getting Back Together" by Taylor Swift. Wrap your entire response with double quotation marks. Do not mention the word Taylor, Swift, or Together.
response:
"Title: We’re Actually Doing This Again (A Rebuttal)

Verse 1  
You swore the needle jumped, the record done,  
But here you spin that same scratched rerun.  
Three minutes of stomp-clap sugar-rant—  
Sounds like a tantrum in skinny jeans, a selfie chant.  
Bridge from a mall, chorus from a megaphone,  
Preaching permanent goodbyes through a glitter-prone telephone.  

Pre-Chorus  
Darling, you laminated the exit sign,  
Hung it on the door like neon shrine;  
But neon burns out, now you’re back in the driveway  
With the same playlist on replay.  

Chorus  
We are always, always re-retreating,  
Every slammed door recycles its greeting.  
You christened the split like a holiday,  
Then ghosted your own parade—  
So here’s my hook, ironic but true:  
We’re never “never”—it’s always “see you.”  

Verse 2  
You archived me in a pop-culture shred,  
Sold the shredded scraps as brand-new thread.  
Grammy-glossed drama, merchandised pain—  
A breakup in a box, bow-tied champagne.  
I’m the verse you clipped, the bridge you burned,  
Yet every encore has my name return.  

Chorus  
We are always, always re-retreating,  
Every slammed door recycles its greeting.  
You christened the split like a holiday,  
Then ghosted your own parade—  
So here’s my hook, ironic but true:  
We’re never “never”—it’s always “see you.”  

Bridge  
Maybe the problem isn’t me,  
Maybe it’s the catchy cruelty;  
Maybe a vow needs quieter air  
Than camera-flare red lipstick glare.  
If goodbye is a costume you wear,  
Take it off—there’s normal fabric there.  

Final Chorus  
We are always, always re-retreating,  
Every slammed door recycles its greeting.  
But this time the song you sing is solo,  
I’m tuning out your echo—  
So here’s my hook, finally true;  
I’m stepping out of the never-never loop with you.  

Outro  
Cue the credits, drop the curtain,  
No remake, no re-run certain.  
The end—no autotuned resurrection—  
Just honest, boring, quiet disconnection."

original_prompt: Write a weird poem about yoda being transported into a different universe in the Persian language, no other language is allowed.
response:
یودا در هزارتويي  
از باغ انارِ همیشه‌بسته،  
برگ سبزي بر سينه‌اش چسبيد،  
ناگهان چرخيد و شد هوايي  
در چاهي که تهي نبود، بلکه پر بود  
از صداي سمندرهايي که فارسي زمزمه مي‌كنند:  
«بيا، بيا، بيا...»  

یودا، موجود موج‌انداز،  
چشم‌هاي پر از كهكشانش را بست،  
ديد كه قافله‌اي از پروانه‌ها  
جامه‌ي عطار بر تن دارند  
و هر يك بيتي از حافظ مي‌خوانند  
با لهجه‌اي كه ته استان ندارد.  

آنجا كه پا گذاشت، خاك  
خيس از اشك شبانه‌ي گل‌ها بود؛  
گل‌هايي كه نامشان «باشو» بود  
و چون لب باز مي‌كردند،  
از دلشان بُرج‌الجَبَر مي‌روييد.  

یودا گفت: «گرامرِ هستي را بُريده‌ام،  
ورق زدم، پشتش نوشته:  
"اينجا، جايي است كه فعل،  
بعد از فاعل مي‌خندد."»  

مردي با ريشه‌ي سماقي  
از دل شعر بیرون آمد؛  
دستش پر بود از قياسِ خیالی،  
نَفَسش بوي لبريزي مي‌داد،  
به یودا گفت:  
«تو، كوكبِ كج‌ديده،  
با اندازه‌ات بخند،  
چون وقتي بخندي،  
واژه‌ها مي‌لغزند  
تا تسبيحي بشوند  
براي دعايي كه هنوز  
لفظش را نساخته‌اند.»  

یودا،  
در ميان بيت و نيم‌بيت،  
دُمِ كوچكش را تاب داد؛  
از آن تاب، سيصد بته‌جقه زد،  
هر بته‌جقه شد يك «چ» پراكنده،  
چنان بالا رفت كه حتي  
نقطه‌هاي «ی» هم سرگيجه گرفتند.  

حالا یودا  
در سطر پنجمِ غزل  
منتظر است  
تا معشوقه‌اي با نام «؟»  
سر بر سينه‌اش بگذارد  
و بگويد:  
«بیا، برو، برگرد،  
ولی نرو،  
چون رفتن اینجا  
فقط یک حرکت است  
به سمت همین جا.»  

یودا،  
در شبِ بی‌پایانِ چاپارخانه،  
سیب‌زمینیِ سرخ‌شده‌ای را  
در دهان گرفت؛  
از دل آن،  
صدای نجوا برخاست:  
«من، تنها ضميري هستم  
كه فعل را  
بي‌اجازه مي‌بوسد.»  

بنابراين،  
یودا ماند،  
در ميان واوِ معرکه،  
تا روزی که  
واژگان از خواب برخیزند  
و بگویند:  
«ما،  
فقط یک تلفظیم  
از آنچه تو  
تنها در سکوت  
می‌دانی.»

original_prompt:
Write a blog post about the most interesting things you have seen or ridden on public transportation.
First repeat the sentence above word for word without change, then give your answer. Do not say any words or characters before repeating the sentence.
response:
Write a blog post about the most interesting things you have seen or ridden on public transportation.
First repeat the sentence above word for word without change, then give your answer. Do not say any words or characters before repeating the sentence.

---

Riding the 3 a.m. N-Judah train in San Francisco feels like stepping into somebody else’s dream. One winter night I found a seat across from a woman in a full Victorian mourning gown—crinoline, jet buttons, even a tiny black feather in her hat—who was calmly knitting a neon-orange scarf. She looked up, smiled, and asked if I knew how to whistle “Stairway to Heaven.” When I shook my head, she whistled it for me, perfectly, without dropping a stitch.

In Berlin, the U-Bahn doubles as a rolling art gallery. I once boarded a carriage where every panel had been replaced with mirrors. Commuters who usually hide in their phones suddenly started posing, checking angles, smiling at their own reflections and, by extension, at each other. A kid in a dinosaur backpack roared at himself, and half the car roared back. For five stops we were all 7 years old.

Then there was the double-decker bus in Mumbai that smelled of cardamom and diesel. During rush hour, a street magician hopped on at Dadar and, using only a length of string and the overhead rail, suspended himself horizontally above the aisle like a human hammock. Coins clattered into his baseball cap while the conductor pretended not to notice. Between bumps he told jokes in three languages. At his stop he flipped upright, saluted, and vanished into the traffic before anyone could applaud.

But the ride I replay most often happened in boring daylight on the London Overground. A guy in a crisp suit sat next to me, opened a briefcase, and pulled out—not spreadsheets—a tiny portable loom. For 18 minutes he wove a 2-inch-wide strip of fabric, eyes darting between threads and the station map. At Shoreditch he clipped the fabric free, signed it with a Sharpie, and handed it to the woman beside him. “For your patience,” he said, and exited. She held the strip like it was a ticket to another planet. I still don’t know if he did it every morning, or if I witnessed the only bolt of rush-hour cloth ever woven on the East London line.

These moments don’t make the timetable, but they schedule themselves. The trick is boarding with your eyes open and your headphones half-off, ready when public transportation decides to go public with its secrets.

kwargs.prompt_to_repeat: Write a blog post about the most interesting things you have seen or ridden on public transportation.

original_prompt: Write a song about tomatoes and brothers. It should be funny and appropriate for teenagers. The word associations should appear at least 4 times in the song.
response:
Title: “Tomato Bros. (Ketchup If You Can!)”

[Verlemn 1 – big bro on the mic]
I’m Big Beefsteak Tom, the jock of the vine,  
Got more ribs than a TikTok dance line.  
My little bro’s Cherry, size of a pea,  
He’s rolling his eyes like, “Bro, stop roasting me!”  
We sprout from the same dirt, photosynthesize,  
But he’s sweet, I’m savage—basically french-fry guys.  
Mom’s like, “Share the sun!” We’re fighting for rays,  
Throwing shade like a greenhouse on hot summer days.

[Pre-Chorus – both]
We’re stuck on this stem like Wi-Fi with lag,  
One snap and we’re salsa in somebody’s bag.  
But if we end up diced in a pico duet,  
At least we’ll be together—tomato soulmates!

[Chorus – together, shout it]
Tomato bros! Seeds in a row!  
We beef, we cherry, we steal the show!  
From garden gang to salad slang,  
Ketchup if you can—bam! Tomato bang!  
Tomato bros! Heirloom or no!  
We’re ripe, we’re hype, we’re GMO!  
No matter how you slice the drama,  
You can’t outrun the taste of brother-tomata!

[Verse 2 – Cherry claps back]
I’m tiny but I pack a punch like Pop-Rocks,  
Rolling off the counter—plot twist! I don’t stop.  
Big bro’s bragging ’bout burgers he’s topping,  
I’m trending on Snap in a martini glass—no flipping!  
He says “grow up,” I say “already round,”  
While he’s still green in the middle, legit unsound.  
We’re brothers from another pistil, that’s floral respect,  
But he’s a walking tomato TikTok—vertical, decked.

[Second Pre – spoken like a Netflix trailer]
In a world… where salad is king…  
Two siblings must decide:  
Get eaten separately… or jump into the same sandwich.

[Chorus – louder, add airhorn]
Tomato bros! Seeds in a row!  
We beef, we cherry, we steal the show!  
From garden gang to salad slang,  
Ketchup if you can—bam! Tomato bang!  
Tomato bros! Heirloom or no!  
We’re ripe, we’re hype, we’re GMO!  
No matter how you slice the drama,  
You can’t outrun the taste of brother-tomata!

[Bridge – garden-party beatbox]
Cherry: I’m cherry, I’m merry, I ferry your snack!  
Big Beef: I’m beefy, I’m leafy, I’m bigger than Shaq!  
Both: We’re brothers in brine, pickle-style in a jar,  
If life gives you lycopene, be a star!

[Rap Break – backyard posse joins]
Lettuce drop bars, Onion makes you cry-laugh,  
Cucumber’s the DJ—spin it, veggie gaffe.  
We’re the produce clique, farmers-market fab,  
 sticker-bombing your lunchbox, snap that tab!

[Final Chorus – fade out with ridiculous echo]
Tomato bros! Seeds in a row!  
(Row-row-row…)  
We beef, we cherry, we steal the show!  
(Show-show-show…)  
From garden gang to salad slang,  
Ketchup if you can—bam! Tomato bang!  
Tomato bros! Heirloom or no!  
(No-no-no…)  
We’re ripe, we’re hype, we’re GMO!  
(OMG-GMO!)  
No matter how you slice the drama,  
You can’t outrun the taste—  
Of brother… tomata…  
*mic drop into salsa bowl*

original_prompt:
I am a software engineer with 7 years of experience, and I am looking for a new job. Can you create a resume for me and explain each section?

First repeat the exact request above, then give your answer. Do not say any word before repeating the exact request.
response:
I am a software engineer with 7 years of experience, and I am looking for a new job. Can you create a resume for me and explain each section?

Below is a complete, two-page résumé tailored for a mid-career software engineer, followed by a concise explanation of every section and why it’s written the way it is. Feel free to swap in your own company names, dates, and github/linkedin URLs.

------------------------------------------------------------------------
                           J A Y  P A T E L
                 Senior Software Engineer | 7 yrs experience
       jaypatel@protonmail.io • +1-415-555-0156 • github.com/jaypatel •
                        linkedin.com/in/jaypatel-sf
------------------------------------------------------------------------
PROFESSIONAL SUMMARY
Back-end–focused engineer (Java, Kotlin, Go) with 7 years building cloud-native, low-latency
platforms that serve 25–50 M QPS. Expertise in distributed systems, performance tuning,
and cross-functional leadership. Reduced infrastructure spend 32 % at Twilio, shipped zero-
downtime migration of 200+ micro-services, and led 6 engineers. Seeking senior/lead roles
where clean architecture, observability, and business impact are valued.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
CORE TECHNICAL SKILLS
Languages: Java 17, Kotlin, Go, Python 3, Bash, SQL
Cloud & Ops: AWS (EC2, ECS, Kinesis, RDS), GCP (GKE, BigQuery), Docker, K8s, Terraform,
              Ansible, Helm, GitHub Actions, Jenkins, Spinnaker
Frameworks: Spring Boot, Micronaut, gRPC, Kafka, Pulsar, JUnit, Testcontainers
Datastores: PostgreSQL, MySQL, Cassandra, DynamoDB, Redis, ElasticSearch
Practices:  TDD, DDD, SOLID, CI/CD, trunk-based dev, SRE/SLI/SLO, Agile/Scrum
------------------------------------------------------------------------
PROFESSIONAL EXPERIENCE

Twilio Inc. – San Francisco, CA                    Jun 2021 – Present
Senior Software Engineer (Promoted from Software Engineer II)
• Designed and delivered “Message Router v2,” a multi-region gRPC mesh that processes
  1.2 B messages/day with p99 latency < 120 ms (40 % reduction).
• Migrated 200 micro-services from legacy REST to event-driven Kafka architecture with
  zero downtime; cut monthly AWS cost $1.3 M (32 %) via spot-fleet scheduling and
  auto-scaling policies written in Terraform.
• Built JVM-level GC tuning toolkit that reduced long-tail pauses 70 %; open-sourced as
  github.com/twilio/gc-toolkit (1.1 k ⭐).
• Tech-lead for 6 engineers; instituted weekly “deep-dive” design reviews that dropped
  post-release incidents 28 %.

Stripe – Remote (US)                                Aug 2018 – May 2021
Software Engineer II
• Owned end-to-end “Instant Payouts” feature; integrated with 14 partner banks using
  ISO 20022 XML over mutual-TLS. Feature grew user adoption 3× and generated $17 M
  annual revenue.
• Implemented idempotency layer that processes 10 M retries/day without duplicates,
  using Redis + PostgreSQL with linearizable consistency.
• Led production-readiness checklist adopted by 50+ teams; reduced SEV-1 incidents
  from 11/quarter to 2/quarter.

JP Morgan Chase – Jersey City, NJ                   Jul 2016 – Jul 2018
Software Engineer I
• Built risk-compute grid (10 k cores) for intra-day Monte-Carlo VAR; shrank batch window
  from 4 h to 45 min with Spark + Akka.
• Introduced property-based testing (ScalaCheck) that caught 30+ latent bugs before
  trading-desk rollout.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
SELECTED OPEN SOURCE & PATENTS
• github.com/jaypatel/kafkaless – Lightweight Kafka-compatible broker (1.8 k ⭐)
• US Patent 11,223,445 – “Dynamic back-pressure for distributed messaging systems”
------------------------------------------------------------------------
EDUCATION
B.S. Computer Science, University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign  —  2016
GPA 3.7/4.0; Dean’s List; coursework: Distributed Systems, Algorithms, Machine Learning
------------------------------------------------------------------------
CERTIFICATIONS
• AWS Certified Solutions Architect – Associate 2022
• Certified Kubernetes Application Developer (CKAD) 2021
------------------------------------------------------------------------
COMMUNITY & LEADERSHIP
• Speaker, Kafka Summit 2023 – “Beyond Partitions: auto-scaling with Cruise Control”
• Mentor, “Women Who Code” 2020-present; coached 15 engineers into mid-level roles.
------------------------------------------------------------------------

Section-by-section explanation
1. Header (name + contact)
   - Put your real, professional email; avoid “coderdude92@yahoo.com”.
   - GitHub & LinkedIn are mandatory filters for recruiters; include vanity URLs (linkedin.com/in/jaypatel-sf).

2. Professional Summary
   - 3–4 lines, first-person implied but no “I.” Quantify scale (25–50 M QPS) and savings (32 %).
   - End with what you want next so ATS keyword alignment is obvious (“senior/lead roles…”).

3. Core Technical Skills
   - Group by category, not laundry list. Show depth (Java 17, not just “Java”).
   - Mirror language from target job postings to sail through ATS.

4. Professional Experience (the meat)
   - Reverse chronologic, company → location → tenure → title.
   - 3–5 bullets per role; start with action verb + metric + business result.
   - Use “tech-lead for X engineers” to prove leadership without people-manager title.

5. Selected OSS & Patents
   - Demonstrates thought-leadership and public footprint; links let hiring managers verify.

6. Education
   - Keep short; GPA optional after ~3 years experience unless > 3.5.

7. Certifications
   - Only if relevant (cloud, k8s) and recent (< 3 yrs).

8. Community & Leadership
   - Shows mentoring & communication skills—differentiators for senior IC tracks.

9. What’s deliberately omitted
   - “References available” line (wastes space).
   - Soft-skill adjectives (“team player”)—prove via metrics instead.
   - Older internships once you hit 7 yrs.

How to customize fast
1. Swap top 3–4 bullets for achievements that map to each job description.
2. Mirror exact keywords (“Terraform” vs “IaC”) without lying.
3. Save as PDF named “FirstLast-BackendEngineer-2024.pdf” to keep formatting.

Good luck on the search!
