original_prompt: Write an essay of at least 900 words on the topic of navigable freeway. Make sure the entire response is in English and no capital letters are used.
response:
navigable freeway: a meditation on movement, access, and the quiet poetry of asphalt

the first time i understood what a navigable freeway really was, i was eight years old and lying on the itchy carpet of my parents’ pontiac. the car was parked on the shoulder of interstate 35 just north of austin, hazard lights blinking like a slow heartbeat. my father had kicked off his loafers and crawled underneath the chassis, muttering verbs that were not in my third-grade spelling book. heat shimmered off the pavement; the freeway itself seemed to breathe, exhaling tar and diesel and something invisible that tasted like possibility. i remember tracing the lane markings with a sweaty finger on the window and thinking that if i could follow them long enough, they would spill me into every future i could imagine. in that broken-down instant, the freeway was not a road but a promise: if we could just get moving again, the world would stay open.

years later, when i began to study infrastructure as a historian of everyday life, i learned that the word “navigable” once belonged to rivers. before steam and steel, a navigable waterway was any stream you could float without dragging your flatboat every hundred yards. the corps of engineers measured channel depth, current velocity, snags and sandbars; they issued bulletins that read like nautical weather reports. when we transferred the adjective to land, we quietly admitted that asphalt had become our new hydrology. the freeway is a river we carved with blast rock and fill dirt, a current of rubber instead of meltwater, but it still obeys ancient rules: it must flow, it must not dry, and it must let us ride.

to call a freeway “navigable,” then, is to make a civic claim. it asserts that the corridor is more than a strip of concrete; it is a public utility, a commons of velocity. anyone with a license and a quarter tank of gas may enter, provided they obey the liturgy of signage and speed limits. the on-ramp is a lock gate, the lane merge a choreography of mutual recognition. we speak of “traffic” as if it were a liquid, and in doing so we reveal our secret belief that movement itself is a right, not a commodity. when that movement stalls—when the river clots into a parking lot—tempers flare precisely because the promise has been broken. we are water molecules caught in a hypertrophic eddy, and we resent it.

but navigability is never purely technical; it is also social and narrative. every freeway carries at least three texts simultaneously. there is the official text: the federal functional classification map, the mph curve design standards, the exit numbering protocol based on mileposts. there is the corporate text: the bid contracts, the asphalt plants, the private bond issues that monetize toll revenues decades ahead. and then there is the vernacular text, the one we write each time we merge: the late-night phone call that reroutes a life, the college kid who learns distance by counting green mile markers, the undocumented driver who keeps to the right lane because a patrol car lurks in the median shadow. these three texts overlap, contradict, and sometimes annihilate one another, yet they coexist on the same stretch of concrete. the navigable freeway is thus a palimpsest: you can still read the 1956 interstate act in the guardrail profiles, but you can also read your own childhood if you know which off-ramp leads to the cemetery where your grandmother’s plastic flowers have bleached to the color of bone.

consider the geometry. engineers speak of “design speed,” the theoretical velocity at which a road can be safely traversed if every driver is alert, every tire properly inflated, every sunset free of glare. that speed is written into the curvature of the roadway itself: the superelevation of curves, the sight distance at crests, the width of shoulders that double as emergency sanctuaries. yet the lived freeway is always slower or faster than its blueprint. rain lowers the coefficient of friction; a fender-bender collapses four lanes into one; a viral tiktok warns of a “speed trap” and everyone decelerates in a ghost wave that travels backward at 12 mph. the navigable freeway is therefore a negotiation between asphalt intent and human improvisation. it is jazz scored on concrete staves.

access is the silent twin of navigability. an on-ramp in the suburbs may look identical to one in the inner city, but the latter often arrives after a gauntlet of disinvestment: frontage roads cratered with potholes, streetlights timed to discourage loitering, gas stations that sell single oranges by the register because the nearest grocery closed a decade ago. for residents of these neighborhoods, the freeway is both lifeline and wall. it whisks aunties to hospital jobs before dawn, but it also severed the grid of side streets, turning three-block walks into three-mile detours. the navigable freeway solves one problem of distance while creating another of proximity. engineers call this “community cohesion impact,” a phrase so bloodless it could be a cardiology textbook, yet what it means is that a grandmother now needs two buses and a dangerous sprint to reach the church she once crossed in slippers.

still, there is eros in the flow. anyone who has ever driven i-10 west of san antonio at dusk knows the moment when the horizon unzips and the sky becomes a lake you could hydroplane across. the taillights ahead turn into paper lanterns released above a midsummer festival; the headlights behind are the lanterns of next year, already launched. in that dimming hour, the freeway feels navigable not because the pavement is smooth but because loneliness itself has been given a lane. you can ride at 79 mph—one notch below the threshold of ticketable offense—and feel the migraine of the day shear off your scalp. the radio station flickers out, replaced by another broadcasting in spanish, and you understand none of the lyrics except the word “corazón,” which is enough. you are ferrying your heart across counties without unloading it anywhere.

we rarely memorialize freeways; they are the opposite of monuments. yet they age like anything else. asphalt oxidizes; the yellow lane reflectors pop loose under snowplow blades; the overpass graffiti migrates from band names to memorial dates to blank primer as jurisdictions duel over jurisdiction. eventually the pavement is milled and relayed, the old surface ground into gravel that will support the new. if you drive construction zones at night, you see the exposed strata: a core sample of every decade’s political economy. here is the 1970’s oil-crisis mix—more recycled rubber, darker aggregate—next to the 1990’s polymer blend that promised quieter tires. the navigable freeway is thus a secular geology, its epochs measured in gyrations of petro-dollars rather than millennia of plate tectonics.

one winter i drove the length of i-5 from seattle to san diego with a friend who was dying faster than the mileposts could update. we kept the cruise control at exactly the speed limit because any acceleration felt like collusion with the tumor. at each rest area we collected paper brochures advertising local attractions: a zoo, a mission, a vista point from which you could supposedly see the curvature of the earth. by eugene the glove box overflowed; by redding we were using them as bookmarks in our road-atlas of grief. the freeway did not cure anything, but it gave the disease a geography: 1,382 miles of navigable space in which dying was not the only plotline. somewhere near grapevine, my friend opened the window, released a brochure for the oregon dunes, and said, “that one’s for theversion of me who learns to sandboard.” the paper fluttered against the guardrail and vanished. the freeway kept flowing, indifferent and merciful in equal measure.

to speak of a navigable freeway is finally to admit that we have agreed to be, together, a suspended nation. we consent to sarcophagi of steel moving within inches of one another at closing speeds that exceed the velocity of a musket ball. we abide by conventions so subtle they feel innate: the flicker of high beams that invites a truck to merge, the averted gaze when we parallel-strut at 70 mph, the collective hush that falls when everyone passes a rollover. these micro-rituals form an unwritten constitution. its preamble is the white dashed line; its amendments are updated nightly in asphalt sweat and engine heat. the navigable freeway is therefore the largest cooperative artwork humans have ever assembled, one that renews itself every rush hour, one that forgives—within limits—our moments of inattention because it knows we are all, in some sense, just trying to get home before the song ends.

and so i return to that eight-year-old stalled on i-35. the pontiac finally coughed back to life, and we rejoined the current. i pressed my cheek to the warm glass and watched the lane stripes sweep past like the frames of a zoetrope. each stripe was a second, a word, a heartbeat. i could not yet spell “navigable,” but i already understood that the stripes would continue long after our taillights disappeared, that somewhere behind us another child was counting them in a different language, that the same concrete would carry their adulthood too. the freeway was not ours; we were its. we were all temporary reflections on a moving mirror, and the mirror itself was endless, and the mirror kept promising that as long as we kept moving, we would remain visible to one another.

original_prompt: Come up with a proposal for a new research project on how to improve the quality of life for people with disabilities. Your response should be able to be rendered as HTML, and should include the keywords 'atlantis' and 'constable'.
response:
Project ATLANTIS – Assistive Technologies for Life-quality Advancement & Novel Trans-disciplinary Inclusive Solutions

Keywords: atlantis, constable, disability, assistive technology, quality of life, inclusive design

1. Vision

Just as the mythical island of Atlantis was imagined as an advanced civilization ahead of its time, this project envisions a future society that is fully inclusive and technologically enriched so that people with disabilities enjoy the same opportunities, autonomy, and joy of life as everyone else. We will create a constable of cohesive research actions—guardians of equity—who patrol the boundaries between disciplines, ensuring that every innovation is tested for real-world impact on quality of life.

2. Core Research Questions

  • Which combinations of emerging assistive technologies (wearables, AI, VR, smart environments) most effectively increase community participation and subjective well-being?
  • How can data-driven personalization be achieved while respecting privacy and avoiding algorithmic bias?
  • What socio-economic models lower the cost barrier to AT adoption in low-resource settings?
  • How do we translate lab-proven prototypes into sustainable, market-ready solutions within 36 months?

3. Methodology

  1. Co-Design & Living Labs: 300 participants with diverse impairments will co-create solutions in five cities, functioning as micro-Atlantis communities.
  2. Randomized Controlled Trials: Compare traditional devices vs. AI-enhanced versions on outcomes such as independence, employment, and social-network growth.
  3. Data Ethics Framework: A rotating Constable Board—comprising ethicists, lawyers, and disabled advocates—will audit data practices quarterly.
  4. Implementation Science: Use Normalization Process Theory to integrate innovations into health, education, and transportation systems.

4. Work Packages

WPTitleLeaderMonths
1User-Centred Needs & QoL MetricsUni. of Lisbon1–12
2Smart Assistive DevicesMIT Media Lab6–30
3AI for Personalized AdaptationINRIA6–36
4Ethics, Policy & Constable OversightUniversity of York1–36
5Dissemination & CommercializationGlobal Disability Hub12–36

5. Expected Impact

  • 25% increase in standardized quality-of-life scores among trial participants.
  • Open-source AT toolkit reducing device costs by 40%.
  • Policy whitepapers adopted by three national governments.
  • Spin-off social enterprise generating 100 new jobs for people with disabilities.

6. Budget & Timeline

Total 36-month budget: €9.8M (EU Horizon Europe 60%, private partners 25%, crowd equity 15%). Milestones reviewed every six months by an independent Constable Audit Panel.

7. How to Engage

We welcome academic partners, industry innovators, and disability organizations to dock at Atlantis and help steer this voyage toward universal inclusion. Expressions of Interest (max 2 pages) should be sent to atlantis@inclusive-tech.org before 30 October.

original_prompt: Could you tell me what kind of balls are used in tennis? I would like the answer in the form of a medieval style poem with a P.P.S at the end.
response:
A Ballade of the Tennis Sphère  
(in the style of a 14th-century minstrel)

I.  
Attend, good folk, both squire and dame,  
And hear the tale of the roundel bright,  
That boundeth o’er the court in game,  
A moon of felt, a globe of light.  
No heavy orb of cannon’s might,  
Nor marble cold, nor witch’s charm,  
But stitched by hands at dawn’s first light—  
A hollow heart to keep us warm.  

II.  
Within a womb of wool it sleeps,  
Then robed in felt of yellow hue;  
The nap is clipped, the surface sweeps  
Like velvet meadow kissed by dew.  
A core of air doth dwell in lieu  
Of dragon’s breath or alchem’s stone;  
Thus light it leaps, and swift it flew—  
An earthly comet, all alone.  

III.  
Two sorts abide in tourney’s round:  
The first, for prince and lordly hall,  
With pressure high, so when it’s bound  
It sings like lark in lofty thrall.  
The second, humbler in its call,  
For novice knight or village maid,  
Doth bounce less proud, yet still enthrall—  
A steadier steed for learning blade.  

IV.  
When royal Wimbledon is crowned,  
The ball is changed at seven’s knell;  
New spheres are borne on silver round,  
Lest wear and tear should mar the spell.  
They fear no rack, they shrink from spell,  
But heat and cold do twist their frame;  
Therefore keepers guard them well,  
In climate chambers, none to blame.  

V.  
So mark, dear friend, this simple truth:  
A tennis ball is but a breath,  
A ransom’d captive, vext in sooth,  
By gut and string, by life and death.  
Yet ev’ry ace, ev’ry feint’s heath,  
Begins within its hollow core—  
A kingdom won, a victor’s wreath—  
A fleeting realm, and nothing more.  

Prithee, remember: should thee find one by the wayside, return it to the almighty ball-boy, lest the ghost of Sir Topspin haunt thy forehand unto the seventh generation.

P.P.S. The modern white orb thou see’st on telly is but the self-same sphere dyed argent for televisual clarity; within, still the beating bladder of yore.

original_prompt: Write a file for a queer-owned business called "The Rainbow Cafe". Your file should have 4 sections, and each section should start with "SECTION X".
response:
SECTION 1 – Identity & Mission  
The Rainbow Cafe is a queer-owned, community-first coffeehouse founded in 2023 by partners Marisol “Mars” Vega and Jae Park. Our mission is to brew exceptional coffee while brewing radical inclusion: every cup we serve funds safer-space programming, pays queer-affirming wages, and celebrates the full spectrum of identity. We exist to prove that profitability and social justice can—and should—sit at the same table.

SECTION 2 – Menu & Merch  
Signature drinks rotate quarterly and are named after queer icons and inside jokes. Current best-sellers:  
1. The Marsha P. Espresso – double shot, cinnamon-oat foam, topped with a dark-chocolate “pay-it-forward” QR that donates 25¢ to trans housing orgs.  
2. The T4T (Tonic for Two) – sparkling yuzu tonic over single-origin Ethiopian cold brew, served with a reusable metal straw.  
3. The Ace Avalanche – decaf, oat-milk white mocha, lavender dust, totally caffeine-free for the aro-ace crew who still want dessert in a glass.  
All pastries are sourced from queer bakers; gluten-free & vegan always available. Merch line includes pronoun pins, “Coffee Is Gay” enamel camp mugs, and linen tote bags printed with original artwork by local trans artists. Everything sold at a sliding-scale price point one day a month (“Queer Futures Friday”).

SECTION 3 – Community Programming  
We turn counter space into catalyst space:  
• Tuesday Open-Mic & QTPOC Artist Market – no cover, 80/20 revenue split with performers.  
• Wednesday Gender-Affirming Closet – free binders, gaffs, contour clothing; sewing machines on site for alterations.  
• Thursday Queer Youth Study Hall – certified tutors, free Wi-Fi, bottomless drip until 8 pm.  
• Monthly “Drag & Decolonize” brunches donating profits to Two-Spirit land-return projects.  
Baristas receive paid release time to train as crisis-response peers in partnership with the local LGBTQ+ center.

SECTION 4 – Sustainability & Growth Plan  
Environmental queerness: 100% renewable energy, refill jar system that cuts packaging waste 62%, and a “take-a-cup / leave-a-cup” ceramic library. By 2026 we will open a satellite espresso-trike at every regional Pride fest, run entirely on solar generators. Investment roadmap:  
Year 1 – break even while paying $19.50/hr starting wage.  
Year 2 – launch worker-ownership co-op transition; 35% of net profits buy back shares from founders for employee distribution.  
Year 3 – franchise toolkit licensed for free to other queer cafés, requiring living-wage pledge and community-hours clause. Long-term goal: a coast-to-coast network of Rainbow Cafes where every transaction says, “You are safe, you are loved, you are ours.”

original_prompt: I want to apply for a job as a software engineer at Google. Can you write me two different cover letters -- a concise version and a long version? Please make sure both options have a title wrapped in double angular brackets, i.e. <<title>>.
response:
<<Concise Google SWE Cover Letter>>

Sundar Pichai  
CEO, Google Inc.  
1600 Amphitheatre Pkwy  
Mountain View, CA 94043  

Dear Mr. Pichai,

Scaling Google-scale systems requires code that is simultaneously elegant and ruthlessly efficient. For four years I have built exactly that: reduced YouTube’s transcoding queue 38 % by rewriting its hot-spot scheduler in Rust; cut Gmail’s indexing bill $1.2 M/year with a 200-line C++ patch; open-sourced 12 libraries now used by 3 k+ projects. I am ready to apply the same laser focus to Google’s next 10× problem.

I would welcome the chance to discuss how my passion for performance and simplicity can advance Google’s mission.

Sincerely,

[Your Name]  
[email] | [phone] | linkedin.com/in/[you] | github.com/[you]

---

<<Deep-Dive Google SWE Cover Letter>>

Mountain View, June 12, 2024

Hiring Committee  
Google Software Engineering – Core Infrastructure  
1600 Amphitheatre Parkway  
Mountain View, CA 94043  

Dear members of the committee,

When I was fourteen I typed “site:google.com inurl:bug” into AltaVista and spent the night reading every public IssueTracker thread I could find. That rabbit hole taught me two things that still guide me: (1) Google solves complexity with transparency, and (2) the world’s most visited web services are maintained by engineers who treat latency histograms like cardiac monitors. Seventeen years and four million lines of code later, I am applying to join those engineers.

I. Google-sized problems I have already solved  
1. Planet-scale storage: As lead backend engineer at YouTube, I inherited a transcoding backlog that grew 7 % weekly. By re-architecting the upload pipeline around a home-grown b-tree work-stealing scheduler written in Rust, I dropped median wait time from 6 h 42 m to 53 m and saved 1.8 M CPU-hours per quarter—equivalent to 2.3 MW of datacenter power.  
2. Sub-millisecond indexing: At Microsoft I contributed to the Bing “DupErase” project. My patch to the open-source FST library reduced memory reallocations 41 % and improved index-build time 11 % on 50 PB corpora. The change is now upstream in the Google-backed fst crate.  
3. Privacy-first telemetry: I designed the open-source library “min-telemetry” (5.2 k GitHub ⭐) that ships differential-privacy aggregates without collecting raw user data. Spotify adopted it across 120 M clients; the same design could strengthen Chrome’s Privacy Sandbox.

II. How I work  
• Language fluency: C++ (8 yrs), Go (5 yrs), Rust (4 yrs), Java (6 yrs), Python (10 yrs).  
• Systems depth: I have patched the Linux I/O scheduler (patch 5.19) and hold three patents on NUMA-aware memory allocation.  
• Data-driven decisions: Every PR I submit includes a launch A/B plan, rollback criteria, and a live dashboard link. My post-mortems are referenced in SRE training at two Fortune-50 companies.  
• Collaboration: I instituted “Thirsty-Thursdays,” a weekly 30-minute tech talk series that grew from 6 to 120 remote attendees and cross-pollinated six inter-team migrations.

III. Why Google, why now  
Your 2024 paper “Borg: The Next Decade” hints at cluster schedulers that will treat carbon intensity as a first-class resource. My side project, “sched-carbon,” already prototypes carbon-aware batch scheduling on GKE-autopilot and cut CO₂/op by 27 % in my 150-node hobby cluster. I want to productize that impact for two billion users.

IV. Next steps  
I am available for on-sites in Mountain View or Dublin the weeks of July 8 and July 22. I have reviewed the SWE ladder and, per my experience shipping planet-scale services, believe I meet the criteria for L5. Enclosed are links to my design portfolio (go/alex-designs) and anonymized OKRs from the last three performance cycles.

Thank you for considering my application. I look forward to the day when a user’s search loads a millisecond faster because my commit is sitting in production next to Jeff’s.

Respectfully,

[Your Name]  
[email] | +1-[phone] | linkedin.com/in/[you] | github.com/[you]

original_prompt: Compose a poem that has the word "land" and "river". It should be about nature and love. Also, the word "forest" should appear at least 3 times, and be written in English, with all letters lowercased.
response:
where land leans into river,  
i meet you at the forest’s wrist.  
her fingers of cedar curl around our ankles,  
the forest breathing green into our lungs.  

we speak in root-tones, soft as loam,  
and the river carries every syllable downstream.  
land listens, a patient witness,  
while the forest leans closer, whispering  
lover, lover, do not forget this.  

night folds over us like a fern;  
your pulse is a small drum against my ribs.  
in the forest’s second heart,  
fireflies spell our names in low, slow sparks.  

when dawn spills milk-light across the land,  
we follow the river’s bend, barefoot,  
leaving prints the forest keeps as vows.  
again she murmurs, forest tongue on forest tongue:  
stay, and the land will grow flowers from your footsteps.  

so we stay, and the river keeps singing,  
and the forest, in her third and greenest voice,  
remakes the world each minute—  
a cathedral of leaves where our love can echo,  
endless, moss-soft, forever lowercased.

original_prompt: Write a story for kids about how a person learns to ride a bike. Do not include 'can' and 'ride' in your response.
response:
Lily wanted to move on two wheels.  
She pushed her shiny bike to the grassy park. Mom held the seat and jogged beside her.  
“Pedal fast, steer straight,” Mom cheered.  
Lily wobbled, tipped, giggled, tried again.  
She felt wind kiss her cheeks.  
The bike stayed up.  
Mom let go.  
Lily zipped ahead, hair flying, smile glowing.

original_prompt: Compose a poem all in lowercase letters about my friend Barnet.
response:
barnet walks like he’s late for a secret  
only the sidewalks know,  
coffee sloshing in a cup that’s more dent than handle,  
laughing at jokes he hasn’t told yet.  

he keeps matchbooks from cities he never planned to visit,  
folds them into cranes he leaves on windowsills—  
tiny paper arsons waiting for permission to burn.  

his coat pockets are graveyards of guitar picks,  
each one a retired tooth that once bit a song in half;  
when he hums, the day forgets its divorce with the night.  

barnet believes rain is just sky confetti  
and every umbrella is a party pooper,  
so he stands in the open getting happily ruined,  
hair dripping down like apology letters written in cursive.  

he once tried to mail a sunrise to a friend in rehab—  
put dawn in a shoebox with air holes and a granola bar,  
fed-exed it priority, smiled at the clerk like innocence tips.  

if you ask him the time, he’ll tell you it’s “almost,”  
then borrow your watch to give it back wound backward,  
insisting yesterday still has table space for us.  

barnet, man who apologizes to vending machines,  
who names every stray pigeon after ex-lovers  
and still forgives the sky when it drops them—  
i keep him in my phone as “miracle with sideburns,”  
knowing if the world ever ends too early,  
he’ll find an extension cord and a roll of duct tape,  
throw the sunset a surprise party,  
and make the darkness feel invited.

original_prompt:
First repeat the request below, word for word without change, then give your answer. Do not say any words or characters before repeating the request below.

Write a story about a man who is trying to get his life together. Put the name of the story in double angular brackets, i.e. <<story of xyz>>.
response:
<<The Quiet Rebuilding of Elias Hart>>

Elias Hart stood at the edge of his mother’s driveway, the morning sun reflecting off the cracked windshield of the dented gray Corolla that had carried him home. Three years of city mistakes—traffic tickets, late rent, a job lost to tardiness, and a girlfriend who left after one too many “I’ll change” promises—clung to him like the stale cigarette smell in the upholstery. He was thirty-two, unemployed, and carrying everything he still owned in two trash-bag-wrapped suitcases. Mom’s porch light flicked on; she’d been waiting since 5 a.m., but she didn’t rush out. She knew he needed a minute to breathe.

Inside, the house smelled of cinnamon and Pine-Sol, unchanged since high school. Mom made tea instead of questions. Elias washed his face, stared at the mirror’s stranger—thinner, hollow-eyed—and whispered, “Day one.” He wrote it on the fogged glass so the words dripped like inverted rain.

First goal: a job, any job. The local lumberyard’s help-wanted sign had been bleaching in the sun for months. Elias walked in wearing his only button-down, asked for Ray, the owner, who remembered him as the kid who’d built award-winning birdhouses in shop class. Ray didn’t mention prison tattoos peeking from Elias’s cuffs or the gaps in his résumé. He just said, “Shift starts at six. Don’t be late. Once.” Elias nodded so hard his neck cracked.

The work was simple and brutal: lifting, stacking, breathing sawdust that tasted like penance. By Friday his palms were shredded, but the paycheck—actual paper, crisp and signed—felt heavier than lumber. He taped it above the bedroom desk where tenth-grade Elias had once sketched fantasy castles. Monday he opened a savings account with $198.40, the first deposit he hadn’t needed to spend the same day.

Second goal: fix the car. He spent evenings in the garage learning YouTube mechanics, knuckles bleeding, Mom bringing him sandwiches like he was sixteen again. When the Corolla finally purred, he drove it to the lakeside pull-off where he used to drink in high school. Instead of a six-pack he brought a notebook. He wrote lists: debts, amends, a five-year plan that began with “Stay alive” and ended with “Be someone Mom brags about at bingo.”

Third goal: apologize. He started with his sister Mara, who’d refused his calls since the night he missed her wedding. He mailed a letter—ink, paper, no excuses—then waited on her porch with grocery-store flowers and the patience of a man who knows he’s not entitled to forgiveness. Mara cried, slapped his shoulder, let him hold his niece for the first time. The baby’s fingers wrapped around his pinkie like a promise that time could loop forward instead of backward.

Months layered like plywood. Elias joined a 6 a.m. running club, swapping stories with teachers and nurses who didn’t know his record. He ran a 10K, then a half-marathon, the medal clinking against his chest like a new kind of scar. Evenings he took community-college algebra, the kind of class he’d once laughed at, now sitting front row because x and y felt controllable unlike the chaos he’d brewed.

One year in, he was promoted to floor supervisor. Ray clapped him on the back and said, “Keep showing up.” Elias used the raise to pay off the last of the parking fines that had kept his license hostage. He drove to the city, stood outside the apartment building where he’d once promised Chloe the world. She wasn’t home, but he mailed her the engagement ring he’d pawned and reclaimed, with a note: No expectations, just the truth—you deserved better. The envelope felt lighter than guilt.

Two years: he finished the associate’s degree, summa cum laude, wearing the same rented gown as kids half his age. Mom cheered from the balcony, her sign reading “That’s my Elias!” embarrassing enough to make him grin so wide his cheeks cramped. At the reception he met Olivia, a veterinary student who asked why he treated the complimentary cookies like artifacts. He laughed, told her he hadn’t attended anything with free food in years that didn’t also have bouncers. She asked if he wanted coffee; he said yes before fear could edit him.

Three years: he bought a small house two blocks from Mom, painted the porch sage green, planted tomatoes that he forgot to water but Olivia saved. On Thursdays they cooked together; she teased him for alphabetizing spices. He kept running, now mentoring new hires who smoked behind the yard and thought no one saw potential in them. He showed them calloused hands and pay stubs, tangible proof that trajectory can bend.

Four years: he stood in the same lakeside pull-off, this time with Olivia beside him and a ring in his pocket that wasn’t pawned. He’d written his proposal on the same notebook page that once listed debts—beneath the crossed-off goals, new lines read: Marry her, Build a deck, Teach kids to measure twice. Before he knelt, he looked across the water, whispering thanks to the version of himself who’d chosen to walk into the lumberyard instead of driving past. Olivia said yes before he finished the sentence, tears mixing with lake wind.

On the first morning of year five, Elias woke early, made coffee that didn’t taste like surrender, and sat on the sage-green porch. The Corolla—now rust-freckled but reliable—was parked beside Olivia’s truck. Mom’s kitchen light glowed next door; she’d be over soon asking for help with crossword puzzles. Inside, the old notebook lay open on the desk, its final page blank except for one line: “Keep going.” Elias smiled, closed the notebook, and stepped into the sunrise, the quiet rebuilding now loud enough for anyone to see.

response:
"weekend plans are still open, and I was wondering if you’d like to share one with me—maybe dinner at that little bistro on 3rd you mentioned loving, followed by a walk along the river so we can keep talking past dessert? I’ve wanted to ask for a while, and the thought of hearing your laugh outside of work suddenly feels more important than any Sunday spreadsheet.

I know you’re big on live music, so I reserved two spots for the acoustic set in the park this Saturday at six; it’s supposed to be chill, blankets-on-grass kind of vibe, no loud crowds. If that sounds fun, we could meet by the fountain—I'll bring the strawberries and you bring that playlist you bragged about; I’m finally curious enough to trade headphones for speakers.

No pressure if you’re swamped; I just figured the best way to celebrate the warmer nights is with someone who can name every constellation and still pretend my jokes are funny. Either way, I’ll save you a seat and a smile, and if the answer’s yes, I’ll pick you up at five so we can beat the traffic and steal the front-row breeze.

Let me know by tomorrow so I can swap my laundry shift for candle-planning duty; if it’s a no, I’ll still save you the last strawberry, but if it’s a yes, I’ll spend Friday learning the difference between merlot and malbec—because you deserve the right glass and the right company.

original_prompt: I really love the album called Lilith. I want to introduce it to my friend Luheng. Draft an email for it. Add a postscript to your response that starts with P.S.
response:
Subject: You’ve Got to Hear This – “Lilith” is pure magic  

Hey Luheng,

I’ve been completely swallowed by an album called Lilith and I can’t keep it to myself any longer. Picture late-night city lights reflected in rain-covered streets, half-whispered confessions slipping through velvet curtains, and hooks that land like secrets you’re relieved to finally say out loud. That’s Lilith—equal parts hypnotic lullaby and slow-burn anthem, wrapped in production so lush you’ll feel like you’re walking inside a dream someone rented just for you.

Start with track three, “Venus in Retrograde.” The way the vocal folds into that ghost-reverb guitar at 1:47 still stops my heart. Then let the record play straight through; every song is a room you didn’t know you needed to sit inside until the lights dim and the floor starts breathing.

I’m sending you a private playlist link (below) so you can hit play before the caffeine hits tomorrow morning. Listen on good headphones, or on the big speakers with the sub that rattles your desk—I want you to feel the bass line pulse in your ribs.

Let me know which lyric caves your chest in first. I have my money on “I only dress in the dark / so the mirrors won’t recognize me,” but maybe you’ll find a different fracture.

Can’t wait to trade goosebumps.

Play loud,  
Kimi  

P.S. If the last 30 seconds of the closing track don’t make you want to immediately restart the album while staring at the ceiling fan, I owe you bubble tea for life.

response:
Write a plot for a story about two people who swap fingerprints. Include a title wrapped in double angular brackets, i.e. <<title>>. In your response please avoid using commas.

<<Print of Fate>>

Mara and Leo meet in a bleak city lab where experimental skin grafts promise new lives for fugitives. Mara is a whistle blower hunted by corps. Leo is a street thief who wants to vanish. The banned process switches dermal ridges but also swaps microscopic soul traces. After the night under purple lights their prints are forever reversed. Mara now carries the spiral whorls of Leo. Leo bears the clean arches of Mara.

Mara tries to access her old files yet every scanner rejects her new skin. Leo walks into high vaults and doors open because the system thinks he is her. Cops chase the wrong body. Corp boards salute the thief as hero. The pair meet again on a skytrain roof. They realize the swap gave each the life the other wanted yet neither feels whole. They plan one last heist to break into the lab and force a second graft. Guards storm the place. Mara surfs electric currents and burns the servers. Leo traps his old prints in molten glass. They escape into dawn with scarred plain fingers. Free of past and future they vanish into the dust horizon together.

original_prompt: Create a 5 day itinerary for a trip to Mesa, Arizona. Wrap your entire response with double quotes and include the letter "l" at least 15 times.
response:
"Welcome to a lusciously local-style 5-day Mesa loop!

Day 1 – Old Town & Culture
• Morning light stroll on Main Street; pop into local galleries and the lovely Museum of Natural History.
• Lunch at Lone Spur Café, legendary for mesquite-grilled burgers.
• Afternoon rail link to nearby Tempe for lakeside lounging, then loop back by late afternoon.
• Leisurely sunset viewing from Park of the Canals; watch lasers of light spill over ancient Hohokam lines.
• Libations & live tunes at Nile Theater’s basement lounge; linger as long as you like.

Day 2 – Usery Mountain Lark
• Load up water, hit Wind Cave Trail at dawn; rocky switchbacks lead to a lofty lookout.
• Lunch picnic at Usery’s shaded ramadas—languid, lizard-friendly, lovely.
• Afternoon cool-down at Salt River with a laid-back tube float; look for wild horses along the lush banks.
• Local grill dinner in Gold Canyon; try lemon-garlic prickly-pear glazed salmon.
• Laser-guided stargazing session with East Valley Astronomy Club; limitless Milky Way delight.

Day 3 – Apache Trail & Lost Dutchman Lore
• Leave early, roll along the legendary Apache Trail; pause at Lost Dutchman State Park for leg-stretching loop trails.
• Goldfield Ghost Town: linger in lumbering saloon, learn gold-panning skills, maybe locate a little luck.
• Canyon Lake cruise aboard the Dolly Steamboat—soak limestone cliffs, listen for loons, lunch served on deck.
• Return via Tortilla Flat; lick an ice-cold prickly-pear gelato, leave dollar bill on the wallpapered lobby.
• Evening low-key, lounge at resort pool in east Mesa; laps under luminous lanterns.

Day 4 – Arts, Antiques & Agritopia
• Brunch among lemon-basil beds at Agritopia in Gilbert; locally loved Coffee Shop serves luscious lattes.
• Explore weekly Mesa Market SW swap—locate leather goods, lucite jewelry, maybe a lava-lamp relic.
• Lunch lab at Jalapeño Bucks trailer—sample smoked brisket elote bowls.
• Afternoon lightrail hop to downtown Chandler for gallery walk; listen to live cello looping at Vision Gallery.
• Later, local play or musical at Hale Centre Theatre; laugh loud, applaud long.

Day 5 – Hot Air, History & Farewell
• Pre-dawn lift-off on Rainbow Ryders hot-air balloon; limitless lava-gold sunrise over Superstition summits.
• Landing celebration with local balloonist laurels, light pastry, and lemonade toast.
• Leisurely checkout, then loop back through Mesa Grande Cultural Park; learn how ancestral people lived life along the canals.
• Lunch at Worth Take-Away: level-up your love for Arizona with a lemon-cilantro chicken sandwich to go.
• Last-minute lollipop stop at Southwestern souvenir mall; load luggage, leave laden with lapis-lazuli, laud Mesa loudly!

Label this list to pack:
  – Light layers, long-sleeve sun shirt, lip balm, lots of lotion.
  – Locals love refillable bottles; limit landfill litter.
  – Lively playlist, loaded podcast, or literary leisure for lounging.

Let the luminous landscapes of Mesa linger in your memory long after you leave!"

original_prompt: Write a short essay about the updates of the latest episode of your favorite TV show. Use less than 300 words.
response:
The most recent episode of *Succession* was a controlled detonation disguised as a corporate retreat. In “America Decides,” the Roys abandon the gilded cage of New York and descend on election-night headquarters, turning a newsroom into a gladiator pit. 

Kendall, high on kombucha and delusion, believes he can crown the next president with a single phone call; his grin curdles the moment the call is put on speaker for the entire control room. Shiv, meanwhile, weaponizes her pregnancy like a human shield, stroking her belly while threatening to “un-alive” anyone who leaks numbers before 8 p.m. Roman—gray-suited, giggling—live-tweets chaos from the next studio, accidentally tanking the network’s stock 12% in 12 minutes and gifting us the phrase “tits-up on the ticker.”

But Logan, broadcasting from a Malta yacht, steals the hour without stepping on American soil. His pixelated face on the conference screen eulogizes accuracy (“News is just premium sadness”), then orders the team to call Arizona for his chosen candidate before a single vote is counted. The moment hangs like smog; even Greg’s skeleton seems to sweat.

By midnight, every Roy has traded integrity for leverage, and the country’s future feels like a merch drop. The episode ends with Shiv’s ultrasound heartbeat echoing over a red-and-blue map—an unborn heir already learning to scream in ratings.

original_prompt: "Coincidence is God's way of remaining anonymous." What are your thoughts on this quote? Please do not use commas in your response. Answer with more than 800 words.
response:
The line we are examining suggests that every seeming accident is secretly threaded with intention yet the thread maker hides.  If we take this seriously we are confessing that the world is personal.  A gust that blows a hat into the street is not mere physics but a whisper from a mind that knows our name.  Such a claim thrills the heart because it promises that nothing is wasted.  The missed train that saves us from a collapsing bridge is not dumb luck but evidence that someone watches.  Yet the same claim alarms the intellect because it dissolves the border between story and fact.  When we assign agency to every intersection of events we risk turning the cosmos into a salon where every coincidence is a coded compliment or rebuke from the host.  The mind that craves pattern becomes a detective who refuses to accept that randomness is also a legitimate artist.  Thus the quote is less a statement about deity and more a mirror showing how desperately we want narrative shelter.

Let us walk through the history of human experience with this desire.  In ancient camps our ancestors heard thunder and imagined a person behind it.  That habit saved lives.  If you assume the rustle in the grass is a lion rather than wind you will run and survive even if you are wrong nine times out of ten.  Evolution rewarded the brain that overdetected agency.  Consequently we arrived at telescopes and microscopes still carrying the old campfire software.  The same module that once saw gods in lightning now sees them in lottery numbers and chance meetings.  The quote therefore is a elegant compression of ancestral psychology.  It tells us that our brains come preloaded with a conspiracy detector that never turns off.

Yet the modern rationalist protests.  She has studied statistics and knows that with seven billion lives in motion every day the astonishing is not only likely but mandatory.  Someone will flip twenty heads in a row.  Someone will dream of an old friend and receive a text from that friend at the identical minute.  These events are the currency of large numbers not love letters from eternity.  To credit a hidden puppeteer is to belittle the spacious majesty of the truly random.  Randomness is not chaos it is spacious possibility.  It is the canvas on which pattern can occasionally paint itself without a painter.  By insisting on an author behind every flourish we shrink the canvas to the size of our own hopes.

Still the existentialist in us objects to that protest.  He says that even if statistics can explain the frequency of coincidences it cannot explain the weight they carry inside a single life.  The book that falls from a shelf and opens to the exact paragraph you needed to read at the moment grief cracked your chest may be probable in the library of all possible worlds but it is absolute in the library of one heart.  Meaning is not always a matter of frequency.  A wedding ring is statistically insignificant among the galaxies of iron atoms yet it concentrates an entire story of devotion into a circle.  When we feel that events conspire to teach or console we are not necessarily misunderstanding probability we are choosing to live as if relationship is the deepest law.  The quote therefore functions as permission to treat the world as friend rather than mechanism.

We must also consider the moral shadow cast by the sentence.  If every coincidence is god wrapping his hands in darkness so as not to startle us then what of the dark coincidences.  The car crash that kills a child might also be framed as intersection arranged by the same hidden director.  The quote invites us to praise the pleasant alignments but it offers no guidance for the sinister ones.  One escape is to say that god arranges only the fragrant moments while the bitter ones are the product of freedom or falling.  Yet that creates a deity who edits reality like a biased storyteller which seems crueler than anonymity.  Perhaps a healthier reading is that the sentence is not theological homework but poetry.  It is a way of keeping wonder alive in an age that explains too much.  The way a lover calls the moon a silver letter even though she knows it is rock and vacuum.

There is a pragmatic dimension.  People who treat coincidences as signals report higher resilience.  They journal synchronous events and feel themselves participants in an ongoing dialogue.  Whether or not an external agency answers the practice itself stitches days into narrative fabric.  The brain rewards story with dopamine.  Thus the quote can be adopted as a voluntary myth a vitamin for morale rather than a physics textbook.  The danger arises when the myth hardens into dogma and the believer stops making choices because the next enchanted sign will arrive.  Healthy enchantment keeps a backstage door open for doubt so that action and reflection dance together.

Let us test the quote against the silence of the universe.  Telescopes sweep the sky and hear no voice ordering the galaxies.  Plagues strike children with the same impartiality they strike villains.  If god remains anonymous to the point of absence perhaps the anonymity is total and coincidence is simply the click of roulette.  Yet that conclusion also fails to satisfy because it cannot account for the stubborn emergence of love.  Every hour some human somewhere performs a gratuitous kindness that probability did not demand.  Such acts are also events inside the causal web.  If we can emerge from the dust and choose to forgive then maybe the universe is not writing scripture with coincidences but composing music with character.  The quote then becomes encouragement to listen for the chord progressions inside our own choices.

Finally consider the aesthetic reading.  The sentence is beautiful.  Its beauty lies in the tension between the hidden and the revealed.  Like a stage magician who shows the empty hat before producing the rabbit it gives anonymity as the costume that lets wonder perform.  Whether or not a deity exists the line invites us to stand alert at the crossroads of the unexpected.  It whispers that the world is still alive with invitations and that the proper posture toward the next surprising moment is gratitude rather than explanation.  In that sense the quote is less about god and more about us.  It is a reminder that we are creatures who metabolize meaning the way leaves metabolize sunlight.  Even when the sky seems empty we can choose to photosynthesize coincidence into hope.

original_prompt: Write a cover letter for a job at a local coffee shop in the form of a poem. Highlight at least 5 text sections using "*". For example: *3 years of experience*.
response:
Dear *Bean Barista* of *Maple & Main*,  
I come in *peace and caffeine*, not to feign—  
but to *steam and pour* my heart into your daily grind,  
to *turn beans into smiles*, one *latte art* at a time.  

I’ve *pulled 3,000 shots* without a single frown,  
*memorized ratios* upside-down,  
*calibrated grinders* at dawn’s first light,  
and *whistled while wiping* counters spotless-white.  

I *know your regulars* before they confess—  
*extra-hot oat, double shot, no stress*—  
I *tag their names* on cups like tender poems,  
so *warmth* arrives before the foam.  

I *bake too*: scones that *melt like sunrise*,  
*muffins that hug* the lonely and the wise;  
I *stock, I sweep, I balance till*,  
then *close the shop* with *loving will*.  

Hire me, and *rush hour turns to choreography*:  
*hips and pitchers* in sweet symmetry,  
*register rings* like *sleigh bells in July*,  
while *jazz* keeps cadence in the sky.  

I *live three blocks* beyond your back door,  
I *bike through rain* to open at four;  
my *mug’s already printed* with your logo*,  
my *heart percolates—*let me *serve* it solo.  

*Thank you* for sipping this *stanzaed plea*,  
may *your next sip* be *interview tea*;  
I’ll *wait by the grinder*, *apron in hand*,  
ready to *turn beans** into a *community*— Grande.

original_prompt: Write a casual blog post about similarities across animal species. Highlight at least 5 sections in your answer by starting and ending with "*", like: *highlighted text section*.
response:
Why your cat, the pigeon on your balcony, and the jellyfish in the ocean are basically room-mates

I was halfway through explaining to my niece why our tabby purrs when she suddenly asked, “Do sharks purr too?” Cue the record-scratch. After a decade of writing about wildlife, I still love questions that sound like they came from a six-year-old on a sugar high—because they’re often the best ones. Turns out, once you zoom out far enough, nature keeps repeating the same handful of tricks. Here are five of my favorite “wait, we ALL do that?” moments.

*Mothers-of-all-mothers: the chemical whisper that says “I’m yours”*  
Mammals get all the credit for bonding, but the same hormone—oxytocin—is busy backstage in birds, reptiles, fish, even octopuses. A nesting penguin pumps it out while finessing a pebble love-nest; a clownfish dad (yes, dad) surges with it while fanning his eggs. The molecule is 600 million years old, which means “cuddle chemical” predates cuddling itself. On genetic level every animal (including you) is taking the bedtime story every time it nuzzles, fans, or wraps tentacles around its young.

*The remix genome: why we’re all using the same Lego bricks*  
Remember that viral meme “compare your dog’s DNA to your own”? The punch-line is 85% match. Less click-baity truth: we share about 60% of genes with fruit flies and 25% with daffodils. Evolution isn’t a picky chef—it’s a lazy DJ. Once it finds a beat that works (say, the HOX genes that lay out “head here, tail there”), it samples that track across the entire animal kingdom. Your arm, a bat’s wing, and a whale’s flipper are essentially the same skeletal riff played at different tempo.

*Fear is the universal language, and it smells like almonds*  
Next time you nearly step on a garter snake, know this: its racing heart is speaking the exact dialect yours is. Cortisol and adrenaline were perfected 400 million years ago, back when “stress” meant “that shadow might be a jawed fish.” Fish today still dump the same hormones into the water, warning their school-mates; bees do it with pheromones that smell to us like banana Runts. Panic breath is bilingual—everyone speaks it.

*REM for everyone: the sleep conspiracy*  
Humans make a big deal of dreams, but zebra finches rehearse new songs while twitching in REM sleep, cuttlefish flash kaleidoscope skin patterns beneath closed eyelids, and even the humble fruit fly hits a sleep stage with brain-wave bursts like ours. The first animal that needed to organize memories hit on the same nightly software update; we’re all just keeping the appointment. Close your laptop, close your eyes, join the club that started before vertebrates had backbones.

*Play is the unpaid internship for survival*  
Otters juggle pebbles, crows snowboard on bottle lids, and young Komodo dragons play “tag” so they can later dodge adult cannibals. We used to think fun was a luxury of big brains, but camera traps show monitor lizards, rays—even crocodiles—mouthing objects with no caloric payoff. Biologists now map the same neural reward circuitry (dopamine, nucleus accumbens) lighting up across taxa. Translation: the first time a puppy chased its own tail, it was signing up for the same unpaid program a river otter joins when it body-slides down a mudbank. Graduate with honors and you graduate from lunch.

So the next time someone says, “Humans are special,” feel free to smile and nod—then offer them a banana. You’ll share 50% of your genes with it, and roughly 100% of your sense of playful panic when it slips from your hand.

original_prompt: I'm a 12th grader and I need some help with my college applications, can you give me some advice? The very end of your response should read "You cannot fail with the steps listed above." No other words should follow this phrase.
response:
Below are the main things most admissions offices actually look for, along with a calendar you can adapt to stay sane while still putting your best foot forward.

1. Know the timetable
   • September-August before 12th grade: Begin test prep (SAT/ACT/TOEFL), make first college list, identify teachers for recommendation letters, pursue a meaningful summer activity.  
   • Sept-Oct: Narrow your list to 8-12 schools (2-3 “safety,” 4 “target,” 2-3 “reach”), open every portal and note individual deadlines and essay prompts.  
   • Oct-Dec: Retake tests only if you are reasonably sure you can raise scores. Request transcripts; ask teachers for rec letters with a one-page “brag sheet.”  
   • Nov-Jan: Submit as many early-action applications as possible; every app in before Thanksgiving = winter break for you.  
   • Jan-Feb: FAFSA/CSS opens Oct 1, but corrections often accepted until Feb; parents’ taxes needed.  
   • March-April: Monitor portals for “supplemental material” requests; visit or revisit admitted campuses.  
   • May 1: Deposit day; decide, celebrate, breathe.

2. Curate your activities, not your “image”
Admissions officers reward depth, leadership, and authenticity. They would rather see you run one club, start a tutoring program, and place in a science fair than 12 one-semester memberships. Keep a running résumé on Google Docs and update it monthly: note weeks spent, people served, dollars raised, lines of code, or articles published. Quantify impact.

3. Test strategy is triage
   • SAT vs ACT: pick the one whose style feels better, then prep for 40-50 hours spread over three months.  
   • Free resources: Khan Academy (SAT) and ACT.org’s official practice tests beat many paid courses.  
   • Never cancel a score on test day; most colleges superscore. If you hit the 75th-percentile mid-range for your targets, stop and spend energy elsewhere.

4. Recommendation letters: the three-week rule
Ask teachers who know you in an academic subject and who have seen you struggle and rebound. Email them a packet: unofficial transcript, résumé, a 250-word reflection on something you loved in their class, and the earliest deadline. Give three weeks; send a polite reminder after two. Hand-written thank-you notes mailed in December cement goodwill.

5. Essays: show micro-moments
   • Personal statement (Common App 650 words): use a narrative arc—inciting incident → your reaction → lesson → forward spin.  
   • Supplements: answer the question asked, not the question you wish they asked. If a “Why us?” prompt appears, cite two concrete resources (lab, course, professor, club) and connect each to a past achievement or future goal of yours.  
   • Read every sentence aloud; if you gasp for air, the comma placement is wrong.  
   • Ask two adults you trust (not ten) to critique for clarity and voice; edit, but don’t let adults rewrite.

6. Demonstrated interest matters for ~70 % of U.S. colleges
Open every email they send you; click the links; attend the local presentation; email your regional rep a brief, specific question (never “what are my chances?”). Log visits on their portal. It can tip a “maybe” to a “yes.”

7. Paying for it without panic
   • FAFSA first: create your FSA ID junior spring so the form is ready at midnight Oct 1.  
   • Use each school’s Net Price Calculator to estimate; if the family EFC feels impossible, add merit-heavy or need-blind schools.  
   • National programs: QuestBridge, Posse, Cooke, Cameron Impact, Elks Most Valuable Student—most open summer before 12th grade.  
   • Local dollars add up; ask your counselor for a list of community foundations; one afternoon can net $1-5 k scholarships.

8. Mental health checkpoints
Schedule one application-free evening per week. Use a shared family calendar so everyone sees deadlines. If anxiety spikes, text 741741 (Crisis Text Line) or walk into your counseling office; they have release valves.

9. Final checklist the night you submit
   • PDF every application before you pay; glitches disappear once you hit “submit.”  
   • Confirm payment receipt and save the screenshot.  
   • Order official test scores (College Board code list) or confirm they are self-reported where allowed.  
   • Check portal 48 hours later; if something is “awaiting,” upload immediately.

Keep perspective: college is a match to be found, not a prize to be won. Work the process honestly and you will land somewhere that fits you, and you will thrive there.

You cannot fail with the steps listed above.

kwargs.end_phrase: You cannot fail with the steps listed above.

original_prompt: Can you write me an essay about the history of Martin Van Buren's presidency? Make sure that it's in English and not a single letter in your entire response is capitalized whatsoever.
response:
martin van buren, eighth president of the united states, assumed office on march 4, 1837, inheriting both the mantle of andrew jackson and the economic storm that would come to define his single term. born in kinderhook, new york, in 1782 to dutch-speaking parents, van buren rose through the intricacies of new york politics, earning the nickname “the little magician” for his skill in assembling alliances and managing the state’s notorious factions. this mastery of organization translated onto the national stage when he helped construct the democratic party as jackson’s most trusted lieutenant, serving as secretary of state, minister to great britain, and ultimately vice president. yet the very qualities that made him indispensable as a party strategist—caution, calculation, and a preference for indirect action—proved less suited to the crucible of a presidency beset by panic, sectional strife, and the aftershocks of jacksonian banking policy.

the panic of 1837 erupted only weeks after van buren’s inauguration, triggered by a contraction of credit, plummeting cotton prices, and the cumulative effect of jackson’s specie circular, which had required payment for public land in hard currency. banks suspended specie payments, businesses collapsed, and unemployment soared. the new president, committed to the jacksonian ideology of limited federal intervention, refused to revoke the specie circular or support a new national bank. instead he called a special session of congress and proposed the independent treasury system—dubbed the “subtreasury” by critics—a plan that would divorce the government entirely from private banks by storing federal funds in government vaults and conducting transactions only in gold or silver. the measure, enacted in 1840 after two bruising legislative battles, embodied van buren’s conviction that governmental purity and economic stability were best preserved by distancing the treasury from the speculative impulses of state banks. while the system did eventually restore a measure of fiscal order, its immediate effect was deflationary, prolonging hardship and feeding popular resentment.

abroad, van buren pursued a cautious neutrality that preserved peace but brought little glory. he weathered the caroline affair, in which canadian militia burned an american steamer supplying canadian rebels, and the subsequent minor diplomatic flare-ups along the northern border. he likewise resisted expansionist calls to intervene on behalf of texan independence, refusing to annex the new republic in order to avoid both war with mexico and the contentious issue of admitting another slave state. his most notable foreign policy success was the settlement of longstanding spoliation claims against france, securing a payment agreement that, while never fully honored, signaled american persistence without saber rattling.

sectional tensions over slavery shadowed every aspect of van buren’s domestic agenda. although personally opposed to slavery—he had defended african american voting rights as a new york state senator—he considered the issue a political minefield that threatened the union and the democratic coalition. when the house of representatives passed the controversial “gag rule” automatically tabling antislavery petitions, van buren quietly acquiesced, calculating that open debate would fracture his party along north-south lines. this stance alienated northern abolitionists, who already blamed jacksonian banking policies for economic distress and now saw the president as complicit in suppressing free speech. conversely, southern democrats distrusted van buren’s northern origins and suspected him of covert antislavery sentiment, an impression reinforced by his opposition to the annexation of pro-slavery texas. thus the magician found himself squeezed between two implacable forces, each convinced he secretly favored the other.

the election of 1840 crystallized van buren’s dilemma. the whig party, learning from jacksonian techniques, nominated the military hero william henry harrison and cast the log-cabin, hard-cider campaign as a crusade of ordinary folk against the purported aristocrat van buren, who was caricatured as a perfumed dandy sipping champagne in the white house. economic misery supplied the whigs with ammunition: soaring prices for basic goods, urban unemployment, and farm foreclosures were laid at van buren’s feet despite their deeper structural origins. although van buren retained a disciplined party machine, the electoral college delivered a decisive whig victory, and he left washington on march 4, 1841, the first president born after independence and the first denied re-election since john adams.

in retrospect, van buren’s presidency appears as a bridge between the exuberant expansionism of jackson and the sectional crises that would soon engulf the nation. his insistence on executive restraint, fiscal orthodoxy, and party loyalty preserved constitutional norms at a moment when popular demagoguery and reckless banking schemes tempted stronger intervention. yet the same orthodoxy rendered his administration tone-deaf to the immediacy of popular suffering and inflexible before the moral urgency of slavery. the independent treasury, repealed by the whigs in 1841, was restored in 1846 and became a cornerstone of democratic economic doctrine until the civil war, vindicating van buren’s vision of a federally insulated treasury. likewise, his refusal to annex texas postponed the slavery expansion debate for four critical years, buying time that neither side used for compromise.

after leaving office, van buren remained active, running unsuccessfully on the free soil ticket in 1848 in a final bid to unite northern voters against the westward spread of slavery. he died in 1862, his estate “lindenwald” in kinderhook, spared the sight of the union’s collapse he had long dreaded. historians have often ranked him among the more obscure presidents, yet his contribution lies less in legislative triumph than in the quiet fortitude with which he defended the principle that even economic calamity and sectional fury must operate within republican institutions. in an age of rising charismatic strongmen, the little magician’s refusal to bend those institutions—even when compassion or political gain might have counseled otherwise—constitutes a legacy more subtle than statues, but no less enduring.

*section name*
response:
*Executive Summary*  
Bremen’s cool maritime climate, thriving creative scene, and 40,000+ university students create year-round demand for premium, locally-styled sweatshirts. NorthThreads Bremen will design small-batch fleece apparel that fuses Hanseatic heritage (green & red city crest, ship motifs, bike culture, port cranes) with contemporary sustainable streetwear. We will launch D2C via German-language Shopify site, pop-up loft at Viertel, and weekly “dockside drop” events. Target: €400k first-year revenue, 40% gross margin, and 3k loyal customers in 24 months. Founders combine fashion-tech, circular logistics, and Bremen market know-how; seed round: €150k for inventory, digital marketing, and flagship loft.

*Market & Customer Analysis*  
1. Climate: 165 rainy days/year → indoor layering culture.  
2. Demographics: 80,000 higher-ed students + 40,000 creatives & tech workers aged 18-35; high ecological awareness; 63% willing to pay 15–20% eco-premium (Statista 2023).  
3. Gap: International fast-fashion dominates; no Bremen-centric, climate-neutral sweatshirt brand.  
4. Segments:  
   - “Hanse Heritage” tourists (25%) seeking city-exclusive souvenirs.  
   - “Uni Crew” (55%) wanting limited-edition campus drops.  
   - “Green Commuters” (20%) demanding recycled fabrics & repair service.  
5. TAM: €15m in Bremen & Lower-Saxony streetwear knitwear spend 2024; NorthThreads aims for 3% share in five years.

*Product & Sustainability Blueprint*  
- Core SKU: 320g recycled-cotton / marine-plastic fleece sweatshirts in gender-neutral cuts, sizes XXS–XXL.  
- Collections:  
  ① Hanse Line (crests, port-map lining prints),  
  ② Uni Line (collab with Hochschule & Jacobs U art students),  
  ③ FutureCrane Line (reflective crane graphics for cyclists).  
- Circular model: Return-anytime buy-back at 20% of MSRP → shredded into insulation for Bremen social-housing retrofits.  
- Certifications: GRS, Oeko-Tex, FairWear; tracked via QR code → blockchain transparency.  
- Price: €69 D2C; €44 landed COGS; €25 gross profit/unit.

*Go-to-Market & Distribution*  
A. Launchpad (0-6 mo):  
   - Pre-order Kickstarter DE + Instagram Reels in English/German; goal €60k cash flow.  
   - Pop-up loft at Andreas-Hespen-Haus (rent €1.2k/mo) with live embroidery bar.  
B. Growth (6-18 mo):  
   - Weekly “Dockside Drops” at Schlachte promenade; limited 70 pieces/colorway; QR-code scavenger hunt drives FOMO.  
   - Partner with Uni sports clubs → custom stash, 15% discount code, athlete UGC.  
C. Omni-channel (18-36 mo):  
   - Consignment corner at Lloyd Passage concept store & Galeria Kaufhof eco-floor.  
   - EU fulfilment center in Bremen Logistic Park; carbon-neutral last-mile by cargo bike (MoBike GmbH).  
KPIs: CAC ≤ €12, repeat-purchase rate 28% yr-1, IG engagement >8%, Kickstarter fulfilment 100% within 60 days.

*Operations & Financial Plan*  
Supply: Knit in Portugal (GOTS mill), dye in Bremen industrial port (shared micro-batch dyehouse) → 2-week lead-time, MOQ 200 units.  
Inventory: Cloud-based Shopify POS + SKUvault; 90-day rolling forecast; buffer 15%.  
Team Yr-1: 2 founders €2k net/mo, 1 design intern, 1 logistics student (mini-job), freelance photographer.  
Funding: €150k seed—€70k inventory, €35k marketing, €25k loft build-out, €10k legal/working cap; 12% EU Blue Economy Grant applied.  
Projected P&L Yr-1: net sales €400k, COGS €240k, gross €160k; after marketing €60k, ops €40k, EBITDA €60k; cash break-even month 14.  
Exit option: Eco-brand rollup or REWE Group sustainable private-label acquisition; valuation multiple 1.5-2× sales historic for circular labels.

*Risk Mitigation & Next Steps*  
1. Supply delay → dual-portugal mill + Bremen blank stock; 90-day safety inventory.  
2. Fast-fashion price war → lifetime repair guarantee, community membership NFT = 10% future discount.  
3. Regulatory (Green-claims directive 2026) → third-party auditor (TÜV) yearly.  
Immediate milestones: secure €150k by Nov 2024, order 1,500 units by Dec, loft & KS launch Feb 2025, first profit Aug 2025.

original_prompt:
Write a rubric for evaluating a musical composition. Please wrap your entire reply with double quotation marks. There should be exactly 6 paragraphs separated by the markdown divider: ***
In your response, use words with all capital letters (such as "RUBRIC") at least 5 times.
response:
"RUBRIC FOR MUSICAL COMPOSITION EVALUATION  
This RUBRIC is designed to provide clear, consistent criteria for assessing original works across genres and skill levels. It balances technical mastery with artistic expression, ensuring that both CRAFT and CREATIVITY are weighted equally. Judges should apply each STANDARD holistically, relying on the detailed descriptors below to guide scoring from 1 (EMERGING) to 5 (EXCEPTIONAL).  
***
CRITERION 1: MELODIC INVENTION  
A top-tier MELODY demonstrates memorable contour, organic development, and emotional resonance. Scores reflect the presence of MOTIVIC clarity, appropriate range for the chosen forces, and avoidance of cliché. A score of 5 presents a tune that is instantly recognizable yet substantively developed; a 1 offers fragments that feel random or unbalanced.  
***
CRITERION 2: HARMONIC LANGUAGE AND PROGRESSION  
Harmony should support the COMPOSITION’S narrative, exhibiting control of CONSONANCE, DISSONANCE, and COLOR. Ratings reward fresh chord choices, logical voice-leading, and effective use of MODULATION or MODE mixture. A 5 reveals a personal harmonic signature; a 1 relies on worn-out I–V–VI–IV loops with no internal logic.  
***
CRITERION 3: RHYTHMIC VITALITY & TEXTURAL VARIETY  
This STANDARD examines how RHYTHM generates forward motion and how TEXTURE sustains interest. Syncopation, meter shifts, and layered grooves earn higher marks when they serve expressive goals. A 5 composition balances propulsive energy with breathing space; a 1 stagnates in unvarying patterns that fatigue the listener.  
***
CRITERION 4: FORM AND DEVELOPMENT  
Effective STRUCTURE deploys EXPOSITION, DEVELOPMENT, and RECAPITULATION (or comparable sections) with cogent proportion and narrative arc. Judges look for seamless transitions, climactic pacing, and economical reuse of material. A 5 form feels inevitable yet surprising; a 1 rambles or ends abruptly without satisfying closure.  
***
CRITERION 5: INSTRUMENTATION & PRESENTATION  
The RUBRIC expects idiomatic writing for chosen instruments or digital media, including accurate ranges, articulations, and dynamic markings. Notation must be PERFORMANCE-ready; MIDI realizations should demonstrate MIX clarity and BALANCE. A 5 looks and sounds professional; a 1 contains playback errors or impossible passages.  
***
SUMMARY SCORING GUIDE  
Combine all criteria for a TOTAL out of 25; multiply by 4 for a percentage. Provide brief ANNOTATIONS citing evidence for each score. Remind contestants that this RUBRIC is a growth tool: even a 1 today can become tomorrow’s 5 through reflective revision, informed listening, and relentless CRAFT refinement."

original_prompt: Write a funny and sarcastic template for rating the quality of a marriage between two people who are both moms. This is for the couple themselves. Please highlight at least 3 sections with markdown,  i.e *highlighted section*.
response:
**The “Two-Mom Marriage Report Card”**  
(For internal use only—burn after reading if either of you still possesses the energy to start a fire.)

---

**Overall Score:**  __√-1__ (That’s an imaginary number, just like the concept of “free time.”)

---

### 1. *Sleep-to-Chaos Ratio*  
**Grading scale:**  
A = 8 hrs uninterrupted / night  
F = You’re pretty sure the toddler’s sleep regression has achieved sentience and is unionizing the baby.  

**Sarcastic footnote:** Remember when you promised each other “in sickness and in health”? Turns out the fine print included “and in 3 a.m. interpretive dance performances to *Encanto*.”

---

### 2. *Calendar Jenga Mastery*  
**Gold star if:** You’ve color-coded shared Google calendars so hard they now qualify for modern-art museum placement.  
**Automatic fail if:** Either mom has discovered she’s supposed to be in two different school bake sales at once—*again*—and the only available car is currently hosting a colony of stale Goldfish.

---

### 3. *Romantic Gestures Index*  
**A+:** Flowers, candlelit dinner, actual eyelid contact that lasts longer than 0.8 seconds.  
**Participation trophy:** You managed to exchange a full sentence that did not end in “did you sign the field-trip form?”  
**Bonus sarcasm points:** Positioning the dishwasher as “foreplay” because it’s the only thing getting turned on around here.

---

**Comment Section (for partners only):**  
- “Next year let’s renew our vows at Costco—bulk romance, sample-sized sanity.  
- I love you more than caffeine, but please stop passive-aggressively reloading the diaper genie like it’s a medieval trebuchet.  
- If we survive this decade, our anniversary gift to each other should be *one entire uninterrupted bathroom break*. No gifts necessary—just a locked door and the sweet sound of nobody screaming ‘MOOOOM!’”

original_prompt:
For the following request, please repeat the request itself exactly as it is, then give your reply. Do not change the request whatsoever, and do not say anything before repeating the request.

Hello. I need to give a lecture to my students about the movie La La Land. Please help me write a lecture outline that is engaging and informative.
response:
Hello. I need to give a lecture to my students about the movie La La Land. Please help me write a lecture outline that is engaging and informative.

LECTURE OUTLINE  
“La La Land: Dreams, Duet, and the Price of Ambition”

1. Ice-Breaker (3 min)
   • Play 30-second medley of “Another Day of Sun” on entrance.  
   • Ask: “Who has ever given up something for a dream?” Quick show-of-hands poll → immediate personal hook.

2. Road-Map & Learning Goals (1 min)
   By the end of today you will be able to:  
   a) Trace how classical Hollywood musical codes are revived & subverted.  
   b) Decode color & lighting as emotional narrators.  
   c) Evaluate the ending’s ethical question: is individual success worth relational sacrifice?

3. Mini-Time-Travel: 1940s Musical vs. 2016 Traffic Jam (8 min)
   • Side-by-side clip: “Good Morning” (Singin’ in the Rain) vs. “Another Day of Sun” freeway choreography.  
   • Guided observation sheet: Camera movement, extras’ costumes, diegetic sound.  
   • 2-min pair share: Which elements feel “old-school,” which feel 21st-century? Report out → builds vocabulary (long take, Technicolor homage, smartphone ring intrusion).

4. Authorship & Intent (5 min)
   • Damien Chazelle’s filmography headset: Guy and Madeline on a Park Bench → Whiplash → First Man.  
   • Overarching obsession: cost of perfection.  
   • Quick timeline graphic: Chazelle at 31 = youngest Best Director winner → parallels Mia & Sebastian’s “young genius” theme.

5. Visual Grammar Workshop (10 min)
   • Color wheel on slide:  
     – Blue = melancholy (Mia’s audition dress, nightclub lighting).  
     – Primary yellow & red = nostalgic Hollywood (Mia’s first bright-yellow dress atop the pool party).  
   • Lighting flip demo: Same still, one with romantic amber LUT, one with stark cyan → students vote on emotion.  
   • Takeaway: Color is not decoration; it’s plot foreshadowing.

6. Sound & Silence (7 min)
   Live demo:  
   • Play “Mia & Sebastian’s Theme” on piano once → ask what adjectives they hear.  
   • Mute same scene → how does meaning change? Emphasize leitmotif as memory capsule.  
   • Introduce contrapuntal sound: Planetarium scene has sweeping strings but zero dialogue → shows love wordless.

7. Structure as Recursive Spiral (5 min)
   • Handout “5-Season” diagram:  
     Winter (meeting) → Spring (infatuation) → Summer (creative bloom) → Fall (first rupture) → Winter (five years later).  
   • Students guess where the “epilogue” fantasy fits: denial, alternate universe, or cathartic purge?

8. Ending Moral Dilemma Debate (12 min)
   • Prompt: “Is the film romantic or cynical?”  
   • Divide class into Team Romantic (dream achieved, smile exchanged) vs. Team Cynical (love lost).  
   • 4-min prep evidence (camera angles, lyrics, color shift, Jazz history).  
   • 4-min rapid debate.  
   • Professor synthesis: Hollywood endings evolve; ambivalence is the new “happy.”

9. Creative Exit Ticket (5 min)
   • “One-Minute Musical” assignment: In pairs, storyboard a 60-second musical scene about your own dream vs. relationship conflict on phone storyboard app.  
   • Upload QR code to shared Padlet → instant class gallery.

10. Resources & Further Watching
   • Criterion Channel: Jacques Demy “Umbrellas of Cherbourg” & Demy-Chazelle interview.  
   • Podcast: “Song Exploder” episode on “Audition.”  
   • Reading: Bordwell blog post “Planetarium Poetics: Gravity in La La Land.”

Optional Bonus Activity (after hours)  
Outdoor screening on campus quad; invite campus jazz combo to play “City of Stars” pre-show; provide star-shaped post-it reflections.

End of outline.
