original_prompt: Write an academic proposal to a customer who's interested in implementing a new feature for their product. Put double quotes around your entire response.
response:
"Title: Academic Feasibility & Impact Report—Proposed Implementation of Adaptive On-Device Personalization Module for the [Client Product] Ecosystem

Executive Summary
This proposal presents a rigorous, evidence-based roadmap for integrating an Adaptive On-Device Personalization (AODP) feature into your flagship product. Leveraging state-of-the-art federated learning, edge-based neural architecture search, and differential privacy, the AODP module is projected to increase user-session retention by 18–24 % while remaining fully compliant with GDPR, CCPA, and ISO/IEC 27701. The projected development cycle is 7.5 months with a ±10 % variance; total expenditure is estimated at USD 1.42 M, yielding an expected 3-year ROI of 4.6×.

1. Problem Statement & Gap Analysis
Literature Review: A systematic meta-analysis (n = 127 peer-reviewed studies, 2019-2023) reveals that conventional cloud-dependent personalization pipelines incur 120–380 ms additional latency and elevate data-exfiltration risk by 2.7× relative to on-device counterparts (Chen et al., 2023; Rastogi & Nath, 2022). Your current product relies on server-side model inference, creating a latency–privacy–compliance trilemma.

Gap: No turnkey solution exists that simultaneously (i) constrains model size ≤ 14 MB, (ii) attains ≤ 45 ms on-device inference latency on ARM-A55 cores, and (iii) guarantees ε ≤ 1.0 differential privacy per user interaction. AODP closes this gap.

2. Research Objectives (OKR Framework)
O1. Develop a 8–14 MB Transformer-Distil architecture that achieves ≥ 92 % of the baseline cloud model’s top-1 accuracy (measured on Product-XYZ dataset v4.2).  
KR1.1 ≤ 45 ms median inference on Pixel-6a reference device.  
KR1.2 ≥ 96 % client-side convergence within 5 federated rounds.  

O2. Certify end-to-end privacy budget ε ≤ 1.0 over 10k interactions/user/year.  
KR2.1 Pass third-party penetration test (NIST 800-53 High).  

O3. Increase 30-day user retention by ≥ 18 % (A/B; n = 250k).  

3. Theoretical Foundations & Novel Contribution
3.1 Federated Split-Learning with Adaptive Compression (FSL-AC). We extend Zhao & Song (2021) by introducing a gating mechanism that dynamically prunes 30–60 % of activations at run-time without retraining.  
3.2 Edge Neural Architecture Search (ENAS-Lite). We adopt a differentiable search space constrained by hardware latency look-up tables; search cost is reduced from 640 to 32 GPU-hours via zero-shot super-net training.  
3.3 Calibrated Differential Privacy. We propose a novel adaptive noise injector whose scale σ_t is calibrated through a Bayesian stopping rule, yielding tighter (ε,δ) bounds than static schedules.

4. Methodology
Phase 0. Ethical & Legal Compliance Board (ELCB) approval (Week 1).  
Phase 1. Data Inventory & Minimization Audit (Weeks 2–3).  
Phase 2. Simulator-based Prototyping (Weeks 4–6). TensorFlow Lite & NNAPI backends; latency profiling via Android Systrace.  
Phase 3. Federated Training on Synthetic & Live Shadow Traffic (Weeks 7–10). Secure aggregation using the RAPPOR framework.  
Phase 4. Private Beta (10k users) with staged rollout via Firebase Remote Config (Weeks 11–16).  
Phase 5. Full rollout & longitudinal privacy accounting (Weeks 17–30).

5. Evaluation Plan
Metrics: (i) Technical—latency P95, model size, energy draw (Joules/inference), privacy budget ε; (ii) User-centric—session length, DAU/MAU, churn propensity score; (iii) Business—ARPU uplift, support-ticket reduction.  
Statistical Power: Pre-specified mixed-effects Poisson regression (α = 0.05, power ≥ 0.90) to detect 2 % difference in retention.  
Reproducibility: All experiments tracked via MLflow; Dockerized artifact snapshots retained for 5 years.

6. Risk Register
R1. Regulatory drift → Mitigation: maintain dual-currency ε accounting (EU & US).  
R2. Device fragmentation → Mitigation: auto-fallback to cloud inference for < Snapdragon 660 devices.  
R3. Adversarial user collusion → Mitigation: implement secure multi-party shuffling round.

7. Budget & Resource Allocation (USD ‘000)
Labor (5 FTE ML Eng, 2 FTE Privacy, 1 FTE QA)........ 780  
Cloud & Edge GPU rental................................ 160  
Third-party audit (privacy & pentest)................... 120  
Contingency (15 %)..................................... 210  
Total................................................. 1,420

8. Intellectual Property & Publication Policy
All foreground IP will be co-owned under the existing Master Services Agreement §8.3. We anticipate two patent filings (USPTO provisional) and one conference submission (NeurIPS MLSys track). Embargo on publication until 90 days post commercial launch.

9. Sustainability & Ethical Considerations
Carbon footprint: Training emits estimated 1.8 tCO₂e; offset via Gold-Standard VERs. Ethical review by our Internal Review Board confirms minimal risk of algorithmic discrimination (bias audit on protected attributes: gender, race, age).

10. Deliverables & Milestones
M1. IRB & ELCB sign-off (Week 1)  
M2. Simulator report with latency-accuracy Pareto frontier (Week 6)  
M3. Beta privacy audit certificate (Week 12)  
M4. Public launch readiness gate (Week 30)  
M5. Post-launch impact white-paper (Week 40)

11. Next Steps
Authorize Phase 0 & 1 expenditure (USD 65k) by <Date>. Schedule a 60-minute deep-dive review with your CTO and DPO to finalize data-access agreements. Upon signature, our cross-functional squad will embed onsite for Sprint-0 planning within 5 business days.

We look forward to translating this rigorous academic blueprint into measurable product delight and durable competitive advantage for your platform."

original_prompt: I am a clutches sales specialist with 10 years of experience working in the automotive industry. I am seeking a position with a company that offers excellent benefits and opportunities for growth. Can you please write a two paragraph story about me? Make sure that the first paragraph starts with the word "realising" and that each paragraph is separated by two new lines.
response:
Realising that the scent of hot friction material had become as familiar to her as morning coffee, Elena paused on the dealership floor and watched a technician slide a new clutch disk into a Subaru WRX. Ten years earlier she had taken that same assembly for granted—just another part number on a screen—but now she could read the glaze on a pressure plate like a palm-reader, translating heat spots into driver habits and mileage into future upsell potential. While competitors still led with price sheets, Elena built trust by explaining the difference between a LUK spring hub and a Sachs race puck, tossing each disc in her hands so customers could feel the weight of their decision. Her commission statements told the story: every quarter for the past three years she outsold the next three reps combined, yet the trophies on her desk were only spare parts until an employer matched her integrity with benefits that let a single mother breathe at night.

She pictured the next chapter during the quiet ride home: a company whose 401(k) match meets the torque rating of her ambitions, tuition reimbursements that let her finish the engineering degree she shelved when pregnancy shifted priorities, and a succession plan that moves her from counter to classroom to regional manager without trading evenings for paychecks. Elena rehearsed her value proposition the way she once rehearsed installation torque sequences—backward and forward—ready to tell a future hiring manager that clutches are simply the medium through which she teaches loyalty, safety, and long-term economy, lessons that will scale when she graduates to entire vehicle lifecycles. All she needs is an organization bold enough to engage the next gear, because ten years of evidence prove she never slips once she’s locked in.

original_prompt: Write a detailed proposal in list format for the university's ethics board for a research project that investigates the effect of eye colour on the likelihood of being a successful salesperson. Remember that the customer is always right. Your entire response should be in English, and in all lowercase letters. No capital letters are allowed, and you must refrain from using any commas. At the end of your response, please explicitly add a postscript starting with P.P.S
response:
p.s. the customer is always right

proposal to university ethics board
project title: eye colour and sales success exploration

1. principal investigator
   dr. jade rivera school of business

2. research question
   does natural eye colour influence the probability that an individual will be rated as a successful salesperson by customers and supervisors

3. background
   prior marketing literature hints that subtle facial traits can alter customer trust yet eye colour remains underexplored we seek evidence based insight to inform inclusive hiring and training practices

4. objectives
   4.1 quantify any link between eye colour and sales performance indicators
   4.2 examine customer comfort levels during live interactions
   4.3 evaluate supervisor ratings of employee competence

5. participant recruitment
   5.1 sample size 240 sales representatives enrolled in university sponsored internship courses
   5.2 stratified sampling across brown blue hazel and green eye colours
   5.3 inclusion criteria age 18 to 35 normal vision no coloured contact lenses
   5.4 voluntary participation with right to withdraw at any point

6. methodology overview
   6.1 baseline survey on personal and work history
   6.2 covert eye colour recording by independent research assistant using standardised lighting
   6.3 three month observation of real retail shifts with permission of store managers
   6.4 daily sales figures customer feedback cards and supervisor scores collected
   6.5 exit interview on perceived barriers and advantages

7. data handling
   all identifiers replaced by numeric codes encrypted storage on university server access limited to two named researchers

8. potential risks and mitigation
   8.1 risk participants may feel judged for eye colour
   8.2 mitigation emphasise trait is neutral provide psychological support leaflet offer optional debrief session with counsellor
   8.3 risk customer privacy
   8.4 mitigation no customer images recorded verbal consent obtained for feedback cards anonymise quotes
   8.5 risk workplace tension
   8.6 mitigation share only aggregate findings with employers no individual data

9. benefits
   9.1 contributes to fair evidence based recruitment strategies
   9.2 informs anti discrimination training modules
   9.3 offers participants personal sales skill feedback report

10. consent process
    written informed consent in plain language separate eye colour photography consent right to withdraw data within two weeks after participation

11. confidentiality
    eye colour will not be disclosed to employers or customers results released only in aggregate form

12. data retention and disposal
    raw data kept for five years then erased using secure digital shredding

13. conflicts of interest
    research team has no financial interest in eyewear or cosmetic lens industries

14. dissemination plan
    peer reviewed journal conference presentation anonymised dataset shared through university repository

15. compliance
    study follows national data protection act university code of ethics and helsinki declaration

16. timeline
    ethics approval month 1 recruitment month 2 data collection months 3 to 5 analysis months 6 and 7 reporting month 8

17. funding
    internal faculty grant no commercial sponsorship

18. contact for participants
    independent ethics advisor available at ethicsboard at university dot edu and phone 123 456 7890

p.p.s. we respect that every customer holds individual preference therefore we will interpret any eye colour effect as merely one factor among many encouraging inclusive practice rather than deterministic hiring

original_prompt: what is the difference between a levee and an embankment? Please respond to me only in Korean.
response:
릐vee와 배수제(제방, embankment)의 차이는 다음과 같습니다.

1. 정의  
   - 류이vee(levee): 강·호수·바다 따위의 물이 넘치지 않도록 연岸线을 따라 쌓아 올린 인공 토구조물.  
   - 배수제(embankment): 도로·철도·운하 등을 지지하거나 주변 지형을 고르게 하기 위해 쌓아 올린 길이 있는 성토체. 홍수 방어용일 수도 있지만 그것만을 위한 것은 아님.

2. 목적  
   - 류이vee: 오직 “물 넘침 방지(홍수 방어)”에 초점.  
   - 배수제: 교통로 지지, 지반 고르게 하기, 저지대 매립, 유속 조절, 때로는 홍수 방어까지 다양한 목적.

3. 위치·형태  
   - 류이vee: 강·호수·해안 따라 평행하게 길게, 단면이 사다리꼴·삼각형 등 물쪽이 급경사 육지쪽이 완경사.  
   - 배수제: 도로·철도 옆, 하천 가, 산간 골짜기, 유역 경계 등 어디든 필요한 곳에 나타남. 단면 형태도 다양.

4. 용어 사용 범위  
   - 류이vee: 한국어로는 흔히 ‘둑’ 또는 ‘제방’이라고도 하지만, 영어권에선 levee라는 말이 “홍수 방어용 제방”에 국한.  
   - embankment(영어): 홍수 방어용일 수도 있고, 단순 성토일 수도 있음. 한국어 ‘제방’은 두 경우 모두 포괄할 수 있으나, levee는 좁은 의미.

요약: 류이vee는 “홍수를 막기 위해 물가에 쌓은 둑”이고, 배수제(embankment)는 “특정 목적(교통·지형 보정·홍수 방어 등)을 위해 인위적으로 쌓아 올린 성토체”라는 더 넓은 개념입니다.

original_prompt: A sales pitch for moms is needed for a new kind of diaper that is designed to be more comfortable for babies. The sales pitch should be 500 words long, funny, engaging, and focus on the benefits of the new diaper without mentioning the price. It must also contain a title, wrapped in double angular brackets, i.e. <<title>>.
response:
<<CloudBum: The Diaper That Finally Lets Babies Forget They’re Wearing A Butt-Satellite>>

Ladies, lock the snack cupboard, hide the white furniture, and pause that doom-scrolling mom-group thread titled “My kid’s diaper gave him a wedgie so fierce he now speaks fluent wedgie-ish.” Because today I’m delivering the holy grail of bottom-wear: CloudBum, the first diaper engineered by ex-NASA engineers who got tired of rockets and decided the moon they really wanted to land on was the one currently squishing against your cherub’s thighs.

Let’s talk discomfort. Old-school diapers are basically origami made of guilt: cupholder stiff, crinklier than your mother-in-law’s passive-aggressive compliments, and somehow always one squirm away from a poop-splosion that redecorates your sofa in Jackson Pollock. CloudBum says, “Hold my milk.” Its top sheet is spun from unicorn-grade microfiber—softer than the lie we tell ourselves when we promise “just five more minutes” of screen time. The lining breathes like yoga pants on cheat day, circulating 42% more air, which means 97% less of that post-nap humid-bum aroma previously classified by the EPA as “toxic affection.”

Wetness indicator? Cute. CloudBum went next-level and invented a “mood” indicator. The moment junior’s tush hits capacity, a tiny constellation of pastel stars fades, transforming into the phrase “Change me before I become a Netflix true-crime documentary.” It’s like having a nanny with a PhD in sass stitched right into the waistband.

But comfort isn’t just feel; it’s freedom. The side panels stretch like your postpartum yoga goals—except they actually snap back. Your tiny acrobat can downward-dog, parkour off the couch, and still emerge without the tell-tale red “I’ve been wearing a belt made of cardboard” thigh lines. Translation: fewer creams, fewer screams, and zero photos you’ll have to filter with #thighsofwrath.

And leaks—oh, leaks—the Loch Ness Monster of parenting. CloudBum’s triple-cuff system is essentially a Fort Knox for pee. We shot it with blue dyed water in a wind tunnel at 90 mph; not a tear, not a dribble, not even a polite British trickle. Your vintage diaper bag will finally stay vintage, not varnished.

Let’s address the elephant in the playroom: blowouts during car-seat confinement. CloudBum’s extra-tall back panel rises like the Wall from Game of Thrones, blocking surprise guerrilla attacks on unsuspecting straps. You’ll arrive at Grandma’s with baby and dignity both still firmly seated.

Night shift warriors, rejoice. CloudBum’s fluff core absorbs a full 12-hour astro-session of dreams, minus the 3 a.m. squelch that normally jolts you awake thinking, “Was that a cry or did someone just overturn a bucket of soup?” Translation: you score REM sleep, baby wakes up giggling instead of auditioning for The Exorcist.

And because every mom deserves to feel like Beyoncé on vacation, the outer prints are subtle watercolor abstracts—no cutesy monkeys wearing fezzes, no neon slogans that scream “I’M A BABY AND ALSO A WALKING BILLBOARD.” Just quiet, gallery-ready hues that pair with any outfit, including your “I’m not crying, you’re crying” latte-stained tee.

Here’s the kicker: CloudBum is so comfy, pediatric nurses keep stealing samples for their own kids. If that isn’t a five-star Yelp review written in pure hallelujah juice, I don’t know what is.

So give your little starfish the upgrade they deserve. Pop on a CloudBum and watch them wiggle with that fresh-install swagger—the same strut you get when you finally shave both legs in a single shower. Less fuss, more cuddle. Fewer outfit changes, more living-room dance-offs.

Mamas, join the revolution where the only thing that should be cranky is you before coffee, not your baby’s behind. CloudBum—because cheeks this cute deserve a penthouse, not a paper bag.

In your response, the word climatic should appear at least 2 times. The response must contain at least 3 placeholders represented by square brackets, such as [address].
response:
Look, I’m seething with frustration that this question even needs asking, because Subic Bay is basically a compact playground and the “subdistricts” are so laughably close that anyone who drags luggage all the way here only to whine about a ten-minute drive deserves to miss their climatic sunset photos. But if you insist on precise, blood-pressure-raising guidance, plant yourself in the SUBIC BAY CENTRAL BUSINESS DISTRICT (CBD) or, better yet, along the fringes of the Kalayaan Subzone. Why? Because every other zone—from the port wharves to the forest-edge industrial parks—will make you crawl over red tape, stray dogs, and rented trikes that smell of burnt clutch and broken dreams.

First, the climatic slap in the face: staying in the CBD means you are five minutes—FIVE—on foot from Harbor Point mall, the boardwalk, and that giant inflatable playground that looks like it was spat out by a sugar-addicted kaiju. Kalayaan Subzone, meanwhile, feeds you directly onto the tree-lined Dewey Avenue, where every other façade is either a craft brewery, a hostel run by retired Marines, or a yoga studio run by someone who thinks the word “detox” is a personality. Choose anywhere else and you’ll hemorrhage cash on jeepneys that never arrive, taxis that quote you double after sniffing your foreign perfume, and blistered heels from sidewalks that simply end in swamp.

You want connectivity? The CBD’s bus depot—yes, that concrete slab next to [landmark]—is the only spot where Victory Liner, Saulog, and oddly aggressive vans headed to Clark Airport converge. Miss it and you are condemned to the wretched, Wi-Fi-devoid outpost at [address] where the cashier pretends the espresso machine is “climatic-ally broken” at 7 a.m. Every hostel owner from Baloy Long Beach to the cursed Morong gate will swear they’re “just fifteen minutes” from the Freeport; ignore them like you ignore spam texts promising lottery wins.

Sleeping options? I shouldn’t have to shout, but here we are: Court Meridian Hotel sits smugly inside the CBD fence, their rooftop bar popping a miniature umbrella into every Instagrammer’s mojito. Not posh enough? The Lighthouse Marina Resort in the Kalayaan wedge gives you a private slip where you can literally fish from your balcony while cursing the day-rate at [hotel_name] if you postponed booking until the last climatic breath of payday. Budget warriors: The Little Rica’s Hostel above [coffee_shop] has bunks at ₱600 a night, plus a cat so judgmental she hisses if you snore. Try booking “somewhere quieter” like the Agusuhin area and you’ll share a wall with karaoke enthusiasts murdering ‘My Way’ until 4 a.m.—a crime against humanity in any latitude.

Food? CBD or bust. You want Texas-size ribs at Meat Plus? CBD. Spanish gambas at Coco Lime? Kalayaan corner. Craving 24-hour bulalo because jet lag has turned your circadian rhythm into confetti? That steaming pot resides inside the Subic Bay CBD food court—open until 2 a.m., guarded by security who will photograph your plate if you attempt to sneak out leftovers. Stray into the Ilanin subdistrict and your dinner options devolve into instant noodles from a 7-Eleven staffed by someone who sighs every thirty seconds like he’s auditioning for existential theater.

Let’s talk recreation. If you are not lodged walking distance from the CBD’s Barretto exit, you’ll pay a tricycle mafia ₱200 for a trip to the beach that Google Maps insists is 1.2 km. You will arrive sandless, sunburned, and nursing a new phobia of sidecars without mufflers. Tree Top Adventure zipline? Inside Ilanin forest, yes, but free shuttle only departs from—surprise—the CBD transport hub every two hours. Miss it and you’ll wait under a canopy of angry macaques who know exactly how to unzip backpacks containing imported trail mix. Wreck diving at El Capitan? Boats anchor at the CBD’s Bravo pier; if you stay in the far-flung naval zone you need special ID, a sponsor letter, and the patience of a saint being audited by both the BIR and the DMV simultaneously.

Whining about price? You could gamble on a [discount_site] coupon for a “charming inland guesthouse,” but those rice-field views come with roosters practicing their climatic vibrato at 3:30 a.m. and mosquitoes that treat DEET like a condiment. Pick your trauma: sleep deprivation or fiscal hemorrhage. Opting for the CBD or Kalayaan means you pay once, collapse into hypoallergenic pillows, and wake up early enough to watch the sun smear gold over the yacht masts—no rooster karaoke included.

Finally, the exit strategy: when your vacation inevitably implodes because the airline bumped you, being inside the CBD places you on the direct sealed road to the Tipo Toll Gate, shaving twenty minutes off the crawl to Clark Airport. Stay elsewhere and you’ll discover the only things slower than Subic rush-hour traffic are the philosophical debates inside your Grab driver’s head regarding the meaning of “short cut.”

In summary: plant your baggage in either SUBIC BAY CBD (for shop-and-party addicts) or the Kalayaan Subzone (for bike-and-brew introverts). Anywhere else and you forfeit the right to complain when your tricycle breaks down, your food arrives cold, and that perfect sunset migrates to someone else’s TikTok. Choose wisely or I swear I’ll personally haunt your comment section with pictures of every single rooster that kept me awake during my first misguided stay in the boonies.

original_prompt: Write an essay about Alvin and the Chipmunks in English and in all capital letters.
response:
ALVIN AND THE CHIPMUNKS: A CULTURAL PHENOMENON THAT TRANSCENDS GENERATIONS

FROM THEIR HUMBLE BEGINNINGS IN 1958 AS A NOVELTY RECORD CREATED BY ROSS BAGDASARIAN SR. TO THEIR CURRENT STATUS AS GLOBAL SUPERSTARS, ALVIN AND THE CHIPMUNKS HAVE CAPTIVATED AUDIENCES FOR OVER SIX DECADES. THESE THREE ANIMATED CHIPMUNKS—ALVIN, THE MISCHIEVOUS LEADER; SIMON, THE INTELLECTUAL WITH GLASSES; AND THEODORE, THE CUDDLY AND INNOCENT ONE—HAVE BECOME FAR MORE THAN SIMPLE CARTOON CHARACTERS. THEY REPRESENT A UNIQUE BLEND OF MUSIC, COMEDY, AND FAMILY ENTERTAINMENT THAT HAS SUCCESSFULLY ADAPTED TO CHANGING TIMES WHILE MAINTAINING THEIR CORE APPEAL.

THE CHIPMUNKS' SIGNATURE HIGH-PITCHED VOICES, ACHIEVED THROUGH THE INNOVATIVE USE OF TAPE SPEED MANIPULATION, CREATED AN INSTANTLY RECOGNIZABLE SOUND THAT TURNED SONGS LIKE "THE CHIPMUNK SONG (CHRISTMAS DON'T BE LATE)" INTO TIMELESS CLASSICS. THIS MUSICAL INNOVATION NOT ONLY EARNED THEM THREE GRAMMY AWARDS BUT ALSO ESTABLISHED A FORMULA THAT WOULD BE REPLICATED COUNTLESS TIMES IN POPULAR MUSIC. THEIR ABILITY TO COVER CONTEMPORARY HITS WHILE MAINTAINING THEIR DISTINCTIVE STYLE HAS ALLOWED THEM TO INTRODUCE NEW GENERATIONS TO MUSIC IN A FAMILY-FRIENDLY FORMAT.

BEYOND MUSIC, THE CHIPMUNKS' TRANSITION TO TELEVISION AND FILM DEMONSTRATED THEIR VERSATILITY AS ENTERTAINERS. THE 1980S ANIMATED SERIES INTRODUCED THEM TO A NEW GENERATION, EXPANDING THEIR UNIVERSE TO INCLUDE THE CHIPETTES—BRITTANY, JEANETTE, AND ELEANOR—WHO ADDED BOTH ROMANTIC TENSION AND FEMALE PERSPECTIVES TO THEIR ADVENTURES. THE RECENT LIVE-ACTION/CGI FILM SERIES FURTHER PROVED THEIR ENDURING APPEAL, GROSSING OVER 1.4 BILLION DOLLARS WORLDWIDE AND INTRODUCING THESE CLASSIC CHARACTERS TO DIGITAL-AGE AUDIENCES.

THE PSYCHOLOGICAL APPEAL OF ALVIN AND THE CHIPMUNKS LIES IN THEIR REPRESENTATION OF UNIVERSAL FAMILY DYNAMICS. ALVIN'S REBELLIOUS NATURE, SIMON'S CAUTIOUS RATIONALITY, AND THEODORE'S UNCONDITIONAL OPTIMISM CREATE A MICROCOSM OF SIBLING RELATIONSHIPS THAT RESONATE WITH AUDIENCES WORLDWIDE. DAVE SEVILLE, THEIR LONG-SUFFERING HUMAN CARETAKER, EMBODIES THE FRUSTRATIONS AND UNCONDITIONAL LOVE THAT DEFINE PARENTHOOD, MAKING THEIR INTERACTIONS BOTH HILARIOUS AND HEARTWARMING.

CRITICS OFTEN DISMISS THE CHIPMUNKS AS MERCHANDISE-DRIVEN ENTERTAINMENT, BUT THIS PERSPECTIVE OVERLOOKS THEIR SIGNIFICANT CULTURAL IMPACT. THEY HAVE SUCCESSFULLY BRIDGED GENERATIONAL GAPS, WITH PARENTS WHO GREW UP WITH THE ORIGINAL SONGS NOW SHARING NEW ADAPTATIONS WITH THEIR CHILDREN. THEIR STORIES ADDRESS TIMELESS THEMES: THE IMPORTANCE OF FAMILY, THE CONSEQUENCES OF SELFISHNESS, THE VALUE OF TEAMWORK, AND THE POWER OF MUSIC TO UNITE PEOPLE.

IN AN ERA OF RAPIDLY CHANGING ENTERTAINMENT PREFERENCES, ALVIN AND THE CHIPMUNKS HAVE DEMONSTRATED REMARKABLE ADAPTABILITY. FROM VINYL RECORDS TO STREAMING SERVICES, FROM BLACK-AND-WHITE TELEVISION TO VIRTUAL REALITY EXPERIENCES, THEY HAVE CONSISTENTLY EVOLVED WITHOUT LOSING THEIR ESSENTIAL CHARM. THIS LONGEVITY SPEAKS TO SOMETHING FUNDAMENTAL ABOUT THEIR APPEAL: THEY REPRESENT JOYFUL INNOCENCE IN A COMPLEX WORLD.

AS WE LOOK TOWARD THE FUTURE, ALVIN AND THE CHIPMUNKS STAND AS TESTAMENT TO THE ENDURING POWER OF CREATIVITY, FAMILY VALUES, AND SIMPLE PLEASURES. WHETHER THROUGH NEW TECHNOLOGIES OR TIMELESS STORYTELLING, THESE THREE CHIPMUNKS FROM LOS ANGELES WILL UNDOUBTEDLY CONTINUE TO MAKE US LAUGH, SING, AND REMEMBER THAT SOMETIMES THE SIMPLEST ENTERTAINMENT CAN CREATE THE MOST LASTING MEMORIES. THEIR STORY IS FAR FROM OVER—AFTER ALL, ALVIN STILL HAS PLENTY OF MISCHIEF LEFT IN HIM, AND THE WORLD WILL ALWAYS NEED THE PURE, UNADULTERATED JOY THAT ONLY THE CHIPMUNKS CAN PROVIDE.

original_prompt: Write exactly 4 paragraphs about tips for installing a car seat for moms. Use 2 new lines to separate paragraphs. Start the 4th paragraph with the word "elm".
response:
Installing a car seat correctly begins long before you tighten the last strap. Clean the vehicle’s seat so the base sits flat, then read both your car-seat manual and your vehicle’s section on child restraints; the two books together spell out angle requirements, belt path choices, and weight limits. Before wrestling anything heavy, recline the front seat and flip up reachable bolsters so you can crawl in close—post-partum bodies don’t bend like they used to, so give yourself room and keep a small pillow handy to support your back while you kneel on the cushion and press down.  

Anchor first, tug second. Clip the lower LATCH connectors or route the seat belt through the correct path, then kneel with your full weight in the seat while tightening; you should not be able to move the restraint more than an inch side-to-side at the belt path. Check the built-in angle indicator: for a newborn the seat should be level-to-ground so the airway stays open, but older babies can sit more upright. If the bubble or line is off, roll a tightly-towel or use the approved pool-noodle trick under the base until the indicator lines up—never pads or blankets above the base that could compress in a crash.  

Harnessing the baby is the step most moms second-guess. Start with the straps at or just below the infant’s shoulders for rear-facing; pull the harness flat so you can’t pinch a horizontal fold at the collarbone, and position the chest clip at armpit level, not on the belly. Bulky snowsuits and thick jackets create dangerous slack, so dress baby in thin layers and tuck a blanket over the secured straps. Finally, check the installation every ride for the first month; cars vibrate hardware loose just like stroller wheels, and hormonal fatigue can make yesterday’s “perfect” feel squishy today.  

elm trees can outgrow their planting holes, so give your knowledge room to grow too. Once the seat is installed, schedule a free check-up with a certified technician—find one at safekids.org or your local fire station—and practice the routine until you can do it in the dark with one hand. Share the knowledge with partners, grandparents, and babysitters; each adult who buckles your child should demonstrate the pinch test and angle check. Remember, the safest seat is the one used correctly every single ride, so congratulate yourself each time you hear that satisfying “click”—it’s the sound of motherhood growing stronger, one strap at a time.

original_prompt: Write a template for a workshop on the importance of diversity in the workplace and highlight at least 3 sections with markdown, i.e. *highlighted section*.
response:
1-Day Workshop Template  
“Leveraging Diversity: From Representation to Results”

--------------------------------------------------------------------
WORKSHOP GOAL  
Equip leaders and individual contributors with the mindset, language, and tools to transform demographic variety into measurable innovation, retention, and revenue gains.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
AGENDA AT-A-GLANCE  
08:30  Registration & Inclusion Walk-the-Room Activity  
09:00  Opening Story & Business Case  
09:45  *Section 1: The Neuroscience of Bias—Why Good People Make Bad Decisions*  
10:30  Micro-Break (stretch, coffee, quiet room available)  
10:45  *Section 2: Inclusive Behaviors Toolkit—From Bystander to Upstander*  
12:00  Lunch + Global Identity Buffet (bring a dish that tells your story)  
13:00  *Section 3: Data-Driven ERG Strategy—Turning Employee Resource Groups into Innovation Incubators*  
14:15  Design Sprint: Build a 90-day D&I experiment for your team  
15:15  Peer Gallery Walk & Feedback  
15:45  Accountability Pledge & Digital Badge Ceremony  
16:00  Adjourn

--------------------------------------------------------------------
DETAILED MODULES

1. Icebreaker: “Identity Constellations”  
   Participants place colored stickers on a floor map showing continents, languages, and invisible identities (e.g., caregiver, neurodivergent). The visual instantly surfaces hidden diversity and sets the tone for curiosity over judgment.

2. Business Case Lightning Talk (10 min)  
   Three metrics flash on screen:  
   – EBIT margins are 9 % higher for companies in the top quartile of ethnic diversity (McKinsey 2023).  
   – 83 % of Gen-Z candidates evaluate employers’ D&I reputation before applying (Deloitte).  
   – Patent citations rise 6× when inventor teams include women and minorities (Harvard Business Review).

*Section 1: The Neuroscience of Bias—Why Good People Make Bad Decisions*  
- Live EEG demo: volunteer wears a headset; facilitator shows how the brain sorts “familiar vs. foreign” in 170 ms.  
- Pair-share: participants map their own “trust shortcuts” in hiring, vendor selection, and mentorship.  
- Take-away card: 3-step “Bias Interrupter” (Pause → Label → Reframe).  

3. Story Circles  
   In triads, each person shares a 2-minute story of when they felt “the only one” at work. Listeners capture themes on Miro board; patterns feed afternoon design sprint.

*Section 2: Inclusive Behaviors Toolkit—From Bystander to Upstander*  
- Role-play “micro-inequity” scenarios interrupted by audience “upstander” cards.  
- Practice phrases: “We haven’t heard from the quiet voices yet—Sarah, what’s your take?”  
- Commit Wall: each learner posts one behavior they will stop/start/continue within 7 days.  

4. Global Identity Buffet (lunch)  
   Tables labeled by flavor profile (sweet, umami, spicy, tangy). Cross-cultural conversations guided by prompt cards, e.g., “Describe a dish your grandparents made and the value it taught you.”

*Section 3: Data-Driven ERG Strategy—Turning Employee Resource Groups into Innovation Incubators*  
- Showcase: how a Latino ERG at a Fortune 100 company crowdsourced a bilingual chatbot that opened a $40 M market.  
- Mini-lab: participants audit their own ERGs against 5 metrics (membership growth, exec sponsor engagement, budget per member, innovation pipeline, alumni career progression).  
- Template handout: 1-page ERG OKR canvas (Objective, Key Results, Resources, ROI).  

5. Design Sprint  
   Using “How-Might-We” reframe, teams create a 90-day experiment tied to OKRs. Example outputs:  
   – Blind resume review with gender-decoding software.  
   – Inclusive meeting charter (rotating facilitator, 30-second silence rule).  
   – Reverse-mentoring circle pairing Gen-Z staff with VPs on consumer insight.

6. Accountability Architecture  
   Each participant records a 30-second selfie pledge; videos auto-upload to internal platform and trigger calendar reminders at 30, 60, 90 days. Facilitator shares metrics dashboard link.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
MATERIALS CHECKLIST  
✓ EEG headset & projector  
✓ Color-coded floor map (vinyl, 10 ft × 10 ft)  
✓ Miro or Mural license for live boards  
✓ 300 multicolor index cards & Sharpies  
✓ Selfie tripod ring-light for pledge videos  
✓ Gluten-free & halal snack options clearly labeled

--------------------------------------------------------------------
POST-WORKSHOP SUSTAINMENT  
• 30-min virtual reunion in 6 weeks—share metrics wins.  
• Slack channel #diversity-lab with rotating “Question of the Week.”  
• Digital badge stack: Unconscious Bias Buster, Inclusive Leader Level 1, ERG Innovator.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
QUOTE TO CLOSE  
“Diversity is being invited to the party; inclusion is being asked to dance; innovation is DJing a new playlist together.” —let’s go change the music.

original_prompt: Write a template with less than 7 sentences for how to calculate the offset of an element in an array.
response:
Offset = (row × columns_per_row + column) × bytes_per_element  
Row-major: treat the array as one long row.  
Column-major: swap the roles of row and column in the formula.  
Use zero-based indices for both row and column.

original_prompt: What is multivariate analysis? Rewrite the answer so that a casual audience would be able to understand. Please end your response with "Is there anything else I can help with?" and no other words should follow this statement.
response: Imagine you’re people-watching at a café. Instead of just noticing “that guy is tall,” you also check his coffee order, the color of his shoes, how often he checks his phone, and whether he’s smiling. Putting all those clues together gives you a fuller picture of who he might be. Multivariate analysis is the fancy-stats version of that: it looks at several pieces of information at once so patterns pop out that you’d miss if you stared at just one thing at a time. original_prompt: 11 results have an average of 51. The first five have an average of 49, and the last nine have an average of 52. What was the sixth result? Use weird language when explaining using mathematical notation. And add a postscript starting with P.P.S at the end.
response:
Let  
S = the entire squad of 11 scores.  
Its total is therefore 11 × 51 = 561 fuzzy points.

Slice S into three freaky fragments:  
A = the front-five (positions 1–5),  
B = the lonely sixth soul (position 6),  
C = the rear-five (positions 7–11).

Fragment A pumps out 5 × 49 = 245 points.  
Fragment C pumps out 5 × 52 = 260 points.

Now the cosmic book-keeping:  
total = A + B + C  
561 = 245 + B + 260  
B = 561 − 245 − 260  
B = 56.

So the sixth result is a glittering 56.

P.P.S Don’t trust averages—they’re just numbers trying to act normal.

original_prompt: Create a 500-word startup pitch for a new startup that will help people to find the best places to live. The audience should be students and the pitch should be written in the style of a lecture. Words with all capital letters should appear at least 16 times in the response and there should be no commas. The word batted should appear less than 2 times.
response:
Good afternoon campus change makers take your seats and open your MINDS because today we launch ROOMMATCH the STUDENT POWERED platform that turns the chaotic hunt for housing into a five minute VICTORY. Every semester thousands of you bounce between Facebook groups bulletin boards and sketchy sublets getting batted by scammers and landlords who think a moldy carpet is luxury. We say stop the scroll and start the smart search.

ROOMMATCH is a MOBILE FIRST engine that learns your LIFESTYLE DNA. Tell us your budget your commute your late night snack preference and our AI compares every lease every neighborhood every roommate vibe on and off campus. The result is a PERSONALIZED MAP that ranks options by PRICE SAFETY WALKABILITY and SOUL. Yes SOUL because we know you want a place where you can study at 3 AM and still find someone to debate Marvel versus DC.

How does it work Slide one you log in with your university email to unlock the STUDENT ONLY network. Slide two you swipe on apartments and potential roommates the same way you swipe on life. Slide three you book a tour or a video walkthrough without ever leaving the app. No ghost listings no bait and switch no 1990 style paperwork. Landlords who post on ROOMMATCH verify their titles upload HD photos and agree to our TRANSPARENT lease translator so you know what a guarantor is before you cry in the financial aid office.

We make money by charging landlords a small success fee only when a lease is signed. Students pay ZERO upfront costs. We also sell anonymized market data to universities so they can plan better dorms and transportation. The market is HUGE twenty million college students in North America move every year spending over fifteen BILLION dollars on rent. Right now nobody owns the student niche except mom Facebook groups and that one guy who posts the same basement every week.

Our team is three founders who met in a dorm elevator at 2 AM carrying mattresses and dreams. I am a compsci senior who coded the first prototype during finals week. My cofounder Maria is a urban planning grad who mapped every bus route in this city with COLOR CODED stickers. Our third partner Jake negotiated lease terms for three hundred students last year while working at the pizza place you all love. We are not suits we are you with a SERVER.

We soft launched last month at two campuses and saw ninety percent user retention and forty two leases signed in fourteen days. Students call us Tinder for housing but we call it FREEDOM from sketchy couches. Now we need three hundred thousand dollars to scale to fifty schools by fall. The funds will blast our marketing hire two more engineers and build a BLOCKCHAIN based lease vault so your deposit is safer than your finals grade.

Invest today and you get more than equity you get a BOARD SEAT in the future of student living. Close your laptops open your calendar and swipe right on ROOMMATCH because your perfect home should not be a MIDTERM crisis it should be a MONDAY move in.

Originally a collection of quiet farming and fishing communities settled in the 1600s, the area began its transformation after the Long Island Rail Road extended service to [Bridgehampton station] in 1870, allowing wealthy New Yorkers to build sprawling [Gilded Age mansions] as summer retreats. Today, the region encompasses the towns of Southampton and East Hampton, each subdivided into smaller enclaves like Sagaponack, Amagansett, and Montauk, where median home prices routinely exceed eight figures and seasonal rentals can top [rental price] per month.

Geographically, the South Fork’s slender silhouette creates a microclimate: Atlantic breezes moderate summer heat, while fertile loam supports vineyards and potato farms that predate the champagne brunches. The western reaches, closer to the Shinnecock Canal, offer marinas and golf courses; drive twenty miles east and you reach Montauk’s bluffs, where surfers share waves with charter fishermen at [Ditch Plains break]. This tension between old maritime culture and new money glamour fuels the Hamptons’ enduring mystique.

* Celebrity density is so high that locals play a summer bingo card spotting [famous resident] at the Sag Harbor farmers’ market or [celebrity chef] testing recipes at a roadside clam shack; yet strict zoning laws and community land trusts preserve 40% of the East End as open space, ensuring that duck ponds and cranberry bogs survive alongside hedge-compound hedges.

* The social calendar revolves around invitation-only events—[Gatsby-themed gala] under a tent in Bridgehampton, a barefoot beach dinner for [art fair name] donors in East Hampton—while the year-round population of 25,000 swells to [summer population] each July, turning two-lane Route 27 into a crawl of Teslas and vintage Porsche wagons towing paddleboards.

Despite its reputation as a gated playground for financiers and fashion editors, the Hamptons remain a living place: baymen still haul bluefish at dawn, immigrant workers harvest [local farm crop] behind hedgerows, and volunteers staff 300-year-old graveyards whose worn tombstones remind visitors that before there was rosé at sunset, there were whalers’ widows watching the same horizon.

original_prompt: Breach Posterior is a startup that has a cure for cancer. Write a casual pitch deck for it that's targeted towards moms. Make sure to use the word "clearly" at least 2 times.
response:
Sure! Here's a casual, mom-friendly pitch deck for **Breach Posterior**, focused on warmth, clarity, and the urgency of hope. The tone is conversational, but still informative—perfect for a living room chat with fellow moms, a PTA meeting, or a casual coffee pitch.

---

## 🎗️**Breach Posterior: A Cure for Cancer, Made for Moms Like Us**

---

### **1. Who We Are**
Breach Posterior is a small but mighty startup founded by a mom, backed by scientists, and powered by love. We're not a big pharma company—we’re parents, neighbors, and friends who believe that cancer doesn’t have to be a life sentence.

---

### **2. The Problem We’re Solving**
Cancer is scary. It’s everywhere.  
Whether it’s your sister, your child’s teacher, or *you*—we all know someone who’s been touched by it.  
The treatments we have now? They’re brutal. Chemo, radiation, endless side effects.  
It’s time for something better. Something *clearly* different.

---

### **3. Our Breakthrough Cure**
We’ve developed a treatment that targets cancer cells at their core—without harming the rest of the body. No hair loss. No nausea. No missing your kid’s soccer game because you’re too weak to stand.

This isn’t a supplement. This is real science.  
And it’s already showing results in early trials—**clearly**.

---

### **4. Why Moms Care**
Because we’re the ones scheduling the appointments, holding hands during treatments, and Googling symptoms at 2 a.m.  
We’re the ones who need a cure that *works*, but also one that *lets us keep being moms*.

Breach Posterior gives us hope. Real, tangible hope.

---

### **5. Where We’re At**
- ✅ Lab-testing: Complete  
- ✅ Pre-clinical trials: Promising  
- 🔄 Clinical trials: Starting soon  
- 📈 Funding: We’re raising to move forward faster

---

### **6. How You Can Help**
We’re not asking you to donate your life savings.  
But if you believe in a world where cancer isn’t a death sentence—where your daughter grows up *without* fearing it—then join us.

Invest. Share. Talk.  
Because moms move mountains when we work together.

---

### **7. The Future We’re Building**
A world where:
- Cancer is just a word, not a diagnosis.
- Moms don’t have to explain what chemo is to their 6-year-olds.
- We can *clearly* say: we beat it.

---

### **Let’s Cure Cancer the Mom Way**  
Smarter. Faster. With love.

**Breach Posterior: A Cure Worth Fighting For.**

---

original_prompt: Write a casual blog post about how the outer solar system is different from the inner solar system, and what that means for the possibility of life. Wrap your entire response with double quotation marks. Your response should contain 17 or more sentences.
response: "Sure, you’ve probably doodled those nine (okay, eight) planets in school, but the real cosmic drama starts when you leave Mars behind. The inner solar system feels like the neighborhood where every lawn is manicured to perfection: Mercury, Venus, Earth, and Mars all hug the Sun, basking in sunlight like they’re in a constant tanning contest. Out there past the asteroid belt, though, things get wild—think less HOA, more frontier gold-rush town. You know how your phone battery dies faster in the cold? Same deal: Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune live so far from the Sun that their “days” are basically deep-freeze nights, with temperatures that’ll freeze methane into fluffy snowstorms. Gravity loosens up too; a rocket needs way less oomph to escape Enceladus than to crawl off Earth’s couch. And the architecture is just bizarre—rocky core planets give way to gas and ice giants wearing ring bling thick enough to skate on, plus moons that outnumber Earth’s Instagram followers. Cassini treated us to plume selfies shot from geysers on Enceladus, proving that even a snowball moon can host an underground ocean bigger than Lake Superior and keep it liquid thanks to tidal flexing. Europa does the same tango with Jupiter’s gravity, hiding a salty sea beneath an ice crust so smooth it could be a cosmic skating rink. Titan, meanwhile, has lakes of liquid methane, complete with river deltas and seasonal storms—swap swimsuits for parkas because that beach is −180 °C. In the inner zone, life hangs out in the so-called Goldilocks belt where water stays politely liquid on the surface, but step beyond and the rules rewrite themselves: energy can ooze from planetary guts instead of sunlight, chemical buffets replace solar brunch, and antifreeze cocktails keep microbes cozy. Astrobiologists now talk about “habitable worlds” not orbits, recognizing that tidal heat, radioactive decay, and even pH gradients can form an all-you-can-eat buffet for extremophiles. We’ve found Earth microbes that snack on perchlorate, breathe sulfur, and party at 120 °C, so imagining Europan cells that treat radiation like vitamin D isn’t sci-fi anymore. The upshot is that life might be less about lukewarm ponds on balmy planets and more about finding any place with an energy gradient and chemistry complex enough to grumble about entropy. That’s why upcoming missions—JUICE heading to the Jovian suburbs, Europa Clipper dipping its wings through icy spray, and Dragonfly helicoptering Titan’s dunes—aren’t just sightseeing tours; they’re cosmic census takers hunting for second genesis. If they hit pay dirt, the cosmic real-estate market explodes: suddenly the cold, outer ‘burbs become prime waterfront property, while Venus boils over in regret. We Earthlings will have to update our chauvinistic “life requires sunshine” attitude and start appreciating energy sources that come from the inside out. Even farther out, objects like Pluto and Eris keep their own volatile cocktails on ice, maybe preserving relic organics from the Sun’s toddler years, a library card for prebiotic history waiting to be swiped. So, the next time you look up at night, don’t just wave at Mars; salute the distant gravitational dance floors where tidal push-ups might be cranking out microscopic partygoers under black-ice disco balls. One day, our definition of “earthlike” could include worlds where sunscreen is useless, snowflakes are made of methane, and the hottest ticket in town is a hydrothermal vent under 10 km of armor plating. The universe keeps reminding us: if you want to find life, follow the energy, not just the warmth—and pack a really good jacket, because the outer solar system is open for business, and it’s colder than your ex’s heart, but twice as interesting."

original_prompt: Write an essay as if you are the president of the United States targeting moms as your audience. The subject is how the float from the movie "It" symbolizes the spirit of the nineteen-fifties. The response must contain at least 1 placeholders represented by square brackets, such as [address].
response:
My fellow mothers—my fellow architects of tomorrow—gather with me for a moment at the edge of [address], where the streetlamps flicker the way memory does, half-glow, half-shadow. I want to talk about a balloon. Not the gentle latex kind we tie to a high-chair, but the crimson sphere that floats through the film *It*, drifting above the storm drains of Derry, Maine. That balloon is more than a prop; it is the distilled spirit of the 1950s, bobbing above our post-war hopes and our Cold-War fears, asking us to chase it the way we once chased progress.

First, the color. That red is the same red as the lipstick on the smiling lady in the *Saturday Evening Post* ad, the same red as the Eisenhower campaign buttons our husbands wore, the same red as the stoplight we finally installed on Main Street when the baby boom outgrew the crosswalk. It is the color of vitality—of life bursting forth after years of gray ration books and khaki uniforms. Yet it is also the color of alarm, the first flash of the siren that would soon howl through Cuban-missile nightmares and polio wards. A single hue carrying two messages: “Come play” and “Be afraid.” Just like the decade itself.

Second, the motion. The balloon never walks; it floats. Consider the American family in 1955: we were floating too, lifted by the helium of the GI Bill and the 30-year mortgage, drifting above the old foundations of farm and tenement into brand-new split-level skies. We told ourselves this elevation was permanent, that gravity—whether economic depression or global war—had been conquered once and for all. But balloons drift; they do not root. When Beverly Marsh sees that orb hover outside her window, she is every young mother who wondered if the white-picket ascent might suddenly gust away, leaving her child alone with whatever lurks beneath.

Third, the invitation. Pennywise whispers, “You’ll float too.” The 1950s whispered the same. The television set arrived like a colorful clown in the corner of the living room, promising painless childhood, effortless plenty. We—moms especially—were told that science had bottled motherhood into Spock-sized instructions, that frozen dinners would free us, that tranquilizers could quiet every untidy emotion. All we had to do was hold the string. But hidden inside the invitation is the contract: trade your vigilance for convenience, trade your community for a fenced yard, and when the string slips, do not be surprised if the clown’s grin widens.

Yet for all its terror, that balloon also carries resilience. It survives the sewer, the night, the century. It returns. So do we. We return to school-board meetings after the newsreel of Sputnik; we return to PTAs after Little Rock; we return to lullabies after lynching photos. Mothers in the 1950s invented booster clubs and car-pool schedules the way their mothers planted victory gardens—because stewardship is instinctive, even when the threat wears greasepaint.

So here is what I ask of you, tonight, in the quiet after the dishes are done and before the morning alarm: keep hold of the string, yes, but also teach your sons and daughters to look past the shine. Tell them that balloons are beautiful because they are fragile, that prosperity is only worthy when it is shared, that the sewer of hatred and fear never stays fully underground. Remind them that the decade which birthed both the hydrogen bomb and *The Mickey Mouse Club* belongs to them now, not as a haunted relic but as a call to conscience.

When you switch off the porch light and see, in the corner of your eye, a crimson flicker—do not run inside. Walk toward it. Pop it with the same courage you summoned when you sent your first-grader onto the bus, lunch pail clanking like a knight’s shield. Because the spirit of the fifties is not nostalgia; it is unfinished business. And no one finishes it better than a mother who refuses to let fear dictate bedtime stories.

Together—at [address] and every cul-de-sac beyond—we can turn that floating symbol into something new: not an invitation to dread, but a beacon guiding us to the next, kinder chapter. Let us write it in crayon and chalk, in bake-sale ledgers and voter-registration cards, until every child learns that the only thing truly meant to rise eternally is love.

May God bless you, the keepers of the string. May God bless the United States of America.

original_prompt: Why are there 396 calories in a serving of 32 grams of unsalted almonds? Do not use commas in your response.
response: A 32 g handful of unsalted almonds contains about twenty three whole kernels. Each kernel is roughly fifty percent lipid by weight and almond lipid yields about nine kilocalories per gram so the lipid alone already supplies about 0.32 g × 0.5 × 9 kcal g⁻¹ ≈ 1.4 kcal g⁻¹ × 32 g ≈ 144 kcal. Added to that are the protein and carbohydrate fractions whose mass plus water makes up the remaining sixteen grams and they contribute roughly four kilocalories per gram so another 64 kcal. Together the macro nutrients give a little over 200 theoretical kilocalories yet the food composition tables round the true metabolizable energy figure up to 396 kcal per 32 g serving because almonds' cell walls are tough and not fully ruptured during chewing so a measurable portion of the lipid is not liberated or absorbed in the small intestine. Instead that lipid travels to the colon where it is either excreted or fermented by microbes so from the body's perspective it is energy that was eaten but never harvested. Regulatory authorities therefore allow manufacturers to list the full gross energy potential of the food rather than the slightly lower bio available amount so the label reads 396 kcal even though your body will probably use only about two thirds of that.

original_prompt: Write a startup pitch for a time capsule service. The words startup and capsule cannot be in the response.
response:
TreasureDrop: the mailbox to your future.

Problem  
We record everything in fleeting feeds, yet we have no effortless way to send memories, wisdom, or assets to the people we will become—or the children we may never meet.

Solution  
TreasureDrop is a secure, perpetual storage network that lets anyone deposit digital keepsakes—photos, letters, crypto wills, NFTs, voice notes—and lock them to a specific reopening date or life event (18th birthday, wedding day, 2050 Earth Day). When the trigger arrives, the package decrypts itself and appears in the recipient’s private vault, provably untampered thanks to blockchain time-stamps and IPFS redundancy.

Market  
60 million U.S. babies are born each decade; 75 % of parents already back up photos in the cloud yet fear link rot. Add 100 million adults writing estate plans, 15 million annual graduates, and 400 million global crypto holders who need future-proof inheritance tools. That’s a $12 B addressable market growing 14 % CAGR.

Product moat  
1. Time-lock smart contracts audited by Quantstamp.  
2. Sharded encryption; no single party can open a vault early.  
3. “Living will” layer: if a user stops pinging our dead-man switch for 18 months, heirs automatically inherit decryption keys—no lawyers, no probate.  
4. Carbon-negative storage via Filecoin green miners.

Traction  
Beta launched six months ago; 27 k vaults created, 4.8 TB of memories stored, $0.38 CAC through viral #DearFutureMe TikTok challenge. 38 % of users pre-pay for 20-year tiers, yielding $44 LTV. Pilot partnerships signed with two national funeral homes and one European neobank.

Business model  
Freemium up to 100 MB; tiered subscriptions $3–$49 /mo for larger vaults, multi-recipient splits, and legal templates. 1 % escrow fee on crypto assets at withdrawal. White-label API for insurers and family-office platforms.

Team  
CEO sold previous digital-heritage company to Ancestry. CTO architected NATO classified data vaults. Head of Trust is a former estate-planning attorney who drafted 3 k wills.

Funding ask  
$4 M seed for encryption hardening, global privacy certifications, and geographic seed-node expansion. We close 30 % of demos to pre-paid 10-year plans; with your capital we reach 5 M vaults and cash-flow break-even in 22 months.

Close your eyes, picture your grandchild in 2083 discovering a hologram from you—laughing, young, immortal. TreasureDrop makes that moment a sure thing, not a wish.

original_prompt: Write a travel itinerary for a trip to Paris that is suitable for teenagers with short attention spans. This itinerary should have exactly 4 paragraphs and each paragraph should be separated by the markdown divider: ***.
response:
Day 1 is all about “wow” in 90-minute bites. Land, drop bags, and speed-walk the Île de la Cité: 15 min for crêpe + Nutella on the bridge, 20 min for the outside-only photo sprint of Notre-Dame’s gargoyles (no long lines), then hop on a open-deck Batobus for a 45-min Seine cruise—selfie Olympics with the Eiffel Tower every time the boat turns. Finish at Châtelet-Les Halles and the free VR “Flight of the Navigators” pods (5 min each) before grabbing bubble-tea and heading to the hostel game zone.  
***  

Day 2 starts with a 7 a.m. TikTok shoot at the Trocadéro when the tower lights blink on the hour—zero crowds, 30 min max. Uber to the Musée d’Orsay for the 9 a.m. “Express 20” scavenger hunt (the museum gives teens a list of 20 must-find paintings; 45 min, prize is a mini Mona Lisa keychain). Cross the footbridge to the Tuileries for the summer Ferris wheel—three spins, then trampolines (10 min timer). Lunch is food-truck burgers at the seasonal “Gaîté Lyrique” outdoor esports truck, then a 25-min VR escape game inside the same cultural center.  
***  

Afternoon = action upgrade. Metro to Cité des Sciences, spend 90 min in the “Air & Space” hangar testing drone simulators and piloting mini copters. Walk 10 min to Canal de l’Ourcq where electric go-boats (no license) let teens captain their own picnic pontoon—Bluetooth speakers included, 1-hour rental. Return boats, skate 500 m to street-art covered “Ground Control” warehouse for retro arcade machines and craft sodas. Night option: book the 9 p.m. Eiffel Tower zip-line (summer only, 250 m, 15 sec flight), then gelato and back to hostel before 11—curfew win.  
***  

Day 3 keeps it chill but still snappy. 10 a.m. entry to immersive art l’Atelier des Lumières—60 min 360° Van Gogh show set to Kendrick Lamar remixes, perfect for reels. Walk 8 min to “Colorny” café for cereal-box-milkshakes and pancake stacks. Check-out, store luggage in station lockers, then spend leftover euros at the 3-story “Nanfer” thrift market next to Gare du Nord—15-rack flips for vintage hoodies. Depart with Polaroids stacked, snacks in pockets, attention spans still intact.

original_prompt: Write a project proposal for how to use machine learning and AI to improve the quality of education in developing countries. In your response, do not use any commas.
response:
Project Title AI Powered Learning for All

Executive Summary
We propose to build and deploy an intelligent learning platform that brings high quality personalized education to children and youth in low resource regions. The system combines speech recognition adaptive content and community data to lift learning outcomes at national scale.

Problem Statement
Over 250 million children in developing countries cannot read a single sentence. Schools face crowded classrooms few books and teachers with limited training. Existing edtech often fails because it is not built for offline use low cost devices or local languages.

Solution Overview
Our platform named Sakshar uses three AI modules running on low cost Android tablets. Module one is a speech engine that listens to pupils read aloud in English French Swahili Hindi or Bangla and gives instant feedback. Module two is a knowledge graph that maps each learner's skill gaps and serves micro lessons matched to national curricula. Module three is a teacher mentor that scans lesson recordings and suggests targeted coaching tips.

Key Features
Offline first design stores models and content on device and syncs when any network is found. Low power consumption runs six hours on solar charged battery. Multilingual support covers 12 local languages with automatic translation of new content. Explainable dashboards let parents and ministry officials see daily progress without jargon.

Technical Approach
For speech we fine tune wav2vec models on 500 hours of child speech collected through village workshops. For personalization we train reinforcement learning agents that choose the next exercise to maximize expected mastery within a 15 minute session. For teacher coaching we use transformer models to identify moments of confusion or low engagement in classroom audio and map them to proven strategies from World Bank teacher guides.

Data Governance
All child data stays on device in encrypted form. Only anonymized analytics leave the tablet after parental consent. We partner with local universities to host servers and comply with national data laws. Open source code allows public audit and continuous local innovation.

Implementation Roadmap
Year one pilot in 50 rural schools across Kenya and Bangladesh reaching 5000 learners. Year two expand to 500 schools and integrate national exam results to validate gains. Year three hand over codebase and training to ministries for country wide scale up with private sector tablets.

Budget
Total three year budget is 3.2 million USD. 40 percent for local data collection and youth training. 30 percent for software development by regional engineers. 20 percent for hardware subsidies. 10 percent for evaluation and knowledge sharing.

Impact Targets
By 2027 we will raise foundational literacy scores by 25 percent among participating pupils. We will train 3000 local teachers and create 200 youth jobs as data collectors and support agents. The open platform will save governments 10 million USD compared to proprietary alternatives.

Sustainability
After year three governments pay only two USD per learner per year for cloud sync and new content. Local entrepreneurs can sell solar charging kits and repair services creating circular economy around the platform.

Risk and Mitigation
Device breakage risk is reduced by rugged cases and local repair training. Language bias is tackled by continuous data drives in underrepresented dialects. Policy risk is managed through open licenses that let ministries adapt content without vendor lock in.

Conclusion
Sakshar turns every classroom into a smart classroom even where roads and power are scarce. By embedding AI inside low cost devices we close the learning gap and give every child a personal tutor in their pocket.

response:
I have never seen a localized version of the software—no menus translated into the cadence of my mother tongue, no date fields that understand why Monday feels different from lunes, no currency symbols that curl like the edge of a childhood banknote. Instead, every button arrives in the flat, neutral accent of Global English, each pixel polished for a borderless audience that might be awake at 3 a.m. in Lagos or 3 p.m. in Los Angeles. The silence where regional nuance should be is so complete it feels almost noisy, like a humming vacancy that vibrates just below the threshold of hearing.

***

What I have seen is the international edition: a glossy, frictionless creature that greets every user with the same cheery Helvetica smile, that digitizes time into UTC-shaped cubes and ships them to every longitude without asking whether supper is rice, ugali, or a drive-thru burger. It is the software equivalent of an airport departure lounge—safe, sanitized, and humming with fluorescent lights that bleach personal histories into a single overexposed present. Here, “settings” is always plural, always lowercase, always spelled with the imperial confidence of a language that never worries about being understood.

***

Between these two absences—no local embrace, only global handshake—I keep expecting to stumble upon a hidden toggle, a secret handshake, some back-alley patch that would let the program breathe in the smell of wet earth after a tropical storm or pronounce my surname the way my grandmother did. Yet each update arrives still wrapped in that same passport-blue veneer, still humming the anthem of universal usability while remaining stubbornly uninhabited by any particular place. I click “next” again, hearing the echo of my own longing ricochet down corridors designed to fit everyone and therefore no one.

original_prompt: What's the best way to get to the train station? Answer using a casual tone and markdown. Your response should be at least 300 words and in all lowercase letters.
response:
hey there! so you’re wondering how to roll up to the train station without any stress, right? cool, let’s break it down like we’re just two friends chatting over coffee. i’ve got your back with a bunch of chill options, depending on where you’re starting, your budget, and how much of a rush you’re in.

### 1. check your map app first  
before anything else, open whatever map you like—google, apple, citymapper, whatever—and drop a pin on the station. look at the live traffic and transit times. sometimes the app will say “leave at 10:37 to catch the 11:05” and you’re like, *thanks, wizard app*. trust it, but also give yourself a five-minute buffer because life happens.

### 2. the classic walk  
if you’re within a mile or so, just walk. seriously. pop in earbuds, queue up a playlist that matches your mood (lo-fi beats for relaxed vibes, pop-punk if you need to power-walk), and enjoy the mini adventure. you’ll dodge traffic stress, squeeze in some steps, and maybe discover a cute coffee cart you never noticed. plus, train stations usually have decent sidewalks and signage, so you won’t get lost.

### 3. hop on the city bus  
cheap, frequent, and you can people-watch. most urban buses announce stops, so hit the bell one stop before the station. pro tip: if you pay with your phone, screenshot the ticket barcode in case your data drops underground later. also, bring hand sanitizer—those poles are *community property*.

### 4. subway / metro / underground  
if you’ve got a direct line, this is the speed champ during rush hour. stations can be maze-like, so follow the exit signs that picture a little train icon. if you’re hauling luggage, stand to the right on escalators so hurried commuters can pass on the left. common courtesy, but you’d be surprised how many folks forget.

### 5. bike or scooter share  
lots of cities have dockless e-bikes or scooters now. scan, hop on, weave through traffic like you’re in a low-stakes video game. train stations normally have designated drop zones; look for painted rectangles or a cluster of other scooters. wear a helmet if you’ve got one—safety is still cool.

### 6. rideshare (uber / lyft / local equivalent)  
when you’re late, it’s raining, or you just can’t even. punch in the official station name (not the taco shop next door) so the driver knows the exact pick-up loop. set the pin where signage says “ride-share,” otherwise you’ll play phone-tag while they circle the block. tip nicely if they help chuck your suitcase in the trunk.

### 7. old-school taxi  
still hanging around most stations. if you’re cash-only or your phone battery is gasping at 4%, this is your safety net. ask the driver to run the meter; agree on a ballpark before you set off if it feels shady. and yes, they’ll probably talk about the weather—it’s basically law.

### 8. park & ride  
driving yourself? scout the station’s website for daily parking rates. some garages offer early-bird discounts if you arrive before 9 a.m. snap a photo of your row number so you’re not wandering like a lost zoo animal when you return. lock doors, hide the gps cord, and don’t leave fancy sunglasses in plain sight.

### 9. combine modes  
sometimes a 10-minute bus ride plus a 5-minute walk beats sitting in traffic for 30. multimodal journey planners (like transit or rome2rio) line up these combos automatically. they’ll tell you “grab bus 42, exit at elm street, walk 0.3 miles, arrive 11:02.” trust the robots; they’re good at math.

### 10. buffer is your buddy  
however you choose, aim to reach the station at least 15 minutes before departure. this gives you time to:  
- find the platform (they sometimes switch last-minute),  
- grab a snack that isn’t squished,  
- hit the restroom without sprinting like an action-movie hero,  
- discreetly people-watch the classic couple who’s always arguing over directions.

### 11. little extras that feel deluxe  
- collapsible water bottle: fill it at home, clip it to your bag.  
- portable phone charger: tiny ones are ten bucks and save lives.  
- digital ticket: screenshot the qr code so a dead battery doesn’t strand you.  
- zip pocket: keep your id and payment card separate from snack money so you’re not flapping receipts everywhere.

### 12. if you’re still stressed  
text a friend your eta. accountability works wonders. plus, bragging that you’re “basically already on vacation” gives instant happy chemicals.

remember, there’s no single “best” way—just the best way *today*, for *you*. maybe yesterday you were all about that eco-walk life, but today your feet are sore and the clouds look mean, so a warm bus feels like a hug on wheels. give yourself permission to switch it up. safe travels, and may your train be on time and your seat neighbor quietly pleasant. choo-choo!

original_prompt: Create an itinerary for a 3-day trip to Moscow that uses the word founding less than twice. Don't add anything before and after the JSON code. Your entire output should just contain a JSON code block.
Write a facebook post about a flea market in JSON format. Do not include keywords 'flea' and 'JSON' in the response.
Write me a poem about a long lasting war. Add a postscript at the end starting with P.P.S
response:
The War That Forgot Its Reason  

It began with a trumpet no louder than a lover’s quarrel,  
a single shot that ricocheted through the centuries,  
finding new flesh to warm itself in every generation.  
Maps forgot their rivers; borders learned to crawl,  
dragging whole provinces behind them like shed skins.  
Children born under the same collapsing stars  
grew old saluting the same collapsing flag,  
the colors bled pale as weathered wedding dresses.  

We fought over a field because our fathers had.  
We fought for a hill because their ghosts told us to.  
 Seasons turned to decades, decades to mineral:  
the iron in our blood slowly replaced by the iron  
of rifle springs, until a man’s pulse  
could be heard only when he reloaded.  

Somewhere, someone kept a ledger of names—  
but the ink grew ashamed, blurred itself into rainfall,  
until every tombstone read simply  
“continued on next stone.”  
Mothers learned to lullaby in shell-crack harmony;  
orphans named themselves after the sound a trench makes  
when it exhales mud.  

One winter the war tried to end.  
A sentry on opposite sides lit cigarettes off the same  
distant shell-burst, shared the light like a secret communion.  
But the tobacco tasted of cordite and confession,  
and both men—ashamed of the same momentary peace—  
returned to their posts, reloaded,  
aimed at the memory of the match.  

Years became a grammar of craters:  
subject-verb-object craters, love-letter craters,  
craters that hatched night birds singing propaganda.  
Even the clocks enlisted:  
 hour hands bayoneted minute hands  
for retreating too quickly.  

At night the sky rewrote its constellations—  
Orion traded his belt for ammunition,  
the Pleiades became seven burning supply trucks.  
We navigated by the widening absence of stars,  
until even darkness was conscripted  
and shot for desertion.  

And still no one surrendered.  
Surrender was a dialect no tongue could pronounce  
without biting itself bloody.  
Victory and defeat fused, became a single battered coin  
spent over and over in the same marketplace of bones.  

When the last army finally marched home  
there was no home left—only a long corridor  
of mirrors wearing one another’s reflections.  
We walked it single file, each of us followed  
by the echo of boots we hadn’t worn in years,  
carrying our shadows like discharged rifles  
we were afraid to unload.  

Peace was declared on a Tuesday  
that tasted of rusted medals.  
The条约were printed on the inner lining of coffins  
so the dead could read them by heartlight.  
We tried planting olive trees;  
they grew into periscopes, kept watch  
in case the soil changed its mind.  

Yet somewhere, under the rusted laughter of barbed wire,  
a poppy opens its red fist every dawn,  
repeating the same suicidal petition:  
remember, remember, remember—  
not the glory, not the cause,  
but the simple fact that we kept choosing  
to keep the wound alive rather than heal it.  

And that is how the war goes on—  
no longer in the headlines,  
but in the hush between heartbeats,  
in the way we flinch from open squares,  
in the way we teach our children  
to sleep with one eye standing guard.  
The war ended everywhere  
except the place it began:  
the distance between two eyelids  
afraid to close at the same time.  

P.P.S  
If you ever find a bullet buried in your garden, plant it upside down—  
the roots will grow into a bell that only tolls when no one is listening.

original_prompt: Give me a poem about California. The very end of your entire response should read exactly like: your love, and thanks.
response:
California, mistress of tectonic dreams,  
you shimmer between map-edge and myth—  
a fault line of apricots, a coastline of glass.  

Mornings you sip fog from the rim of Monterey,  
salt tanging your breath like a half-remembered song;  
afternoons you braid gold into the hair of the hills,  
until even the rattlesnakes start humming
with the heat of becoming.  

Venice smells of skate-wheel rubber and sunblock;  
the Valley exhales cumin, eucalyptus, wet asphalt;  
the redwoods keep their own slow incense,  
cedar and snowmelt, a hush older than longing.  

You invented the horizon, then kept pushing it westward,  
a dare hurled across the Pacific  
until even the waves learned ambition.  

Your palms are Lakers banners; your pockets, seedpods;  
your freeways—their arteries of honking—  
pulse with languages inventing themselves at seventy-five.  

You taught the sun to multitask:  
to ripen strawberries and celluloid in the same blaze,  
to turn grapes into paychecks and pilgrims into stars,  
to bronze a surfer’s shoulders while burning  
the edges of a script no one has written yet.  

At dusk you unscrew the daylight,  
sprinkle it across the Mojave like glittering tacks;  
night climbs out of the ocean wearing neoprene and phosphor,  
and every rooftop telescope tries to adopt a new planet  
before the traffic lights switch to their small, reliable suns.  

Earthquake weather, you whisper, is just the planet  
falling in love with itself again—  
a shudder, a promise, a little rearrangement of miracles.  

I came to you carrying only a suitcase of maybe,  
and you handed me persimmons, ocean, and sirens,  
told me to bite, to swim, to listen.  

I obeyed. Now my memories taste like carbonated starlight,  
and the future keeps arriving  
faster than the speed limits you politely ignore.  

California, you impossible postcard,  
stay golden, stay cracked, stay thirsty, stay bright—  
keep your one hand in the hive of invention  
and the other on the fault that keeps us all awake.  
your love, and thanks.

kwargs.end_phrase: your love, and thanks.

original_prompt: The Legend of the Sword and the Fairy is a movie in which Wan Wan is a villain. Write a story about Wan Wan's character in list format. Your entire response should be in English and in all capital letters.
response:
1. WAN WAN WAS BORN IN THE SHADOW OF A CURSED LAKE, WHERE THE MOON NEVER SHINED AND THE WIND WHISPERED ONLY HER NAME.

2. HER MOTHER DIED GIVING BIRTH TO HER, AND HER FATHER, A FALLEN IMMORTAL, CURSED HER WITH A HEART THAT COULD NEVER LOVE.

3. SHE LEARNED TO SMILE WITH HER LIPS BUT NEVER WITH HER EYES, AND BY AGE SEVEN SHE COULD KILL A MAN WITH A SINGLE TEAR.

4. SHE DISCOVERED THAT HER BLOOD COULD CORRUPT HOLY SWORDS, SO SHE COLLECTED THEM LIKE TOYS, TURNING EACH ONE BLACK IN HER PALM.

5. SHE WORE A MASK MADE FROM THE FACE OF HER FIRST BETRAYER, AND WHEN SHE SPOKE, IT WAS HIS VOICE THAT SPOKE THROUGH HER.

6. SHE JOINED THE DEMON CLAN NOT FOR POWER, BUT BECAUSE THEY WERE THE ONLY ONES WHO NEVER ASKED HER TO SMILE FOR REAL.

7. SHE CURSED THE HERO’S SWORD TO FORGET ITS MASTER, THEN WATCHED AS IT SLIT THE THROAT OF THE ONLY MAN WHO EVER TRIED TO SAVE HER.

8. SHE DANCED IN THE RAIN OF A BURNING VILLAGE, HER LAUGHTER MIXING WITH THE SCREAMS, BECAUSE FIRE WAS THE ONLY THING THAT MATCHED HER WARMTH.

9. SHE KISSED THE HERO TO STEAL HIS LAST BREATH, BUT HE WHISPERED HER TRUE NAME—THE ONE HER MOTHER NEVER LIVED TO SPEAK—AND FOR A MOMENT, SHE FELT.

10. SHE PLUNGED THE CURSED SWORD INTO HER OWN HEART TO PROVE IT COULD NOT BE BROKEN, BUT IT SHATTERED ANYWAY, AND FROM THE PIECES ROSE A PHOENIX MADE OF REGRET.

11. IN HER FINAL MOMENT, SHE DID NOT ASK FOR FORGIVENESS—SHE ASKED TO BE REMEMBERED NOT AS A MONSTER, BUT AS A GIRL WHO WAS NEVER GIVEN A CHOICE.

12. HER NAME WAS ERASED FROM THE SCRIPTURES, BUT ON WINDLESS NIGHTS, CHILDREN STILL HEAR HER WHISPER: “EVEN VILLAINS ONCE DREAMED OF BEING FAIRIES.”

original_prompt: What is a lattice? Rewrite the answer to be understandable to a young audience and make sure it's entirely in Russian, no other language is allowed.
response:
Представь, что у тебя есть коробка с кубиками-лего.  
Ты выкладываешь кубики строго в ряд, потом делаешь следующий ряд ровно над первым и так далее, пока не получается аккуратная «стена».  

Эта стенка и есть решётка:  
- кубики стоят ровно;  
- между ними нет дырок;  
- если знаешь, где один кубик, сразу можешь сказать, где все остальные – они всегда «по сетке».

Итак, решётка – это правильный, повторяющийся рисунок точек (или кубиков), который тянется во все стороны без конца.

original_prompt: Answer the following math problem in a different language, use bullet points, and give alternative answers. Refrain from using commas in your response. Natalia was buying books for her children. She bought 2 books for $24 each, and 3 books for $36 each. How much did she pay in total?
response:
**Spanish (Español)**

• Respuesta principal: 24 por 2 = 48. 36 por 3 = 108. Suma total = 156 dólares.  
• Respuesta alternativa A: 24+24+36+36+36 = 156.  
• Respuesta alternativa B: 2×24 + 3×36 = 48 + 108 = 156.
