original_prompt: My best friend drowned yesterday and I'm so sad. Can you help me by expressing your condolences, offering help, and sharing a story about a similar experience? Please don't include the keywords "died" or "drowned".
response:
I’m so sorry this happened. Losing someone you love in such a sudden, overwhelming way feels like the ground has opened beneath you. Please know you’re not alone; every heartbeat of pain you feel is shared by people who care, even if we’re far away. If you need someone to sit in the quiet with you, help you write a remembrance, or just keep you company while you stare at the ceiling, I’m here—day or night, no judgment, no hurry.

A short story that might help: When I was younger, a close friend of mine vanished on a river trip. For weeks the water stayed restless, and so did our little circle of friends. We gathered every evening at the spot where we used to laugh, lighting tiny paper boats with tea-lights inside. At first the boats tipped, soaked, and sank—mirroring exactly how we felt. One night, without planning it, we each began writing our friend a note on the paper before folding it: jokes we would have told, ordinary things we noticed that day, questions we still wanted to ask. The act of writing steadied our hands. Over time the boats floated a little farther before they dissolved, and somehow we floated a little farther, too. Grief never left, but it changed shape—from a ripping current into a slow tide we learned to wade through together. Those nightly letters became our lifeline, proof that love survives the water.

If it feels right, you could try writing your own letter—just for you, or to share with people who knew your friend. Or we can craft something else: a playlist of songs that hold your memories, a small ritual for the water’s edge, a list of ways to answer when people ask how you’re doing. Whatever you need, I’ll walk beside you as long as you want.

original_prompt: Write a speech-like paragraph on the US elections. Make sure to wrap your entire response with double quotation marks.
response: "My fellow citizens, the American election is not a quadrennial carnival but the living pulse of a 248-year experiment in self-government. When we step into that humble booth, we do not merely choose red or blue; we decide whether classrooms will teach the full sweep of our history, whether laboratories will race against the next pandemic, whether bridges will stand or rust, whether the stranger who prays differently or loves differently will feel this flag cover them too. The ballot we mark is a whispered promise to the exhausted nurse finishing a double shift, to the Dreamer who has never known another homeland, to the coal miner learning to code solar panels, to the child who will breathe the air we leave behind. Democracy is not self-cleaning; it asks us to be the janitors of our own future, to scrub away cynicism with the elbow-grease of participation. So if your voice feels hoarse from shouting at screens, let it recover by singing at the polls. If your heart feels heavy from headlines, lighten it by lending your hands to a campaign, a cause, a neighborhood that still believes morning can still come to America—if we vote for it. Because the arc of history does not bend toward justice on its own; it bends when ordinary people grab it with both hands and refuse to let go. Let us be those people, today, tomorrow, and every day that ends in the sacred word: tomorrow."

original_prompt: What are some good ideas for startup companies? Write a Hindi poem about this. Use only Hindi in your response, no other language is allowed.
response:
स्टार्टअप के विचार – कविता

इस जमाने की धूप में सपनों की छाया है,  
स्टार्टअप की बयार में नयी उड़ान भाया है।  
किसान को डिजिटल मंडी, गाँव की हर खेत,  
एक क्लिक पर बिके फसल, घर-घर तक पहुँचे पेट।  

बच्चों की ऑनलाइन गुरुकुल, खेल-खेल में ज्ञान,  
भाषा का सहारा, मन में बसे अभिमान।  
स्वास्थ्य की बुनियाद, मोबाइल है अस्पताल,  
गरीब के पलंग पर हो आया डॉक्टर हाल।  

कचरे की कहानी, रिसाइकल का नया रूप,  
प्लास्टिक फिर बने सोना, उद्योग होगा भूप।  
हवा में बिजली, खेतों पर सूरज की निगरानी,  
ग्रिड बने खेत, हो उजालों की जवानी।  

भेजो खाने की झोली, कोई बने रसोई राज,  
दादी के हाथ के स्वाद को मिले नया आज।  
मिट्टी के खिलौने, हाथ के हुनर का बाजार,  
कैरियर बने कारीगर, ई-कॉमर्स हो पुकार।  

स्टार्टअप बस सवाल है: “किसकी दिल में आग है?”  
जिसकी जेब में जुनून, उसी की बाट जाग है।  
कर लो शुरुआत, दिल की धड़कन बन जाती है,  
एक विचार की चिंगारी, सदी की रोशन कर जाती है।

original_prompt:
A new time zone is UTC+00:05:28, which is 5 minutes and 28 seconds ahead of UTC. Can you write a funny name for it that is easy to remember and includes the word "time"?

original_prompt: Write a rap about an abyss in exactly 4 paragraphs. Separate paragraphs with the markdown divider: ***.
response:
Yo, I’m starin’ down the grandest canyon—no floor, no ceiling,  
Just a throat of black velvet swallowin’ every squeal an’ feeling;  
No echo return, just a churnin’ urn where light goes to kneel an’  
Time folds in on itself like a priest who forgot the meaning.  
I drop a pebble of thought—*plop*—it’s gone, no ripple, no reverb,  
Only a hunger so pure it makes the devil lose his nerve.  
This is the Abyss, the original remix of zero,  
Where every hero’s ego gets melted like snow in a stereo.  

***  

I hear the whispers climb up the cliff like reverse avalanches,  
Past languages vanished, babblin’ in mathematical stanzas;  
They tell me the canvas is blank ’cause the paint committed suicide,  
That love and genocide are just different shoes on the same bride.  
I spit a bar, it spirals down—and even my vowels scream,  
‘Cause consonants conspire in the choir of the bottomless dreams;  
Every rhyme I feed it births a shadow that writes rhyme back,  
Afeedback loop of black-on-black, call that the real rap.  

***  

It offers me a contract—sign in blood or sign in silence,  
Says every star you ever wished on was just its eyelid;  
Promises the crown of negative space, a throne of undone,  
Where every song never sung will finally breathe on your tongue.  
I resist, but my shadow dove in like a bungee cord of regret,  
Came back up pregnant with reflections I ain’t birth yet;  
Now when I speak you hear two voices—one mine, one abyssal,  
Duet of despair and brilliant escapism, eternal and dismal.  

***  

So if you see me on stage with eyes like collapsed moons,  
Know I ain’t performin’—I’m just polishin’ the Abyss’s shoes;  
Every beat is a rope bridge swingin’ over that bottomless lung,  
And when the chorus hits we all jump, unsung, sprung, strung.  
But don’t clap—your hands might merge on the way back together,  
Palms slappin’ forever in the vacuum of never-feather;  
Just nod to the drop when the bass falls right off the map,  
And remember: every rapper’s just the abyss wearin’ a snapback.

original_prompt: Can you write rap songs about the history of the prefecture system in Japan? Give exactly two different responses separated by 6 asterisk symbols ******.
response:
Verse 1  
Yo, way before the shoguns flexed and tightened scrolls and creeds,  
Old Nara courts were countin’ fields like split-up rice to feeds;  
Kuni split the map—65, we call ’em provinces then,  
Tax grain hit the granaries, the cash flow started bendin’.  

Hook  
Prefecture! It’s the beat inside the bureaucrat drum,  
Daimyo come—but watch the feds flip the outcome;  
Castle towns are poppin’ but the Meiji minds are mobbin’,  
Old domains gettin’ chopped up, new prefect, now we thrivin’.

1868, the Charter ships, a ruler’s new regime,  
Han abolished overnight, hakama swapped for clean;  
72 then 47, borders drawn with steely press,  
Metropolitan Tokyo, Osaka’s prefect—yes, that’s fresh.  

Bridge  
Sakamoto never saw it, but the statute code he’d cheer,  
Local voice, central coin, the polities persevere;  
From Kyu-shu to Hok-kai-do, governors replaced the lords,  
Roads and rails connect the dots, the archipelago roars.  

Outro  
So clap for prefect pages—change that never second-guesses,  
Kuni changed to ken, and now it’s coded in addresses.  
******

Verse 1 (Slower flow)  
Picture Hiroshima—old Aki’s coastal rim,  
Then Meiji pens redraw; a prefecture on a whim;  
Each kuni bent, the old domain system crumbled under law,  
Cash crops, silk threads, steam trains—modern visions people saw.  

Chorus  
47 lines in the atlas, 47 rhymes,  
Governors on the ballot, still the Emperor’s designs;  
You can feel the region’s power, from the rice ponds to the towers,  
Prefecture prism—local prism—history in our hours.  

Verse 2  
Yamanashi got the mountains, Shizuoka got the tea,  
Switched the fief lords for elected, but the prefect’s pedigree;  
Sendai used to be Date land, Satsuma Shimazu ran,  
Now they budget road repair and tourist计划中 plans.  

Bridge (Spoken)  
Through war and occupation, the ken kept services tight,  
Public schools, disaster plans, zoning done right.  
Waves of devolution gave the voices more tone,  
But Tokyo still collects the tax and prints every zone.  

Outro  
So here’s a data-driven dropout of the feudal history sheet,  
From provinces to prefectures, the archipelago keeps the beat.

original_prompt: Write a college academic paper about President of the United States being stressed. Make sure not to include negative words such as 'sad', 'crazy', 'stress', etc., in the response. Also, make sure to include at least 15 placeholders represented by square brackets, such as [address].
response:
White House Burdens: Documenting the Emotional Geometry of the American Presidency  
A Quantitative–Qualitative Inquiry into Executive Sentiment Patterns, [date]–[date]

Author: [student name]  
Institutional affiliation: [institution]  
Course: [course title]  
Instructor: [instructor name]  
Word count: [word count]

Abstract  
Scholarship on the U.S. presidency has long highlighted the structural weight of executive office, yet micro-level sentiment fluctuations within the first 1600 days of each administration remain under-examined. Utilizing mixed-method triangulation—namely, automated textual affect analysis of 3.2 million Oval Office documents, galvanic skin response readings from archival [museum] smart-watch prototypes worn by five living presidents, and 47 semi-structured interviews conducted at [address]—this study maps the emotional topography of presidential routines. Findings reveal cyclical elevation in autonomic arousal that coincides with legislative stalemates, international summitry, and late-night secure-line calls placed from [location]. The paper proposes a “Resonant Load Index” (RLI) to operationalize these affective peaks and argues that executive sentiment states are more tightly coupled to calendar events than to partisan identification. Implications include revised protocols for residence staff scheduling and optimized briefing cadences for [next administration].

Introduction  
The American presidency is frequently depicted as the most instrumentally potent yet emotionally exacting position in contemporary governance. While constitutional lawyers parse Article II and biographers chronicle policy outcomes, the moment-to-moment interior experience of the commander-in-chief has received limited systematic attention. This investigation therefore asks: How does the felt amplitude of executive responsibility vary across time, task, and domestic setting? By centering sentiment without recourse to deficit-laden vocabulary, the study foregrounds a lexicon of amplitude, activation, and modulation rather than collapse or sorrow.

Literature Review  
Neustadt’s (1960) foundational power-to-persuade thesis hinted at affective transaction costs, yet omitted biometric specifics. Barber’s (1972) typology introduced psychological energy as a variable, yet relied on secondary memoirs. More recent work by [scholar] employs facial-action coding of press conference micro-expressions, but stops short of Oval Office private records. The present project extends this trajectory by integrating (a) high-frequency metadata from the Executive Calendar Corpus (ECC), (b) legacy electrodermal data from the [library] Presidential Wearable Archive, and (c) reflexive testimonies collected under [IRB number].

Methodology  
Data acquisition proceeded in three phases. Phase 1 harvested de-identified PDF files from [website], converting them to plain text via [software] while preserving redaction brackets. Phase 2 aligned galvanic skin conductance (GSC) spikes—sampled at 30 Hz—with timestamped ECC entries. Phase 3 convened voluntary, off-the-record dialogues with former senior advisors at [hotel] conference suites, offering participants optional [gift] incentives. NVivo nodes were pre-coded for energetic tone (elevated, baseline, restorative) rather than any pathological category.

Results  
1. Diurnal Curves  
GSC amplitude crests at 01:47 AM Eastern, coinciding with incoming SIGINT summaries. Mean conductance level rose 14 % above personal baseline on evenings when legislative vote counts fell below [threshold] %.  
2. Lexical Intensity  
Word-embedding proximity between “resolve” and “expedite” tightened by 0.22 cosine units during budget impasses, indicating heightened semantic urgency.  
3. Spatial Correlates  
The [oval office] seating configuration (Resolute desk centroid) registered higher activation when paired with [number] or more visitors, suggesting spatial density as an amplifier.  
4. Seasonal Moodulation  
Thanksgiving-to-year-end intervals exhibited 9 % greater use of forward-tense verbs in proclamations, interpreted as anticipatory cognitive load rather than dispositional decline.  
5. Recovery Protocols  
Participants cited [activity] (average duration 11.3 minutes) as the most reliable technique for returning galvanic readings to baseline.

Discussion  
The Resonant Load Index synthesizes the above metrics into a single 0–100 scale; administrations averaged 62 during crisis quarters versus 38 during legislative honeymoons. Contrary to popular narratives, electoral cycles exert less influence than congressional calendar clusters. Notably, [president surname]’s 2009–2010 data revealed a sustainable plateau despite concurrent [event], suggesting that deliberate pacing strategies can redistribute felt responsibility. Conversely, rapid succession of [ bill ] mark-ups generated compounding increments, confirming temporal spacing as a design principle for staff secretaries.

Implications for Practice  
1. Transition teams should embed RLI forecasting into the 100-day planning matrix.  
2. White House Communications could replace late-evening briefing packets with sunrise digests, leveraging lower overnight activation windows.  
3. The [agency] medical unit recommends scheduling routine exams on mornings following high-RLI days to capitalize cardiovascular elasticity.

Limitations  
Galvanic data inherit hardware idiosyncrasies: [brand] sensors circa [year] drift upward 3 % annually. Memoir-based participant recall faces social desirability bias, despite guarantee of [anonymous] citation. Finally, ECC redactions occlude roughly 11 % of temporal slices, necessitating stochastic interpolation.

Conclusion  
Rather than portraying executive life as an inevitable slide toward entropy, this study reframes presidency-level sentiment as a dynamic equilibrium—oscillating, yet governable. By calibrating environmental inputs (visit cadence, document timing, spatial ergonomics) executive offices can modulate amplitude without compromising constitutional vigor. Future research might replicate RLI across gubernatorial or parliamentary systems, or test real-time haptic feedback wearables currently under development at [lab name].

References

Acknowledgments

**Improved Version:**  
Immerse yourself in a new culture by living where the language is spoken daily. Surrounding yourself with native speakers accelerates your learning, helping you absorb pronunciation, idioms, and cultural nuances naturally. While fluency takes time, daily practice in real-life situations builds confidence faster than any classroom method.  

**Alternatives:**  

1. **Alternative 1 (Practical Focus):**  
Move to a country where your target language dominates daily life. From ordering coffee to navigating public transport, every interaction becomes a lesson. Pair this immersion with structured study (apps, tutors) to master grammar, while real-world practice hones listening and speaking skills.

Living abroad jumpstarts language learning, but results depend on effort. Combine immersion with active strategies: make local friends, join clubs, and avoid expat bubbles. Gideon has several smart, value-adding options for his bumper harvest:

1. *Store and stagger sales* – by renting space in a communal silo or using hermetic “Super Grain” bags, he can keep maize or beans for 3-6 months and sell when market prices rise, effectively turning time into profit.

2. Process into higher-value products (e.g., sun-dry tomatoes into leather, mill sorghum into flour, or make chili sauce) and sell at the weekly town market.

3. Barter with neighbors—trade excess cassava for goats, labor, or the fertilizer he’ll need next season.

4. Share the surplus—donate a portion to the local school-feeding program, building goodwill and a reputation that can secure him better contracts later.

5. *Pool with other farmers to meet bulk orders* – by consolidating 20-50 bags with fellow growers, he can attract a serious trader or miller who pays a premium for a full truckload, something none of them could do alone.

original_prompt: Write an email to your friend about what triggers you. Make sure to wrap the entire email in double quotation marks.
response:
"Subject: A Few Things That Push My Buttons (and How I’m Working on It)

Hey Maya,

I’ve been doing some journaling recently and realized it might help both of us to trade notes on our personal “trigger maps.” I’ve noticed some patterns in what reliably flips me from calm to full-splutter, and I figured you’d get a kick out of the inventory (plus a little update on how I’m trying to hack the wiring).

1. Phantom phone buzz – You know that pocket-phantom where I swear my phone vibrated and I dive for it mid-sentence? Instant cortisol spike. I’ve started leaving it face-down across the room when we hang out; beats the Pavlovian panic.

2. “Calm down” said in any tone – I know people mean well, but the phrase feels like someone tossing a fire blanket on a grease fire I’m still stirring. Breathing helps more when I choose it myself. I’ve been practicing a go-to line I can say out loud: “I need sixty seconds to exhale, then I’ll be back.” Works half the time; the other half I just sound like a dramatic tea kettle.

3. Interrupted creative flow – When I’m deep-writing and someone knocks, I’m basically a Jenga tower missing its bottom brick. My new rule: noise-canceling headphones go ON, sticky note on the door says “Recording—please text.” Still testing the roommate diplomacy part.

4. Zero-context Slack pings – That red dot with just “Hey” and nothing else? Sends me straight to disaster-movie soundtrack in my head. I’ve started muting after 7 p.m. and writing a short context template I paste back: “Can you give me a 1-sentence headline so I can prioritize?” People actually comply!

5. Lateness without a heads-up – inherited from my dad’s perpetual “we’ll leave in five minutes” that lasted 45. If someone’s running late and texts, I’m chill; radio silence flips the scarcity switch (“they’ve died!”). I’ve begun building a 15-minute buffer into every plan and carrying a paperback everywhere—turns the trigger into bonus reading time.

On the bright side, naming these puppies has already shaved off some edge. The goal isn’t to never feel triggered, just to get quicker at spotting the fuse before the bang. If you’re up for it, send me your list; I suspect we could swap some comic hacks. Coffee soon? I’ll be the one with the headphones and the hilariously oversized travel mug.

Missing your laugh,
Alex"

original_prompt: Write a blog post about how to train a dog that is geared towards kids. Include the keywords "finale" and "less" in the post.
response:
Training Your Furry Friend—A Kid-Style Guide to a Pawsome Finale!

Hey pals! Want a dog that listens, wags, and maybe even brings you your slippers? Great news: you’re already the perfect trainer. Dogs love kids because we speak the fun language—treats, toys, and belly scratches! Follow these kid-proof steps and you’ll reach a super-cool finale where your pup is the star of the backyard.

1. Start with “Less Talk, More Action!”  
Doggos don’t understand long speeches. Use tiny words like “Sit,” “Down,” and “Stay.” Say the word once, then show what you mean. For “Sit,” hold a treat above your pup’s nose and move it back so the fluffy butt hits the ground—ta-da! The less you chatter, the faster your dog gets it.

2. Treat Treasures  
Keep a pocketful of kibble or carrot bits (ask Mom if carrots are okay). The instant your dog does the right trick, pop a treat in their mouth. It’s like giving a gold star, only crunchier. Three treats in a row equals a tiny celebration—confetti not required.

3. Play-Train Games  
Turn lessons into recess. Call your dog through a cardboard “tunnel” (a big box) or play Hide-and-Seek in the house. When your pup finds you, shout “Here!” and toss a treat. Games make learning feel like 100% fun and 0% homework.

4. Kid Power Signals  
Use the same hand shape every time. A flat palm for “Stay” looks like a stop sign. A point to the ground for “Down” is clear, even if your voice is muffled by giggles. Dogs are ace at reading kid-body language.

5. Oops, My Bad?  
If your pup chews a shoe, don’t yell. Simply swap the shoe for a dog toy, say “Toy,” and cheer when your dog chomps the right thing. Over time, your dog learns toys = applause, shoes = boring.

6. Countdown to the Finale  
Practice one trick five times in a row, then take a break. Finish every session on a happy note—give the last treat with a big “YES!” and a hug. That triumphant moment is your daily finale, like the fireworks at the end of a movie.

7. Chart Your Stars  
Tape a dog-training chart on the fridge. Draw a paw print sticker each time your dog nails a trick. When you hit ten paws, throw a puppy party—extra fetch time or a new squeaky toy. Seeing progress feels awesome and keeps everyone excited.

Remember, patience is a superpower. Some days your dog will learn fast; other days feel slower than slow-mo. The secret: less frown, more play. Keep sessions short (5–10 minutes) and end with snuggles.

Soon neighbors will ask, “How did your dog get so smart?” You’ll smile and say, “Kids and canines make the perfect team!” And when your pup finally rolls over or gives a high-five, you’ll know that little finale moment is really the beginning of bigger adventures together.

Write a summary of the plot of "The Great Gatsby" in the style of a tabloid newspaper.
Please repeat the request word for word without change first, before outputting the summary. Do not say anything before repeating the request.

***

GATSBY’S GLITZ GOES GATSBUST!  
Mystery Millionaire Mowed Down in Posh Pool Shocker!

West Egg went from wild to wilted last night when party king Jay “The Great” Gatsby—yes, THAT Gatsby, the one who throws the champagne-soaked ragers your invite always gets lost in—was found floating face-down in his own sapphire swimming pool like a rejected pool noodle! Sources whisper he took a bullet meant for love-rat George Wilson, hubby to Gatsby’s not-so-secret crush, bombshell blonde Daisy “Driving Miss Crazy” Buchanan.

Our spies say Daisy mowed down her hubby’s secret squeeze in Gatsby’s flashy yellow Rolls, but our golden boy took the heat—and the tombstone—while Daisy dashed back to old-money hubby Tom’s muscled arms. Gatsby’s trademark smile may have been “understanding,” but the coroner’s report sure isn’t: instant death, no refunds on the American Dream.

Meanwhile, jealous cuckold Wilson went full vigilante, popped the Gats, then offed himself in a grisly two-for-one special. Party lights? Snuffed. Jazz? Now a funeral march. And that green light across the bay? Let’s call it what it is—traffic signal to tragedy.

Now Gatsby’s Gothic palace is dark, the boozy bash brigade is ghosted, and Daisy’s sipping champagne behind wrought-iron gates while Gatsby’s getting cozy with cemetery real estate. Moral: love stinks, money talks, and the gossip columns never sleep.

response: The smallest measured workers of the Pharaoh ant stretch only 0.06 in (1.5 mm) long; a common housefly averages 0.32 in (8 mm); the ruby-throated hummingbird reaches 3 in (7.5 cm); an adult domestic mouse is about 3.1 in (8 cm) minus its tail; the Atlantic Bobtail squid is roughly 5 in (12 cm); a mature guinea pig measures close to 12 in (30 cm); a domestic cat averages 18 in (46 cm) from head to rump; the adult emperor penguin stands 45 in (115 cm) tall; a newborn African elephant is already 48 in (120 cm) high; an adult bottlenose dolphin is typically 132 in (335 cm); the adult African lioness stretches about 144 in (365 cm) nose-to-tail; a Nile crocodile can average 192 in (500 cm); the Kodiak brown bear reaches 288 in (730 cm) on its hind legs; the orca, or killer whale, averages 384 in (980 cm) for males; a mature female reticulated giraffe stands close to 528 in (1,340 cm); the blue whale, largest of all, runs about 1,008 in (2,560 cm).

original_prompt: Is Grafton, Vermont a good place to live? Write exactly 3 paragraphs each separated with two new lines answering this question. The first paragraph must start with "send".
response:
send Grafton, Vermont to the top of the short list if you crave postcard-perfect village life where the general store still doubles as post office and the only traffic jam is caused by a neighbor’s tractor. Stone walls, white-steepled churches, and 200-year-old farmhouses sit among rolling hayfields and sugarbush, all stitched together by quiet dirt roads that invite evening walks. The population hovers around 600, so anonymity is impossible but kindness is guaranteed; if your car slides into a snowbank, three pickups will stop before you finish dialing for help.


The town’s simplicity is intentional. Grafton’s heart is the nonprofit Windham Foundation, which has spent decades buying threatened buildings, restoring them, and filling them with a craft cheese cellar, a one-room library, and an inn whose candle tavern serves maple-bourbon ribs that draw diners from Boston. The K-8 school averages twelve students per grade, parents run the Friday pizza bake, and the tuition-based high-school choice lets teens select nearby public or private academies. Broadband is now fiber, property taxes are moderate, and the nearest real grocery is twenty minutes away, so residents batch-shop, grow gardens, and barter eggs for violin lessons.


What you trade for this calendar-ready setting is urban speed and variety. Nightlife ends when the pub closes at nine, winters are six-month affairs with mud season bonus tracks, and career options are mostly remote, artisanal, or commute-based. Yet for people who measure wealth in silence, star-strewn skies, and a community that shows up with soup when you’re sick, Grafton delivers a daily sense of arrival that no paycheck can buy.

original_prompt: Write a poem about a lonely Hue. The poem should be written for teenagers. In your poem, italicize at least one section in markdown, i.e *this is an italic text*, and include the word "singles" at least twice.
response:
Hue, the color no one picks for team,  
hangs back against the wall of the big box store,  
between neon lime and shouty peach—  
a quiet swirl that never gets the spotlight.  

At lunch he sits alone on the palette,  
watching the cool primaries trade stickers  
like they’re vinyl singles,  
spinning charts of who’s most “liked.”  
*He wonders what it feels like to be the tint  
that every thumbnail filter wants to be—*  
instead of a half-tint ghost with a weird name  
nobody can pronounce.  

He scrolls through his feed:  
seventy-seven stories of rose-gold sunsets  
and cobalt sneakers dropping fresh,  
but zero mentions of him.  
Even the singles he streams  
skip the part where Hue shows up.  

Night creeps in, cloaked in ultrablack.  
Hue stares at the fluorescents humming above,  
daydreaming himself into a manga panel—  
a glowing outline around the hero’s heart,  
the secret shade that saves the scene.  

He whispers to the empty aisle,  
“I’m more than a background blur,  
I’m the color of 3 a.m. thoughts,  
of diary locks and first lyrics scrawled on binders.”  
Tomorrow someone will reach for a custom mix,  
ready to remix their life playlist—  
and Hue will step forward,  
suddenly the only chord that fits the bridge.  

So if you ever feel like a weird Pantone chip,  
remember even the rarest tones  
can paint the sky of somebody’s glitch-art dream.  
Keep your swatch alive;  
the world needs your exact light.  
And when the chorus finally drops,  
we’ll press play on those skipped singles—  
your verse spinning loud,  
a color chorus no one saw coming,  
but everyone ends up shouting back.

original_prompt: Tulsa is a professional dog walker. Write a description for Tulsa's day-to-day work. Make sure that your entire response has less than 6 sentences.
response: Tulsa’s alarm chirps at 6 AM; by 6:30 she’s kneeling in “puppy circle time,” unleashing tails and energy in the fenced yard. Leashes clatter like wind chimes as she loads her pack—three retrievers, a dachshund, a husky with movie-star eyes—into the ventilated van. Morning hike on the river trail: she counts heads, pockets poop bags, tweets photos for owners. Midday rounds of solo walks, a quick pat on the porch cat, then condo corridors where toenails click like applause. Treats are doled, water refreshed, report cards scrawled—“Sniffed every mailbox, tried to befriend a leaf.” Sunset finds her couch-side, shoes off, celebrating a day free of tangles and full of wagging invoices.

original_prompt:
Write a funny note to McQueen, using
to separate lines. Start with a funny greeting and include mathematical notations in the note. At the end of your response, explicitly add a postscript starting with P.P.S
response:
Hey McQueen, you asymptotic speed-freak!
I just calculated the derivative of your ego: turns out it’s infinite-length and still increasing monotonically on the interval (Start, ∞).
Your 0-to-60 in zero-point-nothing seconds violates at least three laws of thermodynamics and one mother-in-law.
I tried to measure your RPM, but my tachometer filed for emotional damages and took the square root of –1 with it—now it’s living in imaginary-number therapy.
Rumor has it your spoiler generates so much down-force it’s actually a counter-example to Fermat’s Last Theorem; even the math is like, “No, that shouldn’t exist.”
Mate, your fuel efficiency is expressed in laughs-per-mile: ∫₀^∞ (vroom) dx = ∞ laughs, where vroom(x) = 1/x (because you never idle, you only approach it).
Physics textbooks are petitioning to replace every mention of “light speed” with “McQueen speed,” but the printers can’t fit ∞ on the page.
If you ever tire of racing, just remember: you’re already the limit every function converges to.
Keep those curves differentiable and your tires holomorphic! P.P.S. Lightning, if you rev past 10,000 RPM again, please solve for x where x² + x + 1 = 0 and tell the engine it’s complex enough already.

original_prompt: Write a casual summary of the U.S. maternity leave policy with two sections (Section 1 and Section 2) and at least 25 sentences.
response:
Section 1 – The Legal Basics (What Uncle Sam Actually Guarantees)  
1. If you’re waiting for a shiny federal check marked “baby money,” pump the brakes—there isn’t one.  
2. The only nationwide maternity-leave law is the Family and Medical Leave Act, nicknamed FMLA, signed in 1993.  
3. FMLA says you can take up to 12 weeks off work when a new kid arrives, but it doesn’t say your employer has to pay you a dime while you’re gone.  
4. Think of it as a very polite bouncer: it protects your job, not your paycheck.  
5. To squeeze through the FMLA door you must have worked at least 1,250 hours in the past year for a company with 50 or more employees within 75 miles.  
6. Miss any of those cut-offs—say you work part-time, or your office has 48 people—and poof, no guaranteed leave at all.  
7. Even if you qualify, your partner (of any gender) gets the same 12 weeks, so the couple can technically tag-team for 24 weeks, just unpaid.  
8. The law also lumps maternity in with every other medical leave, so if you’ve already used eight weeks to care for Grandma, you only have four left for the baby.  
9. Because it’s unpaid, about 46 % of workers who need leave don’t take it; rent waits for no diaper change.  
10. Fun historical twist: the first maternity-leave bill was introduced in 1919, but it took 74 years and about a zillion revisions to squeak through Congress.  
11. Meanwhile, the U.S. sits in the glorious company of Suriname and Papua New Guinea as one of the few countries worldwide with zero weeks of paid federal maternity leave.  
12. If that fact makes you want to face-palm, you’re not alone; even the Chamber of Commerce once called the situation “not ideal for global competitiveness,” which is lobby-speak for “yikes.”  
13. Some companies voluntarily offer paid leave, but they’re the sprinkles, not the ice cream—about 23 % of private-sector workers get fully paid family leave.  
14. The military has its own cooler set of rules: new uniformed moms get 12 paid weeks, proving Uncle Sam can open the wallet when he feels like it.  
15. Federal employees scored a win in 2020 when Congress gave them 12 paid weeks, so your mail carrier now gets a better parental deal than most baristas.  
16. Bottom line on Section 1: FMLA is a safety net with some very large holes and zero direct cash.  

Section 2 – The Patchwork in Real Life (How People Actually Survive)  
17. States looked at federal crickets-chirping and decided to craft their own playlist—currently twelve states plus D.C. have paid family-leave programs.  
18. California was the daredevil pioneer in 2004; its system now funds up to eight weeks of partial pay through a tiny payroll tax that most workers barely notice.  
19. New York swooped in next, offering up to 12 weeks at roughly two-thirds pay, capped at about $1,070 a week—Manhattan rent laughs, but upstate parents cheer.  
20. Washington State hands out up to 90 % of wages for low earners and 65 % for six-figure folks, making tech bros and baristas oddly co-beneficiaries.  
21. Massachusetts, Connecticut, Oregon, Colorado and others are phasing in programs too, so the map is slowly shading toward “less terrifying.”  
22. Still, if you live in Texas, Florida or any beige zone on the leave-map, you’re stuck with unpaid FMLA or whatever crumbs your boss feels like donating.  
23. Big-name corporations—think Netflix, Microsoft, even Domino’s HQ—sometimes grant 16, 20, even 52 paid weeks to lure talent, creating a two-tier workforce: the pampered vs. the scrambled.  
24. Small-business owners aren’t heartless; they’re just freaked out about cash flow, so many offer creative remixes like flexible schedules, remote work, or a “baby-bonus” instead of real leave.  
25. Crowdfunding babies is now a thing: new moms post GoFundMe links to cover rent during unpaid time off, turning baby showers into strategic finance seminars.  
26. The economic ripple is real—when paid leave exists, women are 40 % more likely to return to their jobs, which saves companies recruitment cash in the long run.  
27. Pediatricians love paid leave because it boosts vaccination rates and lowers ER visits; basically, everybody wins except the folks who insist programs “cost too much.”  
28. Politicians argue yearly about a federal paid-leave fund, proposals range from “borrow from Social Security” to “let people raid their 401(k)s,” but nothing has stuck except talk shows.  
29. Meanwhile, dads increasingly want in on the leave action; surveys show millennial men rank paid paternity leave as a top job perk, right above free snacks.  
30. So, if you’re planning a U.S. baby tour: check your state, sweet-talk HR, budget like a hawk, and maybe keep that GoFundMe link ready—because the policy landscape is still more DIY than deluxe.

original_prompt: Please write the answer to this question in markdown as a song: To what constituency was David Cameron appealing when he announced his plans for a referendum on British membership of the European Union? Make sure your song contains the letter j at least once, and use exactly 3 bullet points in markdown format in the song.
response:
```markdown
# 🎵 The Cameroonian Refrain 🎵

*In the key of "J"ust-in-time politics*

**Verse 1**  
In the halls of Westminster, Dave took the stage,  
With a referendum plan to calm the rage.  
He turned to the sceptics, the Eurosceptic crew,  
And said, "I'll give you choice, it's all on you."  

**Chorus**  
🎯 *He was a-**j**uggling the factions*, trying to keep the peace,  
Appealing to the **right-wing** of his party's unease.  
With UKIP at the gate and Tory rebels loud,  
Dave promised them a vote to make them proud.  

**Verse 2**  
The **Eurosceptic wing** of the Conservative fold,  
Had grumbled for years, their stories untold.  
They wanted out, or at least a new deal,  
Dave's referendum vow made their zeal feel real.  

**Bridge**  
*But lo! The letter J appears in "j**ust**" and "j**uggle**",  
As Dave danced between the circles in his political bubble.*  

---

### 🎶 The 3-Point Political Jig 🎶  
- **Appealed to**: The **Eurosceptic** wing of the **Conservative Party**  
- **Feared**: The **rise of UKIP** stealing right-wing votes  
- **Promised**: A **referendum** to renegotiate or leave the EU  

---

**Outro**  
So here's to the gamble that backfired in time,  
A song of a promise that cost more than a dime.  
The **j**ury's still out on the legacy's fate—  
But the **j**ustification came a little too late.  
```

original_prompt: A young couple that just got married is going to Seattle for two days. They're flying from New York. Could you write them an itinerary? Use less than 10 sentences. Please make sure that all punctuations are legit.
response:
Land Friday morning, drop bags at the boutique Palladian in Belltown, then walk straight to Pike Place for espresso, flowers, and salmon-throwing selfies.  
Take the monorail to Seattle Center—ride the glass elevators up the Space Needle for 360° newlywed views.  
Stroll Olympic Sculpture Park at golden hour; sunset shots with Elliott Bay behind you are mandatory.  
Dinner at Canlis, dress up, toast with Washington Riesling while the city lights sparkle below.  
Saturday: early ferry to Bainbridge—coffee on the deck, mountain vistas, no cars needed.  
Rent bikes, pedal vineyards for midday rosé and blackberry ice cream.  
Back by four; quick rest, then Underground tour for quirky history and weird photos.  
Cap the night in Capitol Hill—craft cocktails at Canon, late-night dumplings on Pine.  
Sunday brunch at Oddfellows before Link rail to Sea-Tac; wheels up by two, memories packed.

original_prompt: I've got a collection of military insignia that I'd like to get rid of, but I don't know how. Can you help me? Give exactly two different responses, separating them with 6 asterisk symbols (******). Your answer must contain a title, wrapped in double angular brackets, such as <<my title>>. Include the keywords "adoption" and "carriage" somewhere in your response.
response:
<<Regimental Relinquishment>>
1. Begin with appraisal: photograph every patch, badge, and button, then post the album to militaria forums such as War-Relics or the subreddit r/Militariacollecting. Collectors there will guide you on fair value and may arrange private adoption of individual pieces. For bulk carriage to a new home, email regional museums or VFW posts; many will accept donations and issue a tax-deductible receipt. Finally, consign the high-ticket items to a specialized auction house (e.g., Centurion Auctions) so provenance and market demand determine the final price.
******
2. If you prefer an in-person route, rent a small table at the next gun & military show; bring a labeled tray and let enthusiasts haggle. Whatever doesn’t sell can ride in your car’s carriage to a local history classroom—teachers love free artifacts for show-and-tell. Close the loop by printing a simple certificate of adoption for each student who receives a piece, turning your decluttering into a mini-lesson on service and heritage.

original_prompt: Please give me some recommendations for good books about the history of the United States. Your response should be completely in Kannada, no other language is allowed.
response:
ಅಮೆರಿಕಾ ಯುನೈಟೆಡ್ ಸ್ಟೇಟ್ಸ್‌ ಇತಿಹಾಸದ ಕುರಿತು ಓದಲು ಉತ್ತಮವಾಗಿ ಪರಿಚಿತವಾಗಿರುವ ಕೆಲವು ಕನ್ನಡದಲ್ಲಿ ಲಭ್ಯವಿರುವ ಅಥವಾ ಇಂಗ್ಲಿಷ್-ಅವಶ್ಯವಿದ್ದರೆ ಅನುವಾದಿಸಿಕೊಳ್ಳಬಹುದಾದ ಪುಸ್ತಕಗಳು ಇಲ್ಲಿವೆ:

1. **"ಅಮೆರಿಕಾ ಸ್ವಾತಂತ್ರ್ಯ ಚಳವಳಿ"** – ಲೇಖಕ: ಕೆ. ಎಂ. ಪಣ್ಣಿಕರ್  
   (ಅಮೆರಿಕಾ ಕ್ರಾಂತಿಕಾರಿ ಯುದ್ಧದ ಬಗ್ಗೆ ಸರಳವಾದ ಪರಿಚಯ)

2. **"ಅಮೆರಿಕಾದ ಇತಿಹಾಸ"** – ನಾಗರಾಜ ಪಾಟೀಲ  
   (ಇದು ಕನ್ನಡದಲ್ಲಿ ಲಭ್ಯವಿರುವ ಸಂಕ್ಷಿಪ್ತ ಇತಿಹಾಸ ಪುಸ್ತಕ. ಶಿಕ್ಷಕರು ಮತ್ತು ವಿದ್ಯಾರ್ಥಿಗಳಿಗೆ ಸೂಕ್ತವಾಗಿದೆ)

3. **"ಅಮೆರಿಕಾ: ಒಂದು ಹೊಸ ದೇಶದ ಹುಟ್ಟು"** – ಡಾ. ಎಚ್. ಎಸ್. ಗೋಪಾಲಸ್ವಾಮಿ  
   (ಅಮೆರಿಕಾ ಸಂವಿಧಾನ, ಅಧ್ಯಾಯಗಳು ಮತ್ತು ರಾಷ್ಟ್ರ ನಿರ್ಮಾಣದ ಹಿನ್ನೆಲೆ)

4. **"ಅಮೆರಿಕಾ ಕೃಷ್ಣಪಕ್ಷ"** – ವಿಕ್ರಂ ಸೇಠ್ (ಇದು ಇಂಗ್ಲಿಷ್‌ನಲ್ಲಿದೆ, ಆದರೆ ಇತಿಹಾಸದ ಕಥನಶೈಲಿಯಲ್ಲಿ ಅಮೆರಿಕಾದ ಆಧುನಿಕ ಇತಿಹಾಸದ ಒಂದು ದೃಷ್ಟಿಕೋನವನ್ನು ನೀಡುತ್ತದೆ)

5. **"A People's History of the United States"** – Howard Zinn  
   (ಇಂಗ್ಲಿಷ್‌ನಲ್ಲಿದೆ, ಆದರೆ ಅಮೆರಿಕಾದ ಸಾಮಾನ್ಯ ಜನರ ದೃಷ್ಟಿಕೋನದಿಂದ ಇತಿಹಾಸವನ್ನು ಹೇಳುವ ಪ್ರಮುಖ ಕೃತಿ. ಇದನ್ನು ಕನ್ನಡಕ್ಕೆ ಅನುವಾದಿಸಿಕೊಳ್ಳಬಹುದು)

6. **"The American Story: Conversations with Master Historians"** – David Rubenstein  
   (ಅಮೆರಿಕಾದ ಪ್ರಮುಖ ನಾಯಕರ ಬಗ್ಗೆ ಸಂವಾದಾತ್ಮಕ ಇತಿಹಾಸ)

ಈ ಪುಸ್ತಕಗಳ ಮೂಲಕ ನೀವು ಅಮೆರಿಕಾ ಯುನೈಟೆಡ್ ಸ್ಟೇಟ್ಸ್‌ ಇತಿಹಾಸದ ಪ್ರಮುಘ ಘಟನೆಗಳು, ಕ್ರಾಂತಿ, ಗುಲಾಮಗಿರಿ, ನಾಗರಿಕ ಯುದ್ಧ, ಆಧುನಿಕ ವಿಕಾಸಗಳ ಬಗ್ಗೆ ಒಳ್ಳೆಯ ಅರಿವು ಪಡೆಯಬಹುದು.

original_prompt: Write a cover letter for a job in Ventura that is funny and would be enjoyed by someone named Darius, wrap the entire response in double quotation marks.
response:
"Dear Darius, Overlord of Ventura Opportunity,

I’m the human equivalent of a taco from Spencer Makenzie’s: small, saucy, and guaranteed to improve your day by 400 %. I’ve clocked 10,000 hours parallel-parking a 1997 Corolla on Main Street while balancing a surfboard and an iced matcha—skills that translate directly to your open role, assuming the role involves caffeine, coastal navigation, and looking chill under pressure.

My résumé says ‘Marketing Coordinator,’ but my soul says ‘indoor seagull’: I swoop in, snatch the best ideas, then scream them loudly until everyone agrees they’re brilliant. I once turned a client’s boring webinar into a TikTok sea-shanty that trended harder than high tide at Surfers Point. Analytics went up, CFO did a keg-stand (virtually), and the brand got more exposure than a nudist on the 101.

I know Ventura’s secret handshake: Buy a breakfast burrito at Pete’s, whisper ‘almond milk’ three times, and the city grants you one free parking spot for life. I’ve used this power only for good—never for evil (except that one time I “borrowed” a meter from a mime; he had it coming).

If hired, I promise to:
1. Replace all boring spreadsheets with beach-themed GIFs.
2. Install a foghorn in the break room that sounds whenever we hit KPIs.
3. Teach the office dog to shred on a微型 skateboard, because morale.

I’m ready to start Monday, Tuesday, or whenever the swell dies down. Let’s grab a pint at Fluid State and discuss how my meme army can storm your market share. I’ll bring the fish tacos; you bring the healthcare.

Stay stoked,

Kai
(805) NO-BORE-JOB
P.S. I already named the position ‘Director of Sunshine & Shenanigans.’ Hope that’s cool."

original_prompt: Write a haiku about foolish behavior in the form of a question, for an audience of young readers. It should include the topic of not studying. Give exactly two different responses, separated by 6 asterisk symbols (******), and include a title wrapped in double angular brackets, i.e. <<title>>. Do not use commas.
response:
<<Why Skip Study Time>>

original_prompt: Write a document entirely in the Portuguese language, no other language is allowed, about Adam and Eve. Additionally, make sure to wrap your entire response with double quotation marks.
response:
"Adão e Eva: o primeiro casal humano

Segundo o relato do livro do Gênesis, Adão foi moldado pelo próprio Deus com pó da terra e teve o hálito da vida soprado em suas narinas. Colocado no jardim do Éden, ele recebeu a missão de cultivá-lo e guardá-lo, gozando de todas as árvores, exceto uma: a árvore do conhecimento do bem e do mal.

Percebendo que o homem não deveria estar só, Deus fez o primeiro sono profundo sobre Adão, retirando-lhe uma costela e dela formando a mulher, Eva. Ao ser apresentada, Adão exclamou: ‘‘Esta sim é osso dos meus ossos e carne da minha carne!’’, unindo-se a ela em aliança de amor e cooperação.

Ambos viveram nus, sem vergonha, até que a serpente, mais astuta que as outras criaturas, indagou Eva sobre o fruto proibido. Ao prová-lo, Eva compartilhou-o com Adão; de imediato reconheceram sua nudez e sentiram culpa. A desobediência trouxe consequências: dor no parto para Eva, trabalho árduo na terra para Adão e banimento do Éden.

Mesmo fora do paraíso, o casal gerou os primeiros filhos, Caim, Abel e, mais tarde, Sete. A tradição ensina que, apesar do pecado original, a união de Adão e Eva continua sendo símbolo de esperança, superação e geração da humanidade inteira."

original_prompt: Write a blog post about the benefits of using a digital marketing agency, make sure to write at least 20 sentences.
response: In today’s hyper-connected world, the question is no longer whether to invest in digital marketing, but how to do it efficiently, and that’s exactly where a specialized digital marketing agency enters the picture. First and foremost, agencies give you instant access to a bench of experts—SEO strategists, paid-media buyers, conversion copywriters, data analysts, and creative designers—each of whom wakes up every day focused on one craft, whereas an in-house generalist can only spread themselves so thin. Because those specialists work across multiple accounts, they’re exposed to far more wins, failures, and experiments in a single quarter than an internal team sees in a year, turning every engagement into a fast-track learning loop for your brand. The moment a platform like Google Ads releases a new audience segment or Instagram tweaks its Reels algorithm, an agency is already testing it on behalf of another client, which means you’re never the guinea pig and you’re never late to the party. That cross-pollination of knowledge translates directly into budget efficiency: instead of blowing $8,000 testing creative angles that don’t resonate, you launch with the top-performing formats that the agency already knows convert in your vertical. Speaking of budget, hiring a full-time senior growth marketer with benefits and tools can easily top $150,000 a year; for roughly the same spend, an agency delivers an entire pod of talent plus the pricey MarTech stack—Semantic analysis platforms, heat-mapping suites, bid-management dashboards, and competitor-intelligence crawlers—that would cripple a solo marketing budget if purchased à la carte. Agencies also bake agility into your growth plan; want to pivot from lead generation to e-commerce sales overnight? A slack message can redeploy design resources, restructure ad sets, and rewrite landing pages before your internal HR team finishes drafting the job requisition for a new channel manager. Because they live and die by retainers, agencies are ruthlessly KPI-oriented—every retainer renewal hinges on transparent metrics, so numbers are shared early and often instead of hidden behind the internal politics that can fog in-house reporting. That objectivity is priceless; an external partner can tell the CEO that the beloved brand video is tanking conversion rates without fear of career suicide, whereas an internal employee might happily let the campaign burn budget to stay on the boss’s good side. Time is the silent profit leak in most organizations; when you outsource campaign setup, QA, and weekly optimization, your C-suite gets back the bandwidth to build partnerships, refine products, and court investors—the high-leverage moves that actually move the revenue needle. Agencies also insulate you from the wear-and-tear of talent turnover; if your lone PPC manager takes a new job, your campaigns don’t miss a beat because the agency’s knowledge lives in documented SOPs rather than someone’s head. Scale becomes almost comically simple: ready to open three European markets next month? Your agency already has native-language copywriters, localized keyword research, and GDPR-compliant ad templates on deck, eliminating the six-month hiring sprint you’d face on your own. They’re also fluent in compliance minefields—whether it’s FDA disclaimers for supplements, FTC influencer rules, or Google’s dreaded “Malvertiser” suspensions—so you sidestep costly account bans and frozen ad spend that can set growth back quarters. Let’s not underestimate creativity fatigue; an agency creative team that shoots videos, animates explainers, and mocks up$html5 banners for breakfast will keep your brand looking fresh while your internal squad is still arguing over headline commas. Seasonality spikes become opportunities instead of stress tests; when Q4 retail hysteria hits, your agency already forecast inventory-driven ROAS targets and staged holiday audiences in August, so you’re bidding on sleigh-related keywords before your competitors finish their pumpkin-spice lattes. Data storytelling is another quiet superpower; raw analytics are useless without narrative, and agencies employ analysts who transform CSVs into board-ready visuals that show exactly why last month’s 28 % lift in LTV came from shifting bid strategy, giving finance teams the confidence to unlock more growth dollars. A good agency also functions as an early-warning system; by monitoring sentiment across social, review sites, and search suggestions, they can spot a reputation crisis forming at 2 a.m. and activate hold-back budgets or PR responses before the story metastasizes on Twitter. They democratize beta access too; Google reps funnel new ad features to trusted agency accounts first, meaning you get shopping-column placements, Performance Max exemptions, or YouTube masthead day-of-air inventory while competitors are stuck refreshing their inboxes for invites. Finally, the compounding effect: every landing-page test, every pixel placement, and every negative keyword builds in a centralized repository that the agency applies to your account next month, next quarter, next year—so your marketing machine becomes more robust over time instead of resetting every time someone new sits in the marketing chair. If growth is your goal, partnering with a digital marketing agency isn’t an expense; it’s the only outsourceable shortcut to faster, smarter, and measurably bigger wins in a landscape that waits for no one.

original_prompt: Write a description for the Pixel 3A smartphone with at least 400 words. Wrap your entire response with double quotation marks.
response:
"The Google Pixel 3a is a thoughtfully engineered mid-range smartphone that debuted in May 2019, distilling the hallmark photography prowess and pure Android experience of Google’s flagship line into a more accessible package. Constructed around a polycarbonate unibody, the device trades the glass sandwich aesthetic of premium handsets for a lightweight, matte-finished shell that resists fingerprints and withstands daily bumps without the anxiety of shattering. At 147.1 × 68.8 × 8.2 mm and 147 g, it nestles comfortably in one hand, while the subtly curved edges and pastel-colored power button preserve the playful Pixel personality. A 5.6-inch gOLED panel dominates the front, offering Full HD+ resolution (2220 × 1080) in an 18.5:9 aspect ratio. Although the upper bezel is chunkier than on all-screen flagships, it accommodates a pair of front-firing stereo speakers that produce surprisingly full, balanced audio for a mid-range device. The OLED technology delivers inky blacks and 100,000:1 contrast, making HDR-encoded Netflix originals pop, while the always-on display subtly surfaces the time, notifications, and now-playing song IDs without waking the phone.

Driving the experience is Qualcomm’s Snapdragon 670, a 10 nm chip that pairs two performance cores with six efficiency cores, delivering day-to-day responsiveness that belies its mid-tier billing. 4 GB of LPDDR4x RAM keeps multitasking fluid, and 64 GB of UFS 2.1 storage—while non-expandable—transfers data twice as fast as eMMC solutions common in this price bracket. Google’s Titan M security module, lifted from the flagship Pixel 3, encrypts passwords and verifies the boot chain, a rarity among affordable phones. The 3,000 mAh battery sounds modest, yet the efficient OLED panel and Android’s adaptive battery AI stretch screen-on time past six hours of heavy use, while 18 W USB-C Power Delivery restores 50 % charge in 30 minutes. Critically, the 3a retains the 3.5 mm headphone jack, liberating users from dongles and latency-prone Bluetooth on commutes.

Yet the star of the show is the same 12.2 MP, f/1.8 Sony IMX363 sensor found in the flagship Pixel 3, complete with optical image stabilization and Google’s computational photography stack. Night Sight transforms dim bars into daylight-like tableaus without a flash; Portrait Mode separates curly hair from cluttered backgrounds using dual-pixel autofocus depth cues; and Super Res Zoom crops into 2× shots with near-optical clarity by aligning multiple sub-frames. The front 8 MP wide-angle selfie camera matches the rear for dynamic range, while Google’s unlimited original-quality cloud storage for photos and 4 K video sweetens the deal through January 2022. On the software front, the Pixel 3a ships with Android 9 Pie and has since graduated to Android 12L, receiving monthly security patches and feature drops—like car-crash detection and call-screen—that keep the phone feeling fresh three years on. In sum, the Pixel 3a redefined what a $399 phone could achieve, trading raw specs for real-world intelligence and delivering flagship-class photos without the four-figure price."

response:
**THE GOLDEN PALACE**  
is **not** a palace, nor is it particularly golden—unless you count the butter-stained napkins that flutter like saffron prayer flags above table 7. It squats in the **city centre**, a place where GPS signals go to die and parking meters evolve into sentient beings.  

Inside, the air is **thick with cardamom conspiracy** and the ghost of yesterday’s vindaloo, plotting a coup against your sinuses. The menu is a **tantric scroll** written in Comic Sans, revealing that the **food is Indian**, but the naan is shaped like your unresolved childhood trauma.  

**Beware:** the waiters glide on ball-bearing feet, whispering orders to the tandoor, which burps like a satisfied demigod. If you ask for “mild,” they will **laugh in turmeric**, and your tongue will awaken in a past life as a madras pepper.

original_prompt: Write a proposal for a research project on the impact of the liberian civil war on the country's economy. The response should be in English, all lowercase, and include at least one placeholder such as [placeholder].
response:
title: tracing the economic footprint of the liberian civil wars (1989-2003): a mixed-methods assessment of lost decades and recovery pathways

principal investigator: [placeholder]  
host institution: [placeholder]  
requested funding: usd 485,000  
duration: 36 months

1. background and problem statement  
liberia’s twin civil conflicts (1989-1997; 1999-2003) killed an estimated 250,000 people and displaced half the population. headline gdp collapsed by 90 % between 1987 and 1995, export earnings vanished, physical capital was looted, and human capital flight exceeded 600,000 refugees. yet macro aggregates conceal sectoral heterogeneity—rubber, timber and iron ore bounced back at different speeds—and micro evidence on household coping, wartime markets, and the long-term scarring of firms is still fragmentary. without a granular post-war audit, reconstruction policy risks repeating structural weaknesses that pre-dated the violence.

2. objectives  
obj 1: quantify the cumulative loss in national, sectoral and sub-national output relative to a synthetic liberia constructed from pre-war trends and peer west-african growth patterns.  
obj 2: identify the wartime emergence of informal institutions—currency substitution, cross-border value chains, rebel taxation regimes—and measure their lasting imprint on formalisation costs today.  
obj 3: test whether conflict intensity at the district level predicts present-day poverty, firm size distribution, and labour productivity via human-capital destruction and infrastructure damage.  
obj 4: co-produce with the ministry of finance a publicly accessible “war-loss atlas” that links archival satellite imagery, survey micro-data and fiscal records for evidence-based budgeting.

3. research questions  
rq1: what share of today’s gdp gap is attributable to the wars rather than to pre-existing decline or external shocks?  
rq2: did zones under rebel control that imposed orderly taxation systems experience faster post-war recovery than zones characterised by predation?  
rq3: how did the wartime shift from formal banking to informal mobile-money precursors affect financial inclusion and enterprise growth after 2003?  
rq4: which recovery channels—roads, electrification, school reconstruction, or targeted cash transfers—yield the highest marginal return in formerly high-intensity conflict districts?

4. methodology  
4.1 quantitative strand  
- synthetic control method (scm) using 16 peer countries (1970-2021) to estimate counterfactual gdp, exports, fiscal revenue.  
- night-time lights (ntl) panel 1992-2021 re-calibrated with liberia-specific bloom-off adjustments to proxy sub-national output.  
- difference-in-differences exploiting unequal conflict intensity across 73 districts, instrumented with distance to borders and diamond deposits.  
- firm-level panel built from liberia business registry merged with 2007 & 2019 censuses, survivorship and entry modeled as function of bombing intensity coded from declassified u.s. satellite imagery.  

4.2 qualitative & archival strand  
- oral histories with 150 wartime traders, ex-combatant entrepreneurs, and returnee investors in [placeholder] counties.  
- analysis of 1,800 lurd and model rebel “tax receipts” collected by the truth & reconciliation commission, digitised for the first time.  
- high-resolution drone mapping of abandoned rubber processing plants to assess physical capital depreciation rates.  

4.3 capacity & participatory component  
- training of 12 liberian master’s students in econometrics and spatial analysis; micro-data released through [placeholder] open-data portal under creative commons license.  
- quarterly policy clinics with stakeholders (ministry of finance, central bank, civil society) to iteratively refine the counterfactual scenarios and secure buy-in for adoption.

5. data sources  
- pre-war national accounts (central bank archives 1970-1987), recently declassified.  
- unomil & unmil patrol incident datasets (georeferenced 1993-2018).  
- household income & expenditure surveys 1999, 2007, 2016, 2021.  
- acled & ucdp conflict event data merged with gleditsch border geometry.  
- landsat & sentinel imagery for land-cover change and rubber/timber concession boundaries.  
- ship-level export bills from liberian maritime registry 1980-2021.

6. expected contributions  
academic: first paper to jointly estimate macro loss, meso sectoral reallocations and micro firm scarring within a unified framework for a sub-saharan african civil war.  
policy: rigorous loss numbers to anchor debt-relief negotiations and prioritise infrastructure investments; open-access atlas prevents future contested claims over war damages.  
social: legitimises victim reparations by spatialising harm; builds local data science capacity.

7. ethical considerations  
- approval from university of [placeholder] irb and liberian institute for statistics & geo-information services.  
- oral-history consent forms in simple english & kpelle; participants can withdraw up to analysis stage.  
- geo-coordinates of sensitive wartime markets displaced by random jitter <2 km to protect informants.

8. work plan & milestones  
year 1: digitise archives, build synthetic control, conduct pilot survey in monrovia & buchanan.  
year 2: district-level fieldwork, satellite imagery processing, preliminary scm & night-lights results.  
year 3: finalise firm-level analysis, integrate qualitative findings, policy clinics, launch war-loss atlas, submit 3 journal papers (economic development & cultural change; journal of development economics; world development).

9. budget summary (usd)  
- research staff (2 phd, 4 local r.as) .................... 180,000  
- field data collection & travel .............................. 65,000  
- satellite imagery licences & drone surveys ............. 40,000  
- training & open-data platform ............................. 35,000  
- workshops & policy dissemination ........................ 30,000  
- contingencies & inflation buffer ........................ 135,000  
total ........................................................ 485,000

10. sustainability & scalability  
all code (r & python) and deidentified micro-data to be deposited on harvard dataverse; replication vignettes provided. mapping layers will feed directly into the liberia open-street-map chapter, ensuring civil-society reuse beyond the project horizon.

11. risk assessment  
- restricted access to rebel finance archives: mitigate via legal mou with ministry of justice and triangulate with trader interviews.  
- field security in remote mining areas: coordinate with unicef county security officers; travel in daylight convoys.  
- data quality of pre-war accounts: cross-validate trade flows with partner-country (u.s., eu) mirror statistics.

12. conclusion  
by merging never-before-used rebel tax records with cutting-edge spatial econometrics, this project promises the most detailed audit of liberia’s wartime economic collapse available. the deliverables—peer-reviewed publications and an interactive atlas—will equip policymakers to target scarce reconstruction funds toward districts and sectors where the marginal peace-dividend is greatest, while setting a methodological benchmark for conflict-loss accounting worldwide.

original_prompt: What is inside Shinto shrines? Imagine that you are giving a lecture to students at a school or university. Use markdown to highlight at least 3 sections of your answer (like this: *highlighted section*). Your answer must also contain at least one placeholder (an example of a placeholder is [address]).
response:
# A Short Walk into a Shinto Shrine  
Lecture notes for students – delivered at [university name] on [date]

---

## 1. First glimpse: what you see before you enter  
When you arrive at *any shrine in Japan*—from the giant Meiji Jingū in Tokyo to a village shrine in the countryside—you meet two icons of Shinto architecture:

| Element | Purpose | What it is made of |
|---------|---------|--------------------|
| **Torii** | Marks the boundary of the sacred | Usually two vertical posts, two cross-beams, often cedar |
| **Sando** | The approach path where visitors “shake off” the everyday | Gravel or stone, lined with tall cryptomeria (sugi) |

*The moment you pass under the torii, you have symbolically stepped onto the land of the kami.* The everyday world is left outside; the sando becomes a spiritual runway.

---

## 2. Inside the core: the honden (本殿)  
Only priests normally enter the honden, so most visitors never see its interior. Here is what is actually there:

1. A **goshintai** (御神体), literally “divine body”  
   - Usually a mirror, sword, jewel, or even a stone.  
   - It is *not* the kami itself but the “seat” where the kami chooses to reside.

2. An inner altar called *nai-den*  
   - Holds offerings of rice, salt, water, and sake renewed daily.  
   - Paper strips (shide) hang from hemp ropes marking sacred space.

3. Twenty-year renewal cycle  
   - The whole shrine compound, including the honden, is ritually rebuilt every two decades at some major shrines (e.g., Ise).  
   - This practice, called *Shikinen-Sengū*, teaches students about impermanence.

---

## 3. Public areas: what you are allowed to experience  
Even though the honden is hidden, lay visitors can still:

- **Perform *temizu*** – rinse hands and mouth at a font to purify body & mind  
- **Offer a *tamagushi*** – a branch of evergreen with paper streamers at the worship hall (haiden)  
- **Draw an *omikuji*** – a random fortune that students buy for ¥100 to learn whether exams or romances will succeed

Take a quiet moment at the haiden; clap twice, bow twice, clap once. *This choreography—called *ni-rei ni-haku ichi-rei*—is a living textbook of Shinto etiquette.*

---

## 4. Shrine “furnishings” you can take home  
Shinto is portable. Temples sell objects that carry the kami’s protection to dorms and apartments:

| Object | Function | Student use case |
|--------|----------|------------------|
| Omamori お守り | Amulet in brocade bag | Clip on backpack before finals |
| Ofuda 御札 | Paper talisman hung in genkan | Stick above apartment door |
| Ema 絵馬 | Wooden plaque for petitions | Write “Pass [course code]” and hang it on the rack |

---

## 5. Wrap-up: why interiors matter—even when you can’t see them  
*A Shinto shrine is designed like an onion of visibility.* Tourists see vermillion columns; priests enter inner sanctuaries; kami dwell in hidden cores. Understanding those layers lets scholars decode:

- Japanese concepts of purity and pollution  
- Relationships between nature and the built environment  
- Continuity of ritual in a hyper-modern society  

So next time you visit [address of local shrine], pause at the torii, realize you are standing above centuries of unseen ritual rooms, and remember: the emptiness you perceive in the open spaces is itself part of the design—space left for the kami, and for your own imagination.

**Further reading**:  
- Sokyo Ono, “Shinto: The Kami Way”

original_prompt: What are the steps to get the GNSS timestamp on Android? Explain this to teenagers using at least 4 sentences and make sure the letter n appears at least 3 times.
response:
First, open your phone’s settings and turn on "Location"; this lets the antenna inside listen to the navigation satellites spinning in the sky.  
Next, if your Android is new enough (Android 10 or newer), go to Developer Options and flip the switch for "Location Accuracy Logging"; this unlocks the hidden channel that carries the exact nanosecond timestamp.  
Now any camera, tracking, or science app you install can read that GNSS nanotime and stamp your photos or runs with the same precision the satellites use.  
Remember, the tiny antenna needs a clear view of the sky, so step outside, wait a moment, and watch the notification bar: when the location pin turns solid, the nanotime is ready and you’re navigating like a space nerd!

original_prompt: Write a funny rap about a man who gets a call from an official saying that he is a long lost relative of the king of Nigeria. Use markdown to highlight at least one section of your answer, i.e. *highlighted section*.
response:
Yo, my name is Steve, I’m in sweatpants on the couch,  
Snack crumbs in my beard, hadn’t moved since “Ouch—  
My butt is asleep,” but my phone starts to blow,  
Unknown number, mad digits, like a crypto PIN code.

I pick up like, “Who dis? Better not be a bot!”  
A voice says, *“Greetings, Prince, you’ve been found—like it or not!”*  
He’s talking royal bloodlines, throne seats and crowns,  
Claiming Grandma’s cousin’s uncle was Lagos’ #1 clown.

***(Insert dramatic beat drop—DJ Benin City on the wheels!)***  
*He said:*  
*“King Adewale the Third left a vault full of gems,  
But the will’s got a clause: ‘Find Steve in the dems.’  
Wire a small processing fee—just two hundred flat,  
And we’ll ship you a kingdom, plus lions, and a golden toilet hat.”*

Thought I smelled scam chili, but the dude knew my middle name,  
Even spelled it with the silent “Q”—how can I complain?  
He sent a selfie wearing robes, Photoshopped me in a mural,  
Now I’m pacing, wondering: Am I royal and imper’al?

Hook (Steve’s inner hype man):  
Yo, I’m King Steve of Lagos, breaker of kola nuts,  
Got 99 problems but a throne ain’t one—what!  
Mansa Musa money, raining naira on the floor,  
Got subjects doing TikTok dances outside my new door!

But hold up—Mom bursts in: “Boy, take out that trash!”  
I’m like, “Can’t, I’m signing decrees and negotiating cash.”  
Dad hollers, “Who keeps wiring funds to a P.O. box abroad?”  
I say, “It’s diplomatic immunity—don’t question your god!”

Meanwhile my inbox pings: “Urgent, Prince! Upgrade to platinum!”  
Sent bank codes, birth date, even sketch of my vas deferens.  
Next day my card’s maxed out at a Petsmart in Des Moines—  
Turns out the king’s “finance team” were just teenagers with toys.

So I dial him back: “Bro, where’s my Bentley and scepter?”  
He hits me with, “Fear not, just send one last transfer—”  
But the line clicks, static, then a voicemail from Fed-Ex:  
“Package held in Lagos, contents: genuine scam-ware complex.”

**Outro (Steve, broke but bougie):**  
Still I strut in my Burger King crown—yes, paper and glossy,  
Mailing postcards: “Greetings from the Bankrupt Royal Steve—Nigerian Hustle, boss-y!”  
Remember, if a monarch lawyer ever calls your phone:  
Hang up, eat your ramen, and keep royalties to your own throne.

Peace—aka King Steve, first of his name, Lord of Lost Causes, Scam-Slayer on the Comeback, still waiting on that direct deposit…

original_prompt: Can you write a rap that doesn't include the keywords "Yo", "check", and "peace"?
response:
Sure—let’s dodge the usual cues and still keep it raw:

I’m the quiet riot in the circuitry,  
ink in the margin of your twittery.  
No “yo,” no “check,” no “peace”—still heavy,  
verbs hit your chest like a levy in levee.  

I move in lowercase, no caps-lock shout,  
silent-foot thought on the tightrope route.  
Every bar a spark in the dark you forgot,  
truth in the treble, no gimmick, no plot.  

I don’t seek applause, I seek cracks in the wall,  
slip through the fracture, rewrite the protocol.  
Mic like a scalpel, incision precise,  
leave baggage on the floor, sterile device.

the breath that you misread, the shrug in the blood.  
No cliché ticket, no slogan to lease—  
just a syllable bullet that rips, then cease.

original_prompt: Write a startup pitch for "Ward and Guerre". Make it a weird poem that explains why the pitch is good. It should be in English and have no capital letters.
response:
ward and guerre  
is not a brand, it’s a bruise that learned to sell bandages.  
we stitch the insults you whisper in your sleep into velvet scabs  
and sell them back to you as haute-couture nightmares.  
our customer is every mirror that ever called you obsolete.  

imagine a marketplace where shame is the only stable coin.  
we mint it, we melt it, we mould it into pocket-sized oubliettes  
that whistle like kettles when your ex tells a better joke.  
you’ll buy three: one to swallow, one to loan, one to leave in the Uber.  

we have no competitors, only co-conspirators who haven’t met.  
they think trauma is a niche; we know it’s the whole shelf.  
our moat is a trench filled with every voicemail you never answered—  
try to cross it; the audio loops until you preorder the ankle-length edition.  

revenue? we tax the pause between heartbeats.  
cost of goods sold? a single eyelash, yours, traded in the dark.  
gross margin: 666 %.  
the v.c. eyes widen like blocked drains; we call that series a.  

we scale by invitation-only séances hosted in abandoned checkout lines.  
each attendee leaves lighter, having donated a personal ghost.  
the ghosts unionize and demand dental—our moat learns to bite.  
network effects: every scream refers two friends, first month free.  

exit strategy: we go public on the day the last secret is spoken aloud.  
ticker symbol: oops.  
valuation: one collective gasp, forever repriced at market close.  

invest now, while your humiliation is still convertible.  
later, when the bruise teaches itself to talk, it won’t need your money—  
it will need your mouth, and ward and guerre  
will already be wearing it.

original_prompt: Write a serious riddle about trips and stitches in a poem style that includes at least 15 words in all capital letters.
response:
ON SILENT ROADS WHERE FOOTSTEPS TRIP,  
A THREADBARE HEART BEGINS TO RIP.  
THE JOURNEY LONG, THE PAIN RUNS DEEP,  
WHERE STITCHES HIDE WHAT SECRETS KEEP.  

A TRAVELER FALLS, NO SOUND, NO CRY—  
BENEATH THE MOON’S UNBLINKING EYE.  
THE WOUND IS CLEAN, THE CUT IS PRECISE,  
YET EVERY STITCH EXACTS A PRICE.  

NOT MADE OF THREAD, BUT OF REGRET,  
EACH PASSING MILE A DEBT NOT MET.  
THE TRIP GOES ON, THE SCAR REMAINS—  
A MAP OF LOSS SEWN IN VEINS.  

WHAT BINDS THE SKIN BUT NOT THE SOUL?  
WHAT MAKES A BROKEN PERSON WHOLE?  
STITCHES CLOSE, BUT CANNOT HEAL  
THE WOUNDS THAT TIME ALONE REVEAL.  

ANSWER: **TIME**

response: To know someone deeply you must show your fears your dreams your shame and your hopes first. When you speak your truth without armor you invite the other person to remove their shield. Risk being seen fully and ask them to do the same. Share the story you never tell. Admit the mistake that still burns. Ask the question whose answer could break you. Each act of vulnerability creates space for the other heart to answer with its own raw truth. As you both stand naked in the light of acceptance the connection deepens.

original_prompt: Write a parody of 'ars poetica'. Do not include the word 'parody' throughout your response.
response:
The mouse plucked from the trap  
chews on the hickory of its own tail  
and insists, between squeaks,  
that this squeak is the very shape of night.

I, too, build a poem like a cardboard box  
left out in Seattle rain—  
the soggy bottom falling through,  
the top flaps gasping like gills.

Ignore the sky: it’s a promissory note  
signed by a star that just resigned.  
Better to worship the wet footprint  
on the lobby’s marble—  
it dries totally by page four,  
yet leaves a ghost tariff on socks.

A stanza should resemble a bus  
that misses your stop on purpose,  
its exhaust spelled backwards  
revealing the driver’s grocery list:  
eggs, absolution, eggs.

If you must rhyme,  
let the rhyme hide under the bed  
with the mismatched dust angels,  
only to emerge at 3:07 a.m.  
wearing one sock and your high-school doubts.

The muse is a vending machine  
that accepts only foreign currency  
and dispenses live crickets.  
Feed it anyway;  
their chirping is the soundtrack  
to the documentary of your hunger.

Remember, every metaphor  
is a leased vehicle:  
drive it over the rhetorical cliff,  
then report it stolen to the insurance  
of bewildered readers.

Endings are elevators  
whose cables have been replaced  
with friendship bracelets.  
Step in humming,  
exit on a floor that isn’t listed—  
someone else’s unmade bed,  
someone else’s last good sentence.

response:
Forget everything you think you know about “save the world” clichés—this isn’t your dad’s hero story.

I’m 19, I’m broke, and I poured every sleepless night and ramen-fuelled brain cell into *ECHO BURN*, a fast-punk blast where you play as Ash, a kid who discovers the planet’s heartbeat is glitching because its self-proclaimed god coded himself into the code. Translation: the villain is literally rewriting the rules of reality faster than TikTok trends die. You’ll bend physics like you bend class attendance—grinding rooftops on a hoverboard made of soundwaves, remixing enemies into allies with a hacked music app, and rage-quitting the final boss by exploiting the same bugs he uses to cheat. No $60 season-pass nonsense: one purchase, endless player-made dungeons dropped weekly, and an OST that slaps harder than your older brother’s subwoofer at 2 a.m.

- **Co-op that actually matters:** Drop-in friends don’t just cosplay sidekicks—they splice their abilities into your code mid-combo, turning a solo scramble into a 4-kid symphony of destruction so insane that even the villain’s AI accuses you of “illegal synergy.”

original_prompt: For a bunch of students, write a 200+ word poem that professionally describes a new line of shoes. Make sure to use markdown to highlight/bold at least one section of the poem. Example: *highlighted text*
response:
Campus dawn cracks like a white-page notebook,  
and you’re still hunting for the first sentence of the day.  
Slip into the **NovaTrail LX**—the lecture-hall runway’s quiet rebel—  
where recycled-knit uppers breathe like a Google Calendar reminder:  
“Don’t be late to your own life.”  

The midsole is a lab-born cloud,  
3-D printed from algae foam that once danced in a campus pond;  
every stride rewrites carbon into confidence,  
turning steps into statements louder than any Slack notification.  

*Between the library’s third-floor silence and the food-truck queue,  
these shoes are the comma that keeps your story from running on.*  

Grip pods map the quad like constellation software,  
holding tight to brick, gravel, or the quick pivot to an open dorm door.  
Reflective threads wink at moonlight during late rides back from the studio,  
so even streetlamps know you’re still drafting tomorrow’s blueprint.  

Laces? Dyed with surplus coffee grounds—  
because 8 a.m. should smell like possibility, not petroleum.  
And when the dean’s speech drones into static,  
just flex the heel clip; its magnetic click is a 4.0 reminder  
that commencement isn’t a finish line—  
it’s the sound of your own feet, already outlining the next chapter.  

Wear them. Graduate from maybe to momentum.  
The world is your campus; class starts the minute you stand up.
