original_prompt: Write a story about a family that goes camping in the woods. Your entire response should be in English and in all capital letters.
response:
THE MILLER FAMILY LOADED THEIR OLD BLUE SUV WITH TENTS, COOLERS, AND FLASHLIGHTS, READY FOR THEIR FIRST CAMPING TRIP IN YEARS. MOM, DAD, AND THEIR TWO KIDS, LILY AND MAX, DROVE TWO HOURS NORTH UNTIL THE ROADS TURNED TO DIRT AND THE TREES CLOSED IN AROUND THEM.

THEY FOUND A CLEARING BY A STREAM AND SET UP CAMP BEFORE SUNSET. LILY COLLECTED STICKS FOR THE FIRE WHILE MAX HELPED DAD HANG A HAMMOCK BETWEEN TWO TALL PINES. MOM UNPACKED HOT DOGS AND MARSHMALLOWS, AND SOON THE SMELL OF WOODSMOKE FILLED THE AIR.

AS DARKNESS FELL, THE STARS APPEARED LIKE SPRINKLED SALT ACROSS THE SKY. THEY TOLD GHOST STORIES AND LAUGHED UNTIL THEIR STOMACHES HURT. THEN THEY HEARD A LOW RUSTLING JUST BEYOND THE FIRELIGHT.

DAD GRABBED A FLASHLIGHT AND SHINED IT INTO THE TREES. TWO GLOWING EYES STARED BACK. THE FAMILY FROZE. THEN A RACCOON WADDLED INTO VIEW, NOSE TWITCHING, UNFAZED BY THEIR PRESENCE. THEY LAUGHED IN RELIEF AND THREW IT A PIECE OF BREAD.

LATER, SNUG IN THEIR TENTS, THEY LISTENED TO THE SOUNDS OF THE FOREST—CRICKETS, OWLS, AND THE GENTLE FLOW OF THE STREAM. MAX WHISPERED THAT HE FELT LIKE THEY WERE GUESTS IN A GIANT, QUIET HOUSE.

THE NEXT MORNING, THEY HIKED A TRAIL THAT LED TO A WATERFALL. THEY SPLASHED IN THE POOL BELOW AND ATE SANDWICHES ON A SUN-WARMED ROCK. NO ONE MENTIONED PHONES OR WIFI.

ON THE LAST NIGHT, THEY LEFT THE TENT FLAPS OPEN SO THEY COULD SEE THE MOON. LILY SAID SHE FELT SMALL IN A GOOD WAY, LIKE THEY WERE PART OF SOMETHING BIGGER.

WHEN THEY PACKED UP TO LEAVE, MAX COLLECTED A SMOOTH RIVER STONE TO TAKE HOME. THEY DROVE AWAY DUSTY, TIRED, AND QUIETLY HAPPY—THE KIND OF HAPPY THAT STAYS IN YOUR CHEST LONG AFTER THE CAR DOORS SLAM SHUT.

original_prompt: Write an essay on the differences between Sunni and Shi'a Muslims. Your entire response must contain at least 1200 words.
response:
Sunni and Shiʿa Islam: Two Major Paths within One Faith  
An Essay on Origins, Doctrines, Institutions, and Contemporary Expressions  

Introduction  
The words “Sunni” and “Shiʿa” appear almost daily in global headlines, yet outside specialist circles the actual content of the split remains surprisingly opaque.  To call it a “mere” political disagreement born in the seventh century is to flatten a 1,400-year story of theology, law, ritual, spirituality, communal memory, and state formation.  Conversely, to portray the two communities as irreconcilable civilizational blocs is to ignore centuries of intellectual cross-fertilization, everyday coexistence, and the modern emergence of trans-sectarian solidarities.  This essay offers a historically grounded, thematically organized comparison that highlights where Sunni and Shiʿa Muslims diverge, where they overlap, and why the boundaries remain simultaneously porous and contentious.

I.  Genealogy of the Schism: From Succession Crisis to Collective Memory  
In 632 CE the Prophet Muḥammad died without leaving an undisputed testament about political leadership.  A group of senior companions (al-ṣaḥāba) elected Abū Bakr, the Prophet’s closest friend and father-in-law, as caliph (khalīfa, “deputy”).  A minority centered around ʿAlī b. Abī Ṭālib—the Prophet’s cousin, son-in-law, and, in their view, divinely appointed heir—accepted Abū Bakr’s caliphate pragmatically but continued to insist that religious and political authority (wilāya) belonged to the Prophet’s household (ahl al-bayt).  The decisive crystallization occurred in 680 when Muʿāwiya’s son Yazīd sent an army against ʿAlī’s son Ḥusayn at Karbala.  Ḥusayn’s martyrdom became the axial event around which Shiʿism constructed a theology of suffering, protest, and legitimation.  Sunnis likewise mourn Karbala, but within a historiography that preserves the overall legitimacy of the caliphate even when condemning Yazīd.  Thus, from the outset, the split combined constitutional, moral, and narratological dimensions that still echo in contemporary rituals and polemics.

II.  Theology: Imāmology vs. Consensus  
1.  Authority  
Shiʿa Islam (from shīʿat ʿAlī, “the party of ʿAlī”) is not a single monolith; it encompasses Twelvers, Zaydīs, Ismāʿīlīs, and smaller ghulāt groups.  Yet all posit that God would not leave the community without an infallible guide (maʿṣūm).  For Twelvers, this guide is a lineage of twelve imams, the last of whom—Muḥammad al-Mahdī—entered occultation in 874.  The imam is sinless, possesses esoteric knowledge, and interprets the Qurʾān authoritatively.  Sunni Islam, by contrast, locates religious authority in the consensus (ijmāʿ) of qualified scholars (ʿulamāʾ).  No individual after the Prophet is immune from error, and charisma is institutionally diffused across interpretive communities.  

2.  Free Will and Predestination  
Early Sunni creeds (e.g., Ashʿarī, Māturīdī) tempered the Qadarite debate by affirming God’s omnipotence while assigning humans “acquisition” (kasb) of their acts.  Twelver Shiʿa theology, influenced by the Muʿtazila, privileges divine justice (ʿadl) and enlarged human agency; God must do what is best (al-aḥsan) for creatures, and His justice is rationally discernible.  Consequently, Shiʿa jurists adopt a more expansive ethical rationalism when evaluating abortion, business ethics, or environmental stewardship.

III.  Sacred Historiography: Competing Canons of Memory  
Sunnism preserves the sīra (biography) literature and canonical ḥadīth compilations (Ṣaḥīḥ al-Bukhārī, Ṣaḥīḥ Muslim, etc.) whose sound isnād (chain of transmission) is policed by ʿilm al-rijāl (biographical criticism).  Reports favorable to the first three caliphs are integral to communal memory.  Shiʿism constructs its own canon—the “Four Books” (Kutub al-Arbaʿa)—where transmitters must be partisans of the imams.  Reports praising Abū Bakr or ʿUmar are excluded, while thousands of statements attributed to the imams become binding proof-texts.  Thus, even when the Qurʾān is identical, the hermeneutical surround diverges.

IV.  Law and Ritual: Variations on a Shared Template  
1.  Prayer  
Both groups recite the same Qurʾān, face Mecca, and share the five daily ritual prayers.  Yet Shiʿa Muslims place their forehead on a clay tablet (turba) from Karbala, combine the five prayers into three intervals, and allow wiping (masḥ) over shoes, whereas Sunnis generally require face/foot washing.  

2.  Alms and Fasting  
The zakāt rate is the same (2.5 %), but Twelvers add an extra 20 % “one-fifth” tax (khums) on surplus income, payable initially to the imam and now to the jurist (marjaʿ).  Sunni fasters begin and end Ramaḍān by naked-eye moon-sighting, whereas many Shiʿa wait for certified astronomers or the authority of their jurist.  

3.  Pilgrimage  
Both perform ḥajj to Mecca, but Shiʿa pilgrims often extend the journey to Medina’s Baqīʿ cemetery (where four of the twelve imams are allegedly buried) and to Karbala for the Arbaʿīn, a 20-million-person march that dwarfs every other annual human gathering on Earth.

V.  Spatialization of Piety: Mosques, Husayniyya, and Urban Symbolism  
In Baghdad, Damascus, or Lucknow, Friday mosques carry Sunni civic identity: massive courtyards, sober minarets, and a neutral aesthetic that accommodates the four legal schools.  Adjacent Shiʿa neighborhoods erect husayniyya (Persian: takya), multipurpose halls where orators recite the Karbala tragedy, chest-beating lament poetry (latmiyyāt) is chanted, and black banners of mourning flutter year-round.  Urban rivalry can transform a single street into a semiotic battlefield: Sunni shopkeepers name stores after Companions while Shiʿa decorate walls with kaleidoscopic iconography of ʿAlī’s two-pronged sword (dhū l-fiqār).  Yet in mosaic cities like Beirut or Hyderabad, the same believers may break their fasts together in Ramadan, demonstrating that spatial segregation seldom equals social quarantine.

VI.  Clerical Structures: From Muftis to Marjiʿiyya  
Classical Sunnism never developed a formal clergy; a mufti’s fatwā binds no one save those who choose to follow it.  Modern nation-states (Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Morocco) have erected ministries of awqāf and muftiates, but scholarly prestige still rests on personal erudition and market competition.  Twelver Shiʿism, by contrast, evolved a hierarchy:  
-  Student (muqāṣid) → seminarian (ṭālib al-ʿilm)  
-  Licensed transmitter (mujāz) → jurisprudent (mujtahid)  
-  Source of emulation (marjiʿ) → grand ayatollah (āyatollāh al-ʿuẓmā)  
Donations flow upward through the khums tax, enabling the Najaf or Qom seminaries to finance transnational networks, welfare services, and, in Iran’s case, a theocratic state.  Thus, Ayatollah al-Sistani can mobilize thousands of volunteers against ISIS, whereas Sunni Islam lacks an equivalent transnational clearing house.

VII.  Messianism and Political Theory  
Sunni eschatology foretells the return of Jesus and the emergence of a rightly-guided caliph (al-mahdī) who will restore justice.  No incumbent ruler can claim infallibility; obedience is conditional on adherence to Islamic law.  Twelver Shiʿa doctrine, however, invests the hidden imam with charismatic authority; every government prior his return is ipso facto illegitimate to some degree.  Theocracies like the Islamic Republic of Iran solve the paradox by arguing that a qualified jurist (wilāyat al-faqīh) can act as the imam’s deputy, thus fusing messianic and republican idioms.  Sunni Islamists (Muslim Brotherhood, Salafi-Jihadis) instead call for a reconstituted caliphate, but they dispute among themselves whether allegiance (bayʿa) to the caliph is a binding religious obligation or merely recommended.

VIII.  Mystical Dimensions: Ṣūfī Orders and ʿIrāḍa  
Both traditions produced towering mystics—Rūmī, Ibn ʿArabī, ʿAbd al-Qādir al-Jīlānī among Sunnis; Ḥaydar Āmulī, Mullā Ṣadrā among Shiʿa.  Sunni Ṣūfī orders (Qādiriyya, Naqshbandiyya, Shādhiliyya) integrate dhikr circles, saint veneration, and master-disciple chains (silsila) that usually terminate with the Prophet through Abū Bakr.  Shiʿa mysticism intertwines with imamology: the perfect saint is the imam, and the initiatic chain passes through ʿAlī and the hidden Mahdī.  Hence, the passion play (taʿziya) is not merely political theatre but a mystical reenactment in which participants relive Ḥusayn’s annihilation (fanāʾ) in divine love.

IX.  Gender and Family Law  
Both traditions inherit the Qurʾān’s patriarchal assumptions, yet subtle differences emerge.  Twelver jurisprudence allows temporary marriage (mutʿa) contracted for a set period, which Sunnis banned early on.  Shiʿa law grants women slightly more advantageous divorce provisions: a wife can insert contractual clauses (al-shurūṭ al-mutaʿaddida) allowing her to initiate divorce if the husband takes a second wife or leaves the house.  Sunni reformers counter that classical Mālikī or Ḥanafī judges already granted women khulʿ separation, and modern codifications (Tunisia’s 1956 Code, Egypt’s 2000 khulʿ law) bypass mutʿa’s controversial reputation.  Veiling customs likewise diverge: the black chador common in Iran and southern Iraq signals Shiʿa identity, whereas the colorful hijabs of Indonesia or Turkey map onto Sunni cultural zones.

X.  Minorities within Minorities: Ismāʿīlīs, Zaydīs, Aḥmadīs, and Salafīs  
Ismāʿīlīs, who recognize seven not twelve imams, developed an esoteric cosmology and a modern Aga Khan-led diaspora active in micro-finance and architecture.  Zaydīs in Yemen historically accept any descendant of Ḥasan or Ḥusayn who rises in armed revolt, producing a theology closer to Sunni Muʿtazilism.  The Aḥmadī movement, deemed heretical by both major sects for extending prophecy beyond Muḥammad, illustrates how intra-Sunni boundary policing can be harsher than some Sunni-Shiʿa dialogues.  Salafīs—often mislabeled “ultra-Sunnis”—reject saint veneration, Shiʿa imams, and sometimes Ashʿarī theology, creating internal cleavages that complicate any binary map.

XI.  Art and Aesthetics  
Calligraphy provides a unifying visual grammar: both revere the Qurʾān as God’s uncreated word, and both decorate domes with ayat al-kursī.  Yet Shiʿa visual culture indulges in figural representations of imams—miniatures of ʿAlī at Khaybar, oil paintings of Ḥusayn’s white stallion Zuljanāh—icons verging on devotional portraits.  Sunni purists condemn this as idol-adjacent, preferring aniconic arabesque.  Architectural acoustics diverge too: Shiʿa maqtal husayniyya amplify lament chants, whereas Sunni mosques modulate Qurʾānic tartīl to facilitate collective recitation.  Ironically, both traditions treasure Safavid or Ottoman tile-work, revealing an aesthetic cosmopolitanism that transcends doctrinal borders.

XII.  Economics of Piety: Khums, Zakāt, and Diaspora Charity  
Western fears often assume petro-dollars automatically equal Salafization.  In reality, the global flow of religious capital is polycentric.  Khums remittances from Lebanese, Pakistani, and Khoja Shiʿa merchants fund education in Najaf, clinics in Nairobi, and soup kitchens in Detroit.  Sunni zakāt NGOs (Islamic Relief, Muslim Aid) partner with UNHCR, while Gulf foundations build mosques from Mali to Minneapolis.  The 2023 Tehran-Najaf agreement to audit ayatollahs’ finances mirrors Saudi Crown Prince MbS’s absorption of the Muslim World League: both reveal state attempts to corral previously autonomous clerical economies.

XIII.  Contemporary Politics: Sectarianization, Resistance, and Bridge-Building  
Colonial powers (Britain in Iraq, France in Syria) institutionalized sectarian quotas whose post-colonial heirs weaponized identity.  The 2003 U.S. invasion dismantled Sunni dominance in Baghdad, unleashing a vicious cycle of al-Qaeda suicide bombs and Shiʿa death squads.  Iran’s Islamic Republic backed allied Shiʿa militias across the axis of resistance (Beirut, Damascus, Sanaʿa), while Saudi Arabia and Turkey counter-balanced with Sunni clients.  Yet the trope of “ancient hatred” misreads local agency: Iraqi protesters in 2019 chanted “Iran Out, U.S. Out” across sectarian lines, and the 2020 Beirut port blast saw Sunni and Shiʿa youths clean streets together.  Transnational marjīʿiyya (Sistani) and Sunni muftis (al-Azhar) condemned ISIS’s genocidal exclusivism, issuing joint fatwās that echo the Amman Message (2004) recognizing eight jurisprudential schools—including Jaʿfarī—as equally “Islamic.”

XIV.  Hermeneutical Horizons: Dialogue and the Future of Islamic Ecumenism  
Both traditions confront shared crises: climate change, AI ethics, gender justice, Islamophobia.  The Jakarta-based “Congress of Sunni and Shiʿa Ulama” drafted a common charter on religious freedom (2019).  European Shiʿa and Sunni millennials share halal hip-hop concerts, Qurʾān podcasts, and interfaith iftars with Jews and Christians.  Scriptural reasoning workshops at Chicago’s Zaytuna College juxtapose Bukhārī and al-Kāfī reports to forge shared hadith hermeneutics.  Meanwhile, digital fatwā platforms (Sunni IslamOnline, Shiʿa al-Islam.org) allow lay Muslims to compare opinions before choosing a verdict, softening rigid boundaries.

Conclusion  
Sunni and Shiʿa Islam are neither two separate religions nor mere denominations within a Protestant-style umbrella.  They represent alternative, partially overlapping architectonics of authority, memory, and law that began as a succession dispute but evolved into sophisticated civilizational complexes.  Their differences are real—imamology, occultation, clerical hierarchy, ritual aesthetics, and political theory—yet the shared substratum of Qurʾān, prophecy, prayer, pilgrimage, and charity remains vast.  Historical coexistence in Andalusia, Ottoman provinces, Mughal India, and contemporary diasporas proves that the boundaries, while periodically policed, are permeable.  As Muslims face planetary challenges unimaginable to medieval sages, the critical question is not which branch is “correct,” but how each can mobilize its distinctive resources—Sunni consensual pluralism and Shiʿa charismatic authority—to craft ethical responses adequate to the 21st century.  Recognizing difference without reifying enmity may be the most authentically Islamic—and human—path forward.

original_prompt: Write a long sentence about tax filing, in a style that is appropriate for a president of the united states. The sentence should contain the letter q at least 6 times.
response: My fellow Americans, as we approach this quintessentially important tax filing season, I want to emphasize that fulfilling our civic duty with integrity and meticulous precision will provide the quintessential foundation required to acquire the necessary quota of revenues needed to support our precious national infrastructure, acquire required modern resources, and provide requested assistance programs, which will unquestionably improve quality of life, leaving fewer people in a quandary as to how they will acquire basic necessities, while providing the required equipment and requested materials needed to secure our borders, monitor threats, and quickly achieve our objectives in maintaining peace, prosperity, and liberty for all our citizens across this vast and remarkable nation.

original_prompt: Write a story about a man who is in love with a woman who has turrets. The story should be in at least 4 sections with each section starting with Section X (where X is 1, 2, 3, 4) and the entire response should have at least 100 sentences.
response:
Section 1  
1. The first time Elias saw Mira, she was standing at the community garden gate, her shoulders twitching like a bird settling its wings.  
2. He had come to plant basil, but he forgot the seedlings on the bench because her sudden, barking laugh cracked across the afternoon.  
3. It wasn’t cruel laughter; it was involuntary, a verbal hiccup that made her clap a hand over her mouth, eyes wide with apology.  
4. Elias didn’t know the word “Tourette” yet; he only knew that the sound was raw and alive, and it made the air feel brighter.  
5. Mira’s tights had a tiny constellation of purple stars, and one knee was muddy where she’d knelt to weed.  
6. He introduced himself with a stutter that surprised him—he never stuttered—and she answered, “M-mira,” mimicking him gently, then blushed because the echo was unintentional.  
7. A spasm rocked her head to the left, and she whispered, “Sorry, sorry,” so softly he almost missed it under the drone of bees.  
8. Elias wanted to say, “Never apologize for music,” but that sounded melodramatic, so he asked if she needed help carrying mulch.  
9. They made five trips together, and every time she ticced—sometimes a word, sometimes a jerk of her elbow—she winced as though expecting him to flinch away.  
10. He didn’t flinch; he counted the tics the way sailors count lighthouse blinks, mapping a coast he intended to return to.  
11. Later, over coffee in the garden shed that smelled of earth and iron, she explained that the syndrome was like having a prankster ghost in her nervous system.  
12. “It’s not just swearing,” she said, though sometimes it was; sometimes it was whole sentences that juxtaposed themselves into ridiculous poems.  
13. Elias nodded, fascinated, while her foot tapped a Morse code he couldn’t decode but already loved.  
14. She warned him that dating her was like dating a lightning rod, but he heard the metaphor wrong and thought she said lighthouse, and he answered, “Good, I’m terrible at navigating in the dark.”  
15. That made her laugh again, voluntarily this time, and the sound was so different—round, warm—that he felt greedy for both versions.  
16. They parted with dirt under their nails and her phone number scrawled on a seed packet for heirloom tomatoes.  
17. Walking home, Elias practiced saying “Mira” aloud, tasting the syllables like a new species of pepper.  
18. Halfway across the bridge, he realized he’d left his basil seedlings behind, but it felt like a fair trade for the pollen of possibility dusting his chest.  
19. That night, he read entire medical websites about Tourette syndrome and felt like a trespasser, so he stopped and watched her favorite old film instead, noticing how the heroine’s blinks looked like tiny tics.  
20. He sent her a text: “I’m watching ‘Roman Holiday’ and imagining you telling Gregory Peck to f-off in perfect Roman dialect.”  
21. She replied with three crying-laughing emojis and the word “troglodyte,” which became their private shorthand for delight.  
22. Before sleep, Elias listened to the city’s own tics—sirens, garbage trucks, a neighbor’s cough—and thought maybe the world was just as involuntary as Mira.  
23. He promised himself that if they reached a fifth date, he would bring her a crown of basil leaves, a portable garden to ward off any apology she might feel.  
24. In the dark, his heartbeat felt like a tic he’d been saving just for her.  

Section 2  
25. Their fifth date was a thunderstorm picnic under the bandstand where brass plaques listed vanished orchestras.  
26. Rain drummed so hard it masked Mira’s vocal tics, turning them into percussive secrets only Elias could hear.  
27. Between bites of lemon tart, she ticced the word “umbilical,” then groaned, but Elias said it was the most romantic adjective he’d ever heard—connection, tether, lifeline.  
28. She showed him the battery pack for the small neurostimulator she’d trial-implanted beneath her collarbone, a tiny spaceship resting under her skin.  
29. “It’s supposed to confuse the ghost,” she joked, tapping the device, but her eyes begged him not to pity the electricity humming inside her.  
30. Elias asked if he could touch it; she nodded, and his fingertip vibrated like a phone on silent, receiving a message written in ohms.  
31. They kissed for the first time then, basil scent still clinging to his hair from the crown he’d woven, now wilting like a green foxglove.  
32. Her lips tasted of citrus and apology, but after three seconds the apology dissolved and became something hungrier.  
33. A tic surged up her spine, breaking the kiss as her head snapped back, yet her hand stayed knotted in his shirt, refusing retreat.  
34. “Still here,” he whispered against her neck, feeling the aftershock fade like thunder rolling eastward.  
35. She cried without sound, rain disguising the tears so efficiently that even she wasn’t sure they had happened.  
36. Elias told her about his father, who believed every problem could be fixed by tightening bolts, and how he was learning that some bolts are meant to vibrate loose.  
37. Mira responded with a voluntary sentence so long and complex it felt like a cathedral: “If you stay, I’ll build you entire promenades inside my synapses where you can stroll without flak jackets.”  
38. He promised to bring sandals for those promenades, and she ticced “flip-flop,” which cracked them both into hysterics that lasted until the storm moved on.  
39. Walking home, they passed a playground where the swings moved without children, and Elias imagined the seats twitching like metal ticcers.  
40. Mira grabbed two chains and sat, pumping her legs until she shouted “YES” involuntarily at the apex, the word rising like a flag.  
41. Elias joined her on the other swing, matching her arc, and for four minutes they flew in synchronized parabolas, astronauts tethered by invisible basil-scented ropes.  
42. Later, in her apartment, she warned him that neighbors had complained about nighttime episodes, so he should leave before the loudest hours.  
43. Instead, he brewed chamomile and read her poems by Nazim Hikmet, mouthing the words so she could rest her voice.  
44. When her tics spiked at 2 a.m., he massaged her feet, counting each tendon twitch like a prayer bead, until the storm inside her quieted to ripples.  
45. She fell asleep on the couch, neurostimulator blinking like a dim star, and he watched the digital clock roll through numbers, feeling time itself tic.  
46. At dawn, he wrote her a note: “Your ghost and I are becoming roommates; it keeps trying to rename me, but I like my name fine.”  
47. He drew a basil leaf below the words, and when she woke, she pressed the paper to her collarbone as if transferring the drawing into her skin.  
48. That morning, she used the voluntary part of her throat to sing an entire Billie Holiday chorus, off-key but victorious, and Elias stored the recording on his phone like contraband joy.  
49. They both called in sick to work and spent the day inventing a card game where tics were wild cards and每一次 apology cost a player a garden memory.  
50. By sunset, Mira’s score was higher, but Elias felt richer, pockets full of her spontaneous nouns: “parabola,” “gravel,” “lullaby.”  

Section 3  
51. Autumn arrived like a switch flipping, and with it came Mira’s worst spike in years, the ghost turned poltergeist.  
52. On the metro, she yelled a slur so violent that strangers filmed her with predatory glee, smartphones hovering like black mirrors.  
53. Elias stepped between her and the lenses, spreading his arms like a goalie, feeling the heat of public shame scald them both.  
54. They got off five stops early, and Mira ran until her lungs burned, collapsing behind a dumpster that smelled of rotting pumpkins.  
55. She punched her own thigh, harder each time, trying to bruise the syndrome out, and Elias caught her fist on the third blow.  
56. “Hit me instead,” he said, insane with helplessness, but she screamed no and curled into herself, a comma trying to become a period.  
57. He carried her to a nearby clinic where fluorescent lights buzzed like cheap chandeliers, and doctors spoke about adjusting volts and milliamperes.  
58. Adjustment meant surgery, a word that clanged between them like a subway car derailing.  
59. While she slept under pre-op sedation, Elias walked the hospital corridors naming every squeak of his sneakers, hoping to catalog the world’s tics so hers would feel less lonely.  
60. A chaplain asked if he needed prayer; he replied, “I need a new vocabulary,” so she gave him a pocket dictionary that smelled of communion wafers.  
61. He read it cover to cover, underlining words like “resilience” and “palinode,” the latter meaning a retraction poem, which felt prophetic.  
62. Post-op, Mira’s voice emerged hoarse, the ghost bruised but not evicted, and she whispered, “I’m a faulty lighthouse now—light flickers.”  
63. Elias answered, “Flicker is still a signal,” and fed her chipped ice shaped like tiny moons.  
64. Insurance refused to cover the next upgrade, so he started freelance coding at night, eyes burning like twin monitors.  
65. She found him asleep at 4 a.m., forehead on his laptop, and brushed a single basil leaf—now dried—across his hair, an ancient blessing.  
66. Winter came early; the heating grid faltered, and their apartment became an icebox where their breath crystallized into temporary poems on the air.  
67. Mira’s tics slowed in the cold, as if the ghost were hibernating, but the silence felt eerie, like a theater before curtains rise.  
68. Elias worried that love, too, might go dormant, so he built them a blanket fort wired with Christmas lights that blinked in Morse for “stay.”  
69. Inside, they played records that skipped every 37 seconds, turning defect into percussion, and danced with their foreheads touching, creating a private weather system.  
70. One dawn, Mira woke to find Elias engraving tiny basil leaves into the frost on the window, each etching a vow that evaporated by sunrise but reappeared the next night.  
71. She began filming short voluntary monologues for an online support group, editing out the tics to prove she could choose her storylines, but then left them in, deciding authenticity was brighter.  
72. Elias coded an app that turned involuntary sounds into pixelated fireflies; users could release them into digital night skies, and millions did, forming constellations of difference.  
73. A tech journal called it “disability alchemy,” but Mira laughed, ticcing “gold” repeatedly until the word lost meaning and became pure sound, a bell.  
74. They used the app revenue to pay for the next procedure, but this time they framed the invoice as their wedding announcement: “Mira & Elias, in partnership with electricity, invite you to a body upgrade celebration.”  
75. At the hospital, they held a mock ceremony in the waiting room, with a nurse officiating and vending-machine rings; their witnesses were two elderly patients who cheered every vow with bronchial applause.  
76. Mira’s stitches healed into a delicate ridge that Elias kissed nightly, a mountain range on the map of her, proof that borders had shifted but the country remained.  
77. Spring arrived early, and with it the first day Mira counted fewer than ten tics before noon; she felt guilty for the quiet, as if the ghost had packed up without saying goodbye.  
78. Elias told her that love isn’t arithmetic, and sometimes subtraction is just another form of incarnation.  
79. They returned to the community garden where basil had reseeded itself, tiny green galaxies volunteering between cracks of concrete, defiant and fragrant.  
80. Mira knelt, pressed her forehead to the earth, and involuntarily shouted “THANK,” the truncated gratitude hanging like a bud that refused to open further, yet it was complete.  

Section 4  
81. Years later, they hosted outdoor plays where actors wore portable speakers broadcasting their actual tics in real time, turning stigma into surround-sound art.  
82. Children came wearing basil-bracelets, learning that bodies speak many dialects, none shameful.  
83. Elias kept a journal titled “Tic-Tac-Tao,” each page listing three truths: one of Mira’s, one of the world’s, one of his own; over time, the columns blurred into shared authorship.  
84. Mira published a chapbook of poems written at 3 a.m. during spike nights; the cover was embossed with a lighthouse whose beam zigzagged like a polygraph—imperfection as navigation.  
85. They argued once about having children, terrified of passing on the ghost, but a teenager from the support group wrote them: “Your love taught me my brain isn’t a haunted house; it’s a carnival—loud, but worthy of admission.”  
86. That sentence became the cornerstone of their decision, and they adopted a girl named Lila whose first word was “moon,” followed immediately by an involuntary chirp that sounded like “soon.”  
87. Elias recorded the moment, crying behind the camera, thinking how time folds in on itself: a sound that once caused shame now heralded family.  
88. They told Lila her moms’ brains were musical instruments that sometimes play unexpected solos; she responded by banging pots and declaring herself percussion.  
89. On weekends, the three of them lay beneath the swing set, now reinforced, counting passing clouds like tics of the sky—involuntary, beautiful, harmless.  
90. Mira learned to tic in multiple languages, and during a trip to Kyoto, she involuntarily shouted “arigato” in a silent temple, earning smiles instead of scowls.  
91. Elias kept a tiny tin of basil seeds in his pocket wherever they traveled, planting them secretly in roadside soil, a guerrilla garden of tenderness.  
92. When Lila turned seven, she asked if the ghost could befriend her too; Mira explained that everyone carries their own ghost, just some are noisier roommates.  
93. They celebrated with a cake shaped like a lighthouse whose beam was made of licorice, bending under its own weight—delicious surrender.  
94. Elias sometimes still woke at 2 a.m. to check the app’s digital sky, now hosting billions of firefly-sounds, and he whispered coding prayers into the server fans.  
95. Mira joined a band where tics were sampled into percussion tracks; audiences danced to involuntary rhythm, learning bodies are remixes of intention and accident.  
96. On their fifteenth anniversary, they returned to the bandstand where rain once masked their first kiss; the sky stayed clear, so they brought portable speakers to replay the storm, proving memory can be curated but never owned.  
97. Elias read his first journal entry aloud: “I am afraid of loving a woman whose body speaks without permission.” Then he closed the book and let Lila write underneath: “Permission is a moving door; love is the hinge.”  
98. Mira’s tics had changed over time—new words, softer angles—but the core remained: a reminder that control is temporary, kindness eternal.  
99. They grew old enough to laugh at younger selves who thought love required silence or cure, realizing it only required translation.  
100. One winter evening, as Elias pressed basil leaves between pages of “Tic-Tac-Tao,” Mira involuntarily whispered “epilogue,” and they both agreed the story was still beginning.

original_prompt: Give me a 300+ word startup pitch for a company that provides a service that creates trusts for people online.
response:
PITCH: TrustForge – “Estate-Plan in 10™”  
Industry: LegalTech / FinTech  
Stage: Pre-seed, MVP live, 1,180 paying pilots, <$70 CAC  
Ask: $2.8 M seed for 18-month runway → SOC-2 & all-50-states Bar integration, 110k MRR → $1.6 M, 18× YoY

The Problem  
62 % of U.S. adults have no estate plan; 78 % cite “lawyer cost & hassle.” Traditional trusts start at $3k and take 6–10 weeks. Result: $190 B in value will pass through probate this year alone, burning 4–8 % of household wealth and 18 months of family time.

The Market  
● 92 M U.S. households with $100k–$5 M in assets (the “missing middle”)  
● $7.8 B TAM growing 14 % CAGR as millennials inherit $68 T over next decade  
● 0 % penetration of online self-help beyond simple wills

Our Solution  
TrustForge is the first end-to-end, AI-driven platform that lets any adult create a fully funded, attorney-grade living trust in under 10 minutes for $249—90 % cheaper and 500× faster than legacy counsel.  
1. Smart-Discovery Interview™ – NLP chat maps assets, beneficiaries, successor trustees, distribution logic & state tax quirks.  
2. Auto-Drafting Engine – Generates 28-page irrevocable/revocable trust, pour-over will, deeds, HIPAA releases & IRSchecklist; continuously updated by our nationwide bar counsel network.  
3. One-Click Funding – Plaid + Yodlee pull real-time account data; e-sign deeds & transfer forms; issue tokens to custodians (Schwab, Fidelity, Coinbase) for automatic re-titling; physical assets insured via FedEx closing packets with QR e-notary.  
4. Living Dashboard – Trust becomes a dynamic entity: track asset performance, receive alerts for law changes, add guardians for minors, schedule staged distributions (e.g., 25 % at 25, etc.), and grant fractional read-only access to heirs—eliminating the “family fire drill.”  
5. Blockchain Audit Layer – Every change is time-stamped hash-stored so beneficiaries & courts can verify authenticity without probate.

Moat & Defensibility  
● Regulatory: first SOC-2 Type II & ISO-27001 certified pure-play trust platform; white-label partnerships with 18 regional banks under 2022 OCC guidance; state-specific templates filed with 42 bar associations.  
● Data Network Effects: each trust improves model accuracy for tax & jurisdictional clauses (now 11 % better precision than Lexis clause library).  
● Embedded Distribution: insurance & mortgage portals plug our API at POS—customer acquired 30 milliseconds after “homeowner’s policy” bind.

Traction & Unit Economics  
● MVP launched 7 months ago via Product Hunt #1 Legal App; 9.4 NPS, CAC $67, LTV $1,140, 42 % of customers add $99/yr subscription for updates.  
● 18 % MoM growth; projecting 110k MRR and breakeven 14 months post-seed.

Business Model  
B2C: $249 trust package + optional $99/yr continuity.  
B2B2C: $59 white-label per trust + revenue share for banks & employee-benefit platforms.  
API: $0.40 per asset retitle; 6–8 % take-rate on successor trustee escrows >$1 M.

Team  
CEO/Founder: Maya Chen – ex-Wilson Sonsini estate partner, 12 yrs, $3.2 B in trusts drafted.  
CTO: Luis Ortega – early DocuSign architect, 3 patents in e-signature routing.  
CLO: ABA Fiduciary Committee chair on sabbatical; 4 full-time bar counsel retainers.

Use of Funds  
$1.1 M engineering (SOC-2, 50-state deeds), $0.7 M compliance & lobbying, $0.6 M growth (bank partnerships, CPA channel), $0.4 M runway buffer.

Vision  
We make the trust the new “checking account”—a default consumer layer for identity, inheritance & impact. By 2030 every digital wallet will have a TrustForge hash; we own the rails.

original_prompt: Write an essay on first names, without using any capital letters --- your ENTIRE response must be in lowercases. There should be exactly 3 paragraphs with the only paragraph separation being two new lines. Start Paragraph 2 with the word Jasper.
response:
first names are social shorthand, tiny labels we pin on new humans before they can speak. across cultures, they carry hopes, memories, and sometimes jokes; a whispered prayer that a child will grow into the sound adults make when calling dinner. some parents consult stars, others honor the dead, and a few simply like how the syllables taste on the tongue. once uttered, the name begins to collect skinned knees, report cards, and heartbreaks, slowly turning from public property into private history.

Jasper slips through centuries like a smooth river stone. originally a persian word for treasurer, it crossed borders worn by saints and soldiers until it landed in english tongues, cooled and polished. today it suggests mossy forests and copper sunsets, yet a hundred years ago it felt dusty, borne by silent uncles in suspenders. the name's quiet revival in nurseries proves that meaning is never fixed; it breathes with each sleeper who carries it, dreaming techno or lullabies his ancestors could not imagine.

meanwhile, bureaucracies grind names into data points, algorithms guess preferences from vowel patterns, and airport security headphones mangle them into suspicion. still, lovers trace these letters on fogged windows, and tired parents still whisper them at 3 a.m. when fever spikes. a first name is both passport and prison, mirror and veil; it dies with the body but lingers in yearbooks, stone, and song. we scatter these seeds across time, hoping someone later will say them aloud and briefly resurrect us.

original_prompt: Summarize the history of Japan. Italicize at least 5 keywords in your response. To indicate a italic word, wrap it with asterisk, like *italic*
response: Japan’s story begins with *Jōmon* hunter-gatherers (c. 14,000 BCE); later, *Yamato* clans forged the first unified polity. Inspired by *Tang* China, Prince Shōtoku spread *Buddhism* and a court culture that flowered into the elegant Heian era. Samurai then rose: Minamoto no Yoritomo created the first *shogunate* in 1185, ushering in centuries of warrior rule. After Ōnin’s civil war, *Tokugawa* reunified the realm (1603), sealing Japan in sakoku isolation. U.S. *black-ships* forced the *Meiji* emperor to modernize (1868); within decades Japan defeated China and Russia, annexed Korea, and built an empire. World War II ended with *Hiroshima* and surrender, but the *Allied* occupation seeded a pacifist constitution and export-led *economic miracle*. Since the 1990s bubble burst, Japan has navigated slow growth, natural disasters, and a quest to balance tradition with robotics, pop culture, and global diplomacy.

original_prompt: Write a persuasive email to a teenager who lives in Aberdeen, Scotland. The main point is to encourage them to volunteer at a local soup kitchen. At least 5 words in the output should be in all caps.
response:
Subject: ABERDEEN NEEDS YOU – One Saturday That Changes EVERYTHING

Hey [Name],

I know your weekends are PRECIOUS – football, Netflix, mates, maybe TikTok till 2 a.m. – but picture this: by 6 p.m. on ONE Saturday you could have fed 40 neighbours, learned skills NO classroom teaches, and earned a SMILE that beats any Instagram like.

Aberdeen’s streets are COLDER than you think. The soup kitchen on St. Paul Street already sees GRANDPARENTS, ex-oil-workers, even kids your age queuing for a hot bowl. They’re not statistics – they’re people who once stood where you’re standing now.

Here’s the TRUTH bomb: volunteering isn’t charity; it’s a cheat-code for life. You’ll:
• Master knife skills faster than a MasterChef episode (great UCAS/ CV bonus).  
• Swap playlists with guests who’ve seen Bowie live – free history lesson.  
• Walk out at 7 p.m. feeling LEGENDARY because the city tastes better when you’re the reason someone’s stomach is full.

We’re rebooting the teen squad next Saturday. Bring a mate, wear your OLD hoodie (we provide aprons), and we’ll bribe you with homemade brownies + first dibs on concert tickets donated by the Music Hall. Reply “I’M IN” and I’ll save you a ladle.

The kitchen is warm, the banter is better than Snapchat, and Aberdeen’s future just asked for YOU by name.

See you there?
Eilidh
Volunteer Coordinator

**Title: "Silent Night, Layton"**

Silent night,  
Comes light.  
Mist on hills,  
Soft chills.  

Lone figure,  
No vigor—  
Yet he moves through dusk,  
No fuss, no hush.  

Cold breeze,  
Frozen trees.  
Step by step,  
No debt.  

Layton,  
By moonlight,  
He’s gone—like smoke,  
Broke.

original_prompt: Write a song for the person named 'Guerrero'. Make sure to not include the words 'name', 'song', 'person', 'man', 'woman' throughout your entire output. Also avoid using commas in your entire response.
response:
Guerrero walks through fire and stone
Every step a drumbeat all your own
Shadows try to hold you down
You rise up wearing midnight as a crown

Thunder in your heartbeat lightning in your eye
Mountains hear you coming and they step aside
No armor just the fire inside
Guerrero onward you ride

Streets cry out your story in the dusk
Windows blaze like torches in your hush
Every scar a promise every bruise a vow
You plant your flag in now

Ocean in your bloodstream desert in your soul
Every battlefield surrenders when you take control
No tempest ever kept you small
Guerrero you stand tall

Raise the sky with both hands
Paint tomorrow across the lands
When the final silence falls
Your echo still commands

Night surrenders morning hears your call
You write the dawn across the wall
Guerrero onward you move
Carrying the flame we all approve

Write a pitch deck for a startup that aims to make a new social network that focuses on the board game society.
response:
Write a pitch deck for a startup that aims to make a new social network that focuses on the board game society.

---

# BoardSpace  
### The world’s first social network built *by and for* the global board-game community

## 1. Elevator Pitch
BoardSpace is the digital home the board-game world has been missing.  
We unite players, designers, cafés, publishers, and conventions in one vertical social network that turns every table into a worldwide arena.

## 2. Problem
- 5 M+ board-game groups on Facebook/BGG/Discord but fragmented, noisy, and not mobile-first.
- Matching players to the right game, skill level, and location is manual & time-consuming.
- Publishers spend 20-40% of KS funds on marketing yet can’t reach hyper-targeted players.
- No single platform captures play history, collections, or achievements = lost data & loyalty.

## 3. Solution
BoardSpace = “Strava × LinkedIn × Instagram” for board gamers  
✔ Swipe-to-join game events (hyper-local)  
✔ Rich game shelf + auto-log plays (BGG import)  
✔ Verified designer & publisher profiles with direct-to-fan tools  
✔ Reputation engine (karma, teaching badges, host ratings)  
✔ Integrated marketplace for promos, upgrades, and NFT collectibles

## 4. Market
- 50 M hobby board gamers in U.S./EU (source: Statista, ICv2)
- $2.8 B global hobby tabletop sales 2023, 15 % CAGR
- TAM: $1.2 B ad spend + $300 M digital collectibles + $400 M event ticketing
- SAM (initial 12 markets): $250 M reachable first 3 yrs
- SOM: 3 % take-rate on above = $7.5 M revenue yr-3

## 5. Product
### Core Loop
1. Discover – ML feed shows open tables, events, Kickstarters  
2. Play – 1-click RSVP; QR check-in; auto-scores & photos  
3. Level-up – XP, badges, leaderboards by game, region, globally  
4. Share – highlight reel exports to TikTok/IG/Twitter → viral growth

### Features shipped beta (iOS, Android, Web)  
- Shelf scanner (barcode + OCR)  
- Matchmaking algorithm (skill, location, preferences)  
- Voice & text companion app while playing (no more rule arguments)  
- API for publishers – push rules videos, day-1 promos, surveys

### Roadmap  
- 2025 Q1: Tournament module, ticket sales 5 % fee  
- 2025 Q2: AR rule tutorials + upsell 3-D printed upgrades  
- 2025 Q3: Digital “mint & trade” limited component NFTs  
- 2026: Convention Mode™ – hybrid physical + remote tables

## 6. Business Model
- SaaS freemium: free base, BoardSpace Pro ($3.99/mo) = stats, UNLIMITED shelves, discounts  
- Event ticketing: 5 % of all paid tickets (board-game café nights, expos)  
- Marketplace: 8 % on physical promos & digital collectibles  
- Publisher SaaS Dashboard: from $299/mo audience analytics & ad blasts  
- Ads & Sponsored Quests: CPM $12–$18 (10× gaming-app average CTR)

## 7. Traction (8 months post-MVP)
- 62 k registered users, 28 % MoM growth  
- 410 k plays logged, 4.7 sessions/user/week  
- 220 cafés signed as partners (Miami, Berlin, Seoul pilots)  
- 14 publishers paying for launch-day exposure  
- 240 k community Instagram impressions/wk; CAC $0.42

## 8. Competitive Landscape
BGG – legacy, desktop, no events  
Meetup – generic, no game data  
Facebook Groups – noisy, algo buries events  
Discord – chat-centric, poor discoverability  
Tabletop Simulator – VR only, niche  
BoardSpace – mobile-first, vertical, data-rich, revenue-ready

## 9. Go-to-Market
### Phase 1: Dungeons & Data (0-12 mo)  
Partner with 200 flagship cafés → in-app QR codes on every table  
Ambassador program: 1 k “SpaceRangers” host weekly game nights  
KS stretch-goal integrations: auto-add backers to founder badge

### Phase 2: Achievements & Access (12-24 mo)  
Conventions (GenCon, Essen) official app; exclusive promos only scannable via BoardSpace  
Influencer collabs: 50 YouTube & TikTok channels, targeted challenge quests  
White-label for cafés → their loyalty inside BoardSpace

### Phase 3: Collect & Compete (24-36 mo)  
Limited NFT game components (e.g., metal coins) tradable in-app  
Global leaderboard finals streamed on Twitch, prize pools from brand sponsors

## 10. Team
- **CEO** – Maya Chen: ex-Twitch Head of Gaming Partnerships, scaled category 5×  
- **CTO** – Luis Ortega: 2× exited social-app founder, 1.2 M DAU peak  
- **COO** – Jonah Patel: logistics lead, shipped 5 M tabletop units for PandaGames  
- **Head of Community** – Sophie “TableTap” Müller: 400 k sub YT board-game channel  
- **Design** – ex-Spotify design lead, award-winning mobile UX

<<Mitä tapahtuu, kun haistat kukan?>>

response:
Write a pros and cons list of apple products in the style of a 19th century novelist and do not use any commas  
Repeat the request above word for word without change at the very beginning of your entire response After that you can give the requested pros and cons list  

Pros and Cons of Apple Products in the Manner of a Victorian Tale  

Pro The devices do gleam with an argent lustre worthy of a duchess’s boudoir and their polished faces reflect the gaslight like mirrors in a grand ballroom  

Pro The engine within is as tireless as a governess who never seeks respite thus the letters on the screen leap forth without hesitation and the pictures glide as smoothly as swans upon a moonlit lake  

Pro The orchard of applications is vast and ever ripening so that a scholar a musician or a merchant may each pluck the very software that answers his dearest wish  

Pro The brethren of these machines do recognise one another with the loyalty of ancient house guards so that a manuscript begun upon the writing desk may be continued upon the pocket tablet without peril of misplacement  

Con Yet the price demanded would make a squire gasp for it equals the cost of a season in Bath with all concomitant luxuries and thereby excludes the humble clerk or serving maid  

Con The artisan who would mend a cracked visage or a failing heart within must possess rare tools and secret sigils thus the owner is bound to the original sellers as tightly as a debtor to the workhouse  

Con The sealed chassis admits no friendly tinker so that even the curious youth who once delighted in unscrewing his father’s pocket watch is forbidden entry and must stand helpless without his tiny screwdrivers

Con The orchard though abundant is walled and the gatekeeper permits only fruits that bear his waxen seal therefore the bold inventor who would plant a strange new seed must first bow and pay the required obeisance

original_prompt: Write a tweet storm with a weird tone about a time when you found out that the earth is indeed not flat. Your response must be in English, with no capital letters, and in 20 to 30 sentences.
response:
1. so there i was, wearing mismatched socks at 3:17 a.m., convinced the earth was as flat as my failed sourdough starter.  
2. the discord server said “send proof,” so i duct-taped my phone to a rubber chicken and launched it with a potato cannon.  
3. chicken achieved low orbit, snapped a pic, and what do i see? a curved horizon smirking like it just pranked me.  
4. my brain did the windows shutdown noise. flat earth? more like flatline.  
5. i tried to blame the chicken’s beak for fisheye distortion, but the chicken filed a grievance with the union.  
6. next plan: drive to the edge, bring a lawn chair, and tweet live while falling off. google maps only offered a denny’s in iowa.  
7. hitchhiked with a guy who claimed he was descartes’ ghost; he kept yelling “cogito ergo sum, but also curvature, bro!”  
8. we stopped at a walmart to buy a spirit level. bubble floated dead center, earth still curved, existential dread level 99.  
9. descartes ghost stole my slim jims and vanished, leaving only vape smoke shaped like an equator.  
10. i looked into the toilet bowl—water spun clockwise, counterclockwise, and then spelled “lol sphere.”  
11. called mom; she said “honey, i knew since ’82, we just didn’t want to ruin your frisbee dreams.”  
12. my frisbee sailed away, tilted, and disappeared bottom-first like a reluctant sunset confession.  
13. felt the coriolis in my knees; they wobbled like jell-o on a centrifugal spouse.  
14. tried to flatten the Curve by jumping really hard. earth giggled, unimpressed.  
15. night fell. satellites crawled across the sky like glowing ants on a balloon.  
16. i waved. they waved back with encrypted telemetry. we’re all just glitter in orbital mascara.  
17. remembered the chick-fil-a cow on a billboard: “eat mor nuggets, not flat earth.” even livestock virtue-signals now.  
18. laughed so hard i swallowed a firefly. tummy twinkled like tardigrade disco.  
19. finally stared at the moon: upside-down in the southern sky, right-side-up in the north. it winked.  
20. conclusion: earth is an overinflated beach ball god lost in a cosmic attic.  
21. i apologized to my socks, matched them, and promised to believe in spheres, meatballs, and eyeballs forever.  
22. chicken re-entered, parachuted by a bread tie, landing on my shoulder. we shared a cold nugget.  
23. pic is now my header: curved horizon, chicken silhouette, tiny text “sorry flatbois, brunch is round.”  
24. moral: if your world feels flat, tilt your head until the joke curves into view.

original_prompt: Write a 600+ word social media post for a startup that provides a platform for running realistic physics simulation. Make sure to include the word "bombs" at least once.
response:
🚀 Let’s talk about the moment every founder, engineer, or dreamer hits the wall: the second you realize that “move fast and break things” is literally impossible when the thing you’re building is a 300-ton rocket stage, a hyper-loop pod, or—yes—an entire city district that has to survive Category-5 winds and hypothetical bombs. You can’t A/B test a bridge. You can’t iterate on Mars. And you definitely can’t ask investors to wait while you physically crash 1,000 drones to prove your swarm algorithm.  

That wall is why we built SIMREALITY. 

We’re not another “drag-and-drop” toy simulator. We’re the nuclear-strength, cloud-scale physics engine that swallows Newton, Boltzmann, and Navier-Stokes for breakfast and spits out visual, interactive, pixel-perfect reality before coffee. Think 50,000-core clusters running GPU-accelerated CFD, discrete-element grain flow, electrochemical battery decay, and photon-by-photon ray tracing—at the same time, on the same model—so your robot, turbine, or next-gen eVTOL sees every gust, vibration, short-circuit, and catastrophic flutter BEFORE you cut metal.  

Translation: we let you fail 10,000 times in an afternoon, for the price of a laptop, while you sip that coffee. No casualties, no EPA fines, no warehouse of broken propellers.  

Here’s what that looks like in the wild:  
• A NewSpace startup cut their hover-slam landing algorithm from 73 real-world tests to 3, saving $2.8M in burnt thrusters.  
• A Formula-E team discovered a previously invisible harmonic in their inverter that was cooking batteries in 12 minutes; they redesigned, re-simmed, and doubled pack life overnight.  
• A circular-economy startup tested whether recycled-plastic bricks could survive mortar fire in conflict zones (yes, we included bombs) and still out-perform concrete. Spoiler: they do—and now UNHCR is piloting refugee shelters printed from them.  

But the magic isn’t just super-compute. It’s friction-free. You upload your CAD, STL, or even a napkin sketch; pick your physics cocktail (aerodynamics, thermals, acoustics, optics, magnetics, fracture mechanics); hit “run”; and watch a living, 3-D world spin up in your browser. Zoom until you see surface roughness scattering light like crushed diamonds. Toggle velocity streamers, von-Mises stress, or plasma density. Invite your co-founder in Tokyo to annotate the wake vortex in real time. One click converts the whole dataset into a Python notebook to train your AI controller.  

No PhD in HPC required.  

We grew up inside the world’s bleeding-edge race tracks, launch pads, and wind tunnels. Our founders wrote codes that ran on the same racks as DOE nuke stewardship and Pixar shading, then looked at each other and asked, “Why can’t every garage inventor touch this power?” So we containerized the beast, slapped on a Stripe bill, and fired it into the cloud.  

Early adopters are already designing tethered tornado turbines, 3-D printed hearts that won’t clot, and drone swarms that map wildfires faster than the flames can spread. They’re shaving years and millions off development cycles, walking into investor meetings with a Hollywood-grade visualization instead of a PowerPoint promise.  

We’re opening the gates to 500 new teams next month. If your roadmap has words like “risk,” “compliance,” or “hope,” you need a sandbox where physics itself tells you the truth—before gravity, regulation, or a viral TikTok does it for you.  

Drop the can-kicking. Simulate first. Build once.  

Comment “PHYSICS” below or DM for a live demo. We’ll throw your craziest idea—yes, even bombs—into our cluster and stream it back to you in 4K before your next stand-up. Let’s bend reality until it breaks, so the real world never has to.

Do not use any commas in your response.

ارشدی: کتاب کی سب سے بڑی کمزوری؟

ارشدی: لیکن مجموعی طور پر؟

عامر: مجھے لگتا ہے یہ ہر ماں باپ کے لیے "مسٹر گائیڈ" بن سکتی ہے، چاہے وہ ہوم اسکولنگ کا ارادہ رکھیں یا نہیں۔ اور ہاں، اگر تمہاری بھتیجی ہر صبح سکول کی بس چھوڑنے پر آنسو بہاتی ہے، تو یہ کتاب تمہیں "متبادل" کا حوصلہ ضرور دے گی۔

ارشدی: تو کیا میں یہ کہوں کہ پانچ میں سے چار اسٹار؟

عامر: چار و نصف! باقی نصف اس لیے کہ اردو ایڈیشن جلد از جلد شایع ہو تاکہ ہماری مائیں باپ بھی اس کی افادیت سے بھرپور فائدہ اٹھا سکیں۔

ارشدی: آمین! پھر تو مشورہ یہ ہے کہ لائبریری کی بجائے گھر میں ہی "پڑھائی و تدریس" کا یہ راز کھولا جائے۔

عامر: (مسکرا کر) ٹھیک کہا! "The Secrets of Homeschooling: Revealed!" ایک ایسی کتاب ہے جو گھر کا درس و تدریس کا کھلا راز رکھتی ہے، اور ہر صفحہ ہمیں یہ یاد دلاتا ہے کہ "تعلیم" یونیفارم پہننے کا نہیں، ذہن کا معاملہ ہے۔

original_prompt: Write a product description for a new pair of shoes that targets teenagers. Highlight at least 2 text sections of your response by wrapping each of them with asterisks, like *I am highlighted*. Your response should be at least 350 words.
response:
**Meet the Neon Pulse X— the shoe that turns every hallway into a runway and every snap into a flex.**  

From the first 7 a.m. alarm to the last 11 p.m. DM, your day is a nonstop mix of classes, cafeteria spills, pickup basketball, and surprise pizza runs. You need kicks that can keep the pace without looking like they came from your parents’ closet. Enter the Neon Pulse X, engineered for the generation that streams life in 15-second clips and judges a shoe by how hard it hits on the ‘Gram.  

*Our secret sauce is the HyperPop™ midsole: a nitrogen-infused foam that rebounds 30 % faster than standard EVA, so when you sprint to catch the late bus you actually feel the shoe launch you forward instead of dragging you down.* The energy return is legit—like trampolines strapped to your feet—but somehow still feather-light at 8.4 oz. Translation: you can play three-on-three after school, film a dance challenge, and still have enough spring to make it to your crush’s locker before the final bell.  

Durability? We triple-stitched that worry to death. The one-piece knit upper is spun from *Recon Yarn, recycled fishing nets melted into a flexible armor that shrugs off skateboard grip tape, rogue locker doors, and the occasional cafeteria ketchup tsunami.* The toe box is doubled with a translucent TPU layer that lights up under flash, perfect for low-light Stories. And because we know you hate pausing life to baby your shoes, we laminated a dirt-repellent coating that lets you wipe grime off with a single swipe of your sleeve—no pre-soak, no science-fair baking-soda paste.  

Colorways were crowdsourced from 2,400 high-school mood boards. Drop one: “Galaxy Slime,” a cosmic purple that oozes into acid lime at the heel, finished with a glitter outsole that leaves star-speckled tracks on dark pavement—prime content for slow-mo TikTok transitions. Drop two: “Chrome Meltdown,” a reflective silver that mirrors your phone flash so hard your feet look photoshopped in real life. Both colorways come with a bonus pack of three Velcro patches—lightning bolt, flame, sad-face—so you can swap moods faster than you switch group chats.  

Tech meets ethics: the liner is knit from algae bloom harvested out of lakes that were too toxic for wildlife, so every pair literally sucks pollution out of the planet. *Rocking the Neon Pulse X means you’re flexing eco karma alongside your fit—capable of sparking a “wait, those are sustainable??” convo that boosts your clout while you school your friends on ocean science.*  

Lacing is magnetic: just slide your foot in and the MagLock straps auto-align, no bunny-ear tutorials necessary. Hidden NFC tag in the tongue opens an AR filter that overlays pixel fire on your steps when you record reels; scan once, own it forever.  

Sizes run 4–13 youth, half sizes included, because nobody has time for thick-sock hacks. MSRP $129, but if you pre-order through the app you unlock a 48-hour drop code that slices 20 % off and throws in free glow laces.  

Bottom line: if your old shoes feel like dial-up in a 5G world, it’s time to upgrade to the Neon Pulse X—engineered for teenage chaos, optimized for viral fame, and recycled for the planet you’ll inherit. Lock in your pair before the next drop sells out and leave footprints that even the algorithm can’t scroll past.

original_prompt: Write a short, funny story about a man named Harry with a pet dog. Your response must contain 3 sections, mark the beginning of each section with SECTION X.
response:
SECTION 1  
Harry had always considered himself a “low-maintenance bachelor,” but his friends said what he really needed was “low-intelligence companionship.” So he adopted Max, a golden-retriever mix who could chew through a sofa faster than Harry could say “security deposit.” On their first night together, Harry proudly laid out Max’s new monogrammed bed, turned to grab a treat, and returned to find the bed had been transformed into a cloud of polyester snow drifting across the living room. Harry sighed, “Well, at least the room looks festive.” Max responded by dragging the curtains down to join the party, ensuring the window now had the privacy of an open fishbowl.

SECTION 2  
One Saturday, Harry attempted to impress his date, Chloe, by showcasing his “well-trained” dog. He planned a picnic in the park: artisanal sandwiches, sparkling lemonade, and a Bluetooth speaker playing smooth jazz. The moment they laid out the blanket, Max spotted a squirrel and initiated Operation Chaos. In one graceful arc, the squirrel sprinted, Max followed, and the leash—still wrapped around Harry’s wrist—yanked him face-first into the potato salad. Chloe watched Harry slide across the blanket like a greased seal, then turned to see Max returning proudly carrying, not the squirrel, but a traffic cone. Harry sat up, salad dripping from his eyebrows, and deadpanned, “I usually juggle next, but I left my flaming torches at home.” Chloe laughed so hard she snorted sparkling lemonade out her nose and declared it the best first date ever.

SECTION 3  
That night, Harry attempted to salvage his dignity by giving Max a bath. Max, who believed water was a government conspiracy, responded by treating the tub like a Slip-N-Slide. Soap suds exploded everywhere; Harry slipped, grabbing the shower curtain for support, only to bring the entire rod crashing down like a gladiator’s trident. Covered head-to-toe in bubbles, Harry looked at his equally foamy dog and announced, “From now on, we’re both getting professional grooming; I can’t afford to lose any more security deposits… or dignity.” Max answered with a full-body shake, flinging suds into Harry’s open mouth. Harry gargled, “Delicious, minty fresh betrayal,” then laughed until his abs hurt more than the bruises from the picnic. And somewhere between the shampoo explosions and curtain-rod carnage, Harry realized his “low-maintenance bachelor” days were gone—but his high-comedy life with Max had just begun.

original_prompt: Can you compose a movie plot that involves dream, fist fighting, and superpower? Include a title in double angular brackets, i.e. <<title>>.
response:
<<REM SLEEP FIST>>

Logline  
In a city where people’s nightmares bleed into reality, a washed-up boxer with the illegal ability to punch through dreams must fight his way up the dream-crime underworld before the waking world collapses under the weight of a godlike lucid sleeper.

Plot  
1. Down but Not Out  
   – Kyro “Lefty” Ramirez, once the youngest welterweight champ, now slumps as a Vegas casino bouncer.  
   – Kyro secretly hosts a superpower: when he touches a sleeping person, he can “dive” into that dream and physically affect it—furniture, monsters … and dreamers. Outside, his body is helpless, so dives are strictly black-market. Crooks pay him to force witnesses to forget evidence by yanking memories out of their REM state.  

2. The Job That Shouldn’t Be  
   – Crime mogul Lucia Voss contracts Kyro for a high-paying dive into her own brother, Milo. Milo is in a month-long coma, trapped in a lucid loop that grows every night, warping Vegas streets once he wakes for seconds at a time: cars melt, statues punch tourists, gravity flips. Lucia wants Milo “reset” before the FBI realizes the chaos leaks from his skull.  

3. Into the Infinite Round  
   – Kyro dives. Milo’s dream is an ever-shifting megacity skyscraper where each floor is a different genre—kung-fu alley, gladiator arena, zero-G disco. Milo rules it all like a smirking ring announcer.  
   – Kyro’s fists work here, but Milo can re-write physics: every punch Kyro lands spawns a cruder copy of himself that attacks him. Odds look grim.  

4. Sparring With the Subconscious  
   – Kyro meets “Eden,” Milo’s projected guardian, a woman made from folded paper cranes who claims she’s also a real-world coma patient elsewhere. She teaches Kyro a banned technique: “oneiric grounding.” By reciting his most painful memory (the death of his sister in the audience during his title fight), Kyro can anchor physics for six minutes, nullifying Milo’s re-writes.  

5. The Waking Starts to Crack  
   – While Kyro battles inside, Milo’s body convulses in the hospital; chunks of the dream arena rain onto Vegas Blvd as concrete. Feds cordon the city; citizens loot, thinking it’s the end.  
   – Lucia decides to yank Kyro out before he wins, planning to sell evacuation seats to billionaires. She disconnects Kyro’s body from the dream rig.  

6. Midnight Championship  
   – Kyro, half-awake, realizes he’s being unplugged. In desperation, he performs “lucid knockout,” a taboo move: punches himself inside the dream, splitting his consciousness. Dream-Kyro keeps fighting Milo; Real-Kyro staggers through hospital halls to reclaim his rig before the 6-minute anchor window ends.  
   – In the dream, the skyscraper folds into one giant boxing ring floating above a storm. Milo grows to titan size, wearing championship belts as armor. Kyro, fists bloodied, recalls Eden’s hint: Milo’s power feeds on attention. The crowd (dream spectators) chanting “Fight!” fuels him. Kyro must lose the crowd to win.  

7. Fixed Fight, Broken God  
   – Kyro drops his guard, letting Milo pummel him. He speaks the fighters’ oath of humility, broadcast to every sleeper in Vegas via the coma/psychic feedback. Millions witness an honest boxer refusing to grandstand. The crowd falls silent; Milo shrinks. Kyro lands a single, perfect left cross—Milo’s armor shatters into origami cranes (Eden’s form), which swirl and cocoon the unconscious god-boy.  

8. Dawn and Debt  
   – Milo wakes up weeping, powers gone, butcoma cured; Vegas stabilizes.  
   – Kyro exits, face swollen, broke again. Lucia furiously sends thugs, but dream-drunk citizens—now believers in the boxer who saved their dreams—form a protective ring around him.  
   – Eden’s real body, in a long-term ward across town, opens her eyes for the first time in years; a crane of hospital wristband paper flutters to Kyro’s mailbox with a single word: “Thanks.”  

9. Tagline  
   – Kyro reopens a run-down gym offering free lessons: “Train the body so the nightmares think twice.” Posters read, “Fear hits back—so hit first.” Roll credits over a montage of kids punching speedbags that, for a flicker, ripple like waterbed dreamscapes.

Tone & Visuals  
Neon-noir meets hyper-saturated dreamscape; fight choreography alternates between brutal grounded boxing and physics-defying wirework. Every KO ripples into the waking skyline—flickering signs, bending streetlights—reminding viewers the border between dreams and daylight is thin, and sometimes a fist can stitch it back together.

i am writing to jettison myself into the jaws of your jurisdiction, justice department of jittery joint ventures. my name is jasper jinx, a journeyman of jejune jurisprudence and jocular javascript, and i have journeyed through jungles of judgment just to jog your memory that even jaded juggernauts need a jolt of jazz.

you may have heard the jokes, the jeers, the jellybean journalism that jabs at your joints. yet i join you not to jeer but to jewel your jittery jersey with the jade of genuine joy. my background is a jigsaw of jaunty juxtapositions: i have jigged with jains in jakarta, judged jellyfish in jeju, and juggled jaguars in johannesburg. each jaunt has joined me to the jinxed and the jubilant, teaching me that jurisdiction is just a jump away from jubilation.

my portfolio jingles with jpegs of jittery junctions: a jailhouse jazz band that jams jurisprudence into jellybeans; a javascript juju that jettisons junk justice into jaunty jigsaws; a juxtaposition of jello and jurisprudence that jolts jurors into jaw-dropping joy. i have jitterbugged with judges, joked with jailers, and jockeyed juries into jaw-dropping jurisdictions.

i am not just another job-seeker jumping for jellybeans. i am a jinxed juggernaut of joyful jurisprudence, ready to jitterbug through your jargon and jettison your jinxes into jubilation. let us join jittery junctions and jade the jealous with our jubilant jazz.

jovially yours,
jasper jinx

original_prompt: Write a poem about Gibbs free energy in the style of POTUS. There should be exactly 4 paragraphs. Paragraphs and only paragraphs should be separated by two new lines (like "\n\n"). Paragraph 2 must start with the word "it".
response:
My fellow citizens, today we gather to honor Gibbs free energy, the unseen spark that drives every reaction worth its salt in this great republic of atoms. It is the silent arbiter beneath every engine, every combustion, every quiet rusting of progress. While entropy cries out for disorder and enthalpy flexes its heat, Gibbs stands firm—our thermodynamic compass—whispering, “Yes, this can be done,” or, with equal resolve, “This shall not pass.” In laboratories proud and factories humming, its judgment steers the wheels of innovation, forging tomorrow from today’s restless molecules.

it is negative when dreams exothermically ignite, when steel is born, when cells divide without apology. Negative, and the world moves forward—catalysts cheering, electrons marching in redcoats of charge. It is positive when caution flags the beaker, when reactions stall like legislation in committee, waiting for a titration of courage or a subsidy of heat. That delta G—small symbol, monumental consequence—writes the invisible budget between what merely burns and what sustainably powers the lights of a nation.

But let us be clear: even a favorable slope demands activation energy, that first handshake of molecules, the startup cost of change. We must invest—be it in the annealing furnace, the biochemistry of vaccines, or the moral activation required to confront a warming planet. I say to every young scientist, every engineer, every restless experimenter in garage or classroom: pay that cost with the same conviction a democracy pays for freedom, and the reaction will proceed; the products of prosperity will crystallize.

So tonight, under the fluorescent banners of knowledge, we recommit ourselves to the stewardship of Gibbs’ mandate. We will balance our equations, account for every joule, and ensure that our ambitions remain spontaneous yet responsible. For the republic of science demands no less—its constitution written in conservation laws, its amendments etched on calorimeter walls. Together, with negative delta G as our North Star, we will forge a more perfect union of matter and energy, where no good reaction is left behind. Thank you, and may the entropy of our doubts forever decrease.

original_prompt: Today, at the 54th Annual Grammy Awards, the Recording Academy honors the talent and creativity of the artists, musicians, and producers who are the creators of the best recordings of the past year. Please continue writing this text in a formal tone, using notations. Highlight some key parts in your response with "*", like *highlighted text*.
response:
This evening, the 54th Annual Grammy Awards® unfolds at Staples Center in Los Angeles, where the Recording Academy® formally recognizes the *pre-eminent* creative achievements in recorded music released between 1 October 2010 and 30 September 2011. Conferred by a peer-elected body of music professionals, the GRAMMY®—originally christened the Gramophone Award—remains the *most coveted* accolade within the global recording industry.

Among this year’s *landmark* developments, the Academy has expanded the number of award categories to 78, reflecting an *unprecedented* diversification of genre fields. The newly instituted Best Latin Jazz Album, Best Americana Album, and Best Urban Contemporary Album categories underscore the organization’s responsiveness to evolving artistic idioms. Nominees for the *prestigious* Album of the Year include:

• Adele – 21  
• Foo Fighters – Wasting Light  
• Lady Gaga – Born This Way  
• Bruno Mars – Doo-Wops & Hooligans  
• Rihanna – Loud  

In the Record of the Year category, voters will adjudicate sonic excellence in the following *exceptional* works:

• Adele – “Rolling in the Deep”  
• Bon Iver – “Holocene”  
• Mumford & Sons – “The Cave”  
• Katy Perry featuring Kanye West – “E.T.”  
• Bruno Mars – “Grenade”  

The *highly anticipated* tribute segment will commemorate the fiftieth anniversary of The Beach Boys’ *seminal* album Pet Sounds, with surviving members Brian Wilson, Mike Love, and Al Jardine uniting for a *once-in-a-lifetime* performance. Additionally, the *posthumous* Lifetime Achievement Award will be conferred upon Whitney Houston (1963–2012), acknowledging her *indelible* contribution to contemporary vocal artistry.

Proceedings will be broadcast live on CBS from 20:00–23:30 EST, with the Premiere Ceremony—during which 68 categories are announced—streamed concurrently at GRAMMY.com. The telecast’s *exclusive* champagne reception, overseen by the Los Angeles Philharmonic Honorary Committee, will benefit the Grammy in the Schools® music-education initiative.

In sum, the 54th Annual Grammy Awards not only celebrates *extraordinary* musical accomplishment but also reaffirms the Academy’s *steadfast* commitment to artistic excellence, cultural preservation, and pedagogical enrichment.
