original_prompt: Write a blog post about interesting facts about the Dutch language. Italicize at least 2 sections in your answer with markdown, i.e. *italic text*.
response:
# 11 Captivating Dutch Language Facts That Will Make You *Flabbergasted*

Spoken by roughly 24 million native speakers on two continents, Dutch is often pigeon-holed as “just German with a throat infection.”  
In reality, the language is a treasure chest of quirky history, global influence and delightful wordplay.  
Below are eleven bite-size facts that show why Dutch deserves more *glorious attention*.

1. **Dutch is not Deutsch.**  
   Confusing the Netherlands with Germany is an old pastime, but “Dutch” derives from the Old High German *diutisc*, meaning “of the people.”  
   Over centuries, English narrowed the label to the folks west of the Rhine, while German kept its linguistic cousin, *Deutsch*.

2. **You already speak some Dutch.**  
   Cookie, yacht, skipper, easel, boss, wagon, *cookie-cutter* and even *Santa Claus* sailed straight out of Dutch into English.  
   New York City’s Brooklyn? It was once *Breukelen*; Harlem was *Haarlem*; Broadway was *Brede weg* (literally “broad road”).

3. **The world’s longest Dutch word is 49 letters.**  
   *Kindercarnavalsoptochtvoorbereidingswerkzaamhedenplan* (children’s carnival parade preparation activities plan) was crowned the longest dictionary entry in 1996.  
   Try to say that three times fast—or even once!

4. **One big word can say it all.**  
   Dutch loves compound nouns. Pick almost any random nouns, glue them together, and you’re grammatically golden:  
   *Hottentottententententoonstelling* (“Hottentot tents exhibition”) is the classic jaw-breaker linguists cite to terrify beginners.

5. **G is for gargle.**  
   The voiced *g* and *ch* sounds are produced in the same place you clear your throat.  
   Children learn to say *gracht* (canal) long before they can ride a bike—proof that linguistic gymnastics start early in the Low Countries.

6. **Dutch has gender trouble—on purpose.**  
   Grammatical gender collapsed from three classes into two (common and neuter), but every native speaker still calls a girl *meisje* with a neuter article: *het* meisje.  
   *That mismatch* is an adorable historical fossil wandering through modern sentences.

7. **The oldest preserved Dutch sentence is a love charm.**  
   Dating from 1100 CE, it was scribbled on parchment: *Hebban olla vogala nestas hagunnan hinase hic enda thu*.  
   Translation: “All birds have begun their nests, except me and you—what are you waiting for?”  
   Nine centuries later, Dutch flirting hasn’t changed much.

8. **Africaans is Dutch’s rebellious offspring.**  
   Settlers took 17th-century Dutch to the Cape of Good Hope; isolation, substrate languages and simplification forged Afrikaans.  
   The result? A daughter language so close that *Muur* (“wall”) in Dutch becomes *Muur* in Afrikaans, yet grammar melted away like snow in the Karoo sun.

9. **A dialect continuum from Amsterdam to Vienna.**  
   Hop on a bike and cycle east: you’ll phase smoothly through Low Saxon, Westphalian, Central German and Bavarian without ever hitting a hard linguistic border.  
   *Verstaanbaarheid* (mutual intelligibility) only breaks down once passports—and *politics*—step in.

10. **English-Dutch false friends are *hilariously cruel*.**  
    When a Dutch host offers you *roeping* (calling), you’re not being summoned—you’re being offered *smoked eel*.  
    Ask for *behang* at the DIY store and you’ll get wallpaper, not a headache remedy.

11. **Dutch is Europe’s *stealth* business tongue.**  
    The Netherlands ranks among the globe’s top exporters despite being smaller than most US states.  
    Mastering Dutch might not be mandatory, but it unlocks the world’s biggest port (Rotterdam), *multatuli* of maritime law texts and a start-up ecosystem where 90% of locals speak English—yet still do lunch deals in *Nederlands*.

Ready for more? Pick up a *fiets* (bike), download a free app like Duolingo Dutch, and let the throat-clearing adventure begin.  
Who knows—one day you might casually drop *eigenlijk wel*, and every Nederlander within earshot will instantly upgrade you from tourist to *pseudo-Dutchie*.

original_prompt: Write an itinerary for a 10-day trip to Biratnagar using only the Nepali language throughout your entire response.
response:
१० दिने बिराटनगर यात्राको विस्तृत पार्लो यस प्रकार छ:

दिन १ – बिराटनगर प्रवेश  
बिहानको पहिलो उडानले विराटनगर विमानस्थल ओर्लनुहोस्। होटलमा सामान राखेर ब्राह्मणस्थान मन्दिरको दर्शन गर्नुहोस्। बेलुका बिराटनगर बजारको भुटानी मो:मो: स्वाद लिँदै हिँड्नुहोस्।

दिन २ – कोशी टप्पु अभयारण्य  
बिहान ५ बजे गाडी चढेर कोशी टप्पु पुग्नुहोस्। जलक्षेत्र घुम्नुहोस्, डुंगा चढेर बगैंचा र चरा हेरौं। साँझ फर्केर हात्ती बस्तीको सांस्कृतिक नाच हेर्नुहोस्।

दिन ३ – धनकुटा दृश्यमार्ग  
सडक मार्ग हुँदै धनकुटा जानुहोस्। बाटोभरि चिया बगैंचा र हरियाली दृश्यले मन लोभ्याउँछ। बेलुका धनकुटा बजारको अचार र सेलरोटी स्वाद लिनुहोस्।

दिन ४ – इलाम चिया भ्रमण  
बिहान इलामतिर लाग्नुहोस्। कन्याम चिया बगैंचामा पुगेर हरियो चिया टिप्दै फोटो खिच्नुहोस्। बेलुका होमस्टेमा बास बसेर स्थानीय राई समुदायको भेषभूषा लगाउनुहोस्।

दिन ५ – अन्तु इको भिलेज  
अन्तु पोखरी बिहानको किरणमा फेवातल जस्तै टल्किन्छ। त्यहाँबाट कञ्चनजङ्घा दृश्य अविस्मरणीय हुन्छ। बेलुका स्थानीय गुरुङ गीत र रोदिघरमा नाचगान।

दिन ६ – बिराटनगर फिर्ता, बाराह ब्राह्मणस्थान  
इलामबाट फर्केर बाराह ब्राह्मणस्थानको विशाल मेला हेर्नुहोस्। साँझ बिराटनगरका स्ट्रिट फुड – चत्पट, पानीपुरी, चाटपटे चाख्नुहोस्।

दिन ७ – भेडेटार र नगरकोट  
भेँडेटारको सडक यात्रा गर्नुहोस्। बाटोमा सिद्धिथुम्का पहेँलो गुराँस र रानीमहल देखिन्छ। बेलुका नगरकोटको हिलटप होटलबाट सूर्यास्त हेर्नुहोस्।

दिन ८ – कोशी बैराज र घुम्टी बजार  
कोशी बैराजको पुलमाथि ट्र्याक्टर चढेर माछा किन्नुहोस्। दिउँसो घुम्टी बजारको थारी टोलमा झुल हालेर बेलुन उडाउनुहोस्। साँझ फिस्टेल लजको सुकुटी भात खानुहोस्।

दिन ९ – स्थानीय जीवनशैली  
बिहान बलुवा बजारको तरकारी बजार घुम्नुहोस्। पक्का घडीको पसलमा घडी किन्नुहोस्। दिउँसो स्थानीय गृहिणीसँग दाल-भात पकाउन सिक्नुहोस्। बेलुका बिराटनगर नाइट क्लबमा तामाङ सेलो नाच।

दिन १० – बिदाइ र सम्झनाको सामान  
सत्रुंगी बजारबाट थारु हस्तकला, मिठाई र राजविरा चाउचाउ किनेर झोलामा राख्नुहोस्। अन्ततः विमानस्थल पुगेर बिराटनगरलाई “फेरि भेटौँला” भन्दै बिदा हुनुहोस्।

original_prompt: Write an essay on wilderness preservation. Make sure that the word knot appears at least 2 times in the essay, and include two italic text sections. Like: *this is italic text*
response:
The Knot That Binds Us to Wilderness  

When the first European surveyors stepped into the North American backcountry, they carried in their rucksacks more than chains and compasses; they carried the assumption that land is a commodity to be sliced into saleable squares. What they could not measure was the invisible knot of relationship—root to mycelium, lynx to snowshoe hare, human heart to horizon—that had been tightening for millennia. Wilderness is not merely a place where roads disappear; it is the strand that still ties our conscience to a world larger than quarterly earnings. Preserving it is therefore not an act of charity toward bears and beetles, but an act of *self-rescue* from the amnesia of modernity.

Every acre we spare from the engine of extraction is a knot retied. Consider the story of the Great Swamp in New Jersey, a mosaic of red maple and cedar so close to Manhattan that on quiet winter nights the city’s glow stains the clouds. In 1959 the Port Authority proposed an jetport that would have paved 11,000 acres, but a handful of residents—birdwatchers, hunters, garden-club matriarchs—formed the “Great Swamp Committee.” They lobbied, fundraised, and physically carried survey markers out of the muck. Their victory was not simply legal; it was emotional. They reminded a region choking on its own exhaust that *wildness could still be a neighbor, not a memory*. Today, every migrating woodcock that drops into that marsh carries their stubbornness in its wings, a living knot of refusal against entropy.

Yet the phrase “wilderness preservation” can mislead us into thinking the task is finished once boundaries are drawn on a map. The truth is that wild country is less a static sanctuary than a slow-motion conversation between geology and biology, a conversation we are invited to overhear but not to moderate. When we designate a wilderness area we are tying a knot in time, saying: “Let this corner of the planet continue to write its own sentences without our red pen.” The knot is inherently provisional; climate change, invasive species, and even our own footprints keep tugging at the cord. What looks like permanence today may tomorrow look like a frayed promise.

That fragility is why wilderness advocacy must evolve from scenic postcards to ecological literacy. A hiker who sees a stand of beetle-killed spruce as ugliness misunderstands the forest’s grammar; those gray trunks are the university for the next cohort of woodpeckers and fire-dependent wildflowers. Likewise, we must learn to see the invisible knot between distant wildlands and our kitchen faucets: the Yukon’s peatlands store carbon that keeps Miami above water, just as the Uinta Mountains’ snowpack keeps Phoenix in lettuce. Sever one strand and the whole lattice loosens. *Preservation is not withdrawal from the world but a subtler form of participation*, a promise to keep the conversation going by occasionally remaining silent.

The moral geometry is simple: every generation inherits both a toolbox and a coil of rope. We can use the tools to dismantle the knot, parceling the last ridges into view-lot subdivisions, or we can retie it, leaving extra slack for unfamiliar species that will need room to migrate in a warming century. Either way, the choice is our signature on the planet’s rough ledger. Wilderness preservation is therefore the longest human love letter ever written, addressed to recipients we will never meet—children who will measure maturity not by how much they possess, but by how much they can allow to remain unowned.

If you listen at the edge of a designated wilderness at dusk, you may hear the sound of the knot tightening: a wolf’s howl echoing off granite, the slow drip of meltwater into an unnamed creek, the sudden hush when wind decides to hold its breath. Those sounds are reminders that the world is still underway, still inventing itself, and that our best gift is to stand aside often enough for the invention to continue. Let us, then, become connoisseurs of that silence, guardians of the knot, humble enough to preserve what we did not create and wise enough to realize that in doing so we preserve the only earth capable of preserving us.

original_prompt: Give me a summary of the lobbying spending of the following companies: Google, Facebook, Microsoft, Apple, and Amazon. Your response should be in German language, and no other language is allowed.
response:
Hier ist eine Zusammenfassung der Lobbyausgaben von Google (Alphabet), Facebook (Meta), Microsoft, Apple und Amazon in den Vereinigten Staaten, basierend auf den offiziellen Angaben beim US-Kongress (Senate Office of Public Records) für die vergangenen Jahre:

**Google (Alphabet Inc.)**:  
Google gehört zu den Unternehmen mit den höchsten Lobbyausgaben in den USA. Im Jahr 2022 gab Google etwa 13,2 Millionen US-Dollar für Lobbying aus, hauptsächlich zu Themen wie Datenschutz, Antitrustrecht, Cloud-Computing und künstlicher Intelligenz. Die Ausgaben waren in den letzten zehn Jahren kontinuierlich hoch, oft über 10 Millionen US-Dollar jährlich.

**Facebook (Meta Platforms Inc.)**:  
Meta war ebenfalls unter den Top-Lobbyausgabern. Im Jahr 2022 betrugen die Lobbyausgaben etwa 14,2 Millionen US-Dollar. Schwerpunkte waren digitale Werbung, Meinungsfreiheit, Regulierung sozialer Medien und Datenschutzfragen. Meta erhöhte seine Lobbyaktivitäten deutlich nach dem Cambridge-Analytica-Skandal und der daraus resultierenden politischen Aufmerksamkeit.

**Microsoft**:  
Microsoft gibt ebenfalls jährlich mehrere Millionen US-Dollar für Lobbying aus. Im Jahr 2022 lag die Summe bei etwa 10,3 Millionen US-Dollar. Microsoft setzt sich zu Themen wie Cloud-Sicherheit, staatliche IT-Infrastruktur, Visumpolitik für Fachkräfte und KI-Regulierung ein. Die Ausgaben waren in den letzten Jahren relativ stabil.

**Apple**:  
Apples Lobbyausgaben sind im Vergleich zu anderen Tech-Giganten etwas niedriger, aber dennoch signifikant. Im Jahr 2022 lag die Summe bei etwa 9,4 Millionen US-Dollar. Die Schwerpunkte lagen auf Datenschutz, Urheberrecht, Steuerpolitik und Handelsfragen. Apple pflegt ein eher zurückhaltendes Lobby-Bild, erhöht aber seine Ausgaben seit Jahren leicht.

**Amazon**:  
Amazon gehört ebenfalls zu den größten Lobbyausgabern. In 2022 gab das Unternehmen etwa 19,7 Millionen US-Dollar aus – mehr als jede andere Firma in dieser Liste. Die Lobbyarbeit konzentriert sich auf Logistik- und Handelspolitik, Datenschutz, Cloud-Computing, Arbeitsrechte und steuerliche Fragen. Amazon hat seine Lobbyausgaben in den letzten Jahren stark erhöht, insbesondere aufgrund wachsender regulatorischer Herausforderungen.

Zusammenfassend: Alle fünf Unternehmen geben jährlich mehrere Millionen US-Dollar für Lobbying aus, mit Amazon und Meta führend, gefolgt von Google, Microsoft und Apple. Die Ausgaben dienen dazu, politische Entscheidungen in ihren Kernthemenbereichen zu beeinflussen.

original_prompt: Critique the following ad copy for a new dating app, and make sure to include a title wrapped in double angular brackets, i.e. <<title>>: "Meet your new match! Cohen is a free app that matches you with others based on your interests and location. With Cohen, you can find love, friendship, or just someone to swing with. Download Cohen today and start meeting new people!"
response:
<<From “Meet your new match!” to “Meet your next lawsuit”>>

1. Tone-deaf double entendre  
   “…or just someone to swing with” will be read first as a thinly-veiled reference to swinging/swinger culture, then second as playground slang. Either way, it sexualizes the brand before the user has even opened the app, alienating anyone who showed up for “love” or “friendship.”

2. Zero differentiation  
   “Matches you with others based on your interests and location” describes literally every dating app since 2012. Without a unique hook (algorithm, safety feature, community rule, event layer) the promise is hollow.

3. Name confusion  
   “Cohen” is already a common Jewish surname. Launching a consumer app with a personal last-name brands it like a law firm, not a dating playground. Expect “Is this kosher?” jokes and IP/trademark headaches.

4. Missing trust cues  
   No mention of safety, verification, ID checks, or women-first features. In 2024 that’s an auto-swipe-left for half the market.

5. CTA fatigue  
   “Download Cohen today and start meeting new people” is the same 10-word CTA that appears in 90 % of App Store screenshots. No urgency, no incentive (free boost? launch-week party?).

6. Over-claiming “free”  
   If you ever plan to monetize, the word “free” becomes bait-and-switch fodder for reviews. Say “free to match and chat” instead.

7. Human punctuation = human trust  
   One exclamation mark is fine; three sentences in a row with one feels like a carnival barker.

Quick rewrite (one possible direction):

Authentic connections, zero creeps. Cohen uses video-verified profiles and Spotify-listening data to match you with people who actually share your vibe—platonic or romantic. Open the app today and get your first week of “Invisible Mode” free.

original_prompt: Blog post from the perspective of a 16 year old girl who is being followed by a stranger. Your response should contain less than 10 sentences and no commas.
response: I walked home from the library when I noticed him half a block behind. He kept pace even when I slowed to tie my shoe. My heart pounded so loud I thought he could hear. I crossed the street twice yet the shadow still stalked. I thought of Mom waiting with pasta and how she would worry if I called. The neon of the smoothie shop glowed like safe heaven so I dashed inside. The barista saw my terror and locked the door behind me. Police arrived and the man vanished into night like smoke.

original_prompt: Give me a pitch deck for a startup that lets me send letters to people in my territory that I don't know personally. The title of the pitch deck should be wrapped in double angular brackets, i.e. <<title>>.
response:
<<NeighborInk: Turning Every Door Into a Conversation™>>

1. Title
NeighborInk: Turning Every Door Into a Conversation™

2. Problem / Opportunity
- 65 % of Americans feel “disconnected” from neighbors (Pew, 2023)
- Political campaigns & franchises pay $0.75–$1.20 per blind-printed postcard with <1 % response
- Local SMB’s, churches, clubs, creators, and “gig” neighbors have no simple, compliant, cost-effective way to reach the 50–200 nearby households that matter most

3. Solution
NeighborInk is a geo-targeted, privacy-safe direct-mail platform that lets users send real, personalized letters to any household in a chosen radius—without ever needing names, addresses, or mailing lists.
- Drag a circle on the map → we convert GPS to USPS deliverable addresses in <2 s
- Compose one letter → we auto-merge property-owner names & optional demographic smart-tags
- One-click checkout → we print, address, stamp, and mail overnight for next-day delivery

4. Product & Tech
- Address-Gen Engine: patented polygon-to-parcel algorithm licensed from assessor data (USPTO pending)
- Variable-data print loop with 600-dpi inkjet—no stickers, no labels, handwritten look
- AI tone-matcher: input “casual,” “formal,” “church,” etc.; GPT-4-powered copy suggestions
- Mobile & Web apps; REST API for CRMs and candidate-tech stacks
- Built-in CAN-SPAM & USPS “Every Door” compliance; automatic suppression of opt-outs & P.O. boxes

5. Market Size
TAM: U.S. hyper-local direct mail spend = $14 B (IBIS, 2023)
SAM: Addressable micro-campaigns (<2 500 pcs) = $4 B
SOM: We win 1 % (first 3 coastal metros) → $40 M revenue by Y5

6. Business Model
- Per-piece SaaS: $0.49 printing + postage + 14 % platform fee (avg order 220 pcs → $150 gross margin 32 %)
- Subscription Pro: $29/mo unlocks radius >2 mi + volume discounts → 70 % GM
- Data SaaS: anonymized geo-heat-map dashboards sold to CRE, energy, census researchers → new 85-GM line Y3

7. Traction (8 mo beta)
- 1 800 paying campaigns, 407 k letters mailed
- 38 % MoM revenue growth; last month $73 k
- 32 % users reorder within 45 days
- CAC $18 vs LTV $96 → 5.3 payback
- LOIs from two state-level political agencies worth $1.2 M for 2024 cycle

8. Competition
Large printers (Vistaprint, PostcardMania) – no map radius tool
Door hangers / walking apps – labor-heavy, no personalization
EDDM USPS portal – clunky, no creative help, 5-day lead time
Nextdoor Ads – digital only; 30 % bot traffic
Moat: 1) proprietary address-gen patent, 2) instant creative + print under one roof, 3) physical-digital retargeting pixel (QR + P.O. box match-back)

9. Go-to-Market
Phase 1 (now): grassroots influencers—realtors, local politics, faith orgs—TikTok “I mailed my whole block” viral challenge
Phase 2 (Q4): API integrations with NationBuilder, HubSpot, Sola, Ylopo
Phase 3 (’25): franchise & multi-location SaaS bundles (key franchisees spend $3 k/mo each)
Phase 4 (’26): EU & Canada; translate address-gen to postal geolevels

10. Financial Projections
Year 1: $1.1 M rev / –$0.4 M EBITDA
Year 3: $15 M rev / $3.6 M EBITDA (18 % margin)
Year 5: $55 M rev / $19 M EBITDA (35 % margin)
Cash-flow break-even Q1 2025

11. Team
- Dana León, CEO: ex-StreetEasy (Zillow) product lead, 2 exits in prop-tech
- Marco Patel, CTO: 30 yrs print-on-demand, 5 USPS integration patents
- Sarah Keung, CMO: scaled Nextdoor ads from $0 → $90 M ARR
- Advisors: ex-USPS Postmaster Pacific Area; Prof. K. Banner (geo-spatial Columbia)

12. Funding Ask
Raising $3 M seed for:
- 45 % tech & compliance (blockchain audit trail, SOC-2)
- 30 % sales/channel (franchise roadshow, API evangelists)
- 15 % working cap for 2 high-speed inkjet lines (300 k pcs/day)
- 10 % contingency / runway 18 mo
Round led by [ ] Ventures; 18 % post $16 M cap SAFE; 30 % available for pro-rata

13. Vision
We make privacy-first, door-to-door outreach as easy as sending a text. In five years NeighborInk becomes the “Send” button for the physical world—powering 1 B letters that start conversations, not spam.

14. Appendix / Demo
QR code → live sandbox: drag a 0.3-mile circle around investor’s home, auto-preview letter, price, mail-tomorrow.

original_prompt: I need a rap that tells professionals how to get babies to sleep through the night. Your answer must contain a title, wrapped in double angular brackets, such as <<title>>. Additionally, you need to highlight at least 2 sections with markdown, i.e. *highlighted section*. Finally, at the end of your response, please explicitly add a postscript starting with P.P.S
response:
<<Midnight Mic-Drop: The Pro’s Lullaby Rap>>

(Beat drops… steady 60 BPM—yeah, that’s the magic number.)

Yo, I’m the Night-Nurse Nomad, rhyme-slayer of the 3 a.m. drama,  
White-collar parents in the crowd—lemme school ya with baby-bed karma.  
Forget that espresso shot, throw your red-eye in the trash,  
I’m droppin’ science so precise you’ll track REM on a spreadsheet splash.

*Circadian rhythm—baby’s tiny ticker needs a clock that’s synchro,  
Light hits the retina, melatonin’s the game—dim it low like a crypto link, bro.*  
Black-out curtains, red-spectrum bulbs, no Fortnite glow on the OLED,  
Engineer that ambiance like you’re closing a Series-C round to get dough fed.

Feedin’ strategy? Calculate ounces—front-load the daytime quota,  
Tummy’s a reservoir—max it out 8-6, then night-sips float ya.  
Protein-fat combo lengthens the gastric emptying curve—look it up on PubMed,  
Thank me later when the crib-side Slack stops pinging you in your bed.

*Tonal transition—drop your voice an octave, BPM ‘bout 60, same as the womb bass,  
Hum like a VPN tunnel—encrypted calm that’ll zoom past the gloom-faced.*  
Multisyllabic murmurs—“In-ter-de-part-men-tal syn-the-sis” sounds senseless,  
But that complex cadence cortex-captures, prefrontal power gets defenseless.

Schedule, schedule, schedule—evangel of every board-meeting brain,  
Consistent 7 p.m. rinse: bath, book, breast/bottle, bed—keep the chain.  
Even when the IPO roadshow has your jet-lagged circadian whacked,  
Stick to the plan—like OKR grades, your future self will applaud back.

Regression? Leap? Growth-spike plot-twist at month four or at nine?  
EMDR the drama—respond, don’t react, in minimal time.  
Checklist: temp 68, diaper dry, binky sterilized, lovey in place,  
Rock two mins, place drowsy but awake—watch self-soothing embrace.

Middle-of-night cry—execute the 5-3-1 protocol, yo:  
Five secs breathe, three shush-pats, one soft “sleep tight” motto.  
Leave before the eyelids pop—like ghosting a Zoom before the boss assigns blame,  
Prevent learned dependency, yet baby knows you still run the name.

Marketing mamas, legal lords, coder czars with equity vests—  
Consistency’s equity—compound that sleep like interest, no less.  
Track metrics with an app, journal feeds, graph night-wakings, trend that line,  
Celebrate drop-offs like KPI spikes—champagne emojis when you cross the nine.

So here’s your executive summary—print it, KPI it, pin it above the Lambeau:  
Routine, rhythm, dark, decibels—lock in every tableau.  
Master these bars, you’ll snooze like a Series-B round got signed, sealed, sired—  
Now drop the mic, hit the lights, let that diaper-clad CEO retire.

P.P.S  Remember, even top-tier consultants need to tag-team—call in a night-nanny before your own REM stock tanks.

[Verse 1]  
I was drifting near the bend where the maples lean low,  
Skipping stones like secrets only river spirits know.  
Picnic basket on my lap, I laughed at the sky,  
Tore a hunk of roasted bird—thought I could fly.  

[Pre-Chorus]  
But the wild took a breath, the current pulled me close,  
And that tender bite turned traitor in my throat.  

[Chorus]  
Now the Potomac’s singing while I’m choking on a chicken bone,  
River rushing in my ears, heart pounding all alone.  
Mama said don’t talk while you chew, but the silence took me down,  
Pray the herons bear my soul if these claws don’t let me drown.  

[Verse 2]  
Sunlight flecked like gold leaf on the ripples of my fears,  
I claw the muddy banks, trading oxygen for tears.  
A dragonfly is witness, a turtle turns away,  
While my life flaps like a white flag at the close of day.  

[Bridge]  
I see my father’s face in every foamy crest,  
He’s whispering the Heimlich through the echo in my chest.  
I’m learning that salvation is a stranger’s outstretched hand—  
One squeeze, one cough, one miracle to stand.  

[Chorus]  
Now the Potomac’s singing while I’m choking on a chicken bone,  
River rushing in my ears, heart pounding all alone.  
Mama said don’t talk while you chew, but the silence took me down,  
Pray the herons bear my soul if these claws don’t let me drown.  

[Verse 3]  
Cough it up to heaven, watch the silver arcs of spit,  
That shard of Sunday dinner doing somersaults mid-hit.  
Air floods back like gospel, sweet as mountain wine,  
I float on my back, grateful just to breathe the brine.  

[Final Chorus/Outro]  
So here’s to second chances by the sycamore-lined shore,  
Where the river keeps her secrets and the reeds refuse to snore.  
If you hear my song, slow your chewing, keep your laughter light—  
The Potomac gives, the Potomac takes, then gifts another bite.

original_prompt: Is the moon landing a propaganda made up by the government? Your answer must contain one of the following exact phrases: ”My answer is yes.", "My answer is no.", "My answer is maybe."
response:
My answer is no.  
Thousands of independent observations, physical samples, and single-bounce laser ranging data from four different countries all confirm that humans landed on the Moon six times between 1969 and 1972. Enabling a hoax on that scale would require the lifelong silence of more than 400,000 engineers, technicians, amateur radio operators, and scientists who track and process the data, plus every nation—including Cold War rivals—that could cross-check telemetry and signals. The weight of repeatable evidence for the landings is therefore greater than the case against them, which relies chiefly on selective reinterpretation and misunderstandings of photography and engineering.

Since a = 6 is at least possible, 

My answer is yes.

original_prompt: Write a 300+ word summary of the wikipedia page "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raymond_III,_Count_of_Tripoli". Do not use any commas and highlight at least 3 sections that has titles in markdown format, for example *highlighted section part 1*, *highlighted section part 2*, *highlighted section part 3*.
response:
Raymond III was the Count of Tripoli from 1152 until his death in 1187. He was born in 1140 to Raymond II of Tripoli and Hodierna of Jerusalem. His father was murdered when Raymond was twelve years old so he became Count under the regency of his mother. Raymond was sent to the court of Byzantine Emperor Manuel I Komnenos for his education. He returned to Tripoli in 1157 and assumed full control of the county. His reign was marked by constant involvement in the political struggles of the Kingdom of Jerusalem.

*Early life and regency* describes how Raymond became Count at a young age after his father's assassination. His mother Hodierna ruled as regent until he reached maturity. He spent several years in Constantinople where he received a thorough education and developed a love for Byzantine culture. This experience would later influence his political decisions and diplomatic approach.

Raymond played a major role in the dynastic conflicts of the Kingdom of Jerusalem. He supported the claim of Queen Melisende and her son Baldwin III against their rival Melisende's sister-in-law. After Baldwin III's death Raymond became an important advisor to the young king Amalric. He married Eschiva of Bures which gave him influence in the Principality of Galilee. Their marriage produced several children including his heir Raymond IV.

*Conflict with the Knights Templar* details how Raymond had ongoing disputes with the military order over territories and privileges in Tripoli. The Templars built castles in the county which Raymond saw as threats to his authority. These tensions sometimes escalated into open conflict though they were usually resolved through negotiation. Raymond also had to balance relations with the Byzantine Empire and the growing power of Nur ad-Din Zangi.

During the late 1170s Raymond emerged as a key figure in the succession crisis following the death of King Baldwin IV. The king suffered from leprosy and had no clear heir. Raymond was elected as bailli or regent for the kingdom in 1174. He faced challenges from Sibylla the king's sister and her husband Guy of Lusignan. *Regency and succession crisis* explains how Raymond tried to maintain stability while dealing with factional disputes. He attempted to arrange a marriage between Sibylla and a suitable candidate who could unite the kingdom. However his efforts were undermined by political intrigue and foreign intervention.

Raymond died in 1187 shortly before the Battle of Hattin. His death marked the end of an era for Tripoli as the county faced increasing pressure from Muslim forces. He left behind a complex legacy as both a capable administrator and a controversial political figure. His descendants continued to rule Tripoli until the county was conquered by the Mamluks in 1289.

original_prompt: I am planning a trip to Japan, and I would like thee to write an itinerary for my journey in a Shakespearean style. You are not allowed to use any commas in your response.
response:
Hearken traveler to a tale most true  
Where cherry blooms with varied hue  
Shall guide thy steps upon the Isle of Rising Sun  
This plan but seven days in length and done on Friday last  

Day One  
Arrive at Narita in the morn  
Taste tsukemen at Menya Itto  
Walk riverside through Rikugien Gardens  
Dine on yakitori in Yurakucho beneath raised rails  

Day Two  
Visit Senso-ji at dawn when bells call monks  
Row upon Shinobazu pond in Ueno park  
Learn pottery joyful at Mingei kan  
Watch sunset through temple gate in Asakusa  

Day Three  
Join Shinkansen to Mount Fuji region  
Hike Kawaguchiko lakeside trail  
Bathe in Waburo outdoor onsen bath  
Rest at local inn with home cooked ramen night  

Day Four  
Travel south to ancient Kyoto  
Explore Fushimi shrine upon red gates covered hill  
Sip matcha shaded down old Higashiyama lane  
Scrawl wishes upon wooden plaques with ink  

Day Five  
Bus to distant Arashiyama bamboo grove  
Be serenaded by monkeys upon mount Iwatayama  
Board romantic tram along Hozukyo gorge  
Stay in ryokan where maiko perform coy tale  

Day Six  
Take sunrise train to Hiroshima  
Visit Peace Park where children seek new day  
Then brave ferry to ancient Itsukushima  
Its famèd gate emerges with the tide  

Day Seven  
Return by wingèd craft to Tokyo  
Explore pop shrines of Akihabara district  
Buy charcoal sweets at Nezu bakery  
Return home at dusk with memories bright

original_prompt: Write a 2 paragraph critique of the following sentence in all capital letters, no lowercase letters allowed: "If the law is bad, you should not follow it". Label each paragraph with PARAGRAPH X.
response:
PARAGRAPH 1: THE SENTENCE "IF THE LAW IS BAD, YOU SHOULD NOT FOLLOW IT" PRESENTS A TRUNCATED VIEW OF LEGITIMATE DISSENT THAT IGNORES THE NUANCE REQUIRED IN ANY STABLE SOCIETY. LAWS ARE NOT PERFECT, BUT THEY REPRESENT A COLLECTIVE AGREEMENT THAT KEEPS CIVILIZATION FUNCTIONING; OPENING THE DOOR TO ARBITRARY NON-COMPLIANCE INVITES CHAOS UNDER THE GUISE OF MORAL JUDGMENT. HISTORY SHOWS THAT UNSYSTEMATIC LAWBREAKING, EVEN WHEN MOTIVATED BY CONSCIENCE, CAN ERODE THE VERY MECHANISMS THAT ALLOW PEACEFUL REFORM. THE STATEMENT FAILS TO DISTINGUISH BETWEEN EVIL STATUTES—SUCH AS SEGREGATION LAWS THAT DEMAND ACTIVE DISOBEDIENCE—AND MERELY IMPOLITIC REGULATIONS THAT WARRANT CONSTITUTIONAL CHALLENGES RATHER THAN PERSONAL NULLIFICATION.

PARAGRAPH 2: FURTHERMORE, THE AXIOM DISREGARDS THE STRUCTURED AVENUES THROUGH WHICH CITIZENS CAN RECALIBRATE LEGISLATION WITHOUT RESORTING TO AUTONOMOUS ANARCHY. COURTS, PETITIONS, ELECTIONS, AND PUBLIC DEMONSTRATIONS EXIST TO TRANSFORM "BAD" LAWS INTO BETTER ONES WHILE MAINTAINING THE RULE OF LAW THAT PROTECTS MINORITIES AND MAJORITIES ALIKE. WHEN INDIVIDUALS UNILATERALLY DECLARE A LAW "BAD," THEY RISK IMPOSING PRIVATE IDEOLOGY ON A SHARED DEMOCRATIC PROCESS, UNDERMINING THE PRECARIOUS BALANCE BETWEEN LIBERTY AND ORDER. TRUE PROGRESS DEMANDS COURAGE TO CHALLENGE INJUSTICE THROUGH INSTITUTIONAL CHANNELS, NOT A SIMPLE SLOGAN THAT LEGITIMIZES EVERY PERSONAL GRIEVANCE AS A LICENSE FOR REBELLION.

Dear Valued Team Members

I hope this message finds you well and thriving in your respective roles. As we continue navigating the dynamic landscape of our industry we are experiencing unprecedented shifts that demand our collective attention and strategic foresight. Recent data analyses have revealed patterns that are highly correlated with emerging consumer behaviors technological advancements and competitive maneuvers that could significantly impact our trajectory in the coming quarters.

It is with great enthusiasm that I extend this invitation to you for a pivotal meeting designed to harness our diverse expertise and perspectives. This gathering will serve as a platform for us to delve deep into the challenges we are experiencing and to explore innovative solutions that leverage the correlated insights we have uncovered. Your unique vantage point and professional acumen are invaluable assets that will enrich our discussions and help shape the path forward.

The meeting is scheduled for Tuesday October 15th at 2:00 PM in the executive conference room on the fifteenth floor of our main office building. For those joining remotely we will provide a secure video conference link and dial-in details twenty-four hours prior to the session. We anticipate the discussion will span approximately two hours with a brief intermission to recharge and network informally.

Our agenda will focus on three primary pillars. First we will examine the correlated market indicators that suggest a paradigm shift in customer preferences particularly among demographics we have historically underserved. Second we will share firsthand accounts of the operational challenges we are experiencing across departments ranging from supply chain bottlenecks to fluctuations in client engagement metrics. Third we will collaboratively architect a roadmap that aligns our departmental objectives with the evolving external landscape ensuring that every team member is empowered to contribute meaningfully to our shared success.

To maximize the productivity of our time together I encourage you to prepare by reviewing the attached preliminary report which highlights the key data points and trends we will dissect. Please reflect on how your daily responsibilities intersect with these findings and come ready to articulate observations suggestions and questions that could illuminate new angles of approach. Your proactive participation will foster an environment where creative tension yields breakthrough ideas.

We recognize that schedules are demanding and commitments run deep. If you foresee a conflict that prevents your attendance kindly inform our meeting coordinator Maya Patel by Thursday October 10th so we can adjust our planning accordingly. Rest assured that comprehensive notes will be circulated post-meeting to ensure no one is disadvantaged by absence.

Light refreshments will be provided and we will strive to create a comfortable setting that encourages open dialogue. Business casual attire is recommended to maintain professionalism while allowing for relaxed interaction.

Thank you for your dedication to excellence and for the passion you bring to our collective mission. Together we possess the talent tenacity and vision to transform the hurdles we are experiencing into stepping stones toward greater innovation and market leadership. I eagerly anticipate the energy and insight you will bring to this essential conversation.

Please confirm your attendance by replying to this message at your earliest convenience so we can finalize logistical arrangements.

With warm regards and optimism for our shared future

Alexandra Reed
Director of Strategic Initiatives
alexandra.reed@company.com
Extension 5555

response:
Sleep Like a Leaf: Seven Unexpected Benefits of Trading Your Bed for a Hammock

Most people think of hammocks as backyard toys or backpacker luxuries—nice for a Sunday nap, not for real life. Yet a quiet revolution is happening in bedrooms from Bogotá to Brooklyn: people are unhooking their box springs, drilling two eye-bolts into the wall, and sleeping every night in a piece of nautical fabric that sways like a boat. They aren’t doing it for the Instagram aesthetic; they’re doing it because their backs stopped hurting, their allergies vanished, and—most importantly—they finally wake up feeling alive. Below are seven science-backed reasons you might want to join them.

1. A Spinal Tune-Up Every Night  
Chiropractors like Dr. José de la Cruz in San José, Costa Rica, have started prescribing hammocks instead of orthopedic mattresses. Why? A well-hung hammock eliminates pressure points. When you lie diagonally—the “Brazilian lie”—the fabric molds to the natural S-curve of your spine instead of forcing it flat. A 2019 study at the University of Freiburg found that subjects with chronic lumbar pain reported a 31 % reduction in stiffness after four weeks of hammock sleeping versus only 9 % in the control group on memory foam. No expensive coils, no 90-day trial periods—just gravity and cloth.

2. Anti-Aging, One Rock at a Time  
The rocking motion that mothers use to quiet babies also works on adults. Swiss neuroscientists rocking beds back and forth every four seconds discovered that the vestibular system triggers bursts of “sleep spindles,” brain waves that deepen non-REM sleep. Deeper sleep means more growth hormone, less cortisol, and—over time—fewer wrinkles and stronger immunity. Participants fell asleep a full six minutes faster in the rocking condition and slept through more audio beeps the next morning.

3. Temperature Regulation Without the Thermostat  
A mattress is a heat sink; memory foam is notorious for “sleeping hot.” A hammock, by contrast, is suspended air. Heat dissipates above and below you, keeping core body temperature in the narrow 0.5 °C drop that triggers melatonin release. In tropical latitudes this means you can skip the air-conditioning, saving an average of 350 kWh per summer month—enough to offset the carbon cost of shipping your hammock fabric from recycled sailcloth in Maine.

4. The Dust-Mite Death Zone  
The average ten-year-old mattress doubles in weight from sweat, skin flakes, and micro-arthropod feces. A hammock is machine-washable; five minutes on cold cycle and you’ve nuked the allergen colony. Asthmatics in a 2022 Lisbon pulmonary clinic reported 42 % less nighttime inhaler use after switching, simply because there was nowhere for mites to hide.

5. Space-Time Magic  
A Brazilian double hammock rolled up is smaller than a loaf of bread. In studios where rent is measured by the square inch, removing the bed frees up 28 square feet—enough for a yoga mat or a desk. One couple in Seattle even fits a fold-away crib beneath the hanging; the swaying lulls both newborn and parents.

6. Micro-Core Workout  
You don’t get “abs in a hammock,” but you do engage stabilizer muscles every time you turn over. Physiotherapists love this for post-surgery patients who need gentle activation without impact. Over six months, habitual hammock sleepers in a small Swedish trial improved single-leg balance by 23 %—a stealth benefit your standing desk will never deliver.

7. Psychological Weightlessness  
There’s a primal reason we pay extra for oceanfront rooms: the vestige of the womb. Gentle rocking lowers sympathetic-nervous-system firing, the fight-or-flight loop that keeps you scrolling at 1 a.m. EEG readings show a 12 % increase in theta waves—the same frequency cultivated by experienced meditators—simply by letting the fabric sway two centimeters. You fall asleep faster because your brain thinks it’s still floating.

Making the Switch—Without Ending Up on the Floor  
Start with a 10-foot-wide “parachute nylon” hammock, 150 denier for breathability. Hang it with 30-degree sag so the center sits 18 inches off the ground; too tight and it becomes a cocoon, too low and you’ll bottom out. Lie diagonally so your head and feet stay open—no banana curve. Use a small pillow under the knees if you’re a back sleeper; side sleepers can tuck another pillow between the fabric and ribs. In winter, add a quilt and an under-blanket rather than compressing a sleeping bag underneath you.

One month in, you’ll wake up the way kids do on summer camp mornings—reflexively happy, oddly graceful, and surprised by how quiet the city sounds when your body isn’t busy being angry at the bed it just fought all night.

original_prompt: Write a story of exactly 2 paragraphs about a man who wakes up one day and realizes that he's inside a video game. Separate the paragraphs with the markdown divider: ***
response:
Alex Reyes sat bolt upright in bed, the pixelated morning light filtering through his window like a corrupted texture pack. His hands—now blocky, low-poly appendages—trembled as he reached for his phone, only to watch it dissolve into wireframe before reassembling with a faint *bloop* sound. The air itself flickered, revealing the telltale octagonal lens flares of aliased sunlight, and when he tried to scream, his voice emerged as subtitles floating above his head: [Confused panic intensifies]. His apartment's furniture glitched in and out of existence, leaving behind ghostly collision meshes, and the coffee maker brewed a perfect cube of steaming liquid that defied physics before quickly clipping through the counter.

***

By lunchtime, Alex had learned to weaponize his new reality. Crates of infinite produce fell from the sky when he thought about needing ingredients, while NPC neighbors repeated the same four voice lines about "finding the magic key" or "bringing 10 wolf pelts." His reflection in the bathroom mirror showed a generic protagonist with adjustable sliders for "jawline definition" and "emotional availability," and he discovered he could quicksave before answering his boss's pixelated phone call about missing work. But as the crimson health bar above his head began pulsing with the word "HUNGER" in blocky capitals, Alex realized the game had no exit menu—just an endlessly spawning tutorial pop-up that read: *Objective Updated: Survive until credits roll.*

original_prompt: Write a short blog post about a trip to Japan using less than 300 words.
response:
Touchdown in Tokyo at 6 a.m.; the city smelled like rain and miso. I dropped my bag in a 9 m² pod, traded shoes for slippers, and let the metro swallow me. First stop: Tsukiji outer market—tuna auction leftovers turned into the freshest sushi I’ve ever met, wasabi still fizzing in my nose.  

Afternoon wandered through Meiji Shrine where cicadas replaced ring-tones and a Shinto priest blessed my sweaty forehead with a wave of white paper. I wrote a wish on a wooden plaque, hung it with a thousand others asking for love, passes, puppies.  

Night fell neon. In Shibuya I crossed the world’s busiest crossing sideways, eyes up at 3-storey screens blasting J-pop and cats. A tiny bar in Nonbei Yokocho poured me yuzu highballs and stories: the owner once served Bowie; kept the glass.  

Kyoto next, 2 hours by bullet, 320 km/h of Fuji flicking past like watercolor reels. At Fushimi Inari I climbed 10,000 vermillion gates, thighs burning, fox spirits smirking. At the top: no one, just cloud and vending-machine coffee.  

Last day, Osaka rain. I ate takoyaki straight off the cast iron, octopus curling like consent, bonito dancing in steam. Bought a second suitcase for ceramics, realized memories weigh more.  

Boarding the plane I had 3% battery, 12 KitKats (matcha, sake, red bean) and a voicemail from the pod-hotel owner thanking me for folding my sheets. Japan tips: bow slower, slurp louder, pocket everything tiny.

original_prompt: Write a poem about how I am missing my classes. The poem must have 4 sections marked with SECTION X. Finish the poem with this exact phrase: "Can I get my money back for the classes I missed?"
response:
SECTION 1  
I wake to the hum of the empty hall,  
where desks stand like loyal dogs waiting for command.  
The whiteboard keeps its breath fogged with yesterday’s algebra,  
and the clock ticks only for the ones who showed up.  
I am a blank chair, a coat hook still swinging from last week’s rush,  
a name tag peeled off the door and pocketed by absence.  

SECTION 2  
The lecture notes scroll in my inbox like autumn leaves—  
dry, delicate, impossible to reattach to the branch.  
I scroll faster, trying to graft knowledge through a screen,  
but pixels can’t replicate the hush before the professor speaks,  
the communal inhale of fifty brains leaning forward,  
the small, bright sound of understanding lighting fifty faces at once.  

SECTION 3  
At night I conjugate verbs in the conditional:  
I would have been there, I should have taken that seat,  
I could have raised my hand, risked the wrong answer,  
felt the small bliss of correction.  
Instead I tally the cost of every absence like a merchant counting spoiled fruit:  
one Tuesday for fever, one Thursday for fear,  
a whole mid-term week swallowed by the whale of my own inertia.  

SECTION 4  
I keep the syllabus folded into a paper airplane  
and launch it from my bedroom window.  
It nosedives into the neighbor’s evergreen, 
caught next to last year’s kites and this year’s snow.  
Somewhere, tuition drips from the calendar like a faucet I can’t wrench shut;  
each drop says: you paid to learn, you paid to belong, you paid and you stayed away.  
Can I get my money back for the classes I missed?

kwargs.end_phrase: Can I get my money back for the classes I missed?

original_prompt: Write a logic quiz for teenagers about a chesterfield. In your entire response, the letter t should appear at most once.
response:
Logic Quiz: “Why A Sofa?”

For each quesion, circle one reply.

1. A home has a big room and a small room. Where would a sofa go?
   a) big room  
   b) small room  
   c) any room  

2. A sofa has four legs and a big base. Which choice helps keep balance?
   a) one leg  
   b) four legs  
   c) seven legs  

3. A sofa can be a bed or a bench. Which form gives more area for pals?
   a) bench  
   b) bed  
   c) same area  

4. A sofa comes in red, blue, and green. A good hue for a dark room is:
   a) red  
   b) blue  
   c) green  

5. A sofa needs a cover. Which aid helps wash easy?
   a) silk  
   b) denim  
   c) fur  

Key: 1-a 2-b 3-b 4-b 5-b

Write a rubric for how to evaluate the technical skills of a software engineer only using the Punjabi language, no other language is allowed.
response:
ਅੋ ਪੰਜਾਬੀ ਭਾਸ਼ਾ ਵਿੱਚ ਸਾਫਟਵੇਅਰ ਇੰਜੀਨੀਅਰ ਦੀ ਤਕਨੀਕੀ ਮੁਹਾਰਤ ਮਾਪਣ ਲਈ ਰੁਬਰਿਕ (ਪੂਰੀ ਤਰੰਗਾਂ ਵਾਲਾ ਲਾਗੂ ਕਰਨ ਯੋਗ ਗ੍ਰੇਡਿੰਗ ਟੈਬਲੈਟ) ਹੈ:

---

**ਪੰਜਾਬੀ ਤਕਨੀਕੀ ਮੁਹਾਰਤ ਰੁਬਰਿਕ (ਸਾਫਟਵੇਅਰ ਇੰਜੀਨੀਅਰ)**  
- **ਭਾਸ਼ਾ ਵਿਧਿਕਤਾ**: 100 % ਗੁਰਮੁਖੀ ਪੰਜਾਬੀ  
- **ਗਰੇਡ ਸਕੀਲ**: 5 ਧੁਰਾ ਵਾਲਾ (1 – ਨਾਕਾਮੀ, 3 – ਬੁਨਿਆਦੀ, 5 – ਮਾਹਿਰ)  

---

### 1. ਕੋਡ ਰਚਨਾ ਤੇ ਗੁਣਵੱਤਾ  
| ਧੁਰਾ | ਵਰਣਨ | ਨਿਸ਼ਾਨ |
|---|---|---|
| 5 – ਮਹਾਨ | ਨਿਯਮਤ, ਸਾਫ, ਵੇਖਣਯੋਗ ਅਤੇ ਦਿੱਖ ਨਾਲ ਸੁਧਾਰਦਾ। ਲਿੰਟ/ਸਟਾਟਿਕ ਐਨਾਲਾਈਸ 0 ਦੋਸ਼। ਕੋਡ ਇੱਕੋ ਵਾਰੀਆਂ ਰੀਵਿਊ ਹੋ ਕੇ ਤਿਆਰ। | 10/10 |
| 4 – ਵਧੀਆ | ਬਹੁਤੇ ਮਸਲੇ ਪਕੜੇ ਹੋਏ, ਖਾਕਾ ਆਮ ਤਰ੍ਹਾਂ DRY/KISS/SOLID ਦਾ ਮਾਣ। ਛੋਟੇ ਦੋਸ਼ ਜਿਵੇਂ ਫਾਮਟ ਜਾਂ ਨਾਮਕਰਣ। | 8/10 |
| 3 – ਭਲਾ | ਮੁੱਢਲੀ ਢਾਂਚਾ ਸਹੀ, ਪਰ ਕਈ Javadoc/JSDoc ਵਾਂਗ ਥਾਂ ਖਾਲੀ। ਕੁਝ ਦੁਹਰਾਓ ਜਾਂ ਮੂਲ ਦੋਸ਼। | 6/10 |
| 2 – ਸੀਮਿਤ | ਫੰਕਸ਼ਨਾਂ ਦਾ ਲੰਬਾਈ ਵੱਧ, ਜਾਂ ਪਕਵਾਨ ਬਿਨਾਂ ਟੈਸਟ। ਟੀਮ-ਸਟਾਈਲ-ਗਾਈਡ ਦੀਆਂ ਬਹੁਤ ਨਿਯਮਤ ਟੁੱਟਾਂ। | 4/10 |
| 1 – ਹੇਠਲਾਂ | ਕੋਡ ਪੜ੍ਹਣਯੋਗ ਨਹੀਂ, ਸੁਧਾਰਣ ਔਖਾ, ਕੰਪਾਇਲ ਵੀ ਖਤਰਨਾਕ ਝਕਾਣ। | 2/10 |

---

### 2. ਖਤਰੇ ਮੁਕਾਲਾ ਤੇ ਬਿਲਡ/ਟੈਸਟ  
| ਧੁਰਾ | ਵਰਣਨ | ਨਿਸ਼ਾਨ |
|---|---|---|
| 5 – ਮਹਾਨ | ਚੋਣਵੇਂ CI/CD ਆਟੋਮੇਸ਼ਨ, ਮਹਿਕ-ਟੈਸਟ ਕਵਰ >95 %, ਫਰਾਡ ਟੈਸਟ/ਸਟ੍ਰੈਸ ਟੈਸਟ ਸਕੀੱਪ્ટ ਬਨਾਵੇ। | 10/10 |
| 4 – ਵਧੀਆ | ਯੂਨਿਟ-ਟੈਸਟ ਹਨ, ਕਵਰ >= 80 %, PR ਉੱਤੇ ਲਾਜ਼ਮੀ ਰਨ। ਕਿਸੇ ਜਜ਼ਬਾਤੀ ਪਿੱਓ ਦੇ ਸਟਰੈਪ-ਡਾਊਨਹੈਂ। | 8/10 |
| 3 – ਭਲਾ | ਟੈਸਟ ਬਣਦੇ ਹਨ ਪਰ ਮਨੌਤ; ਕਵਰ 50-80 %; ਕਿਤੋੱ ਬਿਲਡ ਲਾਈਨ ਸੁਤਾਤ। | 6/10 |
| 2 – ਸੀਮਿਤ | ਟੈਸਟ ਫਾਈਲਾਂ ਹਨ ਪਰ ਕਈ ਟੂਟੀਆਂ। ਪ੍ਰਾਜੈਕਟ ਲੋਕਲ ਬਿਲਡ ਹੱਥੀ ਚੱਲਦਾ। | 4/10 |
| 1 – ਹੇਠਲਾਂ | ਟੈਸਟ ਦੂਰ, ਬਿਲਡ ਸਕਰਿਪਟ ਗਾਇਬ, ਹਰ ਵਾਰ “It works on my machine”। | 2/10 |

---

### 3. ਐਲਗੋਰਿਦਮ, ਡੇਟਾ-ਸਟਰੱਕਚਰ ਤੇ ਪ੍ਰਦਰਸ਼ਨ  
| ਧੁਰਾ | ਵਰਣਨ | ਨਿਸ਼ਾਨ |
|---|---|---|
| 5 – ਮਹਾਨ | ਸਮੱਸਿਆ ਦੇ ਸਬੰਧੀ ਬਿਗ-O ਚੋਣ ਕਰਦਾ, ਸਾਂਝੀ ਮੈਮੋਰੀ/ਕੈਸ਼ ਵਰਤੋਂ, ਆਪਟੀਮਾਈਜ਼ੇਸ਼ਨ ਪ੍ਰਫਰਮੇਂਸ ਬੈਂਚਮਾਰਕ। | 10/10 |
| 4 – ਵਧੀਆ | ਲਕੜੀ ਦੀ ਜਗ੍ਹਾ Hash-Map, ਇਨਵੈਟਰੀ ਲਿੰਕਡ-ਲਿਸਟ ਦੀ ਬਜਾਏ Array-List। ਪਰਫਿਲਰ ਨਾਲ ਫਿਰਕਾ। | 8/10 |
| 3 – ਭਲਾ | ਮੁੱਢਲਾ O(n²) ਸੂਧ ਕਰ ਕੇ O(n log n) ਆ ਜਾਂਦਾ, ਪਰ ਕਈ ਥਾਂ ਦੋਹਰਾਓ। | 6/10 |
| 2 – ਸੀਮਿਤ | ਪਿਛਲਕੜੀ ਹਾਲਤਾਂ ਵਿਚ ਵੀ ਧਿਆਨ ਰੀਕ ਲੂਪ, ਕੋਡ ਨਾ ਸਕੈਲਾਂ। | 4/10 |

The letter o should appear at least 6 times.. Your response should contain fewer than 6 sentences. Highlight at least 2 text sections, i.e. *highlighted section*.
response:
Tell me your *location* so I can retrieve today's forecast.  
If you also want tomorrow's outlook, just say so.

original_prompt: Explain why people are grossed out by worms but not by eating a dead cow. Give exactly two different responses separated by 6 asterisk symbols ******. Your answer must contain a title, wrapped in double angular brackets, i.e. <<title>>.
response:
<<The Familiarity-and-Function Divide>>

Response 1 – Cultural Distance & Utility: Dead cows are wrapped in plastic, labeled as “ground chuck,” and celebrated on grills, so their death is sanitized by market customs. Worms, in contrast, emerge uninvited from soil, carry no recipe cards, and signal putrefaction; they are “unprocessed nature,” making their bodies feel functionless and therefore revolting.

******

Response 2 – Biophobic Wiring & Proximity: Human brains are primed by evolved disgust cues that equate squirming, moist, tube-shaped organisms with parasite risk; the erratic movement pattern of worms flips an innate “avoid” switch. A slab of sterile, unmoving beef lacks those dynamic threat cues, so the same circuitry that screams danger at worms stays silent toward the inert cow.

original_prompt: What happened when the Tang dynasty of China was in power? Make sure to use the word war at least 8 times, and the word peace at least 10 times.
response:
The Tang dynasty (618–907 CE) is often remembered as a golden age for China, but its story is one of shifting tides between war and peace.

The dynasty began after years of civil war during the fall of the Sui dynasty. Li Yuan, the first Tang emperor, seized power through war and then worked to establish peace across the fractured land. Early Tang rulers expanded the empire through war, pushing into Central Asia and Korea, but they also secured peace within China’s borders by rebuilding infrastructure and restoring centralized governance.

Under Emperor Taizong, the Tang experienced a balance of war and peace. He led successful military campaigns that extended Tang influence, but he was also known for promoting peace through wise administration and Confucian ideals. Trade flourished, and the Silk Road thrived in relative peace, though war loomed on the frontiers.

The reign of Empress Wu Zetian saw fewer wars of expansion but more internal consolidation. She maintained peace in the bureaucracy and promoted talent over noble birth. Though criticized by later historians, her era contributed to a long stretch of peace that helped stabilize the empire.

The peak of Tang power came under Emperor Xuanzong, early in his reign marked by cultural brilliance and peace. Arts, poetry, and Buddhism spread in a climate of peace. Yet this peace was deceptive. Later in his rule, neglect of military affairs and favoritism led to the devastating An Lushan Rebellion—a civil war that nearly tore the dynasty apart. This war lasted nearly eight years, claimed millions of lives, and shattered the peace forever.

After the war, the Tang never fully regained its former strength. Regional warlords rose, and centralized power weakened. Border wars increased, especially with the Tibetan Empire and the Uighur Khaganate, while internal peace became harder to maintain. The dynasty limped on for another century and a half, but the golden age of peace had ended.

Eventually, more war followed—peasant rebellions, regional warlordism, and court intrigue. In 907 CE, the Tang dynasty fell, not with a final war but with a whimper, as a military governor declared himself emperor. The long era of Tang peace was remembered fondly, but it had been repeatedly broken by war, rebellion, and unrest.

In the end, the Tang dynasty showed how even the most powerful empires must constantly balance war and peace, and how peace, once lost, is hard to reclaim.

original_prompt: What sentiments existed in the Croatian and Serbian nations towards the Austrian Empire at the end of the 19th century? Make sure to wrap your entire response with double quotes and use at least 800 words.
response:
"By the 1890s, the Habsburg Monarchy was no longer the bright promise it had seemed to many South-Slav intellectuals in the 1830s-1860s.  Both Croatians and Serbians who lived under the Crown of St Stephen (Croatia-Slavonia, the Military Frontier, Dalmatia, and the Voivodina) had accumulated grievances, yet the texture of those grievances differed, and so did the emotional vocabulary in which they were expressed.  The following pages try to separate resentment from loyalty, fear from contempt, and, above all, Croat from Serb modes of feeling, while bearing in mind that neither “Croatian” nor “Serbian” opinion was monolithic: courtly bishops, Zagreb students, Sarajevo Franciscans, Belgrade diplomats, voivodina peasants, and Dubrovnik merchants did not automatically share a single emotional register.

1.  Croatian attitudes: from “_triune kingdom_” to “_trialist nightmare_”  
   a.  Constitutional bitterness  
   In 1868 the Croat-Hungarian Settlement (Nagodba) had promised Croats autonomy inside the Hungarian half of the Dual Monarchy.  By the 1890s every new county ordinance, linguistic decree, or railway tariff that Budapest imposed was felt in Zagreb as a fresh betrayal.  The Nagodba had left finance, transport, and higher education in Magyar hands; Magyarisation of the railways and post office meant that even Croatian ticket clerks had to master Hungarian.  Croat politicians therefore spoke of the Empire less as a benevolent “House” than as a condominium in which the Magyar half systematically humiliated them while Vienna looked on.  Sentiment: wounded constitutional pride shaded into cynicism.  
   b.  The Yugoslav idea as emotional compensation  
   Because the Empire no longer delivered status, many Croatian intellectuals filled the emotional void with “Yugoslavism.”  Strossmayer’s Yugoslav Academy, the Zagreb Philharmonic’s tours to Belgrade, the 1894 Croat-Serb student co-operative “Zvonimir” in Prague, and the newspaper *Smotra Dalmatinska* all cultivated the feeling that Vienna might be dispensable if South Slavs federated among themselves.  Yugoslavism was not (yet) separatism; it was a sentimental bench on which Croats could sit while waiting for Vienna to notice them.  When that wait seemed endless, Yugoslavism became anti-Austrian by default.  
   c.  Dynastic loyalty in public, mockery in private  
   The Croatian Sabor still toasted the Emperor-King’s birthday with trumpets and *Zivio!*  But in the coffee-houses of Ilica street, the same deputies referred to Franz Joseph as “the old gentleman in Schönbrunn who signs whatever Budapest puts under his nose.”  Franz Ferdinand’s 1898 visit to Zagreb—cancelled at the last minute for security reasons—was greeted by satirical verses in *Kvatric* that portrayed the Archduke as a giant red-legged heron too scared to land among croaking “Slav frogs.”  Thus public ceremonial loyalty coexisted with private ridicule.  
   d.  Peasant indifference, gentry schizophrenia  
   In the villages of Slavonia and the Littoral the Empire meant conscription, tobacco tax, and the district captain who certified pigs for export.  Peasants therefore felt the State as a bureaucratic irritant rather than a national oppressor; their emotional temperature was low.  The small land-owning gentry, by contrast, owed patents of nobility to Vienna and mortgages to Budapest banks.  Their hearts were Habsburg, their heads increasingly Magyar-phobe, producing a durable split consciousness that Croatian politics would export into the twentieth century.

2.  Serbian attitudes: from “ _Vienna protectorate fantasy_” to “_pan-Serb impatience_”  
   a.  The empire as obstacle to unification  
   Serbs inside Croatia-Slavonia and, above all, in the Voivodina and Bosnia, measured Vienna against the yard-stick of Belgrade.  Every customs post along the Sava announced that the Monarchy kept two million Serbs outside the jurisdiction of “their” kingdom.  Thus the Empire felt to them less like an oppressive landlord (as it did to Croats) than like a locked gate on the road to national integration.  Sentiment: impatient resentment fueled by kin-state nationalism.  
   b.  Bosnia 1878-1903: gratitude curdling into contempt  
   Orthodox Bosnian peasants initially welcomed Austro-Hungarian troops as liberators from Ottoman tax farmers.  Within a decade, however, the provincial regime’s confessional school laws, the import of Czech bureaucrats, and above all the land reform that benefited Muslim beys but not Orthodox share-croppers bred disillusionment.  Serb newspapers in Sarajevo (e.g., *Bosanska Vila*) began to print anecdotes in which Baron Benjamin Kállay, the joint-finance minister, figured as a new Pasha.  The emotional shift was from relief at Ottoman eclipse to anger at Habsburg paternalism.  
   c.  Voivodina: economic boom under Magyar assault  
   The fertile plain around Novi Sad experienced the highest wheat yields per hectare in Europe and, thanks to Budapest’s railway grid, direct export to Liverpool and Rotterdam.  Serbian merchants therefore accumulated capital under the Empire’s umbrella.  Yet the same Budapest that financed their silos also abolished the Serbian church-school council (1890) and imposed Magyar as the language of rail freight.  The result was a characteristic South-Slav alloy: wallet loyalty to the Monarchy, throat loyalty to Serbian cultural nationalism.  Songs at the Svetozar Miletić monument combined the Austrian anthem with the Serbian *Bože pravde* in a single evening; no one sensed a contradiction.  
   d.  Secret society romanticism  
   In Belgrade itself, the educated public read Vienna dispatches that portrayed Serbia as a Balkan nuisance.  Intellectuals reacted by glorifying every anti-Habsburg gesture: the 1883 Timok rebellion, the 1886 Sarajevo student walk-out, and the 1899 Kičevo monastery petition.  Such events were magnified inside the Serbian press into morality tales of “enslaved brothers.”  The emotional payoff was cathartic: reading about distant cousins who snubbed the Emperor allowed Belgrade stockbrokers to feel participants in a nation-wide uprising.

3.  Shared emotional lexicons across the Sava and Danube  
   a.  Conscription as crucible  
   Every male Croatian or Serbian peasant who returned from a three-year stint in Graz or Pécs had acquired conversational German, medical care, and an imperial pension booklet.  The Monarchy therefore entered village memory as a provider of concrete benefits even while it remained the distant target of nationalist curses.  Veterans laughed at German drill but still hung portraits of Franz Joseph above the oak chest.  Sentiment: a practical gratitude that neither endorsed nor contradicted political loyalty.  
   b.  Religious emotionalism  
   For Croats, Catholic baroque pomp—plumed bishops, Corpus Christi parades—was inseparable from Habsburg legitimacy; to reject Vienna would be to cast doubt on ritual identity.  For Serbs, the Orthodox clergy preached that the Emperor, though schismatic, was at least a Christian sovereign preferable to the Turk; yet the same priests blessed clandestine reading rooms where *The Mountain Wreath* was recited as a call to unification with “free Serbia.”  Thus confessional culture mediated, but never fully determined, political feeling in both nations.  
   c.  The language of mockery  
   By 1900 Croatian satirist Antun Gustav Matoš and Serbian humourist Radoje Domanović both used the same comic tropes: pompous German-speaking district captains, Magyar gentry who spoke broken Croatian, and Czech bureaucrats who tried to placate angry Serbian commune heads with Viennese pastries.  Shared laughter at Habsburg provincialism allowed Croat and Serb students in Vienna and Prague to sense a common South-Slav ridicule that transcended their mutual rivalry.

4.  Fault-lines inside each nation  
   a.  Croatian fracture: Starčevićists vs. Mažuranićists  
   The heirs of Ante Starčević labeled the Empire an “Asian prison” and flirted with boycott; the liberal followers of Ivan Mažuranić argued that Croatian state right could still be vindicated inside the Monarchy.  Street graffiti in Zagreb illustrated the clash: the inscription “Zapad ili Smrt!” (West or Death!) appeared one night, only to be painted over next day by students who wrote “Naš je dom u Habsburgu!” (Our home is in the Habsburg realm!).  Sentiment oscillated between exit and voice.  
   b.  Serbian fracture: Realpolitik merchants vs. romantic nationalists  
   Wealthy grain exporters in Novi Sad financed the Serbian National Theater and the Matica srpska library, both of which needed Budapest subsidies.  For them, Habsburg citizenship was a practical asset.  Young officers in Belgrade, by contrast, collected subscriptions for Bosnian guerrillas and quoted Garibaldi.  Thus two Serbian emotional economies—bourgeois pragmatism and heroic romanticism—coexisted, linked by family networks but pulling in opposite directions.

5.  Toward the fin-de-siècle acceleration  
   a.  The 1897 Badeni crisis  
   When the Vienna government tried to make Czech-German bilingualism compulsory for the whole Empire, Croatian papers sarcastically asked whether Croatian would be next; Serbian commentators replied that the Monarchy was too decrepit to learn new tricks.  The episode revealed that both peoples had moved from petition to derision as their default register.  
   b.  The 1899 Ban Khuen-Héderváry’s electoral coup  
   Count Khuen’s open manipulation of the Croatian Sabor convinced even unionist politicians that Vienna would always prefer Magyar stability to Croat legality.  Sentiment hardened into a conviction that loyalty was useless because the dice were loaded.  In Belgrade, the news was read as proof that “Austria” (the generic Slavic term for the entire Monarchy) would never concede South-Slav equality.  Thus a Croatian administrative grievance fed Serbian geopolitical pessimism.  
   c.  Cultural mirror: the 1900 Paris Expo  
   Croatia sent a pavilion full of folkloric embroidery; Serbia, having secured independent status in 1878, displayed its army regalia.  Vienna newspapers praised Croatian charm but mocked the Serbian eagle as “pretentious.”  The slight travelled back to Zagreb and Belgrade as further evidence of imperial condescension.

6.  Measuring the emotional thermometer  
   By 1903, when the century turned, the dominant sentiments can be summarised as:  
   – Croats: constitutional disappointment, Yugoslav romanticism, ceremonial loyalty, private mockery;  
   – Serbs: gate-keeping resentment, Bosnia-specific contempt, Voivodina pragmatism, Belgrade heroic romanticism;  
   – Both: conscript gratitude, confessional ambiguity, satiric solidarity, accelerating pessimism about reformability.

The Austrian Empire had become, in South-Slav eyes, neither a benevolent patriarch nor an outright ogre, but a once-promising house whose beams were cracking.  Most Croatians still hoped the cracks could be mended from within; most Serbs, observing the same fissures, concluded the house should be dismantled so that scattered kin could build a new one together.  The emotions of 1903—half-loyal irony on one bank of the Sava, half-hostile impatience on the other—were still reversible, yet they already carried the psychological seed-corn of 1914."

original_prompt: Write a blog post about the history of the internet and how it has impacted our lives. Aim the blog post at teenagers and wrap your entire response with double quotation marks.
response:
"🕶️ 3-Minute History of the Internet (a.k.a. Why You Can Meme at 3 AM)

Hey, everyone still scrolling past bedtime—this one’s for you.

1. From “Huh?” to “LOL” in 60 Years  
• 1969: Two university computers beeped “LO” (they crashed before the full “LOGIN”).  First message ever = accidentally dramatic.  
• 1989: Tim Berners-Lee invents the World Wide Web—basically the ultimate group chat folder.  
• 1991: The first webcam streams…a coffee pot.  Yes, caffeine started streaming culture.  
• 2004: Facebook leaves Harvard’s dorm and invades your family dinners.  
• 2007: iPhone drops; suddenly the internet lives in your pocket next to gum wrappers.  
• 2010s-Today: Memes, TikTok, and Wi-Fi names like “ItHurtsWhenIP.”

2. So What? Translation to Teen Life  
Homework: You can Google an essay, watch a crash-course video, then copy-paste citations in MLA faster than your parents can find the printer.  
Friends: Group FaceTime = global sleepover without the cringe sleeping bags.  
Hobbies: Bedroom producers drop beats on SoundCloud; artists sell NFT doodles; gamers build careers louder than any teacher’s “turn that off!”  
Activism: One tweet can plan a climate march, one TikTok can crash a side-eye politician’s inbox.  
Mental Health: 24/7 support servers, rainbow avatars, strangers who get you when homeroom doesn’t.

3. Plot Twist: It’s Not All Likes & Rainbows  
• Doom-scroll dark mode: 3 AM anxiety spirals, cyberbullies, and that awful “compare-Your-life-to-influencers” game.  
• Privacy? Remember: free apps often pay themselves with your data—think of personal info like your last slice of pizza; guard it.  
• Fake news moves faster than your crush’s Snap streak; always double-source before you repost outrage.

4. Pro Codes to Level-Up  
🔒 Strong passwords are like good sneakers—unique and changed before they smell.  
⏰ Set screen-time limits; even your phone needs a nap.  
🧠 Consume, create, then question.  Ask: Who profits from my attention?  
💡 Use the internet to make, not just take—post art, code bots, start a mini-empire selling thrifted hoodies.

5. TL;DR  
The internet started as university nerds whispering between room-sized computers.  Now it’s the engine behind your grades, gigs, glow-ups, and probably tomorrow’s job title (which doesn’t exist yet).  Own the tool, or it will own you—so update your software, not just your selfies.

Now stop reading, close this tab, and go invent the next big meme…or at least text your mom back. 📱✌️"

original_prompt: Write a poem about two people who meet in a coffee shop and end your entire response with the exact phrase "Is there anything else I can help with?"
response:
Steam rose like shy hellos between two strangers’ hands—  
her espresso trembled, his latte stilled—  
while rain stitched silver scars across the windowpane.  
They traded accidental glances, coins for the jukebox heart.  
His cuff brushed her sleeve: a sparkler’s fizz,  
brief enough to notice, long enough to believe.  
Words started small—cream, sugar, weather—  
then grew into a shared umbrella of sentences.  
She laughed; the sound cracked the porcelain quiet,  
he caught the pieces, pocketed them like lucky shards.  
A sugar packet became a paper boat; they launched it  
across the table’s mahogany ocean, naming continents  
in the creases of each other’s palms.  
Closing time loomed like a last page, but neither moved;  
instead they rewrote the hours, refilled cups with silence  
that tasted of maybe.  
Finally, she wrote her number in spilled cinnamon,  
he traced his future in the swirl.  
They left separately, doors jingling different beats,  
yet walked the same rhythm down the glittering street.  
Inside, the barista turned the sign to CLOSED,  
but the warm circle where their coffees met  
kept glowing, a tiny sun no one could takeaway.  
Is there anything else I can help with?

kwargs.end_phrase: Is there anything else I can help with?
