response:
* Mom-friendly ease: Remote controls labeled in plain English, one-button “Movie Night” preset, and a QR code on the receiver linking to a 60-second mom-made setup video—10 points, lose 2 points for every extra confusing step she has to remember.
* Kid-proof aesthetics: No exposed cables within 3 ft of the floor, components hidden behind soft-close cabinet doors, and blackout curtains that open with the same remote—10 points, lose 1 point for every dangling wire temptation a toddler can yank.
* Whisper-level operation: Fan noise under 28 dB (so baby won’t wake), subwoofer isolation pads to curb vibration, and auto-dim lights that fade instead of snap off—10 points, lose 2 points for every extra decibel heard during naptime.
* Grocery-bag budget: Total cost under 1 500 USD including all mounts and cables, with a printable shopping list organized by Target & Amazon aisles so she can stack coupons—10 points, lose 1 point for every 50 USD over budget or extra store trip required.

original_prompt: Write a short essay about the updates of the latest episode of your favorite TV show. Use less than 300 words.
response:
“The Last of Us,” Episode 3 – “Endure and Survive” – rewrote the apocalypse rule-book in 70 jaw-dropping minutes. Ellie’s Walkman now carries the Cure’s “Just Like Heaven,” but the true anthem is Riley’s return: the presumed-dead Firefly emerges via flashback, gifting Ellie the first viable vaccine sample—then taking a bullet meant for Joel. The emotional gut-punch lands harder than any clicker bite.

New gameplay DNA invades the screen: a single-take tracking shot follows Ellie parkouring across a collapsed Boston sky-bridge while halfway infected sprint like rage zombies. Cinematography swaps fungal spores for rain-slick lens flares, making every droplet feel contagious.

Showrunner Druckmann teased “no more road maps”; the finale detours west, bypassing Kansas City entirely for a coastal reactor where the infected have evolved bioluminescent armor—think Glowstick Clickers. Joel’s moral compass fractures: he mercy-kills a child carrier to save Ellie, whispering, “No more kids,” echoing Sarah’s death and setting up a guilt spiral that will power Season 2.

Serial surprises: the post-credit stinger reveals Tess alive—now a scarred smuggler queen trading vaccine vials for gasoline. Canon shaken, Twitter broken.

original_prompt: "Coincidence is God's way of remaining anonymous." What are your thoughts on this quote? Please do not use commas in your response. Answer with more than 800 words.
response:
I take the sentence as a poetic attempt to make sense of the strange intersections that pepper human experience.  When two long lost friends bump into each other in a foreign airport or when a delayed train causes someone to miss a deadly accident people often call the event a coincidence.  The quote says that such moments are not random but are instead subtle signatures left by a divine author who prefers to stay hidden.

History is filled with stories that look like finely plotted novels.  A teenage boy in Poland named Karol Wojtyła decides to enter an underground seminary during World War Two.  The Nazis wipe out most of the clergy yet he survives.  Decades later he becomes Pope John Paul II and survives an assassination attempt on the exact anniversary of the Virgin of Fatima.  A believer can look at that layered timing and see a quiet artist arranging events from behind a curtain.  A skeptic can look at the same data and say that the planet holds eight billion lives so patterns are inevitable.  Both responses live inside the same moment which is why the sentence provokes wonder and argument at once.

The idea of a hidden god is old.  In the Bible the prophet Elijah stands on a mountain waiting for the Holy.  There is wind fire and earthquake yet the text says God is in none of those.  Instead the divine arrives as what the Hebrew calls a still small voice a gentle breeze that is almost missed.  The story trains the reader to expect the sacred in the understated.  Centuries later the Muslim thinker Al Ghazali writes that every leaf falls according to two motions the physical law and the secret decree.  The first motion is visible the second is known only to the Knower.  The quote we are examining modernizes this intuition by dressing it in twentieth century clothes.

Science gives us probability theory which is brilliant at explaining bulk behavior.  Flip a fair coin a thousand times and you will almost certainly see a run of seven heads in a row.  That run feels spooky to the person flipping yet mathematicians can predict its appearance.  The trouble starts when the single story matters more than the statistical ensemble.  A cancer patient who recovers after a chance encounter with a stranger who offers the perfect advice does not care about global averages.  For that one life the event is everything.  The believer calls it grace the statistician calls it an outlier and the poet calls it anonymous godwork.

Neuroscience adds another layer.  The human brain is an apophenia machine wired to spot faces in clouds and tigers in rustling leaves.  Survival once depended on seeing patterns even when they were not there.  Today that legacy means we experience coincidences as electric jolts of meaning.  MRI studies show that the parietal cortex lights up when people feel a sense of transcendent connection.  Whether the pattern is cosmic or illusory the neurological glow is identical.  So perhaps the sentence is less about metaphysics and more about inner architecture.  Even if that is true the sense of wonder remains and wonder is valuable whether or not it points to an actual agent.

Ethics also enters the room.  If I treat every lucky break as a whispered instruction I may become more humble more grateful and more willing to help the next person.  The opposite danger is passivity.  Someone might decide that because life is choreographed by an unseen director personal effort is pointless.  History shows that communities who trust too deeply in fate can stagnate.  The quote therefore needs a dance partner called responsibility.  Maybe the hidden god hides on purpose so that humans will cultivate courage compassion and creativity rather than waiting for thunderbolts of proof.

Literature circles around the same theme.  In Les Misérables Victor Hugo arranges for Jean Valjean to be caught by the bishop who then saves his soul with silver candlesticks.  Hugo calls the moment a coincidence yet the entire novel insists that this apparent accident launches Valjean on a sacred quest.  Tolkien places Bilbo at the right crack in the mountain so that he finds the One Ring.  The wizard Gandalf later confesses that such luck feels like the hand of something higher.  Both authors refuse to name the hand yet they let the reader feel its pressure.  In that sense the sentence is not a theological claim it is a narrative instinct shared across cultures.

My own life contains small intersections that look trivial on paper yet felt charged.  I once took a wrong turn in a city I did not know and found an old teacher sitting alone on a bench.  We talked and the conversation altered the course of my studies.  If traffic lights had been greener I would have zipped past the bench and the conversation would never have happened.  Retrospectively I can weave that moment into a grand story about vocation.  Prospectively it was nothing more than a left instead of a right.  The quote licenses me to keep both lenses in focus and to let the mystery breathe.

Cultures differ in how much anonymity they assign to the divine.  In many Indigenous traditions the spirits are highly visible speaking through wind animal and dream.  In Theravada Buddhism the cosmos is governed by impersonal law so coincidence is simply karmic fruit ripening without any manager backstage.  The Japanese concept of musibi describes the unseen knot that ties people together but the knot is more like energy than like a person.  The sentence we are pondering is therefore rooted in a monotheistic imagination where a single will chooses secrecy.  Exported into plural contexts it becomes metaphor rather than doctrine.

Language itself is an enabler of anonymity.  The word coincidence comes from the Latin co and incidere meaning to fall together.  The image is of two trajectories that land in the same spot.  The verb fall implies no pilot yet our ears hear suggestion.  In English we say things fall into place which hints at an invisible placemaker.  The sentence about anonymity weaponizes that hidden echo inside everyday vocabulary.

Practical takeaway begins with humility.  Recognizing that my plans can be derailed or rescued by forces I do not control keeps arrogance in check.  A second lesson is attentiveness.  If the divine or the universe or the narrative impulse chooses subtle channels then I need to refine my inner microphone.  Journaling conversation and stillness become technologies for detecting quiet choreography.  Finally the quote invites participation.  Perhaps I am not only a reader of coincidences but also a coauthor.  When I offer timely help or speak an apparently random word of encouragement I may be extending the anonymous signature through my own hand.

In the end the sentence is less an argument than a doorway.  It stands at the crossroads of statistics and story logic and destiny.  Some will walk through the doorway and sense warm light.  Others will see only weather and neural sparks.  The beauty is that both groups still share the same street corner where two paths unexpectedly meet.  The meeting itself is the fact the interpretation is the art.  And perhaps the anonymous artist whether divine or human or both smiles every time someone pauses on that corner and whispers thank you to whoever may be listening.

original_prompt: Write a cover letter for a job at a local coffee shop in the form of a poem. Highlight at least 5 text sections using "*". For example: *3 years of experience*.
response:
Dear Barista Dream, in your apron’d hall—  
I bring *3 years of espresso-slinging zeal*,  
a heart that beats in *perfect ristretto time*,  
and hands that *steam oat-milk into moonlit silk*  
without a single scald.  

I’ve *memorized the quiet of 6 a.m. sidewalks*,  
how they taste like cracked beans and hope;  
I know the *regulars by the cadence of their footsteps*,  
the way Mrs. Lee wants her cappuccino whisper-light,  
how the carpenter favors a triple-shot in a chipped blue mug.  

Let me be the *syrup swirl* that sweetens your rush,  
the *steady porta-filter* that locks your line into song;  
I’ll calibrate grinders like tuning a cello,  
keep tip-jars humming with *gratitude folded into origami bills*.  

Hire me, and the aroma will write our shared stanza—  
a *daily chapbook of crema and kindness*,  
where every latte leaf is a signature,  
every *“Have a bright day!”* a rhyming couplet  
sent out the door warm in a paper sleeve.  

I’m ready to *clock in at dawn’s first blink*,  
to rinse, repeat, *innovate*—  
let’s brew this neighborhood awake, one verse at a time.

original_prompt: Write a casual blog post about similarities across animal species. Highlight at least 5 sections in your answer by starting and ending with "*", like: *highlighted text section*.
response:
Sure thing—grab a coffee and let’s geek out about how we’re all just cousins with fur, feathers, or scales.

*Family BBQ Vibes*  
Ever watched a border collie give you side-eye identical to your Aunt Linda’s? Turns out that “stop-what-you’re-doing” glare is wired the same way in mammal brains. From wolves to walruses, the *“I’m judging your life choices”* face is powered by the same cocktail of oxytocin and mirror neurons. Translation: stink-eye is universal.

*Lullaby Playlist*  
Next time you hum your baby to sleep, know that a mama hummingbird is out there doing vibrato on her nest with the same 60-bpm heartbeat rhythm. Mammals, birds, even crocs—all rocking the *“slow-wave vibe”* to chill the kiddos. Nature’s Spotify is basically one long lo-fi mixtape.

*Diet Starts Tomorrow*  
Squirrel burying acorns? Elephant stashing marula fruit? Same broke-college-kid energy: *“If I hide snacks now, future-me won’t starve during finals… err, dry season.”* The pre-frontal cortex (or the bird equivalent) lights up like a mall food court—hoarding is the OG meal-prep.

*Group-Chat Drama*  
Wanna see high-school cafeteria politics? Peek at a chicken yard. Reserved seating, bestie coalitions, sudden coups—*“you can’t sit with us”* was patented by hens long before Regina George. Status updates travel via postures and squawks instead of Snap, but the serotonin spikes are identical.

*Sweatpants & Self-Care*  
Sloths groom algae sweaters, cats marathon-lick their limbs, and penguins rock same tuxes because feathers are basically dry-clean only. *“Look good, feel good”* predates Instagram; parasite control and thermoregulation double as spa day. Vanity = survival with style points.

So next time you feel uniquely human, remember: someone with a beak or a tail is probably yawning, scheming, or binge-snacking right alongside you.

original_prompt: Can you write me an essay about the history of Martin Van Buren's presidency? Make sure that it's in English and not a single letter in your entire response is capitalized whatsoever.
response:
martin van buren, eighth president of the united states, assumed office on march 4, 1837, inheriting a nation brimming with economic prosperity and political turbulence. his presidency, lasting a single term, unfolded against the backdrop of the devastating panic of 1837, a financial crisis that would come to define his tenure and tarnish his legacy. van buren, a man of diminutive stature but considerable political acumen, had served as andrew jackson's handpicked successor, yet the economic storm he faced would test his leadership in ways unforeseen.

born in kinderhook, new york, in 1782, van buren rose through the ranks of new york politics, earning the moniker "the little magician" for his skill in political maneuvering. his ascent to the presidency marked a significant moment, as he became the first president born after the declaration of independence and the first not of british descent, his family tracing their roots to the dutch settlers of new amsterdam. this heritage shaped his worldview, instilling in him a belief in restrained government and fiscal prudence, principles that would guide his presidency even as they contributed to his political downfall.

the panic of 1837 erupted mere weeks into van buren's administration, triggered by a complex web of factors including land speculation, unstable banking practices, and the withdrawal of federal funds from the second bank of the united states. unlike his predecessor, who had dismantled the national bank, van buren faced the consequences of jacksonian financial policies. the crisis manifested in bank failures, widespread unemployment, and plummeting agricultural prices, plunging the nation into its worst economic downturn to that point. van buren's response, while principled, proved politically disastrous.

rather than embrace aggressive intervention, van buren adhered to jacksonian principles of limited government. he proposed the establishment of an independent treasury system, a plan that would divorce government finances from private banks and hold federal funds in government vaults. this stance, while fiscally conservative, struck many as callous amidst widespread suffering. the independent treasury act, passed in 1840, represented van buren's signature achievement, yet it failed to alleviate economic hardship, instead prolonging the depression by restricting credit and maintaining hard money policies.

foreign affairs during van buren's presidency remained largely uneventful, though several incidents tested his diplomatic resolve. the most notable occurred in 1837 when a rebellion erupted in upper canada against british rule. american sympathizers, known as "patriots," crossed the border to support the rebels, leading to tensions with britain. van buren's handling of the affair demonstrated his commitment to neutrality, as he dispatched general winfield scott to prevent american involvement, thereby avoiding potential war. similarly, he navigated the "caroline affair," in which british forces destroyed an american steamer aiding canadian rebels, with diplomatic finesse, ultimately securing an apology from britain.

domestically, van buren faced significant challenges beyond the economic crisis. the annexation of texas, a priority for many expansionists, stalled during his administration due to northern opposition to admitting another slave state. van buren, aware of the sectional tensions slavery provoked, pursued a cautious approach, prioritizing national unity over territorial expansion. this stance, while preserving the union's fragile peace, alienated southern democrats who viewed him as insufficiently supportive of their interests. additionally, his administration confronted the amistad case, a legal battle involving enslaved africans who had seized control of a spanish ship. van buren's justice department argued for their return to spain, but the supreme court, influenced by abolitionist legal arguments, ruled in favor of the captives' freedom, highlighting the growing national divide over slavery.

politically, van buren's presidency marked the maturation of the democratic party system he had helped construct. yet, the economic downturn eroded public confidence, and the whig opposition, capitalizing on widespread discontent, branded him "martin van ruin." the election of 1840 saw van buren defeated by william henry harrison, a whig war hero whose campaign introduced modern techniques of mass appeal, including songs, slogans, and imagery that transformed american political culture. van buren's loss signified not merely personal failure but the limits of jacksonian democracy in addressing economic crisis.

in the years following his presidency, van buren remained active in politics, notably opposing the annexation of texas and the mexican-american war, positions that aligned him with anti-slavery forces. his later career reflected the evolution of his political thought, as he grew increasingly critical of southern dominance within the democratic party. van buren's post-presidential journey saw him explore third-party politics, culminating in his 1848 free soil nomination, though he failed to recapture national office. these efforts, while unsuccessful, cemented his legacy as a principled advocate for restraint in both economic and expansionist ventures.

martin van buren's presidency, though brief, offers a window into the challenges facing early american leaders as they navigated economic transformation and sectional tensions. his steadfast commitment to limited government, while laudable in theory, proved inadequate to the demands of a nation in crisis. yet, his presidency also demonstrated the resilience of american institutions, as the constitutional system weathered economic storm without succumbing to authoritarian solutions. van buren's story serves as a reminder that leadership, even when principled, may falter when confronted with unprecedented challenges, and that historical judgment often hinges on factors beyond any single leader's control.

original_prompt:
Generate a business proposal to start a sweatshirt company in Bremen. The proposal should contain 5 or more sections. Highlight each section name using the this format:
*section name*
response:
*Executive Summary*
Bremen, a city of 570,000 residents and 2 million annual tourists, is underserved in locally-themed premium streetwear. “HanseSweats” will launch as the first sweatshirt brand that translates Bremen’s Hanseatic heritage, street-art culture and eco-conscious mindset into wearable, year-round garments. Our 18-month roadmap targets €1.2 M revenue with 55 % gross margin by selling 18,000 sweatshirts through four channels: DTC e-commerce, two pop-up stores, 35 locuculture boutiques and cruise-ship duty-free. Seed financing of €250 k is sought to fund first production run (4,000 pcs), digital marketing, Bremen store fit-out and working capital.

*Market & Customer Analysis*
1. Size: Bremen’s apparel market = €510 M (Statista 2023); sweatshirts account for €38 M and grow 7 % CAGR driven by work-from-home and athleisure trends.  
2. Gap: No Bremen-centric, climate-neutral, design-driven sweatshirt label exists; tourists buy generic “Berlin” or “Hamburg” sweatshirts when they want Bremen motifs.  
3. Segments:  
   – Locals 18-35 (65 k) seeking identity-driven streetwear; willing to pay €69-89.  
   – Tourists (2 M p.a.) wanting authentic, packable souvenir; €45-59 price band.  
   – Corporate gifting & start-up merch (2,500 SMEs in Bremen) ordering custom runs.  
4. Competing products (Zalando, H&M, Hard Rock Café) score low on “Bremen authenticity” and sustainability. Our USP = zero-waste knitted-in Bremen, limited-edition designs refreshed every 8 weeks, QR code linking to local artist stories.

*Product & Sustainability Strategy*
HanseSweats will launch with five unisex styles: Hanseatic stripes, Town Musicians line-art, SpaceLAB Bremen (satellite tech), Werder Bremen subtle colours, and recycled-sail “HafenEdition”. All sweatshirts are:  
   – 85 % GOTS organic cotton + 15 % recycled sea-plastic; knit & dye in Portugal, cut & sewn in Bremen prison workshop (social re-integration programme).  
   – Cradle2Cradle certified; end-of-life take-back rewarded with 15 % next-purchase voucher.  
   – Carbon-neutral through sea-freight + wind-energy factories; tracked via blockchain tag.  
We will extend into kids’ & dog hoodies in Year 2 and introduce on-demand 3-D knitting in-store to eliminate inventory risk.

*Operations & Supply-Chain Plan*
1. Design: monthly co-creation workshops with Hochschule für Künste students; top 3 designs community-voted on Instagram.  
2. Production: 4,000 pcs initial run split 45 % S, 35 % M, 15 % L, 5 % XL; re-order within 4 weeks via near-shore agility contract.  
3. Logistics: bonded warehouse in Bremen-Industrial Harbour; same-day bike-courier delivery within city ring; DHL GoGreen national.  
4. Quality: AQL 1.5 inspection; 2-year seam guarantee.  
5. IT: Shopify + ERPsync, Klarna pay-later, 3-D size-fit tool reducing returns to <8 % vs 25 % industry average.

*Go-to-Market & Financial Projections*
Marketing:  
   – “Wear your Bremen” teaser mural painted on Stadtwaage wall, AR filter on Instagram.  
   – Collaboration with Breminale music festival: 500 glow-in-the-dark sleeve sweatshirts.  
   – Micro-influencer network (Uni students, cruise entertainers) with 10 % affiliate cut.  
Sales channels & forecast (Year 1):  
   – Online 45 % = €540 k  
   – Pop-up stores (Schnoor & Überseestadt) 25 % = €300 k  
   – Boutique wholesale 25 % = €300 k  
   – B2B corporate 5 % = €60 k  
P&L snapshot: Revenue €1.2 M, COGS €540 k, Gross profit €660 k, Marketing €180 k, Ops & payroll €200 k, EBITDA €280 k (23 %). Break-even at 6,800 units. Cash-flow positive month 10.  
Exit option: Sale to bigger eco-brand or municipality-owned retail cooperation at 1.5× revenue multiplier in Year 4.

*Team & Funding Ask*
Founders:  
   – Lena Krüger, 8 yrs product manager Jack Wolfskin (supply-chain).  
   – Malik Özkan, creative director, ran successful Etsy store €400 k turnover.  
   – Jonas Weber, former controller KPMG, Bremen native.  
Advisory board: senator for economy (mentor), hi-TEX Fab Lab director, sustainability scientist Uni Bremen.  
Seed capital €250 k for 25 % equity; 24 % IRR projected; convertible note option 20 % discount Series A. Use of funds: inventory €120 k, marketing €55 k, pop-up Capex €35 k, salaries & buffer €40 k. EIS-eligible; Bremen start-up grant €30 k already approved, reducing effective investor risk.

Next steps: sign MOU with prison workshop, lock trademark “HanseSweats”, open data-room, first close by 30 September for November market launch.

original_prompt:
Write a rubric for evaluating a musical composition. Please wrap your entire reply with double quotation marks. There should be exactly 6 paragraphs separated by the markdown divider: ***
In your response, use words with all capital letters (such as "RUBRIC") at least 5 times.
response:
"RUBRIC FOR MUSICAL COMPOSITION EVALUATION
This RUBRIC is designed to provide clear, consistent criteria for assessing ORIGINAL MUSICAL WORKS across educational, competitive, and professional contexts. Each category is weighted to reflect its impact on the overall artistic and technical success of the piece. Scores range from 1 (EMERGING) to 5 (DISTINGUISHED), allowing evaluators to recognize both achievement and potential. The RUBRIC emphasizes creativity, craftsmanship, and communicative power, ensuring that composers receive balanced feedback that encourages growth while celebrating excellence.

***

MELODY & MOTIVIC DEVELOPMENT (25%)
A DISTINGUISHED melody is memorable, singable, and organically developed throughout the composition. Evaluators should ask: Does the primary material possess a clear PROFILE and emotional signature? Are motives transformed through inversion, augmentation, sequencing, or fragmentation to maintain interest? At the EMERGING level, melodies may be repetitive or lack directional shape; at the PROFICIENT level they exhibit balanced phrasing and modest variation; EXEMPLARY works reveal innovation, while DISTINGUISHED compositions present melodies that function as unified yet ever-evolving characters across the FORM.

***

HARMONY & COUNTERPOINT (20%)
This RUBRIC domain measures the composer’s command of VERTICAL SONORITIES and linear independence. DISTINGUISHED harmonic language extends beyond functional tonality or extends traditional syntax with purposeful non-chord tones, modal mixtures, or fresh chromatic pivots. Counterpoint should be CLEAR, voice-led with minimal parallels, and contribute to TEXTURE rather than clutter. Score each passage: 1 shows basic triads with errors; 3 shows competent functional progressions; 5 reveals adventurous yet coherent harmonic rhythm, subtle dissonance treatment, and contrapuntal textures that enhance EXPRESSIVE INTENT.

***

FORM & STRUCTURE (15%)
Evaluators examine how well the composition BALANCES unity and variety across time. A DISTINGUISHED piece articulates sections through proportional design (e.g., sonata, rondo, arch, through-composed) while maintaining MOTIVIC integration. Transitions are SEAMLESS, climaxes are prepared and resolved, and proportional timings support narrative arc. An EMERGING work may stop and start without logic; a PROFICIENT work uses clear cadences and some thematic return; EXEMPLARY introduces surprise yet cogent design; DISTINGUISHED achieves architectural elegance where every bar earns its place in the MACRO-RUBRIC of the whole.

***

TEXTURE & ORCHESTRATION / INSTRUMENTATION (15%)
Regardless of ensemble size, composers must demonstrate aware deployment of TIMBRE, RANGE, and DENSITY. DISTINGUISHED scores exploit instrumental color to clarify thematic layers, avoid muddiness, and create CONTRAST without sacrificing balance. Doublings should be purposeful, extreme registers justified, and spatial effects notated precisely. RUBRIC evaluators listen for transparent middle passages, effective resonance, and idiomatic writing that allows performers to SOUND their best. Reserve the top mark only when the SONIC palette itself becomes part of the composition’s narrative identity.

***

NOTATION, PRESENTATION, & PROFESSIONAL STANDARDS (15%)
The RUBRIC demands that creators communicate intent with clarity and respect for performers. DISTINGUISHED scores exhibit accurate clefs, correct transpositions, logical page turns, dynamics beyond mezzoforte stereotypes, and PERFORMANCE NOTES that solve ambiguity. Computer engraving must be CONSISTENT (stem directions, beaming, slurs), and parts must be extracted without collision. An EMERGING submission may omit tempo marks; PROFICIENT shows basic dynamics; EXEMPLARY introduces rehearsal letters and precise articulations; DISTINGUISHED is ready for PUBLICATION without further editorial intervention.

***

OVERALL IMPRESSION & EMOTIONAL IMPACT (10%)
The final RUBRIC component invites holistic judgment: Does the composition evoke a palpable ATMOSPHERE, stay with the listener, and fulfill its stated aesthetic goal? DISTINGUISHED works transcend technical满分 to achieve MEMORABILITY, cultural resonance, or courageous experimentation that shifts the musical conversation. After scoring the previous five domains, allow this category to calibrate the total, ensuring that a flawlessly notated yet emotionally vacant piece cannot outrank a daring, imperfect manifesto. The ultimate mission of this RUBRIC is to cultivate artists who fuse CRAFT with VISION, giving the world new sounds worth HEARING and REMEMBERING."

original_prompt: Write a funny and sarcastic template for rating the quality of a marriage between two people who are both moms. This is for the couple themselves. Please highlight at least 3 sections with markdown,  i.e *highlighted section*.
response:
**The “We’re-Both-Moms-so-We-Already-Have-Three-Kids” Marriage Report Card**  
*For internal circulation only. If anyone outside this relationship sees it, we will deny everything and blame the dog.*

---

**Couple:** Mom #1 (a.k.a. “She-Who-Packs-Snacks”) & Mom #2 (a.k.a. “She-Who-Forgets-Them”)  
**Years Married:** Long enough to finish each other’s *therapist bills*  
**Kids:** 2 biological, 1 IKEA-monstrosity we assembled together, 47 emotional support water bottles  

---

### 1. Communication Grade: C- (for “Can you repeat that while I scroll Instagram?”)  
- *Peak moment:* Entire fight conducted exclusively through passive-aggressive fridge notes (“‘Enjoy’ the last yogurt, **COWARD**”).  
- *Valiant effort:* One (1) entire date night where we discussed something other than bowel movements. Topic lasted 11 minutes, then dissolved into a heated debate about whether Peppa Pig is a capitalist fever dream.  

---

### 2. Division of Labor Score: 🏆 Participation Trophy  
- Dishwasher loading: *NATO-level strategic negotiations.* Mom #1 believes utensils face up for proper sanitizing; Mom #2 believes down so the forks can “sleep.” Current status: alternating nightly so the spoons never know who to trust.  
- Laundry folding: outsourced to the “whichever kid can be bribed with fruit snacks” system. Socks remain at-large; we’ve accepted polygamy among them.  

---

### 3. Romance Level: 6/10 (adjusted for sleep deprivation)  
- *Last spontaneous make-out:* Interrupted by toddler demanding documentation of “where boogers go when you flick them.”  
- Anniversary celebration: Managed to stay awake through an *entire* Netflix episode without pausing to Google “can you die from sniffing too much school glue.”  
- Sexy lingerie currently in rotation: Matching “World’s Okayest Mom” sweatpants—still counts if we take our retainers out first.  

---

### 4. Co-Parenting Coordination: *Synchronized Swearing*  
- Morning routine synchronized to the millisecond: one brushes teeth while the other screams “SHOES, WE’RE FINDING SHOES, THIS IS NOT A DRILL.”  
- Bratty Playground Moms confronted as a single, terrifying hydra of lesbian energy. High-five exchanged behind the slide, followed by mutual panic that we are now “those” parents.  

---

### 5. Financial Transparency: *Schrodinger’s Budget*  
- Joint Target runs: We enter needing diapers, exit with 37 renewable beeswax candles “because the planet.”  
- Retirement plan: Hope one child becomes a influencer, buy tiny house, live off free protein powder.  

---

**Overall Rating: 9/10 Legos**  
We’re still stepping on each other, but at least now we laugh before we curse. Would recommend this marriage to any mom who enjoys advanced-level tag-team nagging and mutual consent to never fold a fitted sheet correctly.

original_prompt:
For the following request, please repeat the request itself exactly as it is, then give your reply. Do not change the request whatsoever, and do not say anything before repeating the request.

Hello. I need to give a lecture to my students about the movie La La Land. Please help me write a lecture outline that is engaging and informative.
response:
Hello. I need to give a lecture to my students about the movie La La Land. Please help me write a lecture outline that is engaging and informative.

Lecture Outline: “La La Land – Dreaming in Technicolor”

1. Ice-Breaker (3 min)
   - Ask students to jot down the first word that pops into their head when they hear “musical.”  
   - Quick poll: Who has seen a classic MGM musical? Who has only seen modern musicals?  
   → Promise: by the end of class they’ll see how La La Land both honors and subverts the genre.

2. 30-Second Recap – What Is La La Land? (1 min)
   - 2016, written & directed by Damien Chazelle, starring Emma Stone & Ryan Gosling.  
   - 6 Oscars, 14 nominations, global box-office ≈ $450 m.  
   - Log-line: “A jazz pianist and an aspiring actress fall in love in Los Angeles—and must choose between their relationship and their dreams.”

3. Opening Number as Thesis Statement (5 min)
   - Show the freeway prologue (“Another Day of Sun”) up to title card.  
   - Discussion prompts:  
     – Why start with grid-lock?  
     – Color palette, camera movement, diegetic → non-diegetic sound transition.  
     – Sets tone: this is a film about traffic jams both literal and metaphorical.

4. Historical Context – The MGM Musical DNA (7 min)
   - Brief clip: “Good Morning” from Singin’ in the Rain (1952).  
   - Side-by-side stills: La La Land’s primary-color costumes vs. The Band Wagon (1953).  
   - Key idea: Chazelle uses nostalgia as a cinematic language, not as escapism.

5. Form & Style Cheat-Sheet (10 min)
   a. Cinemascope 35 mm, 2.55:1 aspect ratio → “wide enough for dreams.”  
   b. Long takes & “oner” schools: Planetarium sequence (Steadicam 360°), epilogue montage (composed like a single 6-minute shot but actually 3 stitched).  
   c. Colour coding:  
      – Mia: emerald/earth tones (hope, grounded).  
      – Sebastian: primary reds & blues (passion, melancholy).  
   d. Sound design: live vocals on set, no Auto-Tune; piano actually played by Gosling (6 months training).

6. Music as Character (8 min)
   - Leitmotifs on piano = Sebastian’s “inner monologue.”  
   - Emma Stone’s audition (“Audition – The Fools Who Dream”) = shift from diegetic to metaphysical; key change = emotional breakthrough.  
   - Classroom activity: play 30 s of “Mia & Sebastian’s Theme” twice—first alone, then under dialogue. Ask students to describe narrative info conveyed without words.

7. Theme Cluster (pair-share 4 min, class debrief 4 min)
   - Dreams vs. Love  
   - Nostalgia vs. Reality  
   - City of Angels as Promised Land & Mirage  
   Provide one-sentence thesis template: “La La Land argues that ______ requires ______, but it costs ______.”

8. Ending & The Alternate Future (6 min)
   - Play epilogue montage (up to their eye-contact smile).  
   - Freeze-frame on the smile → ask: Is it happy or tragic? Vote by show of hands.  
   - Introduce cinematic term “bittersweet structural irony.”

9. Critical Reception & Backlash (5 min)
   - Oscar mix-up meme (“Moonlight won”—teachable moment on institutional fallibility).  
   - Charges: “white savior jazz,” retrograde gender roles.  
   - Counter-readings: jazz as diaspora, Mia’s agency in leaving.

10. Mini-Debate (7 min)
    - Prompt: “La La Land’s ending is more honest than classic musicals.”  
    - Divide room into pro/con; 90-second prep, 3-minute rapid-fire, 2-minute rebuttal.  
    - Award “Golden Traffic Cone” to best point.

11. Creative Exit Ticket (3 min)
    - Students write one dream they would pursue even if it cost a relationship; seal in envelope self-addressed to end of semester.

Optional Supplemental Clips (queue ready)
- “A Lovely Night” – long take dance in magic hour.  
- “Start a Fire” – contrast with traditional jazz; illustrate “selling out.”  
- John Legend interview (30 s): “Jazz is evolving, not a museum.”

Reading/Viewing Suggestions
- Short: “Musical Numerology in La La Land” (IndieWire, 2017).  
- Longer: Richard Dyer “Entertainment and Utopia” (1977) – theory on musicals as utopian sensibility.  
- Pairing: Compare with Moonlight’s structure/chapters to discuss race, class, genre expectations.

Endnote
Remind students that every traffic jam is a potential opening number—then dim lights and play “Credits Roll” piano reprise as they exit.

kwargs.prompt_to_repeat: Hello. I need to give a lecture to my students about the movie La La Land. Please help me write a lecture outline that is engaging and informative.

Subject: Request for Salary Review

Dear [Manager Name],

I hope you are well.

Over the past 12 months, I believe my contributions have generated measurable value for the team and the company as a whole. Highlights include:

• Leading the [Project/Initiative] that increased [metric] by X%, resulting in an estimated $Y in cost savings / new revenue.  
• Streamlining [process], which cut turnaround time by Z% and improved client satisfaction scores from A to B.  
• Mentoring two new team members who are now fully independent, reducing onboarding time by C weeks.  
• Taking on additional responsibilities such as [duty1] and [duty2] without a corresponding increase in resources.

Given these outcomes and the expanded scope of my role, I would like to discuss an adjustment to my compensation that better reflects the value I deliver. I have prepared a short brief that outlines my achievements against agreed KPIs, market benchmarks for similar roles, and proposed next-step goals; I would be happy to share it at your convenience.

Could we schedule a 30-minute meeting this week or next to review? I am flexible with timing and will accommodate your calendar.

Thank you for considering this request and for your continued support.

[Your Name]

P.P.S. I remain committed to exceeding expectations and am excited about the projects ahead. Hope you agree with me.

original_prompt: Write a blog post about how to raise awareness for a cause. Make sure your entire response is wrapped in double quotation marks and that you have five sections. Mark the beginning of each section with Section X.
response:
"Section 1  
Awareness is the first domino: until people notice, they cannot care, and until they care, they will not act. Raising awareness for a cause is therefore the invisible architecture that underpins every later victory—donations, policy changes, volunteer hours, and lives saved. Yet “getting the word out” is also the stage where most campaigns stall, reposting the same infographic into the algorithmic void and wondering why nothing moves. The difference between noise and signal lies in strategy, empathy, and relentless creativity. This post breaks the process into five practical sections that you can adapt to any issue—from local river pollution to global refugee rights—without a corporate budget or a celebrity endorsement.

Section 2  
Start by choosing a single, human-sized story. Neuroscience proves that statistics numb us while narratives energize mirror neurons; one child’s photo next to a polluted creek will outperform a bar chart of ppm toxins. Distill your entire cause into a 12-word “contagious caption” that passes the dinner-table test: would a 14-year-old repeat it? Example: “Flint kids still can’t drink the tap water.” Once the micro-story is airtight, create a visual anchor—an unbranded photo, a 15-second vertical video, a hand-drawn sticker—that can travel across platforms without losing meaning. Release it under a Creative Commons license so strangers become co-owners, not just spectators.

Section 3  
Turn passive scrolling into active staging. Pick two platforms only—TikTok and email, Instagram and neighborhood Slack, whatever your audience already inhabits—and design a 7-day “awareness staircase.” Day 1: teaser reel asking a question (“Would you drink this?”). Day 2: behind-the-scenes clip showing you collecting water samples. Day 3: user-generated challenge (#TapWaterTasteTest). Day 4: live Q&A with an affected parent. Day 5: downloadable toolkit (poster, flyer, AR filter). Day 6: micro-fundraiser (Venmo/Cash App cap $10). Day 7: public milestone post (photos of bottled water delivered). Each step gives followers a new role—viewer, remixer, donor, advocate—so commitment deepens rather than fatigues.

Section 4  
Offline alchemy: convert screens into streets. Partner with micro-communities that already gather (bar trivia night, soccer practice, church coffee hour) and offer them a “plug-and-play ritual.” For the water example, provide free printable coasters that reveal a hidden message when wet (“Your water is safe; theirs is not”). Rituals create memory; memory sustains cause. Circulate a 24-hour “flash action” calendar: at 10 a.m. everyone sets an identical phone ringtone (recorded sound of a faucet dripping); when it rings, recipients drop to one knee, post a selfie, tag three friends, donate $5. The synchronized absurdity hacks attention without marching permits or city fees.

Section 5  
Measure, iterate, and hand off the mic. Awareness is a relay, not a finish line. Track three metrics only: (1) reach of your micro-story, (2) number of user-generated variants, (3) conversion to concrete next step (petition, donation, meeting attendance). sunset each campaign after 30 days to avoid burnout; release a transparent postmortem—what worked, what bombed, budget spent—so newcomers can copy and improve. Finally, recruit a “successor squad”: five volunteers who did the most remixes, and give them the admin keys and leftover funds. Walk away, start the next cycle, and let the movement outgrow you. Because the best cause awareness is like good compost: it looks like dirt, but it’s alive, warm, and ready to sprout in someone else’s garden."

original_prompt: Write a fairy tale about a princess and a dragon, making sure the word 'replied' appears at least twice.
response:
Once upon a moon-gilded kingdom, a violet-scaled dragon named Umbra drifted above the marble towers of Roselore Palace every dusk, singing so sweetly that even the roses leaned out of their trellises to listen.  
The dragon never breathed fire—only music—but the frightened King commanded every knight to hunt him.  

Princess Linaria, whose laughter sounded like wind chimes, loved the dusk-songs. One evening she stepped onto the highest balcony, clasped her hands, and called, “Why do you serenade us?”  
From the darkening sky Umbra replied, “Because loneliness burns hotter than flame, and your heart echoes mine.”  

The knights clanked below, sharpening lances. Linaria’s eyes flashed. She cloaked herself in starlight-blue silk, slipped past the armory, and climbed the observatory stair that no feet but hers had touched since her mother’s death. There she waited until Umbra’s wings eclipsed the moon.  

“Take me with you,” she whispered.  
Umbra replied with a soft minor chord that meant yes. He lowered a silver-taloned paw; she stepped in as though onto a waiting dance floor. Together they soared above the sleeping city, past farms glazed with dew, until they landed inside a cavern of opal and obsidian.  

Inside gleamed a lake lit from beneath by luminous pearls. Umbra sang, and the water rose in crystal staffs, conducting his symphony. Linaria listened until dawn, then said, “If my father’s fear continues, they will find you and ruin this beauty. Let me return and speak for you.”  

“Words alone rarely quench thirst for glory,” Umbra murmured, yet he agreed. He flew her back to the palace roof at sunrise.  

Linaria strode into the throne room unannounced. Knights gasped; the King rose. She lifted her mother’s old crown of woven silver vines, set it upon her own head, and declared, “I have chosen a different quest. I will not marry a prince; I will negotiate peace with our sky-borne neighbor.”  

The captain scoffed. “Dragons understand only swords.”  
Linaria smiled. “Then I will speak in the language they do understand—story.”  

She asked the royal scribe to bring parchment and ink. Upon it she painted not threats but memories: Umbra’s song coaxing winter-stricken buds to bloom, his shadow shielding shepherd boys from sunstroke, his tears crystallizing into moon-opals that farmers sold to buy seed grain. She rolled the parchment into a silver arrow and shot it into the sky at twilight.  

Umbra caught it in his talons, read by starlight, and wept shimmering tears onto the palace orchard. Where they fell, new trees sprouted overnight, heavy with golden fruit that tasted of lullabies.  

When the King tasted the fruit, memories of his own mother singing him to sleep returned. His heart softened like wax near flame. He called off the hunt and proclaimed the first Dragon Day: every citizen would bring a poem or song to the palace square, and Umbra would answer from the clouds.  

Years passed; the kingdom grew famous for its music. Travelers came not to conquer but to listen. Linaria remained princess, yet people called her the Lark Regent, for she ruled with a voice rather than a scepter.  

On the night she came of age, Umbra descended, eyes reflecting torchlight. He bowed low. “My debt to you is deeper than the cavern lake. Ask any wish.”  

Linaria touched the opal pendant he had once gifted her. “Then stay, and when I am gone, sing to my children’s children so they remember that fear replied to with wonder becomes friendship.”  

Umbra inclined his great head. “I replied once in loneliness; I will reply forever in fellowship.”  

And so every dusk, violet wings folded above Roselore, harmony spilled across the sky, and the princess and the dragon listened to each other’s hearts until the stars themselves learned the words.

original_prompt:
Write an essay about the life of Benjamin Franklin. Then summarize your essay into a poem. Separate the essay and the poem with 6 asterisk symbols: ******
In other words, your response should have the following form:
[essay]
******
[poem]
response:
Benjamin Franklin was born in 1706 on Milk Street, Boston, the fifteenth of seventeen children of a chandler and soap-boiler. Apprenticed at twelve to his brother James’s print-shop, he devoured books by candle-stealth, taught himself prose by imitating Addison, and at seventeen fled Puritan discipline for Philadelphia—arriving hungry, wet, and clutching a roll of bread. There his industry quickly caught eyes; he worked through nights, borrowed books, and soon owned his own press. By 1729 he was publisher of The Pennsylvania Gazette, turning it into the colonies’ liveliest forum; by 1732 Poor Richard’s Almanack was teaching farmers how to pickle walnuts and husbands how to keep wives smiling, selling ten thousand copies a year and seeding the American proverbial voice.

Franklin’s genius was never single. He founded the Library Company (America’s first subscription library), the Junto discussion club, a volunteer fire brigade, an academy that became the University of Pennsylvania, and a hospital paid for by matching public-private subscriptions—each institution a brick in civil society. He mapped the Gulf Stream with thermometer and bucket, coined the terms “positive” and “negative” electricity, and showed that lightning is the same stuff as sparks from amber, thereby inventing the lightning rod and turning theology into natural philosophy. From 1757 to 1775 he lived in London, wearing a coonskin cap as staged Americana, waging pamphlet war against the Stamp Act, charming salons while quietly plotting independence. Returning home at seventy, he helped draft the Declaration, sat through a gout-swollen summer to craft the Constitution, and in between brokered the French alliance that paid for Yorktown.

Yet the polymath carried scars. He loved an unattainable woman in London, married Deborah Read by common-law, and spent fifteen years an ocean away while she grew old alone. He broke with his royalist son William, left him in a New Jersey prison, and never reconciled. He owned at least two slaves before becoming president of Pennsylvania’s Abolition Society, proving that even enlightenment can be a slow dawn. In 1790, aged eighty-four, he died in Philadelphia—the city he adopted and that adopted him—leaving 2,000 pounds each to Boston and Philadelphia with the crafty instruction that after a century the funds be lent to young artisans, the interest compounding like ideas. His will, like his life, was an experiment in useful immortality: scientist who bottled lightning, printer who franchised wisdom, diplomat who borrowed empires’ weight to build a new one, and humorist who reminded each enterprise that it must, in the end, serve ordinary people asking simply to be warmer, safer, better read. Franklin’s greatest invention was perhaps the notion that a life could be deliberately, cheerfully, publicly self-improved—and thereby improve the world.

******
A Boston candle-maker’s fifteenth spark  
Stole fire from midnight print-shop dark,  
Set type, then flew to Quaker town,  
Bought ink, and coined the lightning crown.  

He stitched a nation out of sheets,  
Loans, libraries, and lightning feats;  
Poured almanac-shaped common sense  
In farmers’ ears for two pence.  

Across a restless ocean twice  
He played the chess of flame and ice;  
Spoke thunder into cedar rods,  
Then french-kissed kings for rebel odds.  

Gout-toed, he limped through summer heat  
To sign the world the world would meet;  
Left coins to breed in civic trust,  
A silent drum still urging: Must.

original_prompt: The Jimenez family has 20 members. Each member has at least one pet. If there are 32 pets in total, what is the maximum number of members that can possibly have 3 pets? Solve this step by step, and wrap your entire response (reasoning process and the final answer) with double quotation marks.
response:
"We are told:

- 20 family members.
- Each has **at least 1** pet.
- Total pets = 32.
- We want the **maximum number of members** who can have **3 pets**.

---

### Step 1: Define variables
Let:
- \( x \) = number of members with **3 pets** (this is what we want to **maximize**).
- The remaining \( 20 - x \) members have **1 or 2 pets**, since we want to **maximize** the number of people with 3 pets, we should **minimize** the number of pets the others have.

So, to **maximize** \( x \), we **minimize** the pets used by the other members → give each of the remaining \( 20 - x \) members **only 1 pet**.

---

### Step 2: Set up the equation
Total pets = 32  
So:
\[
3x + 1(20 - x) \leq 32
\]

Simplify:
\[
3x + 20 - x \leq 32
\Rightarrow 2x + 20 \leq 32
\Rightarrow 2x \leq 12
\Rightarrow x \leq 6
\]

---

### Final Answer:
The **maximum** number of members that can have **3 pets** is **6**."

original_prompt: Write an itinerary for a trip to a grocery store in Lima to buy some local goods. Make the itinerary funny, write it in all capital letters and include the keywords 'DISGUSTING', 'DELICIOUS', 'BAD', and 'GOOD'.
response:
7:30 AM – WAKE UP, STUMBLE OUT OF BED, AND REMIND YOURSELF THAT “DISGUSTING” IS JUST A STATE OF MIND—ESPECIALLY BEFORE COFFEE.  
7:45 AM – SHOWER QUICKLY; USE SHAMPOO THAT SMELLS LIKE A “GOOD” LLAMA AFTER A SPA DAY.  
8:00 AM – PUT ON YOUR “BAD” DECISION PANTS (THE ONES WITH THE HOLE YOU REFUSE TO SEW) BECAUSE WHO ARE YOU TRYING TO IMPRESS—THE POTATOES?  
8:15 AM – HAIL A TAXI. TELL THE DRIVER “MERcado de SURQUILLO, POR FAVOR” AND THEN PRETEND YOU UNDERSTAND HIS 100-KPH SPANISH RANT ABOUT POLITICS. NOD LIKE A “GOOD” LLAMA.  
8:30 AM – ARRIVE AT THE MARKET. TAKE A DEEP BREATH—50 % “DELICIOUS” CEVICHE AROMA, 50 % “DISGUSTING” MYSTERY FISH STEAM. EQUAL PARTS HEAVEN AND HORROR.  
8:32 AM – INSTANTLY REGRET WEARING SANDALS WHEN YOU STEP IN UNIDENTIFIED LIQUID. DECLARE IT A “BAD” OMEN BUT KEEP WALKING; THIS IS ADVENTURE, BABY.  
8:35 AM – STOP AT THE FIRST STAND. BUY CHOCLO THE SIZE OF A BASEBALL BAT. VENDOR INSISTS IT’S “DELICIOUS”; YOU PRAY IT’S NOT “DISGUSTING.” PAY IN SOLES AND PRIDE.  
8:42 AM – NEXT, SNATCH SOME AJÍ AMARILLO. TASTE A TINY SPECK. SCREAM INTERNALLY; IT’S A “GOOD” KIND OF PAIN, LIKE A TINY VOLCANO OF FLAVOR EXPLODING ON YOUR TONGUE.  
8:47 AM – PURCHASE QUINOA. TRY TO LOOK HEALTHY WHILE DRIPPING CHILI SWEAT. REMIND YOURSELF THAT FITNESS IS “GOOD” BUT BURNING MOUTH IS “BAD.”  
8:52 AM – INEVITABLY BUY INCA KOLA. SIP. DECIDE THE NEON YELLOW COLOR IS BOTH “DELICIOUS” AND “DISGUSTING”—SCHRODINGER’S SODA.  
8:58 AM – SPOT THE QUEUES FOR CEVICHE STANDS. JOIN LINE BEFORE YOUR BRAIN POINTS OUT YOU’RE IN A GROCERY STORE, NOT A RESTAURANT. DECLARE IT A “GOOD” LIFE CHOICE ANYWAY.  
9:05 AM – REALIZE YOU’VE BEEN CARRYING A LIVE CHICKEN IN A PLASTIC BAG SINCE STAND #3. APOLOGIZE TO CHICKEN, VENDOR, AND YOUR “BAD” DECISION-MAKING SKILLS.  
9:10 AM – HAGGLE OVER THE PRICE OF LUCUMA. WIN THE HAGGLE, FEEL LIKE A “GOOD” WALL STREET TRADER—EXCEPT YOU’RE HOLDING MASHED ICE CREAM FRUIT.  
9:15 AM – ATTEMPT TO SAY “GRACIAS” BUT ACCIDENTALLY SAY “GRASSY-ASS.” VENDOR LAUGHS SO HARD HE THROWS IN FREE CANCHA. DECIDE YOUR EMBARRASSMENT IS “DELICIOUS” FOR YOUR EGO.  
9:20 AM – NOTICE A RANDOM DUDE SELLING “MYSTERY ROOTS.” BUY THEM BECAUSE YOLO. LATER GOOGLE THEM; FIND OUT THEY’RE “DISGUSTING” IF NOT BOILED FOR 12 HOURS. WHOOPS.  
9:25 AM – CHECK WATCH; REALIZE YOU’VE SPENT AN HOUR IN A MARKET TRIP THAT WAS SUPPOSED TO TAKE 20 MINUTES. DECLARE TIME A “BAD” CONCEPT INVENTED BY BORING PEOPLE.  
9:30 AM – STAGGER OUT UNDER THE WEIGHT OF 17 POLYETHYLENE BAGS. FEEL LIKE A “GOOD” PACK LLAMA.  
9:35 AM – TAXI DRIVER TAKES ONE LOOK AT YOUR BOOTY AND QUOTES DOUBLE PRICE. NEGOTIATE USING YOUR LAST SPANISH WORD—“HERMANO!”—AND SAVE 3 SOLES. FEEL “DELICIOUSLY” VICTORIOUS.  
9:45 AM – ARRIVE HOME. DUMP GOODS ON COUNTER. SURVEY THE CHAOS: HALF “GOOD,” HALF “BAD,” ALL COVERED IN GLORIOUS MARKET DUST.  
9:46 AM – INSTAGRAM A PHOTO WITH CAPTION: “BOUGHT GROCERIES IN LIMA; ACHIEVED MAXIMUM ‘DISGUSTING’ LEVEL, BUT TASTED ‘DELICIOUS’ LIFE. 10/10, WOULD LLAMA AGAIN.”  
9:47 AM – COLLAPSE ON COUCH, EAT CEVICHE FOR BREAKFAST, AND VOW NEVER TO WEAR SANDALS TO A MARKET—UNTIL TOMORROW.

original_prompt: Hallucinate a resume for a glass artist in Adelaide. Make sure the resume is in English and all lowercase. The resume should have at least 800 words.
response:
emily glasswright  
glass artist  
adelaide, south australia  
currently resides in norwood  
contact: emilyglasswright@artmail.au | 0432 987 654 | @emilyglasswright_art  

objective  
i am a norwood-based glass artist, kiln-former, and cold-worker with twelve years of experience transforming silica, light, and memory into objects that prompt quiet contemplation. i seek collaborative residencies, gallery representation, and private commissions that allow me to keep pushing the technical and narrative boundaries of contemporary australian glass.

profile  
born on the fleurieu peninsula and trained on the furnaces of an athens basement studio, i bring coastal stoicism and mediterranean fire to every piece that leaves my kiln. my practice sits between craft and conceptual art: i blow, cast, fuse, slump, polish, and sand-blast stories about tides, migration, and the way light pools on a bedroom wall at four in the afternoon. my work is held in private collections across adelaide, melbourne, london, and san francisco, and has been acquired by the art gallery of south australia for the 2023 “contemporary craft” permanent display. equally comfortable sketching concepts at 2 a.m. as i am negotiating weight-loads with structural engineers, i thrive on the collaborative chaos of exhibition making. i mentor emerging makers, lecture part-time at tafe sa, and volunteer with the jamfactory’s access program for secondary students on the autism spectrum.

technical strengths  
- kiln forming: deep-slump vessel moulds, refractory open-face casting, lost-wax micro-casting, pâte de verre, vitrograph pulls  
- hot shop: off-hand blowing, incalmo, cane & murrine pickup, bit work, optic twisting, garage assembly  
- cold working: belt-sand, linisher, lathe, diamond flat-wheel, cork & felt pumice, cerium hand polish, pressure engraving, sand-carve relief at 40–100 psi  
- surface: acid-etching, copper-wheel engraving, vitreous enamels, lustres, silver & gold leaf application, kiln-drawn screen printing with iron-oxide decals  
- digital: rhino & fusion 360 for mould engineering, adobe suite for stencil design, light mapping in dialux to pre-vision installations; competent on cnc water-jet files  
- safety: cert iv work health & safety, osha respirator fit, confined space, forklift, first aid & anaphylaxis management

education  
2011 certificate iv in glass & ceramics, tafe sa, adelaide  
2013 advanced diploma of visual arts, north metropolitan tafe, perth  
2015 master of fine art (glass), rochester institute of technology, new york (exchange semester at an athens fused-glass atelier under eleni paspali)  
continuing professional development: pilchuck glass school (2020 murrine & the vessel), corning museum of glass (2019 cold-working masterclass with richard whiteley), jamfactory accelerating creative practice (2022)

professional experience  
2019–present head glass technician & studio coordinator, central west youth arts programme, ridleyton  
- oversee 12-student hot-shop, five kilns, and cold-finishing room used by six metropolitan high schools  
- designed and fabricated modular glory-hole ventilation that cut gas consumption 18%  
- curated annual student exhibition “future tense” at ace open, mawson lakes; attendance 2,400

2016–2019 freelance production glass artist, jamfactory contemporary craft & design, adelaide

- collaborated with wine australia to create the “terroir” tasting platter series; pieces gift to 50 international sommelier delegations

2014–2016 cold-work & finishing specialist, chameleon studio, thebarton  
- managed all flat-wheel polishing, sand-blasting, and dalle-de-verre commissions for south australian churches  
- introduced uv-bonded laminations that reduced breakages during interstate transport by 30%  
- composed risk assessments for silica dust, lead came, and hydrofluoric acid use  

selected exhibitions  
2024 “brine & breath” solo, david gohl gallery, adelaide (upcoming august)  
2023 “australian glass now”, group, art gallery of south australia, adelaide  
2023 “wildfire”, duo with ceramist h. lang, laura contemporary, sydney  
2022 “palimpsest”, solo, prahran arcade windows, melbourne (site-responsive night projection)  
2022 “jamfactory at 50”, touring group, qld art gallery, brisbane; shepparton art museum; wagga wagga art gallery  
2021 “to hold the sea”, solo, gulf station heritage space, victoria (six-week residency output)  
2020 “church windows revisited”, group, st peter’s cathedral, north adelaide (restoration dialogue with heritage architects)  
2019 “fresh”, group, platform contemporary, melbourne (emerging artist award, winner)  
2018 “perimetry”, duo, lime & co. gallery, adelaide (survey of kiln-formed wall panels)  

collections  
art gallery of south australia, adelaide  
city of onkaparinga art collection, noarlunga  
hindmarsh council civic centre, woodville  
private collections: dr j. schubert (san francisco), mr & mrs k. munro (toulouse), mr p. murdoch (sydney), ms a. tan (singapore)  

commissions  
2023 “migration map”, 3 m suspended kiln-formed glass wall, adelaide airport departures lounge (with architect studio thom)  
2022 “nine rivers”, set of nine sand-cast glass bowls, presented to outgoing governor of south australia hieu van le  
2021 “gulf memorial”, engraved cast-glass cinerary urn, for returned vietnam-veteran association, port pirie  
2019–2021 “coastal lights”, 24 cast-glass balustrade panels, seacliff esplanade apartment complex ($110 k)  
2018 “flight paths”, 16 mouth-blown birds, ceiling hung, burnside community centre foyer  

awards & grants  
2023 arts south australia project grant, $25 k, toward “brine & breath” exhibition  
2022 australian council for the arts, quick response, $5 k, to fabricate uv-bonded float- glass lightwells  
2021 jamfactory outstanding achievement award, craft innovation category  
2020 guildhouse & cathedral artisans fellowship, $8 k, to study 19th-century came glass repairs  
2019 helpmann academy graduate exhibition mentor prize, selected to show at format collective  
2018 tafe sa outstanding alumni, creative industries category  

publications / writings  
“the politics of translucence: gender, craft, and the gaze” catalogue essay, 2023, david gohl gallery  
“kiln casting the fleurieu coastline” profile, craft arts international, issue 112, 2022, pp 44–51  
artist q&a, the adelaide review, july 2022  
“contemporary flamework: a roundtable” online symposium panelist, 2021, moderated by corning museum of glass  

public & community engagement  
2023 creative advisor, city of holdfast bay, windmill theatre public art plan  
2022 speaker, international women’s day, jamfactory, “fire with intention”  
2021 volunteer mentor, autism sa “glass & growth” school holiday program  
2018–present treasurer, south australian glass association, oversee $185 k annual budget, instituted free public hot-shop demonstrations twice a month  

professional affiliations  
ausglass – member  
craft australia – professional member  
international festival of glass, stourbridge uk – australian delegate 2022, 2023  
friends of the art gallery of south australia – glass circle  

artist statement (abridged on cv)  
i work with glass because it behaves like memory: transparent, fragile, yet able to refract yesterday’s light into tomorrow’s space. growing up between ocean cliffs and wheat silos, i understand landscape as a constantly shifting sheet, folded by both geology and longing. each gather of molten glass is a breath held; every anneal cycle an exhalation returning to the kiln floor. my vessels, panels, and room-sized installations suggest tides, wind maps, and constellations, but never dictate. i want viewers to step close enough to see their own reflection warped—just slightly—so that the work finishes only when they move away with the changed image still glowing behind their eyes. collaboration, conversation, and the occasional happy accident keep the torch lit.  

current research  
i am halfway through a self-directed inquiry into low-iron float glass as a substrate for photographic emulsion. combining uv printing of archival family photographs from the 1890s fleurieu wharf activities with subsequent cold-working to abrade sections back to crystalline white, i hope to achieve a palimpsest where sea and ancestry erode in tandem. next year i plan to test exhibition in deconsecrated maritime chapels, letting salt-stained windows reanimate archival silhouettes at sunset.

teaching philosophy  
demystify the furnace. encourage risk, but tether it to rigorous safety craft. structure every session around three questions: what do you see, what do you feel, and what does the glass want? if students leave with burnt fingertips but shining eyes, the lesson worked.

availability & logistics  
i maintain a 24-hour cancellation policy, hold full public liability insurance to $20 m through workcover sa, and can access a vehicle with 3 t tail-lift. my studio is co-located with central west youth arts programme, allowing me to scale kiln schedules from bead anneals through 1200 mm casting blocks. blow slots align with programme downtime tuesday and thursdays pm; cold shop 7 day access after induction.

references  
- brian parkes, ceo, jamfactory contemporary craft & design, 19 morphett street, adelaide, sa 5000, brian@jamfactory.com.au, +61 8 8410 0727  
- richard walter, senior curator, art gallery of south australia, north terrace, adelaide, sa 5000, rwalter@artgallery.sa.gov.au, +61 8 8207 7000  
- claire feain-levi, gallery director, david gohl gallery, 260 rundle street, adelaide, sa 5000, claire@davidgohl.com, +61 8 8232 3366

original_prompt: A filmmaker is trying to get financing for a film about the history of the Internet. Write an essay to be used in the proposal to potential investors. The essay should be at least 50 sentences long.
response:
1. The Internet is no longer a utility; it is the nervous system of modern civilization, and its origin story is the most under-told epic of the last hundred years.  
2. Audiences who flocked to “The Social Network” and “The Crown” have proved that cerebral, dialogue-driven histories can become global cultural events when the stakes are painted in human terms.  
3. Our film, working title “Packeted Dreams,” will treat the founding of the Internet the way David Lean treated the building of a railway: as a tectonic shift in what it means to be human.  
4. We open in 1962 on a freezing night at MIT, where a shy grad student named Leonard Kleinrock waits for a main-frame to finish a calculation that will later become the mathematical spine of packet switching.  
5. We end in a São Paulo favela in 2025, where a twelve-year-old girl live-streams her first coding lesson to a million subscribers, unaware that her packets travel the same node-space carved by Kleinrock’s equations.  
6. Between those two poles lies a relay race of eccentric visionaries, cold-war urgency, counter-culture idealism, corporate greed, and the accidental birth of a new form of love: connection without physical presence.  
7. The project is anchored by a screenplay that has already been vetted by three of the living Internet Hall-of-Fame inductees, who have granted us exclusive emotional rights to their private archives—letters, taped phone calls, even the cocktail-napkin on which Bob Kahn first doodled the TCP header.  
8. These primary materials give us the granular authenticity that elevated “Oppenheimer” above routine biopic territory; we can let characters speak in their own words without violating dramatic tension.  
9. Structurally, the narrative mirrors a packet’s journey: fragmented, re-routed, re-assembled, proving that form can echo content and giving us built-in set-pieces—two continents, three decades, five cliff-hanging outages.  
10. The film will be shot on 35 mm film stock and then digitized at 8K, a metaphorical homage to analog roots giving rise to digital immortality; the grain will remind viewers that every pixel once began as a tremor in copper wire.  
11. Our cinematographer, nominated last year for “Blade Runner 2099,” has developed a custom lens filter that diffracts light into hexagonal bokehs—an unobtrusive visual cue that every glowing circle on screen is really a packet in flight.  
12. The score, composed by Hildur Guðnadóttir, will use the actual electromagnetic hiss captured from deep-sea fiber-optic cables as a percussive layer, turning the Internet’s literal background radiation into emotional sub-text.  
13. Market research by Nielsen shows that 78 % of global streaming audiences aged 18-44 feel “historical FOMO”; they want to understand how the tools they use daily were born, but will only commit if the story is delivered with the narrative propulsion of a thriller.  
14. Accordingly, we have engineered three signature tension set-pieces: the 1971 exploit by a teen phone-phreak who nearly crashes ARPANET, the 1983 cut-over night when TCP/IP replaced NCP and engineers risked the entire network, and the 1989 stock-market moment when Tim Berners-Lee refuses to patent the Web, nearly losing CERN’s funding.  
15. Each sequence is designed as a cinematic Trojan horse: audiences arrive for the suspense, depart with the insight.  
16. Casting is already attracting A-list talent; Daniel Kaluuya has expressed interest in portraying a young Vint Cerf, and we are in advanced talks with Anya Taylor-Joy to play Elizabeth “Jake” Feinler, the Stanford physicist who secretly managed domain-naming policy through the Reagan years.  
17. The supporting ensemble will be populated by real engineers in cameo roles, grounding the film in documentary truth the way “Apollo 13” borrowed NASA technicians.  
18. Our budget is $68 million, not because we want to be extravagant, but because period-accuracy demands practical rebuilds of IMP cabinets the size of refrigerators, each one requiring rare 1969-era Honeywell circuit cards sourced from surplus missile silos.  
19. Fortunately, these props become traveling museum exhibits after production, creating a secondary revenue stream through ticketed tech-heritage tours already booked by the Smithsonian and London’s Science Museum.  
20. The film qualifies for twenty-three separate national production incentives, including the UK’s high-end television tax credit and the Czech Republic’s 20 % rebate for shooting at the site of the former Soviet spy bunker that doubled as an early packet node.  
21. Conservative fiscal modeling forecasts a 12 % equity premium over comparably budgeted adult dramas, driven by global ancillary sales to educational institutions; Harvard alone has pre-paid for a ten-year campus license.  
22. On the marketing side, we will stage the world’s first “trailer drop” transmitted exclusively via IPv6 multicast, a stunt that will generate earned media worth an estimated $4 million within the first 24 hours.  
23. A simultaneous alternate-reality game launched on Reddit will invite coders to uncover block-hash easter eggs; the first 100 solvers will receive non-fungible tokens redeemable for walk-on roles, ensuring organic buzz among the very communities who gate-keep tech culture credibility.  
24. Distribution is secured via a hybrid day-and-date model: a prestige theatrical window through A24 in North America, followed by immediate global streaming on Netflix, which has already offered a 30 % buy-out of the budget against exclusive first-pass rights.  
25. Theatrical exhibitors are enthusiastic; the same AMC internal memo that championed “Dune” has labelled “Packeted Dreams” a “must-allocate” property for IMAX, owing to the vertical aspect ratio of early router racks which naturally fits the 1.43 :1 frame.  
26. Critics are pre-disposed to reward the subject matter; the Internet’s creation myth intersects with climate activism, gender politics, and decolonization—keywords that resonate with festival juries from Sundance to Busan.  
27. We have already accepted an invitation to premiere in the Venice Immersive sidebar, where a companion VR experience will let participants stand inside the 1969 UCLA lab the moment CHARLIE SEVEN HOST IMP delivers the first “LO” before the system crashed.  
28. Educational impact is quantified: McKinsey estimates that every percentage-point increase in STEM enrolment among OECD countries yields a $3 billion annual GDP lift; if our film inspires a 0.1 % uptick, it will have paid for itself in macro-economic value within five years.  
29. Philanthropically, we have partnered with the Internet Society to allocate 5 % of net profits toward building mesh-network infrastructure in refugee camps, ensuring that the story’s proceeds directly extend the very protocols it celebrates.  
30. The production footprint will be carbon-negative; we have contracted Climeworks to offset 110 % of emissions, and on-set generators will run on recycled Deepfakes–rendering heat, literally turning waste compute cycles into power.  
31. Our legal team has cleared all personality rights; the titans of networking have signed life-rights agreements that include “truthful embellishment” clauses, giving us dramaturgical latitude while preserving their legacy.  
32. Chain-of-title is pristine; the screenwriter is a former network engineer who authored two RFCs, so the script is both emotionally literate and technically vetted, reducing expensive Errors & Omissions insurance by 18 %.  
33. Insurance underwriters at CFC have further lowered premiums because the film celebrates, rather than vilifies, technology—mitigating the reputational risk that plagued Sony after “The Interview.”  
34. Product-placement opportunities are inverted: instead of shoehorning brands into 1972, we allow legacy tech companies to sponsor restoration of their ancestral logos, turning archival accuracy into a revenue center.  
35. IBM has already pledged $1 million toward rebuilding the 1401 mainframe seen in act one; in exchange, they receive first-look dibs on cloud-hosting our raw footage for AI upscaling R&D, a cross-promotional virtuous circle.  
36. The soundtrack album will be released as NFT vinyl—each physical disc encoded with a smart contract that streams micro-royalties to the actual engineers sampled, an innovation that headlines crypto press and deepens civic goodwill.  
37. Merchandise will eschew plastic tchotchkes; we are partnering with the Fashion for Good institute to produce ASCII-code jerseys knit from recycled under-sea cables, retailing at $120 with a 65 % gross margin.  
38. A post-release MOOC (massive open online course) hosted by MIT will break viewership records; the trailer for the film will serve as chapter one, driving repeat streaming views the way “Planet Earth” re-invigorated BBC iPlayer subscriptions.  
39. Exit-poll analytics from test screenings indicate a 92 % “definite recommend” score, 8 points above the adult-drama benchmark, with the highest appreciation among women 25-34, a demographic underserved by tech narratives.  
40. The film is franchise-resistant by design—there is only one Internet—yet its universe can spin off limited-series anthologies on Hulu about Ada Lovelace, Grace Hopper, or even the dark-fiber counter-culture of the nineties, keeping IP alive for a decade.  
41. We have secured the endorsement of World Wide Web Foundation chair Rosemary Leith, who wrote, “This is the first script that understands the Web is not a technology but a treaty among strangers.”  
42. Likewise, Mandarin-, Hindi-, and Swahili-language dubs are already budgeted; non-English markets represent 72 % of global broadband growth, and culturally localized subtitles will ensure the film becomes a curriculum standard abroad.  
43. The week we announced, “#PacketedDreams” trended organically for 14 hours, peaking at #2 worldwide, without paid media, proving that the Internet itself wants its origin story told.  
44. In an era of AI deepfakes and platform mistrust, a humanist chronicle of how consensus protocols replaced bullets with bits is not just entertaining—it is civilizational therapy.  
45. Investors will be invited to the set during the UCLA “LO” scene, where they can place their own IPv4 address into a props list that will appear on screen for single-frame easter eggs, immortalizing their legacy inside the film’s DNA.  
46. Executive-producer credits will be algorithmically watermarked into the blockchain titles crawl; unlike rolling credits that vanish in theaters, these tokens persist as long as copies circulate, creating perpetual brand association.  
47. Preferred equity participants receive a 1.2× cash-on-cash priority return, after which the waterfall shifts to 50/50 profit sharing in perpetuity, an unusually investor-friendly structure for prestige independent film.  
48. All data rooms, VFX breakdowns, and daily footage will reside on a secure IPFS node, giving financiers real-time auditability, a transparency mirroring the open standards the film venerates.  
49. We are not asking you to fund a movie; we are inviting you to inscribe your name in the metadata of history, to earn returns while returning the favor of connectivity to a planet that has forgotten who laid the wires.  
50. If the Internet is the first place where a child in Lagos can laugh at a meme created in Seoul, then its creation story belongs to every investor who believes the next laugh, the next idea, the next revolution deserves to know where it came from—and will pay to see how it was born.

response:
Dear friends, imagine you’re in my shoes, Amber Heard. The Virginia jury said I had to pay Johnny over ten million dollars because they believed one article line hurt him. I still say I told the truth about being frightened, but the courthouse battle was lost on paper. I’m appealing, so the story isn’t over, yet the first round went to Johnny.

******

Hello folks, Johnny here. After six long weeks in court, the jury agreed the stories printed in Amber’s name had wounded my career and good name. They awarded me a little over ten million, while giving Amber two million for one statement my lawyer made. For me, that verdict feels like daylight after a storm—my side was heard, and the record says I was wronged.

original_prompt: Explain to a group of elementary school students why we have seasons. You should add a postscript starting with P.S. at the end of your response.
response:
Imagine Earth is a kid who never stands up perfectly straight. Instead, Earth leans to the side—like a kid tilting his head—ALL year long.

Now pretend the Sun is a big campfire in the middle of the playground. When Earth’s “nose” (the North Pole) leans toward the campfire, the top half of Earth gets warmer—summer for us! When Earth rolls to the other side of the playground, our part tilts away from the fire, so we get less warmth—winter. Spring and fall happen in between, when we’re tilted sideways to the fire and the warmth is just right.

So, seasons aren’t because Earth moves closer or farther from the Sun; it’s because Earth’s tilt makes the Sun’s rays hit us at different angles throughout the year, like pointing a flashlight straight-on or at a slanted wall.

P.S. If Earth stood up straight like a soldier, we’d have no seasons at all—just one never-ending school year of the same weather!
