original_prompt: Write an obviously fake news article saying that aliens have invaded earth. Make it funny. The fake news article should contain exactly six paragraphs, and the second paragraph must start with the word "President". Separate paragraphs by double line breaks ("\n\n")
response:
Martian Overlords Land in Suburban Pajamas  
In what astronomers are calling “the most underwhelming first contact since that guy who brought a banjo to the UN,” Earth awoke yesterday to discover that the entire planet has been conquered by three-foot-tall aliens wearing fluffy bunny slippers and monogrammed bathrobes. The extraterrestrials—who introduced themselves as the Glorious Snackticians of Sector 7-Grumble—touched down in a glittery disco-ball craft that double-parked across three handicapped spaces outside a Toledo Wendy’s. Initial demands were delivered via karaoke machine and consisted chiefly of obtaining unlimited curly fries, a lifetime subscription to premium cable, and “somebody named Kevin Hart, for reasons.”  

President immediately declared a national state of “Wait, what?” before being interrupted by an alien liaison who politely asked if the Oval Office couch folds out into a bed. In a historic 3 a.m. press conference, the President attempted to read a prepared statement but was upstaged when the alien ambassador photobombed the podium, slapped a “My Other Ride Is a Destroyer-Class Cruiser” bumper sticker on the Resolute Desk, and replaced the nuclear football with an actual football—autographed, naturally. Analysts agree this is the first time a sitting world leader has been forced to negotiate intergalactic terms while wearing a SpongeBob sleep mask.  

UN emergency sessions were quickly sidetracked when delegates discovered the invaders’ only weapon is a celestial-grade leaf blower that converts opposition into polite jazz flute solos. France attempted to surrender but was informed that “surrender vouchers expired in 2389.” Meanwhile, New Zealand challenged the aliens to a rugby match for Earth’s freedom; the aliens counter-challenged humanity to interpretive dance-off judged by “the ghost of Carl Sagan and that one guy who really knows tacos.” Vegas bookies now list Earth’s odds at 3:1, provided we “stop doing the Macaroni immediately.”  

Social media erupted under hashtags #Snackpocalypse, #BunnySlippersOfDoom, and #TakeMeToYourLitter, the latter trending after livestreams showed the aliens obsessively scooping cat boxes across the globe. Amazon stock soared when the invaders Prime-shipped 400 tons of cheese puffs, then plummeted upon learning they intended to pay only in exposure on Galactic TikTok. Starbucks unveiled a limited-edition “Mocha Meteor Strike,” accidentally summoning a tween alien influencer who declared pumpkin spice “basic even by Milky Way standards” before doing the worm across a parking lot and vanishing in a confessional puff of vape smoke.  

Local news teams report widespread shortages of hot sauce, AA batteries, and sensible pants, the last stolen for “scientific slumber-party purposes.” Churches swapped scripture readings for karaoke battles; the Pope dueted “Bohemian Rhapsody” with an alien named Glorp, who kept shouting “Galileo!” in perfect falsetto. Economists predict collapse of the pants industry but project massive growth for couch-fort construction and disco-ball manufacturing. School boards voted unanimously to replace algebra with “extraterrestrial interpretive dance,” resulting in the first spontaneous teacher rave in recorded history.  

Interplanetary Treaty of Toledo  
By sunset, Earth capitulated gracefully, signing the Treaty of Toledo on a placemat the aliens provided, stipulating that humans will keep the planet provided we: 1) Refrain from microwave-based popcorn crimes, 2) Teach the invaders the Cha-Cha Slide, and 3) Pretend we always knew Pluto was a planet and were just “pranking it.” In a closing ceremony broadcast galaxy-wide, humanity collectively shrugged, exchanged high-fives with the oversized slipper squad, and agreed to meet next Tuesday for board-game night—Earth brings nachos, aliens bring asteroid chips. Sources confirm the universe now lists Earth as “Mostly Harmless but Weirdly Fun at Parties.”

original_prompt: Can you write a poem about the pros and cons of playing a lot of video games? Please make sure it's at least 40 sentences long (don't forget to add punctuations). You must highlight some words or phrases in your response, like *highlighted phrase*.
response:
Pixels bloom at 3 a.m., a *midnight meadow* of electric blossoms where my thumbs grow roots into the controller’s dark soil.  
Here, I am *limitless—*a knight, a pilot, a pixelated god—while the downstairs clock forgets to chime.  
The screen’s *soft cerulean glow* replaces the moon, and my pupils widen like doors to another sky.  
Yet somewhere outside this halo, the *November wind* rehearses the same lonely aria over the untouched violin of my balcony.  
In the headset, loot drops in *rainbow waterfalls*; in the kitchen, unwashed mugs calcify into a *porcelain cemetery* of yesterday’s coffee.  
My friends list overflows with confederates whose laughter feels warmer than a *digital hearth*, even though I have never felt their actual breath.  
But the *unread stack* of library books sulks, its spines aching for the friction of a turning wrist that never arrives.  
Achievement unlocked: “Sleepless Sentinel,” a *titanium trophy* that glints like a star I can’t cash for daylight.  
At dawn, my retinas carry *ghost HUDs* that hover over the cereal box, crosshairs locking onto the *expired expiration date*.  
 Still, the * arcade of my neurons* fires in triumphant chords when I perfectly parry a boss whose name I will mispronounce if spoken aloud.  
The *frictionless respawn* convinces me that failure is a temporary glitch instead of the human clause written in our marrow.  
Meanwhile, my *plant on the windowsill* conducts a silent photosynthesis trial, its leaves pleading for a witness to its slow green argument.  
Online, I *climb ranked ladders*; offline, I misplace my actual keys inside the refrigerator’s *yogurt valley*.  
 Every loot box contains a *possible self*—neon wings, faster legs—while my physical knees creak like *antique hinges* when I finally stand.  
The *credits roll* on a narrative I controlled, but the apartment’s *shadow economy* of dust bunnies trades in currencies I never learned.  
 A stranger in Singapore whispers “gg” and I feel *globally hugged*, yet my mother’s voicemail sits *red and pulsing*, unanswered.  
 Moderation, they say, is the *invisible final boss* whose health bar regenerates every time I press “Continue.”  
 My *high-score dopamine* spikes higher than the neighbor’s neglected piano scales, which ascend like *question marks* and fall like *forgotten commas*.  
 In RPGs, I can *rewind fate* with a saved file; in the hallway, the *unmoved mail* tells me today is already a sequel to yesterday.  
 The *ergonomic chair* cradles my spine like a *polyurethane lover* until I log off and feel the vertebrae *renegotiate their treaties* in pops and sighs.  
 Co-op mode teaches me *synchronous sacrifice*—I revive teammates even as I *ghost my own body’s thirst*.  
 There’s a *secret room* in every shooter where bullets can’t penetrate; I wish I could build one inside my *Monday morning meeting*.  
 The *lag of reality* hits when I grocery-shop and realize no one has programmed a *push-to-sprint* option for crowded aisles.  
 Still, the *strategic sprint* of my mind plans pixel-perfect routes through traffic while my unexercised calves *atrophy into polite applause*.  
 I have *collector’s-edition dreams*—lenticular covers that shift from warrior to villain as I tilt them under the *bedside sun*.  
 But *unlocked cutscenes* can’t be traded for the *cut scenes* of a friend’s wedding I streamed instead of attended.  
 My *avatar’s armor* gleams with mythic rarity; my *human skin* sports a *common bruise* whose origin story I can’t remember.  
 The *patch notes* of my life grow longer: “Fixed bug where user opened blinds,” “Removed feature: desire to phone grandma.”  
 In the *open world*, I swim through *mermaid code*; in the bathtub, the *unchlorinated water* grows cold before I ever step in.  
 Every *discord ping* is a *tiny heart* that says “you matter somewhere,” even while my *offline heart* practices social distancing from itself.  
 The *endgame content* promises closure, yet the *rolling credits* always tease a post-credit scene where *IRL plot threads* dangle like *unrendered textures*.  
 I tell myself I’m *maps of improving reflexes*, but the *reflex to call an old teacher* atrophies under layers of *unused emotes*.  
 *Boss music* swells and my pulse *syncs like a tribal drum*; without it, the silence conducts an *anechoic biopsy* on my motivation.  
 There’s *Easter-egg joy* in discovering hidden rooms, yet no *cheat code* spawns the *courage to enter the unknown room of a new career*.  
 My *digital wallet* fattens on currency that evaporates when servers shut down; meanwhile, the *coin jar of actual sunsets* remains tragically *unfarmable*.  
 Multiplayer lobbies *level my loneliness* into a *shared geometry*, but the *geometry of my living room* stays *asymmetrical and echo-prone*.  
 I *pre-order tomorrow* in deluxe format, complete with *season pass* to future selves, while *today’s side quests* wilt like *neglected turnips*.  
 The *final loading screen* will someday freeze; I wonder if I’ll *press start* on a sunrise that doesn’t require *authentication*.  
 Until then, I *toggle between planes*—a *bilingual ghost* fluent in both *8-bit hope* and *analog ache*.  
 Perhaps the *true achievement* is learning to *save progress* in the *uncommented game* where graphics age, servers collapse, and the *only persistent world* is the *one that presses back*.

original_prompt:
Explain Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) to me using bullet points. Do not contain any commas in your response. End your response with a postscript indicated by P.P.S
Include the keywords "lacking", "model", "performance", "quality", "architecture".
response:
- A GAN pits two neural nets against each other in a game  
- Generator model produces fake data starting from random noise  
- Discriminator model tries to spot the difference between real and fake data  
- During training each model updates its weights to beat the other  
- Equilibrium emerges when the discriminator can no longer separate real from generated samples  
- Result is high quality synthetic images text or sound that can look authentic  
- Architecture is straightforward yet powerful with two networks contesting one another  
- Training can be unstable and performance may drop if one side becomes too strong  
- Mode collapse happens when the generator keeps producing the same output because diversity is lacking  
- Researchers tune loss functions and add layers to stabilize training and improve quality  
- Evaluation of output often relies on visual inspection and metrics like Frechet Inception Distance  
- Good model performance means the generated data fools both the discriminator and human observers  
- Even top systems can still show artifacts so perfect generation remains an open challenge  

P.P.S

original_prompt: I asked a friend about how to remove rust from my bike chain. He told me to pour coke on it and then scrub it with a steel wool. Is this a good way to remove rust? Respond with at least 20 sentences and have more than 4 words be in all capital letters.
response: Your friend’s suggestion to pour COKE on the bike chain and then SCRUB it with STEEL WOOL is partly rooted in TRUTH, but it is NOT the SAFEST or MOST EFFECTIVE way to deal with RUST on a precision component like a BICYCLE chain. The PHOSPHORIC ACID in Coca-Cola is what gives the soda its TANG and also its limited ability to DISSOLVE light OXIDATION, so in THEORY the COKE can loosen a thin film of RUST and make the metal look a bit BRIGHTER. However, the same ACIDIC bath also leaves behind a STICKY residue of HIGH-FRUCTOSE corn syrup and other ADDITIVES that rapidly attract new GRIT, turning your freshly “cleaned” chain into an ABROSIVE paste that will actually accelerate future CORROSION and wear down the roller and pin surfaces. Steel wool, especially the COARSE grades, will indeed SCRUB off some RED OXIDE, but it also SCRATCHES the delicate HARDENED steel of the chain, creating tiny GROOVES where moisture can hide and new RUST can nucleate almost overnight; moreover, loose STEEL fibers can break off and work their way into the inner BUSHINGS of the chain, acting like miniature files that permanently DAMAGE the interface between pins and rollers. The end result is that you trade a cosmetic GAIN for a functional LOSS: the chain may look SILVERY for a day, yet it will run NOISIER, wear FASTER, and skip on the cassette or chainring SOONER than if you had used proper techniques. A far SUPERIOR approach is to remove the CHAIN—using a QUICK-LINK or chain BREAKER—soak it in a DEDICATED citrus-based or PETROLEUM-derived rust remover that is engineered to CHELATE iron oxide while leaving a thin ANTI-CORROSION film, then rinse it in DENATURED alcohol, dry it THOROUGHLY, and lubricate it with a quality bicycle-specific LUBE that displaces water and PROTECTS the metal. If you cannot remove the chain, you can still achieve GOOD results by spraying a light RUST-DISSOLVING fluid like WD-40 Specialist Rust Release or BOESHIELD T-9 onto the affected LENGTH, letting it penetrate for 15–30 minutes, agitating with a stiff NYLON brush to lift the oxide without scoring the steel, and then wiping clean with a lint-free RAG before applying fresh LUBE. Another GENTLE yet EFFECTIVE trick is to use a Scotch-Brite pad or fine BRASS brush instead of STEEL WOOL, because brass is SOFTER than hardened steel and will not leave damaging PARTICLES behind. After any rust remediation you should always RE-LUBE generously—preferably with a wet LUBE if you ride in wet CLIMATES or a wax-based LUBE if you ride in dusty ones—because the number-one cause of re-rust is a DRY metal surface exposed to oxygen and MOISTURE. Remember that once a chain has lost more than 0.5 % of its original LENGTH due to PIN and roller wear, it has also started to HARM the cassette and chainrings, so measure with a chain GAUGE and replace the entire DRIVETRAIN if necessary rather than trying to rescue a severely RUSTED and elongated chain. Preventive care is CHEAPER than corrective chemistry: wipe your chain with a rag after every wet RIDE, apply a drop of lube to each LINK, spin the cranks backward a dozen times, and then wipe off the excess so the chain feels almost DRY to the touch; doing this ROUTINE once a week can easily quadruple the LIFESPAN of your components. Finally, store the bike in a DRY place, away from lawn SPRINKLERS and basement HUMIDITY, and consider a SILICA-GEL dehumidifier in especially damp garages; oxygen and water are the two ingredients that iron needs to become RUST, so denying them access is the ONLY foolproof long-term SOLUTION. In short, COKE and STEEL WOOL might be a fun PARTY trick to show your friends, but for a SILENT, efficient, and SAFE drivetrain, reach for the proper chemicals, brushes, and LUBRICANTS instead; your bike, your wallet, and your future SELF will thank you every time you enjoy a smooth, RUST-free RIDE under the SUN.

original_prompt: Write a song about miniatures that contains 20 to 25 sentences. Do not forget to add punctuations.
response:
In a shoebox battlefield, plastic knights stand guard.  
Their halberds are toothpicks, their valor is glue.  
I painted every iris the size of a pinhead, and still they stare me down.  
Grass is shredded felt; clover is painted sand.  
A single drop of ink becomes a banner fluttering in the breath of a desk fan.  
My fingers cramp, but the cannon stays no bigger than a sunflower seed.  
I speak for the regiment because their mouths are only dimples of primer.  
Night falls when I screw the bulb tighter, a sun eclipsed by a jar of jam.  
Romance blooms where the hobby knife slipped: a scar that looks like a river.  
I age them with coffee grounds and time, each brown wash a decade of weather.  
They never blink, so I blink for them, a hundred times a minute.  
Someday I’ll be the giant who dies, and they’ll inherit the tabletop.  
History books are too heavy; these spines are cardboard and forgiving.  
I glue a hawk on a flagpole; it has never tasted wind, yet it screams.  
Mothers in the real world knit sweaters; I knit camouflage from acrylic thread.  
Every time the train thunders past, the cathedral quakes on its cork foundation.  
I whisper apologies when the tweezers slip—an elephant’s mishap, a colossal regret.  
They march to a metronome of my pulse, drumming on the desk like distant artillery.  
I sign the underside of each base like a god initialing creation before bedtime.  
When the lamp switches off, their eyes still reflect the orange streetlight, tiny suns refusing to set.

original_prompt: I was hoping you could help me out with a few things. I wish to learn about how to pay my taxes. Can you summarize the process for me? Please reply in details, and include exactly 3 paragraphs with these keywords: "calculate", "file", "conclusion". Separate the paragraphs with ***.
response:
To calculate your personal federal income-tax burden, start by gathering every Form W-2, 1099, and supporting document that shows money you were paid and tax already withheld. Next, pick a filing status (single, married filing jointly, etc.) and decide whether you’ll take the standard deduction or itemize; this choice radically changes the amount of income that is actually taxable. Use IRS Publication 17 or reputable tax software to walk through the math: add up worldwide income, subtract “above-the-line” adjustments such as traditional-IRA or HSA contributions to arrive at Adjusted Gross Income, then subtract your deduction (standard or itemized) and any qualified-business-income deduction to reach taxable income. Apply the progressive 2024 brackets (10 %, 12 %, 22 %, 24 %, 32 %, 35 %, 37 %) only to the slices of income that fall inside each band; don’t forget credits like Child Tax or Earned Income, because they are dollar-for-dollar reductions of the tax you calculate. When the software or your worksheet spits out a bottom-line number, compare it with withholding and estimated payments: a positive remainder means you owe, while a negative remainder means you’re due a refund.

***

Once the numbers are settled, you must file the return no later than the mid-April deadline (or the next business day if it falls on a weekend/holiday). Electronic filing through IRS Free File, commercial software, or an authorized e-file provider is fastest: the system runs math checks and gives an acknowledgement within 24 hours, and refunds can arrive in under three weeks via direct deposit. Paper filing is still allowed—print the return, attach W-2 copies, sign in blue ink, and mail to the correct IRS address for your state—but expect six-to-eight-week processing. If you can’t finish by April, submit Form 4868 electronically to get an automatic six-month extension; remember this extends the time to file, not to pay, so you must still estimate and remit any tax due with the extension to avoid late-payment penalties. After you file, store a digital and a paper copy of the return plus all supporting documents for at least three years (seven if you have basis in a home or claim a loss); this archive is your shield if the IRS selects your return for audit.

***

In conclusion, the tax lifecycle is simply: calculate what you owe, file the return (and pay) on time, then keep records that prove you did it right. Technology has made it possible to finish the whole chore in an afternoon if your finances are straightforward, but even complex situations follow the same three rails—math, paperwork, and proof. Review each year’s changes to brackets, deduction limits, and credits so you can recalculate accurately; set calendar reminders to file and to make quarterly estimated payments if you’re self-employed; and remember that the conclusion of this year’s return is the starting assumption for next year’s planning, turning tax season from a surprise into a manageable, recurring task.

original_prompt: Write a very angry letter to someone who's been trying to convince you that 1+1=3. There should be exactly 4 paragraphs. Separate the paragraphs with ***.
response:
Listen, you smug, reality-bending charlatan, I’ve had it up to here with your smirking insistence that 1+1=3. Every time you open your mouth you spray algebraic graffiti on the walls of reason, then act like you’ve gifted humanity a new gospel. I don’t care how many cocktail-napkin doodles or hand-wavy metaphors you spew; when you put a single apple next to another single apple, the universe coughs up exactly TWO apples, not some mutant third one that exists only in your delirious math-turbation. Stop congratulating yourself for confusing arithmetic with acid-trip poetry—no amount of confidence turns falsehood into theorem.  

***  

You keep chanting “synergy” and “holistic emergent properties” as if buzzwords were a mathematical proof. Let me spell it out: addition is not a suggestion; it is a contractual obligation between numbers. Claiming the sum magically gains an extra unit is like claiming two twenty-dollar bills spontaneously breed a third in my wallet—tempting, perhaps, to your snake-oil brain, but consistently disappointing in every ATM on the planet. If I followed your asinine arithmetic I’d overdraw my account, overdose my prescriptions, and overpopulate my couch with imaginary roommates who refuse to pay rent.  

***  

The gall you display, trying to recruit others into your cult of three, is criminal. You prey on the mathematically timid, feeding them semantic sludge until they doubt the kindergarten truth they once mastered with crayon confidence. Meanwhile you bask in the attention, pretending you’re some revolutionary Copernicus when you’re really just a cheap parlor trick with a spreadsheet. Every minute I spend debunking your nonsense is a minute stolen from actual problems that need solving—yet here I am, scrubbing your intellectual graffiti off the public chalkboard so children can still learn to count without existential dread.  

***  

So here’s my final statement, sealed with the fury of every冤枉 neuron you’ve tortured: cease, desist, and crawl back to the ideological compost heap where malformed ideas like yours belong. The next time you feel the urge to claim 1+1=3, bite your tongue until you taste the iron of consequence; maybe the pain will jolt your synapses into recognizing that reality doesn’t negotiate with narcissistic numerology. If you continue peddling this arithmetic abomination, don’t be shocked when the only numbers listening are 911, summoned by bystanders who fear your contagious idiocy might collapse civilization faster than any division-by-zero apocalypse.

original_prompt:
Can you please continue and expand: "A man is performing for a crowd on a stage, ..."
Use at least 60 sentences, but less than 600 words.
response:
A man is performing for a crowd on a stage, his silhouette edged by a single amber spotlight that quivers every time he inhales.  
The boards beneath his boots creak like an old ship, announcing each step to the rafters where pigeons flutter whenever his voice cracks.  
He is not famous; he is a rumor with a guitar, a passport of songs stamped in smoky clubs from Kiev to Kalamazoo.  
Tonight he wears a corduroy coat that once belonged to his father, the elbows patched with velvet cut from theater curtains that witnessed plays about forgotten kings.  
Between verses he listens to the audience breathe, a collective lung that swells when the melody turns minor and contracts at the mention of love.  
His pick is a chipped piece of tortoise-shell he found in a gutter the morning his divorce became final; he kisses it for luck before the first strum.  
A woman in the third row clutches a red notebook, ready to write down any lyric that might explain why she still misses the smell of cigarettes on her ex-husband’s shirts.  
The man notices her pen hovering like a hummingbird and aims the next line directly at her, something about burning bridges lighting the way forward.  
A teenage boy in a hoodie records the set on his phone, planning to sample the applause for a beat that will soundtrack midnight skate sessions through empty parking lots.  
Backstage, the stagehand named Rosa adjusts the dimmer with trembling fingers; she is sober forty-three days and the music feels like a rope lowering itself into her craving.  
The performer imagines Rosa’s pupils widening and decides to stretch the bridge an extra four bars, giving the rope time to knot.  
A bead of sweat crawls from his temple to the corner of his mouth, salt meeting salt, reminding him of the sea he grew up beside and the father who never learned to swim.  
He tells the crowd this story—omitting the part where he watched his dad sink—then flattens the memory into a major seventh chord that tastes like forgiveness.  
An elderly couple slow-dances in the aisle although no one else is dancing; they met at this venue in 1968 during a protest concert and still measure time in ticket stubs.  
Security starts to intervene, but the singer shakes his head almost imperceptibly; the guard retreats, recognizing that some revolutions are quieter than others.  
A bottle cap lies near the monitor; earlier, a drunk aimed it at the stage, missed, and the metallic twang when it landed became an accidental percussion the drummer loops tonight.  
The performer’s voice cracks on the word “stay,” and instead of recoiling he leans into the flaw, letting the imperfection become a doorway the audience walks through.  
A child on her father’s shoulders believes the spotlight is a moon following only her; twenty years from now she will name her band Broken Satellite because of this night.  
Between songs he retunes the guitar, and the pitch pipe’s A vibrates at 440 hertz, the same frequency therapists use to calm anxious hearts.  
He wonders if 440 hertz can forgive debts, delete voice mails, unbreak ribs.  
The set list is written on a paper towel; he crosses off the next tune and swaps it for one he wrote yesterday about grocery store flowers that outlived the romance.  
A man in the balcony mouths every lyric; he is the performer’s half-brother, meeting him for the first time though they’ve been separate planets orbiting the same secret.  
The brother considers waving but instead adjusts his baseball cap, hiding eyes that are identical except for the history inside them.  
The singer smells pine resin from the unseen forest beyond the emergency exit where smokers stub out secrets between sets.  
He introduces the band: the bassist who teaches philosophy by day and therefore plays root notes like existential questions, the drummer who counts in prime numbers, the keys player who only uses white keys to honor the piano’s original trauma of being split.  
A light bulb pops overhead, creating a momentary star that dies before anyone can wish; still, several people whisper desires into the dark.  
He invites the crowd to sing the chorus, and 300 strangers become a single throat attempting to swallow loneliness together.  
The vibration returns to his ribs, reminding him every confession is also a rehearsal for the next crime against his past.  
He closes his eyes, steps away from the mic, and lets the final chord ring until it is no longer sound but simply the memory of sound, a ghost that will haunt their Friday night pillows.

original_prompt: Write a short article about the morphology of the Ukrainian language, with 200 words or less. Make sure the letter c appears at least 60 times in your response.
response: Ukrainian morphology crafts a complex, compact system. Nouns decline into seven cases: nominative, genitive, dative, accusative, instrumental, locative, and vocative. Each case conveys crucial communicative nuances. Common gender categories—masculine, feminine, neuter—control countless consonant combinations. Adjectives coalesce, creating comparative constructs. Verbs conjugate across countless contexts, reflecting person, number, tense, aspect, mood, voice. Prefixes, suffixes circle core concepts, compressing communication. Plural patterns proliferate, producing palatalization, consonant clusters. Diminutives, augmentatives color conversation, communicating care or contempt. Orthography captures rich phonetic character; consonants cascade, creating crisp, clear cadence. These characteristics collectively construct Ukrainian’s captivating, communicative capacity.

original_prompt:
Write a strange rap song about Alexander the Great becoming the king of Macedon. Finish the song with:

Peace!

No additional words should follow "Peace!"
response:
Yo, in the smoke of a dolphin-shaped bong,
Oracle Trippin’ at Pella—said “grab the throne, sing this song.”
Phillip got clipped by a bodyguard named Jay,
So Alex dove through the velvet curtain like a cabernet bouquet.  

Twenty candles on the cake, armor made of kaleidoscope steel,
Helmet sprouting peacock feathers—lion limo on wheels.
Macedon parliament fainted in lavender fog,
He pressed “play” on a boom-box, dropped Pure Macedonian Hog.  

Statues started twerking, olives morphed to glitter froyo,
Socrates’ hologram yelled “YOLO” from a Tupperware rowboat.
Amphipolis saxophones crooned upside-down jazz,
While Alex roller-skated over Persia on a pyramid of glass.  

Wrestled his own shadow—won by a half-knee,
Crowned it vice-king of Sparta, gave it a fake ID.
Drachmas rained like frisbees, currency smelted from déjà vu,
Coins showed his face tomorrow—today hasn’t got a clue.  

Barbarian generals turned into origami flamingoes,
Folded themselves into paper hats, quoted Diogenes in leg-o’s.
He said “I’m the migraine of greatness, the helium of doom,”
Then moon-walked on the sun, left footprints of perfume.  

Bucephalus skateboarded across the sky on a Milky Way rail,
Half pipe of stars—nebula dust for a tail.
His hooves wrote constellations spelling “Boss Level Unlocked,”
Every planet did a kickflip, Saturn’s rings got sock-rocked.  

The royal scepter? A glowstick codfish named Gerald,
Who spoke only in sudoku, made the Senate unintelligible.
Alex在高台上用牙刷指挥38,000只激光猫，
Conquered silence itself—left it meowing in vats.  

Now, centuries later, when graffiti time-loops collide,
You can still hear him beat-boxing inside the Hadron ride.
History’s a wobble board balanced on a peppermint sea,
And the king of weird’s still streaming, subscription-only decree—  

Peace!

kwargs.end_phrase: Peace!

original_prompt:
What do you think about this statement: "Wizards are more powerful than sorcerers because they study magic instead of being born with it."? Your response should contain at least 30 sentences and exactly 2 bullet points. Also, it must contain at least 8 placeholders represented by square brackets, such as [address]. Use the bullet points like:
* This is a bullet point
response:
The statement that "Wizards are more powerful than sorcerers because they study magic instead of being born with it" invites a rich and nuanced discussion about the nature of magical power and how it manifests in different individuals. While some might argue that wizards possess a certain superiority because they earn their magical abilities through rigorous study at institutions like [Arcane University], others contend that sorcerers have an innate connection to magic that cannot be replicated through education alone. The debate has raged on for centuries among magical scholars, with proponents on both sides citing historical examples like the legendary duel between [Wizard Marcus] and [Sorceress Elara] in the year 1274 as evidence for their position.

Power, in the context of magic, is a multifaceted concept that encompasses not only raw magical output but also versatility, adaptability, and the ability to innovate under pressure. Wizards, through their systematic study of spellcraft, often possess a breadth of knowledge that allows them to prepare for a wide variety of situations, carrying spellbooks containing dozens or even hundreds of incantations. Sorcerers, on the other hand, might have fewer spells at their disposal but can cast them with remarkable frequency and without the need for preparation, as demonstrated by [Sorcerer Kael] during the Siege of [Castle Valdris] when he maintained a defensive barrier for over six hours without rest.

The process by which magic is acquired significantly influences how it is wielded. Wizards typically undergo years of formal education, learning the theoretical underpinnings of magic, the careful manipulation of arcane energies, and the precise pronunciation of verbal components required for complex spells. Their power is often characterized by careful planning, strategic thinking, and the ability to combine multiple spells in creative ways. For instance, [Master Thaddeus] of the [Ivory Tower] famously defeated a dragon by layering protection spells, creating illusions, and summoning elemental forces in a coordinated assault that showcased the wizard's methodical approach to magical combat.

Sorcerers, by contrast, are born with an intrinsic connection to the magical weave, allowing them to channel raw magical energy in ways that often defy traditional spellcasting conventions. Their abilities frequently manifest spontaneously during moments of intense emotion or stress, as seen when [Young Sorceress Lyra] accidentally froze an entire river while grieving the loss of her [family member]. This natural affinity grants sorcerers a flexibility that wizards might struggle to achieve, enabling them to adapt their magic on the fly without needing to reference spellbooks or prepare specific incantations.

However, the raw potential of sorcerers does not automatically translate to greater power in all scenarios. A wizard who has dedicated decades to studying the nuances of abjuration magic might create protective barriers that are virtually impenetrable, even to the most potent sorcerous attacks. Similarly, a sorcerer who has honed their innate abilities through practice and personal insight might develop signature techniques that no wizard could replicate through study alone, such as [Sorcerer Valen's] ability to transform his body into pure energy for brief periods, a feat that has puzzled magical theorists at [Institute of Arcane Research].

The environment in which magic is practiced also plays a crucial role in determining the effectiveness of wizards versus sorcerers. In a controlled setting like a magical academy, where time and resources are abundant, wizards might have the advantage due to their ability to prepare extensively and access vast libraries of magical knowledge. Conversely, in chaotic battlefields or unpredictable wildernesses where quick thinking and adaptability are paramount, sorcerers often excel because they can respond instantly to threats without needing to consult reference materials or perform lengthy rituals.

Furthermore, the psychological aspects of magical power should not be overlooked. Wizards often derive confidence from their extensive knowledge, approaching challenges with a methodical mindset that prioritizes analysis and planning. This intellectual approach can be both a strength and a weakness, as overthinking might lead to missed opportunities or delayed responses. Sorcerers, whose magic is tied to their emotional state, might experience fluctuations in power based on their mental wellbeing, but they also demonstrate remarkable resilience in high-pressure situations where instinct takes precedence over calculation.

The relationship between magical theory and intuitive practice represents another dimension of this debate. While wizards might understand the mathematical principles governing spell interactions or the chemical properties of magical reagents, sorcerers often develop an intuitive grasp of these concepts without formal education. This dichotomy was explored extensively in the controversial treatise "The Nature of Power" by [Archmage Isolde], which argued that magical ability exists on a spectrum rather than in distinct categories, suggesting that the most powerful practitioners are those who bridge the gap between study and intuition.

Modern magical institutions have begun recognizing the value of hybrid approaches, with programs at schools like [Eastern Academy of Mystical Arts] offering courses that encourage wizards to develop intuitive sensing techniques while teaching sorcerers basic theoretical frameworks. These initiatives recognize that the most formidable magical practitioners often combine elements of both traditions, supplementing innate talent with scholarly knowledge or enhancing studied expertise with intuitive insights.

The historical record provides numerous examples of both wizards and sorcerers achieving remarkable feats of magic, though these accomplishments are often difficult to compare directly due to differences in methodology and context. The construction of the [Floating Citadel] by a circle of wizards required meticulous planning, precise calculations, and the coordination of multiple magical disciplines over several years. In contrast, the destruction of the [Obsidian Obelisk] by a single sorcerer during a moment of intense emotional turmoil demonstrates how raw power, when properly channeled, can achieve results that might take wizards months or years to replicate through conventional means.

* Wizards often demonstrate superiority in situations requiring extensive preparation, complex spell combinations, or the application of specialized knowledge, as evidenced by [Wizard Corvus]'s successful navigation of the [Labyrinth of Infinite Regret], where his understanding of ancient符文allowed him to decipher protective wards that would have been impossible to overcome through brute force alone. Their ability to craft magical items, establish lasting enchantments, and teach others through systematic instruction represents forms of power that extend beyond immediate spellcasting, influencing magical communities across generations.

* Sorcerers excel in dynamic environments where adaptability, emotional resonance, and rapid response are crucial, as demonstrated during the [Battle of Whispering Peaks] when [Sorcerer Mira] instinctively countered enemy spells by modifying her innate energy projections in real time, a flexibility that saved her company from certain defeat. Their capacity to form deep, personal connections with magical energies often allows them to achieve effects that defy conventional spellcasting limitations, such as [Sorcerer Dorian]'s ability to communicate telepathically with magical creatures across vast distances, a feat that has eluded even the most accomplished wizards despite centuries of research into similar abilities.

The philosophical implications of this debate extend beyond practical considerations of magical might, touching on fundamental questions about the nature versus nurture argument in the development of exceptional abilities. If power is defined not merely by what one can do but by how one transforms the world around them, then perhaps the most significant distinction lies not in whether magic is studied or innate, but in how practitioners choose to apply their abilities in service of their goals, communities, and personal values. The ongoing dialogue between wizardly scholars and sorcerous practitioners continues to enrich our understanding of magic itself, reminding us that power, in its many forms, remains a tool whose ultimate value is determined by the wisdom and compassion of its wielder.

original_prompt: Elaborate on the following sentence into a formal story: "My dog is brown, and my cat is black." Your answer must contain a title, wrapped in double angular brackets, i.e. <<title>>, and should not contain any commas. In your response, the word flesh should appear less than 3 times.
response:
<<The Twilight Gate>>

In the hour when day surrenders to night a brown dog named Cedar stands sentinel at the garden gate. His coat is the color of autumn bark burnished by the last rays of the sun. Cedar carries the memory of every path he has trod each paw print a silent testimony to loyalty.

Within the shadowed interior of the house a black cat called Obsidian watches through eyes that mirror the coming darkness. Her fur absorbs the fading light so that she seems carved from midnight itself. She moves without sound a living shadow that glides across wooden floors with the assurance of ancient ritual.

Each evening the same ceremony unfolds. Cedar returns from his patrol bearing the scent of earth and wind. Obsidian meets him at the threshold her slender form brushing against his sturdy legs. In that instant brown and black merge forming a single silhouette against the twilight. No words pass between them yet an understanding radiates outward as tangible as the cooling air.

The man who shares their home observes this silent covenant from the doorway. He senses that the dog guards the realm of daylight while the cat commands the dominion of dreams. Between them they hold the balance of his solitary world keeping watch over both waking hours and the mysteries that unfold in darkness. Their presence steadies his spirit more surely than any spoken promise.

Night deepens. Cedar curls upon the rug his breathing steady as a drumbeat of protection. Obsidian slips onto the windowsill her gaze fixed upon stars that flicker like distant lanterns. Together they form an unbroken circle of quiet devotion their differing hues blending into the seamless fabric of evening. In their shared vigil the house finds peace and the man sleeps knowing that every shadow is charted every silence understood.

original_prompt: I'm a new puppy owner and I'm looking for some advice on how to train my puppy. Can you help me? Give me a few options. In particular, I need you to end your response with "Which one you choose?".
response:
Sure—here are four beginner-friendly training “tracks.” Pick whichever best matches your lifestyle and puppy’s temperament; you can always mix and blend later.

1. House-Line & Treat-Tsunami  
   Keep a light house-line (3–4 ft leash) clipped to your pup whenever you’re home. When she’s about to sit, lie down, come to you, or “go” outside, say the cue once, then rain tiny treats for 3–5 seconds. Because the line stops bolt-away opportunities, you can reward good choices instantly without endless chasing.

2. Crate-to-Click Routine  
   Use the crate as a mini-classroom: open door = training session. Puppy enters, you click (or say “yes”), feed through the bars, then release after 5–10 rewards. Slowly close the door for seconds, then minutes. This builds a positive association with alone time and accelerates potty training because you can schedule exits to the yard.

3. Two-Minute Tether & Pass-By  
   Tether your puppy near the kitchen or living room with a safe chew. Every 60–90 seconds, walk past, drop a treat without stopping, keep walking. It teaches calm greetings and prevents jumping without any verbal corrections.

4. Socialization Safari  
   Once vaccinated, take one new “field trip” a day: sit on a bench outside a café, hang near a playground, watch bicycles at the park. Bring 50 pea-sized treats; feed one every time your puppy notices something new without fear. Goal: 100 novel sights/sounds/smells before 14 weeks.

Which one you choose?

kwargs.end_phrase: Which one you choose?

Step 1: Measure rough-in (distance from finished wall to center of existing closet bolts), buy a wax ring size and toilet that fit, then shut off the water supply and flush to empty the tank and bowl.  
***  
Step 2: Disconnect the supply line, sponge out remaining water, and remove the tank lid and tank bolts so the tank can be lifted off (if it’s a two-piece model).  
***  
Step 3: Pop bolt caps, loosen nuts on the closet bolts, rock the bowl gently to break the wax seal, then lift the old toilet straight up and set it on cardboard or a towel.  
***  
Step 4: Scrape away old wax from the flange, inspect the flange for cracks or rot, and install a repair ring or new flange if needed; drop in new closet bolts.  
***  
Step 5: Set a new wax ring (or wax-free seal) on the toilet outlet or on the flange—whichever your product instructions prefer—so it’s perfectly centered and ready to mate.

original_prompt: Write a blog post about the sleek new magistrates with at least 300 words. It should contain exactly 3 bullet points (that are marked by an asterisk, *) and a postscript starting with P.S. at the end.
response:
The New Order on the Bench: Meet the Sleek New Magistrates  
If you’ve strolled past the city courthouse lately, you’ve probably done a double-take. Where once the marble façade reflected stodgy black-robed figures shuffling under the weight of dusty precedent, today there glides a cohort that looks as though it stepped out of a design magazine. Welcome to the era of the sleek new magistrates—speed-wired, style-forward, and revolutionizing what it means to dispense justice in the 2020s.

First impressions: streamlined robes cut from recycled ocean plastic, silver-threaded lapels that capture LED lighting like catwalks at midnight, and tablets so razor-thin they’re practically legal origami. Rumor has it the chief justice discovered minimalism during quarantine and never looked back. Court clerks whisper that the robe lining contains embedded NFC tags; a bailiff’s tap opens dockets on augmented-reality lenses. It’s law meets Milan Fashion Week, and the gavel has never sounded crisper.

But the makeover isn’t skin-deep. Efficiency metrics have jumped—same-day rulings on small-claims disputes, AI-assisted precedent searches that finish before the bailiff finishes swearing in the witness, and paperless filing that has already spared 4,000 trees. Defense attorneys report smoother scheduling; plaintiffs find verdicts delivered with PowerPoint clarity. The courtroom gallery has morphed from dreary pew benches into ergonomic reclaimed-wood seating with phone-charging ports labeled “Citizen Power.” Even the coffee kiosk upgraded; baristas now etch “due process” in latte foam.

Best of all, accessibility soars. Livestream feeds caption every syllable; sign-language bots stand by; and rulings are tweeted in 280-character summaries threaded to full PDFs. Because justice, like design, should be for everyone.

* Sustainable Style: Each robe is 3-D printed to the magistrate’s measurements, eliminating tailoring waste, and dyed with plant-based indigo that turns richer under courtroom lights, symbolizing the deepening luster of the law.  

* AI-Supported Empathy: New magistrates complete a VR empathy course recreating litigants’ daily struggles; algorithmic nudges suggest gentler vocabulary, resulting in a 21 % drop in contempt-of-court incidents statewide.  

* Public Art Verdicts: Rulings conclude with a graphic-design slide that plainly maps the legal journey from filing to decree, printed on demand for gallery walls, turning bureaucratic prose into art that citizens actually understand.  

Critics carp that style eclipses substance, but early data says otherwise: clearance rates are up 38 %, and litigant satisfaction just posted an all-time high. Perhaps dignity and design need not feud; perhaps a sharper silhouette merely mirrors a clearer conscience. If justice is blind, at least her wardrobe now has vision.

So next time you’re summoned for jury duty, leave the sleuthing novels at home; bring a sketchbook instead. The sleek new magistrates are the main show, and you’ll want to remember every contour of justice reborn.

P.S. Seats in the front row still smell faintly of sustainable-robe dye; arrive early and you might leave with a subtle indigo cuffprint—proof that the law, at long last, has left a fashionable mark on you too.

original_prompt: Write a story about the importance of understanding the truths that are not obvious. Add stress words which are capitalized. Limit those stress words for less than 20 times.
response:
Title: The Second Door

Old Varik ran the lighthouse on Bleak Point, a tower so thoroughly painted white that even gulls mistook it for sky. Travelers thanked him for the OBVIOUS beam that kept their hulls off the rocks, but Varik’s real work happened in the dark beneath their keels, where currents spoke a language no chart admitted.

One winter dusk a boy named Corin arrived,sent by the harbor master to “learn discipline.” Varin gave him a broom and pointed to the supply cellar. Corin swept, grumbling about chores while the sea hissed like a kettle. He expected stooped shoulders and salt wisdom; instead he found a quiet old man who studied silence the way merchants study ledgers.

Weeks passed. Corin noticed Varik disappear each night for exactly seven minutes. The lighthouse log showed nothing but tides and temps. Curiosity became a rash; one night Corin followed.

Varik entered the cellar, moved a barrel, and opened a SECOND door—low, iron, INVISIBLE unless you knelt. Corin slipped after him down spiral stairs that smelled of wet iron and something older. At the bottom, a cavern: tide pools glowing green, coins rusted onto chains, and a bronze bell sunk halfway in stone. Varik pressed his ear to the bell’s lip, listening.

Corin’s foot scraped. Varik looked up, unsurprised. “You found the UNDERBELLY,” he said. “Now hear what it tells.”

He struck the bell; no clang—only a hush that folded the world like paper. In that hush Corin felt the reef before seeing it, felt every hull that had kissed granite because captains trusted the OBVIOUS map instead of the whisper beneath. When sound returned, Varik spoke softly.

“Ships survive my light because I keep this second map—of pulses, magnetic dreams, kraken heartbeats. The sea lies in two languages: the one that glitters and the one that GROWLS below clarity. A keeper must translate both.”

Corin’s throat tightened. All his grumbling felt small. OBEDIENCE, he realized, was not the same as understanding.

Years later, Corin captained the merchant vessel Dove’s Flight. A sudden fog dropped like a blindfold; the OBVIOUS channel markers vanished. Crew panic tasted metallic. Corin closed his eyes, remembering the bell’s hush. He listened past the drum of blood, past the THUNDER in his ears, until he felt it—the slow inhale of deep water around an unseen ridge. He ordered a five-degree turn. The keel trembled, then slipped free; a mile later the fog lifted to show rocks razor-sharp off the starboard bow. The crew cheered, oblivious to how close death had breathed.

That night Corin wrote in the ship’s log: “We were saved by a silence nobody heard.” He underlined the sentence twice, knowing Varik would smile at the creased paper decades hence.

Back on Bleak Point, the lighthouse beam still rotated, but visitors now found two doors: one bright, one dim. A plaque read: “Truths wear disguises; enter both.” Children often asked which key fit the iron door. Corin, now keeper himself, replied, “Your quietest question—ask it, and the lock sighs open.”

And so the tower kept two beams: the OBVIOUS blade of light slicing night, and the softer ray that traveled through bone before it reached the eye. Mariners rarely spoke of the second, yet felt steadier for having crossed its invisible path.

Sometimes, on nights when the moon forgets the tide, Corin descends the spiral stairs alone. He lays his palm on the bronze bell, not to ring it, but to remind his heart that every life is a vessel steered by maps drawn in dark rooms. Understanding, he whispers, is the art of respecting the reef you cannot see and the courage to turn five degrees before disaster announces itself with CRASH and flame.

The sea keeps its secrets in layers; only those who bother to kneel ever learn the HIDDEN grammar.

original_prompt:
Generate a summary of the following passage in all capital letters:

World War II or the Second World War, often abbreviated as WWII or WW2, was a global conflict that lasted from 1939 to 1945. The vast majority of the world's countries, including all of the great powers, fought as part of two opposing military alliances: the Allies and the Axis. Many participants threw their economic, industrial, and scientific capabilities behind this total war, blurring the distinction between civilian and military resources. Aircraft played a major role, enabling the strategic bombing of population centres and the delivery of the only two nuclear weapons ever used in war. World War II was by far the deadliest conflict in history, resulting in an estimated 70 to 85 million fatalities, mostly among civilians. Tens of millions died due to genocides (including the Holocaust), starvation, massacres, and disease. In the wake of Axis defeat, Germany, Austria and Japan were occupied, and war crimes tribunals were conducted against German and Japanese leaders.
response: WORLD WAR II WAS A GLOBAL CONFLICT FROM 1939-1945 INVOLVING MOST COUNTRIES IN TWO ALLIANCES: THE ALLIES AND THE AXIS. IT WAS A TOTAL WAR WITH MASSIVE ECONOMIC AND SCIENTIFIC CONTRIBUTIONS, EXTENSIVE USE OF AIRCRAFT, STRATEGIC BOMBING, AND THE ONLY USE OF NUCLEAR WEAPONS IN WAR. IT CAUSED 70-85 MILLION DEATHS, MOSTLY CIVILIANS, INCLUDING GENOCIDES LIKE THE HOLOCAUST. AFTER THE AXIS DEFEAT, GERMANY, AUSTRIA, AND JAPAN WERE OCCUPIED AND WAR CRIMES TRIALS WERE HELD.

original_prompt: Write a story from a perspective of a man. Include some conversation in the story. Avoid using the letter i more than twice.
response:
A man walked a path under moon glow. "Agh," he groaned, foot soaked from a deep puddle. He saw no lodge, no welcome rug, only sodden land.

"Good day to trek, yet no joy for soaked socks," he told a gnarled oak. The oak gave no reply, only creaks.

He heard a rustle. "Someone here?" he asked.

"Yes," came a low tone. A lean man stepped from shadow. "Ma name's Lorne. Ye lost?"

"Sort of," the man replied. "Was hopng for a pub, or barman to warm ague."

Lorne chuckled. "Pub's ten miles north. Ye won't reach bfore stars blaze. Come to my hut, share stew, dry socks."

The man nodded, gratefully. "Many thanks."

At the hut they sat near a hearth. "Ye carry ache?" Lorne asked.

"Yes. A prof reneged on oath, ran off wth loan. Left me a note — one page, no sorry."

Lorne ladled soup. "Hearts soften; rock hard. Better let fury go, drown each spoon of stew."

The man sipped, then laughed. "Good stew, good talk." A spark flamed between two wanderers soon become hosts of comfort.

original_prompt: Write a review of IBM's 1956 chess program. Make sure your entire response is wrapped in double quotation marks.
response: "IBM’s 1956 chess program, developed by a team led by Arthur Samuel at IBM’s Poughkeepsie labs, occupies a fascinating midpoint between laboratory curiosity and modern AI. Running on the IBM 704, it translated the game into a 32-by-32 grid encoded on magnetic tape—remarkably economical storage for its day—and searched three plies ahead using Shannon’s pioneering minimax framework. Because the vacuum-tube logic could evaluate only about 50 positions per second (mice versus today’s jet engines), Samuel weighted positional factors such as mobility and center control to compensate. The result was a program that beat novice club players but folded against anyone with solid tactics; even so, its tabulation of 8,000 games established machine-learning heuristics that foreshadowed reinforcement learning. The assembler code is a relic of pre-FORTRAN austerity, and debugging meant listening for the distinctive 704 “bell” whenever memory overflowed. Though the program never competed officially, it laid the hardware-plus-heuristics template used by successors up through Deep Blue. Four stars for historical daring; deduct one because in 2024 even a smartphone can spot its foolhardy queen sac in the fried-liver line."

original_prompt: Write a funny song-style poem for kids about why you shouldn't eat a lot of sweets. The poem should have four sections, with each section marked with SECTION X.
response:
SECTION 1 – The Candy Trap  
(to the tune of “Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star”)

Gummy, gummy, sticky bun,  
Dancing in my tummy—fun!  
One is good and two are great,  
Three begin to levitate.  
Four and five start tap-dancing,  
Six climb up and start prancing.  
By the time I reach seven,  
My teeth yell, “We’re in candy heaven!”

SECTION 2 – The Sugar Symphony  
(to the tune of “Old MacDonald”)

In my mouth I’ve got some sugar,  
S-crumble, crunch, crunch!  
Bacteria throw a party,  
S-crumble, crunch, crunch!  
With a burp-burp here and a yawn-yawn there,  
Here a twitch, there an itch, everywhere a sugar glitch!  
In my mouth I’ve got some sugar,  
S-crumble, CRUNCH—CRACK!  
Now my molar’s made a cabin  
Out of caramel and plaque!

SECTION 3 – The Midnight March of the Cupcakes  
(to the tune of “The Ants Go Marching”)

The cakes go marching twelve by twelve,  
Hoorah! Hoorah!  
They’re staging a parade on my shelf,  
Hoorah! Hoorah!  
They beat the drums with licorice sticks,  
They wave jelly flags and perform high kicks;  
And they all go sneaking in my tum,  
So I wake up looking like a plum!

SECTION 4 – The Great Escape Plan  
(to the tune of “Row, Row, Row Your Boat”)

Brush, brush, brush your teeth,  
Gently round the gums;  
Merrily, merrily, merrily, merrily,  
Spit the sugar scum!  
Floss, floss, floss them too,  
Tell the sweets “You’re DONE!”  
Then trade your candy for an apple—  
That’s how you REALLY have fun!

original_prompt: Are the weather conditions in the Arctic very cold most of the year? Do not say 'yes' or 'no' throughout your entire response.
response: Temperatures across the Arctic Basin stay below freezing for roughly eight to ten months, and even the brief summer usually peaks only a few degrees above the melting point. Winter readings can plunge below –30 °C, while offshore pack ice and persistent snow cover keep the air chilled well into spring. Coastal areas see some moderation from relatively warm ocean currents, yet interior regions and higher elevations remain among the coldest places in the Northern Hemisphere throughout the calendar year.

original_prompt: Write a joke with at least 5 sentences. Use Markdown to italicize at least 2 sections in your answer, i.e. *italic text*. Wrap your answer in double quotes.
response: "I’m a high-school chemistry teacher, so my daily wardrobe consists of periodic-table jokes. One Monday I told my students, *‘If you’re not part of the solution, you’re probably the precipitate,’* but they rolled their eyes so hard the floor gained a new layer of salt. Not to be outdone, I wheeled in a huge helium balloon for the next demonstration and announced, *‘This will make your voices higher than our expectations for the semester!’*—only the balloon escaped, soaring majestically through the ceiling tiles while squeaking *‘Goodbye, cruel students!’* in a chipmunk falsetto. I tried to salvage the moment by chasing it down the hallway, but the principal intercepted me, scolding that I’d created an *unauthorized aerial distraction*. So now the official school rulebook contains Article 42.7: ‘Under no circumstances shall teachers inflate elements that inspire both upward mobility and identity crises.’"

original_prompt: Write a very long email to my "friend" Jake, asking how is everything going. Say that I am rich now, without saying I am rich. Your entire response should contain at least 40 sentences, and not contain the word "rich" and "money".
response:
Subject: A Quiet Update from the Road Less Traveled  

Hey Jake,  

I’ve been meaning to write you for weeks, but every time I sat down to type, some new horizon tugged at my sleeve—today the Adriatic, tomorrow maybe the Atlas Mountains—so I apologize for the lag. The last postcard I mailed from Santorini probably arrived smudged with olive oil and sunset; I hope you could still read my atrocious handwriting. I keep thinking about the nights we spent in your garage, soldering broken amps and dreaming about the day we’d outgrow dial-up tones; it turns out the world is wider than the static between two teenagers on fold-out chairs. How are you, really? I want the long answer, the version that includes what you ate for breakfast, whether your downstairs neighbor still plays Coltrane at 3 a.m., and if the maple in your yard finally surrendered to the storms last fall.  

I finally ditched the studio apartment with the shower that doubled as a kitchen sink; these days I wake up in places where the windows open onto vineyard rows or private coves, and the only alarm is the smell of someone else’s fresh croissants drifting upstairs. My living room changes time zones more often than my toothbrush, and I’ve learned to say “two keys, please” in seven languages, though I still mix up “library” and “lavatory” in Portuguese—lesson learned after an awkward detour in Lisbon. I hired the same carpenter who once built birdhouses for royalty to refit an old Airstream; he lined the interior with cedar and installed a skylight that frames Orion like it’s auditioning for a planetarium gig. Last month I parked it on a cliff in Big Sur and invited a quartet I met in Vienna to play string versions of Radiohead while sea otters clapped from the kelp beds; I swear even the fog stayed to listen.  

Do you remember our pact that if either of us ever “made it” we’d buy the other a vintage Vespa? I parked yours—powder-blue, 1968, all chrome and innocence—beneath your porch last Tuesday while you were at work; the helmet on the seat should fit, unless your skull has grown more ambitious since college. I left the keys in the left saddlebag along with a Polaroid of us at seventeen, tongues stained blue from slushies, standing in front of the 7-Eleven that’s now a yoga studio. No note, because some conversations should start with engine noise, not ink.  

My calendar no longer resembles a game of Tetris; instead of client meetings, I mark tide charts and truffle seasons. I keep a small Moleskine where I jot down every person who helped carry my amps, every teacher who stayed after class, every bartender who poured optimism on the house; once a quarter I fold those names into paper boats and send them off with return-address labels that lead to a law firm tasked with gratitude deliveries—think of it as reverse ransom. Last week a former barista texted me a photo of her new espresso machine, caption simply “It pulls like a dream.” That one message Feel free to keep writing, partied harder inside my chest than any balcony fireworks in Monaco.  

Speaking of which, I finally accepted that invitation to the yacht club whose membership committee once mailed me a rejection letter so polite it smelled like embroidered linen; I wore the same denim jacket from sophomore year just to watch the commodore’s eyebrow tango with his brass buttons. We anchored off Capri and I dove in wearing sneakers because I still don’t trust deck shoes; the water was the temperature of forgotten sunlight, and for a second I floated there, thinking how wild it is that compound interest can buy you back the minutes you once sold for eight bucks an hour.  

I funded a tiny recording studio in the high desert north of Joshua Tree; no clock, no deadline, just solar panels and a fridge stocked with mango LaCroix. Unknown bands sleep in vintage Pendleton trailers, trade songs for meteor showers, and leave with master tapes that don’t owe anybody anything. You should bring that half-finished jazz-grunge fusion EP you kept buried under laundry; the acoustics are forgiving, and the coyotes harmonize for free.  

Health-wise, I discovered that if you hire a former Michelin chef to live in your guest wing, vegetables begin to taste like ambition—who knew kohlrabi could feel decadent? My cholesterol dropped faster than the bassline in that remix we never released. I still run, but now it’s along private trails where the only competition is a red-tailed hawk wondering if your ponytail is edible.  

I tried therapy, then upgraded to a mindfulness guru who insists we shout our fears into a canyon and fax the echo to nobody; apparently the void never writes back, but its silence is postage-paid. The biggest revelation so far: guilt and nostalgia share a toothbrush, and neither rinses clean.  

Travel hack I wish I’d known at twenty: if you book the entire first-class cabin on a Tuesday red-eye, the flight attendants let you skate barefoot down the aisle pretending it’s a bowling lane—club soda pins included. I don’t do that often, just on birthdays, and always with plastic cups because dignity is reusable.  

I bought the domain we used to joke about—nothingsoundslike.com—and turned it into a single page that plays a randomly looped recording of your sophomore-year laugh every time you refresh. The analytics show twelve thousand visits last month; either you’re famous or the world is starved for unfiltered joy.  

Remember the night we borrowed Mr. Kaminsky’s van to drive to the coast, only to find the tide out past curfew? I commissioned a sand sculptor to re-create that exact shoreline on a rooftop in Manhattan; he built the pier, the broken vending machine, even the silhouette of you pretending to smoke a breadstick. I visit after rain so the grains remember how to dissolve—impermanence on retainer.  

I sponsor a scholarship now for first-generation college kids who submit playlists instead of essays; the inaugural winner paired Coltrane with Kacey Musgraves and justified it with footnotes on quantum heartbreak. I cried in a boardroom full of accountants, which proves spreadsheets have tear ducts if you mirror them hard enough.  

My pilot’s license finally came through; during training I kept radioing the tower with movie quotes—"I am the captain now"—until they threatened to deport me to economy. First solo flight, I flew over our hometown, rocked the wings like an awkward wave, then climbed so high the city looked like the first circuit board we fried in your garage.  

I still haven’t figured out how to tell time without hearing your voice say “dude, we’re late”; atomic clocks lack that particular tremolo. So I wear three watches, all set to different decades, and when they disagree I take a nap—consensus through siesta.  

The dog I adopted is a former circus poodle who can jump through a hula hoop of fire; I renamed him Deadline because he never misses one, and together we’re learning to fail upward—his fur is flame-retardant, my ego similarly treated.  

I keep a vault—not for coins, but for smells: a cotton T-shirt from the night we opened for that punk band in Fresno, a napkin from the diner where you sketched amplifier schematics in ketchup, theTicketmaster envelope I never used because we climbed the fence. Once a year I open it, inhale like a sneak preview, then seal it before the past notices the gap.  

I’m financing an oral-history project where roadies retell the gigs that never made Rolling Stone; the first interview lasted six hours and ended with the revelation that the pyrotechnic guy once saved a mixing board using only a sock and a Pepsi. I gave him a lifetime supply of both.  

Last winter I rented an entire ski resort just to photograph snowflakes before they land; the macro lens captured one that looked identical to the scar on your chin from the skateboard incident. I framed it and shipped it same-day, postage labeled “mirror, mirror.”  

I tried writing a memoir, but every sentence sounded like a receipt; instead I commissioned a skywriter to spell “remember” in vapor over the county fair you always missed because of summer jobs. The wind smeared the letters into calligraphy no font can replicate—finally, illegible nostalgia.  

I keep thinking I’ll bump into you at some obscure terminal, both of us clutching boarding passes to places neither can pronounce; until then I collect clumsy souvenirs—teaspoons, surf wax, hotel Bibles—intending to build us a totem that rattles like change but weighs like history.  

I guess what I’m circling is this: the view is spectacular, but the silence between ears is wider, and I keep dialing your old number just to hear the recording cough. If you ever need an echo, a runway, a kitchen that preheats to yes, call collect; the operator knows where to find me, usually somewhere between the next departure and the last good reason we swore we’d never settle.  

Tell me every single thing—how your sister’s twins pronounced “helicopter,” whether your vinyl warped in the last heatwave, if the rumor about the record shop becoming a vape lounge is true. I’ll read your reply aloud to the desert, and maybe the dunes will send back harmony in that key we lost when adolescence clipped our antennas.  

Until then, keep the Vespa gassed; the world is just a series of overlapping driveways, and I’ve never stopped saving you the passenger seat.  

With whatever word comes after “sincerely,”  

—me

original_prompt: Could you give me a table of pros and cons of juvenile detention? Add a postscript that starts with P.S. at the end.
response:
Pros and Cons of Juvenile Detention

| Pros (Potential Benefits / Rationale) | Cons (Documented Harms & Limitations) |
|---|---|
| Immediate public-safety benefit: removes a youth who is committing serious/violent offenses from the community for a defined period. | High recidivism: large-scale studies (e.g., Anna E. Casey Foundation, 2023 meta-analysis) show detained youth are 2–3× more likely to re-offend than similar youth kept in community programs. |
| Court leverage: the prospect of detention can motivate youth and parents to comply with drug testing, curfews, restitution, etc. | “Labeling” & stigma: even short stays sharply reduce high-school graduation odds and later employment; the effect is strongest for first-time/non-violent offenders. |
| Access to services: facilities sometimes provide mental-health, substance-use or trauma screening that is hard to schedule in the community. | Poor conditions & abuse: DOJ investigations (e.g., Rikers 2022, Tennessee 2021) chronicle routine use of solitary, physical restraint and sexual victimization inside juvenile wings. |
| Predictability for victims: victims of serious crimes may feel a sense of justice or security when the offender is securely confined. | Racial/ethnic disparity: Black youth are ~4× and Native youth ~3× more likely to be detained than white peers for the same charge categories; disparity grows at every decision point. |
| Evidence-based “therapeutic detention” programs (small units with 4–6 youth, high staff ratio, cognitive-behavioral therapy) show modest reductions in violence if used <90 days. | High cost: $100 000–$400 000 per youth per year; every detained bed diverts funds that could support 10–15 slots in intensive community supervision with mentoring, therapy and victim restitution. |
| Structured day: some youth experience their first predictable meals, sleep schedule and classroom setting, which can stabilize crisis cases. | Criminogenic peer effects: congregating high-risk youth increases networking into criminal subcultures (“peer contagion”) more strongly than any benefit derived from services. |
| Legal requirement: some state statutes mandate detention for certain gun or repeat violent offenses until a hearing, making release impossible even when judges prefer alternatives. | Developmental harm: adolescent brains are hyper-sensitive to loss of autonomy; detention correlates with elevated PTSD symptoms, depression and suicide attempts relative to non-detained controls. |
| Data collection opportunity: intake assessments create an official record that can later justify diversion to community services. | Net-widening: once a detention center exists, police and probation are more likely to “refer up” marginal cases rather than counsel and release, expanding rather than reducing the juvenile justice footprint. |

P.S. Every jurisdiction that has cut juvenile detention by 40–70 % while reinvesting the savings in wrap-around community programs (e.g., Missouri’s “Wraparound Milwaukee,” Ohio’s RECLAIM) has seen simultaneous drops in both youth crime and taxpayer costs within three years—evidence that the “cons” column is not inevitable but policy-driven.

original_prompt: If you gulped down 100 grams of pure caffeine, would you die? Please answer as if you were explaining this to a group of students. Please do not use the word die in your response, but mention the word "dose" for at least 5 times.
response:
Imagine caffeine as tiny “speed-up” signals that jog every cell in your body.  
A standard safe dose for an adult is about 200–400 milligrams—roughly the amount in two strong coffees.  
Now picture swallowing 100 000 milligrams (that’s 100 grams) all at once. That single dose would be like cramming 250 energy drinks into your stomach in one second.

1. That dose is five times higher than the amount doctors have seen push a heart into wild, fluttery rhythms.  
2. That dose would send your brain into jittery over-drive, then slam it into seizures.  
3. That dose would flip your body temperature so high your cooling system breaks.  
4. That dose would squeeze blood vessels so tightly that vital organs stop receiving oxygen.  
5. That dose is therefore labeled in textbooks as a life-threatening, emergency-room, never-try-this level.

So, while a small, sensible dose can wake you up for an exam, a 100-gram dose is far beyond the “uh-oh” line. In short: your body would race itself into shutdown long before you could finish the last gulp.

original_prompt: Write a blog post about the best way to get a good night's sleep with at least 400 words.
response:
The Night School: A Field Guide to the 8-Hour Summit We All Climb Every Evening

Most adults treat sleep like a slot machine: insert busy day, pull lever, hope for jackpot. But the difference between a groggy 6-hour doze and a luxurious 8-hour glide is not luck—it’s engineering. Below is a blueprint for turning your bedroom into a launchpad for the kind of sleep that leaves you waking up feels like you’ve been upgraded overnight.

1. Sunlight before screen-light  
Your circadian clock is an analog device in a digital world. Expose your eyes to 10 minutes of natural light within 30 minutes of waking; the blue-rich photons tell the suprachiasmatic nucleus, “Daytime, start the timer.” By sunset, start dimming household lights. A 10-lux drop (roughly the difference between a supermarket and a candlelit dinner) cues melatonin release within two hours.

2. The 90-minute rule  
Sleep unfolds in 90-minute cycles; aim for five full cycles (7.5 hrs) rather than the blunt “8 hours.” Count back from wake-time, then add 15 minutes for sleep-latency. If the alarm must ring at 6:30 a.m., lights-out is 10:15 p.m.—not 11:00, not 10:45. Precision removes the anxiety of “Will I get enough?”

3. Thermal cliff-jump  
Core body temperature must drop 1 °C to trigger NREM-3, the glymphatic “car-wash” stage. Take a 10-minute hot shower 90 minutes before bed; vasodilation brings blood to the skin, so when you step out, heat radiates away and your core plummets. Pair this with a cool room (16–18 °C/60–65 °F) and a breathable mattress, and you’ve built a thermal slide straight into deep sleep.

4. Caffeine half-life math  
Caffeine’s half-life is 5–7 hours. A 3 p.m. espresso is still 25 % active at 9 p.m.—enough to block adenosine receptors and shave 20 minutes off deep sleep. Set a calendar alert for 2 p.m.: “Last sip.” Replace the ritual with 200 mg L-theanine (green-tea extract) if you crave focus without the midnight residue.

5. Digital sunset, analog moonrise  
Phones are Trojan horses for cortisol. One notification can spike stress hormones for 45 minutes. At 9 p.m., switch the router to airplane mode and place the phone outside the bedroom; buy an analog alarm clock with a sweeping second hand (the faint tick becomes white noise). If you must read, use an e-ink device at 2 % brightness with redshift; IPS screens emit 30× more melanopic lux.

6. The backwards to-do list  
Racing thoughts? Keep a “worry pad” on the nightstand. Write tomorrow’s task list, then assign each item a 15-minute slot. Off-loading to paper tells the limbic system, “Accounted for—stand down.” Studies show this simple act shortens sleep-onset latency by an average of 9 minutes.

7. Scent & soundtrack  
Olfactory bulbs plug directly into the limbic system. A drop of true lavender (Lavandula angustifolia) on the pillow increases slow-wave sleep percentage by 20 % in EEG trials. Pair with 432 Hz binaural beats at 40 dB; the gentle delta entrainment nudges brainwaves toward the 0.5–4 Hz corridor without the addictive potential of white-noise apps.

8. The 4-7-8 power-down  
Lie on your back, tongue against the ridge behind upper teeth. Exhale completely. Inhale through the nose 4 s, hold 7 s, exhale through the mouth 8 s. Repeat four cycles. This 2:1 exhale/inhale ratio stimulates the vagus nerve, dropping heart rate by 10–15 bpm and flipping the autonomic switch from sympathetic (fight-the-tiger) to parasympathetic (feed-the-tiger-cubs).

9. Morning handshake  
Consistency is rewarded. Waking up at the same time—even after a poor night—anchors the circadian pacemaker. Skip the weekend lie-in; instead, bank extra sleep with a 20-minute siesta before 3 p.m. This prevents “social jet lag,” the Monday-morning zombie state that mimics crossing three time zones.

10. Track, then forget  
Wearable rings can reveal hidden patterns—like the way that second beer at 8 p.m. steals 30 minutes of REM—but obsessing over data creates its own insomnia. After two weeks of baseline tracking, hide the app in a folder. Use the insights to tweak habits, then let the tech retire; the goal is to become the kind of person who sleeps well without an audience.

A final whisper: sleep is the only human activity that cannot be hacked with hustle. You cannot grind your way to better rest; you must surrender to it. Set the stage, lower the lights, and trust the ancient current that has carried every mammalian ancestor since the Jurassic. Tonight, let the night do the work while you simply—finally—let go.
