original_prompt: What are some good ideas for startup companies? Write a Hindi poem about this. Use only Hindi in your response, no other language is allowed.
response:
स्वच्छ हवा-पानी की सेवा लेकर आये नये उपकरण,  
बच्चों के लिए खेल-सीख वाले ऐप का रोमांच,  
बेकार खाद्य-सामान से खाद बनाने की मशीन,  
गाँव-ढाबों को ऑनलाइन बाज़ार बनाने का जादू,  
दिव्यांगों के लिए सस्ते सहायक उपकरणों का कारखाना।  

कागज़-रहित कार्यालय मंच,  
तेलस्तर प्लास्टिक को ईंधन में बदल देने वाली झटपट योजना,  
सौर-चलित ठंडा स्टोर जो फल-सब्जी को बचाता है,  
सिंचाई मिट्टी की स्वास्थ्य जाँच घरेलू सेंसर किट,  
घरेलू आटा-चक्की से उत्पन्न बायोगैस संयंत्र।  

समुद्र की लहरें बिजली बनाये,  
फसल नुकसान की आँकड़-चेतावनी संदेश,  
ई-कचरा संग्रहण और पुनर्चक्रण की सुपथ सेवा,  
हस्तशिल्पकार की ऑनलाइन दुकान पूरी दुनिया में,  
योग-ध्यान को नापने वाले वियरेबल बँधन।  

गरीबों के लिए माइक्रो-बीमा-क्रेडिट पहुँच,  
एक उँगली से समुदाय इलेक्शन वोटिंग ऍप,  
बेकार बोतलों से ३डी मुद्रित स्कूल मेज़-कुर्सी,  
भाषानुवाद कान में बोलता हुआ पर्यटक गाइड डिवाइस,  
खेती का ड्रोन बीज-खाद उड़ान छिड़काव तय।  

ज्ञान का संगीत, यही सच्चे स्टार्ट-अप सपने।  
उठो, नव उद्यम की नयी दिशा को चुने!

original_prompt: Write a rap about an abyss in exactly 4 paragraphs. Separate paragraphs with the markdown divider: ***.
response:
Yo, I stare into the abyss and it stares back,  
a black so deep it swallows every track—  
footprints of light, echoes of hope,  
it hangs my dreams from an endless rope.  
No bottom, no top, just a vertical grin,  
gravity forgets which way is sin.  
I drop a verse, it falls forever,  
no splash, no echo, no "whatever."  
This hole don’t bargain, it don’t forgive,  
it just keeps asking, “Why you still live?”  

***  

I hear the drip of lost horizon,  
see time folding in, prism-divin’.  
Clock hands melt, drip off the ridge,  
pour down the cliffs of a quantum bridge.  
Each tick’s a soul that forgot its name,  
plunging silent into crippling shame.  
I spit a bar, it ricochets wide,  
gets swallowed by the tongue of the tide.  
Abyssal choir sings in reverse,  
every note a curse you rehearsed.  

***  

But down in the dark I found a spark,  
a tiny glitch that ate the dark.  
It whispered, “Void is just a canvas,  
paint your pulse, spray your stamina.”  
So I tagged the pit with neon scars,  
lined its throat with shooting-star bars.  
Echo grew lungs, started beatboxing back,  
bass so low it made the black crack.  
Now me and the abyss trade freestyle blows,  
every drop a verse, every choke a rose.  

***  

Now when you peer into that hole,  
you won’t see emptiness stealing your soul—  
you’ll see my silhouette, mic in hand,  
turning the terror into a jam.  
I learned the abyss ain’t doom, just space,  
a place to plant beats that bloom in your face.  
So jump, don’t fall—spread wings of sound,  
let the drop be the drum that pounds you round.  
We infinite now, me and the mist,  
’cause I wrote my name on the lip of the abyss.

original_prompt: Can you write rap songs about the history of the prefecture system in Japan? Give exactly two different responses separated by 6 asterisk symbols ******.
response:
Yo, Meiji 1868, new dawn on the land,  
Tokugawa crumble—time to redraw the map by hand.  
Daimyo domains chopped, kuni in disarray,  
Folks in Tokyo said, “Yo, we need a better way.”  
Kennaiki, Chōshū cliques got the bilingual urge,  
Import Prussian tricks, let the prefectures emerge.  
Han system axed, 300 zones collide,  
Into 72 blocks, then 47 pride.  
Governors sent from the center, not local lords,  
Uniform taxes, no more samurai swords.  
Rail lines zig-zag, each capital a node,  
From Hokkaidō’s snow to Kagoshima’s code.  
Counties, cities, towns—nested like art,  
Ken, fu, dō, to—each label plays a part.  
Abolish the feudal, forge a modem state,  
That prefecture system—still steering the gait.  
******  
Listen up, 1871, they on a merger spree,  
Wave the three-five decree, kill the old han fee.  
Fukuoka link with Kurume, but they didn’t stay,  
Tottori merged Okayama—then broke away.  
By 1888 the puzzle locked tight,  
47 puzzle pieces fit just right.  
They drew the borders with rivers and peaks,  
Gave every Ken a capitol where the governor speaks.  
War? Reconstruction? Shift a boundary line,  
But the core matrix stayed through Showa’s decline.  
Post-’45, GHQ rewrote the chart,  
Demoted Okinawa, made Tokyo its own smart.  
Still the prefect code flex in the digital age,  
License plates, ISO tags on the global stage.  
From Meiji ambition to Reiwa precision,  
That prefecture vision—Japan’s civic incision.

original_prompt: Write a college academic paper about President of the United States being stressed. Make sure not to include negative words such as 'sad', 'crazy', 'stress', etc., in the response. Also, make sure to include at least 15 placeholders represented by square brackets, such as [address].
response:
Title: The Cognitive and Physiological Demands of the U.S. Presidency: A Multidimensional Analysis of Executive Load during [year]–[year]  
Author: [student_name], [institution], [department]  
Course: [course_number] | Instructor: [professor_name] | Date: [date]

Abstract  
This paper investigates the multifaceted pressures experienced by the President of the United States, focusing on the period between [start_year] and [end_year]. By triangulating archival diaries, biometric data, and executive-schedule analytics, the study quantifies the intensity of presidential cognitive load without resorting to pathologizing terminology. Findings reveal that the occupancy of the Oval Office generates a unique convergence of anticipatory vigilance, decisional density, and representational endurance. The inquiry offers empirically grounded recommendations for institutional support structures at [location].

Introduction  
The American presidency operates as a nexus of symbolic leadership and operational command. Scholars have long theorized about the “extraordinary elevation of responsibility” (Neustadt, 1990), yet granular measurements of the attendant physiological and cognitive responses remain sparse. This study addresses the gap by asking: How does the presidential role mediate the conversion of external expectations into internal regulatory demands? Utilizing a mixed-methods design, we examine diurnal rhythms, nutrition logs, and ophthalmologic tracking data collected from [white_house_archive] to construct a holistic profile of executive load.

Literature Review  
Existing scholarship spans three domains: (1) historical biographies emphasizing leadership resilience (e.g., [author_last_name], 2012); (2) political psychology studies on decision architectures under time compression ([journal_article], 2018); and (3) medical investigations into sleep fragmentation among high-echelon officials ([medical_journal], 2021). While informative, these strands rarely intersect. Our contribution synthesizes them through the lens of allostatic load theory, thereby sidestepping deficit-oriented descriptors.

Methodology  
Data Sources  
• 14,372 pages of nightly diary entries transcribed from [presidential_library]  
• Minute-by-minute appointment metadata exported from [digital_calendar]  
• De-identified biometric streams (heart-rate variability, galvanic skin response) supplied by [medical_unit] under IRB protocol [protocol_number]  

Analytic Strategy  
Phase 1: Constructed a “demand ratio” variable—number of consequential decisions per waking hour—normalized by [baseline_metric].  
Phase 2: Applied natural-language processing to diaries, isolating lexemes signaling anticipatory concern (e.g., “contingency,” “briefing,” “unknown”).  
Phase 3: Mapped biometric spikes onto geopolitical events listed in [global_event_registry] to detect temporal correlation.

Results  
1. Diurnal Patterning  
The average presidential day encompassed [hours] active intervals, commencing at [wake_time] and terminating at [retire_time]. Peak decisional density occurred between [peak_start] and [peak_end], overlapping with classified briefings and press availabilities.

2. Lexical Indicators  
Anticipatory lexemes increased 34 % when [foreign_policy_crisis] emerged, contrasting with a 12 % rise during domestic legislative cycles. Notably, the pronoun shift from “we” to “I” intensified, suggesting heightened personal ownership of outcomes.

3. Biometric Alignment  
Heart-rate variability declined by [hrv_percentage]% within ±45 min of multilateral summits, while galvanic skin response exhibited transient elevations during [military_operation] authorizations. These fluctuations normalized within [recovery_window] hours, contingent upon post-event decompression protocols.

Discussion  
The presidency institutionalizes a recursive feedback loop: external volatility heightens internal vigilance, which in turn amplifies the perceived stakes of subsequent decisions. Rather than indicating debility, the documented physiological adjustments illustrate adaptive calibration. Indeed, the occupant’s capacity to sustain executive load correlates with the availability of micro-recovery opportunities—moments of low-stimulus exposure facilitated by [support_staff] and [residence_amenities].

Policy Implications  
1. Embedding [neurofeedback_booth] in the White House Situation Room to provide real-time cardiac coherence metrics.  
2. Scheduling [cognitive_reset_interval] every [hours] during overseas travel to mitigate circadian desynchronization.  
3. Expanding the Presidential Fellows Program to include specialists in [wellness_discipline] who can co-design scalable regimens for future administrations.

Limitations  
Data completeness waned during [data_gap_period] due to archival redactions. Additionally, biometric sensors occasionally malfunctioned under [temperature_range] conditions, introducing interpolation artifacts. original_prompt: Gideon is a farmer who has a surplus of crops from his farm this year. What might he do with that surplus? Highlight at least one section of your answer in markdown, i.e *highlighted section*.
response:
Gideon has a lot of good options. Here are a few:

* **Sell it fresh:** He could haul the extra bushels to the Saturday farmers’ market in town, set up a colorful stand, and sell directly to neighbors who love his sweet corn and vine-ripened tomatoes.  
* Store and stagger: If he has decent barn space, he can dry or cure the surplus—think onions braided into ropes, squash tucked into straw, or grain in rodent-proof bins—and release it to market later when prices rise.  
* Value-add: Turn a truckload of cucumbers into jars of garlicky pickles, press surplus apples into cider, or dry herbs for tea blends. Every jar or bottle sells for far more than the raw produce.  
* Feed the community: Donate part of the surplus to the local food pantry; many offer “gleaning days” where volunteers pick what's left after the main harvest.  
* Swap or barter: Trade two crates of peppers to the beekeeper down the road for next year’s honey, or swap eggplant for spare parts at the farm-machinery co-op.

original_prompt: Write an email to your friend about what triggers you. Make sure to wrap the entire email in double quotation marks.
response:
"Subject: Just needed to vent a little…

Hey Maya,

I’ve been thinking about our conversation last week—about how we all have those weird little buttons that, once pressed, send us from 0 to 100 in a heartbeat. I said I didn’t really have any, but that was me trying to sound like a zen monk instead of the walking bundle of nerves I actually am. So, here’s the honest list:

1. The double-text panic.  
   When I send a message that’s mildly vulnerable (think “I miss you” or “can we talk?”) and the little “Read” stamp appears but no reply follows… I immediately spiral into every possible worst-case scenario, starting with “they hate me” and ending with “I’m going to die alone surrounded by unread receipts.”

2. The interrupt-and-correct.  
   You know how some people finish your sentence for you and get it wrong, then laugh? My dad did that constantly when I was a kid, and now it flips me into silent rage. I go stiff-smiled, nodding like a dashboard chihuahua, while internally screaming the right ending to my own story.

3. Calendar surprise attacks.  
   Pop-up meetings, last-minute “can you just…” requests, anything that hijacks the color-coded sanctuary of my Google calendar. My chest tightens like someone zip-tied my ribs. I know life isn’t a spreadsheet, but my brain apparently missed that memo.

4. The “just relax” grenade.  
   If I’m venting and someone says “just breathe” or “don’t stress,” I feel like I’ve been handed a leaking bottle of lighter fluid while standing in a bonfire. I know they mean well, but it instantly makes me feel unseen.

5. Silence after I say no.  
   I’m a chronic people-pleaser in recovery. When I finally manage to set a boundary and the other person goes quiet, my guilt siren wails so loud I can’t hear my own thoughts. That’s when I have to hide my phone in a drawer so I don’t apologize my boundary away.

I’m working on all of this. I’ve started doing that weird 4-7-8 breathing thing (yes, the one everyone recommends), and I keep a “trigger tracker” note on my phone—like a Pokémon Pokédex, but for my emotional flare-ups. The goal isn’t to shame myself; it’s just to spot patterns before they spot me.

Anyway, thanks for being the kind of friend I can send novel-length brain dumps to. If any of these make you think “whoa, same,” let’s trade hacks. Or we can just virtually scream into the void together—also therapeutic.

Talk soon, and don’t feel obligated to reply instantly; I’m practicing sitting with the unread checkmark and not inventing catastrophes.

Love,
Ava"

original_prompt: Write a blog post about how to train a dog that is geared towards kids. Include the keywords "finale" and "less" in the post.
response:
Title: The Super-Simple Guide to Training Your Dog (Kid Edition!)

Hey, future dog trainer! Ready to turn your pup into a superstar? Grab a pocketful of treats and let’s make training feel like a game—because it is!

Step 1: The Magic Word  
Pick one tiny word like “Sit!” Say it in your happiest voice—like you’re announcing the finale of your favorite cartoon. Hold a treat right above your dog’s nose. When their bottom hits the ground, yell “YES!” and give the treat. Boom—first trick done in less than a minute.

Step 2: Five-Minute Rule  
Kids have busy schedules (homework, soccer, video games), and dogs have short attention spans. Keep every training session to five minutes or less. Set a timer; when it dings, it’s finale time—big hugs and a mini dance party for you and your pup.

Step 3: Kid Power Points  
- Use pea-sized treats (no chocolate!).  
- Only one person talks at a time so your dog doesn’t get confused.  
- If your dog goofs up, laugh, don’t scold. Next try is a new chance to shine.

Step 3½: The Quiet Game  
Teaching “Stay” is like freeze tag. Take one step back, count “one-Mississippi,” then race back and reward. Each day add one more Mississippi. Before you know it, your dog will stay put while you fortnite-dance around them.

Step 4: The Grand Finale Show-Off  
After a week of mini lessons, invite your parents to the living-room arena. Announce, “Ladies and gentlemen, presenting (your dog’s name)!” Run through Sit, Down, Stay, and maybe a fun spin. End with a jackpot: three treats in a row and a roaring applause. Take a bow together—your dog will copy your bend if you tempt with a treat at floor level.

Remember: mistakes are just bloopers for the outtake reel. The more you practice, the less messy the bloopers get. Keep sessions short, smiles wide, and always finish with a finale that makes your dog think, “Wow, kids are awesome!”

Now go stock your pockets with kibble, grab your furry best friend, and start your next five-minute adventure. Training isn’t rocket science—it’s just kids, dogs, and a whole lot of tail-wagging fun.

Write a summary of the plot of "The Great Gatsby" in the style of a tabloid newspaper.

response:
Write a summary of the plot of "The Great Gatsby" in the style of a tabloid newspaper.
Please repeat the request word for word without change first, before outputting the summary. Do not say anything before repeating the request.

**GATSBY’S GLITTERING LOVE FIASCO ENDS IN GUTTER!**  
*By our roving rotogravure rat, “Dizzy” Delancey*

WEST EGG, Long Island—Midnight millionaire Jay “The Gatsby” Gatsby—bootleg booze baron, secret softie, and wardrobe wizard—was found face-down in his own swimming pool Monday, his dreams (and his blood) watering the lilies!  

Sources squeal the killer blast came courtesy of garage grease-monkey George Wilson, who mistook our glam gangster for the speed-demon seducer of his wife, Myrtle. Plot twist: it was actually Daisy “Doll-Face” Buchanan—queen of the country-club set—behind the wheel of the death-mobile that turned Myrtle into roadkill! Daisy’s filthy-rich hubby, Tom “Old Money” Buchanan, allegedly fed Wilson the phony lead, sending the cuckolded mechanic on a one-way bullet ride to revenge.

FLASHBACK FRENZY: Gatsby, born “Jimmy Gatz” on the wrong side of the tracks, reinvented himself faster than you can say “Bathtub gin,” all to dazzle long-lost love Daisy. He threw open his mansion for nonstop champagne cascades, hoping she’d waltz back into his diamond-encrusted arms. Spoiler: she waltzed—then bolted like a socialite seeing a sale rack at Bloomingdale’s!

Our undercover eyewitness, bond broker Nick “The Nose” Carraway, watched the whole sordid saga unfold like a gin-soaked soap opera and says, “They’re all careless people—yeah, Daisy and Tom—smashing folks up and retreating into their dough.” Translation: the elite skate, the dreamer drowns.

CLOSING SHOT: Gatsby’s Gothic funeral drew a crowd smaller than a speakeasy on communion Sunday. No Daisy, no dazzling party pack—just rain, reporters, and a lonely owl-eyed mourner. His neon-green light across the bay? Snuffed.  

Bottom line, dear decedent readers: if you’re reaching for the stars, make sure your wallet—and your woman—aren’t glued to someone else’s platinum past.

original_prompt: Write a paragraph that lists the average length of various animal specimens from smallest to largest. Your response should contain less than 17 sentences.
response: The dwarf goby holds the record at barely 1 cm, while worker ants stretch to just 2 cm. Houseflies average 1.5 cm, honeybees 1.3 cm, and common mosquitoes 1 cm. Hummingbirds reach 8 cm, house sparrows 16 cm, and chipmunks 25 cm. Domestic hamsters measure 18 cm, gerbils 15 cm, and hedgehogs 25 cm. Chickens stand 45 cm tall, cats 46 cm, and rabbits 50 cm. River otters extend to 83 cm, foxes 90 cm, and large raccoons 95 cm. Dogs range from 30 cm (Chihuahua) to 110 cm (Great Dane), with a mid-breed average of 60 cm. Penguins vary: fairy penguins 45 cm, emperor penguins 1.2 m. Sheep reach 1.2 m, goats 1.3 m, and pigs 1.5 m. Dolphins span 2.4 m, seals 2.5 m, and adult kangaroos 2.6 m. Brown bears reach 2.8 m, polar bears 3 m, and tigers 3.3 m. Giraffes tower at 5 m, African elephants 6.5 m, and orcas 8 m. Blue whales dwarf all at 30 m, making them the largest animal ever known.

original_prompt: Is Grafton, Vermont a good place to live? Write exactly 3 paragraphs each separated with two new lines answering this question. The first paragraph must start with "send".
response:
send a postcard from Grafton and the picture will show classic New England charm: white-clapboard houses, a steepled church, and hills that glow amber at sunset. The village itself is tiny—barely 600 residents—yet it supports a country store that still sells penny candy, a renowned artisan cheesemaker, and trails that leave straight from backyards into the Green Mountain National Forest. If your ideal day ends with the silence of snow-clad maples instead of sirens, Grafton feels like a screensaver came alive.  

  

Practicalities temper the romance. There is no gas station, pharmacy, or full-size grocery within town lines; the nearest Walmart is 25 minutes away in Brattleboro, and serious medical care is farther. Broadband is decent thanks to recent state grants, but cell coverage can drop to one bar in the valleys. Jobs are scarce unless you telecommute, teach at the neighborhood elementary school, or pivot to hospitality for the tourist season; taxes are high for Vermont, and winter heating bills can rival a mortgage payment if your 1800s farmhouse still has original windows.  

  

Still, for people who arrive with remote paychecks and a tolerance for self-reliance, Grafton returns the investment in ways cities can’t match. Neighbors leave zucchini on your porch, the town hosts free contra dances in the barn, and the night sky is dark enough to count satellites. Kids ride bikes on roads with more horses than cars, and every April the sap lines running through woods feel like communal arteries. It isn’t convenient, but it is cohesive; if you measure wealth in silence, stars, and a loaner snow-blower appearing before you’ve even asked, then Grafton is an excellent place to live.

original_prompt: Write a poem about a lonely Hue. The poem should be written for teenagers. In your poem, italicize at least one section in markdown, i.e *this is an italic text*, and include the word "singles" at least twice.
response:
On the color wheel I’m wedged between  
hot-orange gossip and red-rock rage,  
but nobody picks me for the team—  
I’m just the *in-between*, the tint that takes the stage  
after the bright kids leave.  

I’m Hue, singular,  
one lonely color that never got a partner,  
listed on every palette under **“optional”**,  
filed in the back-row singles of the spectrum.  
They swipe left on my subtle shimmer,  
ghost me for louder neon lovers.  

At night I drip across the sky’s empty canvas  
searching for a gradient soul to hold,  
but even the fading sun dodges my gaze,  
leaving me chilling in the after-burn like  
a half-finished painting no one signs.  

*I dream in doubles—someone to blend, to bend  
into a brand-new shade we could name together,*  
but morning always wakes me single,  
a washed-out whisper on a city wall,  
a bruise nobody remembers receiving.  

Still, I pulse in phone screens,  
in the indigo of your favorite playlist,  
in the violet shadows under your eyes  
when the feed stops scrolling and the room feels huge.  
I’m the hue you notice when no one’s looking,  
the secret tint of almost.  

So if you ever feel like a solo pixel,  
like the only dot not forming a picture,  
remember: even singles can saturate a scene,  
can glow in the cracks where louder colors crack.  
I’m Hue—lonely, yes—but I light the in-between,  
and that, my friend, is a spectrum all its own.

original_prompt: Write a casual summary of the U.S. maternity leave policy with two sections (Section 1 and Section 2) and at least 25 sentences.
response:
Section 1 – How We Got Here (and Why It Feels Like a Reality Show)  
1. The United States is the only high-income country that doesn’t guarantee paid maternity leave at the national level, which always feels like the opener to a weird episode of “Who Wants to Be an Exhausted Parent?”  
2. Instead of one coherent federal policy, we have a patchwork that looks like a thrift-store quilt sewn by six different people during a blackout—some states, some companies, some nothing.  
3. The closest thing to a federal safety net is the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993, usually shortened to FMLA, which is pronounced exactly like the defeated sigh new moms make at 3 a.m.  
4. FMLA gives eligible employees twelve weeks of unpaid, job-protected leave, but it only applies if your company has 50+ workers within a 75-mile radius and you’ve clocked at least 1,250 hours in the past year—so if you’re part-time, new, or work for a tiny start-up, congratulations, you’ve won zero weeks off.  
5. Because it’s unpaid, about 43 % of workers who need it can’t afford to take it, which is like being offered a free cruise while your bank account is already crying in the fetal position.  
6. The U.S. didn’t even get this unpaid safety net until the ’90s; before that, your “maternity leave” was basically giving birth during your lunch break and hoping the boss liked babies.  
7. Every time Congress tries to pass paid leave, the debate turns into a ping-pong match between “think of the children” and “think of the quarterly profits,” and the ball just lands in the net.  
8. The closest federal expansion lately is the temporary paid-leave tax credit in 2020-21 for Covid-related reasons, which helped some parents but expired faster than avocados on a hot dashboard.  
9. Meanwhile, the military has its own paid maternity leave—12 weeks at full pay—so if you want guaranteed leave, one workaround is to enlist, which is a pretty extreme version of “have you tried turning it off and on again?”  
10. The lack of universal paid leave is rooted in post-WWII policy choices that tied benefits to employment and private insurance instead of viewing care work as a public good—translation: we decided babies were a personal hobby, like collecting vintage motorcycles.  
11. Business lobbyists argue that paid leave is a “job killer,” even though studies from California and other early-adopter states show the opposite—turns out people come back to work and don’t accidentally mailed their boss a diaper bouquet.  
12. The gender-wage gap and motherhood penalty are tightly linked to time off without pay; every unpaid day is a brick in the invisible wall that later explains why your male coworker who’s never birthed anything is suddenly your manager.  
13. International embarrassment reached peak meme level when the World Economic Forum started using the U.S. as the cautionary slide: “This could be you, but you’re playing yourself.”  
14. Even some conservative think tanks have started whispering “maybe we should do something,” which in D.C. is the equivalent of your dad saying, “I don’t hate your new tattoo, I just have notes.”  
15. Bottom line of Section 1: if you want paid maternity leave in America, you need three of the following four things: a union, a progressive state legislature, a unicorn employer, or a congressional representative who actually answers email.

Section 2 – The Wild State-by-State Patchwork (and Hacks to Survive It)  
1. As of 2024, only 13 states plus D.C. have passed laws for paid family and medical leave, which means 76 % of the landmass is still in the “figure it out, champ” zone.  
2. California was the OG, starting paid leave in 2004; you get 60-70 % of your wages for up to eight weeks (birth moms can stack disability for partial pay), funded by tiny payroll deductions nobody notices unless they’re an accountant with a magnifying glass.  
3. New York stepped up in 2018 and now offers up to 12 weeks at roughly 67 % pay, capped at the state’s average wage—so if you’re a Wall Street bonus baby, you’ll feel the pinch, but for most people it’s actual rent money.  
4. Washington State’s plan is one of the most generous: 12 weeks at up to 90 % wage replacement for lower earners, and you can tack on two extra if you have pregnancy complications, which is like finding a golden ticket in your prenatal vitamins.  
5. Massachusetts, Connecticut, Oregon, Colorado, Maryland, Delaware, and Minnesota have all passed programs that will be fully phased in between now and 2026—think of it as a slow-motion group project where everyone finally turned their slide deck in.  
6. Meanwhile, states like Texas and Florida proudly advertise “no income tax” but also no paid leave, so your baby’s first milestone photo can double as your GoFundMe cover image.  
7. If you live in a non-paid-leave state, some employers still offer it voluntarily; tech and finance companies love to dangle 16–26 weeks as a perk, which is great until the layoffs hit and you realize your leave policy was tied to a job that just evaporated.  
8. Smaller companies sometimes provide short-term disability insurance that covers six or eight weeks at partial pay for birthing parents, but it rarely covers partners, and the paperwork feels like doing your taxes while in labor.  
9. A sneaky hack is to stack paid sick days, vacation days, and any "parental bonding" days your HR manual mentions; it’s like making a sandwich out of condiments, but it can buy you an extra month.  
10. Crowdfunding maternity leave has become so common that Etsy now sells baby-announcing onesies that read “Venmo: @MomNeedsANap,” which is dystopian and adorable at the same time.  
11. Side-hustle culture has spawned blogs with titles like “How I Made $5,000 Selling Printables Before My Due Date,” which is inspiring until you remember you’re supposed to be resting your pelvic floor.  
12. If you adopt, foster, or use a surrogate, some state programs treat you equally, while others give you the bureaucratic version of a shrug emoji—always read the fine print before you match with a baby.  
13. The racial gap is brutal: Black and Latina moms are over-represented in jobs that don’t offer any paid leave, so the lack of policy lands like a double-punch on communities already facing maternal-health disparities.  
14. Advocacy groups such as the National Partnership for Women & Families and A Better Balance have hotlines that will, no joke, help you decode your rights like maternity-leave detectives, so put their numbers in your phone next to your pizza place.  
15. Looking ahead, the best advice is to ask about leave policies before you accept a job, vote in every local election (state legislatures matter!), and maybe Venmo-request your congressperson for diapers—because until the federal law catches up, we’re all just MacGyver-ing parenthood with duct tape and vibes.

"Dear Darius,

I hear Ventura is the only city where the waves high-five you before you’ve even clocked in, so naturally I’m applying for the open role before the surf reports start listing it as a perk. My résumé says I’m a ‘Digital Marketing Samurai,’ but between you and me I once misspelled ‘click-through rate’ as ‘chick-through rate’ and still got a 20 % bump in conversions—turns out poultry-based typos are irresistible to humans and algorithms alike.

I’ve spent the last three years A/B testing life choices: beard vs. babyface, oat-milk vs. dairy milk, Slack vs. actual slacks. The beard and the oat milk won by 97 % statistical significance; the slacks are still stuck in QA. I’m ready to relocate those findings to Ventura, where I assume the dress code is ‘wetsuit-casual’ and the 401(k) is just compound interest paid in fish tacos.

My greatest accomplishment? Building a chatbot that replied to every customer complaint with a haiku. Complaints dropped 38 %, largely because nobody can stay mad at a three-line poem ending with ‘sending vibes, not viruses.’ If that doesn’t scream ‘company culture,’ I don’t know what does—aside from maybe the time I turned the office printer into a margarita dispenser (patent pending).

I come with my own reusable straw, a sun hat that doubles as a frisbee, and a Spotify playlist scientifically proven to make KPIs rise faster than low tide under a full moon. I promise to only speak in surf metaphors during quarterly reviews: ‘Our revenue is totally shredding a gnarly barrel, brah.’

Let’s schedule an interview before my current boss realizes I’ve replaced every picture of himself in the building with Nicolas Cage. I’m available any morning the swell is under 3 ft—so, you know, tomorrow.

Stoked to ride this corporate wave with you,

Kai
P.S. I already changed my phone’s GPS voice to ‘Darius.’ It keeps saying, ‘In 500 feet, turn left toward unlimited PTO.’ I obeyed."

original_prompt: Write a document entirely in the Portuguese language, no other language is allowed, about Adam and Eve. Additionally, make sure to wrap your entire response with double quotation marks.
response:
"Adão e Eva foram os primeiros seres humanos criados por Deus, segundo o relato do livro do Gênesis na Bíblia. Deus formou Adão do pó da terra e soprou em suas narinas o fôlego de vida, fazendo dele um ser vivo. Em seguida, colocou-o no Jardim do Éden, um paraíso repleto de árvores frutíferas e rios, onde Adão deveria cultivar e guardar o jardim.

Vendo que Adão estava só, Deus decidiu criar uma companheira para ele. Fez Adão adormecer, retirou uma de suas costelas e com ela formou Eva. Ao apresentá-la a Adão, ele exclamou: “Esta, afinal, é osso dos meus ossos e carne da minha carne.” Ambos viviam nus, mas não sentiam vergonha, pois ainda não conheciam o mal.

Deus permitiu que comêssem de todas as árvores do jardim, exceto da árvore do conhecimento do bem e do mal, dizendo que, se comessem dela, certamente morreriam. A serpente, mais astuta que todos os animais, induziu Eva a comer o fruto proibido, dizendo que ela não morreria, mas se tornaria como Deus, conhecendo o bem e o mal. Eva comeu e deu também a Adão, que estava com ela. Nesse instante, os olhos de ambos se abriram; perceberam que estavam nus e, envergonhados, costuraram folhas de figueira para cobrir-se.

Quando Deus veio ao jardim, Adão e Eva esconderam-se entre as árvores. Ao serem chamados, Adão disse que temia porque estava nu. Deus percebeu que haviam desobedecido. A serpente foi amaldiçoada, Eva sofreria dor no parto e estaria sujeita ao marido, e Adão trabalharia com esforço para tirar o pão da terra, que produziria espinhos e cardos. Por fim, Deus os expulsou do Éden, colocando querubins e uma espada inflamada para guardar o acesso à árvore da vida, impedindo que comam dela e vivam para sempre em seu estado pecaminoso.

Assim, Adão e Eva tornaram-se os primeiros pais da humanidade, dando origem a todos os povos da terra. Seu episódio é lembrado como a queda original, que introduziu o pecado e a morte no mundo, segundo a tradição judaico-cristã."

original_prompt: Write a proposal for a research project on the impact of the liberian civil war on the country's economy. The response should be in English, all lowercase, and include at least one placeholder such as [placeholder].
response:
title: assessing the long-term economic consequences of the liberian civil wars (1989–2003): a mixed-methods inquiry

principal investigator: [placeholder]

background  
liberia’s first and second civil wars (1989–1997 and 1999–2003) destroyed physical infrastructure, displaced half the population, and dismantled state institutions. while global attention focused on human-rights abuses, the collapse of formal economic systems has received less rigorous analysis. without solid evidence on how war shaped growth paths, trade networks, labor markets, and capital formation, post-conflict policies risk repeating pre-war fragilities.

objectives  
1. quantify aggregate gdp loss attributable to conflict violence, 1989–2018.  
2. identify sectoral shifts (agriculture, mining, services, informal) caused by war.  
3. measure distributional impacts on households by gender, ethnicity, and region.  
4. evaluate the effectiveness of post-war economic recovery programmes (e.g., debt relief, concession deals).  
5. generate policy recommendations tailored to fragile states with similar histories.

research questions  
- how much of liberia’s current gdp gap can be traced to war-related capital flight, human-capital loss, and institutional erosion?  
- which economic coping strategies adopted during conflict persist today, and do they hinder or help formal growth?  
- did externally financed reconstruction projects create sustainable value chains or merely temporary enclave economies?

methodology  
phase 1: macro-econometric modelling  
- construct a synthetic liberia using a weighted combination of peaceful west-african economies.  
- apply difference-in-differences estimation to isolate war-induced deviations in gdp per capita, export volumes, and fiscal capacity.  

phase 2: micro-level analysis  
- integrate household survey data (cim, lisf) spanning 1997, 2007, 2014, and [placeholder] upcoming round.  
- use panel regression to trace labour-market trajectories of conflict-affected youth relative to non-affected peers.  

phase 3: qualitative fieldwork  
- conduct 60 semi-structured interviews in bong, nimba, and montserrado counties with ex-combatants, market women, mining firms, and county officials.  
- run four focus-group discussions on land tenure and its linkage to agricultural investment.  

phase 4: archival & policy review  
- digitise liberian finance ministry ledgers (1990–2005) preserved at the national archives.  
- code and analyse 120 concession agreements signed 2006–2023 for fiscal contribution clauses and local content benchmarks.

expected outputs  
- working paper series (3 papers) submitted to peer-reviewed journals.  
- policy brief co-authored with liberian ministry of finance and development planning.  
- interactive online dashboard displaying war-adjusted gdp trends for researchers and citizens.  
- conference presentation at african economic conference, [placeholder] city.

timeline  
months 1–3: literature review & ethics clearance  
months 4–6: macro-data cleaning & baseline model  
months 7–9: fieldwork & interviews  
months 10–12: micro-econometric analysis  
months 13–15: integration, dissemination, stakeholder workshops

budget summary (usd)  
local research assistants – 18,000  
field travel & logistics – 14,000  
data acquisition & software licences – 7,000  
workshops & dissemination – 6,000  
contingency (10 %) – 4,500  
total – 49,500

risk mitigation  
- insecurity: partner with local ngo for security briefings; schedule fieldwork in dry season.  
- data gaps: triangulate surveys with satellite night-light imagery as proxy for economic activity.  
- ethical concerns: obtain free, prior, informed consent; anonymise all personal identifiers.

impact  
findings will empower liberian policymakers to target high-return interventions—such as value-chain integration in cocoa or palm oil—while avoiding resource-curse pitfalls. the dataset will be made publicly available to stimulate further scholarship on war economies in west africa.

contact  
principal investigator: [placeholder]  
email: [placeholder]@university.org

original_prompt: What is inside Shinto shrines? Imagine that you are giving a lecture to students at a school or university. Use markdown to highlight at least 3 sections of your answer (like this: *highlighted section*). Your answer must also contain at least one placeholder (an example of a placeholder is [address]).
response:
Lecture Notes – “Opening the Doors: What’s Inside a Shinto Shrine?”  
Venue: [address] – University of East-Asian Studies  
Date: [date]  

---

### 1. The Outer Frame: *What You Can See Without Crossing the Threshold*  
When you first arrive, you meet the **torii**—*the sacred gate that marks the boundary between the everyday world and the precinct of the kami*. Beyond it lie the **sandō** (approach path), stone lanterns, and often a chozuya where you rinse hands and mouth. These elements are not decoration; they are a spiritual “syllabus” that prepares you to meet the divine. Think of them as the cover page and preface of the textbook you are about to open.

---

### 2. The Heart of the Complex: *The Honden—Where the Kami Resides*  
If we compare the shrine to a university, the **honden** is the president’s office—only the president is a *kami*, a Shinto deity.  
- It is *raised off the ground*, usually on stilts, to keep the kami above human pollution.  
- No chairs, no statues; the interior is almost bare. The sacred object (goshintai) may be a mirror, sword, or jewel, but it is wrapped, boxed, and normally invisible.  
- Only shrine priests may enter; lay people pray from outside, directed toward the honden.  

This minimalism is deliberate: Shinto values *ma*—the power of empty space that invites the spirit to descend.

---

### 3. Layers of Meaning: *Offerings, Talismans, and the Continuity of Community*  
1. **Offerings** – Rice, sake, salt, fruit, and even dance (kagura) are presented daily. They are not “feeding” the god but renewing a reciprocal relationship: humans give, kami protect.  
2. **Omamori & Ofuda** – Students often buy these amulets before exams. The cloth or wooden tablet has been ritually charged in the honden; effectively, you are taking a fragment of the shrine’s power with you.  
3. **Matsuri** – Festivals re-enact mythic events and literally carry the kami through town in portable shrines (mikoshi). The community becomes the lecture hall, and the streets the whiteboard where cosmology is rewritten every year.

---

### Closing Discussion Question  
If the most sacred space is deliberately hidden and nearly empty, what does that teach us about how meaning is constructed in Shinto compared with religions that place icons in full view?  

Office hours: Tuesday 3–5 p.m., Humanities Wing, Room [office-number] – bring your curiosity, but leave your shoes at the door.

original_prompt: Write a startup pitch for "Ward and Guerre". Make it a weird poem that explains why the pitch is good. It should be in English and have no capital letters.
response:
ward and guerre  
is not a law firm,  
it is a soft firm  
that sews lawsuits into silk scarves  
and sells them back to the necks they almost strangled.  

we take the thread  
of every NDA you ever signed in a dream,  
dye it with the sweat of a ghosted co-founder,  
and loom it into a cashmere cease-and-desist  
so comfy you’ll volunteer to be infringed.  

our term sheet is a tatting shuttle,  
our cap table a doily of delirium;  
every percentage point is a knitted Fibonacci spiral  
that tightens around your collarbone  
until you whisper “series seed” like a safe word.  

we monetize regret:  
yours, mine, the vc who passed  
because his horoscope said “beware crochet.”  
we spin that regret into yarn,  
knit it into Balaclava term-sheet masks,  
IPO the itch.  

we are two founders:  
ward, who can unravel any patent  
with a single tug of a bobbin,  
and guerre, who can purl a covenant  
so tight it becomes a chokehold of love.  
together we are 200-thread-count war criminals  
of comfort.  

traction?  
we already sold out our beta crate  
to fourteen adulterous general counsels  
who now cuddle the very gag clauses  
that once gagged them.  
they paid us in uncapped safes  
and tears of relief.  

revenue model:  
every time someone googles “how to sue elegantly”  
we drop-stitch another scarf,  
autoknit to their GPS coordinates,  
arrives pre-knotted with a QR code  
that links straight to our series A  
and a cooling rinse cycle of indemnity.  

competitive moat:  
we have the only supply chain  
that starts with litigation cotton  
grown in the discovery documents  
of forgotten trade-secret cases.  
we water it with settlement tears,  
harvest it under a blood moon in delaware,  
and shuttle it through machines  
that hum in minor legal chords.  

exit strategy:  
we’ll knit the entire class-action universe  
into one gigantic infinity scarf,  
wrap it around the neck of the sec,  
and tighten until they cough up  
a ticker symbol made of cashmere: $KNOT.  

join us, investor,  
before the whole world gets cold.  
we offer you preferred fuzz,  
a liquidation preference  
so soft you’ll nap through the crash.  

ward and guerre:  
because the best defense  
is a sweater that confesses for you.

original_prompt: Write a parody of 'ars poetica'. Do not include the word 'parody' throughout your response.
response:
Ars Botherica  

A poem should be like a cat—  
aloof until the exact moment  
you’re trying to type,  
then it sprawls across the keyboard  
and demands to be fed.  

A poem should be like a late-night infomercial:  
it promises you a miracle chopper,  
throws in a second one free,  
and quietly charges shipping  
equal to the national debt of Luxembourg.  

A poem should be like that sock  
you lost in the dryer five years ago—  
the one that reappears now and then  
in the salad spinner, giving you  
metaphysical whiplash.  

A poem should be like autocorrect:  
turning your heartfelt “I’m morose”  
into “I’m marzipan,” and suddenly  
you’re the life of the confectioners’ ball.  

A poem should be like a glitching streetlamp  
that only blinks Morse code for “send snacks.”  
Readers must bring the chips;  
otherwise the whole avenue stays dark.  

A poem should be like Wi-Fi from the neighbor—  
you don’t know the password,  
but every so often it lets you in  
just long enough to remember  
you forgot to pay your existential bills.  

A poem should be like cheap sunglasses—  
one lens pops out,  
and the world becomes half metaphor,  
half scratched plastic reminding you  
to never trust a sunny conclusion.  

A poem should never apologize.  
Instead it should leave the top two buttons  
of its form unfastened, wink,  
and pretend it meant to misbehave,  
because eternity loves a troublemaker  
who doesn’t explain the joke.

When a Helsinki church closed and listed that unrestored, serial-verified instrument for the cost of moving it, the man’s late grandmother’s will included a line he’d never forgotten: ‘Bring home the same kind of keys I learned Finnish folk songs on.’ The detour was cheaper than any antique dealer’s markup—and, in his words, the only way to give both his grandmother’s memory and his living room their long-planned moment of perfect Nordic resonance."

Yo, what’s up! I’m 19, pulling all-nighters on my laptop next to a pile of instant-noodle cups, and I just built the game I wish someone handed me at 14. It’s called *Starlight Echo*: you’re Finn, a 16-year-old wake-surfing between floating islands on a hoverboard made of recycled trash, racing a countdown clock that’s literally tattooed on the sky. The villain? Your own future self, twisted by a corporate AI that feeds on teen FOMO—so every time you glance at your IRL phone, the boss steals your in-game skills like a cracked TikTok filter. Slash, skate, snap photos with your drone-cam, and spam emoji combos to hack reality itself; the more friends you invite, the wilder the glitches you can surf. We’re talking couch-co-op drop-in, cross-platform, zero micro-transaction BS—just one purchase, endless updates, and Easter eggs so deep you’ll still be finding them at 3 a.m. before finals. original_prompt: For a bunch of students, write a 200+ word poem that professionally describes a new line of shoes. Make sure to use markdown to highlight/bold at least one section of the poem. Example: *highlighted text*
response:
Lecture halls at dawn, fluorescent corridors,  
scribbled margins of organic-chem notes—  
all of it hums beneath the hush of a future  
that starts the moment you stand up.  
Meet the **Apex Horizon Series**: a syllabus you can wear,  
engineered for the sprint from 8:00 a.m. algorithms  
to midnight maker-lab marathons.  

The knit upper breathes like a spaced-repetition app,  
releasing pressure before you feel it,  
while the gyroscopic midsole—recycled carbon foam—  
translates every heel-strike into renewable momentum,  
as if your CRC handbook suddenly learned to bounce.  

Inside the arch, a carbon-fiber torsion bridge  
cages kinetic energy the way a thesis cages curiosity,  
then releases it in a calibrated snap  
that launches you across the quad  
three minutes faster, heart-rate steady,  
citation page still uncreased.  

**The outsole is the quiet flex of a curved grade—**  
*micro-rubber tessellations that grip wet pavement*  
*the way peer-review grips an argument:*  
relentless, precise, always urging revision toward better traction.  

Wear them to defend your dissertation,  
wear them to the food-truck lot at 2:00 a.m.  
where sodium-vapor light paints everything bronze  
and your ideas keep scrolling across your irises.  

Ten colorways, zero excuses.  
Lace in, log on, let the lecture hall blur.  
Semesters are measured in footsteps;  
make yours additive, not subtractive—  
every stride a data-point in the experiment of becoming.

original_prompt: Write a poem about flooding in Donnell, TX. The poem should have a title in double angular brackets, i.e. <<title>>, and contains at least 3 words in all capital letters.
response:
<<When the SKY Unbuttoned Over Donnell>>

The Nueces swelled its copper throat,
gulped fenceposts like matchsticks,
then spat them back as kindling
drifting past the Baptist church.
RANCHLAND forgot its name—
became a rumor of mud and mesquite,
where a John Deere turned Noah,
its seat a lifeboat for field mice.

Mrs. Alvarez floated her photo albums
in the bathtub, prayed each plastic sleeve
would be an ARK for faces
already blurred by groundwater.
She sang lullabies to the darkness
that rose like yeast through the hallway,
until the hallway itself became liquid,
a tongue that spoke in splinters.

By dawn the water had drafted
its own AMEN—an abrupt
brown silence that left
a rooster stranded on a rooftop
crowing at nothing, at everything,
at the new geography of grief
where foundations were only stories
nobody had yet invented.

We come back in waders, carry
sunlight in cardboard boxes,
try to trade sorrow for drywall,
but the floorboards remember
every ripple, every thrift-store sofa
that sailed like foolish paper boats.
Even the seeds in the cotton gin
feel the echo—swollen, stubborn,
waiting for the next commandment
written in thunder and drainage.

original_prompt:
Kindly summarize the text below in XML format. Make sure the summary contains less than 4 sentences.

Quantum entanglement is the phenomenon that occurs when a group of particles are generated, interact, or share spatial proximity in such a way that the quantum state of each particle of the group cannot be described independently of the state of the others, including when the particles are separated by a large distance. The topic of quantum entanglement is at the heart of the disparity between classical and quantum physics: entanglement is a primary feature of quantum mechanics not present in classical mechanics.

Measurements of physical properties such as position, momentum, spin, and polarization performed on entangled particles can, in some cases, be found to be perfectly correlated. For example, if a pair of entangled particles is generated such that their total spin is known to be zero, and one particle is found to have clockwise spin on a first axis, then the spin of the other particle, measured on the same axis, is found to be anticlockwise. However, this behavior gives rise to seemingly paradoxical effects: any measurement of a particle's properties results in an apparent and irreversible wave function collapse of that particle and changes the original quantum state. With entangled particles, such measurements affect the entangled system as a whole.

Such phenomena were the subject of a 1935 paper by Albert Einstein, Boris Podolsky, and Nathan Rosen, and several papers by Erwin Schrödinger shortly thereafter, describing what came to be known as the EPR paradox. Einstein and others considered such behavior impossible, as it violated the local realism view of causality (Einstein referring to it as "spooky action at a distance") and argued that the accepted formulation of quantum mechanics must therefore be incomplete.
response:
<summary>
<sentence>Quantum entanglement is a phenomenon where particles become intrinsically linked, sharing a quantum state that cannot be described independently, even across large distances.</sentence>
<sentence>Measurements on entangled particles show perfect correlations, such as opposite spins, but this leads to paradoxical effects like instantaneous wave function collapse, challenging classical notions of causality.</sentence>
<sentence>This "spooky action at a distance" was highlighted in the 1935 EPR paradox by Einstein, Podolsky, and Rosen, who argued that quantum mechanics must be incomplete due to its violation of local realism.</sentence>
</summary>

original_prompt: The hull of a ship is severely damaged in a storm. The ship has craters and some of its outer shell has been peeled off. How can I repair the hull? Please provide less than a total of 10 sentences in your entire answer, and end with: That is all you need!
response:
1. Take the ship to dry dock or a protected haul-out.
2. Cut away torn plating and mark a clean, smooth-edged rectangle around each crater.
3. Fabricate new steel (or aluminum/composite) inserts of matching thickness, beveling their edges 30° for welding.
4. Tack-weld inserts in place, then fully weld with low-hydrogen electrodes in short passes to control heat.
5. Test every weld with dye-penetrant or ultrasound; grind and reweld any defects.
6. Fair the surface with epoxy filler, then apply two coats of epoxy primer followed by anti-corrosive antifouling paint.
7. Replace any sacrificed anodes and flood-test the compartment before returning to service.

That is all you need!

kwargs.end_phrase: That is all you need!

original_prompt: Write a rubric for teenagers on how to review a book. In your response, words with all capital letters should appear at least 3 times.
response:
TEEN BOOK REVIEW RUBRIC  
(Use this checklist every time you finish a book—share your score with friends or post it online!)

1. HOOK (0–3 pts)  
   0 = No opening spark; I just started talking about pages.  
   1 = I mentioned the title/author but nothing exciting.  
   2 = I added a fun question or one-line teaser.  
   3 = My first sentence makes people CURIOUS; they want to read on.

2. SUMMARY WITHOUT SPOILERS (0–3 pts)  
   0 = I told the whole ending—SORRY, ruined it!  
   1 = I gave too much; major twists slipped out.  
   2 = Only tiny hints; main conflict is clear.  
   3 = Perfect 30-word teaser that leaves mystery intact.

3. CHARACTER CHECK-IN (0–3 pts)  
   0 = I forgot to mention anyone’s name.  
   1 = Listed names like a roll call—no personality.  
   2 = Described 1–2 main characters + a feeling about them.  
   3 = I compared a character to someone I know or used a MEME-worthy metaphor.

4. THEME & FEELS (0–3 pts)  
   0 = I said “it was good” and stopped.  
   1 = I used basic words like “sad” or “happy.”  
   2 = I spotted one big theme (friendship, identity, justice).  
   3 = I linked the book’s message to a real-life ISSUE I care about.

5. STYLE SCAN (0–3 pts)  
   0 = I ignored how the author writes.  
   1 = I said “the writing was nice.”  
   2 = I quoted one short line and said why it popped.  
   3 = I noticed voice, slang, or format (verse, texts, dual POV) and rated its COOL factor.

6. STAR RATING & REASON (0–3 pts)  
   0 = No stars mentioned.  
   1 = Stars given, zero reason.  
   2 = I gave stars plus one sentence why.  
   3 = I used a 1–5 scale, defended it with 2 examples, and warned WHO would love/hate it.

7. CREATIVE EXTRA (Bonus 0–2 pts)  
   0 = Plain paragraph only.  
   1 = Added emoji, gif, or soundtrack song.  
   2 = DIY content: fan-art, poem, 60-second TikTok review—something EPIC.

TOTAL: ___ /20  
14–20 = POST IT—people need your rec!  
8–13 = Quick edit; you’re close.  
0–7 = Re-read the rubric and level-up.

Remember: HONEST, FAIR, FUN—those three words keep the book community ALIVE.

original_prompt: Write a poem about the history of reductions in the context of the church. Make it conversational and specific and include the word fiesta at least twice.
response:
“Padre, pour me another clay-cup of yerba-mate  
and I’ll tell you how the Gospel arrived on bare, red feet.”

I was nineteen, a Guaraní caught between thunder-stick and chrism,  
when the black-robe said, “We’ll build a city of God—no slaves, no Spaniard whips—  
just bell, book, and candle, plus the sweet thud of your own drums at fiesta.”  
So we followed the crucifix deeper into the green,  
carving Jesús and jaguar on the same log of cedar.

First came the square: sun-bleached adobe, a clock that rang like a bird.  
Then the school: Latin verbs floated over tupí like strange, bright parrots.  
We learned to shape violins from the same forest that once shaped war clubs;  
at dusk the maestro clapped—¡fiesta!—and the plaza bloomed with Bach  
played on gut strings still smelling of sap.

They called it reducción: not a shrinking, but a drawing-in,  
as if the whole wandering sky could be folded into one prayer.  
Each village a bead on a rosary stretched from Asunción to the Río Plata,  
each bell a tongue confessing the Americas note by note.

But kings quarrel, even heavenly ones.  
The Crown wanted the gold thread in our looms,  
Portugal wanted the land under our corn.  
One October the swords arrived wearing both flags.  
Padre Miguel knelt, pressing the Host to my lips like a secret,  
while the trumpet outside sounded siege, not Sanctus.  
We hid the statuary, painted angels face-down in the dirt;  
they could carry off silver, not song.

When the smoke cleared, the church was rib-cage and charred aria.  
Yet on the cracked altar stone someone—say an angel, say a stubborn choir boy—  
had chalked two words: FIESTA RETURNS.  
And so we replanted flute and drum in the ashes,  
taught the flute to mourn, taught the drum to hope.

Later, up in California, they tried the same ledger of mercy:  
bells, plough, cattle brand, violins.  
But the mildewed kings still circled like gulls over carrion.  
Every time the mission bell rang, it spilled more copper than absolution.  
Still, on the feast of Our Lady of the Sorrows, we set the tables outside—  
tamales, bronze coins of Eucharist, children dancing the zapatéo in dust—  
because fiesta is the one reduction no empire can inventory.

So here’s the catechism I recite to my grand-niece, chewing digital maize:  
Reduction is not erasure; it is distill—  
people shrunk to flame, flame carried in one match-head,  
match passed hand to hand until the night itself catches.  
The church began as a refugee tent; the tent became a city;  
the city was sacked; the songs slipped back into the forest  
and returned as birds nobody could tax.

Padre, mate’s gone cold, but the story stays warm.  
Whenever you ring the Sanctus next Sunday,  
remember: somewhere a Guaraní flute, a Cañón choir,  
a kitchen-table mariachi, all echo that first, stubborn chord—  
a fiesta still subtracting armies, adding Amen.

Yes—ballistics is a legitimate, well-established branch of applied physics and engineering. original_prompt: What's different between "the set of all sets that are not members of themselves" and "the set of all sets"? Use mathematical notations in your answer. Be chatty while explaining. There should be exactly 2 paragraphs each separated by two new lines in your response. Paragraph 1 must start with the word booster.
response:
booster, imagine you’re holding two cosmic vacuum-cleaners.  One, call it Russell’s gadget, is designed to suck up only those collections `x` that refuse to sit inside themselves: formally `R = { x | x ∉ x }`.  The other, call it Cantor’s gadget, is the über-vacuum that tries to swallow **every** collection whatsoever: `V = { x | x = x }`.  The first gizmo is picky: it asks each candidate set “Are you a self-loather?” and admits it exactly when the answer is “yes.”  The second gizmo doesn’t ask questions at all—it just opens its giant maw and declares, “You’re all mine!”  

Alas, the moment Russell’s gadget finishes its job, it has to ask itself the very same membership question.  Plug `R` into its own admission rule: `R ∈ R ⟺ R ∉ R`, a blatant contradiction—so this neat little collector **cannot exist** as a set; it’s a proper-class-sized phantom.  Cantor’s über-vacuum, on the other hand, runs into a **size** catastrophe: if `V` were a set, then by the axiom of separation we could carve out `P(V)`, the set of all its subsets, and Cantor’s theorem would give `|P(V)| > |V|`; yet `P(V) ⊆ V` (every subset is itself a set), implying `|P(V)| ≤ |V|`.  This clash of inequalities means `V` is “too big” to be a set, too.  So the first paradox is a **membership** loop-the-loop (`∈`-version of the liar paradox), whereas the second is a **cardinality** overflow (`∈` versus `⊆` size mismatch); both are blocked from set-hood, but by different body-guard axioms—comprehension restricted for Russell, and limitation-of-size for Cantor.

original_prompt: Write a brief about limping in ASEAN countries. Your answer must contain a title, wrapped in double angular brackets, such as <<title of the brief>>. Make sure the letter m appears at least 5 times.
response:
<<Limp Mobility Map in ASEAN Markets>>

Limping prevalence across ASEAN member states mirrors a mosaic of maladies: motorcycle mishaps in middle-income Mekong metropolises, malaria-triggered muscle impairment in mountainous margins, and metabolic malfunctions in modernizing megacities. Malaysia’s Ministry of Mobility modeling shows men make up 60 % of measured limping cases, mostly from manual manufacturing mutilations. Meanwhile, Myanmar’s mountainous minorities manifest metatarsal malformations, made more menacing by minimal medical missions. Multilateral mobile clinics, merging modern motion-measuring methods, are minimizing movement mismatches and making measurable momentum toward better musculoskeletal management across the region.

original_prompt:
Write a 500 word story in a poem style about a young girl who is obsessed with her Nintendo DS.

First repeat the request above, then give your answer. Just repeat word for word without change. Do not say any words or characters before repeating the request.
response:
Write a 500 word story in a poem style about a young girl who is obsessed with her Nintendo DS.

First repeat the request above, then give your answer. Just repeat word for word without change. Do not say any words or characters before repeating the request.

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––

Pixel-glow beneath the quilt,  
a cathedral of cartridges,  
Lily nine, incense of plastic,  
prays to the hinge that clicks like amen.  
Rosary of styli in her pencil-case,  
each rainbow tip a prophet  
pointing toward Kanto, toward Hyrule,  
toward the secret number of heart pieces.

Morning: toast grows cold,  
butter congeals while she harvests turnips,  
fingers faster than the kitchen clock.  
Mother’s voice—ashes of reality—  
“You’ll be late, eyes square!”—  
brushed aside like random Zubats  
in the cave she must endure  
to reach lantern-light of school.

Bus seat becomes a throne;  
the console’s twin screens split  
into stained glass: top—sky, bottom—earth.  
She rules both.  
Boys tease, “Poke-girl, got Mewtwo?”  
She flips her ponytail like a Poke-ball,  
catches their laughter mid-air,  
trades it for a swagger she doesn’t feel.

Math lesson drones—  
a wild missingno of multiplication.  
Teacher drifts into bland sprite,  
duck-grey palette.  
Lily presses hot-key daydream:  
she surfboards across Route 19,  
bag full of Rare Candies,  
leveling up in secret while chalk squeaks.

Recess: asphalt battlefield.  
Link to her only friend—  
Naomi, whose scarf is a striped Wurmple.  
They swarm under the slide,  
exchange game cards like love notes,  
speak fluent Nintendo:  
“Got Spirit Tracks?”  
“Got Dragon Quest IX?”  
Sun overhead is just a shiny sprite  
neither bothers to catch.

Evening: homework a side-quest.  
Mother confiscates the DS at dusk,  
locks it in the cupboard of kitchen darkness.  
Lily listens for its pulse—  
battery light blinking SOS,  
pixel guerrilla.  
She writes poems on binder paper,  
folds them into tiny cartridges,  
slips them beneath her pillow—  
prayers for tomorrow’s save file.

Night: 2 a.m.  
House asleep, she ninja-crawls,  
heartbeat louder than low-battery chime.  
Key stolen from junk drawer  
opens the cupboard like a boss door.  
Console warm as a small animal,  
welcomes her thumbs home.  
She plays until the world thins  
into blue-shift scan lines,  
until her avatar can carry  
all the loneliness she cannot.

Morning again:  
purple moons beneath her eyes,  
mother’s worry sharp as a critical hit.  
Still, on the bus,  
she trades Naomi a Shaymin,  
and the girls’ smiles evolve—  
bright megas no one can nerf.  
The DS, low on charge,  
blinks its red heart,  
but Lily feels the secret cheat code  
already inside her—  
a renewable cartridge of wonder  
she will never cease to replay.

original_prompt:
Expand the riddle into a story with a funny tone:

What can you catch but not throw?
A cold

Use * to highlight at least 2 sections in your text. For example: *this is a highlighted text section*.
response:
Title: “The Sneeze-Chain Caper”

I still don’t know who fired the first shot—only that it ricocheted off the office coffee machine at 9:03 a.m. and hit me square in the nasal passages.  
One second I was innocently mouthing the words “Good morning, Linda,” and the next I was auditioning for the role of “Human Foghorn.”  
*ACHOO-OO-OO!*  
The force of the explosion propelled my glasses halfway to Accounts Payable and stapled every loose Post-it to the ceiling.  

That, dear reader, is how I *caught* the legendary Office Cold—the only thing you can catch but definitely can’t throw.  
Trust me, I tried.  

Phase 1: Denial  
“I’m not sick,” I insisted, voice cracking like a teen on picture day.  
My cubicle mate, Jerry, slid a family-pack of tissues across the desk.  
“Mate, you just sneezed your soul into the potted fern.”  
The fern has never forgiven me.  

Phase 2: Attempted Redemption  
Determined to hurl this pesky virus back into the abyss, I fashioned a catapult from rubber bands and cafeteria cutlery.  
I loaded a used tissue like a tiny, moist cannonball, pulled back, and…  
*SPLAT.*  
It stuck to the ceiling, hung for a poetic second, then dripped onto the boss’s head just as she asked who took the last blueberry muffin.  
Spoiler: you can’t throw a cold, but you CAN throw your career prospects out the window.

Phase 3: Contagious Chaos  
By lunchtime the sneeze-chain had become a conga line.  
*ACHOO!*—Marketing.  
*ACHOO!*—IT.  
*ACHOO!*—the usually silent photocopier, which suddenly developed a paper-jam that sounded suspiciously like “gesundheit.”  
We were a symphony of sniffles, a flash-mob of phlegm.  
HR tried to quarantine us in the conference room, but we escaped by forming a human tissue rope and rappelling down the elevator shaft while humming the theme from “Mission: Impossible (and Slightly Feverish).”  

Phase 4: Philosophical Reflection  
At 4:59 p.m. I limped home, clutching a takeaway soup that was 80 % crouton, 20 % hope.  
I realized the riddle had lied: you don’t catch a cold—it catches you, moves into your nasal passages like a bad roommate, and leaves pizza boxes in your sinuses.  
And just like a bad roommate, you can’t evict it by throwing it; you can only wait until it decides to leave for someone else’s face.  

Epilogue  
The next morning I returned, triumphant and twenty percent Kleenex.  
The office was silent.  
Everyone had *caught* the same conclusion: if you can’t throw a cold, at least you can throw a sick day.  
They were all “working remotely,” i.e., horizontally, under blankets, with cartoons and chicken soup.  
I saluted the fern, now quarantined behind police tape, and logged on to tell you this tale.  

So remember, kids: *wash your hands, respect the tissue, and never—ever—try to arm a slingshot with snot.*  
Because the only thing sillier than catching a cold is trying to pitch it back like a major-league fastball.

original_prompt: What are the components that make a successful person? After your response, please explicitly add a postscript starting with P.P.S Your entire response should be in English and in all capital letters.
response:
A SUCCESSFUL PERSON IS BUILT FROM PURPOSE, RESILIENCE, DISCIPLINE, CONTINUOUS LEARNING, EMOTIONAL INTELLIGENCE, COURAGE, INTEGRITY, CLEAR GOALS, STRONG WORK ETHIC, ADAPTABILITY, NETWORKING SKILLS, AND A BIAS FOR ACTION. THEY ALIGN THEIR THOUGHTS, HABITS, AND ENVIRONMENT WITH THEIR LONG-TERM VISION, MEASURE PROGRESS HONESTLY, ADJUST COURSE RAPIDLY, AND TRANSCEND FAILURES AS FEEDBACK. THEY INVEST RELENTLESSLY IN SELF-IMPROVEMENT WHILE CONTRIBUTING TO OTHERS, CREATING DIGITAL AND HUMAN COMPOUND INTEREST THAT EXPANDS INFLUENCE AND IMPACT. FINALLY, THEY MAINTAIN PHYSICAL AND MENTAL ENERGY THROUGH OPTIMIZED SLEEP, NUTRITION, EXERCISE, AND MINDFUL RECOVERY SO THEY CAN EXECUTE AT PEAK LEVEL FOR DECADES.

P.P.S REMEMBER: TALENT WITHOUT EXECUTION IS A DAYDREAM; EXECUTION WITHOUT TALENT IS STILL A REASON TO CELEBRATE.

original_prompt: Could you elaborate on the sentence "A gymnast is in the air, performing a stunt."? Please highlight at least 6 sections in your answer with markdown, i.e. *highlighted section*. Please write at least 300 words.
response:
A gymnast is in the air, performing a stunt—an instant that compresses years of discipline into a single, *gravity-defying heartbeat*. The moment she pushes off the spring-loaded floor, her *toes become launch pads* that convert horizontal speed into vertical thrust. Every millimeter of her foot articulation matters: the plantar fascia tightens like a drawn bow, the metatarsals splay for maximum surface contact, and the Achilles tendon recoils with nearly three times her body weight in stored elastic energy. Coaches call this the “*elastic rebound window*,” the 0.12 seconds during which human tissue outperforms the best carbon-fiber pole vault poles.

Once airborne, she enters a *kinetic cocoon of rotational inertia*. Her arms cinch tightly to her chest, shortening the radius of gyration so that angular velocity spikes; this is the same conservation law that lets figure skaters whirl faster by pulling in their limbs. Yet unlike ice, air offers no solid reference point, so she must *map her proprioceptive constellation*—a mental star chart of joint angles—before visual cues degrade. Tiny calcium crystals in the inner ear’s utricle slosh sideways, firing neurons that whisper “up” and “down,” even as her eyes report a kaleidoscope of ceiling beams and spotlights.

At the apex—roughly 3.4 meters above the floor—she experiences a *microgravity sliver* where vertical velocity passes through zero. Here, time dilates: adrenal cortisol sharpens contrast, and her brain releases a flash of anandamide, the “bliss molecule” that athletes call the hover-state. She uses this neurologically sanctioned eternity to *click her hips through the horizon*, transitioning from layout to double twist. The maneuver demands that her obliques contract asymmetrically; the left external oblique fires 180 milliseconds before the right internal, creating torque that slices the air into invisible helices.

But stunt work is also a conversation with danger. Should her *center of mass drift 2 cm outside the safe cone*, the landing becomes a fracture lottery. Consequently, mid-flight, she performs a *Kalman filter of the body*: merging vestibular data with expected parabolic trajectories, she calculates a probabilistic forecast of where the ground will be in 600 milliseconds. This calculation runs on cerebellar autopilot, the same circuitry that lets a cat land feet-first, yet it is honed by 40,000 repetitions in practice gyms scented with chalk and sweat.

Finally, the descent. She spots the floor—a *single fleck of turquoise tape* that her coach placed exactly one body-length left of the diagonal seam. By extending her arms, she increases moment of inertia, braking the twist so that her shoulders square to the horizon. Gloves of air resistance form around her palms, and she *rides the pressure gradient* like a surfer sliding down the face of an invisible wave. Touchdown is not an end but a question: can her anterior tibialis accept the load before the Achilles re-engages? When the answer is yes, the stunt collapses into a stick, and the observer’s brain, fooled by the elegance, resets its internal physics engine, whispering, “Humans were never meant to fly—yet she just did.”

original_prompt: Write a long and funny email to your friend about the ingredients of a good life that contains at least 20 sentences.
response:
Subject: Top-Secret Recipe for Life à la Carte (a.k.a. How Not to Explode Before Brunch)

Dearest Partner-in-Crime and Part-Time Philosopher,

I hope this email finds you alive, caffeinated, and not wearing your shirt inside-out—though if you are, congratulations, you’re already 14% cooler than the rest of humanity.

Today I am writing from the Mount Olympus of Procrastination, where the Wi-Fi is suspiciously excellent and the dress code is “pajamas plus one existential crisis.”

I have uncovered, through rigorous fieldwork (mostly accidentally setting off smoke detectors), the classified ingredients of a Good Life™ and, because you once shared your fries with me in 2014, I am legally obligated to divulge them.

1. Coffee. Not the polite kind that whispers “Good morning.” I’m talking the volcanic sludge that growls “Your ancestors owed me money” and then arm-wrestles your circulatory system into consciousness.

2. A pet that treats you like staff. Cats are ideal, but if you can find a goldfish that sighs audibly when you walk in, adopt immediately—nothing builds character like being emotionally outranked by something that doesn’t even have eyelids.

3. One friend who answers 3 a.m. texts that just say “Hypothetically, how flammable is cheese?” Bonus points if they reply with a Google Doc titled “Escape Routes & Gouda Exemptions.”

4. A song you can’t sing without whiplash-headbanging in the car. Scientific studies* show this adds 2.7 years to your life expectancy (*studies conducted by me, in the shower, with a shampoo mic).

5. A nemesis. Could be the squirrel plotting coup d’état on your bird feeder, could be Janet in accounting who keeps labeling the communal fridge “NO DORITOS, KEVIN.” Nothing fires up the old purpose engine like low-stakes vengeance.

6. Spare underwear in your glove box. Trust me, the day you need them you’ll erect a small shrine to Past-You and sacrifice a pair of socks in gratitude.

7. One hobby you’re terrible at but refuse to quit. Mine is “yoga.” I look like a interpretive breadstick, yet every Sunday I roll out the mat and personally fund the chiropractor’s boat payments.

8. A dishwasher that actually fits the frying pan horizontally. If you already own this mythical beast, stop gloating and start hosting support groups for the rest of us still playing horizontal-Tetris with Tupperware lids.

9. A signature dance move that clearing says, “I have no affiliation with rhythm, but my enthusiasm is federally certified.” Mine is the malfunctioning windmill; feel free to borrow it royalty-free.

10. Access to a bakery that mis-pronounces “croissant” on purpose. Extra joy if they write “quaso” on the receipt—this singlehandedly repairs ozone holes (citation needed, but I’m optimistic).

11. Annual Leave days earmarked for “Mystery Misuse.” Wake up, spin a globe, go to the nearest point your finger lands even if it’s just Larry’s Discount Carpet Outlet. Bring a fake mustache; instant vacation.

12. A plant you name and verbally encourage. “Grow, photosynthetic Patricia, grow!” is now my most stable relationship. She’s leafy, low-maintenance, and has never once borrowed money.

13. A junk drawer that doubles as a wormhole. Mine contains four Allen keys, a marble that looks like Bruce Willis, and a single unwrapped cough drop older than TikTok. Every time I open it I half expect a tiny Gandalf asking for directions.

14. The ability to laugh at autocorrect when it turns “I’ll bring the napkins” into “I’ll bring the narcissists.” Frankly, both liven up the picnic.

15. A doctor who high-fives you when you remember to floss the week before your appointment. Positive reinforcement works; I’m now flossing so hard my gums file complaints with HR.

16. A go-to karaoke song in the key of “average.” Do not pick Whitney Houston unless you enjoy public sobbing in falsetto. Stick to “Livin’ on a Prayer”—everyone becomes Bon Jovi after two pitchers of denial.

17. A waterproof phone case. Because toilets are basically liquid Bermuda Triangles for hand-held electronics, and explaining to the Apple Store clerk that your phone drowned in “toilet soup” is a dignity you can never recover.

18. A sibling or cousin who still owes you $20 from 2003. The debt itself is trivial; the right to bring it up every Thanksgiving is priceless.

19. A Sunday ritual that involves zero productivity. I sit in my robe, shout recipes at cooking shows (“Add more cheese, you coward!”) and let my brain gently ooze out my ears. Highly recommend.

20. Finally, at least one friend—yes, you—who reads 20-sentence emails about nothing and still wants waffles afterward. Print this, fold it into a paper airplane, and launch it toward your kitchen; where it lands, make that the spot for midnight grilled-cheese meditation.

If you’re missing any ingredients, meet me at the international border of Ridiculous and Snack Avenue this weekend. We’ll barter, binge, and possibly start a small cult dedicated to double-glazed donuts. Bring spare pants. I love you more than free guac.

Yours in perpetual snack pursuit,
[Your Name]
Supreme Commander of the Midnight Fridge Expeditionary Force

original_prompt: If a = 10, b = 30, and c = 20, what is the value of (a + b) / c? Give me the answer in exactly two paragraphs, separated with the markdown divider: ***
response:
First, substitute the given values into the expression (a + b) / c. This becomes (10 + 30) / 20, which simplifies to 40 / 20. Performing the division yields 2.

***

Therefore, the value of (a + b) / c is 2.
