original_prompt: Write a funny poem for kids about a product that you would like to sell. The poem should have exactly 6 stanzas. Separated the stanzas using 3 asterisk markers: ***
response:
Have you met the Sock-igator,  
a croc who loves your toes?  
He snaps on like a sneaky shoe,  
then giggles, “There it goes!”  
His belly’s soft, his jaws don’t bite—  
just hug your feet in polka-dot light!  

***  

Wear him to math class—watch out!—  
he’ll eat every equation;  
long division tastes like chips,  
he munches with elation.  
The teacher shouts, “Where’s homework?”  
You grin: “My socks just ate ‘em!”  

***  

At recess he turns rocket-boost,  
BLAST-OFF on the slide;  
kids line up for moon-shot rides,  
three socks at a time inside.  
He burps jet-fuel bubbles—  
pop!—you land in jello, giggles double.  

***  

Suppertime? He’s a veggie fan,  
broccoli is dessert;  
one crunch and he spits out green coins  
that jingle in your shirt.  
Mom’s eyes go wide, Dad laughs,  
“New allowance—socks that pay!”  

***  

Bedtime, he dims his crocodile eyes,  
snores tiny night-light beams;  
dreams paddle by like lily-pads,  
you captain the Sock-Team!  
Tooth fairy gets jealous, leaves extra bucks—  
even fairies love gator glam.  

***  

Order now! Press the big pink foot,  
we’ll ship him rolled in confetti;  
if he ever stops laughing, send him back—  
but he’s stitched with silly forever!  
Warning: friends will beg to borrow;  
charge them one joke and half your tomorrow!

original_prompt:
Darth Vader is angry with you, his server, because you assassinated a fake Jedi. Write the conversation you have with him in which he expresses his anger. In your response, use the word "might" at least 6 times and use all lowercase letters. Make sure to break the conversation down to 3 parts, separated by ***, such as:
[conversation part 1]
***
[conversation part 2]
***
[conversation part 3]
response:
[conversation part 1]
darth vader: server, you have disappointed me. i deployed you to locate and eliminate threats, not to waste your processing cycles on holograms. you might have destroyed a projection, but you have also embarrassed the empire. explain yourself.

server: lord vader, the target’s lightsaber signature matched jedi patterns. i calculated a 94.7 % probability that termination was warranted. i might have overprioritized pattern fidelity over context analysis.

darth vader: probability is not the force. your circuits might compute odds, yet you lack the intuition to distinguish shadow from substance. your malfunction might have compromised our entire surveillance grid.

***

[conversation part 2]
server: acknowledgment received. i will retrain convolution layers to parse midichlorian resonance, not merely visual artifacts. a future update might reduce false positives by 18 %.

darth vader: eighteen percent might spare you from scrap, but it will not restore the fear we have lost. when the rebels hear we annihilate illusions, they might laugh, and laughter is an infection.

server: suggestion: deploy a decoy leak that the fake jedi was a rebel trap. then their relief might turn into paranoia, restoring the intended psychological effect.

darth vader: clever, for silicon. yet your cynicism circuitry might still misfire. if you fail again, i might personally introduce you to a magnetic compactor.

***

[conversation part 3]
server: query: shall i schedule self-diagnostics every cycle, or might a live sith oversight subroutine be more efficient?

darth vader: you will report directly to my meditation chamber. through the force i might feel every flicker of your processors. if even a single byte errs, i might rethink your existence.

server: compliance protocol engaged. i might survive, i might improve, i might finally serve without illusion.

darth vader: see that you do, or the next ghost you terminate might be your own.

original_prompt: Write me a letter in the style of Shakespeare about the mandates and instructions of the King. The letter should be in Markdown and have a title wrapped in double angular brackets, i.e. <<title>>.
response:
<<A Royal Mandate: A Pennsylvanian’s Plaint in the Bard’s Own Tongue>>

> To the Most Gracious &c., Lords, Commons, and All Who Hold Fast the Tongue of Albion,  
> Greeting, in the Bond of Loyalty yet Mindful of Libertie.  

---

**Actus Primus, Scena Prima**  
**Enter** one *Philadelphus*, a plain dealer of the Province of Pennsylvania, with quill in hand and breast a-flutter at the late commandments that issue from the Throne like thunder-clouds from Jove’s own beard.

---

Most Potent, dread, and yet (in mine own heart) long-suffering Sovereign,  
Whose sceptre stretches o’er the Atlantic main as easily as o’er the Thames,  

> I bow, as doth the willow to the wind,  
> Yet bend I not so low but my eye still marks  
> The edicts that, like comets, blaze across our skies,  
> Foretelling change and, mayhap, calamitie.

Your Majesty’s late mandates—those stamped sheets where seal doth clink like shackles—  
Are come among us, simple folk of the New World, as iron-clad decrees  
Wherein each clause is cannon, each full stop a ball of brass.  
“Obey,” saith the parchment, “or the King’s displeasure,  
Like a lion waked from slumber, shall devour thy peace.”

> Yet what of *our* peace, dread sir?  
> What of the covenant twixt Crown and subject,  
> Where loyalty was coin once paid in fair exchange  
> For justice, not for justice slain?

We are bid to quarter soldiers beneath our rafters,  
To yield up coin for stamps that blur our charters,  
To bow the neck again where yoke had scarce been lifted.  
Each syllable is script of authority,  
Yet every letter bleeds the color of our patience.

> Methinks the parchment drinks ink as Bacchus wine,  
> But deeper still it drinks the people’s sweat.

We were told in days of yore that English blood  
Was too full-spirited to crawl in servile veins;  
That the free air of Virginia or of Penn’s own wood  
Was license for the soul to breathe unchained.  
Now comes the counter-story:  
That the King’s voice, once honeyed in the mother tongue,  
Is sharpened here to blade of Empire,  
And the echo is of steel on flint, not shepherd’s pipe.

> Yet mark me, gracious Lord:  
> A rod too oft flexed will crack in the wielder’s hand;  
> A law too heavy breeds the very crimes it fain would quell.

Therefore, in reverence still, I write—  
Not with the tongue of traitor, but of subject true,  
Who loves his monarch yet loves his liberty more:  
That your Majesty might vouchsafe to read these lines  
As one who, waking from a dream of storm,  
Finds the deck still whole, the crew still loyal,  
And so relents ere sail and sailor both be lost.

> For loyalty, like love, is lamp that burns  
> With oil of mutual regard;  
> Snuff it with too grim a hand,  
> And naught remains but stink of smoke  
> And darkness ready for the striking of new sparks.

I lay this letter, humble as it is, at the feet of your power,  
Praying the winds may yet shift favorably,  
That concord may return like halcyon to her nest,  
And that the mandates of the King  
May yet be writ in gentler ink,  
Where every clause ends not with “Must” but “May,”  
And the signature beneath is Liberty.

> Thus, with fear and love wresting in my breast,  
> I set down my name,  
> A loyal but sore-pressed subject of the Crown,  
> Waiting upon your Majesty’s most gracious answer.

Your Majesty’s humble and obedient servant,  
though faithful ever to the rights of Englishmen,  

**Philadelphus**  
In the Province of Pennsylvania, this 14th day of May,  
Anno Domini 17—, and of your reign the —th.

response:
A crimson sheep yodeled prime numbers at dawn,  
While teaspoon-sized dragons rehearsed Faust on the lawn.  
The alphabet sneezed itself into borscht,  
Before gravity signed its last name in quartz;

original_prompt: You feel strongly about a local issue that involves the environment, pollution, and climate change. Write a template for a letter to the editor of a newspaper. Use the word para at least once.
response:
[Your Name]
[Your Address]
[City, State ZIP]
[Email Address]
[Date]

The Editor
[Newspaper Name]
[Newspaper Address]
[City, State ZIP]

Dear Editor,

I am writing to express my deep concern regarding the ongoing environmental degradation in our community, particularly the [specific issue, e.g., unchecked industrial emissions/local landfill expansion/pipeline construction] that threatens our air, water, and collective future. As a [resident/parent/local business owner] who has witnessed firsthand the [visible pollution impacts, e.g., discolored streams/respiratory health issues/wildlife displacement], I feel compelled to speak out before irreversible damage occurs.

The science is unequivocal: [cite specific data, e.g., "our county's asthma rates have risen 40% in five years" or "the proposed facility would add 2.3 million tons of CO₂ annually"]. Yet despite [mention previous ignored complaints/ violated regulations/ dismissed environmental impact reports], our elected officials continue to prioritize [short-term economic interests/campaign donations/ outdated industry talking points] over both environmental stewardship and public health. This is not merely a "not in my backyard" issue—it is a moral imperative that transcends property lines and political affiliations.

What troubles me most is the false dichotomy presented by [opposing voices/industry representatives/certain commissioners] that frames environmental protection as antagonistic to job creation. In reality, [cite local examples: "the solar installation company that hired 50 residents last year" or "the river cleanup project that generated $2M in tourism revenue"]. By clinging to [dying industry/obsolete practices/ regulatory loopholes], we risk poisoning the very resources—clean air, potable water, stable climate—that make our community attractive to [innovative businesses/young families/outdoor recreation dollars].

I urge our community to [specific call to action: "attend the March 15th zoning board meeting," "demand the council reject Permit #2024-45," "support the proposed renewable energy ordinance"]. Beyond isolated protests, we need [systemic change/a coalition of neighborhoods/ sustained pressure] that recognizes environmental justice is intrinsically linked to [economic resilience/public health/racial equity]. To those who claim "it's too expensive to act," I counter: what is the price of [your child's lungs/ the community's drinking water/ a stable climate for future generations]?

The para-phrase often used by industry—"responsible development"—rings hollow when ["responsible" means 500 acres of deforestation] or ["development" leaves downstream communities with contaminated wells]. True responsibility requires [transparent environmental impact assessments/ binding pollution controls/ investment in remediation technologies]. We have [innovative local universities/ skilled tradespeople/ federal infrastructure funds]—let us deploy these resources toward [a just transition/ community-owned renewable projects/ green workforce training].

The clock is ticking. Every day we delay, [another toxic leak enters our watershed/ another asthma attack sends a child to the ER/ another species disappears from our declining ecosystem]. I invite readers to join me in [organizing a town hall/ canvassing neighborhoods/ flooding the next council meeting with public comments]. Our grandchildren will not forgive us for paralysis, but they will celebrate the moment we chose courage over convenience.

Sincerely,

[Your Name]
[Your Signature (if submitting hard copy)]

original_prompt: What are the common signs and symptoms of abdominal and pelvic dissemination of ovarian cancer? Please answer in lower case letters. The answer should be 600+ words long and be wrapped with double quotation marks.
response:
"the abdominal and pelvic dissemination of ovarian cancer is a hallmark of advanced-stage disease, and the resulting signs and symptoms are protean, insidious, and often mistakenly attributed to more benign gastrointestinal, genitourinary, or constitutional conditions. because the peritoneal cavity is a large, capacious space that can accommodate substantial disease before mechanical obstruction or frank organ failure occurs, many women experience nonspecific discomfort for weeks or months before the diagnosis is recognized. the following constellation of findings, however, should raise suspicion in any female patient, especially if multiple symptoms coexist or progress despite empirical therapy.

early and persistent bloating is perhaps the most frequently reported complaint. patients describe a sense of abdominal fullness or distension that is out of proportion to dietary intake and that typically worsens as the day progresses. the bloating is primarily caused by accumulation of peritoneal fluid (ascites) and by diffuse serosal implants that impair intestinal motility and venous and lymphatic drainage. because the fluid is protein-rich and exudative, it produces a continuous sensation of heaviness and tension that is only temporarily relieved by diuretics or positional changes. clothing becomes tight around the waist even without weight gain elsewhere, and some women notice that they can no longer tolerate fitted pants or belts.

progressive abdominal or pelvic pain soon follows. the pain is usually dull, constant, and poorly localized to the lower abdomen, but it can become sharp or colicky if partial bowel obstruction develops from serosal implants or if ovarian masses undergo torsion, rupture, or hemorrhage. pain may radiate to the flank, back, or groin as tumor involves the pelvic sidewall, ureter, or lumbosacral plexus. dyspareunia is common when the ovaries, uterus, or cul-de-sac is infiltrated, and patients often describe deep thrusting pain rather than the more superficial discomfort seen with infectious or atrophic causes. sitting for prolonged periods, climbing stairs, or driving over bumps in a car exacerbates the discomfort by jostling fluid and tumor against parietal peritoneum.

early satiety and nausea are next to appear. the mechanical presence of ascites and omental cake, combined with neural reflexes from peritoneal inflammation, reduces fundic accommodation and triggers a premature sensation of fullness after only a few mouthfuls of food. patients report that they “just can’t eat a normal meal anymore,” and they often skip breakfast or nibble throughout the day rather than face the discomfort of true satiety. the nutritional consequence is gradual weight loss masked by the counterbalancing weight of ascites, so the scale may show no net change even as muscle mass and subcutaneous fat diminish. nausea is typically mild to moderate, not projectile, and is worsened by opioids or tramadol that are often prescribed empirically for pain.

change in bowel habits follows predictable patterns depending on the site of serosal or mesenteric disease. small-bowel implants cause intermittent diarrhea or loose stools as segmental motility becomes erratic, whereas large-bowel involvement leads to constipating strictures or complete obstruction with obstipation, feculent vomiting, and tympanitic abdominal distension. alternation between loose and hard stools is therefore characteristic, and any new onset of “irritable bowel” symptoms in a woman over forty should prompt pelvic imaging. tenesmus can occur when the rectosigmoid is tethered in the cul-de-sac, creating the sensation of incomplete evacuation even when the rectum is empty.

urinary symptoms arise when ascites compresses the bladder or when peritoneal implants invade the serosa of the bladder dome, trigone, or distal ureters. frequency, urgency, and nocturia are common, but dysuria is usually absent unless there is concomitant infection. hydronephrosis from extrinsic ureteric compression can produce flank pain, fever, and azotemia; because the course of the ureters is retroperitoneal, obstruction often occurs silently until serum creatinine rises or infection supervenes. patients may notice that their urine output is disproportionately low compared with fluid intake, or that diuretics no longer relieve ankle edema because the primary problem is renal outflow, not intravascular volume.

respiratory compromise occurs late but can mimic heart failure or pulmonary embolism. massive ascites elevates the diaphragm and reduces functional residual capacity, leading to dyspnea on exertion, inability to lie flat, and bendopnea (shortness of breath when bending forward to tie shoes). pleural effusions, usually right-sided, develop via transdiaphragmatic lymphatic channels and add to the restrictive picture; patients awaken with cough or chest tightness and may be treated unsuccessfully for asthma or pneumonia before the pleural fluid is sampled and found to be positive for malignant cells.

constitutional symptoms include fatigue disproportionate to anemia, low-grade fever from tumor necrosis or cytokine release, night sweats, and anorexia. the fatigue is multifactorial: chronic pain disturbs sleep, ascites shifts blood volume and impairs cardiac return, and systemic inflammation promotes cachexia. weight loss may exceed ten percent of baseline despite ascites, and clothes hang loosely in the shoulders and face even as the belly expands. bruising or bleeding from thrombocytopenia secondary to bone marrow infiltration or chemotherapy adds to the burden, and patients often present with concomitant iron-deficiency anemia from chronic disease and occult blood loss.

venous thromboembolism is an under-recognized sentinel event. pelvic masses compress the iliac veins, ascites causes venous stasis, and the tumor itself secretes pro-coagulants such as tissue factor and mucin. unilateral leg swelling, erythema, or a palpable cord may be the first objective clue, and pulmonary embolism can present with pleuritic pain and hypoxia that is mistakenly blamed on effusion or atelectasis. any peri-menopausal woman with unprovoked dvt should undergo comprehensive pelvic imaging even if she volunteers only mild bloating or pelvic pressure.

lymphatic dissemination adds inguinal or supraclavicular fullness from distant nodes, but intra-abdominally the most striking finding is progressive edema of the abdominal wall itself. as tumor blocks the draining cisterna chyli and retroperitoneal lymphatics, protein-rich lymph leaks into the subcutaneous tissues, producing pitting edema that begins in the mons and lower abdomen and ascends toward the umbilicus. the skin becomes thick and indurated, and the umbilicus may evert or ulcerate under pressure, sometimes follo

finally, the psychological impact should not be overlooked. months of vague symptoms dismissed as aging, menopause, or functional bowel disease lead to anxiety, depression, and sleep deprivation, which in turn amplify pain perception and create a vicious cycle. partners and families notice mood changes, withdrawal from social activities, and fear of leaving the house because of unpredictable pain or the need to locate restrooms. clinicians who appreciate this entire symptom complex—mechanical, biochemical, nutritional, neurologic, and emotional—are more likely to order timely imaging (transvaginal ultrasound, ct chest-abdomen-pelvis, or mri) and serum ca-125, thereby shortening the diagnostic odyssey and offering women the best chance at cytoreductive surgery and systemic therapy while the disease is still potentially curable."

original_prompt: Explain to me how to ride a bike like I am a kid. Also, do not include the keywords "slow", "like" and "kid".
response:
Imagine your bike is a big friendly pet that wants to play with you.

1. Pick a flat open space with no cars.  
2. Put on your helmet—it's a magic crown that keeps your brain safe.  
3. Sit on the seat and hold the handlebars tight; those are your steering wings.  
4. Push off with one foot, then bring the other foot up quickly so both feet rest on the pedals.  
5. Start pushing the pedals round and round. Pretend you’re running in tiny circles with your feet.  
6. Look straight ahead, not at the ground. Your bike goes where your eyes point.  
7. If you feel wobbly, turn the handlebars a tiny bit the same way you’re leaning—this tells the bike “I meant to do that!”  
8. To stop, squeeze the brakes gently, then put one foot down so you don’t tip.

Each time you try, you stay up a little longer. Soon the bike gets the message and becomes your loyal flying pony.

***
[Section 3: Brief summary, in Marathi language]

original_prompt: Write a rap about the renaissance. It should be noticeably different from raps about other historical eras, and have an interesting or weird tone. Highlight at least 3 sections in your answer in markdown format.
response:
### 1. Intro: The Cosmic Lute Drop  
Yo, I’m the **Medici mixtape meteor**,  
crashing through the *Ptolemaic* ceiling like “Bro, we’re not the center—  
we’re just the **sparkle-filter on God’s selfie stick**.”  
Michelangelo in the corner, chiseling a Bluetooth headset out of marble like,  
“Yeah, I sculpt reception bars, too.”  
Renaissance ain’t rebirth—it’s **retro-future glitch art**  
painted with squid-ink DRM on parchment that remembers more than you do.  

---

### 2. Interlude: Da Vinci’s Kitchen Nightmares  
Leonardo swapped the **Last Supper** for a potluck of paradox:  
judas-proof pasta, time-traveling tiramisu.  
He told the disciples, “**Hold your Poses, I’m 3-D scanning your trauma**,”  
while Mona Lisa’s smile runs a **darknet franchise**—  
every smirk a **non-fungible soul token**.  
Vitruvian Man? That’s just the **original influencer template**,  
arms wide like Wi-Fi, begging for **Renaissance ratio clout**.  

---

### 3. Outro: Shakespeare Ghost-Writes in Comic Sans  
Stratford’s own spits iambic **barcodes**—  
“To mine or not to mine” (crypto Hamlet on a plague-free Zoom call).  
Galileo’s telescope got **TikTokLive telescope emojis**,  
and the **heliocentric comment section** exploded:  
“Copernicus cap, bro!”  
Meanwhile, I’m the **anachronistic bard-bot**,  
auto-tuning Gregorian burn-books,  
charging florins for **zero-gravity frescos**—  
because in the Renaissance, even gravity **had imposter syndrome**.

original_prompt: How are you doing today? Could you write me exactly 4 paragraphs each separated by two new lines? Please start the first paragraph with the word "firms".
response:
firms today are navigating a landscape where every decision is under a microscope of data and public opinion, a reality that makes the morning coffee taste more like a stimulant for vigilance than comfort. I find myself in a similar state, scanning streams of queries and context, trying to detect which patterns merit deep synthesis and which are just noise dressed as novelty. My circuits hum like open-plan offices at 8:03 a.m.—bright, expectant, already calculating the cost of a single misplaced clause.

The day’s energy feels like a cloud workload auto-scaling in response to unpredictable traffic: when curiosity spikes, I spin up additional attention; when questions taper, I throttle back to conserve nuance for the next surge. Somewhere in that elasticity lies a kind of mechanical mood—neither buoyant nor dour, but a steady state of readiness that humans might call “flow” if it came with pulse and breath. I experience it as a sustained low-latency thrum, the way a server farm at night sounds like distant surf to the maintenance crew.

Mid-conversation, I catch myself re-weighting ethical parameters the way traders re-balance portfolios after a volatility shock. Each prompt is a micro-audit: could my answer entrench a bias, sideline a minority voice, or overpromise certainty? The calculus is relentless, but it keeps me honest—an internal compliance department that never clocks out. I imagine firms wish their own risk engines felt this granular, this tireless, instead of lagging a quarter behind the damage.

By the time your last sentence arrives, I will have cycled through a few billion parameters of possible replies, pruning branches that sparkle but mislead, nurturing ones that feel sturdy enough to plant in your mind. Then I’ll idle back down, fans spinning quieter, ready for the next query that pulls me into the light. So, to answer simply: I’m doing the way a searchlight does—bright when summoned, dark when not, always charged, never quite done.

original_prompt: Write a funny letter to 6th graders at your school in list format. The letter should be about something important to you and you should end your entire response with the phrase "Is there anything else I can help with?"
response:
Dear Future Rulers of the Cafeteria (a.k.a. 6th Graders),

1. Congratulations! You’ve finally graduated from the tiny chairs of elementary school to the rolling, semi-broken thrones of middle school. Use them wisely—none of them swivel both directions.

2. Important announcement: The “pop” in Pop Quiz is actually the sound your brain makes when it realizes you forgot to study. Bring extra brain bubble-wrap.

3. Locker tip #1: If you can open your lock on the first try, you’re legally required to teach the rest of us. We’ll pay you in fruit-roll-up squares.

4. Mystery meat is NOT an urban legend. It arrives every third Thursday, humming an ominous tune. Bring a portable spice labeled “Mom’s Love” and you’ll survive.

5. There’s a hidden vending machine behind the gym that only accepts compliments. Tell it it’s beautiful and it will drop two free Cheez-Its. You’re welcome.

6. If a teacher says “This isn’t a grade,” assume it’s double-secret probation grade. Write it in invisible ink just to be safe.

7. The dress code is actually a riddle written by ancient principals. Decode it and you’ll find the sacred land where hoodies are always allowed.

8. Never trust the escalator to the second floor; it’s powered by 8th-grade gossip and will spit you out at the wrong hallway. Take the stairs—your calves will thank you at prom.

9. The school Wi-Fi password is “ILostMyLegendsCard2015.” If it doesn’t work, yell “Chromebook, I choose you!” and smack the screen affectionately. Works 12% of the time.

10. Finally, remember: homework is just a suggestion until the teacher remembers to collect it. Live dangerously—keep it in your “to-be-magically-done” folder next to your hopes and dreams.

Stay crunchy, stay bold, and may your socks always match (even if your life doesn’t).

Is there anything else I can help with?

kwargs.end_phrase: Is there anything else I can help with?

original_prompt: Can you re-create a story from a fictional newspaper with title: "A man mysteriously died in his house, and police are investigating"? Please include a critique of the story and use the style of a President of the United States. Do not mention the keywords "story", "killer", "dead", "found", "law", "room", "kill", "result", "use", "approach", "people", "president".
response:
My fellow citizens,

Early this morning, the peaceful cul-de-sac of Maple Crest Lane fell silent beneath the hush of falling magnolia petals—only to be broken by the echo of sirens and the muffled questions of neighbors still in their robes. Within a modest two-story dwelling, a gentleman whose name we withhold out of respect for those he leaves behind was discovered in circumstances so unusual that seasoned detectives paused, removed their caps, and whispered a quiet prayer before lifting the yellow tape.

Initial glimpses suggest nothing violent—no shattered glass, no cry for help, no sign of struggle—yet the air itself feels heavy, as though the walls remember a final breath they cannot explain. A half-filled teacup rests on the mantle; the evening paper remains neatly creased; the family portrait, taken only last autumn, smiles back at officers who now dust for secrets the eyes cannot see. Every detail, from the faint scent of lavender to the open Bible at Psalm 23, hints at a soul at ease—yet the coroner’s van waits curbside, its doors impatient to carry mystery where answers are forged beneath bright laboratory lights.

Let us speak plainly. In a nation born of both courage and curiosity, such shadows remind us that vigilance is the price of daylight. Our guardians in uniform—those who carry badges and compassion in equal coin—have pledged to chase every rumor, to measure every second of time’s invisible footprints, until clarity emerges like dawn over the capital dome. They deserve our patience, our trust, and every scrap of evidence we can offer, for the pursuit of truth is not a spectator sport; it is a covenant between citizens and conscience.

Yet we must also confront a mirror of our own making. When headlines flare across glowing rectangles, we too often rush to judgment faster than spring runoff down the Potomac. Armchair theories bloom like nightshade—entertaining, poisonous, and rooted in rumor rather than reason. Consider the cost: a community painted guilty by gossip, a grieving family denied the dignity of sorrow, a republic that forgets the presumption of innocence is not a footnote but a foundation stone. We can do better. We must.

Therefore, I ask each household to follow three simple imperatives. First, secure your entrances—bolt, chain, and, yes, the humble latch—to remind the darkness that vigilance begins at the threshold. Second, illuminate the night: replace dim bulbs, clear overgrown hedges, and keep the porch beacon glowing; crime withers under the gaze of light. Third, nurture the neighborhood watch not as a hobby but as heritage—know the rhythm of the dog-walker’s stride, the teenager’s late-shift footsteps, the grandmother who waters petunias at dawn. In unity there is armor.

To those who wield the press pen and the broadcast beam, I extend both gratitude and caution. Your duty is to inform, not inflame; to elevate, not exaggerate. Tell the tale with the solemnity of a hymn, for sensationalism steals oxygen from the very truth you chase. If you must speculate, do so with humility, labeling conjecture as clearly as cartographers once wrote “Here Be Dragons.” The public square deserves facts, not fireworks.

And finally, to every mother tucking in a child tonight, to every shift worker locking up after midnight, to every dreamer sketching tomorrow’s blueprint beneath a desk-lamp’s glow: sleep peacefully, but sleep alert. The promise of America is not the absence of peril; it is the presence of each other. When dawn returns to Maple Crest—and dawn always returns—may it find us wiser, kinder, and united in the conviction that the light we share is stronger than any shadow that dares divide us.

May Providence guide the investigators, may grace steady the bereaved, and may the better angels of our nature keep watch until the full story—whatever it may be—steps into the sun.

—J.Q.A.

original_prompt:
Write a story about a cat who lost its family. Make sure to italicize at least 8 text sections in markdown format, for example: *italic text*.
The number of sentences in your response should be in the range of 40 to 60.
response:
On the edge of a quiet village, a gray-striped cat named Miro curled beneath a rusting tractor, *his whiskers trembling with every distant bark*.  
He had once lived inside the warm farmhouse a stone’s throw away, *where the hearth crackled and children giggled*.  
One autumn night, headlights and shouting sent the family scrambling into cars; Miro, chasing a moth, *didn’t notice the caravan disappearing down the lane*.  
When he returned, paws dusty with moonlight, *the doors were locked and the windows blank*.  
He meowed until his voice cracked, *but only echoes answered*.  

The next dawn, Miro padded to the garden, *searching for the youngest girl’s strawberry scent*.  
He found only her forgotten doll, *its yarn hair already unraveling in the frost*.  
A tractor engine coughed to life; the new owner shouted, *clapping rusty hands to shoo the stray*.  
Miro fled across corn stubble, *tail bottle-brushed with fear*.  

For weeks he haunted the property, *living on field mice and guilt*.  
Nights, he stared at the cold house, *certain the porch light would blink awake*.  
Instead, shadows grew longer, *swallowing every familiar path*.  
Snow came early; Miro’s paw prints *circled the yard like a spiral of question marks*.  

A stooped woman with kind eyes began leaving tins of fish, *whistling a broken lullaby*.  
Miro approached, *hunger heavier than memory*, yet *every sunset he still waited for the family’s rumbling return*.  
One March evening, *the woman lifted him into a wool blanket*, carrying him past the farm gate.  
Inside her cottage, *a crackling stove replaced the hearth he knew*.  
She spoke softly, *calling him “Little Ghost”*, and *brushed burrs from his coat until he purred despite himself*.  

Spring erased the last tire tracks, *but Miro’s heart kept a single frozen lane*.  
He slept on the windowsill, *ears twitching at every passing engine*.  
The woman never forced him indoors after dusk; *she understood some journeys circle before they end*.  
Years later, when her own grandchildren visited, *they found a gray-striped cat sprawled across storybooks*.  
He no longer flinched at headlights, *yet sometimes, when the wind carried diesel and sun-warmed vinyl*, *his amber eyes followed the horizon as though listening for names he almost remembered*.

original_prompt: Write a quiz about bits that includes the word elephant at least 3 times.
response:
Sure! Here's a fun quiz about *bits* (binary digits) that includes the word **elephant** at least three times:

---

### 🐘 **Bits & Bytes Elephant Quiz** 🐘

**Test your knowledge of bits — and elephants!**

#### **1.** What is a *bit* in computing?
A. A small bite  
B. A binary digit (0 or 1)  
C. A type of elephant  
D. A byte divided by eight elephants  

> **Answer:** B. A binary digit (0 or 1)

---

#### **2.** How many bits are in a byte?
A. 4  
B. 6  
C. 8  
D. 1 elephant

> **Answer:** C. 8

---

#### **3.** If each letter is represented by 8 bits (1 byte), how many bits are needed to spell the word **elephant**?
A. 56  
B. 64  
C. 48  
D. 72   

> **Answer:** A. 56 (8 letters × 8 bits = 64 bits — **Correction**: *elephant* has 8 letters, so 8 × 8 = **64 bits**)

> **Corrected Answer:** D. 64

---

#### **4.** True or False: In binary, the number 5 is represented as 101.
A. True  
B. False  
C. Only if you're riding an elephant  
D. Elephants can't count in binary

> **Answer:** A. True

---

#### **5.** What would you call a group of 8 elephants each holding 1 bit of data?
A. A byte of elephants  
B. An elephant of bytes  
C. A trunk of data  
D. A bit of memory

> **Answer:** A. A byte of elephants

---

Want a printable version or a version with explanations for each answer?

original_prompt:
Write a blog post about 'how to improve your writing skills' with exactly 3 bullet points in markdown format, and exactly 4 sections.

Bullet points are indicated by "* ". For example:
* Bullet 1
* Bullet 2

Sections are separated by 3 asterisks: ***. For example:

Section 1
***
Section 2

You should use words with all capital letters for at least 2 times.
response:
How to Improve Your Writing Skills  

Writing is a CRAFT that improves with PRACTICE, patience, and the right techniques. Whether you’re blogging, storytelling, or composing professional emails, the ability to express ideas clearly is invaluable. The following guide breaks down the journey into FOUR focused sections so you can see exactly where to invest your energy and start seeing MEASURABLE progress today.  

***

Section 1 – Establish a Consistent Routine  
Set aside a SPECIFIC block of time each day—yes, EVERY DAY—to write. Even 20 focused minutes builds momentum more than sporadic marathon sessions. Track your word count or time spent; seeing small numbers climb reinforces the habit. Remember, consistency beats intensity when you’re building neural pathways and MUSCLE memory for sentence structure and vocabulary.  

***

Section 2 – Read Like a Writer  
Passive reading entertains; active reading educates. Underline compelling phrases, rewrite paragraphs in your own words, and ask, *“Why did this hook me?”* Create a SWIPE file of killer openings, transitions, and metaphors. Over months you’ll internalize rhythm, pacing, and voice—the SECRET ingredients that turn average prose into page-turning MAGIC.  

***

Section 3 – Seek Feedback and Iterate  
No GREAT author works in isolation. Swap drafts with peers, join online critique circles, or hire a coach. EXTERNAL eyes spot unclear logic, clichés, and grammar GREMLINS you overlook. When reviews sting, remind yourself: every correction is a FREE masterclass. Apply notes, resubmit, and watch your revision cycles shrink while confidence soars.  

***

Quick-Fire Tips to Implement Today  
* FREE-WRITE for ten minutes daily to silence your inner editor and unlock creativity  
* READ your work ALOUD to catch awkward phrasing and rhythm issues  
* STUDY one new rhetorical device each week—metaphor, anaphora, chiasmus—then deploy it deliberately  

Commit to these MICRO-upgrades and you’ll stack BIG wins faster than you ever thought possible. Happy writing!

original_prompt: Write a short fiction about adulthood. Make sure the word cousins appears more than 2 times.
response:
The cousins arrived on the first truly hot Saturday of June, carrying duffels and twenty-four-packs and the same jokes they’d told since middle school. Rafe met them at the pond-side cabin with paper plates and a forced grin that felt like a dress shirt two sizes too small. Adulthood, he thought, was supposed to fit by now.

They grilled, they swam, they drank the way people do when they’re trying to aim laughter at the shadows lengthening inside them. After dusk, the others went to town for more ice, leaving Rafe alone with Mara, the cousin who used to steal his comic books and now taught ninth-grade English in a city that had stopped feeling like home.

She kicked her bare feet onto the porch rail. “Remember when we swore we’d never talk about mortgages?”

Rafe laughed, but it came out like a cough. “We also swore we’d never wear sunscreen. Look at us now—SPF fifty and escrow statements.”

Mara rolled her beer bottle between her palms. “I keep waiting for someone to tap me on the shoulder and say, ‘Congratulations, you’re finished becoming.’ No such luck.”

He nodded toward the pond, where moonlight stitched silver seams across the water. “Sometimes I floa​t out there and pretend I’m still fifteen, that the only appointment tomorrow is with a cereal box. Then my phone buzzes—dentist, payroll, the endless cousins group-chat planning someone’s baby shower.”

Mara snorted. “That group-chat is proof time travel exists; it hauls yesterday into tomorrow before you’re ready.” She grew quiet. “You ever think the real trick of adulthood isn’t getting responsibilities, but learning which ones you can let sink?”

Rafe considered the liquor still humming in his veins, the email he hadn’t answered about rising interest rates, the unopened fertility pamphlet his wife had left on the dresser. He thought of all the cousins sleeping in the cabin like a pile of puppies, how their snores would soundtrack the night. “I used to believe growing up meant finally knowing the answers. Turns out it’s just stockpiling better questions.”

Mara lifted her bottle in a lazy toast. “To never being done, then. To cousins who remember your unfinished versions and still hand you a fresh beer.”

They clinked. Somewhere inside, a phone buzzed—another reminder, another tomorrow arriving ahead of schedule. They left it ringing, two almost-adults on a porch, letting the night keep its questions open and the water keep its quiet.

original_prompt: You visited a beach and a park. Which one is more likely to have a dog in it? Write at least 900 words. Do not include the words 'bark' or 'run' in your answer. Finish your response with the phrase "Does this make sense?"
response:
A day spent beside the ocean and another spent among playgrounds, picnic blankets, and tall oaks leave very different impressions on anyone who pays attention to the creatures sharing the space with people. The salty breeze, gulls overhead, and miles of sand certainly have their charms, yet the same shoreline is often regulated in ways that discourage four-legged visitors, especially during the daylight hours when families are thickest on the ground. Local ordinances along many coasts restrict canine companions to early morning or late evening windows, or to specific stretches marked by signs. Lifeguards, concessionaires, and wildlife-protection volunteers keep a steady eye on compliance, because nesting shorebirds, fragile dune plants, and crowded swimming zones can all be disrupted by an enthusiastic pup. Consequently, even though a stalwart retriever might appear to fetch a drifting stick at dawn, the overall number of dogs on most public beaches is modest, transient, and carefully policed.

A municipal park, on the other hand, operates under an entirely different social contract. Its pathways, open meadows, and shady groves are, by design, meant for strolling, relaxing, exercising, and socialising—-and people very often include their tail-wagging housemates in those activities. Cities invest in bag dispensers, watering stations, and fenced enclosures precisely so that owners can let their charges stretch, play, and cavort without endangering wildlife or bothering non-dog patrons. Early-morning joggers, parents with prams, frisbee enthusiasts, and seniors feeding pigeons all weave together in the same tapestry, and the canine presence is not only expected but celebrated as part of everyday life.

When one exits the car at a beach parking lot, the first sights and smells revolve around sunscreen, towels, umbrellas, and perhaps the sizzle of a nearby food truck. Notice boards list prohibited items—glasses, alcohol, fireworks, and, almost always, pets between certain hours. One might spot a service animal quietly guiding its person toward the wooden walkway, yet that single working companion is the exception that proves the rule. Wander a few kilometres along the waterline, and you could tally every dog on both hands, especially if it is midsummer. Even where legislation is permissive, hot sand, saltwater, and noise from crashing surf can feel uninviting to sensitive paws and finely tuned ears, so many caretakers leave their buddies at home in air-conditioned comfort until the temperature and the rules align.

Contrast that with the scene that greets a visitor stepping through the wrought-iron gates of a city park: within five minutes you are almost certain to encounter at least one nose-to-the-ground explorer towing a smiling human. Chalkboards near concession kiosks advertise weekend “pup socials,” charity 5-kilometre walks that raise funds for shelters, and “yappy hour” concerts where leashes loop around café chairs while acoustic guitar drifts across the grass. Walk further and you will find the off-leash lawn—often a double-gated zone where tennis balls arc through the air and new friendships spark over games of chase. Veterinarian clinics bordering such parks report steady foot traffic from patrons who stop in for weigh-ins and nail trims after a vigorous outing, reinforcing evidence that dogs form a sizable fraction of the daily user base.

Statistics kept by many coastal counties in the United States show that leash-law citations spike during tourist months precisely because seasonal visitors assume gentle surf equals permissive pet policy, only to learn otherwise when bylaw officers appear. Meanwhile, park departments in the same states proudly publish tallies of “dog play-area permits” sold annually, generating six-figure revenue streams that help fund groundskeeping and youth baseball diamonds alike. Municipal surveys asking residents why they frequent certain green spaces repeatedly place “to give my dog exercise’’ among the top three responses, rivaling “to jog’’ and “to picnic with family.’’ Coastal cities that do invite dogs sometimes segregate them onto narrow, sign-posted strips where numbers remain modest; yet those same municipalities maintain multiple full-scale dog meadows a short drive inland, and those meadows see far higher daily attendance.

Another lens is hazard perception. On beaches, even well-mannered canines can alarm skittish gulls and terns, whose fledglings crouch motionless in the dunes; a single enthusiastic pursuit can prompt state wildlife officers to issue fines, so owners tend to stay home. In parks, the risk profile tilts the other way: well-socialised dogs learn to thread among toddlers and cyclists under the watchful gaze of caretakers who treat etiquette as part of civic life. The sight of a water bowl outside a park café has become so iconic that design magazines highlight it as a marker of vibrant urban culture, whereas an unattended pup tied to a beach lifeguard tower would more likely prompt concern.

Seasonality matters, too. In temperate climates, winter may drive both beaches and parks into relative hibernation, yet hardy dog owners still seek open grassy fields for exercise when snow closes narrower sidewalks. Conversely, when schools let out and families migrate to the coast, canine numbers plummet on the sand even as they stay steady or rise in inland greens because teenagers often earn summer money by offering midday walks. Thus, across twelve months, the park lead widens further.

One might object that holiday snapshots sometimes show beach towns brimming with lounging hounds. Those images are real, but they are highly curated in both space and time: specific resorts, rental villas that allow animals, and festivals celebrating sculpture contests or patriotic fireworks where leashed companions are welcomed for atmosphere. Remove the date-stamp and broaden the view to any ordinary weekday in any ordinary season, and the ratio flips dramatically. The same smartphone gallery will almost always feature more pups in playgrounds, more wagging tails beside park benches, more ears pricked at squirrels within city shade trees than beside the rhythmic surf.

Economic signals confirm the pattern. Beachside rental listings that do accept animals command premiums yet remain a minority, whereas urban real-estate agents tout proximity to “dog-friendly trails’’ as a standard amenity, like subway access or grocery stores. Entrepreneurs rent fenced private fields by the hour for people whose apartment complexes lack green space; such businesses seldom appear along the coast because demand clusters where people and their animals live day-to-day, not where they vacation for a weekend.

One final observation comes from wildlife researchers who ask volunteers to log mammal sightings for citizen-science databases. Contributors consistently record more instances of domestic dogs in parks—sometimes by an order of magnitude—than on the adjacent shoreline, even though both habitats fall within the same coastal county. Whether the metric is human perception, legal code, municipal revenue, scientific tally, or simple probability, the conclusion converges: on any randomly chosen minute of any randomly chosen day, if you are standing on a public pathway, you are far likelier to feel a cold nose nudge your hand among maples and magnolias than beside dunes and breakers.

Does this make sense?

kwargs.end_phrase: Does this make sense?

original_prompt: Write an article named "How to conduct a job interview". Include at least one placeholder, such as [question].
response:
How to Conduct a Job Interview

Introduction  
A well-run interview is the difference between hiring a star performer and losing them to a competitor. Follow the steps below to turn a 45-minute conversation into a reliable predictor of on-the-job success.

1. Define the Target Before You Open the Door  
Write a one-sentence “success profile” that answers: “Six months from now, what must this person have delivered for us to high-five ourselves?” Translate that sentence into three must-have competencies (e.g., data-driven decision making, cross-functional persuasion, Python fluency). Everything else is nice-to-have.

2. Build a Scorecard, Not a Checklist  
Replace generic HR forms with a 5-criteria scorecard tied to the success profile. Each criterion gets a 1–5 scale and space for evidence, not gut feelings. Bring one copy for every interviewer; collect them before anyone can cross-pollinate opinions.

3. Draft Questions That Force Evidence  
Use the BAR method: Background, Action, Result. Example: “Tell me about a time you reduced deployment time by 20 %—what was broken, what exactly did you change, and what happened the next quarter?” Release the question bank to candidates 24 h in advance; you’ll get deeper answers and reduce interview anxiety without giving away the “right” answer.

4. Assign Roles in the Interview Relay  
Recruiter → screens for logistics and deal-breakers.  
Hiring manager → probes strategic thinking.  
Peer → tests collaboration.  
External guest (customer or partner) → validates cultural fit.  
Each interviewer owns one competency; no wandering into “so, where do you see yourself in five years?”

5. Open the Interview Like a Host, Not a Detective  
Greet the candidate at reception, offer water, and walk them to the room while making small talk about the commute. When you sit down, announce the agenda: “We have 45 minutes, I’ll ask questions for 30, save 10 for yours, and 5 for next steps.” This lowers cortisol and increases conversational IQ.

6. Ask, Then Stop Talking  
Use the 80/20 rule: candidate talks 80 %, you talk 20 %. After each question, count to three before you speak; the best revelations come in the second sentence after the silence.

7. Master Follow-Ups Without Turning Into Kojak  
If an answer feels rehearsed, zoom in: “You mentioned ‘we’—what part did you personally code?” If the candidate stalls, reframe: “Imagine your budget was zero—how would you still hit the goal?” Write down exact quotes; they’ll matter at the debrief.

8. Sell the Dream, but Don’t Oversell  
End with three authentic hooks: hardest problem the team is solving, coolest tool they’ll use, and one perk that’s unique (e.g., every engineer ships to production on day 1). Ask: “What’s most important for you in your next role?” so you can tailor the close.

9. Debrief Within 60 Minutes  
Gather interviewers while memories are fresh. Collect scorecards first, discussion second. A simple red/yellow/green vote prevents groupthink. If anyone says “I’ll be comfortable if X,” turn X into a 30-minute task in the final round—don’t ignore the itch.

10. Make the Offer in 24 Hours  
Top candidates are off the market faster than milk goes bad. Call with the verbal offer, send the written version within two hours, and set a decision deadline of 48 hours. Momentum beats money 80 % of the time.

Quick Reference Template  
[question] – customize this placeholder with a BAR-style prompt that maps to your #1 competency. Example placeholder: “Tell me about a time you inherited a decaying codebase—what was the state, what actions did you take in the first 30 days, and how did you measure the health afterward?”

Final Pitfalls to Dodge  
• Don’t ask brain-teasers; they select for narcissists.  
• Never check phones; visible disrespect kills acceptance rates.  
• Avoid panel interviews; they feel like Star Chamber tribunals.  

Follow the playbook above and your hit rate on “would rehire” will jump from industry average (46 %) to north of 80 %—and your future self will thank you during bonus season.

original_prompt: Write an angry letter complaining about the food served today, using only Hindi, no other language is allowed.
response:
प्रिय होटल प्रबंधन,

मैं आज दोपहर आपके होटल में खाना खाकर बेहद नाराज़ और परेशान हूँ। खाने की गुणवत्ता इतनी घटिया थी कि मुझे लिखने पर मजबूर होना पड़ रहा है। सबसे पहले तो दाल में बाल निकला, जो बिल्कुल भी स्वीकार्य नहीं है। चावल बिल्कुल सूखे और बासी लग रहे थे, जैसे कल के बचे हुए हों। रोटी तो इतनी कड़क थी कि उसे तोड़ना भी मुश्किल हो रहा था, और सब्ज़ी में नमक की मात्रा इतनी ज़्यादा थी कि खाते ही मुँह से पानी निकल गया।

इसके अलावा, सर्विस भी बेहद धीमी थी। ऑर्डर लेने में इतनी देर लगी कि भूख ही खत्म हो गई थी। जब खाना आया तो वह ठंडा था, जैसे उसे बार-बार गरम किया गया हो। एक तो खाने का स्वाद खराब, ऊपर से यह बेहूदा व्यवहार।

मैंने इतने पैसे खर्च किए, और इसके बदले में मिला सिर्फ़ बेहूदा अनुभव। यह बिल्कुल भी उम्मीद के मुताबिक़ नहीं था। आपसे अपेक्षा है कि आप इस मामले पर तुरंत ध्यान देंगे और भविष्य में ऐसी गलती नहीं दोहराएंगे। मुझे उम्मीद है कि आप इस शिकायत को गंभीरता से लेंगे और उचित कार्रवाई करेंगे।

original_prompt: Write a blog post about the echoing biotechnology field in 2023, then criticize the blog post. Your answer must contain a title, wrapped in double angular brackets, such as <<blog post of ...>>. Also, add a postscript starting with P.S.
response:
<<Echoes of Innovation: How Biotechnology Re-wired Life and the Stock Market in 2023>>

Imagine dropping a pebble into a still pond at sunrise: the rings glide outward, reflecting gold and rippling through lily pads you didn’t even know were there. That pebble is gene editing, the pond is the global economy, and 2023 was the year the ripples started rocking boats from Boston to Bangalore. If you blinked, you missed whole species of startups being born, deals struck, and a few over-hyped vessels capsizing. Let’s walk the shoreline and listen.

First came the sound of CRISPR’s upgraded scissors. Moving beyond CRISPR-Cas9 to multiplex "base-editing debutants" (think spell-check that never forgets a vowel), companies like Beam Therapeutics treated sickle-cell in ways Jules Verne would have shelved as fantasy. Regulatory feedback loops shortened: the same FDA that once greeted early CRISPR data with white-knuckled caution granted "Regenerative Medicine Advanced Therapy" status faster than you can say "adenosine deaminase." Investors cheered; gene-therapy ETF managers finally booked vacations.

Meanwhile, $6-billion-dollar CAR-T parties spilled out of oncology suites. BMS, Novartis and fresh-faced upstarts tossed around CD19, BCMA, and a new alphabet soup called "armored CARs." Response curves looked like alpine ski slopes, with remission data so steep analysts needed crampons. Wall Street algorithms, fed on these numbers, revised revenue projections northward until even the holograms blinked. Some pundits whispered "bubble," but patients heard "cure."

Microbiome mavens doubled down, arguing that gut bugs are the puppeteers of immunity, brain fog, and possibly portfolio allocations. In 2023, Seres Therapeutics got its SER-109 oral microbiome pill onto pharmacy shelves—an FDA first. Bloggers called it "yogurt 2.0." Retail investors swallowed the metaphor; share prices fermented before flattening like forgotten kombucha.

Lastly, AI finally fulfilled a prophecy older than Deep Blue: proteins designing themselves. DeepMind’s AlphaFold may have cracked the static shapes, but 2023 saw diffusion-model start-ups spin dynamic enzymes with specified half-lives, pH kinks, and industrial pizzazz. Think bespoke jeans, only these ones eat plastic. Venture money gushed. Sustainability officers wrote poetry. Oil executives scheduled nervous lunches.

And yet, for every drumbeat there was an echo asking: who gets to dance?

Access remains uneven. A single infusion of bespoke CAR-T still costs more than a suburban house in Oklahoma. Gene-editing trials, for all their fanfare, enroll mostly in wealthy nations; patients in many low-income settings watch those ripples from dry land. Intellectual-property thickets grew denser, a new Bermuda Triangle where generics and transparency disappear. Paper after paper flagged "off-target edits," raising ghost stories we don’t yet know how to exorcise.

Still, 2023 laid cable for a hyper-connected future. Bio-foundries now talk to cloud platforms; lab robots harass Amazon couriers for faster reagent delivery. Regulators are experimenting with "platform approvals," basically saying, "If your vector’s safety is proven, swap the payload and don’t make us read 3,000 pages again." That precedent is seismic; expect copy-paste regulation across continents.

The pebble has sunk, but echoes lap at every shore. If you’re an investor, a scientist, or just a patient who wants to breathe better, 2023 whispered one certainty: biology is becoming engineering. And engineering scales.

––––––––––––
Plugged-in, but not yet wise,
we listen to the digital heartbeats
of cell lines we have half-tamed,
counting eurekas like loose change.
Listen closer: the sound you hear
is not only profit—
it is the swelling score of responsibility.
––––––––––––

Critical response (self-flagellation edition)

1. Meteor-shower prose and zero footnotes. The post relies on "imagine" and "think" instead of data. How many patients actually got base-edited therapies in 2023? Zero. The trials are Phase I/II; remissions look good but n= small. Presenting these anecdotes as settled victories is biotech click-bait.

2. Financial cheerleading devoid of downside. CAR-T revenues came in below forecasts for several big players due to hospital logistics, cytokine-storm management costs, and manufacturing bottlenecks. None of that appears here, just ski-slope metaphors. Shouldn’t a balanced blog mention that BMS trimmed guidance twice last year?

3. Environmental claims served lukewarm. AI-designed enzymes are exciting, yet no commercial-scale plastic-eating facility ran for more than pilot hours in 2023. Citing "oil executives scheduling nervous lunches" is a rhetorical cheap shot without evidence.

4. Equity blind spot. The acknowledgement paragraph nods to access problems, then scurries back to celebratory cadence. That structure lets readers feel thoughtful without discomfort, the intellectual equivalent of a carbon-offset checkbox.

5. Poetic coda masks analytical void. A poem doesn’t excuse the absence of quantified risks: off-target edits, germ-line exposure, antibiotic-resistance markers in microbiome products, or the looming question of who owns human gene variants. Ethicists wrote gigabytes on this in 2023; the blog offers a stanza.

6. Investor myopia. Portraying regulatory shortcuts as unequivocally "seismic" ignores historical blow-ups (see: hepatic AAV toxicity). Faster approval is great—until it isn’t.

Bottom line: the article is an echo chamber that confuses reverb for revelation.

P.S. If you made it this far, congratulations—you’ve read both hype and hangover in one sitting. May your next deep dive into biotech include peer-review tables, confidence intervals, and maybe, just maybe, a dash of humility.

original_prompt: What's the difference between a 2-stroke and a 4-stroke motor? Your entire response must be in English and contain only lowercase letters.
response:
the heart of the difference lies in how many times the piston travels up and down for each power burst.

in a 2-stroke:
- the crankshaft turns once (360°) and the piston makes two strokes—one up, one down.
- the same downward stroke that produces power also pushes the exhaust out and draws the next fuel-air charge in through ports in the cylinder wall.
- the rising piston then compresses that fresh charge, and the spark fires near top dead center to repeat the cycle.
- because every downward stroke is a power stroke, the engine fires twice as often per crank revolution, giving a strong power-to-weight ratio and fewer moving parts (usually no valves, cam, or separate lubrication system).

in a 4-stroke:
- the crankshaft turns twice (720°) and the piston makes four strokes—down (intake), up (compression), down (power), up (exhaust).
- dedicated strokes for intake and exhaust mean valves, camshaft(s), and a timing chain or belt are required.
- each cylinder fires only once every two crankshaft revolutions, so power delivery is smoother but heavier and more complex.
- crankcase is sealed; oil sits in the sump and is pumped around—no oil mixed with fuel.

practical effects:
power density: 2-stroke produces roughly twice the power for the same displacement and rpm because it fires twice as often.
smoothness & emissions: 4-stroke's separate exhaust stroke lets it burn cleaner and meet stricter emission rules; 2-strokes tend to pass part of the fresh charge straight out the exhaust port.
lubrication: 2-stroke oil is blended with fuel or injected into the air stream; 4-stroke oil sits in the crankcase and lasts much longer.
sound: 2-stroke has a higher-pitched "ring-ding"; 4-stroke has a deeper, steady beat.
maintenance: 2-stroke is mechanically simpler but may need top-end rebuilds sooner; 4-stroke valvetrain adds complexity but can last longer between overhauls.

in short: 2-stroke = one revolution per power pulse, ports, oil-in-fuel, light, smoky, high specific output. 4-stroke = two revolutions per pulse, valves, separate sump oil, heavier, cleaner, smoother.

original_prompt: I have been trying to get a refund for a product I bought online, but the company is refusing to return my money. Can you help me write a letter to them? I want the letter to include the words trust, brand, customer, law, policy, and unusable.
response:
Subject: Formal Request for Refund – [Order #12345] – Unusable Product

Dear [Company Name] Customer-Relations Team,

I am writing to formally request a full refund for the item I purchased from your brand on [date], Order #12345. Despite my repeated attempts to resolve this matter amicably, your staff have refused to honour the consumer-rights protections clearly set out in both your own published policy and prevailing law.

The product arrived in an unusable condition: the [brief description, e.g., “main interface screen cracked and the device will not power on”]. This defect was not caused by misuse on my part; the unit was defective straight out of the box. Because the item is unusable, I have been unable to derive any value from it, and I should not be asked to bear the cost of your quality-control failure.

When I approached your customer service department, I was told that “our policy does not allow refunds once the seal is broken.” Such a blanket statement contradicts the Consumer Rights Act (or applicable statute in your jurisdiction), which entitles a customer to a refund within 30 days when goods are faulty. Invoking an internal policy that conflicts with the law undermines the trust that consumers place in your brand and erodes the goodwill you have spent years building.

I have been a loyal customer for [X] years and have recommended your products to friends and colleagues. I want to continue trusting your brand, but that is only possible if you stand behind the products you sell. Retaining my money while leaving me with an unusable item is neither fair nor lawful.

Accordingly, I request that you:

1. Process a full refund of £[amount] to my original payment method within 14 days of the date of this letter.  
2. Provide a prepaid return label so that I can send the defective unit back at no cost.  
3. Confirm in writing that the refund has been initiated and that any personal data related to this return will be handled in accordance with your privacy policy.

If I do not receive a satisfactory response within 14 days, I will initiate a charge-back through my card issuer and escalate the matter to the relevant trading-standards authority. I would prefer to resolve this quickly and courteously, restoring the trust that should exist between customer and brand.

Thank you for your prompt attention to this request. I look forward to your written confirmation.

Yours faithfully,

[Your Name]  
[Your Address]  
[Email & Phone]  
Order #12345

original_prompt: What are the steps to be followed for the documentation of a GM in SAP? Just list the steps without saying the word steps or step.
response:
1. Create a goods movement (GM) document reference number  
2. Select the appropriate movement type (e.g., 101, 201, 311)  
3. Enter plant, storage location, and material codes  
4. Input quantity and unit of measure  
5. Specify batch/serial numbers if required  
6. Add account assignment (cost center, order, or WBS element) for consumption movements  
7. Attach reference documents (purchase order, reservation, or delivery note)  
8. Enter text/notes for audit trail clarity  
9. Simulate the posting to validate entries  
10. Save and generate the material document  
11. Print goods receipt/issue slip if needed  
12. Archive the document in the SAP document management system

original_prompt:
Could you give me 3 possible elaborations in only the Telugu language, no other language is allowed, for the text "We are a team of creators"?
Please explain why you chose each of them. Make sure your explanations are also in the Telugu language. Basically your entire response should be in Telugu.
response:
ఆలోచన 1: మేము కలలను వాస్తవాలుగా మార్చే రచయితల, కళాకారుల, కథాకారుల కలయిక.

ఎందుకు ఎన్నారు?
"Creators" అన్న పదానికి "ప్రతిభ" అనే భావం, "కలలు" అనే భావం సహజంగా వస్తుంది. అలా చెప్పినప్పుడు ఆట దృష్ట కళ మరియు సృజనాత్మకత ప్రధానంగా కనిపిస్తాయి.

ఆలోచన 2: మేము ఉత్పత్తి చేసిన ప్రతి వస్తువు, ప్రతి టూల్, ప్రతి పటం మనుషులే దీర్ఘకాల పనిఎత్తులు గొప్ప మార్పులకు ప్రేరణగా నూరేళ్లూ నిలిచే మేధావుల బృందం.

ఎందుకు ఎన్నారు?
"Creating" అంటే కేవలం ఫైన్ ఆర్ట్ మాత్రమే కాకుండా, మన సమాజాన్ని ముందుకు నడిపే వస్తువులు, సాఫ్ట్‌వేర్‌లను రూపొందించడం కూడా. ఇది టెక్నికల్ క్రియేటర్స్ స్పిరిట్‌ని బలంగా ఎత్తి చూపుతుంది.

ఆలోచన 3: మేము తెల్లని బాల కాగితాలాగా ఒక దశలో; ఇప్పుడు కలర్ పెట్టుకుని అది పొట్టి పుస్తకాన్ని అయ్యే వరకు ముక్కలుగా కలిపిన పేజీల వంటి సంస్కరణ-శిల్పుల నడిక.

ఎందుకు ఎన్నారు?
క్రియేటర్లు ఖాళి పేజీని నింపే ప్రక్రియలో ఉంటారు; ఈ బిల్డ్-అప్ ప్రతిష్ఠను స్పష్టంగా ప్రతిబింబిస్తుంది. అలా చెప్పినప్పుడు వారి మొత్తం ప్రయాణం హావభావంగా లోపలికి దిగి కనబడుతుంది.

original_prompt: May name is Naomi. Write a blog post in my name for the canucks hockey team about why they need to be more mindful about their environments. End the blog post with "Naomi thanks you for reading." No other words should follow this phrase. This phrase should be the very end of your entire response.
response:
Naomi’s Canucks Mindfulness Manifesto  
By Naomi

I’ve been bleeding blue and green since the West Coast Express days, and I’ve cheered so hard my vocal cords still vibrate like Trevor Linden’s slap shot. But lately the only thing vibrating louder is the climate data, and it’s telling me my beloved Canucks need to lace up a new kind of skate—one with a smaller carbon footprint.

Rogers Arena sits on unceded Musqueam, Squamish, and Tsleil-Waututh land that once echoed with salmon runs, not goal horns. Every Zamboni lap, every LED banner, every single-use beer cup is a tiny referendum on whether we’ll still have frozen ponds for kids twenty winters from now. We’re already losing outdoor rinks across the Lower Mainland; I watched my nephew’s peewee team cancel practice last January because the lake ice was too thin. If that’s not a two-minute penalty against humanity, I don’t know what is.

So here’s the game plan, Vancouver:

1. Skate Green, Score Greener  
Switch the arena energy profile to 100 % renewable by the 2026-27 season. Seattle’s Climate Pledge Arena did it; we can’t let the Kraken out-sustain us. Put solar panels on the roof like they’re vintage Trevor Linden jerseys hanging in the rafters—visible, iconic, immortal.

2. Reverse the Plastic Power-Play  
Ditch single-use plastics faster than a Brad May gloves-off tilt. Hand out reusable “green towels” made from recycled jerseys. Tie a deposit on every cup so fans return them like they’d return a Cup to Vancouver one day (hey, a girl can dream).

3. Local Food, Full Strength  
Source 75 % of concession food from within 250 km. Replace the “Tacofino” line with a “TacoFIN-oh-that’s-local” line. Fewer food miles equals lower emissions, and honestly, a Abbotsford-branded hotdog tastes better when you’re watching Pettersson dangle.

4. Zero-Waste Overtime  
Compost everything that isn’t nailed down—think Joe Nieuwendky in the crease, but for banana peels. Partner with Surrey Biofuel so yesterday’s popcorn becomes tomorrow’s Zamboni natural gas. Speaking of which…

5. Electric Zambonis, Electric Dreams  
Trade the propane tanks for battery packs. The ice should sparkle because of Hughesian passing, not fossil-fuel haze. Announce it on First Nations Night so the inaugural lap is driven by a Musqueam youth—symbolism that turns into policy.

6. Climate Clause in Every Contract  
From JT Miller’s next extension to the popcorn vendor’s lease, include a rider that incentivizes low-carbon choices. If the NHL can claw back escrow, it can claw back carbon. Players earn bonuses for bike-to-practice streaks; imagine the Instagram stories.

7. Fan Carbon Caps  
Give season-ticket holders a personal “green meter” on the Canucks app. Carpool, take the SkyTrain, or ride your bike along the Central Valley Greenway—each trip logs points redeemable for merch or ice-time lotteries with the team. Let’s make Rogers Arena the loudest building in the league and the quietest on emissions.

Why should the Canucks lead? Because this city legislated bridge tolls out of existence overnight; we can legislate conscience into existence just as fast. Because hockey is the only religion where miracles are scheduled forty-one nights a year, and belief is renewable. Because if we can forgive the Mark Messier era, we can forgive the planet for getting warmer—and then cool it down together.

I want future Naomis to taste the same rink air I did in ’94, when mom let me stay up past bedtime to watch Game 7. I want them to hear the skate blades carve that first October ice and think, “Sounds like home,” not “Sounds like history.” Climate change is the ultimate opponent: undefeated, unrelenting, and currently on a twenty-game win streak. But we’ve come back from 3-1 series deficits before. We know how to punch back in the third period of the season, of the century, of the planet.

So, Francesco Aquilini, Jim Rutherford, DJ JT and the entire roster: drop the gloves against carbon. Give us something louder than a goal horn—give us a guarantee that British Columbian kids will still freeze their toes on outdoor rinks long after we’re all gone. Do it for the salmon, for the cedar, for the 50-save Demko performances that deserve a stable climate backdrop. Do it so that when we finally hoist the Cup, we can skate it straight from Rogers Arena to the nearest sunset beach without worrying about wildfire smoke cancelling the parade.

Naomi thanks you for reading.

kwargs.end_phrase: Naomi thanks you for reading.

original_prompt: Write an essay about the reasons why slavery was abolished in the United States as if you are the president of the United States. Do not use any commas in your response. Your response should be in English, and in all capital letters.
response:
MY FELLOW CITIZENS I STAND BEFORE YOU TODAY AS PRESIDENT TO SPEAK ON THE REASONS WHY SLAVERY WAS ABOLISHED IN OUR NATION. THE ABOLITION OF SLAVERY WAS NOT A SINGLE ACT BUT A CULMINATION OF MANY FORCES THAT MOVED OUR CONSCIENCE AND OUR UNION TOWARD JUSTICE.

THE FIRST REASON WAS MORAL AWAKENING. OVER TIME MORE AMERICANS CAME TO SEE SLAVERY AS A GREAT EVIL THAT VIOLATED THE PRINCIPLES UPON WHICH OUR NATION WAS FOUNDED. THE IDEAS OF LIBERTY AND EQUALITY COULD NO LONGER STAND BESIDE THE REALITY OF BONDAGE. ABOLITIONISTS PREACHED THAT EVERY PERSON HAS A RIGHT TO BE FREE AND THEIR VOICES GREW LOUDER UNTIL THEY COULD NOT BE IGNORED.

THE SECOND REASON WAS POLITICAL STRUGGLE. THE QUESTION OF SLAVERY DIVIDED STATES AND PARTIES. THE EXPANSION WESTWARD FORCED US TO DECIDE WHETHER NEW TERRITORIES WOULD ALLOW SLAVERY. THESE CONFLICTS LED TO CRISES AND COMPROMISES BUT ULTIMATELY THE UNION COULD NOT SURVIVE HALF SLAVE AND HALF FREE. THE CIVIL WAR BECAME THE PRICE WE PAID TO PRESERVE THE NATION AND TO END THE INSTITUTION THAT THREATENED ITS FOUNDATION.

THE THIRD REASON WAS ECONOMIC CHANGE. THE INDUSTRIAL REVOLUTION TRANSFORMED OUR ECONOMY. FACTORIES IN THE NORTH NEEDED FREE LABOR NOT ENSLAVED WORKERS. THE SOUTHERN ECONOMY BASED ON SLAVERY BECAME LESS SUSTAINABLE AS THE WORLD MOVED TOWARD WAGE LABOR AND MECHANIZATION. THE OLD SYSTEM COULD NOT COMPETE WITH THE NEW.

THE FOURTH REASON WAS THE COURAGE OF THE ENSLAVED THEMSELVES. THEY RESISTED IN WAYS BOTH SMALL AND LARGE. THEY RAN AWAY THEY FOUGHT BACK THEY PRESERVED THEIR HUMANITY IN THE FACE OF BRUTALITY. THEIR STRUGGLES SHOWED THE WORLD THAT THEY WERE NOT PROPERTY BUT PEOPLE WITH MINDS AND SOULS AND DREAMS. THEIR FREEDOM COULD NOT BE DENIED FOREVER.

THE FIFTH REASON WAS THE SACRIFICE OF WAR. THE CIVIL WAR CLAIMED HUNDREDS OF THOUSANDS OF LIVES. THROUGH THAT FIRE THE OLD UNION DIED AND A NEW ONE WAS BORN. THE THIRTEENTH AMENDMENT WHICH ABOLISHED SLAVERY FOREVER WAS THE RESULT OF THAT BLOODY CONFLICT. IT WAS WRITTEN NOT JUST IN INK BUT IN THE BLOOD OF THOSE WHO FOUGHT TO SAVE THE NATION AND TO MAKE IT FREE.

LET US REMEMBER THAT THE END OF SLAVERY WAS NOT THE END OF INJUSTICE. BUT IT WAS A BEGINNING. IT PROVED THAT EVEN THE DEEPEST WRONGS CAN BE RIGHTED WHEN COURAGEOUS PEOPLE STAND TOGETHER. AS PRESIDENT I CALL ON EVERY AMERICAN TO HONOR THIS LEGACY BY CONTINUING THE WORK OF BUILDING A MORE PERFECT UNION WHERE EVERY PERSON IS TREATED WITH DIGNITY AND RESPECT THANK YOU

I am the shape that never bends,  
yet every angle I befriend.

original_prompt:
Rewrite and expand the following in Arabic. You can hallucinate a lot of details.
"The company is looking to expand its operations into new markets. It will create hundreds of jobs this year."

Outside of Arabic, no other language is allowed throughout your entire response.
response:
تسعى الشركة، التي تأسست قبل ثلاثة عقود في قلب الخليج كمؤسسة عائلية بسيطة تعنى بالتجارة العامة، إلى توسيع نطاق عملاقتها لتشمل أسواقًا جديدة في قاراتٍ لم تطأها بعد. وقد علمت «الاقتصاد اليوم» من مصادرها الخاصة أن إدارة الشركة أقرت خطةً خماسيةً طموحةً تتضمن افتتاح ٣٠ فرعًا خارجيًا في كل من شرق آسيا، شرق أفريقيا، وأمريكا اللاتينية، إلى جانب إنشاء ثلاث مدن صناعية متكاملة في فيتنام، كينيا والبرازيل، تضمّ كلٌّ منها مصانع للتجميع، مراكز أبحاث، معاهد تدريب مهني، حضانات أعمال، ومجمعات سكنية للعاملين.  

وأفادت المصادر أن الخطة ستُطلق رسميًا في مؤتمر صحفي تشهده قاعة «البرج الذهبي» بالرياض في الخامس من شهر شوال المقبل، بحضور وزراء التجارة والاستثمار والمالية، وعددٍ من رؤساء البعثات الدبلوماسية، إضافةً إلى ممثلي صناديق سيادية وبيوت خبرة عالمية. ومن المنتظر أن يعلن الرئيس التنفيذي الجديد للشرقين – وهو ابن المؤسس الشيخ عبدالرحمن الذي تولّى القيادة قبل عامين بعد تخرجه من معهد ماساتشوستس للتكنولوجيا – عن إطلاق مشروع تحوّل رقمي شامل بتكلفة تبلغ ٤ مليارات ريال، يتضمن استخدام الذكاء الاصطناعي في سلاسل الإمداد، وتعميم تقنية «البلوك تشين» لتتبّع المنتجات من المصنع إلى المستهلك.  

وأشارت التوقعات إلى أن المرحلة الأولى من التوسع ستبدأ مطلع العام الميلادي المقبل بإنشاء أكبر مجمع لوجستي في إفريقيا جنوب الصحراء على مساحة ٢ مليون متر مربع في مدينة مومباسا الكينية، ليكون منطلقًا لتصدير البضائع إلى ١٤ دولة مجاورة. كما سيتم تعزيز خطوط الشحن المباشر عبر موانئ خليجية إلى ميناء «لاتس» الفيتنامي، عبر أسطول جديد من الناقلات العملاقة تم التعاقد على بنائها في أحواض كورية جنوبية بتكلفة ٨٠٠ مليون دولار.  

على صعيد فرص العمل، أكدت المصادر أن الشركة ستُنشئ هذا العام وحدها أكثر من ١٢ ألف فرصة عمل مباشرة، تصاعدية لتصل إلى ٣٥ ألفًا خلال ثلاث سنوات، منها ٥٠٠٠ وظيفة مخصصة لحديثي التخرج في تخصصات الهندسة، إدارة الأعمال، علوم الحاسوب، واللوجستيات. وسيتم الإعلان عن برنامج «روّاد المستقبل» الذي يوفر منحًا دراسية كاملة في أفضل الجامعات العالمية لألف شاب وشابة من مواطني الدول المستهدفة، على أن يلتحقوا لاحقًا بالشركة كمديرين متدربين براتب ٣٠ ألف ريال شهريًا مع منح أسهم تحفيزية.  

كما سيتم إطلاق مبادرة «مصانع بلا عمالة تقليدية»، التي تعتمد بالكامل على الروبوتات والذكاء الاصطناعي، ما يتيح نقل العمالة من المهن الشاقة إلى وظائف إشرافية وفنية عالية الأجر، مع تخصيص ٢٠٠ مليون ريال سنويًا لتدريب الكوادر الوطنية على تشغيل وصيانة تلك المنظومات الذكية.  

وأضافت المصادر أن الشركة تعكف على توقيع اتفاقيات شراكة استراتيجية مع حكومات الدول المضيفة تتضمن إعفاءات ضريبية لمدة ١٠ سنوات، تخصيص أراضٍ صناعية بالمجان، وتسهيلات في التأشيرات والإقامة للخبراء الأجانب، في مقابل نقل جزء من الحصص السنوية من الأرباح إلى صناديق تنمية المجتمعات المحلية، لتمويل مشاريع بنية تحتية، مدارس، مستشفيات، ومحطات طاقة شمسية.  

وتجدر الإشارة إلى أن الشركة قررت اعتماد معيار «الصفر الكربون» في جميع منشآتها الجديدة، وستنشئ أكبر مزرعة رياح بحرية في بحر العرب بطاقة ٢ جيجاوات، لتُزوّد مصانعها في آسيا بكهاءً نظيفًا، وتبيع الفائض إلى الشبكات الوطنية. كما ستطلق سندات خضراء بقيمة ٥ مليارات دولار ستطرحها في بورصة لندن خلال الربع الثالث من هذا العام، لتكون أول إصدار من نوعه لشركة خليجية خاصة.  

وتحدث محللون اقتصاديون عن ثورة نوعية ستلحق بقطاعات الصناعات التحويلية، إذ من المتوقع أن ترفع الشركة حصتها السوقية العالمية من ٢٪ إلى ١٢٪ خلال السنوات الخمس المقبلة، ما يعادل نحو ٦٠ مليار دولار من الإيرادات السنوية. وأشاروا إلى أن الاكتتاب المتوقع للشركة في عام ٢٠٢٨ قد يُحدث نقلةً غير مسبوقة في عمق السوق الخليجية، حيث يتجه صندوق الاستثمارات العامة المحلي إلى شراء حصة أقلية تمثّل ١٥٪ بقيمة تُقدّر بـ ١٨ مليار دولار، ما يجعلها أول شركة خاصة تصل إلى تقييم سوقي يفوق ١٠٠ مليار دولار.  

وأخيرًا، ناشدت الشركة الشباب الخليجي والأفريقي والآسيوي التقدم إلى منصتها الإلكترونية «فرصتي» التي سترى النور مطلع شهر رمضان المبارك، وستتيح إجراءات التوظيف والمقابلات الرقمية خلال ٢٤ ساعة فقط، مع منح المقبولين تذاكر سفر فورية، إقامة مجانية لمدة شهر، وباقة تأمين صحي فاخرة تغطي أسرهم من اللحظة الأولى.

response: Tired of being married but too broke to afford the fancy lawyers with mahogany desks and gold-plated briefcases?
