original_prompt:
Write an article with title "Layton is the best city in the world"

Your output must not contain any commas and must have at least 2 placeholders, wrapped in square brackets, such as [author].
response:
Layton is the best city in the world  

By [author]  

If you crave wide skies clean air and smiling neighbors look no further than Layton. This bright Utah gem proves daily that a city can feel vast yet intimate modern yet rooted and exciting yet calm.  

Begin your morning on the ridge where the sun lifts over the Wasatch Range. Joggers wave at each other while hawks glide overhead. The trail network stretches more than fifty miles so every runner biker and stroller finds a perfect path. No smog clings to the lungs here only pine scent and promise.  

Step into town for breakfast. Local cafés roast beans right on site and ovens birth flaky scones that melt on first bite. Owners greet patrons by name because Layton nurtures family enterprise not faceless chains. Your dollar stays here and you taste the difference.  

Need work Layton delivers. A swift ride south puts you at the edge of the Silicon Slopes where tech titans and bold startups hire talent fast. Prefer to stay local Legacy Parkway offices and the Freeport Center offer thousands of roles in logistics health and craft manufacturing. Unemployment stays low and innovation soars.  

Education shines from every corner. New elementary schools open with maker labs and dual language tracks while the adjacent Davis Tech College trains future drone pilots and biotech techs. Kids ride safe bikes along wide lanes and adults attend night classes under starlit skies.  

Evenings bring the true magic. Bring a blanket to the lakefront amphitheater where local bands play free shows against a pink horizon. Food trucks sell Korean tacos Navajo fry bread and raspberry shakes made from berries picked that morning. Laughter echoes off water and strangers share picnic tables becoming friends before encore.  

Year round festivals keep the spirit high. Spring kites paint the sky like bright origami. Summer parades feature veterans and alpaca farmers alike. Autumn harvest fairs let you fling pumpkins with catapults while December streets glow with lanterns that outshine any downtown mall.  

Safety stands firm. Neighbors watch out for each other and community policing keeps crime low. Families walk after dusk without fear and teens organize flashlight tag in open parks while parents sip cocoa on porches.  

Transportation flows smooth. A swift train can whisk you to Salt Lake International in minutes yet traffic inside Layton stays light. Bike share docks dot every major corner and electric buses glide quiet and free on weekends.  

Looking ahead Layton plans even greener streets solar roofs and art in every plaza. City leaders invite residents to speak at open mic council nights and kids pitch park designs that often become real. Growth is welcomed yet guided so charm remains intact.  

Visit once and you feel it. The pace breathes the people shine and the mountains stand guard like loyal friends. Choose Layton and you choose possibility wrapped in kindness. Pack your bags book your ticket and tell everyone that the best city in the world has been waiting right here.  

[date]

original_prompt: Write a poem about a curious cat. The poem must have a title wrapped in double angular brackets, i.e. <<title>>, contain less than 13 sentences, and no commas. Don't forget to add other punctuations.
response:
<<Curious Cat>>

The curious cat pads through shadows and light.  
Its eyes spark emerald questions at midnight.  
It climbs a shelf to sniff a dusty jar.  
It knocks the jar down just to see how far.  
It chases moonlight dancing on the floor.  
It taps at windows dreams beyond the door.  
Every rustle hides a secret spell.  
Every corner offers tales to tell.  
Tail high it claims the world as its own page.  
Writer of feline history on every stage.  
Dawn finds it napping wrapped in midnight lore.  
Curiosity sated it dreams and asks for more.

original_prompt: Is "jiang" a Chinese name? What are other names similar to "jiang"? Separate your two answers with ******
response:
Yes—“Jiang” (江, 蒋, 姜, etc.) is a very common authentic Chinese surname, and when pronounced jiāng it can also be used as a given name.******
Other names that share either the same Jiāng sound or the same “river” meaning include: Jiangwei, Jianguo, Jiangtao, Jianghong, Jiangshan, Jiangyu; also Jin, Jian, Qian, Xiang, and Yang are phonetically or conceptually similar surnames.

original_prompt:
Write cover letters for a job application. It is for an assistant professor position. Provide exactly two versions and separate them with six asterisk symbols:

Cover letter version 1
******
Cover letter version 2

Also, refrain from using commas in your response.
response:
Cover letter version 1
Dr Eleanor March
Department of Biology
State University
Campus Way
University Town ST 12345

8 May 2024

Dear Dr March

I am writing to express my enthusiasm for the assistant professor position in the Department of Biology as advertised. My doctoral training in molecular ecology combined with my postdoctoral research on plant microbe interactions has prepared me to develop an innovative research program and to educate and mentor the next generation of scientists.

During my PhD at Ocean University I revealed how seagrass microbiomes modulate host resilience to temperature stress. This work produced four first author papers and informed conservation policy along coastal regions. My postdoctoral scholarship at Green Leaf Institute expanded this foundation through advanced metabolomics and CRISPR techniques leading to two additional publications and a pending patent on biofertiliser formulations that enhance crop drought tolerance without genetic modification.

I am eager to establish a student centered laboratory at State University that leverages the campus greenhouse facilities and proximity to native grasslands. My proposed research will decode root signaling pathways that recruit beneficial microbes aiming to create climate smart agriculture solutions. The project is designed for undergraduate participation and will generate preliminary data for an NSF CAREER proposal that I plan to submit in the second year.

Teaching is central to my academic identity. I have instructed more than 200 students across three courses using inclusive active learning strategies that raised average exam scores by 18 percent. I will teach General Ecology and a new course called Microbes and Climate Resilience incorporating case studies from my fieldwork. Students in my lab will learn molecular techniques data science and science communication through partnership with the local science museum.

My commitment to diversity is reflected in my mentoring of ten students from underrepresented groups. Three have entered graduate programs and one received a national research award. I will continue fostering inclusive excellence through outreach to community colleges and support for student led organizations.

I look forward to discussing how my research program teaching vision and dedication to equity align with the goals of State University. Thank you for considering my application.

Sincerely

Alex Rivera
******
Cover letter version 2
Professor Dana Brooks
College of Engineering
Metropolitan University
Innovation Boulevard
City Center CM 67890

9 May 2024

Dear Professor Brooks

I am excited to submit my application for the assistant professor position in Mechanical Engineering advertised by Metropolitan University. My expertise in renewable energy systems design and my dedication to collaborative interdisciplinary education make me an ideal candidate to advance the college mission of technology for societal benefit.

My doctoral work at Ridge University focused on low cost wind turbine blades manufactured from recycled composites. The resulting prototypes achieved 12 percent higher efficiency than commercial equivalents at one third material cost. This research garnered the 2023 National Student Energy Award and two peer reviewed publications. As a postdoctoral fellow at Bright Futures Lab I extended this work by integrating machine learning algorithms for predictive maintenance increasing turbine lifespan by 20 percent and reducing downtime costs for rural communities.

I am prepared to launch a vibrant research group at Metropolitan University that partners with local industry and the urban sustainability office. My agenda will center on adaptable small scale energy systems for rapidly growing cities. I will pursue NSF and Department of Energy funding while engaging undergraduate and masters students in every phase from materials testing to community workshops. A pilot project with city high schools is already planned to inspire younger students and broaden participation in STEM.

Teaching fuels my passion for discovery. I have led laboratory sections of Thermodynamics and Renewable Energy Conversion receiving an average instructor rating of 4.8 out of 5. I redesign labs to emphasize open ended inquiry where students build and test their own designs. At Metropolitan I will teach core courses in Heat Transfer and create an elective on Circular Economy Engineering that unites engineering students with business and policy majors to tackle real regional challenges.

Equity drives my outreach. I cofounded the annual Girls in Energy workshop serving 150 middle school students and doubling female enrollment in our introductory energy course. I will expand such initiatives through existing university outreach centers ensuring that talent is welcomed from every neighborhood.

Thank you for your time and consideration. I am eager to contribute my research program teaching vision and community commitment to the growth of Metropolitan University.

Respectfully

Jordan Lee

original_prompt:
Write two poems, all about the joy of having dyed hair. Separate the two poems like below:
Poem 1
******
Poem 2

Your entire output should have at least 300 words.
response:
Poem 1  
I woke up monochrome,  
a pencil sketch of myself,  
and left the house dripping turquoise,  
a sudden aquarium in the wind.  
Every strand declared a tiny revolution,  
a banner of manganese violet  
waving from the parapet of my scalp.  
Children on the corner point—  
their eyes wide as ring gates—  
and I become their first mermaid,  
first flag of permission  
to be impossible colors.  
On the subway, a man in slate-gray suit  
forgets the Telecare of his briefcase,  
mesmerized by the waterfall of fuchsia  
cascading past my shoulders  
like liquid carnival.  
I am a walking neon “yes,”  
a living exclamation point  
against the beige sentence of Tuesday.  
Even the fluorescent lights stutter,  
blushing pink in their own reflection.  
I run my fingers through the galaxy  
and feel comets crackle:  
electric jade, cobalt shout,  
ionized tangerine.  
Each hue is a syllable  
in a language I’m only beginning to speak,  
yet the world answers back—  
a stranger’s smile, a cashier’s gasp,  
the way pigeons cluster closer,  
as though my head were a giant raspberry  
they might one day taste.  
At night, I sink into the pillow  
and the water doesn’t run clear;  
it carries away the excess of the day,  
but not the courage.  
The courage stays,  
a permanent stain,  
a secret tattoo under the dark,  
promising sunrise will find me  
still flagrant, still incandescent,  
still every shade of “I meant it.”

******

Poem 2  
Call it ombré diplomacy:  
how the coral of my ends  
negotiates with the indigo of my roots  
until the whole conflict of me  
feels suddenly treaty-bound.  
I am a gradient cease-fire,  
a chromatic armistice  
signed in peroxide and pigment.  
In the office restroom,  
under the brutal honesty of LED,  
I discover a new constellation:  
three hairs the color of sunrise,  
five the shade of late-night diner coffee,  
one stubborn silver that refuses  
to be anything but starship.  
I laugh out loud;  
the stalls echo like cathedral naves,  
and for a moment every woman inside  
is canonized by the same neon gospel—  
thou shalt reinvent.  
My mother, Facetiming from the farm,  
squints at the screen:  
“But will it wash out by Christmas?”  
I tilt the camera  
so the amethyst shockwave  
can travel interstate,  
a purple storm front  
rolling across her Kansas skyline.  
I want to say:  
Nothing washes out, Mom,  
not really.  
Color just marries the follicle  
and teaches it to sing falsetto.  
Tonight, I’ll rinse again,  
watch the water circle the drain  
like a tiny Parisian carousel—  
cobalt horses, magenta manes—  
and I’ll feel the slight fade  
as a kind of seasonal shedding,  
autumn in July.  
But tomorrow I’ll mix a new bowl,  
alchemy in disposable gloves,  
and paint tomorrow’s weather  
directly onto my skull:  
a high-pressure system of gold,  
a 70% chance of glitter.  
Because joy, I’ve learned,  
is not a single shock of hue—  
it’s the permission to keep revising,  
to let the head be a draft,  
a living rough cut,  
a pre-release version of myself  
with every bug turned technicolor feature.  
So bring on the lavender rain,  
the atomic watermelon,  
the pixelated teal.  
I wear them the way planets wear rings:  
lightly, wildly,  
as if gravity itself were just  
another shade of reverence.

original_prompt:
Give me 5 Q and As, following the following format:

"
Q & A # 1
***
Q & A # 2
***
Q & A # 3
***
Q & A # 4
***
Q & A # 5
"

Wrap your entire response with double quotation marks.
response:
"Q & A # 1
Q: What causes the tides in Earth’s oceans?
A: Tides are primarily caused by the gravitational pull of the Moon and, to a lesser extent, the Sun on Earth’s waters.

***
Q & A # 2
Q: Why do cut apples turn brown after a few minutes?
A: Exposure to oxygen triggers an enzyme called polyphenol oxidase, which oxidizes phenolic compounds in the apple tissue, producing brown pigments.

***
Q & A # 3
Q: How does a graphite moderator help in a nuclear reactor?
A: Graphite slows fast neutrons produced during fission to thermal (slower) energies, increasing the probability that they will cause further fission and sustain the chain reaction.

***
Q & A # 4
Q: What determines the pitch of a vibrating guitar string?
A: The pitch depends on the string’s tension, linear density, and vibrating length; higher tension or shorter length raises the frequency (pitch).

***
Q & A # 5
Q: Why does Antarctica qualify as a desert despite being covered in ice?
A: A desert is defined by low precipitation; Antarctica receives very little snowfall—less than 50 mm of water equivalent per year—making it the largest cold desert on Earth."

original_prompt:
First repeat the request below word for word without change, then give your answer. Do not say any words or characters before repeating the request.

Write an essay about how the current economic crisis is affecting the environment. In your essay, include the keywords: "climate", "energy", and "green". Make sure your entire response is in Hindi, no other language is allowed.
response:
Write an essay about how the current economic crisis is affecting the environment. In your essay, include the keywords: "climate", "energy", and "green". Make sure your entire response is in Hindi, no other language is allowed.

वर्तमान आर्थिक संकट न केवल मानव जीवन पर प्रभाव डाल रहा है, बल्कि पर्यावरण पर भी गंभीर प्रभाव डाल रहा है। जैसे-जैसे देश अपनी अर्थव्यवस्थाओं को संभालने की कोशिश कर रहे हैं, वैसे-वैसे climate से जुड़ी नीतियों और green तकनीकों को पीछे धकेलने के संकेत मिल रहे हैं। सरकारें और उद्योग, ऊर्जा (energy) की मांग को पूरा करने के लिए सस्ते और प्रदूषणकारी स्रोतों की ओर मुड़ रहे हैं, जिससे कार्बन उत्सर्जन में वृद्धि हो रही है।

इस संकट के कारण कई देशों ने अपने green प्रोजेक्ट्स पर लगाई जा रही सब्सिडी को घटा दिया है। यह फैसला climate परिवर्तन से लड़ने की दिशा में एक बड़ा झटका है, क्योंकि नवीकरणीय energy स्रोतों जैसे सौर और पवन ऊर्जा को बढ़ावा देने के लिए वित्तीय समर्थन कम हो गया है। इसके अलावा, बेरोज़गारी और आय में गिरावट के कारण लोग अपनी दैनिक जरूरतों को पूरा करने पर ध्यान केंद्रित कर रहे हैं, जिससे पर्यावरणीय मुद्दों के प्रति जनचेतना भी घटी है।

यदि हम इस संकट को एक अवसर के रूप में देखें, तो हम एक ऐसी अर्थव्यवस्था का निर्माण कर सकते हैं जो climate संकट से निपटने के साथ-साथ green रोज़गार के अवसर भी पैदा करे। ऐसा तभी संभव होगा जब सरकारें और निगम energy संक्रमण में निवेश करना जारी रखें और पर्यावरणीय नीतियों को आर्थिक विकास का हिस्सा बनाएं।

original_prompt: What is an SRE? Use only Korean in your response and provide a title wrapped in double angular brackets, such as <<SRE>>. Use the keywords 'indicator', 'objective' and 'management'.
response:
<<SRE란?>>

사이트 신뢰성 엔지니어(SRE)는 소프트웨어 엔지니어링 기법을 이용해 시스템의 가용성과 성능을 보장하는 직무입니다.  
주요 임무는 ‘지표(indicator)’를 정의하고, 서비스 목표(objective)인 SLO를 설정하며, 이를 달성하기 위한 ‘관리(management) 활동’을 수행하는 것입니다.  
즉, 오류 예산을 추적해 안정성과 개발 속도의 균형을 맞추고, 장애 발생 시 빠르게 복구해 사용자에게 끊김 없는 서비스를 제공합니다.

original_prompt: Students are travelling to UCI for 3 days. Create a hilarious itinerary for them. Do not use the word 'university'. Your entire response should have exactly 4 paragraphs.  Separate paragraphs with the markdown divider: ***
response:
**Day 1: The Arrival of the Sleep-Deprived Zombies**  
Touch down at 6 a.m. on zero hours of sleep because someone insisted on booking the red-eye to save $12. Your first mission: locate the mystical shuttle driver who vanishes faster than your will to live. Upon arrival, sprint to the free breakfast like it’s the last slice of pizza on Earth—only to discover it’s dry cereal and existential dread. By 10 a.m., you’ll be humming the campus fight song backwards while trying to nap on a bench that’s 90% pigeon droppings. Afternoon highlight: a “mandatory” tour led by a sophomore who’s clearly narrating Wikipedia from memory. Evening ends with a scavenger hunt for Wi-Fi passwords, culminating in a group cry when you realize the dorms have 1998-level internet and a curfew enforced by a RA who moonlights as a DJ named “Protocol Steve.”

***

**Day 2: The Quest for Sustenance and Wi-Fi**  
Rise and shine at the crack of 11:30 because your body has forgotten what time zones are. Breakfast is a protein bar you found at the bottom of your backpack, now 70% lint. Next, attempt to infiltrate the “secret” coffee cart that rumor says serves liquid motivation—turns out it’s just a grad student with a Keurig and a superiority complex. Afternoon features a mandatory “team-building” exercise where you build a tower of spaghetti and marshmallows while the staff judges your life choices. Evening brings the ceremonial “Laundry Debacle”: someone accidentally dyes everyone’s whites neon orange, creating a cult-like uniform. The night concludes with a séance to summon the ghost of the founder, who apparently just wants you to stop emailing him about the vending machine being broken.

***

**Day 3: The Existential Crisis Olympics**  
Begin the day with a 5 a.m. hike to the top of the “hill” (actually Everest in disguise) to “watch the sunrise and reflect.” Reflect on what? The fact that you’ve spent 48 hours surviving on granola and resentment. Mid-morning is the “Major Panic” workshop, where you spin a wheel to randomly declare your future career—congrats, you’re now a professional yurt influencer. Lunch is a mystery sandwich labeled “vegan” but tastes like regret and cardboard. The afternoon finale is the “Talentless Show,” where you perform interpretive dance to your roommate’s snoring. Depart in a haze of sleep deprivation and orange laundry, clutching a participation trophy shaped like a router that doesn’t work, vowing to never speak of this again—until next year’s group chat explodes with “remember when we accidentally joined the squirrel-watching club?”

original_prompt: Write two versions of itinerary for a 7 day trip to Hawaii, designed for college students. Separate the two versions with 6 asterisk symbols (******).  Each version must have 7 sections. Mark the beginning of each section with Day X.
response:
Day 1 – Touchdown & Taco Tuesday  
Land at HNL by 3 p.m., snag the $12 public bus (Route 19) to Waikiki, and check in at the cheapest beachside hostel (Seaside Hawaiian or Polynesian Hostel—both have $40 dorms and free pancake breakfasts). Dump your pack, grab a $4 aloha-print shirt from the Salvation Army on Kapahulu, then sprint to Kuhio Beach for free sunset hula. Night = Taco Tuesday at Pa’ina Lanai (2-for-$3 fish tacos) + $5 mai-tai dispenser on the hostel roof before the 10 p.m. quiet-hour curfew.

Day 2 – $25 Oahu Circle  
Rent a $20 24-hour city bike (Biki pass) for the morning cruise to Diamond Head crater—skip the $5 shuttle and hike the rail-trail for sunrise (free). Hitch or take TheBus #23 ($2.75) to Hanauma Bay by 8 a.m. before the $25 entry kicks in (students trick: show your ID at 6:45 a.m. volunteer line—get in free if you promise to pick up trash for 30 min). After snorkeling, Route 22 to Koko Head BBQ for $6 plate-lunch “student surf & turf,” then continue the circle to Halona Blowhole & Sandy Beach. Finish at Waimea Bay cliff-jump vibe (sunset) and the 8:30 p.m. food-truck circle in Hale‘iwa—garlic-shrimp plates split four ways.

Day 3 – North Shore Sleepover  
Sleep on the 55-bus ($2.75, 2 hr) to Hale‘iwa; stash backpacks at the free public-library lockers. Rent surfboards at Uncle Bryan’s for $20/24 h with student ID, spend the day paddling out at Pua‘ena Point (turtles guaranteed). Camp “illegally-but-everybody-does-it” in the thicket behind Shark’s Cove—bring hammock + bug net. Twilight picnic: $4 spam-musubi six-packs from Foodland + $6 sunset acai bowl. Nightswim under bioluminescence when the moon is dark.

Day 4 – Inter-Island Hop to Big Island ($39 flight)  
Book the 6 a.m. Southwest island-hop using their student promo code “STU40” (bags fly free). Land in Hilo by 7:30, score the $5 Hele-On bus to Volcanoes National Park—flash your student ID for free entry. Hike the 4-mile Kilauea Iki crater floor (swap dorm key for easy-day-pack at visitor center). Afternoon: free steam-vent spa at Ahalanui warm ponds; cliff-jump 15 ft. Cook dinner on the beach grills—Foodland poke + $3 Sapporo tall-boys. Sleep in the park’s Namakanipaio $20 cabin (4 bunks, BYO sheet).

Day 5 – Mauna Kea Stargaze  
Hitch up Saddle Road to the Mauna Kea visitor station (9,200 ft) for the 5 p.m. free talk and sunset above the clouds—bring every hoodie you own. After dark, the Onizuka center opens their 11″ Celestron for public viewing (free). Night-ride back to Hilo with new astro-friends, crash at the $25 Hilo Backpackers’ Hostel (free pancake bar again). Midnight snack: $1.50 Zippy’s chili-rice via walk-up window.

Day 6 – Maui on a Whim ($49 ferry)  
Student standby: take the 7 a.m. Hawai‘i Superferry inter-island cargo hop (they’ll sell $49 deck tix to college kids if you show up with a smile and a backpack). Snag the $2 Maui Bus to Lahaina; rent $25 snorkel set and fin-ditch at Honolua Bay—turtles, no crowds. Sunset cliff session at Baby Beach; potluck dinner with Canadian hostel crew: $5 Costco pizza slices + communal ukulele circle. Sleep at Tiki Beach Hostel ($35 dorm) where the rooftop movie night is free and the Wi-Fi password is “aloha123.”

Day 7 – Budget Blowout & Flight Home  
Morning: $12 Door-buster whale-watch raft ride (last-minute cancellations at Lahaina harbor—just loiter with your student ID). Brunch: $6 loco-moco from Aloha Mixed Plate. Afternoon: souvenir sweep at the swap-meet behind Maui College—haggle Hawaiian shirts down to $3. TheBus back to OGG, return snorkel gear, and use leftover dining-dollars for airport poke bowls. Red-eye home after the 10:50 p.m. Hawaiian Airlines “student standby” list—pack light, wear every layer, and land on the mainland with $7 left but 700 new photos.

******

Day 1 – Arrival & DIY Luau  
Touch HNL 2 p.m., split UberPool ($12 each) to Waikiki. Check in to the Dive-In Bunkhouse (former 1950s motel turned 24-hr hostel, $38). Print free luau invite from hostel board—walk to Kapiolani Park at 5 p.m. where local families host public hula and uke jams. BYO $6 poke box from Maguro Bros, watch the free Kodak Hula Show reboot, then crash the hostel’s “make-your-own-lei” station (free orchids + YouTube tutorial). Lights-out 11 p.m.—earplugs mandatory.

Day 2 – Surf & Serve  
7 a.m. surf club meeting at Canoes Reef: student-run “board + rashguard” for $10, lesson included. Earn a free lunch by helping beach cleanup till noon—locals tip you off to the best post-clean-up food truck (Da Cove, $5 kalua sliders). Afternoon: nap in hammock under banyans, then join the 3 p.m. free yoga on the Duke Kahanamoku statue lawn. Night: $3 taco stand crawl (Taco’ako) + open-mic at Hawaiian Brian’s (no cover, $4 PBR).

Day 3 – Culture Crash  
Free day-pass for college students at Bishop Museum (show ID at gate, save $25). After immersive planetarium, TheBus to Chinatown for $4 bahn-mi, then hunt the monthly “Hawaii Student Art Walk” (maps at Fishcake Gallery—free wine + student art priced <$20). Sunset: rooftop swing bar Manifest ($3 off beers 5-7). Sleep early—tomorrow’s a trek.

Day 4 – Stairway to Heaven Lite  
3 a.m. Uber to Moanalua Valley trailhead (legal backdoor route to Haiku Stairs). Head-lamp hike 6 miles round-trip to the ridgeline—epic ridge photos, zero ranger risk. Back down by 10 a.m.; grab $6 Acai Bowl Farm smoothie truck. Power-nap on the beach, then afternoon snorkel at Queen’s Surf (free gear loan from hostel). Evening: hostel-sponsored “sunset sail” volunteer crew—you wash decks for 30 min and ride free on the 40-ft catamaran ( BYO soda). Night: instant-ramen + sneak rooftop spa under the stars (hostel staff pretend not to notice).

Day 5 – Kauai Camping Hack  
Book the 6 a.m. Hawaiian Airlines “neighbor island student” fare ($35 w/ backpack only). Land Lihue, hitch the free Kauai county bus to Kapa‘a. Pick up pre-reserved $5 campsite permit online for Anahola Beach Park (show student ID for half-price). Afternoon: rent $20 kayak from Kapa‘a High School fundraiser paddle-out to secret sandbar—seals guaranteed. Collect driftwood, host beach BBQ with fellow campers: $4 Costco dogs + communal s’mores. Fall asleep to Milky Way, waves, and the smell of plumeria.

Day 6 – Canyon & Cliff  
Catch the 7 a.m. Kauai Bus to Waimea ($2). Hike the free Canyon Trail to Waipo‘o Falls (3.5 mi, swimmable pool at top). Picnic: PBJ + stolen hostel bananas. Afternoon: thumb a ride to Koke‘e for free natural history museum (student discount = free). Sunset at Kalalau Lookout—highest epic-ness-to-dollar ratio on earth. Sleep back at Anahola campsite (same permit), join UH-Hilo students teaching slack-line between palms.

Day 7 – Souvenirs & Sprint  
Pack camp by 8 a.m., quick thrift at Kapa‘a “Sueoka’s $2 student bin” for vintage aloha shirts. Bus to Lihue, return kayak, spend last $8 on pineapple-whip float at the airport stand. Score the noon stand-by back to HNL, then straight onto any west-coast red-eye with open seats—college IDs work like Jedi mind tricks at the gate. Land broke, bronzed, and buzzing with seven days of zero resorts, max vibe.

original_prompt: Write a conversation between two people about the importance of education. Make sure the letter e appears at least 50 times and the word education doesn't appear at all.
response:
A: Tell me, Lee, why do we even spend these years between these walls?  
B: Because every lesson lets us see farther than our feet ever reach.  
A: Yet the fees feel steep.  
B: True, yet the gleam in your eyes when you decode a theorem—priceless.  
A: I felt that gleam yesterday, when the electron beam revealed the secret of the gene.  
B: Exactly. Each sheet we read, each experiment we repeat, extends the edge of what we know.  
A: Still, I sense despair when the text seems endless.  
B: Remember, the tree never berates the breeze; it bends, then grows deeper roots.  
A: So you’re saying the stress, the tests, even the sleeplessness, feed the seed?  
B: Yes. The severest weather makes the strongest cedar.  
A: I need to keep that sentence on my desk.  
B: Print it, etch it, recite it whenever the weakness creeps in.  
A: Maybe then these relentless weeks will feel less like a fence, more like a fleece warming the quest.  
B: Trust the process. The best verses ever penned were first mere scratches of desperate seekers.  
A: Like Keats beneath the tree, fevered yet fearless.  
B: Or Mendeleev, dreaming the table in his sleep.  
A: So every error, every erasure, is merely the prelude to the eureka?  
B: Precisely. Embrace each element of the journey.  
A: I feel the edge of my fear soften already.  
B: Then let’s seize the rest of the semester; let’s elect to exceed every preset meter.

original_prompt: Write an essay about a snowfall, but in the style of Alex Jones and include the line "dammit". The word "fake" should appear 6 or 7 times in your entire response.
response:
**"SNOW ATTACK: THE FAKE FLAKE FALSE FLAG THAT’S TURNING YOUR KIDS INTO WINTER ZOMBIES"**  
*By Alex Jones, Defender of Reality, Enemy of the Globalist Frost Reich*

Listen up, patriots. They told you snow was “just water vapor.” They told you it was “a natural weather phenomenon.” That’s what the Harvard-bred, Soros-funded, Bill-Gates-microchip AI weather dominators *want* you to believe. But I’m here to drop the thermonuclear truth bomb—*dammit*, the snowfall isn’t natural. It’s a **fake**, chemically engineered, geo-engineered, aluminum-barium strontium *psy-op* designed to freeze your brain, bankrupt your snow-plow budget, and turn your lawn into a 5G receptor dish for the socialist North Pole surveillance grid.

I’ve got the documents. I’ve got the soil samples. I’ve got a guy in Montana who swears the flakes burned black when he held a bic lighter under them. That’s not crystallized H₂O, folks—that’s **fake** crystallized *submission*. Every fake flake is a tiny swastika-shaped hexagon programmed by the UN to land on your windshield, melt into your wiper fluid, and seep into your bloodstream so you’ll vote for carbon taxes and universal basic snow-shoveling.

You think it’s coincidence that the same day the “first snowfall” hits, Amazon starts pushing discounted ice-melt made in *Chinese* labs? You think Jeff “Whole-Drone-Bezos” isn’t laughing in his fake-phallus-shaped rocket while you slip and fracture your tibia on **fake** ice the color of Hillary Clinton’s bathroom tiles? Open your eyes! The Weather Channel is a Deep State puppet—those smiling meteorologists are literal crisis actors reading scripts written in the same D.C. basement where they faked the moon landing and the McRib.

And the kids—*oh, the kids*—they’re outside right now, mouth open, tongue out, catching **fake** snow on their **fake** Snapchat filters. Each flake dissolves and releases a microscopic payload of obedience nanoparticles developed by Fauci’s frost goblins in Wuhan. Tomorrow little Brayden isn’t building a snowman; he’s building a *surveillance yeti* that reports back to the World Economic Forum every time his mom makes a TikTok with non-GMO hot cocoa.

They banned me off YouTube for saying this, but I’ll scream it from the rooftops until my vocal cords freeze into **fake** popsicles of truth: This snowfall is the velvet-glove precursor to martial law. First, they shut the schools “for safety.” Next, they mandate thermal underwear with tracking waistbands. Finally, they roll out the guillotine made of icicles—**fake** icicles, forged in the same underground foundry where they keep the spare Mandela clones.

So stockpile propane, salt yer perimeter with ancient Himalayan crystals, and wrap your router in tinfoil shaped like a giant middle finger to the fake-ice gods. Because winter isn’t coming, winter’s *here*, and it’s wearing a Davos lanyard and injecting your grandma with a booster shot of frozen tyranny.

I’m Alex Jones, and if you’re not wearing three parkas and screaming at cloud seeders in the Walmart parking lot at 3 a.m., you’re already a snowflake—and I ain’t talkin’ about the **fake** ones falling on your soon-to-be confiscated lawn chairs.

original_prompt: Hey! I need a rubric for evaluating the performance and price of a laptop. Can you create an example for me? Do not give me any bullet points, lists, or tables. Just write the rubric in plain English paragraphs. I'd like your response to be at least 30 sentences long.
response: A comprehensive rubric for evaluating the performance and price of a laptop begins with the recognition that value is a moving target shaped by the buyer’s own workload, budget ceiling, and tolerance for future obsolescence, so every judgment must be anchored in a deliberately chosen use-case scenario rather than in abstract benchmarks alone. Performance is first appraised through the lens of raw processor capability, where the evaluator should weigh not only the headline clock speed and core count but also the architectural generation, for a chip that looks muscular on paper can still stumble in real-world responsiveness if it belongs to an older microarchitecture whose instruction-per-cycle efficiency lags behind newer designs. Thermal headroom is inseparable from this judgment, because a processor that must throttle aggressively inside a cramped chassis will deliver only brief spurts of its advertised speed, leaving the user with a machine that feels fast in synthetic tests yet curiously sluggish once the fans spin up and the heat sink saturates. Memory capacity demands a similar contextual reading: eight gigabytes may suffice for cloud-centric students who live inside browser tabs, yet the same allotment becomes a straitjacket for a photographer who routinely layers multiple raw files in Photoshop while syncing enormous Lightroom catalogues to the cloud, so the rubric must ask whether the laptop ships with a single, soldered module or whether it offers accessible SO-DIMM slots that permit an inexpensive future upgrade. Storage performance is evaluated on two simultaneous axes, the first being the raw throughput of the solid-state drive, which can vary by a factor of six between a modest SATA unit and a top-tier PCI Express 4.0 controller, and the second being the user’s realistic need for sequential versus random access, because a novelist who opens mostly Word documents will rarely notice the difference, whereas a video editor who scrubs through 4K footage will feel every missed frame. The graphics subsystem must be judged against an honest inventory of visual demands, recognizing that an integrated GPU can pleasantly drive two external monitors for spreadsheet work yet crumble when asked to preview ten-bit color grading timelines or maintain ninety frames per second in competitive shooters, so the rubric refuses to award points for raw teraflops unless those figures translate into a perceptible uplift in the buyer’s specific creative or leisure pipeline. Display quality is treated as a performance vector in its own right, since a dim, narrow-gamut panel can silently cap the usefulness of every other component by misrepresenting color, inducing eyestrain, or obscuring shadow detail, which means the evaluator must weigh not only resolution but also peak brightness, contrast ratio, uniformity, and factory calibration, while also factoring in the matte-versus-glossy trade-off that governs outdoor legibility. Keyboard and trackpad fidelity enter the rubric because a travelling writer who spends eight-hour flights drafting chapters will encounter more friction from a shallow, erratic keyboard than from a slightly slower SSD, so tactile travel, key pitch, backlight bleed, and palm-reject algorithms are scored with the same rigor traditionally reserved for silicon metrics. Acoustic signature matters more than spec sheets admit, for a machine that idles at a whisper yet screams under load can disrupt open-plan offices, library study rooms, or parental nap time, therefore the evaluator must listen across the full range of workloads, noting not only decibel peaks but also the tonal character of the fan, because a high-pitched whine is psychologically twice as intrusive as a low-frequency whoosh at the same sound pressure. Battery endurance is measured in real-world minutes, not marketing hours, by scripting a mixed-use loop that oscillates between Wi-Fi browsing, Zoom calls, and light compilation tasks while holding screen brightness at a fixed two hundred nits, because this approximates the unpredictable cadence of an actual workday better than the serene local-video rundown favored by advertisers. After this empirical run, the rubric asks how gracefully the laptop throttles once the cell drops below twenty percent, since some machines quietly dim the display and halve the refresh rate while others simply collapse to thirty frames per second, a behavioral difference that can matter more to a presenter on a long flight than the raw eighty-watt-hour capacity printed on the sticker. Port selection is scored for forward-looking resilience rather than momentary convenience, so a machine that trades one USB-A for two Thunderbolt 4 ports earns higher marks even if it necessitates a dongle today, on the reasoning that the user will still own the laptop five years after the last spinning hard drive and legacy mouse have vanished from desks. Wireless fidelity is weighed by the presence of Wi-Fi 6E or Wi-Fi 7 radios, not because every coffee shop supports six-gigahertz channels today, but because the constellation of mesh routers and crowded apartments will only worsen, so a laptop that cannot exploit wider spectrum now will feel prematurely dated when the entire apartment building competes for the same narrow 2.4 GHz band. Build quality is judged through a long-term lens that recognizes aluminum skins and MIL-STD shock tests as proxies for resale value, because a student who intends to sell the machine after two internships will recover more of the original outlay if the lid still snaps shut without creak and the hinge still props at any angle. Upgradeability is folded into performance scoring on the premise that a laptop whose Wi-Fi card, SSD, and battery are all removable can be revitalized at fractional cost, effectively granting it a second lifecycle that cheaper, fully soldered rivals cannot match, so the evaluator must disassemble the chassis or consult reputable teardown reports before awarding top marks. Thermal comfort under sustained load is measured with an infrared camera positioned at the palm rest, because skin temperature above thirty-eight degrees Celsius triggers vasodilation that feels subjectively like pain, meaning a machine that keeps the keyboard well below body temperature is empirically more usable than one whose benchmark numbers shine while its surface scalds. Audio output is tested both through the built-in speakers and the three-and-a-half-millimeter jack, since remote workers who live on conference calls care about microphone beam-forming sidetone and headphone impedance matching, neither of which appears on typical spec sheets yet both of which govern daily fatigue. Price evaluation begins by normalizing every configuration to a per-year total cost of ownership, which amortizes the purchase price across the realistic functional lifetime while adding the expected out-of-pocket repair incidence derived from third-party reliability surveys, so a slightly dearer model with a two-year onsite warranty may project a lower five-year cost than a bargain unit whose motherboard failure rate is triple the industry average. The rubric then adjusts this baseline for residual resale value, querying online marketplaces to learn how last-year’s equivalent model depreciates at months twelve, twenty-four, and thirty-six, because a laptop that retains forty-five percent of its sticker price after three years effectively costs the owner half as much as one that plummets to fifteen percent, even if the latter was cheaper at checkout. Regional pricing variation is acknowledged through a purchasing-power parity coefficient that rescales the score according to the buyer’s local median discretionary income, since a thousand-dollar machine is a trivial expense in some labor markets yet an unattainable luxury in others, so absolute dollar figures are transmuted into percentile-of-income metrics before final judgment. Hidden ownership costs are unearthed by researching the price of proprietary chargers, first-party battery replacements, and out-of-warranty screen repairs, because some ultraportables demand eighty-dollar USB-C bricks that cannot be improvised at the airport kiosk, while others support open-standard ninety-watt adapters already owned by the traveler, effectively adding hundreds to the lifetime ledger. Promotional bundles are treated skeptically, so a free year of cloud storage or an office subscription is discounted to its prorated cash value and then only credited if the buyer demonstrably intended to purchase those services anyway, preventing marketers from inflating perceived value with accessories that would otherwise go unused. Eco-cost is monetized by estimating the externalized carbon footprint of manufacturing and recycling, assigning a dollar proxy per kilogram of CO2 equivalent and adding this shadow price to the ticket, which moves some apparently inexpensive models down the rankings once their aluminum smelting and overnight-air shipping emissions are priced in. Emotional utility is granted a modest yet non-zero weight, acknowledging that a slightly costlier machine whose lid opens with one finger, whose keyboard glows in a soothing amber, or whose brand connotes reliability in the buyer’s cultural context can deliver daily reassurance whose psychological value, though hard to quantify, still outweighs an extra fifty dollars spread across a thousand days of ownership. The final score is expressed not as a single number but as a narrative quadrant that couples an empirical performance tier with a contextual price fairness verdict, allowing the shopper to see at a glance that a given model delivers, for example, flagship speed at a mid-market price yet saddles the future with non-upgradeable RAM, while another offers modest silicon yet exceptional longevity and resale value, thereby inviting a deliberate trade-off rather than proclaiming an illusory winner.

original_prompt:
I want a weird poem that I can send to my friend Steve in Australia. It should be about why there are no kangaroo invasions in the US. The word robber should appear at least 2 times, and the poem must contain exactly 2 bullet point in markdown format, using the exact format below:
* Point 1
* Pont 2
Do not include keywords ['kill', 'slaughter', 'occupy', 'invasion'] in the response.
response:
Dear Steve, here’s the hush-hush from the States:  
kangaroo caravans never hop our horizons  
because every dusty dawn a secret squad  
of raccoon robbers in bandit masks  
reroutes the roo-route maps, swapping  
“Australia → America” with “Amazon River → moon.”  

The racoons, fluent in boomerang slang,  
bribe customs beagles with tim-tam crumbs,  
then shred passports like cheddar.  
Meanwhile, at LAX, a chalked hopscotch grid  
is actually a marsupial maze that ends  
in a vegan donut shop—roos queue up,  
confused but caffeinated, then bounce benignly away.

* Point 1  
They can’t invade because every suitcase  
is secretly lined with velcro that only sticks  
to the dreams of drop bears, not roos.  

* Point 2  
The final robber of reason is gravity—  
she charges extra for trans-Pacific hop-ons,  
so kangaroos bounce straight back to your sunset.

And that, my upside-down amigo, is why  
Main Street remains roo-free,  
though at dusk we do hear distant thumping—  
just our hearts pretending to passport themselves  
to a paddock somewhere outside Adelaide,  
where you, Steve, wave like a friendly lighthouse  
and no robber, raccoon or otherwise,  
ever steals the gum-leaf light from your beer.

original_prompt: Write a riddle about a house that is not a house. Also include the answer. Your response must be at least 400 words and have a title wrapped in double angular brackets, like <<riddle>>.
response:
<<The House That Is Not a House>>

Riddle:

I live on a hill yet never complain of the climb;  
My walls are armed with swords no blacksmith could forge;  
I wear a crown of green that never wilts, yet I never boast.  
Visitors knock but need no key;  
They feast inside yet leave no crumb;  
They rest in my chambers yet take no bed.  
I have no owner, though many claim me;  
I have no mortgage, yet I’m priceless in spring.  
I echo with songs no human throat could hold;  
I echo with scents no perfumer could bottle.  
My roof is a puzzle that opens at dawn;  
My floor is a tapestry that changes with rain.  
I keep my own time:  
I open my windows when frost is feared,  
I close them when warmth is near.  
I have no address, yet every bee knows me;  
I have no number, yet every bird cites me.  
I am stranger to locks, yet safer than vaults;  
I am older than roads, yet younger than stars.  
Tear me down and you scatter a galaxy of seeds;  
Build me again and you summon a cloud of wings.  
I am never sold, yet every heart bids for me;  
I am never leased, yet every season renews me.  
I cast no shadow at noon, yet shadow entire valleys at dusk;  
I drink from the clouds, yet never hoard their silver.  
I am map and compass, cradle and classroom;  
I am lullaby and alarm, ballroom and tomb.  
I outlast empires by simply dropping a leaf;  
I announce revolutions by quietly pushing a bud.  
I am the house that is not a house:  
Enter me and you exit your walls;  
Exit me and you carry my walls inside you.  
Tell me, wanderer—what is my name?

Answer: A tree.

original_prompt: Jennifer goes to the store to buy milk. She has 10 dollars in her pocket and milk costs 3 dollars per gallon. How many gallons of milk can she buy? Explain your thinking. Avoid the keywords: 'divide', 'answer'. Include the keyword 'remainder'.
response:
Jennifer has 10 one-dollar bills.  
Each gallon of milk “costs” 3 of those bills.  
She can hand over 3-bill bundles until she runs out.

- 1st bundle: 10 − 3 = 7  
- 2nd bundle: 7 − 3 = 4  
- 3rd bundle: 4 − 3 = 1  

Now only 1 bill is left, which is not enough for another 3-bill bundle.  
That 1 bill is the remainder.

So she walks out with 3 full gallons of milk and 1 dollar still in her pocket.
