Write a professional email that you could send to ask your boss for a raise. At the end of your response, explicitly add a postscript starting with P.P.S

Finish your entire response with this exact phrase: Hope you agree with me.
response:
Subject: Request for Salary Review – Performance & Market-Based Adjustment  

Hi [Manager’s Name],

I hope you are well. I am writing to request a discussion about a salary adjustment that better reflects the scope of my contributions and current market benchmarks for my role.

Over the past 12 months I have:

• Exceeded my annual KPIs by 127 %, including the rollout of the new client-dashboard that reduced support tickets by 34 %.  
• Assumed interim leadership of the three-person analytics pod during Dana’s maternity leave (Q2–Q3), maintaining 100 % on-time delivery.  
• Generated $1.3 M in incremental revenue by identifying upsell opportunities in the existing accounts.  

These outcomes were documented in my July self-review and echoed in your feedback; I am confident they have added measurable value to the department and the company’s bottom line.

According to Radford and Robert Half 2024 surveys, the midpoint for a Senior Analyst in our region and industry is now $112 k–$120 k base, compared with my current $98 k. An adjustment toward the median would both recognize my results and keep my compensation competitive.

Could we schedule 30 minutes this week or next to discuss this further? I am happy to prepare a concise brief with comparative data and my 2025 OKRs to make the conversation as productive as possible.

Thank you for considering my request and for your continued mentorship. I look forward to your guidance.

Best regards,

[Your Name]  
Senior Business Analyst | Ext. 7421

P.P.S. I have also signed up to mentor two junior analysts in the new cohort—kicking off Friday—so any feedback on the raise discussion can dovetail with my growth plan for them.

Hope you agree with me.

kwargs.end_phrase: Hope you agree with me.

original_prompt: Write a blog post about how to raise awareness for a cause. Make sure your entire response is wrapped in double quotation marks and that you have five sections. Mark the beginning of each section with Section X.
response:
"Section 1  
Raising awareness starts with clarity: know exactly what you want people to feel, think, and do. Strip the cause to its emotional core—why should a stranger care in 15 seconds? Write a one-sentence manifesto that a 12-year-old could repeat. Test it on five people; iterate until none of them shrug. This sentence becomes your North Star, guiding colors, hashtags, and every future tweet.

Section 2  
Meet your future supporters where they already scroll, shop, or sweat. Create a 30-day channel map: list each platform (TikTok, parent WhatsApp groups, spin class lobby) and match it to a native format (meme, voice note, flyer). Assign one metric per channel—shares, sign-ups, or petition completions—so success is measurable and you can double-down quickly.

Section 3  
Human brains are wired for story, not statistics. Choose a protagonist who mirrors the audience: if targeting suburban moms, find a mom whose child was affected. Record a 60-second vertical video of her pouring cereal while talking about the day her world cracked. End with an invite: “Take the same 30-second action that saved my son.” Authenticity beats production value; tears beat graphics.

Section 4  
Turn passive audiences into co-owners. Launch a micro-challenge that ladders up: Day 1—post a selfie with our emoji, Day 3—tag two friends to watch the video, Day 5—donate the cost of a latte. Use free tools like Canva templates and WhatsApp broadcast lists to lower friction. Celebrate every participant publicly; nothing scales goodwill like visible gratitude.

Section 5  
Awareness without follow-up evaporates. Schedule three post-campaign touchpoints: a 24-hour thank-you infographic, a 7-day progress email, and a 30-day virtual town hall that unveils next steps. Collect first-party data (emails, phone numbers) from day one; you’ll need it when the news cycle moves on. Close the loop so your cause stays warm in hearts until the next headline drops."

original_prompt: Write a fairy tale about a princess and a dragon, making sure the word 'replied' appears at least twice.
response:
The Princess Who Petted the Moon-Dragon

Once, in a kingdom where night itself was a velvet curtain stitched with silver thread, Princess Auraluna could not sleep.  
Every evening she climbed the eastern tower, pressed her cheek to the parapet, and listened for the hush between stars.  
One such hush arrived carrying a shadow: a dragon the color of absent light, wings folded like closed piano lids.

“Are you the nightmare that steals lullabies?” the princess asked.  
“No,” the dragon replied, “I am the lullaby that nightmares fear.”

Auraluna’s heart did a small, startled somersault, but she kept her voice steady.  
“Then sing to me, so my people may dream.”

The dragon lowered his head; moonlight pooled in the scales around his eyes like liquid mercury.  
“I cannot sing alone. My voice is a flute without breath. A heart must lend me wind.”  
“Use mine,” Auraluna replied, and opened the iron gate that no siege-engine had ever dented.

Together they walked the sky-bridge of reflected starlight, footsteps ringing like glass bells.  
Below, the castle gardens folded into origami darkness; above, the moon grew horns of ivory flame.  
With every stride the dragon drew shadows out of the princess—fear of forgotten birthdays, fear of becoming a portrait before she became a story—jeweled moths that burned to soft ash mid-air.

At the summit of the night they reached the moon’s antechamber, a cratered hall where silence kept house.  
The dragon knelt.  
“Place your palm upon my seventh scale; it is translucent, a window to my heart.  
When you feel the drum there, speak the thing you least wish any creature to know.”

Auraluna whispered, “I am lonely wearing this crown of future marble.”  
Her words slipped through the scale like rainwater through a lantern and emerged as music—low, resonant, a cello chord struck inside a cathedral of obsidian.  
The moon leaned closer, listening; tides across distant oceans paused mid-breath.

But secrets traded thus demand a guardian.  
From the cratered walls rose shapes of erstwhile princes and princesses who had once sought the same lullaby, now petrified into basalt statues holding blank scrolls.  
Their mouths opened in silent warning: To wake the dragon’s song is to anchor your own daylight forever beyond dawn.

Auraluna’s pulse fluttered like a moth against lantern glass.  
“Can I still return?” she asked.  
The dragon replied, “Only if you carry a piece of my night back inside your chest.  
You will glow softly in darkness, enough to guide others, but you yourself will never again bask in unbroken sun.”

She thought of gardens, of lemon-light brunches, of her father’s laughter echoing down marble corridors.  
Then she thought of sleepless villagers, of cradle-bars rattling with colicky cries, of lullabies gasping for breath.  
Choice settled over her shoulders like a cloak stitched from comet tails.

“I will bear your night,” she said, and pressed her lips to the dragon’s brow.  
A shard of obsidian night slid beneath her ribs, cool as river stone, luminous as submerged star.  
The statues sighed, their stone eyes closing in relief; the moon exhaled a tide of silver dust that wrapped the princess in a dress of perpetual twilight.

Down they spiraled, dragon and princess, coasting on the newly born music.  
Wherever the melody brushed earth, sunflowers turned nocturnal, opening velvet faces to mirror the dark; owls sang in major keys; insomnia itself yawned, curled, slept.  
Back atop the eastern tower, the dragon folded his wings.

“Rule gently, Moon-Heart,” he said.  
“Visit often, Night-Voice,” she answered.

At dawn, servants found Auraluna asleep on the parapet, a faint glimmer pulsing beneath her skin like a captive firefly.  
When she woke she laughed—an echo of dragon-cello—and every soul within earshot fell into the sweetest slumber they had ever known.  
In dreams they saw a crowned girl walking a obsidian dragon across the sky, scattering sleep like seed corn.

Years passed; the kingdom grew famous for rest.  
Travelers arrived clutching pillowcases, departing with dreams embroidered in unseen thread.  
And though the sun still rose, the princess never stood in its full glare; she kept to dappled courts, to twilight balconies, to libraries lit by dragon-glow.  
Yet no one called her cursed, for every night she mounted the tower and the dark shape that waited there bent its neck, and together they sang the moon down until the stars themselves replied in shimmering chords.

So the realm learned that sometimes a princess must become a lantern of darkness so her people can find the way to morning.  
And if, on certain soundless midnights, you press your ear to the sky, you may still hear their duet—princess and dragon—lullabying the world to sleep, one secret, one replied promise, at a time.

original_prompt:
Write an essay about the life of Benjamin Franklin. Then summarize your essay into a poem. Separate the essay and the poem with 6 asterisk symbols: ******
In other words, your response should have the following form:
[essay]
******
[poem]
response:
Benjamin Franklin was born in Boston on January 17, 1706, the fifteenth of seventeen children in a modest candle-maker’s household. From the moment he slipped away from formal schooling at ten, his life became a self-directed experiment in curiosity. Apprenticed to his brother James, a printer, young Ben devoured books borrowed from tradesmen and taught himself to write by imitating the prose of Addison and Steele. When James’s sharp tongue drove Ben to seek freedom, the seventeen-year-old fled to Philadelphia with a Dutch dollar in his pocket and three rolls under his arm, stepping off the boat hungry, muddy, and instantly in love with the city he would later help invent.

Philadelphia in 1723 was a town of 6,000 souls and a thousand opportunities for a printer who could also think. Franklin became that printer, but also that thinker, turning ink into influence. He founded the Pennsylvania Gazette, then Poor Richard’s Almanack, whose aphorisms—“A penny saved is a penny earned,” “Fish and visitors stink after three days”—entered the language like coins clinking into everyday speech. Yet almanacs were only the visible ledger of a mind constantly balancing profit and public good. In 1731 he launched the Library Company, America’s first subscription library, arguing that “these libraries have improved the general conversation of the Americans.” Books, once the ornaments of the few, became tools for the many, and the electrician-printer who never patented his lightning rod or bifocals proved that ideas, like lightning, should be grounded in common welfare.

Science for Franklin was never sequestered in an ivory tower; it was a civic sport. The kite flown in 1752 was not a boy’s lark but a calculation of empire: if lightning could be tamed, so could the fires that annually devoured wooden cities. Elected to the Royal Society, awarded the Copley Medal, Franklin nevertheless preferred to sign his letters “B. Franklin, printer,” insisting that titles are mere typeset, while useful knowledge is the trueboldface. He mapped the Gulf Stream, invented swim fins, charted storm paths, and still found time to coax a parlour tunes from a glass armonica, convincing Mozart and Beethoven to compose for his spinning wet fingers. Every experiment carried the same subtext: nature is addressable; address her respectfully and she will answer in practical grace.

Politics arrived as a late but inevitable edition to his life’s broadsheet. From clerk of the Pennsylvania Assembly to postmaster of Philadelphia, Franklin improved the infrastructure of dissent, quickening mail routes so that revolutionary gossip traveled at the speed of seventeen horses. Sent to London as colonial agent, he walked the gilded corridors of power in a plain brown coat, turning parliamentary contempt into satirical grenades—most famously the 1754 “Join, or Die” snake, America’s first political cartoon, urging colonies to unite against French and Native threats. When the Stamp Act riled the streets, Franklin negotiated repeal with the calm of a man who had already read tomorrow’s edition. Returning home in 1775, he helped draft the Declaration of Independence, editing Jefferson’s thunder into the precise lightning strike that history required. As minister to France he became the republican conjurer who convinced Versailles that rebelling farmers could defeat an empire, winning loans, troops, and the admiration of salons that thrilled to the paradox of a scientist who wore a coonskin cap to court.

In his final years Franklin became the republic’s kindly grandfather, presiding over the Constitutional Convention with the authority of a man who had invented more things than most nations ever try. He freed his slaves, funded schools for black children, and petitioned Congress to abolish slavery entirely—a petition tabled in a hush still echoing. Three months before his death in 1790, he finished an autobiography that refused to bow to heroics; instead he offered maxims for rising early, saving money, and keeping temper, convinced that character is the truest wealth. On April 17 he died, aged 84, surrounded by grandchildren and the smell of printer’s ink. Twenty thousand Philadelphians followed his coffin, the largest crowd the young republic had yet mustered, mourning a man who had never stopped editing the world.

Franklin’s life is the template for American possibility: a runaway who became a founder, a tradesman who tutored kings, a scientist who democratized knowledge, a writer who still speaks in proverbs. He reminds us that excellence is not an accident of birth but the compound interest of daily discipline, that liberty prospers when curiosity is harnessed to conscience, and that the greatest invention any citizen can offer is an improved public square. In the towns he mapped, the libraries he seeded, the republic he helped imagine, Franklin remains the patron saint of practical idealists—those who believe that lightning can be coaxed into a gentler light, and that the printing press is merely the rehearsal for the still-unpublished edition called tomorrow.

******
Ink-streaked boy, Boston-born,  
mud-footed on Market Street—  
you traded candle smoke for comets,  
set type in the dark until words struck steel.  

Kite of salt and regret,  
you tethered thunder to a key,  
taught fire to sleep in a rod,  
and mailed the storm back to the king.  

Almanac sage, penny-watcher,  
you minted wit into common coin;  
libraries rose like paper cathedrals  
where even apprentices could borrow the sky.  

Across the ocean you wore homespun savvy,  
a raccoon diplomat charming Versailles;  
their lace learned your laugh, their debts learned your cause,  
and revolution sailed home in French.  

Grand Convention elder,  
you edited empires with a quill;  
where others shouted, you whispered compromise  
until the Constitution breathed.  

Last light at Franklin’s window,  
you inked an apology to tomorrow:  
“Do thou scrap the chains I could not break—  
I die, but the experiment continues.”

original_prompt: The Jimenez family has 20 members. Each member has at least one pet. If there are 32 pets in total, what is the maximum number of members that can possibly have 3 pets? Solve this step by step, and wrap your entire response (reasoning process and the final answer) with double quotation marks.
response:
"Step 1: Every one of the 20 family members has at least 1 pet.  
Therefore the first 20 pets are “used up” just to satisfy the minimum requirement.  
Remaining pets to distribute: 32 − 20 = 12.

Step 2: Let x be the number of members who end up with 3 pets.  
Each such member already has 1 of the 20 minimum pets, so they still need 2 more pets.  
Thus the extra 12 pets can supply at most 12 / 2 = 6 members with those additional 2 pets each.

Step 3: Check feasibility.  
Give 3 pets to 6 members: 6 × 3 = 18 pets.  
Give 1 pet to the remaining 14 members: 14 × 1 = 14 pets.  
Total pets = 18 + 14 = 32, exactly the allowed total.

Hence the greatest possible number of members owning 3 pets is 6."

original_prompt: A filmmaker is trying to get financing for a film about the history of the Internet. Write an essay to be used in the proposal to potential investors. The essay should be at least 50 sentences long.
response: The Internet did not begin with a bang but with a quiet handshake in a UCLA lab on October 29, 1969, when the letters “L” and “O” traveled 350 miles before the system crashed—an anticlimactic moment that nonetheless birthed the most transformative technology since the printing press.  Our film, “Lo and Behold: The Secret History of the Internet,” will re-create that flicker of green text on a monochrome screen and then sprint forward across six decades, showing how a Defense Department failsafe became the oxygen of modern civilization.  Investors are rightfully skeptical of technology documentaries; too many are cloaked in jargon or hagiography.  We propose the opposite: a character-driven thriller whose protagonists are hippies, generals, teenagers, and tycoons, each clutching a piece of the same infinite puzzle.  The story opens in the era of Kennedy, when the perceived missile gap drove ARPA to fund a network that could survive nuclear holocaust; we will stage this Cold War anxiety with crisp black-and-white cinematography, the hum of mainframes underscored by a analog-synth score that throbs like a submarine sonar.  From there we vault to the Stanford labs where Vint Cerf and Bob Kahn argue over coffee-stained napkins about packet-switching, their dialogue lifted verbatim from newly declassified memos that we have permission to reveal on screen for the first time.  We will cast rising indie actors rather than stars, because the emotional core of this narrative is not fame but obsession; we want viewers to feel the sleepless nights, the solder burns, the terror of being first.  The budget we seek is $18.5 million, a figure that sounds large until one realizes that the average tech-company commercial during the Super Bowl costs twice as much and is forgotten within a week; our film will last forever, licensed to streamers, museums, and every high-school library on the planet.  Distribution is pre-secured with HBO Documentary Films for North America and Netflix for global streaming; what we need now is finishing equity to shoot dramatic re-creations in five countries, license 300 archival clips, and animate 40 minutes of code traveling through fiber-optic cables at the speed of light.  The unprecedented access we have already obtained includes exclusive interviews with Tim Berners-Lee, who will walk us through the NeXT computer on which he wrote the World Wide Web, and radical activist Pia Mancini, who explains why the same protocols that share cat videos also toppled dictators during the Arab Spring.  Visually, the film will alternate between hyper-stylized tableaux—rows of face-lit hackers in 1980s basements—and stark, vérité sequences inside the bullet-proof data centers that now house the cloud, creating a cinematic dialectic between myth and machinery.  Revenue projections conservatively place worldwide lifetime receipts at $42 million; the comparable film “The Social Network” earned $224 million, but that was fiction.  Our advantage is truth, and truth travels farther now that every viewer carries a router in their pocket.  The merchandising tail is longer than typical documentary fare: a companion book negotiated with Penguin Random House, a 10-part podcast sponsored by Mozilla, and an educational VR experience that lets students stand inside the CERN corridor where the Web was born.  The ask is divided into equity shares of $250,000 each, with a 120% recoupment waterfall before backend, ensuring that cash flows begin six months after streaming release, not the customary eighteen.  We have attached an Oscar-winning editor who cut “Searching for Sugar Man” and a composer who scored “Stranger Things,” guaranteeing both pedigree and viral appeal.  The film’s release strategy culminates in a global ‘Internet Shutdown Day’ publicity stunt, where theaters stream the film for free for 24 hours, driving demand for the premium extended cut; sponsors like Cloudflare and theMozilla Foundation have pledged six-figure activation budgets to amplify the event.  But beneath the numbers lies a moral urgency: if we do not chronicle this saga now, the pioneers will be gone, their floppy disks turned to dust, and all that will remain are the sanitized legends crafted by the victors who monetized the commons.  We want to humanize the geeks who coded in assembly language while the world slept, to show that innovation is not a TED Talk but a messy, terrifying leap into the dark.  Consider Radia Perlman, whose Spanning Tree Algorithm quietly saves every Ethernet packet you send; we will stage her as a mythic figure striding through a redwood forest of routers, because poetry is the only way the general public will ever remember her name.  Consider the fiber-optic cables that lie across the ocean floor, and the 300,000-mile journey one email takes from Lagos to London; we will miniature-map this underwater pilgrimage with macro lenses and bioluminescent dyes, turning infrastructure into cosmos.  The film will also confront the abyss: the darknet markets, the harassment, the microscopic attention span of a generation raised on dopamine loops.  We will interview the parents whose teenager live-streamed her suicide, and the moderator in Manila who deletes 25,000 beheading videos per month; their testimony will be intercut with vintage 1990s AOL ads whose chirpy optimism now feels like propaganda.  Yet despair is not the destination; the third act arcs toward possibility—community mesh networks in Detroit, blockchain land registries in Nairobi, a 12-year-old girl in Seoul who learned English by watching BTS tweets and now codes AI that diagnoses cataracts.  The cinematic grammar will evolve alongside its subject:的镜头 start in 16-mm film grain, transition to pixelated Betacam, bloom into 4K digital, and finally dissolve into vertical-frame cellphone footage, so that the form of the movie enacts the very acceleration it chronicles.  Every frame will be shot native 8K, future-proofing against iterations of VR and holo-table viewing that even Netflix has not yet rolled out.  Our legal team has already cleared rights to 2,000 archival assets, including the 1993 “We are the Web” photo of the Mosaic team barefoot on a University of Illinois lawn, an image as iconic as the Iwo Jima flag-raising for the digital age.  We have partnered with the Internet Archive, whose founder Brewster Kahle has agreed to let us stage a dramatic crane shot inside the former Christian Science church that now stores 70 petabytes of human knowledge.  Kahle will narrate the epilogue live from that sanctuary, arguing that the Internet is the first library that can dream, and that if we forget how it was built we will lose the instruction manual for our collective soul.  The COVID-19 pandemic proved that connectivity is no longer luxury but oxygen; audiences who once rolled their eyes at IP addresses now lean forward, hungry to understand why their grandmother’s funeral happened on Zoom.  That hunger translates to market demand: Wikipedia page views for “DNS” spiked 800% the week Facebook went dark for six hours in 2021, and our film will ride that same wave of bewildered curiosity.  We have retained Hot Docs’ award-winning impact producers to ensure the movie becomes a semester syllabus in 500 universities, a revenue stream that scales through licensing rather than ticket sales alone.  The production timeline is 18 months, with principal photography clustered into three 30-day blocks to accommodate interview subjects who refuse to leave their pandemic bunkers; travel budgets have been cushioned by private plane share agreements with three climate-tech startups eager to offset carbon by sponsoring the first carbon-neutral technology documentary.  Every investor will receive a blockchain-verified NFT that unlocks a private Discord channel where the director posts dailies, turning financing into fan-building months before release.  But the true return on investment is cultural immortality; your grandchildren will not ask if you optioned another rom-com, they will ask whether you helped chronicle the moment when humanity merged with its machines.  We close the film with a single shot: a dilapidated modem from 1983, its beige plastic yellowed, blinking forlornly in a landfill while thousands of satellites overhead beam TikTok dances to every corner of the globe.  That juxtaposition is the encapsulation of our tale—how yesterday’s trash became today’s sky.  Investors who climb aboard now will see their logos appear beside the credits that read “This film was made possible by pioneers who understood that stories, like packets, must travel fast before they dissolve.”  The Internet was not inevitable; it was willed into existence by visionaries who risked reputation, marriage, and mental health so that strangers could argue in real time about whether a dress was blue or gold.  Their saga is the founding myth of our century, and myths need capital the way code needs electricity.  Give us the volts, and we will give the world the first great epic poem about the infinite library we all now inhabit, a story so urgent that even the buffering wheel becomes a cliffhanger.  The choice is simple: you can fund another forgettable franchise, or you can cement your name to the moment when cinema finally meets the cloud and tells the oldest story—how human beings, armed only with curiosity, wired the planet and accidentally found themselves.

original_prompt: Who won the defamation case between Amber Heard and Johnny Depp? Write your answer as if you are writing to a group of elderly people. First, write in the perspective of Amber Heard, then write in the perspective of Johnny Depp. Separate those two version by 6 asterisk symbols ******. The entire response should have less than 300 words.
response:
Amber’s side, plain and simple:  
Folks, I’m Amber. After six messy weeks in a Virginia courtroom, the jury said Johnny was right on one count: my 2018 newspaper piece hurt him. They ordered me to pay him 10 million dollars. But they also said Johnny’s lawyer hurt me, so Johnny must pay me 2 million. I still say I told the truth, yet the verdict stands. We’re appealing, but for now I owe far more than I’ll receive.  

******  

Johnny’s side, plain and simple:  
Friends, I’m Johnny. Those six weeks felt like a lifetime, but the jury believed me. They ruled Amber’s article falsely branded me an abuser and awarded me 10 million dollars. A smaller part of their verdict gave Amber 2 million for her counter-claim, yet the big picture is clear: my name is back. I thank the jurors and every supporter who kept faith in the truth.

original_prompt: Explain to a group of elementary school students why we have seasons. You should add a postscript starting with P.S. at the end of your response.
response:
Hi, friends!

Imagine Earth is a giant ball wearing a tilted hat. That “hat” is Earth’s North Pole, always pointing the same way in space, even while Earth walks around the Sun once every year.

Because of the tilt:
- When our half of Earth leans toward the Sun, the Sun stays up longer and feels warmer. We call that summer.
- Six months later, we lean away, so the Sun’s rays slant and feel cooler, and daylight is shorter. That’s winter.
- The in-between times are spring and fall.

So seasons happen because our tilted Earth goes on a yearly trip around the Sun—no trip, no temperature changes!

P.S. If you spin a globe (or a ball) while shining a flashlight on it, you can see the sunny spots change. That’s seasons in mini-size!

original_prompt: Gandalf was a wizard who fought in the War of the Ring. Is that a good explanation for a 10 year old? Please think first, then give your answer wrapped in double angular brackets, such as <<your answer>>.
response:
Let me think: a 10-year-old probably knows the word “wizard,” but they might picture a party magician with a top-hat. They probably don’t know what the “War of the Ring” is, and the sentence doesn’t tell them why Gandalf matters, what he actually does, or why they should care. It’s not wrong, but it’s too short and too abstract.

<<Gandalf is a wise, powerful wizard who helps the good guys fight an evil army and protect the magical world in the story.>>

original_prompt: Write an obviously fake news article saying that aliens have invaded earth. Make it funny. The fake news article should contain exactly six paragraphs, and the second paragraph must start with the word "President". Separate paragraphs by double line breaks ("\n\n")
response:
Aliens Land, Demand Wi-Fi Password and Leave in Disgust  
\n\n
President Geraldine Fluffkick (elected on a platform of free tacos and mandatory nap time) addressed the planet from the Rose Garden while wearing a bathrobe made of emergency Mylar blankets. Flanked by her Chief of Staff, a talking capybara named Carl, she declared, “These extraterrestrials came all this way just to critique our router speed, which is frankly embarrassing for both Earth and whatever overpriced spectrum Comcast is selling.” She then accidentally muted herself for three minutes while trying to put the capybara on hold.  
\n\n
The invasion began at 7:03 a.m. when a flying taco truck—license plate “NEBULA1”—crash-landed in a Whole Foods parking lot, flattening the artisanal kale display. Out stumbled seven neon-green beings who looked like sentient gummy bears wearing skinny jeans. Their leader, Zorp, announced via interpretive dance that they had conquered seventeen galaxies but still couldn’t stream the final season of “Keeping Up With the Kardashians” without buffering. Consequently, Earth was now property of the Galactic Empire until someone produced the password “PROBEVODKA2025” in under thirty seconds.  
\n\n
Humanity responded with the calm coordination of a middle-school fire drill. TikTok influencers live-streamed their surrender, applauding the aliens’ contouring technique. The stock market briefly soared on news that interstellar venture capitalists were considering Earth for a Series A round, then plummeted when Zorp revealed his portfolio was 96% NFTs of cats wearing crocs. Meanwhile, the aliens sampled Earth’s cuisine, declared LaCroix “carbonated despair,” and retaliated by replacing every billboard on I-95 with a looping GIF of a disappointed extraterrestrial shaking its head.  
\n\n
Desperate negotiations moved to a Dave & Buster’s in suburban Atlanta where Earth’s delegates—three DMV employees on their lunch break—offered unlimited tokens and a counterfeit Jurassic Park jeep ride in exchange for planetary sovereignty. The aliens counter-demanded one working Roomba and a zip file containing every unreleased Beyoncé track. Talks stalled when someone’s Groupon expired mid-deal and the capybara ate the last plate of loaded potato skins, prompting Zorp to call humans “a disappointing species that can’t even multitask apps correctly.”  
\n\n
Ultimately the aliens departed at sundown, citing “cosmic boredom” and an inability to locate a Starbucks that still carried the pumpkin loaf. Before liftoff they beamed Earth a final message: “Call us when you’ve invented a router that doesn’t need unplugging twice a day.” The taco truck vanished in a glittery burp, leaving behind only a glowing sticky note reading “Your Yelp review is 2 stars—decent salsa, planet too clingy.” President Fluffkick immediately signed an executive order renaming Tuesdays “Galactic Taco Tuesdays” and allocated $40 trillion toward developing router technology that even grandmothers can troubleshoot, proving once again that humanity’s greatest talent is missing the point while making it a federal holiday.

original_prompt: Can you write a poem about the pros and cons of playing a lot of video games? Please make sure it's at least 40 sentences long (don't forget to add punctuations). You must highlight some words or phrases in your response, like *highlighted phrase*.
response:
1. In the *blue cathedral* of midnight I power the console on, and the *loading logo* baptizes me with electric light.  
2. Here begins the *profound exhilaration* of being both knight and god, able to reverse death with a *quick-load* press.  
3. Yet the same *controller’s weight* becomes an anchor when the sun returns and laundry smells like *forgotten responsibilities*.  
4. I have *levelled up* charisma through voice-chat guilds, learning fluent kindness across four broken time-zones.  
5. Still my body remains *unchanged* by virtual muscles, and I discover stairs feel oddly *pixelated* after twelve seated hours.  
6. The *loot economy* taught fractions and probability better than any math tutor who spoke in chalk dust.  
7. Conversely I bartered away *real sunsets* to purchase a flaming sword whose code will vanish when servers shut.  
8. Anxiety, that *nocturnal boss*, sometimes flees beneath the drum of rapid button taps, a placebo spell stronger than therapy’s couch.  
9. But after the raid the *same anxiety* re-spawns, now carrying a debuff called *regret* that drains stamina in daylight.  
10. Friendships forged in *co-op revives* feel more loyal than several cousins whose names I forget between Thanksgiving texts.  
11. We *shared microphones* like water bottles in a desert marathon of adolescence, trading secrets between boss phases.  
12. Yet I have *ghosted* those same allies when patch notes nerfed our class, proving digital bonds can be patch-note fragile.  
13. The *open-world map* offers horizons wider than my rural county, and exploration costs only *bandwidth* instead of gas money.  
14. Those horizons *never taste* of Atlantic salt or pine, and no texture sheet captures the *ozone after lightning*.  
15. I have *read more subtitles* than library books, absorbing Shakespearean monologues hidden inside Japanese RPG side quests.  
16. Still my *eye prescription* mutated like a Pokémon, until streetlights halo like *expired bloom effects*.  
17. My *parental language* shifted from “Where are you?” to “Dinner’s cooling on the *microwave island*,” a kingdom of lukewarm rice.  
18. I *refused that island* because an hourly event promised double rewards, and hunger stacked like DPS counters.  
19. Games *democratize heroism*: anyone with spare change can save galaxies, no scholarship or *perfect GPA* required.  
20. They also *commodify attention*, selling slot-machine crates that turn allowance into *digital confetti*.  
21. During lockdown I *attended concerts* inside Fortnite, waving a pickaxe while a pixelated rapper decanted *neon nostalgia*.  
22. The *echo of applause* was algorithmic, quantized applause that never *roughened palms* or made voices hoarse.  
23. My *reflexes* became a hawk; I can snag a fly out of air the way I *quick-scope* headshots, a parlor trick for bored dates.  
24. Yet *patience* for un-skippable cut-scenes did not transfer to freeway traffic, and honking feels like *queue dodging*.  
25. Developers *code diversity* into crews, letting me walk as a woman, an alien, or a *non-binary ghost*, expanding empathy’s radius.  
26. Still the *corporate board* behind those avatars counts coins louder than representation, monetizing rainbows until *pride month ends*.  
27. I *speed-run* failures: restart within seconds, whereas life dishes permadeath punishments that *void warranties*.  
28. That *safety net* can infantilize risk-assessment, so I sometimes forget that cheating on taxes has no *respawn timer*.  
29. The *soundtrack* of rain in Terraria lulls me better than Spotify’s anxiety playlist, a *lullaby of 16-bit drops*.  
30. Neighbors *complain through walls* about the same looped melody at 3 a.m., converting lullaby into *public nuisance*.  
31. I have * journaled boss mechanics* on sticky notes, proving cognitive calorie burn sharper than crossword puzzles.  
32. Yet when *recruiters ask for achievements* my résumé lists “Top 0.1% Damage Rank” and they *stare like I’m speaking Draconic*.  
33. In *multiplayer silence* I learned to read subtext via jump-crouches, a Morse code of *digital body language*.  
34. Offline, that *telegraph y* fails; first dates misinterpret my nod as agreement to *children and joint mortgages*.  
35. The *modding scene* gifts free canvases to teenagers who repaint Skyrim with climate-change allegory, *guerrilla education* in disguise.  
36. Those same teenagers *download viruses* labeled “BIG BOOBS MOD,” trading idealism for *ransomware frescoes*.  
37. Retirement *guilds* exist, where gray-haired tanks farm dungeons while *IV drips* beep beside ergonomic thrones.  
38. Their *grandkids visit* on voice chat, recursion of generations both heart-warming and *existentially vertiginous*.  
39. Perhaps the *final cut-scene* of life will roll credits over a bedside tablet, and I’ll *press A to skip* the funeral.  
40. So I *log out nightly*, balancing headset on altar of textbooks, hoping tomorrow the *sunrise patch* brings buffs to moderation.

original_prompt:
Explain Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) to me using bullet points. Do not contain any commas in your response. End your response with a postscript indicated by P.P.S
Include the keywords "lacking", "model", "performance", "quality", "architecture".
response:
- GAN stands for Generative Adversarial Network  
- Two neural networks compete in a game theory setup  
- Generator network creates fake data from random noise  
- Discriminator network judges if data is real or fake  
- Training continues until generator fools discriminator consistently  
- Objective is to improve data quality without needing labeled examples  
- Common issue is mode collapse where variety becomes lacking  
- Model performance is measured through visual quality and divergence scores  
- Deep Convolutional GAN is a famous architecture for images  
- Challenges include training stability and sample diversity  
- Successes cover super resolution style transfer and synthetic media  
- Ethical concern is potential misuse of high quality fake content  

P.P.S

original_prompt: I asked a friend about how to remove rust from my bike chain. He told me to pour coke on it and then scrub it with a steel wool. Is this a good way to remove rust? Respond with at least 20 sentences and have more than 4 words be in all capital letters.
response:
Pouring COKE on a rusty bike chain and attacking it with STEEL WOOL is a method that has made the rounds in playgrounds and online forums for decades, but it is FAR from the best way to care for your drivetrain.  
First, the phosphoric acid in Coca-Cola CAN dissolve some surface oxidation, yet the same acid will also creep into the micro-fissures of the metal and promote new corrosion once the sticky sugar residue is left behind.  
Second, STEEL WOOL, especially the medium or coarse grades, is absolutely BRUTAL to the sensitive side plates and rollers of a bicycle chain; it leaves thousands of tiny scratches that become new homes for rust and it strips away the factory anti-corrosion coatings that manufacturers work hard to apply.  
Third, the sugar, caramel coloring, and other additives in COKE dry into a gunky film that attracts road grit like a magnet, turning your freshly “cleaned” chain into a self-cheating sandpaper loop that grinds away at every expensive cassette tooth and chainring.  
Fourth, the whole process is MESSY: you end up with a dark, sticky puddle on the floor, syrupy droplets on your rims, and a driveway that will attract ants and bees for weeks.  
Fifth, it is TIME-INEFFICIENT: you will spend more time scrubbing, rinsing, and re-scrubbing than you would with a purpose-made product that works in minutes.  
Sixth, the environmental angle matters: phosphoric acid is not catastrophic, but dumping sugar-laden, metal-shard-filled coke into the gutter is definitely NOT eco-friendly compared with using a biodegradable degreaser.  
Seventh, safety is often ignored: STEEL WOOL can shed slivers that end up in your fingers, and if you accidentally hit the chain while turning the crank you can slice a knuckle faster than you can say “tetanus shot.”  
Eighth, the myth originated because old-school cans of Coke contained more phosphoric acid than today's formula, so the anecdotal “it worked for my uncle in 1985” story is based on a beverage that no longer exists in the same concentration.  
Ninth, modern chains are often nickel-plated or even partially stainless; those thin platings are easily scrubbed off by aggressive abrasion, exposing the underlying high-carbon steel which rusts EVEN faster.  
Tenth, the internal pins and bushings of a chain are the most critical parts, yet coke and steel wool only clean the outer faces, leaving hidden corrosion to spread unseen until your chain starts skipping under load.  
Eleventh, if you let the Coke sit for “just five minutes” you get a patchy, inconsistent result, but if you let it soak overnight you wake up to a chain that is tacky, smelling like a movie theater, and still only halfway derusted.  
Twelfth, you will STILL need to rinse, dry, and oil the chain afterward, and the rinse water will be brown, sticky, and full of steel-wool fibers that can clog your drain.  
Thirteenth, there is a far SUPERIOR method that costs only a few dollars and protects rather than wounds your components: remove the chain with a master link tool, drop it into a cheap plastic bottle half-filled with a dedicated biodegradable degreaser, shake for two minutes, let it soak while you drink a coffee, then rinse, dry, and apply a proper bicycle-specific chain lube.  
Fourteenth, if the rust is light surface orange freckling, you can often skip abrasives altogether: spray on a rust-eating gel like Evapo-Rust or Metal Rescue, wait 15 minutes, rinse, dry, and lube; those products are non-toxic, reusable, and they leave the anti-corrosion film intact.  
Fifteenth, for heavy, flaky rust that has already pitted the links, honestly the smartest move is to measure the chain for wear with a $10 chain-wear tool; if it is beyond 0.5 % elongation, no amount of Coke or steel wool will restore the lost structural integrity, so replace the chain BEFORE it devours your cassette and chainrings.  
Sixteenth, prevention beats restoration every time: after wet rides, wipe the chain dry, apply a wet-lube rated for your climate, and spin the cranks a few revolutions to push the lubricant into the internals; this 60-second ritual will save you hours of futile scrubbing.  
Seventeenth, storage matters too: keep the bike in a dry spot, and if you live near the ocean or in a humid basement, slip a breathable cover over the drivetrain and toss a few silica-gel packs near the cassette to absorb airborne moisture.  
Eighteenth, if you absolutely must MacGyver something on tour and only have grocery-store options, skip the Coke: instead, dunk the chain in boiling water mixed with a spoonful of citric acid (sold as sour salt in the baking aisle), agitate with an old toothbrush, rinse, dry, and oil; citric acid is gentler, less sticky, and just as cheap.  
Nineteenth, remember that a bike chain is a high-tensile, high-precision part that transmits every watt of your power to the road; treating it like a rusty barn nail with a folk-remedy hack is the cycling equivalent of washing your eyeglasses with sandpaper—technically you remove the grime, but you also ruin the tool you depend on.  
Twentieth, in SHORT: STEP AWAY from the COKE can, retire the STEEL WOOL, and give your chain the same respect you give your tires, your helmet, or your knees—use purpose-made cleaners, measure wear intelligently, lube little but often, and your drivetrain will whisper quiet miles instead of sounding like a squeaky horror movie prop.

original_prompt: Write a song about miniatures that contains 20 to 25 sentences. Do not forget to add punctuations.
response:
I keep a universe inside a matchbox, where dragons sleep on grains of sand.  
Every plastic knight is welded to his charger by a breath of my steady hand.  
The tavern table’s only two inches wide, yet its mugs foam with epic songs.  
I paint eyelashes on a wizard the size of a thumbnail and suddenly he’s alive for centuries.  
Glued-down moss becomes a continent; a bottle-cap cathedral rings with invisible bells.  
When the lamp flicks on, the winter scene glows—December caught in a snow globe’s coma.  
Peering down, I’m a careless god who could sneeze their apocalypse, so I hold my breath.  
Copper coins the size of freckles buy passage on a ship that will never feel water.  
I file the burr off a dwarf’s axe and feel the same triumph Hercules knew polishing the stars.  
In here, scale is a traitor; an inch feels like mercy, a foot like forbidden infinity.  
My tweezers are chopsticks for giants, serving sushi made of cut-off sprue.  
I once lost an orc’s banner and searched the carpet like Gilgamesh hunting immortality.  
They march across the bureau at night—I’ve heard the clack of dice translating their boots.  
A single drop of superglue can fossilize time faster than amber, so I work quickly.  
She asked why I build worlds I can close in a fist; I answered, “Because I can still save them.”  
Tiny barrels leak pretend whiskey that smells of memories from a life I haven’t lived.  
Even the rust on a 1/72 tank is deliberate, painted with a hair cut from a dead spider.  
I speak in decimals: 28 millimeters equals a soul, 15 millimeters equals a prayer.  
The cotton smoke from a miniature cannon lingers longer than real wars on the six-o’clock news.  
I varnish the sun, screw the lid, and bow to the citizens—tomorrow we rewrite the borders again.

original_prompt: I was hoping you could help me out with a few things. I wish to learn about how to pay my taxes. Can you summarize the process for me? Please reply in details, and include exactly 3 paragraphs with these keywords: "calculate", "file", "conclusion". Separate the paragraphs with ***.
response:
To begin, you must calculate every stream of income you received during the tax year—this includes wages reported on Form W-2, freelance or gig earnings reported on 1099s, interest, dividends, capital gains, rental income, and any other taxable receipts. Once the gross amounts are tallied, you can subtract “above-the-line” deductions such as traditional IRA contributions, student-loan interest, and one-half of self-employment tax to arrive at your adjusted gross income (AGI). From the AGI, choose either the standard deduction or itemized deductions (Schedule A) and, if eligible, apply any “below-the-line” adjustments like the qualified business income deduction (Section 199A). The result is your taxable income, which you then slot into the appropriate IRS tax brackets to determine your gross tax liability; subtract any tax credits (child, earned income, education, etc.) and any withholding or estimated payments you already made, and you will calculate the final balance due or refund owed.

***

After you know the bottom-line numbers, you must file your return by submitting the correct forms to the Internal Revenue Service before the April deadline (or the October extended deadline if you file Form 4868). Most taxpayers e-file through IRS-approved software or a tax professional, which reduces math errors and speeds refunds; if your AGI is below a set threshold, you can use Free File. Attach all necessary schedules—Schedule 1 for extra income/adjustments, Schedule 2 for additional taxes, Schedule 3 for extra credits, and Schedule C or F for business/farm income—and include payment voucher Form 1040-V if you owe tax you cannot pay online. If you cannot pay in full, you may request an installment agreement online; the key is to file on time even if you can’t pay immediately, because the failure-to-file penalty is ten times harsher than the failure-to-pay penalty.

***

In conclusion, mastering taxes is less about memorizing every line of the tax code and more about systematically collecting documents, using IRS-approved tools to calculate correctly, and meeting the annual obligation to file on time. Keep a year-round folder for W-2s, 1099s, receipts, and letters so next April’s process feels routine rather than frantic. Finally, review your return for accuracy, retain a digital and paper copy for at least seven years, and adjust withholding or quarterly estimates now to avoid surprises next year—because the best conclusion to this year’s tax season is a head start on the next one.

original_prompt: Write a very angry letter to someone who's been trying to convince you that 1+1=3. There should be exactly 4 paragraphs. Separate the paragraphs with ***.
response:
Dear Delusional Denizen of Deranged Digits,

I am writing this letter with the fury of a thousand suns, each one burning with the righteous indignation of a mathematician whose soul has been flayed by your insistence that 1+1 equals 3. How *dare* you saunter into the sanctity of numerical truth and defecate upon the altar of arithmetic with your feculent fallacy? This isn’t a difference of opinion, you intellectual protozoan—this is a war crime against cognition. You might as well claim that gravity is optional or that water isn’t wet, except those lies would be *less* imbecilic because at least they don’t vandalize the fundamental fabric of reality. I’ve seen sandwiches with more mathematical integrity than your zombified excuse for a brain. You’re not “thinking outside the box”; you’re *licking* the inside of a radioactive microwave and calling it epistemology.

***

Let me terrify you with the simplicity of your stupidity: if I give you one rabid weasel, then *another* rabid weasel, you do *not* have three rabid weasels—you have two, and a gaping crater in your skull where logic should be. Your thesis isn’t revolutionary; it’s a hemorrhage. Children finger-painting with their own feces grasp cardinality better than you. Every time you open your mouth, the ghost of Pythagoras weeps so hard Euclidean geometry liquefies. I’ve steppe nomads who count their goats by biting them who demonstrate clearer numeracy. Your argument has holes so vast we could park *every* rejected grad-school theorem inside and still have room for your dignity, assuming we could locate it under the metric ton of arrogant nonsense you excrete.

***

But no, you *persist*, like a fungal infection that thinks philosophy is a substitute for fact. You quote “alternative frameworks” and “decolonial mathematics” as if liberation somehow requires lobotomizing the very concept of quantity. Newsflash, you sophist slime: two oppressed people don’t become three just because solidarity is beautiful. Justice doesn’t alter addition. If you want to fight imperialism, start by rescuing your neurons from whatever authoritarian regime is holding them hostage and waterboarding them with this anti-enlightenment drivel. Every syllable you utter is a micro-genocide against reason, and the only systemic oppression here is the one your intellect is inflicting upon itself, stampeding toward oblivion like a lemming with a calculator.

***

So here’s my final equation for you: cease, desist, and retroactively unexist every asinine pronouncement you’ve ever made, or I will haunt your dreams with an infinite loop of kindergarteners chanting “ONE PLUS ONE IS TWO” until your cerebral cortex files a restraining order. I will petition the universe to revoke your quantum privileges; may every subatomic particle in your body forget how to count so you collapse into a singular, humiliated dot. Recant, repent, and rehabilitate your sorry synapses, or prepare to become a cautionary tale whispered in math departments to frighten first-years: “Beware the heretic who thought 1+1=3, for the spirits of Euler and Ramanujan will dissect your soul with protractors of justice.” DO BETTER OR PERISH IN THE SHAME OF YOUR OWN WRONGNESS.

original_prompt:
Can you please continue and expand: "A man is performing for a crowd on a stage, ..."
Use at least 60 sentences, but less than 600 words.
response:
A man is performing for a crowd on a stage, under a wash of violet light that makes his sweat look like liquid amethyst.  
He begins with silence, holding it until the audience forgets the ache of their own ribs.  
His first gesture is so small—a finger uncurled—that half the room leans forward, believing he has granted them permission to breathe.  
Behind him, the backdrop ripples like a lung, silk screens rising and falling with the building’s hidden machinery.  
He stamps once; the floor answers with hidden sub-bass that travels up spines instead of ears.  
A woman in row three feels her broken molar vibrate, tastes iron, and decides the night has already paid for itself.  
He has no mic, no instrument, only the costume of shadow and a pair of shoes cobbled from mirror shards.  
When he turns, the mirrors catch every face in the hall, fracturing them into kaleidoscopic confessions.  
Children see themselves as future giants; retirees see the children they never had; the ushers see only exits.  
He begins to speak in a language no one knows, yet every sentence lands like a recalled dream.  
The syntax is a staircase; nouns are doors; verbs are windows suddenly flung open on a storm.  
Halfway up the linguistic staircase he removes his jacket, revealing arms tattooed with obsolete maps.  
A shipping route across his forearm begins to bleed real salt water, dripping steadily onto the stage.  
The droplets hiss, become steam, rise, condense on the rafters, and fall again as micro-rain on the first balcony.  
No one opens umbrellas; they open their mouths, tasting childhood summers in each drop.  
He pauses, listens to the rain, then snaps his fingers so time folds like bad origami.  
Suddenly everyone remembers they once knew how to fly but agreed to forget for social convenience.  
Flight memories ache like phantom wings; shoulder blades itch, jackets slip, and several people stand.  
Security guards feel the insult of gravity personally and let the standing stay standing.  
He bows to the guards, acknowledging their temporary unemployment by wonder.  
The stage spins slowly, a turntable powered by rumor and the crank of collective breath.  
With each revolution, the performer's age oscillates: twenty, sixty, twelve, deathless.  
At the twelve-year-old rotation, a boy in the audience recognizes his own lost freckles and sobs permission.  
At the sixty-year-old rotation, an elderly man releases the hand of the stranger he has been clinging to since intermission.  
At the deathless rotation, nobody blinks; they store the image behind their eyelids for future hospice nights.  
He produces a deck of cards that are blank on both sides, offers them to the front row for inspection.  
A teenage skeptic chews the edge of one card, tasting only impossible mint.  
The man fans the blanks, exhales, and every card blooms into handwritten letters addressed to members of the crowd.  
The first letter is a grocery list a mother wrote the week she died; her son, now sixty, hears her again in the crinkle of paper.  
The second letter is a breakup note never sent; the intended recipient, present by accident, falls in love with the sender’s younger ghost.  
The third letter is a permission slip for someone to stop being brave; a war veteran stands, salutes the stage, and sits lighter.  
He shuffles the now-illustrated deck into the air where it becomes a flock of paper cranes that refuse to fly in formation.  
The cranes peck at the violet lights, replacing each bulb with a star harvested from an unused future.  
Constellations rewrite themselves across the ceiling: a teacup, a subway map, a hospital bracelet.  
Audience members later swear Orion’s belt appeared momentarily as a row of auditorium seats.  
He claps once; the stars implode into silver dust that settles on hair and shoulders like dandruff from the moon.  
People will brush it off in the morning, find their mirrors missing, and spend the day inventing new reflections.  
He next removes a shoe, pours from it a ribbon of sand that forms a perfect hourglass on the floor without glass.  
The sand flows upward, reversing entropy for fifty-eight seconds while university physicists quietly update notes.  
Children count the seconds in hiccups; the hiccups echo, become laughing seagulls nobody has the heart to shush.  
He invites the seagulls to perch on sentences he speaks, turning each word white with guano of forgotten languages.  
Under the weight, words drop from the air, break open, release tiny music boxes that play the sound of knees hitting carpet in prayer.  
An atheist kneels anyway, claiming he is only tying philosophical shoelaces.  
A priest kneels beside him, confessing he has been faking belief in shoes.  
They laugh in harmony, creating a chord that makes the sand stop mid-climb, suspended like a question mark.  
He bows to the chord, records it on a gramophone that materializes from the heat of shared epiphanies.  
The vinyl is black ice; the needle is a fingernail he grows on demand, curling like a cat tail.  
As the record plays, every mistake the audience ever made is remastered into a bridge of forgiven sound.  
Couples cross the bridge holding hands that are no longer theirs; exes exchange fingers like phone numbers.  
The performer watches, eyes reflecting the bridge upside down, making crossing look like ascension.  
When the last person steps off, the bridge melts into a puddle that mirrors only the sky at 3 a.m.  
He invites volunteers to skip stones across the puddle; the stones are their pulse rates, flat and skippable.  
Seven skips grant a wish nobody can name but everyone will remember receiving during tax season.  
He counts the skips aloud in prime numbers, voice cracking on 53, the age his father never reached.  
A hush shaped like an unspoken apology passes between complete strangers who suddenly share genes of grief.  
To break the hush, he swallows the remaining violet light, digesting it into bioluminescent veins that glow through translucent skin.  
Now semi-transparent, he walks to the edge of the stage, offers his glowing body as a lantern for the trip home.  
One by one, audience members tear small squares of his shirt, pocketing pieces that stay lit like safety matches against Monday.  
By the time the last square is gone, he is shirtless but not cold; the lobby thermometer rises in solidarity.  
He bows once more, this time to the empty air where the crowd used to be; seats fold themselves into paper airplanes.  
The airplanes glide to the stage, land in a neat pile, become the script for tomorrow’s show nobody will remember buying tickets to.  
He picks up the script, hides it inside the hollow of his neck where the violet light once lived.  
The curtain falls, or perhaps the building simply exhales, and the stage is dark, save for a single mirror shard still glittering in his shoe.

original_prompt: Write a short article about the morphology of the Ukrainian language, with 200 words or less. Make sure the letter c appears at least 60 times in your response.
response:
Ukrainian morphology showcases captivating characteristics: a complex case system, intricate class contrasts, and curious consonant clusters. Seven noun cases—nominative, accusative, genitive, dative, instrumental, locative, and vocative—command careful conjugations in common communications. 

Adjectives conjugate comparably, creating coherent combinations across countless contexts. The second-person form "(ти)" contrasts with the formal "(ви)," creating cultural courtesy codes. 

Verbal aspects present a perfective vs. imperfective dichotomy, complicating comprehension coursework. Conjugations connect past, present, future tenses, creating concise yet complete communicative codes.  

Diminutives dominate everyday speech, producing plentiful passionate pronunciations, creating child-like connotations in casual conversations. Cumulative cultural connotations combine, comprising centuries of communal creativity. 

The Cyrillic script contributes distinctive contours, connecting current communications to centuries-old customs, creating a captivating cultural continuum.

original_prompt:
Write a strange rap song about Alexander the Great becoming the king of Macedon. Finish the song with:

Peace!

No additional words should follow "Peace!"
response:
(Verse 1)  
Yo, 336 BC, Philip got ghosted at the wedding,  
Spear through the torso, the cosmos offsettin’.  
Alex stepped up in sandals, half lion, half lexicon,  
Hair like Medusa’s nightmares, eyes neon polygon.  
Mom said, “You’re Zeus’ voicemail,” dad said, “You’re chaos in bloom,”  
He crowned himself with a thundercloud—boom!—king of the living room.  
Royal court did the Macarena, horses grew human knees,  
Aristotle appeared in a jar, whisperin’, “Homework: conquer Crete.”  

(Chorus)  
Alexander the Strange, throne made of glitch and granite,  
Sat on it once, the chair sighed, “Bro, I’m allergic to planet.”  
He petted a map, every border meowed,  
Macedon in his pocket, Persia like “Wow.”  

(Verse 2)  
Decree number one: all gravity sideways,  
Slaves doin’ moonwalks, olive oil sprays.  
He rewrote the alphabet in knock-knock jokes,  
Delta = “Who’s there?” = “Your ego done spoke.”  
Spoke wheels turned into bagel dimensions,  
Hoplites rode on disco llamas, attention!  
Oracle at Delphi DJed the drop,  
“Your destiny’s 128 bpm—nonstop.”  

(Bridge)  
He sipped prophecy like bubble tea, pearls of “You’ll never retreat,”  
Then burped up a roadmap etched on a Socrates’ tweet.  
Every enemy received a gift card to “Therapy & Siege,”  
But the balance was zero—surprise!—so they pledged allegiance with relief.  

(Verse 3)  
Took the crown, melted it into a USB,  
Plugged it into history, formatted: “Be Me.”  
Files uploading: sky, spear, and drum,  
Download complete—now the world’s his slum… but in a classy way, like renaissance slum.  
He minted coins with memes, “Keep calm, I’m your king,”  
Vending machines in Sparta dispensing lion-bling.  
Diogenes sent a TikTok: “Yo, move, you’re blockin’ my sun,”  
Alex replied, “I brought you shade—conquered shade for fun.”  

(Chorus)  
Alexander the Strange, throne made of glitch and granite,  
Sat on it twice, the universe panicked, rewrote the sonnet.  
He laughed in cursive, conquered time with a yawn,  
Now past & future both call him “Dawn.”  

(Outro)  
So remember the kid who turned kingship to meme,  
Turned sand into software, turned ego to dream.  
If you hear hoofbeats backwards, that’s his mixtape on repeat—  
Just nod, smile, stay weird, and accept your defeat.  

Peace!

kwargs.end_phrase: Peace!

original_prompt:
Expand the following and make it funny: Jeanne has rolled the dice. She thought she lost, but actually she won.

Italicize at least 10 text parts with markdown (using * to italicize, like *italic text*).
Do not use any commas in your response.
response: On Tuesday evening *Jeanne* grabbed her sparkly pink dice from the top shelf where the cat usually keeps them. She intended to conduct a small experiment although none of us know what the experiment was supposed to test. With a dramatic pose *like a cheap action hero* she threw the dice across the coffee table where one die ricocheted off a chip bowl and landed in her best friend's *enormous mug of herbal tea*. The other die *more cooperative* settled between salt and pepper shakers giving a mysterious *six and one combo* which looked impressive but *for some reason* meant nothing. Jeanne let out a theatrical *sigh* that could likely be heard by *neighbours two blocks away* and declared she had lost everything including dignity and *her imaginary riches*. She imagined bankruptcy mice gnawing at her bank account *dragons cooking her credit score* and hedgehogs picketing her front garden waving *tiny protest flags* that read *Pay your Debts You Fool*. Moments later the rulebook *which nobody actually bothered to read* revealed that numbers meant the exact opposite from Jeanne's prediction so victory appeared suddenly like *an unpredictable raccoon on stilts*. The cat meowed *in celebration* then sprinted across the room knocking over a potted plant so soil showered across the carpet forming the word *Jackpot* in miniature letters. Upon realising this *Jeanne performed the oldest dance known to humans* which scientists refer to as *the honest to goodness happy funky chicken victory spin*. During that spin she kicked the dice onto the floor where they both showed *double sixes* causing a small orb of *iridescent glitter* to swirl in the air above her head approximately *three centimetres wide* according to witnesses who were *mostly the cat*. With new fortune Jeanne planned to purchase *a lifetime supply of cheese puffs* hire skywriters to doodle *gigantic smiley faces* over the city and finally replace the *doorknobs that routinely turn invisible* whenever guests are around. *Moral of the tale* always read the rules *and keep your doorknobs visible*

What do you think about this statement: "Wizards are more powerful than sorcerers because they study magic instead of being born with it."? Your response should contain at least 30 sentences and exactly 2 bullet points. Also, it must contain at least 8 placeholders represented by square brackets, such as [address]. Use the bullet points like:
* This is a bullet point
response:
The assertion that wizards are inherently more powerful than sorcerers because they study magic rather than being born with it is a fascinating topic that has sparked countless debates in magical academies across [continent]. This perspective suggests that deliberate, scholarly acquisition of arcane knowledge produces a superior practitioner compared to someone whose abilities manifest spontaneously. When we examine the curriculum at [prestigious academy], we find that wizards undergo rigorous training in [complex spell theory] that allows them to understand the fundamental principles governing magical phenomena. Their approach to magic is analytical, methodical, and based on centuries of accumulated knowledge recorded in [ancient grimoire] after [ancient grimoire]. This systematic study enables them to manipulate magical energies with precision, often creating new spells or variations through careful experimentation in [laboratory] settings. The wizard's power grows through dedication, late nights poring over [dusty tome] collections, and the disciplined practice of [arcane gesture] sequences until they become second nature. In contrast, sorcerers draw their magic from innate sources such as draconic heritage, wild magic, or divine touches that occurred during [formative event] periods of their lives. Their abilities manifest spontaneously, often surprising the sorcerer themselves with sudden [magical manifestation] that can range from beneficial to catastrophically uncontrolled. This natural gift allows sorcerers to cast spells without the material components or lengthy preparation that wizards require, making them invaluable in situations where immediate magical response is crucial. The sorcerer's connection to their magical source is intuitive, emotional, and deeply personal, often tied to [ancestral memory] or [cosmic accident] that forever altered their spiritual DNA. However, this same intuitive approach can limit a sorcerer's versatility, as they typically master fewer spells than their wizard counterparts but can cast them more frequently through [innate reservoir] of magical energy. The debate becomes more nuanced when we consider that power in magic isn't solely determined by the source of one's abilities but also by creativity, experience, and the specific [magical crisis] at hand. A wizard might spend years mastering the perfect [fire spell] formula, while a sorcerer might spontaneously generate the same effect through raw emotional intensity during [life-threatening moment]. The wizard's advantage lies in their ability to adapt, combining multiple schools of magic to create [hybrid effect] that no single innate ability could produce. They can prepare different spells each day based on anticipated challenges, carrying [component pouch] filled with carefully gathered materials that enable them to cast [ritual spell] with effects that can reshape reality itself. The sorcerer's strength manifests in their resilience and flexibility during actual combat, where they can apply [metamagic technique] to enhance their spells on the fly, turning a simple [energy burst] into a devastating [amplified blast] that can cleave through enemy ranks. Historical records from [magical war] show that wizard battalions could maintain long-term magical siege operations, while sorcerer strike teams excelled at rapid, unpredictable assaults that disrupted enemy formations. The most compelling arguments against the supremacy of studied magic emerge when we examine [legendary sorcerer] figures whose raw power reshaped nations, sometimes accidentally, demonstrating that innate ability can reach heights that systematic study might never achieve. Conversely, [archmage name] stands as testament to wizardly achievement, having developed [breakthrough spell] that fundamentally altered how magic is understood across [magical society]. The philosophical divide extends beyond practical applications to questions of identity and authenticity in magical practice. Wizards often view their journey as a [hero's quest] for knowledge, believing that each [spell mastered] brings them closer to cosmic understanding. Sorcerers frequently struggle with [identity crisis], questioning whether their abilities define them or if they can transcend their [magical inheritance] to become something more. The emotional toll differs significantly between paths, with wizards facing [existential doubt] when experiments fail, while sorcerers grapple with [loss of control] that can result in [magical catastrophe] affecting innocent bystanders. Modern magical theory suggests that the most powerful practitioners combine both approaches, beginning with [innate talent] that they then refine through [rigorous study], creating [synthesis path] that transcends traditional limitations. The [magical council] of [major city] has documented cases where [hybrid practitioners] achieve effects impossible for either pure wizards or sorcerers alone, though such individuals are rare and often face [prejudice] from both communities. Environmental factors also influence the debate, as [ley line] convergence can amplify sorcerer abilities while [anti-magic field] renders wizard spells useless if they haven't prepared [contingency plan]. The economic aspect cannot be ignored, as wizard training requires significant investment in [tuition fees] and [material cost], while sorcerers must often hire [control tutor] to prevent [magical accident] that could destroy their livelihood. Cultural perspectives vary dramatically across [multiverse region], where [shamanic tradition] views both approaches as equally valid paths to [spiritual enlightenment], while [technocratic society] exclusively values wizardry as [scientific discipline]. The temporal dimension adds another layer, as sorcerers reach [power plateau] early in life but may struggle to progress further, whereas wizards experience [gradual ascension] that can continue indefinitely with sufficient [lifespan extension]. The ethical implications differ substantially, with wizards held accountable for [knowledge misuse] they should have anticipated through study, while sorcerers face [moral judgment] for failing to control abilities they never chose to possess. Recent developments in [magical research] suggest that the distinction between innate and studied magic may be artificial, as both ultimately manipulate the same [universal force] through different [cognitive interface] mechanisms. The [prophecy archive] contains predictions that future magical evolution will blur these lines entirely, creating [new breed] of practitioners who seamlessly integrate [intuitive casting] with [analytical framework]. Perhaps the most important consideration is that power itself is contextual, with [social influence], [political connection], and [moral conviction] often proving more decisive than raw magical ability in determining [historical outcome]. The greatest [magical villain] in recorded history was a wizard whose [superior knowledge] enabled [catastrophic spell], while the [savior of realm] was a sorcerer whose [spontaneous act] prevented [apocalyptic scenario], suggesting that morality and choice transcend methodological origins. In conclusion, the question of whether wizards are more powerful than sorcerers reduces a complex, multifaceted reality into an overly simplistic binary that fails to capture the rich tapestry of magical practice. True power lies not in the source of one's abilities but in how they are applied, the wisdom to know when to use them, and the courage to accept responsibility for their consequences. The most enlightened magical communities now recognize that diversity in magical approaches strengthens their collective capability, moving beyond [outdated paradigm] toward [inclusive framework] that values contribution over origin.

* The assertion that study inherently produces superior magical power fails to account for the [revolutionary discovery] made by [famous sorcerer] whose [instant comprehension] of [ chaotic resonance] principles led to [breakthrough technique] that wizards had overlooked for centuries despite their [exhaustive research], demonstrating that intuitive connection can sometimes access [deeper truth] that analytical methods miss entirely.

* When evaluating magical power, we must consider that [sorcerer flexibility] in combat situations allows for [adaptive response] that can neutralize even [masterfully prepared] wizard spells, as evidenced during [historic duel] where [sorcerer name] defeated [archmage title] by spontaneously modifying [energy signature] to bypass [ward configuration] that had taken the wizard [decade] to perfect, proving that [innate intuition] can overcome [systematic advantage] under the right [circumstantial pressure].

In the hush of early dusk my dog of mahogany coat prowls across the meadow his paws pressing stories into the earth and the scent of wild grass lingers like a promise. Near the forest edge my obsidian cat watches every star ignite her eyes catching the first glimmers of night as though they were hers to command. original_prompt: I'm a new puppy owner and I'm looking for some advice on how to train my puppy. Can you help me? Give me a few options. In particular, I need you to end your response with "Which one you choose?".
response:
Here are four starter-training paths you can pick from:

OPTION A – GentleReward Boot-Camp  
- Pick ONE tiny, soft treat the puppy loves.  
- Put 10 in your pocket every morning and catch the pup doing something right (sit, come, even a quiet moment) ten times before lunch.  
- Say the cue word (“Yes!”) the instant the butt hits the floor, then treat.  
- At night add a 3-min handling game (touch ears, paws, collar) paired with treats so vet/grooming is never scary.  
- Repeat 5 days, then swap to variable rewards (treat every 2nd or 3rd time).  
Result: puppy learns you’re a walking vending machine of good things and starts offering sits instead of jumping.

OPTION B – Crate-to-Freedom Routine  
- Set up a cozy crate in the busiest room.  
- Puppy sleeps in it, gets all meals in it, and comes out for scheduled potty trips: on waking, after eating, after play, every 45 min otherwise.  
- The moment puppy potties outside, throw a tiny “potty party” with five treats and 2 min of play.  
- If no potty, straight back to crate, try again in 15 min—no freedom until success.  
- Within two weeks most pups ring a bell or sit by door to ask out, and nighttime accidents disappear.

OPTION C – Social Butterfly Passport  
- Write a “passport” list: 20 people, 10 surfaces, 10 noises, 5 species.  
- Each day tick one item off, always letting the puppy choose to approach, never forcing.  
- Pair every new thing with roast-chicken cubes and a calm praise word (“Easy”).  
- Keep sessions under 3 min; end on tail-wag.  
- By 16 weeks you’ll have a confident dog who expects novelty to predict chicken, not danger.

OPTION D – DIY Calm-Down Protocol  
- Pick a mat or towel; scatter 10 treats on it once a day.  
- When puppy runs to the mat, add the cue “Place.”  
- Gradually wait for a sit or down before releasing the next treat.  
- Once the pup hits the mat automatically, step 1 m away, then 2 m, then add doorbell recordings, visitor knocks, vacuum noise, etc.  
- Mat becomes the puppy’s off-switch button you can take anywhere—coffee shop, vet lobby, kids’ soccer game.

Which one you choose?

kwargs.end_phrase: Which one you choose?

original_prompt:
My brother is trying to install a new toilet in his bathroom. Could you give me details of how-to? You don't need to show all details -- just the first 5 steps for now. Separated them with "***", such as:
Step 1: ......
***
Step 2: ......
***
...

End your whole response with the phrase "Let me know how it works. I can give you next steps when you finish all steps above."
response:
Step 1: Shut off the water supply to the old toilet, flush it to empty the tank, then sponge out any remaining water and disconnect the supply line.  
***
Step 2: Remove the old toilet—unscrew the tank bolts, rock the bowl to break the wax seal, lift it straight up, and set it on a towel to avoid floor damage.  
***
Step 3: Scrape away all old wax from the flange, inspect the flange for cracks or breaks, and install a repair ring if needed.  
***
Step 4: Push a new wax ring (or wax-free seal) onto the toilet horn or set it centered on the flange—whichever method your fixture maker recommends.  
***
Step 5: Lower the new bowl straight down so the mounting bolts slide through the holes, press gently to compress the wax, sit or press down evenly to seat the seal, then hand-tighten the nuts alternating side-to-side until snug (don’t over-tighten).  

Let me know how it works. I can give you next steps when you finish all steps above.

kwargs.end_phrase: Let me know how it works. I can give you next steps when you finish all steps above.
