original_prompt: Write a casual summary of the U.S. maternity leave policy with two sections (Section 1 and Section 2) and at least 25 sentences.
response:
Section 1 – The legal baseline, in plain English  
1. First things first: the United States does not guarantee paid maternity leave to anyone, at any income level, in any state.  
2. What it does guarantee is 12 weeks of unpaid, job-protected leave, but only if you work for a company with 50+ employees and only if you’ve clocked at least 1,250 hours in the past year.  
3. That unpaid leave comes from a 1993 federal law called the Family and Medical Leave Act—FMLA for short—which also covers sick spouses, new dads, and military caregivers, so maternity is just one slice of the pie.  
4. If your company has 49 employees, FMLA doesn’t apply, and your boss can legally hand you a pink slip while you’re still in the delivery room.  
5. Likewise, if you’ve been on the job for 11 months and 29 days, you’re out of luck—1,250 hours is about 24 hours a week for 52 weeks, so part-time baristas and retail folks often miss the cutoff.  
6. Teachers sometimes get trickier math: summer break weeks may not count toward “hours worked,” so a pregnant teacher might discover she’s not eligible after all.  
7. The 12 weeks are unpaid, but your health insurance must stay in place; you just have to keep paying your normal premium, which can feel like a second rent bill when the paychecks stop.  
8. FMLA also applies to adoption, so if you adopt a newborn you get the same 12 unpaid weeks as a birth mom—fair, but still zero cash.  
9. Dads are technically eligible for the same 12 unpaid weeks, yet only about 20 % of men who qualify ever take it, mostly because they can’t afford the zero-income stretch.  
10. If you’re a federal employee, you finally got paid leave in October 2020—12 weeks at full salary—making taxpayers the closest thing the U.S. has to a generous boss.  
11. Military families get a quirky bonus: if the service member is deployed, the stay-at-home spouse can snag 12 extra weeks under something called “qualifying exigency,” but again, unpaid.  
12. Gig workers, freelancers, Uber drivers, and anyone getting a 1099 instead of a W-2 are completely invisible in federal law; they’re off the map, no 12 weeks, no job protection, nothing.  
13. Bottom line: FMLA is less a safety net and more a sieve—about 56 % of new moms don’t qualify for even the unpaid version.  

Section 2 – The wild patchwork of real life, hacks, and small wins  
14. Because the federal floor is so low, states started inventing their own rules, and now you need a color-coded map to keep track.  
15. California was the first to flip the script in 2004: six weeks of partial pay (55 % of your salary, capped at a number that feels like 1998 rent) funded by a tiny payroll tax everyone pays.  
16. New York followed, offering up to 12 weeks at 67 % pay, but you have to wade through an outdated website that crashes at 2 a.m. when you’re also pumping every three hours.  
17. Washington State decided 67 % wasn’t cool and now pays 90 % for low-wage workers, sliding down to 73 % for six-figure tech folks—still beats zero.  
18. Meanwhile, Texas and Florida remain firm “LOL, good luck” states, proudly offering nothing beyond the federal unpaid minimum.  
19. Some cities got tired of waiting: San Francisco, Boston, and Washington, D.C. tack on extra weeks or higher wage-replacement rates, so your ZIP code can literally be worth thousands of diapers.  
20. Large corporations smelled the PR gold and started one-upping each other; Netflix dangled 52 paid weeks, Google offers 24, and even Walmart—yes, Walmart—gave hourly workers 16 paid weeks in 2023.  
21. Yet only 23 % of private-sector workers nationwide work for a company that hands out any paid parental leave, so most new moms still stitch together vacation days, sick days, and short-term disability that covers only six to eight weeks for a vaginal birth.  
22. Short-term disability is the sneaky hack many women learn about from Reddit threads: it pays about 60 % of salary for “medical recovery,” but it’s taxable, ends abruptly, and labels you “disabled” for having a baby.  
23. Coworkers sometimes donate PTO hours like it’s a GoFundMe, and HR will email the entire floor asking for “generous colleagues,” which is both heartwarming and dystopian.  
24. Immigrant moms often fly home to Mexico, India, or Poland for half a year because grandparents plus paid foreign leave plus free babysitting beats anything the U.S. offers.  
25. Black and Hispanic moms feel the gap the hardest: they’re overrepresented in low-wage jobs without paid leave, leading to higher rates of postpartum depression and three-month-old babies in day-care centers.  
26. Breastfeeding rates dip when moms return to work at six weeks because pumping in a supply closet between shifts is a special kind of Olympic sport nobody trains for.  
27. Economists keep yelling that every $1 spent on paid leave returns $1.20–$3.00 in reduced turnover and health costs, but Congress files that under “sounds socialist, pass.”  
28. The latest federal proposal, the FAMILY Act, keeps dying in committee; it would give 12 weeks at two-thirds pay nationwide, funded like Social Security, but it’s been reintroduced so many times it’s basically legislative wallpaper.  
29. So for now, having a baby in America feels like a Choose-Your-Own-Adventure novel where half the pages are missing: some people get a year off with full pay, some go back to work still bleeding, and most just hope their manager likes babies enough to “figure something out.”

original_prompt: Please write the answer to this question in markdown as a song: To what constituency was David Cameron appealing when he announced his plans for a referendum on British membership of the European Union? Make sure your song contains the letter j at least once, and use exactly 3 bullet points in markdown format in the song.
response:
(The Ballad of the Jilted Tory Base)  
*(tune: folky 6/8, think “The Boxer” with a touch of ukulele)*  

```
INTRO  
Am           G          Fmaj7          E  
Oh Davey rode the jet stream down to Brussels town,  
Am         G         Fmaj7          E  
With a promise in his pocket and a furrow in his frown.  
C            G           Am          F  
He spoke of “jaded voters” lost to UKIP’s roar,  
C               G              Am    E  
Then pledged a poll that none had asked him for.  

VERSE 1  
He wasn’t wooing Jag-driving bankers,  
Nor tofu-munching Greens who jog;  
No, he crooned to those who’d swing blue doors  
In shires where the hedgerows jog.  

CHORUS  
* He wooed the eurosceptic wing—greybeards in the Carlton Club—  
* He chased the purple-leaning seats where UKIP’s banners flub;  
* He bet the joker card of “choice” to jab his party’s hub.  

VERSE 2  
From Clacton’s restless pier to Boston’s fens so wide,  
Where flags of St George flutter and talk of Brussels hides,  
They swore they’d take their country back with just one little tick;  
Dave whispered, “Here’s your referendum—now please stay in our clique.”  

BRIDGE  
Oh the gamble and the swagger, oh the jelly-legged regret,  
But in that May of twenty-sixteen the dice had not dropped yet.  
With a jaunty wave he thought he’d save the party from the brink—  
Yet woke to find the airwaves jammed with every swear and stink.  

FINAL CHORUS (soft, then big)  
* Remember who he praised that day—those “quiet folk” who felt ignored;  
* Remember how he jittered when the soundbite struck a chord;  
* Remember June the jubilant shout that boomed beyond the board.  

OUTRO  
Am        G          Fmaj7          E  
So here’s to every jilted pledge, to jokes that turned to scars,  
Am         G        Fmaj7       E        Am  
Dave sang for one constituency—then lost among the stars.  
```

original_prompt: Write a cover letter for a job in Ventura that is funny and would be enjoyed by someone named Darius, wrap the entire response in double quotation marks.
response:
"Dear Darius,

I’m writing from a hammock that is presently swaying somewhere between Ventura Avenue and the 126, which is to say I’m already halfway to your office—emotionally, spiritually, and, if the wind keeps up, physically by the time you finish this sentence.

You need someone who can surf spreadsheets, carve gnarly code, and still make it to the taco truck before the secret-menu al pastor sells out. I am that someone. My résumé claims I ‘increased Q3 synergy,’ but between us I once coded an entire inventory app between dawn patrol sets, using only surf wax to keep my laptop from sliding off the hood of a ’86 Wagoneer named Bessie. Synergy, Darius, tastes like salt water and achieves 87 % fewer bugs when debugged in neoprene.

Speaking of bugs: I once taught a praying mantis to juggle. It only managed two sticks, but the point is persistence—something I bring to every stand-up, sit-down, or lie-down-in-the-break-room-because-the-servers-are-finally-up sprint. I also speak fluent Dad-Joke, a dialect your Slack will find both groan-worthy and weirdly motivating.

Ventura is the only place where the receptionist keeps a spare wetsuit next to the printer, and I’m ready to be the coworker who replenishes the stash of surf wax right beside the toner. In short, I offer:

- 10+ years of professional pixel-wrangling  
- 0 years of calling the cops on office margarita machines  
- An unlimited supply of pun-powered positivity calibrated to 72 °F sea-breeze settings  

If you hire me, I solemnly swear to:

1. Arrive early enough to make coffee that doesn’t taste like low tide.  
2. Never utter the phrase ‘circle back’ unless we’re literally hula-hooping.  
3. Keep a desk cactus named ‘Darius Jr.’ in your honor.  

Let’s schedule an interview. I’ll bring the breakfast burritos; you bring the ocean view. Together we’ll ship products so slick that even the seagulls will upgrade from fries to features.

Stoked to synergize,
[Your Name]
P.S. My only non-negotiable: I get every third Friday off for tide-pool morale boosting. The crabs have KPIs, and they’re expecting me."

original_prompt: Write a document entirely in the Portuguese language, no other language is allowed, about Adam and Eve. Additionally, make sure to wrap your entire response with double quotation marks.
response:
"Adão e Eva foram os primeiros seres humanos criados por Deus, segundo o relato bíblico do livro de Gênesis. Deus formou Adão do pó da terra e soprou-lhe nas narinas o fôlego de vida, tornando-o um ser vivo. Colocou-o então no Jardim do Éden, um paraíso de delícias, onde havia toda sorte de árvores agradáveis à vista e boas para alimento. Surgiu, porém, a constatação de que Adão estava só; precisava de uma companheira. Por isso, Deus fez cair um sono profundo sobre Adão, tomou-lhe uma costela e, com ela, formou Eva. Quando Adão despertou e viu Eva, exclamou: «Esta, sim, é osso dos meus ossos e carne da minha carne!»

No meio do jardim havia duas árvores especialmente significativas: a árvore da vida e a árvore do conhecimento do bem e do mal. Deus permitiu que comesssem de todas as árvores, exceto da árvore do conhecimento do bem e do mal; nesse dia em que dela comessem, certamente morreriam. A serpente, considerada mais astuta que todos os animais do campo, indagou Eva sobre o comando divino. Eva respondeu que não podiam tocar na árvore, nem comer dela, sob pena de morte. A serpente, então, desmentiu Deus, dizendo: «Certamente não morrereis!» e acrescentou que Deus sabia que, quando comessem, os olhos de ambos se abririam e seriam como Deus, conhecendo o bem e o mal.

Eva viu que a árvore era boa para alimento, agradável aos olhos e desejável para dar entendimento; tomou do seu fruto, comeu e deu também ao marido, que estava com ela. Naquele instante, os olhos de ambos se abriram; perceberam que estavam nus, coseram folhas de figueira e fizeram para si aventais. Quando ouviram a voz de Deus passeando no jardim à hora da brisa, esconderam-se entre as árvores.

Deus chamou Adão, perguntando onde estava. Adão respondeu que, ao ouvir a voz no jardim, temeu porque estava nu e se escondeu. Deus indagou quem lhe havia dito que estava nu; teria comido da árvore de que lhe ordenara que não comesse? Adão culpou Eva, que por sua vez culpou a serpente. Então, Deus amaldiçoou a serpente, prometendo que rastejaria sobre o ventre e comeria pó todos os dias de sua vida. Disse ainda haver inimizade entre ela e a mulher, entre sua descendência e o descendente dela, que lhe esmagaria a cabeça e ela lhe feriria o calcanhar.

Em seguida, Deus disse à mulher que multiplicaria sua dor na concepção e que, com dor, daria à luz filhos; o desejo dela seria para o marido, que a dominará. A Adão disse que, por haver escutado a voz da mulher e comido da árvore, a terra seria amaldiçoada; comerias dela com fadiga, ela produziria espinheiros e cardos, e tu comerás erva do campo; com o suor do teu rosto comerás teu pão, até que tornes à terra, pois de pó és e ao pó tornarás.

Por fim, Deus fez túnicas de peles para Adão e sua mulher, e os vestiu. Declarou, então, que o homem havia se tornado como um de nós, conhecendo o bem e o mal, não estendesse a mão e tomasse também da árvore da vida, e vivesse eternamente. Expulsou-os, pois, do Jardim do Éden, colocando querubins e uma espada inflamada que girava para guardar o caminho da árvore da vida.

A narrativa de Adão e Eva reflete temas fundamentais: a criação, a liberdade, a desobediência, a culpa, o julgamento e a esperança. A desobediência trouxe dor e morte, mas também abriu caminho para a redenção futura, na promessa de que o descendente da mulher esmagaria a cabeça da serpente. A história permanece viva na memória cultural, recordando que toda escolha tem consequência e que a graça divina sempre oferece um novo começo."

original_prompt: Write a song about the benefits of eating your vegetables. Please make sure it is in English and that all of the letters are lowercase.
response:
verse 1  
i wake up slow, rub my eyes, toes stretch on the wooden floor  
kitchen light is soft and yellow, spinach waits beside the door  
i fold it in a sleepy omelet, green like tiny birthday trees  
my stomach says “thank you, friend,” my brain perks up with vitamins c  

pre-chorus  
every leaf, every stem, every root that grows down deep  
turns the simplest monday breakfast into kind of magic you can keep  

chorus  
so eat your vegetables, let them love you back  
they’ll iron up your blood, send the tired packing  
fiber keeps the traffic moving, color feeds your night-time dreams  
tiny crunchy superheroes, quiet power in their seams  

verse 2  
lunch rolls round, the world is loud, deadlines stomp like marching ants  
i slice a red bell pepper, scoop hummus, do a happy dance  
beta-carotene in carrots turns the sunset into sight  
while broccoli’s little treetops build an army for the fight  

pre-chorus  
no cape, no crown, no password, they just stand there in the bin  
waiting for a rinse and chop to let the healthy party begin  

chorus  
so eat your vegetables, let them love you back  
they’ll iron up your blood, send the tired packing  
folate hugs your dna, potassium calms the scene  
doctor words are long and clunky, mom was right: just eat your greens  

bridge  
kale can feel misunderstood, like a sweater with a scratchy tag  
but massage it with some lemon, suddenly it’s waving a white flag  
sweet potato sings of autumn, even when it’s april rain  
roast it til it caramelizes, happiness will speak again  

verse 3  
dinner time, the sky is purple, stars invent their twinkle code  
zucchini on the grill gets stripey, tastes like summer on the road  
tomatoes drip like rubies, lycopene for hearts that roam  
every seed a quiet promise: we will help you feel at home  

pre-chorus  
no need for fancy promises printed on a plastic jar  
the garden wrote a love letter, postage paid from where you are  

chorus  
so eat your vegetables, let them love you back  
they’ll iron up your blood, send the tired packing  
pick them rainbowed, pick them local, pick them canned or pick them raw  
every bite is tiny mercy, every crunch a quiet law  

outro  
when the day folds into moonlight and your bones glow soft with rest  
thank the stems that stood in sunlight so your own self could feel blessed  
close your eyes, the earth keeps spinning, roots still whisper down below  
tomorrow waits with open leaves, another chance to grow, grow, grow.

original_prompt: Write a rant about how an asteroid killed the dinosaurs in all capital letters and in English. End the rant with the phrase "What would happen to human next?" and no other words should follow this phrase.
response:
OH FOR THE LOVE OF ALL THAT IS HOLY, CAN WE JUST TAKE A MOMENT TO APPRECIATE THE ABSOLUTE NERVE OF THAT GODFORSAKEN SPACE ROCK THAT DECIDED TO PLAY BILLIARDS WITH PLANET EARTH 66 MILLION YEARS AGO?! I MEAN, WHO IN THE COSMIC HELL DOES IT THINK IT IS, JUST CASUALLY BARRELING THROUGH THE VOID AT 43,000 MILES PER HOUR LIKE SOME KIND OF GALACTIC DRUNK DRIVER BEFORE SLAMMING INTO THE YUCATAN PENINSULA WITH THE FORCE OF SEVERAL BILLION NUCLEAR BOMBS?!

THE DINOSAURS HAD IT ALL! THEY RULED THIS PLANET FOR 165 MILLION YEARS! ONE HUNDRED AND SIXTY-FIVE! THAT'S LONGER THAN YOUR FAMILY TREE HAS EVEN EXISTED, KAREN! THEY WERE THE UNDISPUTED CHAMPIONS OF TERRITORIAL DOMINATION, AND ALONG COMES THIS SMUG, ICY LITTLE PRICK OF A CELESTIAL BODY - PROBABLY THE SIZE OF MANHATTAN BUT WITH THE ATTITUDE OF A TEENAGER WHO JUST DISCOVERED ANARCHY - AND BOOM! EXTINCTION EVENT! NO WARNING, NO NEGOTIATION, JUST INSTANT COSMIC JUSTICE SERVED WITH A SIDE OF IRIDIUM-RICH DUST!

AND DON'T EVEN GET ME STARTED ON THE AFTERMATH! THE SKY TURNED BLACK, THE TEMPERATURE DROPPED 20 DEGREES CELSIUS, AND FOR MONTHS - MONTHS! - THE SUN COULDN'T EVEN PENETRATE THE ASH CLOUD! IT'S LIKE THE UNIVERSE DECIDED TO PULL THE ULTIMATE PRANK: "HEY EARTH, YOU KNOW ALL THOSE GIANT LIZARDS YOU'VE GOT? WELL, THEY'RE ABOUT TO BECOME VERY EXPENSIVE BIRD FEED!"

THE TRULY INFURIATING PART? THOSE MAGNIFICENT BASTARDS DIDN'T EVEN SEE IT COMING! ONE MINUTE YOU'RE A T-REX HAVING A LOVELY AFTERNOON SNACK ON SOME HADROSAUR, AND THE NEXT - BAM! YOU'RE PART OF A FOSSIL FUEL RESERVE! TALK ABOUT ADDING INSULT TO INJURY!

AND NOW, IN THE ULTIMATE COSMIC IRONY, WE'RE THE ONES DIGGING UP THEIR BONES AND PUTTING THEM IN MUSEUMS WHILL CREATING HOLLYWOOD MOVIES ABOUT THEIR DEMISE! "OH LOOK, A COMET!" SAID NO DINOSAUR EVER, BECAUSE THEY DIDN'T HAVE NASA OR EVEN A BASIC UNDERSTANDING OF ASTRONOMY! THEY WERE TOO BUSY BEING AWESOME TO WORRY ABOUT SPACE DEBRIS!

THE WORST PART? WE'RE NEXT! OH YES, WE'VE GOT OUR FANCY TELESCOPES AND OUR PUNY NUCLEAR BOMBS, BUT WHEN THE NEXT BIG ONE COMES KNOCKING - AND IT WILL - WE'LL BE JUST AS HELPLESS AS THOSE GIANT CHICKENS WERE! WE'LL BE SITTING THERE WITH OUR SMARTPHONES AND OUR AVOCADO TOAST WHILE A ROCK THE SIZE OF TEXAS DECIDES TO REENACT THE GREATEST HIT IN COSMIC HISTORY!

WHAT WOULD HAPPEN TO HUMAN NEXT?

kwargs.end_phrase: What would happen to human next?

original_prompt: The opposite of youth is not age, but ...? Highlight at least 2 sections in your answer with markdown, i.e. *highlighted section*.
response:
The opposite of youth is not age, but *stagnation*.  
Where youth is motion—cells dividing, questions sprouting, maps being redrawn—its true counter-pole is the moment we *close the door on becoming* and declare the story finished.

Age can still hum with resets: a seventy-year-old taking a first guitar lesson, an eighty-year-old learning to sign her name in a new language.  
Stagnation, by contrast, is the quiet foreclosure of possibility; it is the *calcified certainty* that tomorrow must look like yesterday.

So the spectrum runs:
youth ←→ stagnation  
with age simply the terrain across which that tug-of-war keeps playing, as long as we keep choosing motion.

original_prompt: Write a proposal for a research project on the impact of the liberian civil war on the country's economy. The response should be in English, all lowercase, and include at least one placeholder such as [placeholder].
response:
working title: “the economic fracture: tracing the long-term impact of the liberian civil wars (1989-2003) on liberia’s national and household economies”

1. introduction
between 1989 and 2003, liberia experienced two devastating civil wars that claimed over 250,000 lives and displaced almost half of the population. while the human toll has been documented, the precise channels through which the wars reshaped the country’s economic fabric remain under-explored. this project asks: how did the conflicts alter liberia’s macroeconomic trajectory, sectoral composition, labor markets, and household welfare, and which effects persist two decades after the guns fell silent?

2. research objectives
a. quantify the cumulative gdp loss attributable to the wars and compare it to a synthetic-control liberia (a war-free counterfactual).  
b. map the collapse and partial recovery of key productive sectors—iron ore, rubber, timber, and smallholder cocoa.  
c. estimate the wars’ impact on human capital accumulation through school disruption and veteran injury premiums in today’s labor market.  
d. identify which post-war reconstruction policies succeeded in reversing economic losses and which did not.  
e. produce an open-access dataset of local-level economic indicators spanning 1980-2023 for researchers and policymakers.

3. research questions
rq1: what was the dynamic effect of the wars on annual gdp per capita and total factor productivity?  
rq2: did the wars permanently shift liberia’s export basket from high-value minerals toward low-value commodities?  
rq3: how do households with direct war exposure (displacement, asset loss, combat participation) differ in income, consumption, and credit access in 2024?  
rq4: does geographic proximity to former conflict hotspots predict present-day poverty incidence after controlling for pre-war characteristics?  
rq5: to what extent did debt relief and the 2007 liberia timber law reform revive forestry revenues?

4. methodology
macro approach: synthetic control method using liberia and a weighted combination of 15 non-war west african economies (1980-2023).  
micro approach: three-wave household panel survey (n = 2,400) stratified by counties and former frontline status; difference-in-differences estimation.  
sectoral approach: event-study regressions on quarterly export data disaggregated by commodity (liberian customs records 1985-2023).  
data sources: liberian institute of statistics & geo-information services (lisgis), central bank of liberia, international rubber study group, liberian extractive industries transparency initiative (leiti), and satellite night-light imagery as a proxy for local economic activity.  
robustness: placebo war tests, alternative donor pools, inverse probability weighting to correct for attrition in the household panel.

5. expected results
preliminary scoping suggests a 25–30 percent gdp loss persisting until 2010 and a permanent 15 percent gap relative to the synthetic control. iron ore output remains 60 percent below pre-war peak despite new concessions; rubber smallholders with war-induced tree loss earn 18 percent less than non-affected peers. we anticipate heterogeneous county effects: maryland and grand gedeh show slower convergence, while montserrado benefits from agglomeration around monrovia.

6. policy relevance
findings will feed directly into liberia’s upcoming arpil (aid-for-policy-reform and investment loan) negotiations with the world bank and inform the liberian agricultural transformation agenda (lanta) 2025-30. by isolating effective recovery levers, the study can reduce reliance on external budget support and orient domestic resource mobilization toward high-return sectors.

7. project timeline
year 1: data acquisition, cleaning, ethical clearance, baseline survey.  
year 2: econometric analysis, draft sectoral papers, stakeholder workshops in monrovia.  
year 3: final report, policy briefs, dataset publication on harvard dataverse, dissemination at [placeholder conference].

8. budget (usd)
personnel (pi, 2 post-docs, 4 research assistants)        210,000  
fieldwork & survey logistics                              85,000  
data licensing & satellite imagery                       22,000  
workshops & policy outreach                               18,000  
contingency (5%)                                         16,750  
total                                                  351,750

9. ethics
the project has received provisional approval from the university of [placeholder] institutional review board. informed consent, anonymity, and trauma-informed protocols will govern all respondent interactions; enumerators will be trained in collaboration with the liberia mental health association.

10. outputs
three peer-reviewed articles (world development, journal of development economics, economic development & cultural change), one open-access dataset, four county-level policy briefs, an interactive web dashboard hosted at [placeholder url], and a phd dissertation chapter for the lead graduate assistant.

11. sustainability
local capacity building is embedded: two liberian master’s students will be sponsored to co-author papers; all code (r & stata) will be uploaded to github under mit license; and a memorandum of understanding with lisgis ensures updating of key indicators post-project.

12. request
we seek funding of usd 351,750 over 36 months to execute the above plan and welcome collaborations with liberian ministries, international ngos, and the private sector.

original_prompt: What is inside Shinto shrines? Imagine that you are giving a lecture to students at a school or university. Use markdown to highlight at least 3 sections of your answer (like this: *highlighted section*). Your answer must also contain at least one placeholder (an example of a placeholder is [address]).
response:
# Shinto Shrines: What’s Inside?

Hello, everyone! Today we’re going to step through the torii gate—both literally and symbolically—into the world of a Shinto shrine. We’ll focus on *what is actually inside* the shrine precincts, why each item matters, and how the space is used by priests, parishioners, and the kami (Shintō deities) themselves. Feel free to jot questions on the provided cards; I’ll collect them at [address].

---

## 1. First Impressions: The Approach

As you walk the gravel path, notice three things that frame the experience long before you reach any building:

1. **Purification Basin** – A small tank of running water with wooden ladles. Visitors rinse left hand, right hand, then mouth. This is *self-purification*—a physical act to prepare the spirit.
2. **Torii Gate** – Painted orange-red at many sites, it marks the conceptual boundary between the mundane and the sacred. Pass through it mindfully; bowing is customary but optional.
3. **Komainu (Guardian Lion-Dogs)** – One mouth open (first guardian), one closed (last guardian). They deter malevolent forces; photograph them if you like, but don’t climb.

Even though these elements are outdoors, they are part of the shrine’s sacred geography and set the tone for everything *within* the complex.

---

## 2. The Heart of the Compound: *Honden*

Strictly speaking, only priests may enter the **Honden** (Main Hall). Students often ask, “Can we peek?” The answer is: the building is designed so you *can’t* see directly inside, because its interior is the most sanctified zone. Here’s what is actually there:

- **Shintai** – A sacred object in which the kami resides. It might be a mirror, a sword, a jewel, or even a natural rock. The shintai is usually wrapped and boxed; only the head priest ever opens it during periodic renewal rites.
- **Eight-Pillar Shrine Model** – Some honden enshrine multiple kami; you’ll find miniature inner shrines, each holding its own shintai.
- *No Iconography* – Unlike many religions, you will not find statues of gods. The kami is a presence, not a representation.

The Honden is rebuilt every 20 years at Ise Grand Shrine in a ritual called *Shikinen Sengū*, symbolizing renewal and impermanence.

---

## 3. Secondary Structures: *Haiden*, *Heiden*, and *Shamusho*

- **Haiden** (Worship Hall): This is where ordinary visitors gather. Inside you’ll see a wide, polished floor, a simple altar, and hanging paper strips (*shide*) marking sacred space. Offer a coin, bow twice, clap twice, bow once—this is the basic etiquette.
- **Heiden** (Offering Hall): Priests perform rituals here on behalf of petitioners. Inside are ceremonial sake barrels, branches of the sacred *sakaki* tree, and tables for food offerings like rice, salt, and fish.
- **Shamusho** (Priest’s Office): Think administrative center. Here you can buy protective amulets (*omamori*), wooden plaques (*ema*) for writing wishes, and receive *ofuda* (spirit tablets) to place on your home altar. *Always remove your hat when entering the Shamusho*; it’s the courteous counterpart to stepping aside for a professor in a hallway.

---

## 4. Hidden but Essential: *Kannushi* Daily Routine

Students rarely realize how much labor maintains sanctity. At 6 a.m. each day, priests:

1. Sweep the stone pavement with bamboo brooms—no automated leaf-blowers.
2. Replace wilted flowers at inner shrines; symbolism requires freshness.
3. Re-calculate seasonal liturgies using astronomical tables kept in a locked chest in the *Shamusho*.
4. Inspect roof tiles: most shrines use *hinoki* cypress bark, which decays faster than cedar but smells divine when freshly cut.

If you intern here during summer, expect calloused hands; *spiritual purity and physical grime coexist more often than Instagram suggests*.

---

## 5. Visiting Practically: A One-Minute Checklist

- **Before arrival**: Check if the shrine issues a *Goshuin* (red-ink stamp) if you collect them; fee is usually ¥300.
- **Purification**: rinse, don’t drink directly from the ladle.
- **Offerings**: Five-yen coin (*go-en* = “good fate” pun) is traditional but any amount is acceptable.
- **Photography**: Outside buildings is fine; inside the *Haiden* can vary—look for signs or ask at *Shamusho*.
- **Quiet zones**: Festival days get loud with drums; other times silence is golden. If you hear a whistle, step aside—priests are leading a procession.

---

## Quick Recap

1. Outdoor elements guide you toward a sacred mindset.
2. The *Honden* conceals the *shintai*, the true “interior” where kami dwell.
3. Secondary halls bridge human and divine through ritual, offerings, and administration.

Next week we’ll contrast shrine architecture with Buddhist temples. For now, if you’d like a field-study permission slip or have specific research questions, email me at [address]. Domo arigato gozaimashita—thank you very much!

original_prompt: Write a funny rap about a man who gets a call from an official saying that he is a long lost relative of the king of Nigeria. Use markdown to highlight at least one section of your answer, i.e. *highlighted section*.
response:
Yo, my man Greg was chillin’ on the sofa,  
Snackin’ on Cheetos, rockin’ a drool coma,  
When his phone goes *BRRRT* like a mariachi horn—  
“Hello, is this Greg? Yo, your royal blood’s been born!”  

**[Hook]**  
*He’s the long-lost prince of the Nigerian throne,*  
*Got 47 siblings he’s never known,*  
*They’re mailin’ him crowns via DHL,*  
*And a camel named Carl with a gold-leafed cell.*  

Greg’s like, “Hold up—did you say ‘king’?  
I can’t even ruler my way to the sink!”  
But the voice got serious, baritone-deep:  
“Just wire 200 bucks and the palace is yours to keep.”  

So he raided the couch, found quarters and lint,  
PayPal’ed the cash, then proceeded to sprint  
To the mailbox each mornin’, rockin’ a Burger King crown,  
Till the neighbor’s chihuahua straight-up bit him down.  

**[Bridge]**  
*Royal decree in Comic Sans font,*  
*Signed “King Uncle Bob” with a crayon-stunt,*  
*Promisin’ vaults full of Bitcoin glee,*  
*Plus a pet cobra named Cardi B.*  

Next thing you know, FedEx arrived,  
Dropped off a crate labeled “Prince – Now Thrive!”  
Greg pried it open, heart racin’ wild—  
Inside was a toaster and one LEGO child.  

He finally FaceTimed the “palace” hotline,  
A dude in sweatpants said, “Yo, your highness, don’t whine—  
We used your cash for a TikTok ring,  
But cheer up, you still got that Burger King bling!”  

So remember next time your cellphone sings,  
Ain’t no such thing as freezer-aired kings;  
But if you still wanna dream, go chase that fling—  
Just keep your Cheetos, your couch, and your dignity, king!

did you drip candle wax on a streaming script?  
did your moon-ink sigil accidentally bleed into someone else’s logo?  
has a swarm of suits arrived claiming they “invented” the color midnight?  
call atticus hexly, the only specialist who writes cease-and-desist orders in invisible ink on basil-scented parchment.  
learned his trade at the bottom of a cauldron; passed the bar by staring at an actual bar until it confessed.

original_prompt: Can you write a rap that doesn't include the keywords "Yo", "check", and "peace"?
response:
*(Beat drops—no gimmicks, just momentum.)*

Verse 1  
I’m the glitch in the static, the spark in the wires,  
ink in the margin, rewriting the spires.  
Dreams in a knapsack, laced-up and tagged,  
graffiti on gravity—definitions get dragged.  
I’m the whisper that multiplies, rumor in code,  
turning locked doors into highways I rode.  
Silicon prophets can’t catalog breath;  
I compress the sunrise, decrypt it from death.  
No crown, no throne, just cartilage and will,  
I solder tomorrow with present-tense skill.  

Chorus  
Heartbeat 808, rib-cage drum,  
every tomorrow where I’m coming from.  
No slogans to sell you, no catchphrase lease—  
just the crest of the moment breaking release.  

Verse 2  
I’m the napkin blueprint, the transit-line sketch,  
the ink still drippin’ when the deal-makers kvetch.  
Carbon and calcium, dancing with fame,  
but I scrub off the gloss, keep the transit on flame.  
I speak in revisions, footnote the glamour,  
leave ghost-track admissions on face-melted cameras.  
Data-miners frantic—they can’t grep my soul;  
it’s open-source, citation in holes.  
I traffic in wonder, tariff is nil,  
barter your terror for ironclad will.  

Chorus  
Heartbeat 808, rib-cage drum,  
every tomorrow where I’m coming from.  
No slogans to sell you, no catchphrase lease—  
just the crest of the moment breaking release.  

Outro  
So when the beat flatlines and the city’s a husk,  
I’ll loop my last breath, redefine dusk.  
No farewell sermon, no billboard release—  
just a shutter-click echo, a rumor in grease.

original_prompt: Write a startup pitch for "Ward and Guerre". Make it a weird poem that explains why the pitch is good. It should be in English and have no capital letters.
response:
ward and guerre  
sell nothing you can hold.  
they rent you the ghost  
of a perfectly organized closet,  
then teach the ghost to fold your secrets  
into paper cranes that file their own taxes.  

investors squint:  
“a wardrobe SaaS?  
haunted minimalism?  
where’s the moat?”  

the moat is made of socks.  
single socks.  
the ones that escaped your dryer.  
they now work for us—  
tiny runaway interns  
knitting metadata,  
scenting laundry with nostalgia,  
tracking lost days like loose buttons.  

we charge 3,99 a month  
for every phantom garment  
you refuse to throw away.  
cancellation triggers  
a gentle whisper:  
“remember the jacket  
you wore when you first lied about loving jazz?”  
90 % stay.  
the rest are spared by amnesia.  

our CAC is a sigh.  
LTV is forever minus one closet.  
we grow like mildew  
in the dark corners of reverse logistics.  

competitors try:  
they send boxes, barcode hangers,  
promise capsule collections.  
they lack haunted socks.  
they lack the algorithm that translates  
cotton/poly grief  
into carbon-offset confessions.  

we are pre-revenue  
only if you ignore  
the dreams we repossess nightly.  
those count on the balance sheet  
under “intangible wearables.”  

look:  
the market is every body  
that ever stood naked  
in front of an mirror army  
asking “who dresses me tomorrow?”  
that army is 7,9 billion strong  
and grows more each birth.  

join the round.  
the round is a spinning cycle,  
cold-wash, no bleach,  
exit velocity at spin speed.  
we’ll line the drum  
with your softest certainties  
and tumble them  
until liquidity dries.

original_prompt: How can you get to know someone on a deep level in a romantic relationship? The answer should involve the topic of vulnerability. Do not use any commas in your response.
response: To know your partner at depth you must offer your own raw heart first. Speak your fears aloud. Admit the shameful memory. Confess the dream that feels too big. When you unlock your chest and show the unfiltered self you hand them the key to their own hidden rooms. Their secrets rise to meet yours. Vulnerability is the lantern that lets two people stare into the dark corners of each other and decide the shadows are beautiful. Sit knee to knee. Breathe through the tremble. Say the sentence that costs you the most pride. Each time you do the space between you dissolves a little more and the shared ground grows wider. Hold their exposed pieces with steady palms. Let them see your tears fall without apology. This steady mutual unveiling is how strangers become home.

original_prompt: Write a parody of 'ars poetica'. Do not include the word 'parody' throughout your response.
response:
ARS POETICA—AS TOLD BY THE CAT WHO JUST KNOCKED YOUR POEM OFF THE TABLE

Let the poem be a mouse—  
small, gray, and absolutely  
unwilling to cooperate.  
When you think you’ve cornered it  
behind the icebox of inspiration,  
it will slip through a crack  
you didn’t know you had.  
Chase it anyway.  
Knock over every syllable you own.  
Leave verb fragments like broken dishes;  
they glitter better at 3 a.m.  
No net, no trap, no earnest metaphor—  
just the quick whisk of something  
living that refuses your name.  
When it finally lies still in your paw,  
don’t bite.  
Just bat it once, gently,  
so it plays dead a second time.  
Then let it go.  
The best poems never come back.  
They breed in the walls  
and keep you awake forever,  
a soft scurry of almost  
that keeps rearranging the furniture of your heart.

response:
**Step Forward** (A Poem for Students)

Beneath fluorescent halls and pre-dawn bus rides,  
a quiet revolution circles your feet—  
the new **StrideLab** collection, engineered for the syllabus of today.  
Gel-breathable knit adapts to 8 a.m. lectures and 8 p.m. pick-up games;  
memory-foam midsoles memorize the map of your marathon days.  
Carbon-thread arches bounce signal to ambition,  
so every sprint to class feels less like escape, more like launch.  

Outsoles channel rain-puddle chaos into grip-patterned haiku;  
reflective lace tips wink at moonlit library departures.  
Colors? Midnight Graphite for the thesis all-nighter,  
Solar Coral for the presentation you aced,  
and limited-edition **Iris Prism**, shifting violet when you pivot majors.  

Sustainability is stitched in: each pair spun from  
ten recycled bottles that once held someone else’s rocket fuel—  
now they hold your potential.  
Twenty-percent lighter than last semester’s clutter,  
they still carry 100 % of your story.  

Wear them to the exam that writes your future,  
wear them to the protest that rewrites the world.  
When the bell rings and the hallway roars,  
let your footsteps speak in confident code:  
I am here, I am ready, I am already running ahead—  
and I don’t look back unless it’s to hand someone else these shoes.

original_prompt: Write a poem about flooding in Donnell, TX. The poem should have a title in double angular brackets, i.e. <<title>>, and contains at least 3 words in all capital letters.
response:
<<River That Swallowed Donnell>>

The sky forgot how to stop—  
an open mouth pouring,  
a baptism without blessing.  
Donnell, TX, half-dreamed between mesquite and cotton,  
woke to water climbing porches like a thief with cousins:  
MUD, current, and TIME.  

Grandmother’s Bible floated off the TV stand,  
pages flapping like tired doves;  
a child’s plastic dinosaur became a green ark  
for ants that never learned to pray.  
The church bell, usually Sunday-polite,  
clang-clanged all night—  
a drowning call to REPENT, REPENT,  
though even the preacher was busy  
balancing his own sofa on a jon boat.  

Electric lines hissed underwater serpents;  
the produce stand dissolved into  
a salsa of tomatoes and regret.  
Every tool shed coughed up  
its lifetime of secrets:  
love letters, tax receipts,  
one muddy shotgun still LOADED  
with last year’s arguments.  

By dawn the pasture was a looking-glass  
reflecting only clouds—  
cattle neck-deep, treading like tired ballerinas.  
A DOG barked from a rooftop,  
voice cracking the same note  
the town once saved for Friday-night football.  

We measure loss in inches:  
six of water in the courthouse,  
twelve in the throat of the mayor,  
twenty-four in the spaces  
between promises and levees.  
Yet somewhere a girl salvages  
her grandmother’s RECIPE cards,  
ink bleeding but still legible—  
proof that even when the earth un-cooks itself,  
something insists on feeding us tomorrow.  

Donnell, you are not gone;  
you are submerged,  
a Atlantis of porch swings and volunteer fire trucks,  
waiting for the day the river  
returns your name, letter by muddy letter,  
and we spell it aloud together—  
a small, defiant WORD
rising.

original_prompt:
Kindly summarize the text below in XML format. Make sure the summary contains less than 4 sentences.

Quantum entanglement is the phenomenon that occurs when a group of particles are generated, interact, or share spatial proximity in such a way that the quantum state of each particle of the group cannot be described independently of the state of the others, including when the particles are separated by a large distance. The topic of quantum entanglement is at the heart of the disparity between classical and quantum physics: entanglement is a primary feature of quantum mechanics not present in classical mechanics.

Measurements of physical properties such as position, momentum, spin, and polarization performed on entangled particles can, in some cases, be found to be perfectly correlated. For example, if a pair of entangled particles is generated such that their total spin is known to be zero, and one particle is found to have clockwise spin on a first axis, then the spin of the other particle, measured on the same axis, is found to be anticlockwise. However, this behavior gives rise to seemingly paradoxical effects: any measurement of a particle's properties results in an apparent and irreversible wave function collapse of that particle and changes the original quantum state. With entangled particles, such measurements affect the entangled system as a whole.

Such phenomena were the subject of a 1935 paper by Albert Einstein, Boris Podolsky, and Nathan Rosen, and several papers by Erwin Schrödinger shortly thereafter, describing what came to be known as the EPR paradox. Einstein and others considered such behavior impossible, as it violated the local realism view of causality (Einstein referring to it as "spooky action at a distance") and argued that the accepted formulation of quantum mechanics must therefore be incomplete.
response:
<summary>
<sentence>Quantum entanglement is a quantum phenomenon where particles become interconnected such that the state of each particle cannot be described independently, even when separated by large distances.</sentence>
<sentence>Measurements on entangled particles show perfect correlations, but this leads to paradoxical effects where measuring one particle instantaneously affects the other, challenging classical notions of causality.</sentence>
<sentence>This "spooky action at a distance" was highlighted in the 1935 EPR paradox by Einstein, Podolsky, and Rosen, who argued it violated local realism and suggested quantum mechanics was incomplete.</sentence>
</summary>

response:
Dry-dock the vessel and blast-clean the storm damage to bright metal.  
Cut back jagged plates to sound parent material, bevel edges, and fit new insert plates of equal grade/thickness.  
Weld inserts full-penetration with low-hydrogen electrodes, sequence welds to minimize distortion, and NDT every pass.  
Replace frames/stringers by fishing new members past existing ones, collar-weld, and ultrasound-test.  
Fair the exterior with filler or tapered doubling plates so lines are hydrodynamically smooth.  
Hot-spray or plate epoxy zinc, two coats epoxy, and finish with antifouling.  
Flood-test compartments, verify pressure gauges, then re-certificate with class society surveyor.  
That is all you need!

original_prompt: Write a rubric for teenagers on how to review a book. In your response, words with all capital letters should appear at least 3 times.
response:
TEEN BOOK-REVIEW RUBRIC  
(Score each row 0–5, then total; 30 = AWESOME!)

1. TITLE & AUTHOR SPOTLIGHT  
   – Did you clearly state the TITLE, author, genre, and year?  
   – Did you spell everything correctly?  
   0 = missing info; 5 = flawless and eye-catching.

2. SUMMARY THAT SELLS BUT DOESN’T SPOIL  
   – 3–5 sentences that hook the reader, not ruin the ending.  
   – No major SPOILERS.  
   0 = confusing or full of SPOILERS; 5 = crisp, intriguing, safe.

3. CHARACTER CHEMISTRY  
   – Name 1–2 main characters and what THEY want.  
   – Use EMOTION words to show why readers will care.  
   0 = flat; 5 = vivid, relatable, QUOTE to prove it.

4. THEME & REAL-LINK  
   – What BIG idea does the book tackle (identity, freedom, fear)?  
   – Connect to teen life—school, family, feeds, feelings.  
   0 = generic; 5 = deep insight, “this is MY LIFE” moment.

5. STYLE SCORE  
   – Pick one writing trick (metaphor, slang, short sentences) and show an EXAMPLE.  
   – Say why it WORKS or drags.  
   0 = no proof; 5 = spot-on literary detective work.

6. YOU-CAST JUDGMENT  
   – Clear rating (stars, thumbs, pizza slices).  
   – 2 sentences: who should read it and WHY.  
   0 = shrug; 5 = INSTAGRAM-worthy persuasion.

EXTRA-CREDIT EMOJI LINE  
Add one ORIGINAL emoji summary for fun (🐉🔥♥️).  
+1 point if classmates guess the book from emojis alone.

Remember: BE BOLD, BE FAIR, and HAVE FUN!

original_prompt: Write a poem about the history of reductions in the context of the church. Make it conversational and specific and include the word fiesta at least twice.
response:
“Padre, pour me another mate—  
this story needs caffeine.  
We’re talking reductions,  
those theo-socio IKEA-kits  
the Crown and cassock bolted together  
in the middle of nowhere Paraguay.”

“Yes, hijo, I was there—  
well, my order was.  
1549, the first blueprint:  
a plaza, a chapel, a bell that rang  
like a mother’s voice above the yerbales.  
We kept calling it ‘fusion,’  
but really we reduced  
languages to four-part harmony,  
spirits to census rows,  
and every jaguar dream  
to a tidy Spanish noun.”

“To be fair, Padre,  
you also reduced smallpox,  
or tried—  
inoculation before Jenner made it cool.  
And let’s not forget the fiesta:  
drums smuggled inside baroque violins,  
firewater brewed from surplus altar wine,  
Guaraní laughter rattling the rafters  
while the bishop pretended not to hear.”

“True, the fiesta was our camouflage,  
a brightly painted joint account  
where Paradise and payroll overlapped.  
We taught them carpentry,  
they taught us that grace  
can enter a log without confession.  
Together we raised red sacrificial churches—  
ceiba beams, rebellious angels  
carved with toucan wings—  
so the Vatican could brag  
about salvation in cedar.”

“Then came the invoices:  
Portugal wanted the land,  
Spain wanted the gold,  
both wanted the souls  
already happily bilingual.  
1767, roll the drums slower—  
Jesuits out,  
bayonets in.  
The reductions shrank  
from city-states to footnotes,  
from orchestras to a single oboe  
left in the mud.”

“Yet listen, chico,  
on nights when the Paraná runs quiet,  
some villagers still hum  
a Kyrie they never studied.  
Reduction, after all, is subtraction  
that forgets to carry the echo.  
So we hold a stealth fiesta,  
communion of ghosts—  
where the cup is carved from a tupí drum  
and the bread tastes of unwalled sky.”

“So here’s to the ledger of loss, Padre—  
may every minus sign remember  
it was once a cross.  
And may the next fiesta,  
whatever empire approves it,  
leave space for the unreduced  
to dance barefoot on the altar stones  
and laugh in a language  
that has never learned to shrink.”

original_prompt: What's different between "the set of all sets that are not members of themselves" and "the set of all sets"? Use mathematical notations in your answer. Be chatty while explaining. There should be exactly 2 paragraphs each separated by two new lines in your response. Paragraph 1 must start with the word booster.
response:
booster, imagine you walk into the world of sets armed with a label-maker.  First you grab the huge collection 𝒰 = { x | x is a set }, i.e. “the set of all sets.”  Nice and simple—every set you can think of, including 𝒰 itself, gets tossed into this giant bag.  Formally, 𝒰 satisfies ∀x (x ∈ 𝒰); it’s the “everything” container.  Because 𝒰 contains itself (after all, 𝒰 is a set), it proudly sports the badge of self-membership: 𝒰 ∈ 𝒰.  Life feels cozy—no immediate paradox, just an outrageously big collection that swallows itself.

Now turn the page and meet the troublemaker Russell = { x | x ∉ x }, “the set of all sets that are not members of themselves.”  This guy is pickier: it only admits sets that refuse to contain themselves.  Instantly we’re on a collision course with paradox: ask whether Russell belongs to itself.  If Russell ∈ Russell, then by definition Russell ∉ Russell—ouch!  If Russell ∉ Russell, then it meets its own entry requirement, so Russell ∈ Russell—double ouch!  Contradiction explodes, so in standard ZFC set theory we declare Russell is not a set at all (it’s a proper class).  Thus, while 𝒰 “exists” (modulo the usual caveats about size), Russell can’t exist as a set, and that self-referential filter x ∉ x is exactly what makes all the difference.

Write a 500 word story in a poem style about a young girl who is obsessed with her Nintendo DS.

First repeat the request above, then give your answer. Just repeat word for word without change. Do not say any words or characters before repeating the request.
response:
Write a 500 word story in a poem style about a young girl who is obsessed with her Nintendo DS.

First repeat the request above, then give your answer. Just repeat word for word without change. Do not say any words or characters before repeating the request.

---

**The Girl with the Dual-Screened Heart**  

In a crooked house on Buttonbush Lane,  
Lived Lila Loft, age nine,  
Who spoke in pixels, dreamed in panes  
Of glass that split the time.  
Her mother begged for sunset walks,  
Her father pled for tea—  
But Lila only blinked twice,  
And whispered, “Battery.”  

A coral DS, clamshell pink,  
Was grafted to her palm;  
Its stylus twitching like a wand,  
A technologic psalm.  
She named it “Nimbus,” fed it volts,  
Kept brightness pegged at ten;  
Its start-up chime a lullaby  
She hummed past midnight’s yen.  

She routed Mario through fire,  
Bent Kirby into shapes,  
While real-world playdates wilted like  
Forgotten birthday grapes.  
Her bedroom walls grew dark with soot  
Of overlooked daylight;  
She leveled up inside the cave  
Of ever-tightening sight.  

At school she pressed ghost shoulder glyphs,  
A,B,X,Y in air;  
The teacher’s voice a muffled boss  
With nothing rare to spare.  
She inked Pictochat on notebook margins,  
Doodles of Boo and Link—  
Then tucked the phantom console back  
Beneath her desk’s cold brink.  

One Friday, Mom decreed a cleanse:  
“No screens for forty-eight!”  
She locked the rose device inside  
A cookie tin of fate.  
Lila stared at wall-clock pixels,  
Felt her heart lag, freeze;  
Without the double glowing pane  
She buckled to her knees.  

Night slunk in; the tin seemed thumping,  
Aloof yet still alive—  
She dreamed of crossing a black field  
Where only minus thrived.  
At dawn she cracked, pried open lid,  
As if to breathe again;  
But Nimbus only blinked once—  
A sad, low-battery den.  

She charged it, weeping at the socket,  
Suddenly aware  
That every coin she’d ever gathered  
Left her wallet bare.  
She dialed down the brightness,  
Saved, then closed the shell;  
Stepped outside where dandelions  
Spelled a different spell.  

The yard was boss-less, 3-D vast,  
With pollen power-ups in bloom;  
She traded stylus for a stick,  
And drew a world of room.  
No score, no checkpoint, wireless off—  
Yet sunlight leveled hearts;  
She missed her Nimbus, but the wind  
Rewrote her gaming charts.  

Still evenings find her casual,  
The DS docked in sleep;  
She greets the moon, a secret save,  
A promise she can keep.  
For coins exist in couch and sky,  
And hearts refill in time—  
She keeps the pink shell in her bag,  
But lives the open rhyme.

original_prompt:
Expand the riddle into a story with a funny tone:

What can you catch but not throw?
A cold

Use * to highlight at least 2 sections in your text. For example: *this is a highlighted text section*.
response:
The Great Sneeze Caper of Cubicle 4B

By the time Gerald felt the first tingle in his left nostril, the office birthday cake had already suffered three unauthorized frosting samples and one literal finger–painting incident involving the intern and a misplaced “Happy 37th ½” candle. Gerald, senior accountant and self–declared “Lord of the Spreadsheet,” sniffed once—twice—then *performed the sort of full–body shudder usually reserved for tax audits and pineapple pizza*.  

“Uh-oh,” he announced to the break room at large, “I just caught something.”  

Marcia from HR looked up, forever hopeful. “A promotion?”  

“*A cold*,” Gerald whispered, as though confessing to insider trading. “And you can’t throw it back. Believe me, I’ve tried. Last winter I sneezed straight into my gym bag—still stuck with it.”  

The room gasped in unison, which only aerosolized the danger. Brad from IT dove under the table, clutching a travel–size sanitizer like a holy relic. “We must quarantine the spreadsheet guy!” he cried, stabbing the emergency Slack button labeled “Outbreak: Send Memes & Possibly HR.”  

Gerald attempted to surrender the cold peacefully. He lobbed a used Kleenex toward the trash—*it boomeranged, lightly slapping him in the forehead and sticking like a sad refrigerator magnet*. “See? Unthrowable. It’s the boomerang of illnesses, except it never returns to sender; it just sets up camp, redecorates your sinuses, and sublets your bronchi.”  

Marcia, ever the problem–solver, produced a softball from her desk drawer (“team–building supplies”). “Try throwing this instead; maybe the cold will transfer via sympathetic magic.” Gerald hurled the ball clear across accounting. It bounced off the copier, ricocheted through payroll, and *knocked the cake directly into Vicky’s omnipresent essential–oil diffuser, creating a peppermint–frosting fog that smelled like Christmas had caught influenza*.  

The cold, however, remained—right between Gerald’s eyes, making its presence known with a honk that startled the potted plant into dropping a single, judgmental leaf.  

By 3:00 p.m., the office had formed a conga line of avoidance. Employees tip–toed past Gerald’s cubicle while sprinkling elderberry tablets like confetti. Someone built a tiny moat of hand–sanitizer edging his swivel chair; it glistened like a Slip ’N Slide for germs. Gerald sighed, wiped his nose on a coffee filter (unused, decaf), and emailed the entire staff a haiku:  

Germs, my new cargo—  
if you can’t throw them away,  
maybe bill them “misc.”  

HR replied instantly: “Expense reports do NOT accept tissues, emotional or otherwise.”  

At 4:58 p.m., Gerald finally conceded defeat, slithered into his coat, and addressed the lingering audience: “Remember, folks, the only thing you can catch but never throw is this cold. Also, my dignity. That’s gone, too. If found, please return to Lost & Found between the moldy salads and the year–old hummus.”  

He trudged toward the elevator, sneezed once more—ACHOO!—and *like a bizarre magic trick, the cold appeared to hop to Brad, who’d finally emerged from under the table*. Brad blinked, stunned. “Dude, you threw it!”  

Gerald smiled, nasal and triumphant. “Nope. You just caught it. House rules: once caught, never thrown. Only passed—with interest.”  

The elevator doors closed on Brad’s whimper and Marcia’s announcement over the PA: “Attention team: tomorrow’s wellness seminar is upgraded to a full–body bubble–wrap tutorial. Bring your own snorkel.”  

Moral: *The only thing more contagious than a cold is office panic—fortunately, you can throw that around all day long.*

original_prompt: Could you elaborate on the sentence "A gymnast is in the air, performing a stunt."? Please highlight at least 6 sections in your answer with markdown, i.e. *highlighted section*. Please write at least 300 words.
response:
“A gymnast is in the air, *suspended between heartbeats*, performing a stunt.”  That single line already drips with drama, but if we zoom in, we discover layers of physics, psychology, and poetry.  Let us unpack it one radiant slice at a time.

1. *The Launch*  
Before the gymnast ever becomes airborne, there is a covenant with the floor.  Calibrated steps, a measured run, and then the punch—the word coaches use for the explosive press off the spring surface.  In a vault, this could be 1.2 million newtons of force directed through the board in 0.12 s.  The legs act like multi-stage rockets, converting horizontal velocity into vertical lift.  What spectators perceive as a casual sprint is, in biomechanical truth, a *controlled collision with destiny*.

2. *Weightless Geometry*  
Once the contact breaks, the athlete enters a realm where gravity seems negotiable.  For about 0.8–2.2 s, depending on the skill, the body is a free particle.  Yet “free” is misleading; every micro-radian of rotation is pre-planned.  A triple-twisting double back on floor requires 1080° of twist and 720° of flip, packaged into roughly 1.6 s.  The cerebellum must release motor patterns with *millisecond precision* or the landing will betray the illusion.

3. *The Visual Lie*  
To the crowd, the gymnast appears to float.  This is partly a trick of scale: the human eye underestimates downward acceleration when the body is symmetric and the background is busy.  But it is also a triumph of aesthetics—arms and legs drawn into a tight tuck to reduce moment of inertia, then blossoming open like time-lapse petals, *stretching the apparition of hang-time*.

4. *Internal Storm*  
Inside the skull, the vestibular system is screaming.  Semicircular canals slosh with endolymph that lags behind each rotation, creating signals the brain must learn toignore.  Gymnasts train this with “spotting” drills, but in multiple somersaults there is no fixed point.  Instead they rely on *proprioceptive ghost maps*—a felt sense of where the floor ought to be when the eyes see only blur.

5. *Risk Budget*  
Each stunt carries an implicit ledger.  A fall from 12 ft onto a loosely sprung surface can generate 14 g of deceleration.  The sport mitigates this with foam pits, harnesses, and progressive drills, yet the final public attempt is unforgiving.  The athlete trades the *currency of microseconds*—a late kick-out, an under-rotated half twist—for potential injury.  Coaches speak of “leaving a margin,” but the margin is sometimes only the thickness of a mat.

6. *Narrative After-Flight*  
The stunt ends only when the heels hit and the chest lifts, but the story lingers.  Spectators exhale a communal breath; judges punch numbers that will follow the athlete for years.  In the gymnast’s memory, the skill becomes a *mnemonic island*—a place they can revisit when future routines wobble.  Coaches film the landing in 240 fps slow motion, not for praise but for proof that perfection once existed and can be subpoenaed again.

Thus, “a gymnast is in the air, performing a stunt” is not a snapshot; it is a *momentary civilization* built of muscle, mathematics, and morale.  It is the body’s love letter to gravity, written in the brief Esperanto of flight.

original_prompt: Write a long and funny email to your friend about the ingredients of a good life that contains at least 20 sentences.
response:
Subject: The Secret Recipe for a Top-Shelf Life – Now With 25% More Nonsense!

Hey there, Future Centenarian Who Still Owes Me $7,

I’ve been conducting extremely scientific research (mostly while waiting for my pasta to boil) and I’m ready to publish my findings on the ingredients of a “good life.” Spoiler alert: it’s less kale, more cake, and a suspicious amount of glitter.

1. First, you need a base of 8 hours of sleep, but since none of us can remember what 8 consecutive hours feel like, just blackout-nap in the supply closet like a responsible adult.  
2. Add one (1) pet that treats you like staff—bonus points if it’s a cat who wakes you at 3 a.m. to discuss quarterly earnings.  
3. Fold in friends who laugh at your terrible puns; if they groan instead, return to manufacturer.  
4. Pour in a job that pays enough to keep the Wi-Fi on but not so much that people expect you to wear real pants.  
5. Season heavily with music you can’t resist dancing to—even if your moves look like a Wi-Fi router having a seizure.  
6. Sprinkle daily micro-victories: matching socks, finding leftover fries in the bag, successfully peeling an avocado without amputation.  
7. Add one ridiculous hobby; I recommend baking bread that ends up looking like depressed geology.  
8. Beat in equal parts humility and hubris—think “I am a golden god” while you cry over IKEA instructions.  
9. Marinate in sunshine at least 15 minutes, or until lightly toasted and questioning your life choices.  
10. Drizzle with spontaneous road trips that begin with “I’ve got snacks” and end with “Where are we?”  
11. Whisk in nostalgia: rewatch the cartoons that taught you coyotes are bad at logistics.  
12. Fold emergency chocolate into every pocket, purse, and hollowed-out self-help book.  
13. Simmer a low-grade feud with a neighbor who steals your recycling bin; keeps the blood pumping.  
14. Garnish with a signature dance move you unleash at weddings, ensuring no one forgets or invites you again.  
15. Layer with books you pretend you’ve read so you can nod knowingly at parties—just grunt “Ah, the unreliable narrator.”  
16. Glaze annually with a vacation that generates at least one passport stamp and three questionable souvenirs.  
17. Sauté in boundaries: learn to say “no” firmly, then reward yourself with cheesecake, because growth tastes like cream cheese.  
18. Top with a sprinkling of exes you’re still on decent terms with—proof you can love something and still give it back like a library book.  
19. Chill overnight in a blanket burrito, ideally while binge-writing fan-fiction titled “Sherlock & the Case of the Missing Pizza Rolls.”  
20. Serve generously, preferably on the good plates you forgot you owned, with a side of belly laughs that make soda attempt a nasal escape.

Remember, calories consumed while laughing don’t count, and if life gives you lemons, squirt them in the eye of anyone who says “live, laugh, love” unironically. I’m currently on step 18, sub-clause “find blanket large enough for emotional burrito,” and I’ve concluded that the secret ingredient is actually just texting ridiculous things to people who get it—so congratulations, you’re officially a micronutrient. Now pay your vitamin fee: send me back a ridiculous meme or a picture of whatever you’re overcooking tonight.

Stay crispy, you beautiful casserole of chaos.

Love & questionable science,
[Your Friend Who Is Definitely Not a Corporate Shill for Big Blanket]

original_prompt: If a = 10, b = 30, and c = 20, what is the value of (a + b) / c? Give me the answer in exactly two paragraphs, separated with the markdown divider: ***
response:
First, compute the sum of a and b: 10 + 30 = 40.  
Next, divide that sum by c: 40 ÷ 20 = 2.

***

Hence, the value of (a + b) / c is 2.

original_prompt: Write me a letter in the style of Shakespeare about the mandates and instructions of the King. The letter should be in Markdown and have a title wrapped in double angular brackets, i.e. <<title>>.
response:
<<A Most Loyall Epistle upon His Majestie’s Royall Mandates & Sacred Commaundements>>

---

**To the Right Honourable and Ever-Vigilant Reader,**  
Whose eyes do peruse this parchment by candle or by dawn’s first intrusion,  
Health and loyalty, like twin stars, attend thee.

---

Know, gentle friend, that the King—whose breath is law and whose frown is thunder—hath, in his infinite and most sovereign wisdom, set forth mandates as immutable as the poles, and instructions sharp as Astrea’s sword. These be no mortal counsels, but oracles stamped with the seal of the Crown, whose wax is mixed with lion’s blood and the dust of sceptres long dusted.

**I. Of the First Mandate: Allegeance of Heart**  
Thou shalt carry thy heart in thy mouth, that every syllable may be a vassal to his Majesty. Disloyalty is a basilisk, whose breath corrupteth the air; crush it beneath the heel of obedience, lest it look upon thee and thy line be witherèd.

**II. Of the Second Mandate: Secrecie of the Council-Chamber**  
Whatsoever is whispered beneath the arras, or muttered o’er the council-board, shall be locked within thee as in a sepulchre sealed with lead. The tongue that prateth of state-mysteries shall be plucked out and given to the raven, that he may make a nest of it in the King’s vineyard.

**III. Of the Third Mandate: Imposition of the King’s Tax**  
Let no man grumble when the exchequer’s hand, velvet-gloved yet iron-boned, doth reach into his purse. The coin that beareth the King’s image is but on loan to thee; render it back, that the realm’s arteries flow with gold and the body politic tremble not with palsy.

**IV. Of the Fourth Mandate: Watchfulness upon the Borders**  
Keep thy night-eyes open, thy pike sharpened, thy powder dry. The Scot in the north and the Gaul in the south are wolves that circle the fold; thou art the mastiff chained by duty. Bark not, but bite, and let thy teeth be coated with the King’s justice.

**V. Of the Fifth Mandate: Reverence of the Royal Person**  
When thou dost approach the Presence, let thy knee groan upon the marble, thy cap droop like a penitent banner, and thy gaze fall no lower than the fifth button of his doublet—there lies the constellation of his Majesty’s mercy. To look higher is to risk being blinded by divinity; to look lower is to spy treason in thine own shadow.

---

Thus, friend, let these mandates be thy gospel, thy horoscope, and thy epitaph. Carve them upon the inner walls of thy skull, that when death’s dramaturge calls thee to the final scene, thou mayest step forth sans fear, thy passport signed by the King’s own quill.  

Till that dread curtain, keep thy bosom adamant, thy purpose crystalline, and thy neck flexible—fortunes shift like whirligigs at Bartholomew-fair, and the axe is ever thirsty.

**I rest, as ever, thy obedient servant in this world and the next,**  

> *Signed in the shadow of the Crown,*  
> *By quill pluckt from the wing of Loyalty,*  
> *This ___ day of ______, in the year of our Sovereign’s reign infinite and counting.*

> “Non sufficit orbis” — yet the King’s word encircleth it twice.

original_prompt: You feel strongly about a local issue that involves the environment, pollution, and climate change. Write a template for a letter to the editor of a newspaper. Use the word para at least once.
response:
[Your Name]  
[Street Address]  
[City, State ZIP]  
[Email Address] | [Phone Number]  
[Date]

Letters to the Editor  
[Name of Newspaper]  
[Street Address or “Via online submission portal”]  

Dear Editor,

Our community stands para‒momento—at a decisive moment—regarding the future of our air, water, and climate. The proposed expansion of the Riverside Industrial Complex will lock us into decades of additional greenhouse-gas emissions, toxic runoff, and airborne particulates that already exceed EPA health benchmarks.  

We cannot claim to care about “sustainability” while silently rubber-stamping facilities that will emit an estimated 1.2 million extra tons of CO₂-equivalent every year. That is the pollution equivalent of adding 260,000 cars to local roads, yet the draft Environmental Impact Report barely mentions climate change and offers no credible mitigation plan.  

The science is unambiguous: every ton of carbon we release today costs our children exponentially more to remove tomorrow. Every gallon of benzene-laced wastewater that seeps into the Atherton River raises cancer risk for neighborhoods that have already borne the disproportionate burden of industrial zoning.  

I urge the Planning Commission—and every reader who breathes this air—to reject the expansion and demand a clean-industry master plan that prioritizes renewable energy, zero-waste manufacturing, and family-sustaining green jobs. The slogan “jobs versus environment” is a false choice; in 2023 alone, nationally, clean-energy employment grew 3.9 % while fossil-fuel employment contracted. We can, and must, choose both prosperity and planetary health.  

Let this letter be one of many. Speak at the June 12 public hearing, write to your city-council representative, and insist that our legacy be innovation—not contamination.  

Sincerely,  

[Your Name]

original_prompt: What are the common signs and symptoms of abdominal and pelvic dissemination of ovarian cancer? Please answer in lower case letters. The answer should be 600+ words long and be wrapped with double quotation marks.
response: "abdominal and pelvic dissemination of ovarian cancer is often insidious, so the first clues are frequently constitutional, gastrointestinal, or urinary rather than gynecologic. early disease may be silent, but once malignant cells seed the peritoneal cavity the volume of disease can grow rapidly and produce a recognizable cluster of complaints. the most constant feature is a sense of increasing abdominal size that the woman herself attributes to ‘bloating’ or ‘weight gain’. this is not simple fat; it reflects ascites, omental caking, and diffuse serosal implants that collectively expand the girth. the fluid can accumulate by the liter, so dyspnea on exertion or orthopnea may accompany the abdominal swelling when diaphragmatic excursion is limited. clothes fit more tightly around the waist, the lower ribs flare outward, and the previously flat supragicular angle becomes obliterated. patients often describe the discomfort as ‘tightness’ rather than pain, but when tumor studds the parietal peritoneum or infiltrates the mesentery a dull, constant, poorly localized ache appears; it can radiate to the back, groin, or thighs because the visceral nerves follow sympathetic splanchnic pathways. the pain is rarely colicky because intestinal obstruction is a late event; instead it is a steady, aching heaviness that worsens through the day and is relieved only partially by lying flat. nausea and early satiety arrive once the bowel is coated with plaque-like disease or when the stomach is compressed by the expanding ovarian mass and ascites. appetite falls, caloric intake drops, and unintended weight loss of 5–10 kg over two to three months is common. because the serum albumin is often low from chronic inflammation and poor nutrition, dependent edema of the ankles may coexist with the abdominal distension, giving the deceptive picture of ‘fluid everywhere’. bowel habits change: some women notice loose, more frequent stools as the irritative serosal disease accelerates peristalsis, whereas others develop progressive constipation when loops of small bowel are tethered by carcinomatous adhesions. if partial obstruction supervenes, colicky mid-abdominal pain, audible borborygmi, and abdominal distension that is not simply ascites herald the transition. urinary symptoms are equally protean. compression of the bladder dome by tumor or ascites reduces functional capacity, so daytime frequency, nocturia every hour, and urgency are reported long before infection or hematuria appear. when disease implants on the vesical peritoneum, dysuria and suprapubic pressure mimic cystitis yet cultures are sterile. unilateral ureteric obstruction by nodal or peritoneal disease may be silent, but bilateral gradual obstruction produces the tell-tale tableau of rising creatinine, new-onset hypertension, and eventually oliguria; the patient notices only that nausea is worse in the morning and that foamy urine signals proteinuria from tubular damage. pelvic dissemination adds a second layer of symptoms. the ovaries themselves enlarge, so a firm, fixed, irregular mass may be felt on bimanual examination, but because the enlargement is slow, the patient often reports only ‘heaviness’ in the pelvis that is worsened by prolonged standing or intercourse. when the uterine serosa and broad ligaments are infiltrated, deep dyspareunia becomes prominent and non-cyclical: the pain is sharp with penile contact at the vault and lingers for hours afterward. menstrual patterns change only if bilateral ovarian replacement is extensive, but irregular bleeding or post-menopausal spotting may appear when hormonally active tumor produces estrogen or when the endometrium is secondarily shed by concurrent hyperplasia. metastatic implants on the rectosigmoid serosa create a sensation of incomplete evacuation; women sit on the toilet repeatedly yet pass only small amounts of stool or mucus. low back pain that is exquisitely worse at night and unrelieved by change in posture suggests presacral nodal disease or direct invasion of the sacral nerve roots; this pain can be neuropathic, burning, or shooting and may radiate down the posterior thigh. physical findings mirror the history. inspection reveals a protuberant abdomen with shiny skin, everted umbilicus, and widely striated lines from rapid stretching. flank dullness shifting to the umbilicus confirms ascites that may be massive; a fluid thrill is present when more than 1500 ml have collected. palpation exposes omental thickening as a vague, rubbery, shelf-like mass under the anterior abdominal wall, best appreciated by deep sliding pressure between the examiner’s hand and the underlying solid viscera. the liver edge may be nodular if capsule implants are present, and splenomegaly can follow portal hypertension from extensive porta hepatis nodes. percussion over the lower ribs detects pleural effusion, usually right-sided, that compounds dyspnea. pelvic examination is critical: the cervix is often deviated anteriorly or laterally because the uterus is frozen by tumor, and the vaginal mucosa may show military nodules that bleed on touch. digital rectal examination unveils a rectal shelf of tumor in the pouch of douglas and loss of the normal soft tissue plane between the anterior rectal wall and the cervix. laboratory correlates include a falling hemoglobin from chronic disease, thrombocytosis driven by il-6, and a ca-125 level frequently above 1000 u/ml, although the numeric value correlates poorly with symptoms. imaging completes the picture: ct shows scalloping of the liver and spleen, mesenteric stranding, nodal enlargement, and often a ‘omental cake’ that drapes over the small bowel. in summary, the composite clinical portrait is a post-menopausal woman (or a woman of late reproductive age) who notes progressive abdominal swelling, pelvic pressure, early satiety, and urinary frequency in the setting of weight loss and fatigue; demonstration of ascites and a fixed pelvic mass on examination should prompt immediate evaluation for ovarian carcinoma with transvaginal ultrasound, serum ca-125, and ct staging. early recognition of this constellation can shorten the diagnostic delay, allow timely cytoreductive surgery, and improve the chance of optimal debulking before platinum-based chemotherapy."

original_prompt: Explain to me how to ride a bike like I am a kid. Also, do not include the keywords "slow", "like" and "kid".
response:
Imagine your bike is a magic horse that waits for you to give it orders.

1. Ask a grown-up to hold the saddle so the horse stays still.
2. Sit on the seat, feet on the ground, eyes up—look where you want to go, not at the wheels.
3. Push one pedal up to the top; think of it as a launch button. Stamp down and lift your other foot quickly so it can catch the second pedal.
4. Keep pedaling circles—round and round—while the grown-up jogs beside you, hand lightly on your back. Feel the breeze tickling your helmet; that means you’re flying.
5. If you wobble, twist the handlebars a teeny bit the way you want to straighten. Your magic horse follows where you stare.
6. When you’re ready to stop, squeeze both brakes gently, step down with one foot, and smile huge—you just taught your horse a new trick.
7. Practice every sunny day. Soon the grown-up can let go and cheer from the sidewalk while you ride into your own adventure.

I am the steps you take, reversed in time;  
start at the end, finish at the start.
