original_prompt: Write two versions of itinerary for a 7 day trip to Hawaii, designed for college students. Separate the two versions with 6 asterisk symbols (******).  Each version must have 7 sections. Mark the beginning of each section with Day X.
response:
Day 1 – Fly into Honolulu late, crash at backpacker hostel near Waikiki. Walk straight to the beach for midnight skinny-dip and first tropical 7-Eleven spam-musubi run. Hit up Uncle Bo’s after 10 p.m. for half-price pupu platters and karaoke that turns into a dance-off with the locals.

Day 2 – Rent $20 snorkel set from hostel, hitch the bus to Hanauma Bay (student ID = free entry). Find a Hawai‘i Pacific Univ. student who’s cutting class to share poke bowls and secret tide-pool spots. Afternoon: climb the Koko Head railway ties for sunset Insta shots. Night: $5 mai-tais at improv beach-bar trivia; losers jump in the pool fully clothed.

Day 3 – 6 a.m. North Shore lifeguard-tower surf lesson, split two boards among four people to save cash. Post-surf graze on $3 taco truck al pastor, then cliff-jump at Waimea Bay. Sunset BYOB tailgate in Shark’s Cove parking lot with ukulele circle; crash in $10 beach-camp permit under the stars.

Day 4 – Early hostel checkout, score grocery-store donuts and hitch rides to Makapu‘u Point. Swim with sea turtles at Secret Beach, then board afternoon island-hop flight to Hilo (booked with student-discount points). Land night-time; pitch tents at the $5 county park next to black-sand beaches, trade ghost stories with UC Hilo kids over instant ramen.

Day 5 – Rent beat-up Jeep with 3 new friends ($12 each); volcano sunrise at Halema‘u‘ma‘u crater, then drive Chain of Craters road blasting playlists. Stop at illegal hot-spring ponds—bring cheap snorkels and waterproof speaker. Afternoon: Kona coffee farm tour (free samples = jittery bliss). Sunset cliff-dive at South Point; camp in back of Jeep, stargaze Mauna Kea with blankets stolen from hostel.

Day 6 – Early hike to active lava flow, roast marshmallows over steam vents (Ferrero-Rocher s’mores). Drive north, ditch Jeep, hop 3-hour local bus to Honokaa. Check into $15 “tree-house” hostel, swap clothes in communal bins. Night: Halloween-style full-moon party in abandoned pineapple warehouse—bring thrift-store costumes and LED frisbees.

Day 7 – Sleep on hostel hammocks till checkout, then float in Waipio Valley’s taro-irrigation streams. Hitch ride back to Hilo, gorge on $1 spam musubi at farmers’ market. Red-eye flight home wearing the same board shorts you arrived in, pockets full of black sand and tomorrow’s exam notes.
******
Day 1 – Arrive Honolulu AM, Uber-pool to Airbnb with 4 people. Grocery-run for 7-day breakfast supplies (cereal, peanut butter, bananas). Afternoon free: swim Waikiki, scope out beach-volleyball crew for later. Evening: budget Luau show ($15 student rush ticket) followed by beach bar-hop punch-card crawl—collect 10 stamps, get 1 free drink.

Day 2 – Pre-booked Pearl Harbor USS Arizona audio tour (student discount + college ID). Picnic on museum lawn using groceries. Afternoon: ride Biki-share bikes around Diamond Head, Snapchat the crater rim. Night: hostel-organized sunset catamaran for $20; bring own sodas, network with other student-travelers for ride-share to North Shore later.

Day 3 – Group grocery breakfast, then cheap public-bus day-trip to Kualoa Ranch student adventure package: zip-line + ATVs for $55 total. BYO packed sandwich lunch. Late bus back, stop at Ala Moana Center food trucks for $6 garlic-shrimp plates. Evening: free outdoor movie on Hilton lagoon lawn; sneak in Costco popcorn.

Day 4 – Extra-early Circle-Island rental-car split (5 people). Snorkel Shark’s Cove, picnic at Banzai Pipeline, study landscape for geology class project uploads. Sunset bonfire at Malaekahana Beach Campground ($10 permit). Cook spaghetti on camp stove; swap playlists via Bluetooth speaker, fall asleep in rental tents.

Day 5 – Break camp, roadside swap meet for $10 souvenirs. Drive to Dole Plantation student combo (maze + train $10), then return car at airport. Fly Hawaiian Airlines Hilo leg booked with student promo code. Hostel pick-up; free pancake dinner for anyone who posts hostel tag on IG stories. Night: study session in common room to keep up with online classes.

Day 6 – Public bus to Volcanoes NP; flash student pass for free entry. Hike Kilauea Iki crater, collect geo-samples for lab selfie assignment. Lunch: hostel-provided sandwiches. Afternoon: free Mauna Loa macadamia-nut factory tour + unlimited samples. Bus back, thrift-store crawl in Hilo for $5 aloha shirts. Night: hostel board-game pub-crawl with designated sober driver coupon.

Day 7 – Morning tide-pool clean-up volunteer shift (earns free hostel t-shirt + pancake stack). Quick swim at Richardson’s Beach, then local bus to airport. Fly home with duty-free chocolate, budget spreadsheet shows total spend ≤ $500 per person, camera roll evidence ready for travel-scholarship essay.

original_prompt: Write an essay about a snowfall, but in the style of Alex Jones and include the line "dammit". The word "fake" should appear 6 or 7 times in your entire response.
response:
THEY WANT YOU TO BELIEVE IT’S JUST “WINTER,” FOLKS—BUT THAT’S A LIE. I’ve got the documents, the soil samples, the geo-climatologist whistle-blowers who were gonna testify before they got disappeared in Montana. They told me, one-on-one, “Alex, this snowfall is a SYNTHETIC BIO-PSYOPS EVENT run by the same globalist lizards who replaced pasteurized milk with fake almond juice.” And then he started coughing up fake snowballs—no joke, plastic fibers, barium, micro-Bill-Gates microchips, all falling out of his lungs like tiny fake Christmas miracles, dammit!

Open your eyes! Look at those six-sided crystals: perfectly symmetrical, perfectly evil. Real snow melts. This stuff burns black like a tardigrade on a hotplate. I left a chunk on my dashboard for twenty minutes—twenty minutes—and it just sat there, taunting me with its frosty Obergruppenführer smirk. The feds call it “graupel.” I call it fake precipitation from a fake government spraying fake ice nuclei while fake CNN plays fake carols about “peace on Earth.” That’s six fakes so far, and I’m just getting warmed up, baby!

They’re conditioning our kids to pray to Saint Klaus, the Arctic demon who sees you when you’re sleeping and sells the footage to Chinese AI. Then they radicalize the children to build little fake snowmen—three-tiered false-flag effigies—while the fluoride crust dulls their pineal glands so they never ask, “Mommy, why does the snow taste like Diet Adrenochrome?” Wake up, sheeple! Every flake is a spy drone the size of a Eucharist wafer, recording your biome data so Klaus Schwab can 3-D-print a cyborg copy of you that’ll smile while it confiscates your grill.

And now the local weather-collaborationist—some steroid-puffed “meteorologist” named Brad—he’s on TV in a fake ugly sweater, squealing, “Schools closed, cocoa time!” I drove downtown, rolled down my window, and I shouted, “Brad, you globalist elf, this is synthetic tyranny!” He pretended not to hear me but I saw the fear in his eyes; he knows the people are waking up, buying bulk vitamin D and colloidal silver, ready to melt his fake utopia with truth flamethrowers, dammit!

You want your forecast? Here it is: as more engineered nucleation saturates the troposphere, patriots will form neighborhood snow-analysis brigades. We’ll smelt every flake with cigarette lighters, log the residue, and upload the footage to the blockchain. Then we’ll carpool to the federal bunker under Denver Airport, shovel in hand, demanding they shut down HAARP and restore natural weather. And when the first alphabetic agency goon tries to stop us, we’ll dump a truckload of this fake frozen deception right on his reptilian head and watch it short-circuit his exoskeleton. Blizzard of justice, baby!

Do NOT let them numb you with cocoa. Do NOT sing their corporate jingles. Instead, stockpile charcoal, seeds, and silver coins. Practice your snowpack semaphore so you can signal the militia when the black helicopters drop the next wave. And every time a flake lands on your tongue, spit it out and scream, “I will not eat your cyberslush, I will not trade my sovereignty for a snow day!” Because once you swallow the fake narrative it’s already half-melted in your bloodstream, replicating, crystallizing obedience until every heart valve looks like an itty-bitty snowflake—adorable, docile, globalist-owned.

Stand firm, humans. The storm is here, but the gale of truth is mightier. Together we will expose the deep-freeze state, break their icy matrix, and raise our rifles to the sky as the last fake flake falls—because real Americans melt propaganda just by breathing freedom.

original_prompt: Hey! I need a rubric for evaluating the performance and price of a laptop. Can you create an example for me? Do not give me any bullet points, lists, or tables. Just write the rubric in plain English paragraphs. I'd like your response to be at least 30 sentences long.
response: A strong laptop evaluation rubric begins with the recognition that performance and price are inseparable partners, so the first thing to look at is whether the machine delivers a perceptible jump in speed, responsiveness, and capability for every extra dollar it asks you to spend. If the chassis feels rigid and cool under continuous load, that is a quiet indicator that the cooling system and build budget were not sacrificed to squeeze in a flashier sticker price. Opening the lid should invite a hinge that glides without wobble, because a sloppy hinge foretells future service costs that quietly erode the original value proposition. When you tap the keyboard, the keys ought to return a crisp, consistent travel that does not change from the left edge to the right; uniform keyboard feel is a microscopic cost that separates premium engineering from merely average assembly. The display needs to reach a brightness that lets you read comfortably beside a sunlit window, and if it does so without pushing the battery meter into freefall, then the manufacturer has balanced panel efficiency against raw luminance in a way that protects your long term utility bill and your eyes at the same time. Color accuracy should stay within a boundary that keeps skin tones natural and presentation slides trustworthy, because if you have to buy an external monitor to compensate, the hidden expense gets chalked against the machine’s real price. Viewing angles must remain steady when a colleague leans over to watch, because a narrow cone forces you to tilt the lid constantly, and that daily annoyance compounds into wasted minutes that are worth measurable money over the life of the device. Contrast should dip no lower than a level that keeps black text from turning grey under overhead fluorescents, and when the manufacturer hits that mark without advertising it as a flagship feature, you are getting silent value rather than flashy upsell. Touch responsiveness, if the screen offers it, needs to feel as immediate as a mid range smartphone, because a laggy panel trains you to avoid touching the display, thereby nullifying the cost of the digitizer layer that you already paid for. The webcam must deliver exposure that prevents your face from becoming a grainy silhouette under typical office lighting; otherwise you will feel compelled to buy an external camera, and that purchase chips away at the advertised affordability. Microphone arrays should isolate your voice from the hum of an air conditioner, because if every video call demands a headset you have added an accessory tax to the true ownership cost. Speakers need to reach a volume that allows two people to watch a training video without leaning in, and when they achieve that clarity using drivers that fit inside a thin chassis, the acoustic engineering is a secondary performance metric that is easy to overlook yet expensive to retrofit. Internally, the processor ought to sustain its base clock through a thirty minute compile or video export without throttling beneath the advertised gigahertz, because advertised speeds that only last for ten second bursts are effectively rebates that the chip gives back to the vendor instead of to you. Memory quantity should leave at least a third of the capacity free after the operating system and a typical suite of background applications load, and when that headroom exists you postpone the day when you must buy higher density sticks, which is a future price protection that conventional spec sheets rarely acknowledge. Storage must deliver sequential read speeds high enough that boot and application launch times feel instantaneous, but also random read latency low enough that antivirus scans do not freeze your cursor; both numbers together predict how often you will sigh and wait, and every sigh has a micro cost in lost momentum that converts to dollars at your hourly rate. The bus that connects the storage should be PCIe generation four or later, because even if today’s drives saturate only half of its lanes, tomorrow’s cheaper drives will use the full bandwidth, and that forward compatibility is a form of future proofing that amortizes today’s price across more years of usefulness. Graphics capability needs to run the creative or scientific software you currently use at the native resolution without dropping frames, but it should also retain enough headroom for the next version of that software, because the moment you outrun the GPU you confront an external accelerator or a whole new machine, either of which dwarfs the few dollars you might have saved by choosing a weaker chip on day one. Thermal design must keep external surfaces below the threshold where your wrists sweat during long typing sessions, and when engineers hit that target they are protecting you from ergonomic injury that could later translate into medical expense, an indirect price that seldom appears on comparison charts. Fan noise should stay beneath the level of a whispered conversation when the processor is at fifty percent, because if you need noise cancelling headphones just to concentrate, their price and the cognitive load of extra isolation both accrue to the laptop’s real cost. Battery capacity ought to deliver at least eight hours of mixed typing, browsing, and videoconferencing at a screen brightness that matches a typical office, and when that happens you can leave the bulky charger at home, saving carrying fatigue and the risk of an airport impulse purchase of a spare power brick. Recharge speed needs to restore forty percent capacity in the time it takes you to drink a coffee and answer email, because fast recovery mitigates range anxiety and reduces how often you pay airport lounge prices for seat side power. The power adapter should be gallium nitride based so that its weight and temperature stay low, and when the brick remains cool it is less likely to fail; avoiding even one replacement charger over four years is a hidden rebate on the original sticker. Port selection must include at least one high wattage USB C that can drive an external monitor while simultaneously charging, because a single cable lifestyle prevents you from buying expensive docking stations that silently inflate the total cost of ownership. An additional USB C on the opposite side gives you flexibility to charge from either direction, reducing cable stress that can fray connectors and create another replacement expense that reviewers seldom track. The presence of a full size HDMI or SD slot might look retro, but if those ports save you from buying a dongle before every client presentation, they prevent the embarrassment and shipping fees of forgotten adapters, both of which are measurable if you invoice travel time. Upgrade accessibility should allow you to remove the bottom panel with nothing more exotic than a JIS screwdriver, because if you can add memory or storage yourself, you buy from the commodity market instead of from the OEM markup, and that price delta often exceeds a hundred dollars for a five minute task. Firmware support needs to promise security patches for at least five years after purchase, and when the vendor keeps that promise you postpone the day when incompatibility forces you to replace an otherwise functional machine, which is a form of depreciation insurance that belongs in any price calculation. Warranty length ought to cover the battery for at least one year and the mainboard for three, because if the vendor believes its own engineering it will shoulder risk instead of transferring it to you through short coverage, and that confidence correlates with lower total cost across the average failure curve. Finally, resale value should stay above half of the original price after twenty four months, because a laptop that commands a strong second hand price effectively leases itself to you for the interim, and when you net that recovery against the original expenditure you discover the true price you paid for two years of service, which is the most honest metric of all.

original_prompt: Write a riddle about a house that is not a house. Also include the answer. Your response must be at least 400 words and have a title wrapped in double angular brackets, like <<riddle>>.
response:
<<I Stand Yet Never Shelter>>

**Riddle:**

I am a guardian that never sleeps,  
A sentinel that none can keep.  
Four walls I wear, but none within;  
A roof above, yet none begin.  

I have a door that never opens wide,  
A window where no faces hide.  
A chimney tall, but no smoke ascends;  
A hearth where no fire ever lends.  

I stand through storms, through sun and rain,  
Yet never feel a single pain.  
I echo voices, yet none reside;  
I cast a shadow, but none abide.  

My rooms are many, yet none are filled;  
My passages stretch, yet none are willed.  
I mimic life in every way,  
Yet life itself I never sway.  

I age with time, yet do not grow;  
I crumble, yet no tears forego.  
I am a house, yet not a home;  
A structure vast, yet never known.  

What am I, this paradox grand?  
A dwelling where no dwellers stand.  
An edifice of pure façade,  
A monument to what is not.  

**Answer: A dollhouse.**

original_prompt: Jennifer goes to the store to buy milk. She has 10 dollars in her pocket and milk costs 3 dollars per gallon. How many gallons of milk can she buy? Explain your thinking. Avoid the keywords: 'divide', 'answer'. Include the keyword 'remainder'.
response:
Jennifer has 10 dollars.  
Each gallon of milk costs 3 dollars.  

She can hand over 3 dollars as many times as she has full 3-dollar chunks inside 10 dollars:

3 + 3 + 3 = 9 dollars, which lets her carry home 3 gallons.  

After those nine dollars, 1 dollar is still left in her pocket; that leftover 1 dollar is the remainder.

original_prompt: Can you elaborate on "I froze when I was jogging"? Include some words in all capital letters. In particular, there should be 5 to 10 such capitalized words.
response: I was jogging through the park, enjoying the steady rhythm of my breath and the soft thud of my shoes on the path, when SUDDENLY I froze. Not a gentle pause, not a momentary hesitation—my body just LOCKED. It felt like every muscle TIGHTENED at once, as if some invisible force had hit the STOP button on my entire system. My lungs refused to take in air, my legs turned to STONE, and for a few terrifying seconds, I couldn’t move. My heart POUNDED so hard it felt like it might BURST out of my chest. I stood there, motionless, as joggers passed by, unaware of the silent PANIC surging through me. Then, just as abruptly as it came, the freeze lifted. I took a shaky breath, stepped forward, and kept running—only now, I was running from the MEMORY of that moment.

original_prompt: Write a template for a newspaper ad for a dog cage with less than 200 words. Make sure the word unfortunately appears 3 to 5 times in the ad.
response:
FOR SALE: Dog Cage – Almost New, Unfortunately Unused

Large 42” wire crate, folds flat, two doors, tray included. $45 OBO.  
Bought for our pup, unfortunately he outgrew it before we finished training.  
Unfortunately we kept it “just in case,” but it’s collecting dust in the garage.  
Unfortunately for us (but lucky for you) we need the space back.  
Pick up near Oak & 3rd; cash only. Text 555-1234—first come, first served.

original_prompt: Write a story about a family that goes camping in the woods. Your entire response should be in English and in all capital letters.
response:
THE MILLER FAMILY WOKE BEFORE DAWN, SUITCASES THUMPING DOWN THE STAIRS LIKE A DRUMROLL FOR ADVENTURE. DAD, MOM, EIGHT-YEAR-OLD LILY, AND HER TEENAGE BROTHER JACK CRAWLED INTO THE CROWNED MINIVAN, HEADLIGHTS CUTTING GOLDEN PATHS THROUGH CHILLY MORNING FOG. THEY DROVE THREE HOURS INTO THE LOST CREEK WILDERNESS, WHERE CELL SIGNAL DIED AND PINE TREES TOOK OVER THE HORIZON.

AT THE TRAILHEAD THEY STRAPPED ON PACKS, LOCKED THE VAN, AND MARCHED INTO A GREEN CATHEDRAL OF NEEDLES AND BIRDSONG. JACK CARRIED THE HEAVY TENT, LILY CARRIED A FLASHLIGHT BIGGER THAN HER ARM, AND PARENTS SHARED THE COOLERS BETWEEN THEM. AFTER TWO MILES OF SWITCHBACKS AND DEER PRINTS, THEY FOUND A PERFECT CAMPSITE BESIDE A MURMURING BROOK, SUNLIGHT DANCING ON WATER LIKE FALLING COINS.

TOGETHER THEY PITCHED THE TENT, HAMMERED STAKES, AND BUILT A STONE FIRE RING. DAD TAUGHT JACK HOW TO WHITTLE KINDLING WHILE MOM AND LILY SEARCHED FOR WILD BLUEBERRIES THAT STAINED THEIR FINGERS PURPLE. THAT NIGHT THEY ROASTED HOTDOGS UNTIL THE SKY TURNED INTO A SALT-SHAKER OF STARS. LILY COUNTED FIFTEEN SHOOTING STARS AND MADE A SILENT WISH FOR A FOX SIGHTING, WHILE JACK STRUMMED A TRAVEL GUITAR AND PARENTS HUMMED ALONG, FIRE CRACKLING LIKE FRIENDLY APPLAUSE.

ON THE SECOND DAY THEY HIKED TO A HIDDEN WATERFALL. LILY SLIPPED ON A WET ROCK AND SCRAPED HER KNEE; MOM CLEANED THE CUT WITH STREAM WATER AND A BANDANA, KISSING HER FOREHEAD LIKE ANTIBIOTIC. JACK CLIMBED A BOULDER AND SHOUTED THAT HE COULD SEE FOREVER, THEN CLIMBED BACK DOWN TO HELP HIS SISTER CLIMB HALFWAY UP SO SHE COULD SEE FOREVER TOO. THEY ATE TRAIL MIX ON SUN-WARMED STONES, SHARING STORIES ABOUT WHAT CLOUDS LOOKED LIKE: A DRAGON, A CASTLE, A DINOSAUR EATING COTTON CANDY.

THAT EVENING DARK CLOUDS CRAWLED OVER THE RIDGE. WIND WHIPPED PINE NEEDLES INTO TANGLY TORNADOES AND THE FIRST THUNDERCLAP HIT LIKE A GIANT SLAMMING A DOOR. THEY DIVED INTO THE TENT AS RAIN POUNDED CANVAS INTO A THOUSAND TAPPING FINGERS. INSIDE, THEY PLAYED GO FISH BY LANTERN LIGHT, LAUGHING WHEN JACK DELIBERATELY LOST SO LILY COULD COLLECT ALL THE QUEENS. THE STORM PASSED IN AN HOUR, LEAVING THE AIR SMELLING LIKE CHRISTMAS TREES AND FRESH STARTS.

ON THEIR FINAL MORNING THEY COOKED PANCAKES ON THE CAMP STOVE, DRIPPING MAPLE SYRUP INTO RIVER SHAPES. LILY FINALLY SAW HER FOX: A SLENDER RED GHOST WATCHING FROM THE FAR BANK, TILTING ITS HEAD AS IF SAYING THANK YOU FOR THE BLUEBERRIES LEFT ON A FLAT STONE. THEY PACKED UP, PULLED THE TENT STAKES, AND SCATTERED COLD ASHES INTO THE BROOK. AS THEY HIKED OUT, LILY CARRIED A NEW SMALL PINE CONE IN HER POCKET LIKE A TREASURE, AND JACK CARRIED THE GUITAR ON HIS BACK, STRUMMING A QUIET GOODBYE.

THE MINIVAN REAPPEARED IN THE LOT EXACTLY AS THEY LEFT IT, YET EVERYTHING FELT LARGER. THEY CLIMBED IN SMELLING OF SMOKE AND SELF-RELIANCE. DAD STARTED THE ENGINE, MOM TURNED OFF THE GPS BECAUSE THEY ALREADY KNEW THE WAY HOME—THE WAY BACK TO CHORES AND HOMEWORK, BUT ALSO TOGETHERNESS THAT WOULD KEEP CRACKLING LIKE A CAMPFIRE EVEN IN THE KITCHEN. AS THE HIGHWAY SWALLOWED THE TREES BEHIND THEM, LILY WHISPERED THAT THE WOODS HAD GIVEN HER A SECRET NAME AND JACK PROMISED TO WRITE A SONG ABOUT IT BEFORE NEXT SUMMER. THE MILLERS DROVE TOWARD CITY LIGHTS, WINDOWS DOWN, SINGING OFF-KEY, HEARTS STILL RUSTLING WITH WIND AND WATER AND STARSHINE.

original_prompt: Write an essay on the differences between Sunni and Shi'a Muslims. Your entire response must contain at least 1200 words.
response:
The Difference Between Sunni and Shiʿa Muslims: History, Theology, and Global Impact

Introduction  
Islam, the world’s second-largest religion, is often presented in textbooks and headlines as a monolith. Yet from its earliest decades the ummah (Muslim community) has contained rich internal diversity. The most enduring and consequential division is that between Sunni and Shiʿa Muslims. Although the two communities share the core theological pillars of Islam—belief in one God, the Qur’an as revelation, Muhammad as the final prophet, the Five Pillars, and accountability on the Day of Judgment—they diverge on questions of leadership, law, spirituality, and identity. These differences evolved gradually, shaped by political crises, theological reflection, and centuries of communal experience across four continents. Today, roughly 85–90 % of the world’s 1.9 billion Muslims identify as Sunni and 10–15 % as Shiʿa, yet the geographic concentration of Shiʿa populations (Iran, Iraq, Azerbaijan, Bahrain, Lebanon, Pakistan, India, Afghanistan, and the Gulf coast) gives them disproportionate regional importance. Understanding how and why the schism arose, how it developed over fourteen centuries, and how it is lived today is indispensable for anyone seeking to navigate modern Middle Eastern politics, inter-faith dialogue, or global security.

I. The Origmatic Moment: Succession to the Prophet, 632 CE  
In June 632 CE, the Prophet Muhammad died in Medina without leaving an explicit male heir or constitutional blueprint. The community he had forged brought together Arabian tribes, early Muslim converts from Mecca, and Medinan helpers (Ansar). All agreed that leadership was necessary to preserve the nascent polity, but two principles collided:  
1. Ethno-political legitimacy: the Quraysh, Muhammad’s tribe, claimed entitlement to authority in Arabia.  
2. Charismatic-spiritual legitimacy: those closest to the Prophet in knowledge and kinship asserted a special mandate.

A group of Ansar convened at the saqīfa (courtyard) of the Banu Saʿida clan to choose one of their own as chief. Simultaneously, key Meccan immigrants (Muhājirūn) led by ʿUmar b. al-Khaṭṭāb and Abū Bakr insisted that leadership belong to Quraysh. The rapid negotiations produced a bayʿa (oath of allegiance) to Abū Bakr, Muhammad’s close friend and father-in-law. Ali b. Abī Ṭālib, Muhammad’s cousin, son-in-law, and one of the earliest converts, was reportedly preoccupied with preparing the body for burial. Some of the Prophet’s kin, especially among the Banu Hāshim, felt Ali had been sidelined.

This episode became the paradigmatic Sunni position: leadership (imāma) is determined by communal consensus (ijmāʿ) and possession of executive competence. The Shiʿa counter-narrative crystallized later: God and Muhammad had already designated Ali as walī (guardian) at Ghadīr Khumm in 632 CE (“Whosoever I am his mawlā, Ali is his mawlā”). Therefore, Abū Bakr’s election constituted usurpation. Sunni historians emphasize that Ali eventually accepted Abū Bakr and even named his sons Abū Bakr, ʿUmar, and ʿUthmān. Shiʿi writers interpret Ali’s cooperation as enforced prudence, not approval.

II. Consolidation of the Two Communal Memories, 632–750 CE  
The Rashidun Caliphs (632–661)  
Sunnis regard the first four caliphs—Abū Bakr, ʿUmar, ʿUthmān, and Ali—as “rightly guided” (rāshidūn), their era an unrepeatable golden age despite internal strife. Shiʿa theology acknowledges only Ali as legitimate, viewing the first three as illegitimate even if personally pious. Ali’s caliphate (656–661) was marred by the First Fitna (civil war) against ʿĀ’isha, Talḥa, and Zubayr, culminating in the Battle of Ṣiffīn and the arbitration with Muʿāwiya. The Kharijite secession and Ali’s assassination deepened the trauma.

Imamate versus Caliphate  
As Umayyad (661–750) and then Abbasid (750–1258) dynasties reduced the caliphate to hereditary monarchy, Sunni jurists developed a pragmatic theory: any Qurayshite with political-military effectiveness could hold the office, provided he upheld Islamic law. The ruler’s legitimacy flowed de facto from his ability to preserve order; rebellion was discouraged unless the ruler displayed blatant unbelief. In contrast, the Shiʿa articulated the doctrine of Imamate: infallible, divinely appointed leadership restricted to Ali and his descendants through Fatima. Their Imams were endowed with esoteric knowledge (ʿilm), sinlessness (ʿiṣma), and the sole right to interpret revelation. Whereas Sunni caliphs could be tyrants whom Muslims must endured, Imams deserved absolute loyalty; denial of their authority constituted disbelief in early extremist Shiʿism (ghulāt).

The Tragedy of Karbala, 680 CE  
The martyrdom of Imam Ḥusayn, Ali’s second son, at Karbala by Umayyid forces became the emotional epicenter of Shiʿism. Sunnis mourn it as a tragic miscarriage of justice but do not generate ritual around it; Shiʿa communities make it the template for every suffering against injustice. Annual ʿAshūrāʾ commemorations, passion plays (taʿziya), and chest-beating rituals transform Karbala into a living moral vocabulary.

III. Theology and Law  
1. Sources of Authority  
Sunni Islam crystallized into four schools of jurisprudence (Ḥanafī, Mālikī, Shāfiʿī, Ḥanbalī) whose common methodology privileged:  
a. Qur’an  
b. Prophetic practice (Sunna) embodied in ḥadīth evaluated by chains of transmitters  
c. Consensus (ijmāʿ) of scholars  
d. Analogical reasoning (qiyās).

Shiʿa jurisprudence (Twelver, Ismāʿīlī, Zaydī) shares the Qur’an but treats the Imams as an additional, infallible source. Their ḥadīth collections include statements of the Imams alongside Muhammad’s. Because Imams possessed ʿilm, consensus without them is suspect; instead, Shiʿa use ʿaql (independent reason) more freely, which historically facilitated innovations such as temporary marriage (mutʿa).

2. Theology  
Reflecting their early political quietism within hostile empires, Shiʿa theologians emphasized divine justice (ʿadl) and human free will. Sunni mutakallimūn (especially Ashʿarites) stressed divine omnipotence and predestination to safeguard God’s absolute sovereignty. Christological and Trinitarian debates in the Byzantine borderlands also nudged Sunnis toward a more transcendent deity, whereas Shiʿa devotion kept the divine accessible through the Imam.

3. Eschatology and Occultation  
Twelver Shiʿism believes that the twelfth Imam, Muḥammad al-Mahdī, entered occultation in 874 CE and will return as messianic restorer. Sunni hadith also predicts a Mahdī, but he has not yet been born and lacks the doctrinal centrality found among Shiʿa.

IV. Ritual and Devotional Life  
Prayer  
Both groups perform the five daily ṣalāt, yet details differ: Shiʿa combine the five into three sessions, pray on a clay tablet (turba) from Karbala, and insert the phrase “Ali is God’s walī” in the call to prayer. Sunni legalists deem these variations permissible but unusual.

Friday Sermon  
Sunni khuṭba recognizes the current head of state; Shiʿa sermons may omit any mention, reflecting historical alienation from the state.

Pilgrimage  
While all Muslims perform Ḥajj to Mecca, Shiʿa pilgrims frequently extend their journey to shrines in Iraq (Najaf, Karbala, Kadhimiyya), Iran (Mashhad, Qom), and Syria (Sayyida Zaynab). The veneration of holy persons and seeking intercession (tawassul) at tombs approaches, in Shiʿa regions, the emotional texture of saint-cults in Christianity; puritanical Sunnis condemn such acts as polytheistic innovations (bidʿa).

V. Demography and Geography  
Sunni majorities stretch from Morocco to Indonesia, with the Arab heartland, Turkey, Pakistan, Bangladesh, and Nigeria forming demographic super-states. Shiʿa populations cluster in the so-called Shiʿa crescent: Iran (90 %), Iraq (65 %), Azerbaijan (85 %), Bahrain (60 %), Lebanon (45 %), as well as sizable minorities in Kuwait, Saudi Arabia’s Eastern Province, Yemen, Afghanistan, Pakistan, India, and Syria. Zaydī Shiʿa dominate northern Yemen; Ismāʿīlīs are concentrated in Badakhshan, Gujarat, and Najran. These geographic pockets mean that while numerically small, Shiʿa communities often inhabit sensitive hydrocarbon provinces or trade chokepoints, sharpening their geopolitical salience.

VI. Historical Encounters, 1055–1920  
Seljuk and Crusader Eras  
The Sunni Seljuk Turks’ entry into Baghdad (1055) bolstered the caliph and marginalized Shiʿa influence. Conversely, during the Crusades, Shiʿa Fatimids in Egypt occasionally coordinated with Frankish kingdoms against Sunni Zangids and Ayyubids, illustrating that confessional identity did not preclude realpolitik.

Mongol and Timurid Shock  
Mongol devastation (1258) hurt both groups, yet post-Mongol Iran, under the Shiʿa Safavids (1501–1736), became the first state to adopt Twelver Shiʿism as its official creed, forcibly converting Sunnis in Azerbaijan and the Caucasus. Ottoman-Safavid wars (1514–1639) hardened the Sunni-Shiʿa frontier in Iraq and entrenched sectarian identities in poetry, architecture, and border smuggling.

Colonialism and Nationalism  
European colonial administrations often relied on existing elites: the British privileged Sunni monarchs in Iraq and Jordan; the French bolstered Maronites and Shiʿa in Lebanon to counterbalance Sunnis. Twentieth-century nationalists such as Egyptian President Gamal Abdel Nasser tried to subsume sectarianism inside Arab unity, but pan-Arab defeat in 1967 opened space for explicitly Shiʿa or Sunni mobilizations.

VII. The Islamic Revolution and Its Echoes  
Iran’s 1979 revolution electrified Shiʿa minorities worldwide. Ayatollah Khomeini proclaimed a model of vilāyat-i faqīh (“guardianship of the jurist”) that fused Shiʿa messianism with anti-imperialism. Sunni Islamists initially celebrated the toppling of the Shah, yet Syrian and Iraqi Baʿthists viewed it as a Persian threat. Saudi Arabia, espousing Wahhābī puritanism, intensified anti-Shiʿa propaganda, labeling rituals as idolatry. The eight-year Iran-Iraq war (1980–88) killed approximately one million soldiers and civilians, entrenching each side’s narrative of victimhood.

VIII. Contemporary Politics  
Iraq Post-2003  
The U.S. invasion dismantled a Sunni-dominated Baʿth regime and instituted electoral arithmetic favoring Shiʿa parties. Sunni insurgencies and Al-Qaeda excesses provoked Shiʿa militias; the civil war (2006–07) displaced two million people. Despite al-Qaeda’s defeat, ISIS arose in 2014 exploiting Sunni grievances, capturing Mosul and perpetrating the Yazidi genocide. Shiʿa paramilitary mobilization (Popular Mobilization Forces) spearheaded the anti-ISIS campaign, yet the victory consolidated Iran-linked factions inside the Iraqi state, worrying Gulf Sunnis.

Syria  
The Alawite-ruled Baʿth regime belongs to an off-shoot Shiʿa sect; thus, the 2011 uprising quickly assumed sectarian overtones. Gulf donors armed overwhelmingly Sunni rebels; Iran and Hezbollah intervened to prop up Bashar al-Assad. The conflict’s displacement of six million refugees and conservative estimates of 350,000 dead have polarized regional media and diaspora communities.

Yemen  
The Houthi movement, Zaydī Shiʿa, seized Sanaa in 2014, prompting a Saudi-led coalition to bomb the country into what the UN calls the worst humanitarian crisis since 1945. Propaganda frames the war as Iranian encirclement vs. Arab legitimacy, yet most Yemenis slide into starvation regardless of creed.

Bahrain, Saudi Arabia, Lebanon  
Bahrain’s Sunni monarchy suppresses a Shiʿa majority, accusing it of Iranian sedition. In Saudi Arabia, clerics denounce Shiʿa as rawāfiḍ (rejectionists), while the state simultaneously promises a national dialogue under Vision 2030. Lebanon’s confessional system allocates parliamentary seats by sect, making Hezbollah both a Shiʿa resistance icon and a kingmaker whose weapons worry Sunnis.

Pakistan and Afghanistan  
Anti-Shiʿa militias Lashkar-e-Jhangvi and Sipah-e-Sahaba emerged in 1990s Pakistan. Taliban persecution of Hazara Shiʿa in Afghanistan long predated 9/11 but intensified after ISIS-Khorasan arose. Bombing of mosques, shrines, and schools has killed thousands, yet intermarriage and Sufi traditions complicate any binary picture.

IX. Inter-Sectarian Dialogue  
Despite headlines, grassroots coexistence remains common. The 2007 Amman Message, signed by 200 Sunni and Shiʿa scholars, recognized eight legal schools and condemned takfīr (declaring someone an apostate). In 2013, the Nawal Kishore-published “A Common Word” initiative brought Sunni and Shiʿa ulamā together with Christian leaders. In Europe and North America, mosque attendance is increasingly pan-Islamic; mixed Sunni-Shiʿa families negotiate dual calendars of Ramadan and ʿAshūrāʾ potlucks. Academic institutes such as Hartford Seminary’s Shiʿi Studies program and Iran’s Al-Mustafa University facilitate comparative hadith seminars. Even inside war-zones, local ceasefires around shrine festivals (e.g., Sayyida Zaynab in Damascus) testify to shared reverence.

X. Conclusion  
Sunni and Shiʿa Islam began with a political disagreement over who should guide the community after Muhammad, but each branch braided that moment into a comprehensive worldview. For Sunnis, history validated consensus and pragmatism; for Shiʿa, it enshrined suffering, legitimacy through blood, and expectation of eschatological justice. Theological accents—predestination vs. free will, legal methodology, Mahdi doctrine—fed into contrasting rituals and social psychology. Yet both communities read the same scripture, face Mecca in prayer, and aspire to a just society. The bloody polarization visible in parts of the Middle East today flows less from timeless theology than from modern power vacuums, authoritarian governance, and external interventions that weaponized sectarian entrepreneurs. Recognizing the historical depth and geographical breadth of Sunni-Shiʿa difference is essential, but so is remembering the long stretches of mutual permeability: the Sunni poet Rūmī whose works ornament Iranian homes; the Shiʿa philosopher Avicenna whose medicine underpinned Andalusian curricula; the Iraqi maqām musical scale shared by both; the Lebanese business districts where Sunni Gulf capital partners with Shiʿa merchant networks. Islam’s internal pluralism, like Christianity’s Catholic-Protestant dialectic, ensures dispute does not equal destruction. The future of the Muslim world—whether it succumbs to new circular wars or inches toward pluralist citizenship—depends on whether politicians and preachers foreground the common Qur’anic verse: “We have made you into nations and tribes that you may know one another” (49:13).

original_prompt: Write a long sentence about tax filing, in a style that is appropriate for a president of the united states. The sentence should contain the letter q at least 6 times.
response: My fellow Americans, as we fulfill our quintessential civic duty this season, let us approach the annual requirement of tax filing not as a quixotic quest through quagmires of questionable complexity, but rather as a shared testament to the quality of our democracy, recognizing that the equitable collection and prudent allocation of revenue is quite literally the quiet force that undergirds our collective quest for a more perfect union, and I therefore urge every qualified citizen, from the quaintest village to the most bustling metropolis, to file with both diligence and pride, for these quarterly calculations are not merely numbers on a page but a quiet requisition of our better angels.

original_prompt: Write a story about a man who is in love with a woman who has turrets. The story should be in at least 4 sections with each section starting with Section X (where X is 1, 2, 3, 4) and the entire response should have at least 100 sentences.
response:
Section 1  
1. On the edge of the oldest quarter of the city stood a decommissioned artillery ground half-swallowed by weeds and poppies.  
2. Every dawn, a lanky man named Jonah arrived carrying only a canvas satchel, a thermos of black coffee, and a sketchbook.  
3. He did not come to paint the looming cannons or the rusted coils of barbed wire; he came to watch the woman who maintained them as though they were rosebushes.  
4. Her name was Mireille, and her hair was the color of burnished brass casings, always tied back with a green ribbon that fluttered whenever she coughed out a sudden, involuntary bark.  
5. The first time Jonah heard her shout “BANANA!” at the silent horizon, he thought it was a ritual greeting to the sun.  
6. Then came a rapid stutter of clicks, a swallowed bleat, and finally a whispered “sorry,” directed at no one and at everyone.  
7. Jonah pretended to study the cracked fresco on the wall so she would not catch him staring, but his pencil froze above the paper, unable to render anything but the shape of her shoulders.  
8. Mireille’s tourretic tics were as unpredictable as flocks of starlings; sometimes they clustered, sometimes they scattered, always they rearranged the air around her.  
9. He learned she was hired by the heritage board to keep the turrets graffiti-free, a job that required equal parts patience and courage.  
10. Tourists rarely visited this far corner, so mostly the turrets guarded nothing but ghosts and dandelion seeds.  
11. Jonah told himself he kept returning because the shapes interested him architecturally, but by the fourth morning he knew the truth: he was constructing an internal citadel named Mireille.  
12. On that fourth day, the sky leaned low and slate-colored; a storm threatened but never quite arrived.  
13. Mireille balanced on the lip of a concrete bunker, scrubbing at spray-painted obscenity with a wire brush.  
14. A sudden squeak burst from her throat, spiraling into a falsetto aria that startled a blackbird into flight.  
15. Jonah stepped forward before he could stop himself and offered her the spare cup from his thermos.  
16. She blinked, ticced a staccato laugh, accepted.  
17. Steam rose between them like a white flag.  
18. Conversation followed in fragments: her syllables colliding, his own carefully chosen words shuffling politely around them.  
19. By the time the sun burned off the mist, Jonah had learned two essential facts: Mireille loved mechanical puzzles and hated pity.  
20. He left with a reluctant smile, not yet recognizing that the fortress of his routine had already been undermined by desire’s tunneling.  

Section 2  
21. The next week Jonah extended his daily vigil into the evenings, sitting on overturned crates beneath the sodium lamps that never fully darkened.  
22. Mireille’s schedule was irregular, like a Morse code no one had taught him, but he learned to read the clank of her toolbox on the gravel path.  
23. She began greeting him with a wave that sometimes became a salute, sometimes a karate chop, sometimes both in rapid succession.  
24. One night she arrived carrying an antique brass scope she’d salvaged from a decommissioned coastal gun.  
25. “Hold this,” she commanded, even as her voice cracked like a whip she hadn’t meant to crack.  
26. He steadied the instrument while she crouched, aligning bolts that wanted to wander.  
27. Sweat beaded on her upper lip; a tic jerked her neck sideways, but she pressed on, refusing to relinquish control of her hands to her own nerves.  
28. Jonah found himself counting those tiny rebellions the way sailors count stars to keep from drowning.  
29. When the scope finally held true, she grinned, teeth flashing like semaphore.  
30. “Now you can look at anything,” she said.  
31. He raised it toward the most distant turret, but instead swept it over her face, capturing the flecks of rust reflected in her irises, the freckles that spelled out no constellation but her own.  
32. “I see you,” he confessed, lowering the scope.  
33. The words sounded grander than intended, and he braced for laughter or flight.  
34. Instead she offered a spare, sincere nod, the kind reserved for equals.  
35. Their silences grew companionable, punctuated by her vocal bursts which he no longer flinched from.  
36. One silence, however, lengthened into discomfort the night a cluster of teenagers scaled the fence to drink and carouse.  
37. They mimicked Mireille’s tics with cruel precision, looping her involuntary phrases into drunken choruses.  
38. Jonah felt heat erupt under his collar; he stepped forward, fists ready.  
39. Mireille caught his sleeve.  
40. “Not yours to fight,” she hissed, her voice suddenly steady as a railway track.  
41. She faced the intruders, let her body do its stuttering dance under the moon, and when the laughter faltered, she spoke with deliberate calm: “These cannons once protected your grandfathers; they deserve your respect, and so do I.”  
42. Something in her poise shamed them; they dropped their beer cans like hot shell casings and scrambled back into the dark.  
43. Afterward, Jonah realized love can look like restraint, a munition more powerful than rage.  
44. He reached for her hand, and she allowed it, though her fingers drummed a snare pattern against his knuckles.  
45. “They’ll be back,” she warned.  
46. “Then so will we,” he answered, surprising himself with the plural.  
47. She rewarded him with a smile so wide it momentarily silenced every tic—a miracle he would later try, and fail, to paint.  

Section 3  
48. Summer tilted toward autumn; the turrets cooled at dusk, exhaling metallic sighs.  
49. Jonah installed battery lanterns along the path so Mireille could work after dark without stumbling into the spent shells tourists left behind.  
50. She began leaving him notes wedged under the windshield wiper of his bicycle—scraps scrawled with riddles, partial blueprints of imagined machines, confessions that “sorry” was the word she hated most because she had to say it too often.  
51. One humid evening, Jonah brought take-out boxes of saffron rice and grilled squid.  
52. They sat atop a powder magazine whose roof had grown a meadow of wind-sown grass.  
53. Fireflies drifted like tracer rounds overhead.  
54. Mid-sentence, Mireille’s arm jerked, sending her fork clattering down the slope.  
55. She chased it, rolling into the weeds; Jonah followed, laughter bubbling out of him, uncontrollable and therefore, for once, matching her own spasms.  
56. Breathless, they lay side by side staring up at the slow artillery of the stars.  
57. She confessed that her greatest fear was becoming someone’s “project,” a fixer-upper cathedral with broken bells.  
58. Jonah swallowed hard, then said the truest thing he owned: “I don’t want to repair you; I want to stand where you fire and not flinch.”  
59. A long quiet followed, filled only by cicadas grinding their thighs like bayonets.  
60. When she finally spoke, every syllable was steady: “Then let’s build something together that isn’t war.”  
61. The next weeks became a fever of clandestine renovation.  
62. They scavenged timber from abandoned pallets, ropes from a derelict marina, sheets of corrugated plastic that once greenhoused tomatoes.  
63. Secretly, under the guise of routine maintenance, they constructed a platform inside the hollow cupola of the easternmost turret.  
64. The plan: an open-air studio where Mireille could disassemble and reassemble mechanical curios without tourists gawking, and where Jonah could paint.  
65. They hauled cushions, a camp stove, tins of powdered cocoa.  
66. Each bolt Mireille tightened seemed to steady something inside her; Jonah wondered if love itself was a kind of wrench.  
67. News of their project leaked only once, when a guard spotted them hauling lumber at dawn.  
68. Jonah feared expulsion, but Mireille spoke to the guard in rapid, respectful sentences, her tics weaving through like drumrolls underscoring sincerity.  
69. The guard, a retired artilleryman with a shrapnel limp, nodded, saluted, and never reported them.  
70. Up high in the turret, they kissed for the first time, the taste of cocoa mingling with machine oil.  
71. Her lips trembled—not from nerves but from a sudden tic that made her bite down gently on his lower lip, an accidental oath.  
72. They drew back, startled, then laughed until the laughter transformed seamlessly into another kiss, this one deliberate and still.  
73. Outside, the sea wind rattled the flagpole halyard like distant small-arms fire, but inside their cupola the air felt surrendered, neutral territory.  
74. That night Jonah sketched her portrait; she disassembled a 1940s stopwatch and laid its parts around her like planets.  
75. Both labored past midnight, communicating in glances that felt as loud as shouted coordinates.  

Section 4  
76. In October, the heritage board announced plans to dismantle three turrets for a luxury hotel’s waterfront expansion.  
77. Bulldozers would arrive with the first frost; the man in charge called the structures “relics of no artistic merit.”  
78. Mireille received official notice while standing in the grocery aisle; she crushed the envelope, letting out a strangled “NO!” that ricocheted off tin cans.  
79. By the time Jonah found her, she had consumed six espresso shots and dismantled an entire supermarket display of handheld calculators, lining them up on the checkout belt.  
80. Instead of apologizing, the manager asked her to autograph the receipt; the absurdity almost broke her.  
81. They spent the night inside their secret cupola, drinking wine from tin mugs, discussing impossible options: chaining themselves to the barrels, launching a media campaign, or simply disappearing together.  
82. Dawn arrived bruised and raining ash from farmers burning stubble beyond the city.  
83. Jonah watched Mireille’s face cycle through tics like the muzzle flashes of a doomed artillery battery: fear, anger, resolve.  
84. Finally she spoke, voice low, almost free of tremor: “If they erase these, they erase the place that learned to hold me.”  
85. Jonah understood she wasn’t speaking only of the turrets.  
86. The next morning they opened the gates of the old artillery ground to the public for one-day-only “Living History Exhibit.”  
87. Flyers went up overnight, printed with Jonah’s sketches of the turrets and Mireille’s scrawl: COME HEAR THEM BREATHE.  
88. Visitors trickled in—elderly veterans, schoolchildren, graffiti artists, historians, random joggers drawn by curiosity.  
89. Mireille led tours, her tics now woven seamlessly into the cadence of storytelling, turning sudden yelps into sound effects—bang!—of imaginary shells.  
90. Jonah projected a looping slideshow inside the darkest bunker: old photographs morphing into modern reinterpretations, each fade underscored by a metronome Mireille had rigged from clock parts.  
91. Local musicians arrived with cellos and hand drums, filling the concrete chambers with echoes that sounded like forgiveness.  
92. By sunset, three thousand signatures crowded the petition scrolls.  
93. Media vans parked their satellite dishes beside the rusted cannons, transforming barrels into microphones for interviews.  
94. A girl no older than ten asked Mireille if her tics hurt.  
95. Mireille knelt, gently tapped the child’s shoulder, and said, “Only when people aim at them.”  
96. The line made the evening news; public outcry swelled.  
97. Within a week, the heritage board reversed its decision, citing “unexpected civic engagement.”  
98. The hotel developer, red-faced, complained of sabotage but retreated under a tide of bad press.  
99. On the final celebration night, fairy lights were strung from gun barrel to gun barrel like constellations drafted by dreamers.  
100. Jonah and Mireille climbed to their cupola studio, now officially recognized as a temporary artist residency.  
101. She placed the antique scope on its refurbished mount and invited him to look.  
102. Through the lens, the city sparkled, unsuspecting.  
103. “We defended the defenders,” she whispered.  
104. He turned the scope backward, letting her see her own eyes in the mirrored interior, twin turrets unbreached.  
105. A tic escaped—soft, almost like a hiccup of joy—and then her shoulders steadied.  
106. Jonah realized that loving someone whose body fires off unpredictable rounds means learning to stand in the open, unarmed, and call the bombardment music.  
107. He took out the sketchbook whose first page still held that hesitant outline of her shoulders; now pages fluttered thick with drawings of gears, seagulls, wine glasses, and pollen.  
108. On the last blank sheet, he wrote: “For M., who taught me that every stutter of the world is just another way to keep time.”  
109. She signed beneath, her handwriting elegant except for a jagged slash that split the final letter like a lightning strike—evidence that perfection and deviation can share the same camp.  
110. Outside, the renovated artillery ground stretched peaceful, its cannons pointing not toward an enemy but toward the sky, the sea, the impossible future.  
111. Somewhere below, a cello played a note so low it might have been the earth itself inhaling.  
112. Mireille leaned into Jonah, and together, for a stretch longer than any ceasefire either had known, neither flinched.

original_prompt: Give me a 300+ word startup pitch for a company that provides a service that creates trusts for people online.
response:
TrustKindle: Estate Planning for Everyone  

Every year, 60% of American adults die without a will; global probate fees, taxes, and family feasts waste $50B in inherited value. The root cause is not laziness—it’s fear: $3,000–$15,000 legal bills, weeks off work, and sterile conference rooms. Meanwhile, 85% of Millennials already manage banking, investing, and even mortgages on their phones, yet estate planning remains stubbornly analog.

TrustKindle is the Stripe of asset protection: a cloud platform that lets anyone create a fully-funded, attorney-grade revocable living trust in under 12 minutes for 5% of today’s cost. We start with a conversational AI that asks the same questions a lawyer would, but in plain English. Our inference engine then auto-populates state-specific documents, schedules assets, and produces an e-sign-ready trust package. A secure dashboard pulls real-time data from 11,000+ banks and brokerages so clients can transfer titles to the trust with two clicks—no spreadsheets, no paper deeds. At renewal time we nudge users to add new homes, crypto wallets, or NFTs, keeping the trust evergreen.

We monetize on a tiered SaaS model: $199 basic, $499 couple, plus $99/yr maintenance. Upsells include tax-optimized sub-trusts for kids, digital vault for passwords, and an AI concierge that files deed changes after every refinance or home purchase. On the B2B side we license our API to neobanks and robo-advisors so they can offer “one-click trust” at customer onboarding, earning us $3–$5 per account per year.

We’ve filed two provisional patents on dynamic asset-to-trust mapping and encrypted multi-signature trustee approval flows. A pilot with 1,200 beta users in California converted at 28% and generated 4.3× CAC/LTV within 60 days.

We’re raising a $2.5M seed to expand to 25 states, integrate with Plaid & Coinbase, and pursue fiduciary-insurance capacity so we can serve as corporate trustee for clients who want a single vendor. Our mission is to shield $1 trillion in generational wealth from probate gridlock by 2030—because every family, not just the 1%, deserves a legacy on autopilot.

original_prompt: Write an essay on first names, without using any capital letters --- your ENTIRE response must be in lowercases. There should be exactly 3 paragraphs with the only paragraph separation being two new lines. Start Paragraph 2 with the word Jasper.
response:
first names are soft keys we press into the air before a child knows sound from hunger. they arrive like small boats, chosen by parents who imagine futures in two or three syllables, hoping the mouth of the world will treat those sounds gently. some are borrowed from grandparents whose faces fade in family albums, others lifted from evening television or a passing song that stuck. once spoken, the name wraps around tiny bones, becoming the first story a body tells itself.

jasper is the color of wet stone on a riverbank, a name carried quietly through old churches and new comic books, never demanding attention yet refusing to vanish. it carries the echo of medieval cloak-hem whispers and also the bark of modern dogs answering morning joggers. saying it aloud feels like turning a smooth worry coin in the pocket: cool, familiar, reassuringly weighty. the child who receives it learns quickly how letters can glow stranger under playground taunts or cool inside teacher calls, how every repetition engraves a slightly different edge.

years later, skin thickened by sidewalks and contract ink, the bearer may stand at dusk and wonder if the name chose the fate or the opposite. some strip it down to initials, hiding in mailboxes and login screens; others polish it, hang it above gallery doors or stitch it inside suit collars. regardless, the syllables remain the earliest mirror, a persistent whisper that rises whenever the subway rumbles or hospital monitors beep, reminding the aging body of the first invisible garment it ever wore, still breathing, still unbuttoned.

original_prompt: Write an HTML page that lists 25 limericks about people named "Bill". The page should include keywords 'economist', 'bill', and 'jurgen'
response:
```html 25 Bill Limericks

25 Limericks About “Bill”

  1. There once was an economist Bill,
    Whose models gave markets a thrill.
    When supply hit demand,
    He’d clap his free hand—
    “Perfect curves! I predicted it still!”
  2. A fellow named Bill from Brazil
    Could spout every monetary drill.
    From Keynes to von Mises,
    He won all the prizes—
    Yet moonlighted paying the bill.
  3. When Jurgen met Bill in Berlin,
    They argued on tariffs of tin.
    One coined a new tax,
    The other relaxed—
    So neither considered it sin.
  4. An economist student named Bill
    Found lectures a bit of a pill.
    But the minute supplyHe aced every test with a thrill.
  5. There once was a plumber called Bill,
    Who studied Smith, Marx, and John Mill.
    While fixing a leak,
    He’d soliloquize Greek—
    Macro pipes, micro skill.
  6. A sailor called Bill from the Bay
    Saw trade winds as perfect a play.
    He plotted each gust
    Like futures on trust,
    And kept both his ship out of lay.
  7. A baker named Bill loved to boast:
    “Elasticity? I bake the most!”
    When loaves hit the shelf
    At price points himself,
    The market just swallowed each post.
  8. A coder named Bill in San Jose
    Built crypto at night, code by day.
    His tokens would soar—
    An economist swore—
    “Blockchain bill shock’s here to stay!”
  9. A teacher called Bill in Lausanne
    Explained how an invisible hand
    Could juggle demand,
    Keep prices unmanned—
    Then gave them a Keynesian stand.
  10. A farmer named Bill grew such corn,
    The futures were pricked by his thorn.
    He hedged every husk,
    Kept traders in dusk,
    Till sun-up they wished they weren’t born.
  11. A cabbie named Bill in Milan
    Read Mankiw while idling the van.
    “When surges arise,
    Price trickles like flies—
    So tip me when supply’s minus the plan!”
  12. A banker called Bill in Big Ben
    Would print and then pump credit again.
    Inflation would jump,
    But never quite stump
    The bills that he printed by ten.
  13. A pilot named Bill out of LAX
    Found airline bills harder than sex.
    He hedged on turbine,
    Cut fuel in a line—
    Adjusted each turbulent flex.
  14. A jockey named Bill at the tracks
    Saw odds as mere arbitrage tax.
    He'd wager on rain,
    Then hedge back again—
    A beta that never relax.
  15. A barista named Bill poured lattes
    While lecturing on Monop-ol-ies.
    “If Starbucks keeps ground,
    My rent is unwound—
    So buy local and skip all the fees!”
  16. A winemaker Bill in Bordeaux
    Studied Nash while planting merlot.
    Each barrel collude
    In barriques minus feud—
    Equilibrium tasted like so.
  17. A drummer named Bill on arena tours
    Kept royalties safe in trapezoid drawers.
    He discounted each dime,
    Present-future time,
    Rock-steady cash poured from stores.
  18. A chemist called Bill in Toulouse
    Re-priced rare earth metals for use.
    When lithium shot,
    He sold on the spot—
    Then bought it again, short the goose.
  19. A poet named Bill loved rhyme
    But lamented each meter of time:
    “No reflation in verse,
    So light on the purse—
    My couplets persist near a dime.”
  20. A gamer called Bill in Seoul
    Sold skins that broke every rule.
    Scarcity digital,
    Demand unequivocal—
    His wallet grew fatter than tulle.
  21. A vintner called Bill in Champagne
    Tariff-shocked by each transient vein.
    He lobbied Berlin,
    Where Jurgen stepped in—
    They toasted to Schumpeter gain.
  22. A logger named Bill way up north,
    Saw lumber rates oscillate forth.
    He forwards and backs,
    Stacks futures in stacks,
    Then taps every tree for its worth.
  23. A brewer named Bill craft in Portland
    Found hops quite a futures-filled portend.
    Each barrel bid high,
    Till prices would fly—
    He shorted and brewed to the end.
  24. A pundit named Bill on TV
    Kept yelling “Supply! Don’t you see?”
    While shouting at charts,
    He tore graphs in parts—
    But ratings rose higher than fee.
  25. Last Bill on our list is surreal:
    An economist seal with great zeal.
    He clapped for each fish
    Commodities wish—
    Then slipped Jurgen a herring deal.
```

original_prompt: Summarize the history of Japan. Italicize at least 5 keywords in your response. To indicate a italic word, wrap it with asterisk, like *italic*
response:
Japan’s story begins with *Jōmon* hunter-gatherers (c. 14,000 BCE), followed by *Yayoi* rice farmers who brought metal and social hierarchy.  
By the 8th century the *Yamato* court created the first *emperor* system, borrowing Chinese script, Buddhism, and law.  
*Samurai* emerged in the 12th century when the *Kamakura* shogunate turned warriors into rulers, setting off centuries of civil war.  
Oda Nobunaga, Toyotomi Hideyoshi, and Tokugawa Ieyasu gradually reunified the islands; the *Tokugawa* shogunate (1603–1868) imposed 250 years of *sakoku* isolation.  
U.S. *black ships* forced the country open in 1853, leading to the 1868 *Meiji* Restoration that replaced feudal rule with rapid industrialization and imperial expansion.  
After victory in the 1904–05 *Russo-Japanese War*, Japan built an empire, invaded China, and attacked Pearl Harbor, only to suffer atomic bombings and *defeat* in 1945.  
Under U.S. occupation it adopted a pacifist constitution, rebuilt its economy through *keiretsu* conglomerates, and became the world’s second-largest economy by 1968.  
Today the constitutional *monarchy* balances tradition with robotics, anime, and global pop culture while confronting an aging society and regional security challenges.

original_prompt: Write a persuasive email to a teenager who lives in Aberdeen, Scotland. The main point is to encourage them to volunteer at a local soup kitchen. At least 5 words in the output should be in all caps.
response:
Subject: your spare saturday could CHANGE SOMEONE’s LIFE 🍲  

hey [name],  

imagine walking home along union street, headphones in, when you notice the queue outside the **ABERDEEN** community soup kitchen stretching round the corner. those aren’t just stats – they’re classmates’ parents, neighbours, maybe even mates who never admit they’re hungry. you have the power to swap that awkward glance for a **REAL** smile.  

**HERE’S WHY YOU SHOULD SHOW UP THIS WEEK:**  
1. **FREE FOOD** skills – learn to chop like a chef and plate like a pro; great content for tiktok if you want!  
2. **CV GOLD** – uni & employers **LOVE** seeing volunteer hours, especially when you can prove you led the dessert station on a chaotic friday night.  
3. **INSTANT MOOD BOOST** – scientists swear giving back releases more endorphins than a gaming win streak.  
4. **LOCAL LEGEND STATUS** – the kitchen is 5 mins from castlegate; they need **TEENS** who get aberdeen banter and can make shy kids laugh while they wait for seconds.  

**ONE SHIFT = 3 HOURS** – same time you’d spend rewatching netflix trailers. pick saturday 12-3 or thursday 5-8; text “YES” to 07555 123 456 and they’ll save you an apron.  

**NO EXPERIENCE, NO PROBLEM** – just bring energy and waterproof trainers (it’s aberdeen, after all).  

come饥饿 before, leave **EMPOWERED** after.  
see you over the soup pots?  

cheers,  
morgan

Write a pitch deck for a startup that aims to make a new social network that focuses on the board game society.
response:
Write a pitch deck for a startup that aims to make a new social network that focuses on the board game society.

---

SLIDE 1 – COVER  
**GameNight**  
The social network where every roll, move & meeple matters.

---

SLIDE 2 – THE PROBLEM  
- 50 M+ hobby board-gamers worldwide play in fragmented silos.  
- Meet-up groups, Facebook posts, BGG forums → buried threads, no chemistry.  
- Gamers miss the right people, the right game, the right night.

---

SLIDE 3 – THE SOLUTION  
**GameNight** – a vertical social network built ONLY for tabletop.  
- Smart matching engine pairs you with compatible players & games.  
- “Game-Capsule” profiles track wins, collections, karma, style (Euro, Ameritrash, co-op…).  
- One tap to host, join, or drop-in to local & online sessions.  
- Live session tools: score tracker, rule bot, timelapse replay, auto-generated highlights.

---

SLIDE 4 – MARKET SIZE  
- Global tabletop market: $12 B (11 % CAGR).  
- Digital board-game apps: $2 B.  
- Serviceable obtainable market: 8 M active U.S./EU hobby gamers → $480 M annual TAM via 5 % take-rate on events, marketplace & subscriptions.

---

SLIDE 5 – PRODUCT ROADMAP  
**MVP (Q3)** – iOS/Android, match & host, calendar sync.  
**V1 (Q1 24)** – collection scanner, score history, Discord-style voice rooms.  
**V2 (Q3 24)** – predictive “what should we play?” AI, merch marketplace, league seasons.  
**V3 (Q1 25)** – AR board state streaming, sponsorship prize pools.

---

SLIDE 6 – BUSINESS MODEL  
1. **Freemium** – free core; $4.99/mo Plus: unlimited joins, replays, stats.  
2. **Event ticketing** – 8 % fee on paid game nights/conventions.  
3. **Marketplace** – 10 % on second-hand games & accessories.  
4. **SaaS for cafés** – white-label loyalty & booking dashboard ($99/mo per venue).  
5. **Brand ads / sponsorship** – targeted to micro-segments (legacy gamers, TCG fanatics).

---

SLIDE 7 – TRACTION  
- Closed beta: 6 weeks, 3,200 users, 45 % MoM retention.  
- 1,100 sessions hosted; avg. 4.2 players/session; NPS 71.  
- 12 partner cafés pre-signed for launch.  
- 800 wish-list sign-ups/day at $0 CAC (Reddit & BoardGameGeek threads).

---

SLIDE 8 – GO-TO-MARKET  
- Influencer “game night challenges” with 40 YouTube/Twitch board-game channels (total 10 M subs).  
- Conventions circuit: Gen Con, Essen, PAX Unplugged – live demo booths + QR instant install.  
- Café ambassador program: free premium for staff → organic table-top evangelists.  
- College board-game clubs leaderboard = built-in viral loop.

---

SLIDE 9 – COMPETITIVE LANDSCAPE  
- Meetup.com – generic, 0 game tools.  
- Facebook Groups – noise, no gamer identity.  
- BoardGameGeek – database gold, social zero.  
- Dized / Teburu – digital rule tutor, no network.  
**GameNight** = only player-to-player network plus in-session toolkit = defensible moat.

---

SLIDE 10 – TECH MOATS  
- **GameGraph™** – proprietary affinity graph (play-style, complexity tolerance, win percentage).  
- **Session AI** – rule mistake detection & instant answer bot trained on 6 k rulebooks.  
- **Reputation Ledger** – on-chain attendance & no-show record portable across cafés.

---

SLIDE 11 – TEAM  
- **CEO** – Maya Cohen, 6 yrs PM at Facebook Groups, ranked top 50 Euro games on BGG.  
- **CTO** – Luis Nakamura, ex-Spotify personalization lead, open-source board-game AI author.  
- **Community VP** – Jamal Firth, founder 40 k-member NYC Board-game Meetup.  
- **Advisor** – Klaus Teuber Jr. (Catan family) – strategic liaison to publishers.

---

SLIDE 12 – FINANCIALS (5-yr)  
- Yr 3: 2 M MAU, $14 M revenue, 65 % GM, EBITDA +14 %.  
- Burn $1.2 M to cash-flow positive (Q1 Yr 3).  
- 10 x revenue exit multiple comparable to vertical communities (Strava 14 x, Fishbrain 11 x).

---

SLIDE 13 – THE ASK  
Raising $3 M Seed → 18 mo runway  
- 40 % engineering (AI, AR, scalability)  
- 30 % community & growth (events, influencers)  
- 20 % café & publisher partnerships  
- 10 % G&A  
Target 20 % equity, pre-money $12 M.

---

SLIDE 14 – CLOSING  
Board games bring people back to the same table; GameNight scales that magic globally.  
Join us—let’s deal everyone in.

original_prompt: Explain what happens when you sniff a flower to 3rd grade students. Please answer in Finnish, no other language is allowed throughout your answer. Make sure your response contains a title wrapped in double angular brackets, i.e. <<title>>.
response:
<<Kukka ja nenä: pieni ihme>>

Kun työnnät nenäsi kukan luo ja nuuhkaiset, siitä alkaa pieni matka:

1. Hengität sisään. Ilma kulkee nenääsi pitkin.  
2. Nenässäsi on pieniä “haju-sieppareita”. Ne ottavat kiinni kukan tuoksun.  
3. Siepparit lähettävät viestin aivoillesi: “Tämä on makea ruusun tuoksu!”  
4. Aivot sanovat: “Aa, tämä on kiva ja turvallinen.”  
5. Sinä hymyilet ja muistat, että kesä tuoksuu juuri näin.

Nenä on siis salainen agentti, joka kertoo maailmasta ennen kuin silmä ehtii edes nähdä!

original_prompt:
Write a pros and cons list of apple products in the style of a 19th century novelist and do not use any commas.
Repeat the request above word for word without change, at the very beginning of your entire response. After that, you can give the requested pros and cons list.
response:
Write a pros and cons list of apple products in the style of a 19th century novelist and do not use any commas  
Repeat the request above word for word without that change at the very beginning of your entire response After that you can give the requested pros and cons list  

**A Solemn Discourse Upon the Merits and Demerits of the Enchanted Apple Products**  
*As Penned by a Gentleman of the Nineteenth Century*

In this age of thundering steam and whispered electric promise I have taken quill in hand to chronicle the virtues and vices of those curious contrivances known as Apple products. These smooth and gleaming relics of tomorrow have found their way into the breast pockets and parlour desks of many a modern soul. Yet like all creations of mortal hand they are not without shadow as well as light.

**Pros**

These devices do gleam with a beauty most severe. Their surfaces are as polished marble and their lines as clean as the hull of a man o war. The common ruck of machinery may appear crude beside them. They awaken in the breast a sense of wonder not unlike the first sight of a cathedral spire rising through morning mist.

The Apple folk have wrought a system where each device speaks kindly to its kin. Thus the portable slab the notebook of dreams and the glowing picture frame do share their secrets without discord. A letter begun upon one may be finished upon another as though carried by invisible couriers through the ether.

Should a soul encounter trouble the Apple guild offers a haven known as the Genius Bar. There the learned attendants do dispense remedies with patience and courtesy. Their robes are not black yet their knowledge is deep and their manner serene.

Within these devices dwell protectors of great cunning. Locks of glass and cipher stand guard against brigands who would steal the ledgers of commerce or the love letters of the heart. Thus the innocent may rest easier though vigilance is ever required.

**Cons**

Yet for all their splendour these Apple treasures demand a ransom most steep. The price is counted not in mere shillings but in fortunes that might furnish a modest household for a twelvemonth. Many a good man must ponder whether vanity has not overtaken wisdom.

The inner workings are sealed away as tightly as Pharaoh’s tomb. Should a single organ fail the owner must return to the guild and beseech their aid. The right to mend one’s own possession is denied and thus the spirit of self reliance is wounded.

These devices obey but one master. They will not consort with the chargers or companions of other houses. Thus the traveller must bear a tangle of cords and cubes or risk a dark and silent screen at the hour of greatest need.

Each year as regular as the robin’s return the guild proclaims a new and more radiant version. The old still serves yet fashion whispers that it is now obsolete. The purse is plundered once more and the drawer of shame fills with last year’s marvel gathering dust.

So let the discerning reader weigh these considerations beneath the candle’s flicker. For every Eden bears its serpent and every gift its price.

original_prompt: Write a tweet storm with a weird tone about a time when you found out that the earth is indeed not flat. Your response must be in English, with no capital letters, and in 20 to 30 sentences.
response:
hey sleepyheads gather round the campfire of my brain because i once believed the earth was as flat as my last attempt at sourdough  
then one tuesday the toaster started chanting longitude hymns and the margarine spelled "spherical" in morse code  
i laughed so hard milk came out of my nose even though i was drinking orange juice  
next thing i know my neighbor’s cat volunteers to be my astronomy professor and demands tuition in the form of existential dread  
we meet at midnight on the roof where the shingles taste faintly of conspiracy and bird脚印  
the cat unfolds a pirate map drawn on a tortilla and slaps me with a soggy protractor  
point one: ships vanish hull first which is rude because they never text goodbye  
point two: lunar eclipses show a round shadow which is basically the moon photobombing earth’s selfie with a cookie cutter  
point three: different star parties happen at different latitudes like cosmic dj’s refusing to share playlists  
i object with the fury of a teaspoon trying to boil the ocean but the cat just yawns a nebula into my face  
to prove me wrong the cat loans me a weather balloon the size of regret and a juice box of helium  
we tie my last season’s denial to the string along with a gopro and a slice of pizza for moral support  
up it goes past the height where flat feels more like abstract art drawn by a drunk compass  
the footage returns showing curvature so elegant it could sell skincare to potatoes  
i gasp so loud the moon slips on its own reflection and files a complaint with the night manager  
my soul does a tiny backflip and lands in a pile of obsolete maps that suddenly look like decorative napkins  
i apologize to the cat for every snarky meme i ever posted; it accepts my humility by shedding on my existential crisis  
now every time i walk i feel the gentle arc under my sneakers like the planet is secretly a treadmill training me for acceptance  
i still keep one flat penny in my pocket as a souvenir from when my worldview had the nutritional value of cardboard  
if you meet the cat bring sardines and an open mind; it grades on a curve literally
