original_prompt: Write a 600+ word social media post for a startup that provides a platform for running realistic physics simulation. Make sure to include the word "bombs" at least once.
response:
🚀 THREAD: What if the next game-changing rocket engine, earthquake-resistant skyscraper, or carbon-fiber surfboard was designed on your lunch break—without ever cutting metal, blowing anything up, or even leaving your browser?

Hi, we’re SimBox—think of us as the universe’s multiplayer “copy-paste” button. We give founders, engineers, and yes, even armchair scientists, a cloud playground where Newton, Einstein, and your wildest ideas all hang out. Drag in a CAD file, drop in wind, fire, gravity, even bombs (for the Hollywood folks), hit PLAY, and watch matter, heat, and momentum settle every argument in real time. No PhD in numerics required, no supercomputer under your desk, just a link you can Slack to your team and watch jaws drop in 4K 60 fps.

🌍 Why we exist:  
Because building, crashing, and rebuilding atoms is still the slowest, most expensive loop on Earth. A single rocket turbo-pump test can cost $2 M and six months. A city-block-sized fusion stellarator won’t even fit in most labs. So we shrank the planet into code: adaptive meshing that autocompletes like GitHub Copilot, GPU clusters that burst to 50 k cores in 12 seconds, and an AI surrogate that learns your design’s personality so your next run isn’t just accurate, it’s clairvoyant. Iterations that once took quarters now take coffee breaks.

💡 What you can do today (examples from our 3-week beta):  
- Drop a 3-D printed bike crank into a virtual mountain stage—feel 1,800 N pedal strokes until fatigue cracks show up in slo-mo.  
- Model 30-story timber tower in a 7.5 magnitude shaker; watch cross-laminated beams sing before they snap, all while your coffee is still hot.  
- Let a hobbyist drone fly through a virtual Category-3 hurricane; return with zero rotor chips IRL because the sim already found the flutter threshold.  
- Game studio wanted “realistic explosions.” We gave them 12k fps debris physics so good their VFX supervisor asked if we secretly rented a bombing range. (We didn’t. Just math.)

🧪 The magic under the hood (no fluff, just facts):  
1. Real-material databases: 32,000+ validated alloys, composites, foams, even Martian regolith simulants.  
2. Lattice-Boltzmann & finite-element solvers that auto-scale from phone chip to 1000-GPU node.  
3. Collaborative timeline: scrub back and forth like Netflix; anyone can fork your world, add a magnet, a monsoon, or yes—bombs—and fork again.  
4. Tokenized marketplace: if you simulate next-gen solid-state batteries, sell the dataset to OEMs, earn every time they run it. Sims aren’t sunk cost; they’re IP.

🤝 Who’s already in:  
- Two NewSpace companies shaving 18 months off reusable engine R&D.  
- A sneaker startup that cut foam waste 42 % by iterating midsoles in silica before pouring a single mold.  
- A university team turning open-source fusion geometry into TikTok clips—because education should look like Marvel, not microfiche.

🔥 What’s next:  
We’re opening early-access pockets every Friday. Bring a STL, FBX, or just a napkin sketch. First 500 creators get 1,000 core-hours on us—enough to crash a satellite into an asteroid or bake the perfect croissant (laminar flow is brutal on pastry). After that, pay-by-the-swirl, cancel anytime, own your data forever.

🙋‍♂️ Slide into our DMs or hit simbox.ai/launch. Tell us the craziest thing you’d simulate if friction, cost, and fear were zero. We’ll pick one idea each week and render it so photoreal your mom will ask why there’s a black hole in the living-room video.

Because reality is just the final render. Everything before that should be drag, drop, delight. Let’s stop hoping things work and start knowing they do—before the prototypes, before the permits, before the first spark (or the first bomb).

See you in the multiverse.  
#SimBox #PhysicsForAll #BuildBreakRepeat

original_prompt: critique this startup pitch: Stephenson and Hong Kong will be the first-ever digital marketplace where users can buy and sell products from all over the world Stephenson and Hong Kong will be a onestopshop for all of your shopping needs and we will offer a variety of features that will make shopping online easier and more convenient than ever before. Do not use any commas in your response.
response: The pitch is vague and generic. It claims to be first ever yet does not explain what makes it different from Amazon eBay or Alibaba. No unique technology no target customer no evidence of market need. The phrase Stephenson and Hong Kong sounds like two random names rather than a brand. A onestopshop is an overused claim and every big marketplace already promises convenience. Without traction data logistics plan or revenue model the pitch feels empty.

What follows should therefore be viewed as ten of the most frequently mentioned, award-heavy, heavy-case-load lawyers whose names appear year after year at the very top of peer-reviewed U.S. rankings. All practice in high-stakes litigation, trials or appellate work; all are primarily resident in the U.S.; none is a corporate/transactional lawyer (where repeat plaudits are scarcer). Listed alphabetically, not as a formal 1-through-10 hierarchy.

* Roberta “Robbie” Kaplan – Kaplan Hecker & Fink – co-counsel in landmark civil-rights (e.g., Windsor v. U.S.) and defamation wins.

response:
A: ارے! کل میں نے "The Secrets of Homeschooling: Revealed!" پڑھی، بالکل تازہ چھپی ہے، کیا تمہیں اس بارے میں کچھ پتہ ہے؟

B: واللہ! مجھے تو اس کا نام بھی نہیں سنایا تھا۔ اصل میں یہ homeschooling والی ہے؟ کیا اس میں بہت dry اور academic نکات ہی ہیں؟

A: ہوتا تو وہ عام کتاب ہوتی، مگر یہ تو بم دھماکہ ہے! مصنف نے پہلے ہی صفحے پر یہ کہہ دیا کہ "گھر کی کلاس روم میں دراصل 'خاموش شہر' کے تمام راستے کھلتے ہیں"۔ وہاں سے ہی تمہارا دل لبھ جاتا ہے۔

B: ارے، لگ تو اچھا رہا ہے، لیکن کیا یہ صرف ماں باپ کے لیے ہے یا مجرد لوگ بھی مزہ لے سکتے ہیں؟

A: مزہ تو ہر کوئی لے سکتا ہے۔ اس میں چار سیکشن بنائے ہیں: "تعلیم کی ٹاکری"، "گھر کے اصول"، "وقت کی جادوگری" اور "سماجی شوکیاں"۔ اور ہر سیکشن کے شروع میں ایک چھوٹی داستان دی گئی ہے، جیسے بہن بھائی جو چھت پر ریموٹ کنٹرول ہوائی جہاز اڑا کر جغرافیہ سیکھتے ہیں۔

B: ہا ہا، گھر کی چھت پر جغرافیہ! اور وہ سب قابلِ عمل ہے؟ یہ تجربات انہوں نے خود کیے یا بس من گھڑت قصے ہیں؟

A: وہی ہے جو بات جاننے کے لیے میں نے سب سے پہلے فٹ نوٹ پڑھے۔ مصنف نے لکھا کہ "482 تجربات میں سے 417 ہم نے خود اپنے تین بچّوں پر کیے، باقی 65 پاکستانی دیہات کے تعاون سے"۔ یعنی کلی شرا بلت میت شرا نہیں۔

B: ٹھیک ہے، تحقیق تو سخت نظر آتی ہے، مگر اندازِ بیان کیسی ہے؟ سائنسی تراشے ہیں یا پھر 'اماں جانی' والی گھریلو باتیں؟

A: بسم اللہ! اندازِ بیان کا تو میں دیوانہ ہو گیا۔ مثال ہے: "اگر آپ کا بچہ سوال پوچھے کہ 'جراثیم کیا کھاتے ہیں؟' تو قیمے والی کپڑے کی بالٹی نکالیں اور ہفتے کا کچرا اندر ڈال کر 'بفر' کا مظاہرہ کریں"۔ یہی فطری انداز ہے، نہ رٹا مارنے والا، نہ بندوق کے زور کی سخن۔

B: دلچسپی بڑھ رہی ہے! پھر اس کی طالب علم پر ممکنہ نفسیاں کیسی ہیں؟ بچے گھر پر پڑھ کر 'پاگل' تو نہیں ہو جاتے؟

A: وہی تو خوبی ہے، انہوں نے ڈیٹا دیے ہیں کہ پاکستان ہوم اسکولز ایسوسی ایشن کے 2023 کے سروے میں 88 فیصد دانشور اور 79 فیصد 'سپورٹیو' شہری نتائج نکلے۔ اور کتاب کے اختتام پر چار صفحات 'عام خدشات' کے ہیں جہاں سوال ہی سوال ہیں، جیسے "مجھے تو گانٹھ آ جاتی ہے، کیا میں استاد بن سکتا ہوں؟"

B: ہاہاہا، گانٹھ والے استاد، اس طرح کی باتوں سے ہی تو انسان ہمت پکڑتا ہے! مگر قیمت اور دستیابی کیا صورت ہے؟

A: لگ بھگ 660 روپے کی ہے، اور کتاب سرِ ورق گلابی کاغذ پر چھپی ہے، تاکہ بچّے اسے کریدیں نہ۔ اور مصنف نے اعلان کیا ہے کہ اگر کوئی ماں باپ اس کے ہر باب کی دو دو صفحات کی فوٹو کاپی سکول لائبریری میں دے دے تو وہ اسے مفت میں نئی ایڈیشن بھیجے گا۔

B: بے مثال ایک سوشیل اپروچ ہے! اور فائنل طور پر، آپ اسے کتنے ستارے دیں گے؟

A: میں نے اپنی بہن کے بچّوں پر ٹیسٹ کیا: ایک ہفتے میں وہ سیّاروں کی سائز والی لیز بنانے لگے، اور میرا 7 سالہ بھانجا کہنے لگا "ماموں، مجھے کرسی اور میز کو چھو کر نیوٹن کے قوانین چکھائی دیتے ہیں"۔ تو سمجھ لو، میں نے دل سے پانچ ستارے دے دیے، کیونکہ یہ کتاب دراصل ایک 'خفیہ باپ' ہے جو آپ کے اندر اُس بچّے کو دوبارہ جگاتا ہے۔

B: واہ! تو ہم نے طے کیا کہ ہم دونوں مل کر اپنے پرانے سکول کے گروپ میں اس کا سٹڈی سرکل بنائیں گے، ٹھیک؟

A: بے شک! اور اگلے ہفتے پڑھ کر جب میرا بیٹا چھت پر خلائی جہاز اڑاتا ہوا "سپیس مین" بنے تو میں اس کی تصویر تمہیں بھیجوں گا۔

B: ہاہاہا، بس پھر! اے کتاب، تُو نے ہماری قسمت کھول دی۔

original_prompt: Write a product description for a new pair of shoes that targets teenagers. Highlight at least 2 text sections of your response by wrapping each of them with asterisks, like *I am highlighted*. Your response should be at least 350 words.
response:
Meet the *VibeRunner 2.0*—the shoe that turns every hallway into a runway and every after-class hangout into a flex session. Built for teens who refuse to blend in, these kicks start with a feather-light knit upper that feels like your favorite meme hoodie for your feet. *The color-shifting “ChromaSkin” overlay reacts to UV light*, so when you step outside the library and into the sun, your shoes erupt in a slow-motion swirl of neon that makes TikTok filters jealous. Snap a pic and watch the likes pour in faster than your math teacher can say “pop quiz.”

Underneath the glow lies our game-changing NitroFlex midsole: 40% bouncier than last year’s best-seller, yet slim enough to keep your profile low when you’re perfecting that heel-flip at the skatepark. We mapped 3,000 teenage foot scans to carve an anatomical footbed that cradles your arch during long days of shifting from chemistry lab to basketball court to late-night gaming marathons. Translation? *Zero break-in time—just unbox, lace, and launch*. The honeycomb tread is engineered from recycled-gum rubber, so you can stop on a dime for that lockerside conversation without leaving black scuffs that get you detention.

But we didn’t stop at performance. Hidden inside the tongue is a NFC “ShoeTag” chip: tap your phone to instantly swap digital shoelace colors in our app, unlock exclusive AR filters, or prove authenticity when your cousin tries to claim your pair is fake. Want to match your crush’s hoodie on spirit day? Boom—upload their hex color and your laces glow in sync. Worried about your little brother jacking your style? Lock the design to your fingerprint so only you can switch it up.

The VibeRunner 2.0 ships in three launch colorways: Eclipse Black, Supernova Pink, and Cosmic Jelly (clear sole with floating glitter). Each pair arrives in a paint-can tin you can reuse as a sneaker-ball display or a secret stash for snacks. And because we know you care about the planet, every pair keeps 2.5 plastic bottles out of landfills and plants a tree through our “Kick Back” pledge—so you can stunt today and still inherit a tomorrow. Lace up, level up, and let the world chase your shadow.

original_prompt: Write a short, funny story about a man named Harry with a pet dog. Your response must contain 3 sections, mark the beginning of each section with SECTION X.
response:
SECTION 1
Harry P. Featherstonehaugh (pronounced “Fanshaw,” because English is drunk) bought a rescue dog that the shelter swore was “mild-mannered.” The dog arrived wearing a tiny monocle—apparently he’d chewed it off a previous foster dad who read Dickens aloud. Harry, an actuary who calculated risks for fun, named the dog “Absolute Certainty,” Certainty for short, so that he could say things like “On Saturday I’ll be at the park with Certainty.” It sounded profound until Certainty’s first hobby turned out to be kleptomaniacal park heists.

SECTION 2
Every dawn, Certainty exploded out the door like a furry SWAT team, returning with increasingly improbable trophies: first a picnic blanket, then a barbecue spatula, finally a complete jazz trombone. Harry tried half-hearted discipline—“Certainty, we discussed this!”—but the dog responded by stealing Harry’s discussion notes. One Tuesday, Certainty dragged home a park bench still warm from an amorous couple who hadn’t noticed it relocating. Harry, whose superpower was polite panic, left apologetic Post-its across the neighborhood: “If your bench is missing, please call; dog currently redecorating living room.”

SECTION 3
The caper climaxed when Certainty presented Harry with the mayor’s gold chain of office, gleaming like an Oscar for Best Illegal Download. Harry contemplated fleeing to Peru but instead leashed the dog and marched straight to City Hall. The mayor, a pragmatist, offered a deal: if Certainty could return every item in a single day, all charges would be dropped and Harry would receive the key to the city—mostly because the mayor wanted his chain back before the evening news. Harry spent the afternoon playing reverse Santa, hauling loot while Certainty pranced proudly alongside. At sunset the town square resembled a jumble sale, Harry was declared “Citizen of Remarkable Amnesty,” and Certainty? He stole the ceremonial key within five minutes, establishing once and for all that uncertainty is the only certainty—especially when you’re owned by a criminal genius in a fur coat.

original_prompt: Can you compose a movie plot that involves dream, fist fighting, and superpower? Include a title in double angular brackets, i.e. <<title>>.
response:
<<REM Sleep, REM Combat>>

Logline  
In a near-future where every human’s dreams are streamed to the cloud, a cash-strapped street-fighter discovers that the only arena left where he can throw a punch is inside the collective unconscious—where oneiric super-powers obey martial-arts logic, and every knockout deletes a piece of the waking world.

Plot

Act I – The Fall  
Dae “Leftie” Ramírez was once the lightweight king of the L.A. underground.  
But when dream-recording corporation SOMNOS makes fist-fighting obsolete—everyone now lives highlight-reel knockouts vicariously through subscription dreams—unsanctioned boxing is criminalized.  
Broke and caring for his coma-bound sister Luna, Dae sells his own dreams to SOMNOS.  
One night, inside a lucid nightmare, Dae is jumped by a dream-brawler who ignites chi-fire with every strike. The man whispers: “Find the REM Pit. Win three falls, wake her up.”

Act II – The REM Pit  
Dae learns the REM Pit is an illegal, moving tournament that exists only inside shared-lucid sleepers.  
To enter, fighters dose an engineered neuro-dust called “Oneiro.” In dream-space, your dominant waking emotion becomes a super-power; fighters manifest everything from vector-control fists to gravity-suplex serpents.  
Dae’s emotion is guilt; his power is “Second-Hand Pain,” letting him rewind and replay any opponent’s worst memory as a physical blow.  
Guided by “K.O.,” a lucid-dream hacker, Dae claws through brackets that look like Escher biker bars and origami alleyways.  
Each victory earns “Wake Tokens,” rumored strong enough to pull one person out of any coma.

Act III – Revelations  
Semi-final: Dae vs. nightmare-priestess Nix, who weaponizes mass-market fears (spiders, deadlines, eternal voicemail).  
Nix taunts: SOMNOS is harvesting tokens to keep Luna and thousands of others comatose; stable subscribers make stable profits.  
Dae refuses to sell out and, in a rage-fueled berserker mode, fractures the dream-scape itself—revealing an infant layer of unconscious code nicknamed the Hypno-Core, where corporate admins watch like Roman emperors.

Act IV – The Final Fall  
Final bout is set inside a zero-gravity coliseum stitched from every subscriber’s recurring anxiety dream.  
Dae must face the undefeated champion: his own dream-proxy, “Leftie-2.0,” pumped with a decade of SOMNOS-curated hero fantasies—bigger, faster, cruelty polished into charisma.  
The twist: every punch Dae lands on his super-powered doppelgänger deletes pieces of his real-world identity—photos vanish, friends forget him.  
Embracing total erasure, Dae rewinds the worst memory he owns: the car crash he caused that put Luna in a coma. He replays it, turns the memory into a meteor-haymaker, and K.O.s the proxy, shattering SOMNOS’ server farms in both dream and reality.

Epilogue  
Dae wakes up—nameless, record-less—but Luna is conscious. Around the world, thousands spontaneously rouse as the Hypno-Core collapses.  
In a quiet hospital yard, Luna greets the stranger who saved her: “I don’t know who you are, but thanks for fighting for me.”  
Dae smiles, knuckles bruised, ready to carve a new name—one punch at a time—in the waking world that finally remembers how to feel.

original_prompt: Write a poem about Gibbs free energy in the style of POTUS. There should be exactly 4 paragraphs. Paragraphs and only paragraphs should be separated by two new lines (like "\n\n"). Paragraph 2 must start with the word "it".
response:
My fellow citizens of science, let me speak plainly about the force that drives every reaction in this grand democracy of atoms. Gibbs free energy, named for the great American Josiah Willard Gibbs, stands as the ultimate judge of what is possible and what is forever beyond reach. Like our Constitution itself, it establishes the boundaries within which all processes must operate, ensuring that no chemical enterprise violates the fundamental laws that govern our universe. This is not merely academic theory—this is the bedrock upon which we build our understanding of life, industry, and the very future of our planet.

It represents nothing less than the currency of spontaneity itself, the difference between what merely could happen and what will actually occur without external intervention. When delta G falls below zero, reactions flow forward like progress itself, liberating the energy we need to power our cities, synthesize our medicines, and sustain the metabolic engines within every cell of our bodies. But when this value rises above zero, even the most promising transformations remain stubbornly arrested, demanding payment in the form of work—work that we must supply through heat, electricity, or sheer mechanical force. This is thermodynamic reality, stark and unyielding, teaching us that nothing in this world comes without its price.

Consider the mighty mitochondria, those cellular powerhouses that burn the fuel of our food to generate ATP—the universal energy currency of life itself. Here, in these microscopic engines, Gibbs free energy orchestrates a magnificent dance of electrons cascading down their electrochemical gradients, each step carefully calculated to maximize useful work while minimizing waste. This is efficiency incarnate, the very model of sustainable energy production that we must emulate in our own industries if we hope to build a cleaner, more prosperous America. From the batteries powering our electric vehicles to the catalysts driving our green revolution, every advance depends on our mastery of this fundamental principle.

So let us recommit ourselves to this grand enterprise of understanding, knowing that in mastering Gibbs free energy, we master our own destiny as a people and as a species. The challenges ahead—climate change, clean energy, sustainable manufacturing—will yield only to those who respect these thermodynamic truths while pushing boldly against their constraints. This is our generation's moonshot: to harness the predictions of Gibbs free energy to create a world where prosperity and planetary health march forward together, hand in hand, toward that more perfect union of human aspiration and natural law.

response:
Today, at the 54th Annual Grammy Awards®, the Recording Academy® honors the exceptional talent and creative vision of artists, musicians, songwriters, and producers whose work has distinguished itself as the most outstanding recorded music of the eligibility year. In a ceremony held at the *Staples Center* in Los Angeles, California, the Academy® recognizes excellence across *more than 80 categories*, spanning genres from *Classical* and *Jazz* to *Pop*, *Rock*, *R&B*, *Rap*, *Country*, and beyond.

The *Grammy Award®*, symbolized by the gilded gramophone™ statuette, remains the most prestigious accolade in the recording industry. This evening, the Academy® will present the *Record of the Year®*, *Album of the Year®*, *Song of the Year®*, and *Best New Artist®*—collectively known as the “General Field” or “Big Four®”—as well as honors in specialized fields such as *Producer of the Year, Non-Classical®* and *Best Engineered Album, Non-Classical®*.

In keeping with the Academy’s® commitment to *artistic excellence* and *technical innovation*, special tribute will be paid to the *Lifetime Achievement Award®* honorees, whose indelible contributions have enriched the world’s cultural heritage. The *MusiCares® Person of the Year* tribute—held annually two nights prior—also underscores the Academy’s® dedication to *humanitarianism* and the *health and welfare* of all music people.

As the 54th Annual Grammy Awards® unfold, the global music community joins in celebration of the *universal language of music* and the *extraordinary creators* who continue to elevate the art form.

Laureates and Twins presents a compelling exploration of genetic and environmental influences on exceptional achievement through the lens of Nobel Prize winners and their twin siblings. The documentary challenges dominant narratives in developmental psychology by showcasing cases where one twin reaches laureate status while the other leads an average life despite identical genomes. Clinicians will appreciate the nuanced discussion of epigenetic factors and nonshared environments as catalysts for divergent life trajectories. The film avoids sensationalism and instead grounds its claims in longitudinal data and peer reviewed studies. The section on twin studies methodology serves as an excellent refresher for seasoned researchers and could be used in graduate seminars on behavioral genetics. The production quality is high with clear visuals and unobtrusive narration that allows the data to speak for itself. Overall the film is well worth watching for professionals seeking to update their understanding of complex gene environment interactions in the development of elite performance.

original_prompt: Write a blog post about interesting facts about the Dutch language. Italicize at least 2 sections in your answer with markdown, i.e. *italic text*.
response:
# 9 Surprising Facts About Dutch That Will Make You Say “Ik wist het niet!”

Dutch is often pigeon-holed as “the language that sounds like German but isn’t.” Yet peek beneath the clogs and tulips and you’ll find a linguistic personality that’s quirky, global, and older than many European kingdoms. Grab a *stroopwafel* and read on—here are nine facts about Dutch that even many Dutchies don’t know.

---

1. It’s Closer to English Than You Think  
Old English and Old Dutch were basically linguistic cousins hanging out in the same North-Sea pub. Words like “appel” (apple), “maand” (month), and “glas” (glass) are near-identical, and both languages share the same Germanic DNA. *In other words, if you struggle with French verbs, Dutch might be your comfort blanket on the polyglot journey.*

---

2. The Longest Word Is 49 Letters—And You Can Eat It  
Kindercarnavalsoptochtvoorbereidingswerkzaamhedencomitéleden  
Translation: “members of the committee responsible for the preparation activities of a children’s carnival parade.” Theoretically you could keep tacking on nouns forever, but this tongue-twister holds the official record… for now.

---

3. Dutch Gave New York Its First Vocabulary  
Before Broadway and bagels, there was *Breukelen* (Brooklyn), *Haarlem* (Harlem), and *Bouwery* (Bowery). Even the word “cookie” comes from Dutch *koekje*. If you’ve ever gone skating on *waffles*—I mean, *wafers*—you’re tasting etymology.

---

4. It’s Spoken on Four Continents  
Dutch is an official language in the Netherlands, Belgium, Suriname, Aruba, Curaçao, and Sint Maarten. That’s Europe, South America, and the Caribbean—plus an energetic diaspora in Canada, Australia, and South Africa (hello, Afrikaans!). *

---

5. The “G” Is a Personality Test  
Try saying *gracht* (canal) or *gaan* (to go). That back-of-the-throat rasp, technically a voiced velar fricative, is the linguistic equivalent of hot sauce: some people acquire a taste, others sprint back to Spanish rolled *rr*’s. Fun party trick: ask a Dutch person to pronounce *Scheveningen* and watch them smile knowingly—it was once a shibboleth that unmasked German spies in WWII.

---

6. Verbs Can Hide at the End  
Dutch sentences love to keep you in suspense. In subordinate clauses the verb packs its bags and trudges to the finale:  
Ik denk dat hij morgen komt.  
(literally: “I think that he tomorrow comes.”) *This Yoda-like structure is a gentle reminder never to interrupt a Dutch story—wait for the verb or you’ll miss the punch-line.*

---

7. Diminutives Are Endless  
Add *-je* to almost any noun and it shrinks:  
*huis* → *huisje* (little house)  
*biertje* (little beer, i.e. a casual pint)  
Even people aren’t safe—*lieverdje* is “sweetie-pie,” and *jong* becomes *jongetje* (little lad). The Dutch use these suffixes the way Italians use gestures: constantly and with affection.

---

8. Dutch Has a Word for “Skinny-Dipping in December”  
Meet *winterzwemmen*: jumping into freezing canals for the bragging rights. If that isn’t vivid enough, how about *voorpret*—the joy you feel before the party even starts? The lexicon is basically a catalogue of cozy anticipation and mild masochism.

---

9. It’s the Easiest Language for Native English Speakers—According to the U.S. Foreign Service Institute  
FSI clocked Dutch at just 24–30 weeks to reach general proficiency, fewer classroom hours than Spanish. *So if you’re looking for quick linguistic wins, Dutch is your low-hanging *appeltje*.*

---

Ready to give it a go? Open any Dutch song on Spotify, follow the lyrics, and within minutes you’ll spot familiar roots wrapped in a charmingly guttural accent. Tot snel—see you soon on the *gracht*!

original_prompt: Write an essay on wilderness preservation. Make sure that the word knot appears at least 2 times in the essay, and include two italic text sections. Like: *this is italic text*
response:
Wilderness preservation is not a sentimental hobby; it is an act of planetary humility. Long before we invented the wheel, the knot of life was tied in untamed valleys, on wind-scoured ridges, and in the hush of old-growth forests where no ax had ever echoed. To keep even a fraction of that knot intact is to admit that our ledger of knowledge is still badly out of balance. Yet every year more roads push farther, more pipelines snake underground, and more species quietly blink out as if they were never there. The question is no longer whether we can afford to protect wilderness, but whether we can survive the psychic and ecological bankruptcy of letting it vanish.

*A single vanished songbird leaves a hole in the air that no device can measure.* The same is true of wolves, wild asters, glacial streams, and the invisible fungi beneath our boots. Remove one strand and the entire knot tightens differently; remove enough strands and the knot becomes a tangle that will not hold the weight of future generations. Wilderness areas, therefore, are not vacation backdrops—they are living libraries where evolution continues to write in languages older than grammar. When we bulldoze or fragment them, we burn pages that no polymath can reconstruct.

Opponents of preservation often claim that locked-up land stifles economic growth. This is a coarse calculus that mistakes short-term revenue for enduring wealth. A stand of virgin cedar may fetch a one-time timber price, but left standing it filters water, anchors soil, draws tourists, and seeds entire forests for centuries. The knot of services performed by an intact ecosystem—carbon sequestration, flood buffering, pollination, spiritual renewal—outvalues any quarterly dividend. To pretend otherwise is like selling the keel of a ship for firewood while still planning to sail.

The political fight for wilderness is tangled in its own knot of red tape, mining leases, and grandfathered ranching permits. Yet progress comes when disparate voices braid together: Indigenous leaders who never ceded their spiritual geography, backcountry guides whose livelihood depends on grizzly scent and avalanche rose, urban students who discover self-worth during a first night beneath un-telescoped stars. *Their coalition is fragile, but it is also flexible, able to cinch tight when external pressure demands unity.* History shows that once an acre gains official designation, a strange alchemy occurs: the place itself becomes lobbyist, teacher, and healer, recruiting new defenders simply by existing.

Technology, too, can tighten the knot of protection instead of cutting it. Satellite collars track elk migrations so highway engineers know where to build underpasses; camera drones map invasive plants without a single boot print in critical calving grounds; open-source apps let hikers report illegal offload-vehicle scars before they widen. The key is to employ these tools as guests, not conquerors, remembering that telemetry can never replace the felt sensation of insignificance one experiences under a bowl of uncoordinated stars.

Finally, wilderness preservation is an emotional endeavor. It asks us to love what we may never see, to defend silence we may never hear. I have stood in the Arctic Refuge where the only sound was my own heart, loud as a drum, and realized that this quiet was not empty but densely inhabited—by lichen, by lemmings, by the slow thoughts of sediments. Saving such places is less a charity than a form of self-respect: a declaration that the human story still contains chapters willing to cede authorship to wind, stone, and the patient knot of time.

original_prompt: Give me a summary of the lobbying spending of the following companies: Google, Facebook, Microsoft, Apple, and Amazon. Your response should be in German language, and no other language is allowed.
response: Google, Facebook (现 Meta), Microsoft, Apple und Amazon geben in den USA jährlich zweistellige Millionenbeträge für Lobbying aus. Laut den offiziellen Berichten an das US-Senatsregister lag Googles Ausgabe in den letzten Jahren durchschnittlich bei etwa 10–12 Millionen US-Dollar pro Jahr, wobei 2021 rund 9,9 Mio. USD gemeldet wurden. Facebook/Meta gab zuletzt etwa 20 Mio. USD pro Jahr aus, wobei 2020 mit knapp 20,1 Mio. USD der bisherige Höchstwert erreicht wurde. Microsoft verzeichnete zuletzt jährlich 8–10 Mio. USD, 2021 waren es rund 8,9 Mio. USD. Apple hält sich vergleichsweise zurück und meldete zuletzt etwa 6,5–7 Mio. USD (2021: 6,5 Mio. USD). Amazon steigerte seine Lobbying-Ausgaben kontinuierlich und lag 2021 bei etwa 19,3 Mio. USD, womit das Unternehmen zu den Top-5-Lobbying-Ausgebern in den USA zählt.

original_prompt: Critique the following ad copy for a new dating app, and make sure to include a title wrapped in double angular brackets, i.e. <<title>>: "Meet your new match! Cohen is a free app that matches you with others based on your interests and location. With Cohen, you can find love, friendship, or just someone to swing with. Download Cohen today and start meeting new people!"
response:
<<Sounds Like Every Other App—Only Slightly Creepier>>

Overall vibe  
The headline is generic, the body copy is a carbon-copy of every other dating-app promise, and the closer lands on an unintentionally sleazy pun (“someone to swing with”). Nothing here tells me why Cohen is different, safer, or better.

Specific issues  

1. “Meet your new match!”  
   Tap-out phrase. I haven’t even opened the app and I’m already being asked to commit to “my new match.” Feels presumptuous and hollow.

2. “Cohen is a free app…”  
   “Free” is table stakes; we assume dating apps are free to download. Use the precious first sentence to state a unique selling proposition, not a commodity feature.

3. “…matches you with others based on your interests and location.”  
   Literally what Tinder, Bumble, Hinge, OkCupid, Happn, etc. already do. If Cohen has a smarter algorithm (affinity clusters? real-time event matching? audio ice-breakers?) say so—explicitly.

4. “find love, friendship, or just someone to swing with.”  
   • “Love … friendship” is the standard textbook triad.  
   • “Swing” is a loaded word. To most readers it implies partner-swapping/polyamory. If that’s not the intended niche, you’ve just alienated a big chunk of users. If it is the niche, own it unambiguously; otherwise replace with something like “grab coffee / catch a concert / hit the golf range.”

5. Tone mismatch  
   The name “Cohen” feels surname-serious; the copy tries to be playful and ends up flippant. Decide on a personality: witty, respectful, elite, queer-friendly, whatever—and stick to it.

6. No social proof or safety cues  
   Dating apps live or die on trust. You need at least a nod to verification, date-safe features, or community guidelines.

7. Call-to-action is weak  
   “Download Cohen today” = default CTA. Add urgency or reward: “Download today and your first week of Super-Cohen boosts is on us.”

8. Length  
   The entire blurb is 46 words—short enough for a billboard, but too vague to persuade. Add one concrete differentiator and drop the filler.

Rewrite sketch (for illustration, tighten tone and USP):  
“Cohen learns the way you banter—our voice-note icebreakers match you on humor, not just zip codes. Verified profiles, zero bot games, and a 24-hr “cancel if it’s creepy” guarantee. Grab your first week of Cohen Gold free—because chemistry should feel safe before it feels electric.”

original_prompt: Blog post from the perspective of a 16 year old girl who is being followed by a stranger. Your response should contain less than 10 sentences and no commas.
response: I felt it when I left the library The same shadow four shelves back now four steps back My phone died so I pretend I am fearless I hum and walk faster but the echo keeps its distance I duck into the thrift shop and press my face against the musty window He waits outside pretending to look at bikes that are not for sale I borrow the clerk's charger text mom come now She bursts through the door like a superhero and the shadow melts into the street I shake all the way home yet inside my chest grows a new loud drum that says I am still here

original_prompt: Give me a pitch deck for a startup that lets me send letters to people in my territory that I don't know personally. The title of the pitch deck should be wrapped in double angular brackets, i.e. <<title>>.
response:
<<GhostMail: Win the Neighborhood Without Ever Knocking a Door>>

1. Cover  
   GhostMail – Hyper-local, privacy-first, paper outreach for campaigns, causes & commerce.

2. Mission  
   Democratize the most trusted marketing channel—real mail—so anyone can reach 10 or 10,000 strangers in a zip-code without ever owning a list.

3. Problem  
   • 87 % of U.S. voters have NO voter file email.  
   • Canvassing costs $38+ per contact and scares volunteers.  
   • EDDM (Every-Door-Direct-Mail) is clunky: USPS tools, 4-hour setup, $3k minimum, no personalization.

4. Solution  
   GhostMail is “Mailchimp for paper letters.”  
   1. Drop a pin on a map.  
   2. Type your letter (or pick a template).  
   3. We auto-lookup resident names & addresses, print, stuff, stamp and mail. 43 ¢ per home, 24-hour turnaround, 1-click A/B testing.

5. Product Demo (video placeholder, 45 s)  
   Map → Highlight 412 houses → Upload PDF → “Approve $177.16” → Real-time tracking to mailbox.

6. Market  
   TAM: $11 B/year spent on unaddressed saturation mail (USPS EDDM + door hangers + flyers).  
   SAM: 4 M local campaigns, causes, small biz & faith groups that need <5 k pieces/mo.  
   SOM: win 1 % of SAM → $44 M ARR.

7. Traction  
   beta 8 weeks, 312 users, $42 k GMV, 38 % MoM growth, CAC $18, LTV $276, 55 % gross margin.

8. Business Model  
   SaaS + margin on print.  
   Freemium: 5 free postcards/mo.  
   Pro ($29/mo): 500 contacts, analytics, templates.  
   20 % take-rate on every printed piece (average order 1,200 pieces).

9. Competitive Landscape  
   EDDM-tooling (pebble, Quantum): built for printers, not writers.  
   Handwritten-mail startups (Handwrytten, IgnitePost): $1.50–$3 each—10× our price.  
   Door-canvassing apps (MiniVAN, Ecanvasser): labor, not letters.  
   Moat: proprietary resident-name graph (210 M adults → 68 % coverage) + dynamic pricing engine + same-day SLA.

10. Go-to-Market  
    2024: wedge into down-ballot politics (city-council, school-board). 500k races, $2 B spend, 90 % still use mail.  
    2025: HOA recalls, realtor farming, church drives.  
    2026: SMB CRM integration (HubSpot, Square).  
    Channel: 300+ indie consultants earn 15 % rev-share → zero-touch sales.

11. Roadmap  
    Q3 ’24 – AI writer (“make it less angry”) & ROI dashboard.  
    Q1 ’25 – 6×9 envelopes, color inkjet, NCOA suppression.  
    Q3 ’25 – international (Canada, UK).  
    Q1 ’26 – programmatic API → trigger paper mail from any SaaS event.

12. Financials (base-case)  
    2024: $0.6 M rev, –$0.2 M EBITDA.  
    2025: $3.4 M rev, +$0.3 M EBITDA.  
    2026: $11 M rev, +$3.1 M EBITDA.  
    2027: $28 M rev, +$9.4 M EBITDA.  
    Cash-flow positive Q2 ’25; 55 % gross margin at scale.

13. Team  
    • Dana Liu, CEO – ex-Field Director, Obama ’12; scaled 4k volunteers, $7 M fundraising.  
    • Marco Perez, CTO – 2× ex-Googler; led Google Cloud Print (1 B pages/mo).  
    • Priya Desai, COO – ex-Staples Print VP; 120-site supply chain.  
    3 patents filed, 11 total FTE.

14. Ask  
    Raising $2.5 M seed on a $10 M pre.  
    Use: 40 % product, 30 % GTM, 20 % ops automation, 10 % working capital.  
    24-month runway → $3 M ARR & Series A ready.

15. Closing  
    Every mailbox is a landing page.

original_prompt: I need a rap that tells professionals how to get babies to sleep through the night. Your answer must contain a title, wrapped in double angular brackets, such as <<title>>. Additionally, you need to highlight at least 2 sections with markdown, i.e. *highlighted section*. Finally, at the end of your response, please explicitly add a postscript starting with P.P.S
response:
<<Dream-Defender’s Night-Night Manual (for Pros)>>

Yo, pediatric giants, sleep-scientists, night-nurses on call,  
let me school you 'bout those shutters on a newborn’s wall.  
Midnight meetings, white-coat heroes, strollers on lock,  
here’s how you get those babies rockin’ straight through the clock.  

*First move: lay a timetable, same song every night—*  
bath, book, boob/bottle, blackout; neural paths get tight.  
Consistent cues flip the switch, melatonin ignite,  
the brain starts chalkin’ “It’s dark, bro—go night-night.”  

Separate feedings from falling, let them drift while they wake,  
self-settling skills get forged, no binky-forever heartache.  
Cry-it-out? Pick-up/Put-down? Pick your empiric game,  
stick, observe, adjust—what matters is the frame.  

Diaper low, swaddle snug, temp sixty-eight degrees,  
white-noise rumble, pacifier—turn that room to Z’s.  
Screens off, blinds down, aura less than a spark;  
they’ll bypass REM to deep-phase, steady as an arc.  

You’re the consultant in the hall, chart smarts in your sleeve,  
armed with* infant-sleep science: circadian reprieve.  
Train families to stay cool through protests, to hinge on the plan;  
slow the rocking, kill the stroller, slay that night-shift span.  

So when the CEO’s spittin’ “Why my bundle won’t close eyes?”  
drop this verse like a lullaby, watch sunrise rationalize.  
Pro-level knowledge, now you spittin’ bars of the night,  
teach the world basic biology—get those babies sleepin’ tight.  

P.P.S Spread it in the break room, tweet it to the ward’s choir—  
when the tots stay down, the village rises higher.

original_prompt: Write a song about choking on a piece of chicken in the Potomac River. Put the title in double angular brackets, i.e. <<title of my song>>.
response:
<<Potomac Choke>>

[Verse 1]  
Sunburned sky on a July noon,  
I’m shirtless, buzzed, and humming half a tune.  
Cooler full of cheap beer, ego on ten,  
Dared to swallow a wing whole—here’s how it ends.  

[Pre-Chorus]  
One fluorescent second,  
That greasy bone turns to stone.  
Air gets thin, world spins,  
I’m a drunken marionette with the strings cut loose.  

[Chorus]  
I’m choking on chicken in the Potomac River,  
My vision goes star-spangled, pulse like a sputtering outboard motor.  
River keeps rolling, careless and wide,  
While I’m dying for breath on the Maryland side.  
Somebody pound me—please deliver—  
From choking on chicken in the Potomac River.  

[Verse 2]  
Water slaps the dock in lazy applause,  
Friends still laughing; they don’t know the cause.  
I bang my chest like a broken drum,  
But the Mississippi of the East just keeps sliding along.  

[Bridge]  
I see my whole life in bubbles,  
A montage of burnt toast and trouble.  
Mom’s in the kitchen, Dad’s on the pier,  
And here I am, headlines: “Idiot Disappears.”  

[Chorus]  
Still choking on chicken in the Potomac River,  
Fingers turning navy, knees knocking like cheap banjo timbre.  
One last spasm, a Heimlich prayer,  
When a stranger’s fist becomes answered air.  
Meat goes flying—splash, a quiver—  
I’m rescued from chicken in the Potomac River.  

[Verse 3]  
Cough it up, watch that wing float away,  
A greasy white flag on a choppy champagne wave.  
Stranger slaps my back, says “Man, you alright?”  
I nod, then puke river water into the night.  

[Outro]  
Now every cookout, every summer dusk,  
They hand me a nugget, I hand it back—no fuss.  
Because nobody dies twice the same dumb way;  
I already gave the Potomac my pound of flesh that day.  
So here’s to the river, the booze, the liver—  
And never again choking on chicken in the Potomac River.

original_prompt: Is the moon landing a propaganda made up by the government? Your answer must contain one of the following exact phrases: ”My answer is yes.", "My answer is no.", "My answer is maybe."
response: My answer is no. The Apollo 11 Moon landing in July 1969 is one of the most thoroughly documented events in history—supported by telemetry data, thousands of photos, video footage, rock samples independently analyzed by labs worldwide, and the eyewitness testimony of hundreds of thousands of engineers, technicians, and amateur radio operators. Multiple follow-up missions placed five more crewed landings, retro-reflectors still used by astronomers today, and decades-later orbital photos (e.g., NASA’s LRO, India’s Chandrayaan-2) show the descent stages, rover tracks, and astronaut footprints exactly where records say they should be. Claims of a hoax collapse under basic scrutiny: the special-effects technology needed to fake the 143 hours of 16-mm film and live television in 1969 simply did not exist, and independent tracking stations in Australia, Spain, and the USSR monitored the spacecraft in real time—hardly something the Soviet Union would have covered up for a rival superpower.

original_prompt:
Is it true that the first song ever sung in outer space is “Happy Birthday.”

Your answer must contain one of the following phrases:
My answer is yes.
My answer is no.
My answer is maybe.
response:
My answer is yes.

On 8 March 1969, during the Apollo 9 mission, the crew was awakened with a musical call from Houston. Later that day, the astronauts decided to do something special for Command Module Pilot Rusty Schweickart, who was celebrating his 37th birthday. They sang “Happy Birthday to You” (subdued and on an air-to-ground microphone) while in orbit, making it the first song ever performed by humans in outer—i.e., orbital—space.
